column1: C01*D001423*Bacterial Infections and Mycoses*Infections caused by bacteria and fungi
column2: general

column1: C01.252*D001424*Bacterial Infections*Infections by bacteria
column2: general or unspecified.

column1: C01.252.100*D016470*Bacteremia*The presence of viable bacteria circulating in the blood. Fever
column2: chills
column4: and tachypnea are common acute manifestations of bacteremia. The majority of cases are seen in already hospitalized patients
column5: most of whom have underlying diseases or procedures which render their bloodstreams susceptible to invasion.

column1: C01.252.100.375*D006483*Hemorrhagic Septicemia*Any of several bacterial diseases
column2: usually caused by PASTEURELLA MULTOCIDA
column3: marked by the presence of hemorrhagic areas in the subcutaneous tissues
column7: and throughout the internal organs. The diseases primarily affect animals and rarely humans.

column1: C01.252.200*D020806*Central Nervous System Bacterial Infections*Bacterial infections of the brain
column2: spinal cord
column4: including infections involving the perimeningeal spaces.

column1: C01.252.200.450*D020852*Lyme Neuroborreliosis*Nervous system infections caused by tick-borne spirochetes of the BORRELIA BURGDORFERI GROUP. The disease may affect elements of the central or peripheral nervous system in isolation or in combination. Common clinical manifestations include a lymphocytic meningitis
column2: cranial neuropathy (most often a facial neuropathy)
column4: and a mild loss of memory and other cognitive functions. Less often more extensive inflammation involving the central nervous system (encephalomyelitis) may occur. In the peripheral nervous system
column5: B. burgdorferi infection is associated with mononeuritis multiplex and polyradiculoneuritis. (From J Neurol Sci 1998 Jan 8;153(2):182-91)

column2: Bacterial*Bacterial infections of the leptomeninges and subarachnoid space
Escherichia coli*A form of gram-negative meningitis that tends to occur in neonates
column3: in association with anatomical abnormalities (which feature communication between the meninges and cutaneous structures) or as OPPORTUNISTIC INFECTIONS in association with IMMUNOLOGIC DEFICIENCY SYNDROMES. In premature neonates the clinical presentation may be limited to ANOREXIA; VOMITING; lethargy; or respiratory distress. Full-term infants may have as additional features FEVER; SEIZURES; and bulging of the anterior fontanelle. (From Menkes

column2: Haemophilus*Infections of the nervous system caused by bacteria of the genus HAEMOPHILUS
column3: and marked by prominent inflammation of the MENINGES. HAEMOPHILUS INFLUENZAE TYPE B is the most common causative organism. The condition primarily affects children under 6 years of age but may occur in adults.

column2: Listeria*Inflammation of the meninges caused by LISTERIA MONOCYTOGENES infection
column3: usually occurring in individuals under the age of 3 years or over the age of 50 years. It may occur at any age in individuals with IMMUNOLOGIC DEFICIENCY SYNDROMES. Clinical manifestations include FEVER

column2: Meningococcal*A fulminant infection of the meninges and subarachnoid fluid by the bacterium NEISSERIA MENINGITIDIS
column3: producing diffuse inflammation and peri-meningeal venous thromboses. Clinical manifestations include FEVER
column11: and COMA. The organism is usually transmitted via nasopharyngeal secretions and is a leading cause of meningitis in children and young adults. Organisms from Neisseria meningitidis serogroups A
column15: and W-135 have been reported to cause meningitis. (From Adams et al.

column1: C01.252.200.500.550.800*D014884*Waterhouse-Friderichsen Syndrome*A condition of HEMORRHAGE and NECROSIS of the ADRENAL GLAND. It is characterized by rapidly developing ADRENAL INSUFFICIENCY; HYPOTENSION; and widespread cutaneous PURPURA.

column2: Pneumococcal*An acute purulent infection of the meninges and subarachnoid space caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae
column3: most prevalent in children and adults over the age of 60. This illness may be associated with OTITIS MEDIA; MASTOIDITIS; SINUSITIS; RESPIRATORY TRACT INFECTIONS; sickle cell disease (ANEMIA
column4: SICKLE CELL); skull fractures; and other disorders. Clinical manifestations include FEVER; HEADACHE; neck stiffness; and somnolence followed by SEIZURES; focal neurologic deficits (notably DEAFNESS); and COMA. (From Miller et al.

column2: Meningeal*A form of bacterial meningitis caused by MYCOBACTERIUM TUBERCULOSIS or rarely MYCOBACTERIUM BOVIS. The organism seeds the meninges and forms microtuberculomas which subsequently rupture. The clinical course tends to be subacute
column3: with progressions occurring over a period of several days or longer. Headache and meningeal irritation may be followed by SEIZURES
column7: and eventually COMA. The illness may occur in immunocompetent individuals or as an OPPORTUNISTIC INFECTION in the ACQUIRED IMMUNODEFICIENCY SYNDROME and other immunodeficiency syndromes. (From Adams et al.

column1: C01.252.200.750*D009494*Neurosyphilis*Infections of the central nervous system caused by TREPONEMA PALLIDUM which present with a variety of clinical syndromes. The initial phase of infection usually causes a mild or asymptomatic meningeal reaction. The meningovascular form may present acutely as BRAIN INFARCTION. The infection may also remain subclinical for several years. Late syndromes include general paresis; TABES DORSALIS; meningeal syphilis; syphilitic OPTIC ATROPHY; and spinal syphilis. General paresis is characterized by progressive DEMENTIA; DYSARTHRIA; TREMOR; MYOCLONUS; SEIZURES; and Argyll-Robertson pupils. (Adams et al.
column2: Principles of Neurology

column1: C01.252.300*D004697*Endocarditis
column2: Bacterial*Inflammation of the ENDOCARDIUM caused by BACTERIA that entered the bloodstream. The strains of bacteria vary with predisposing factors
column3: such as CONGENITAL HEART DEFECTS; HEART VALVE DISEASES; HEART VALVE PROSTHESIS IMPLANTATION; or intravenous drug use.

column2: Subacute Bacterial*ENDOCARDIUM infection that is usually caused by STREPTOCOCCUS. Subacute infective endocarditis evolves over weeks and months with modest toxicity and rare metastatic infection.

column1: C01.252.354*D015818*Eye Infections
column2: Bacterial*Infections in the inner or external eye caused by microorganisms belonging to several families of bacteria. Some of the more common genera found are Haemophilus

column1: C01.252.354.225*D003234*Conjunctivitis
column2: Bacterial*Purulent infections of the conjunctiva by several species of gram-negative
column4: or acid-fast organisms. Some of the more commonly found genera causing conjunctival infections are Haemophilus

column2: Inclusion*An infection of the eyes characterized by the presence in conjunctival epithelial cells of inclusion bodies indistinguishable from those of trachoma. It is acquired by infants during birth and by adults from swimming pools. The etiological agent is CHLAMYDIA TRACHOMATIS whose natural habitat appears to be the genito-urinary tract. Inclusion conjunctivitis is a less severe disease than trachoma and usually clears up spontaneously.

column1: C01.252.354.225.625*D009878*Ophthalmia Neonatorum*Acute conjunctival inflammation in the newborn
column2: usually caused by maternal gonococcal infection. The causative agent is NEISSERIA GONORRHOEAE. The baby's eyes are contaminated during passage through the birth canal.

column1: C01.252.354.225.800*D014141*Trachoma*A chronic infection of the CONJUNCTIVA and CORNEA caused by CHLAMYDIA TRACHOMATIS.

C01.252.354.400*D006726*Hordeolum*Purulent infection of one of the sebaceous glands of Zeis along the eyelid margin (external) or of the meibomian gland on the conjunctival side of the eyelid (internal).
C01.252.354.450*D007639*Keratoconjunctivitis
column2: Infectious*Infectious diseases of cattle
column8: and varying degrees of corneal opacity and ulceration. In cattle the causative agent is MORAXELLA (MORAXELLA) BOVIS; in sheep
column9: MYCOPLASMA; RICKETTSIA; CHLAMYDIA; or ACHOLEPLASMA; in goats

column2: Ocular*Tuberculous infection of the eye

Suppurative*Intraocular infection caused mainly by pus-producing bacteria and rarely by fungi. The infection may be caused by an injury or surgical wound (exogenous) or by endogenous septic emboli in such diseases as bacterial endocarditis or meningococcemia.

column1: C01.252.354.900.675*D010202*Panophthalmitis*Acute suppurative inflammation of the inner eye with necrosis of the sclera (and sometimes the cornea) and extension of the inflammation into the orbit. Pain may be severe and the globe may rupture. In endophthalmitis the globe does not rupture.

C01.252.377*D018934*Fournier Gangrene*An acute necrotic infection of the SCROTUM; PENIS; or PERINEUM. It is characterized by scrotum pain and redness with rapid progression to gangrene and sloughing of tissue. Fournier gangrene is usually secondary to perirectal or periurethral infections associated with local trauma
column2: operative procedures

column1: C01.252.400*D016905*Gram-Negative Bacterial Infections*Infections caused by bacteria that show up as pink (negative) when treated by the gram-staining method.
C01.252.400.050*D059707*Aliivibrio Infections*Infections with bacteria of the genus ALIIVIBRIO.
C01.252.400.054*D000711*Anaplasmataceae Infections*Infections with bacteria of the family ANAPLASMATACEAE.
C01.252.400.054.050*D000712*Anaplasmosis*A disease of cattle caused by parasitization of the red blood cells by bacteria of the genus ANAPLASMA.

C01.252.400.054.160*D016873*Ehrlichiosis*A tick-borne disease characterized by FEVER; HEADACHE; myalgias; ANOREXIA; and occasionally RASH. It is caused by several bacterial species and can produce disease in DOGS; CATTLE; SHEEP; GOATS; HORSES; and humans. The primary species causing human disease are EHRLICHIA CHAFFEENSIS; ANAPLASMA PHAGOCYTOPHILUM; and Ehrlichia ewingii.
C01.252.400.054.160.400*D006357*Heartwater Disease*A tick-borne septicemic disease of domestic and wild ruminants caused by EHRLICHIA RUMINANTIUM.
C01.252.400.110*D016866*Bacteroidaceae Infections*Infections with bacteria of the family BACTEROIDACEAE.
C01.252.400.110.109*D001442*Bacteroides Infections*Infections with bacteria of the genus BACTEROIDES.
C01.252.400.126*D001476*Bartonellaceae Infections*Infections with bacteria of the family BARTONELLACEAE.
C01.252.400.126.100*D001474*Bartonella Infections*Infections by the genus BARTONELLA. Bartonella bacilliformis can cause acute febrile anemia
column2: designated Oroya fever
column4: called verruga peruana. BARTONELLA QUINTANA causes TRENCH FEVER
column5: while BARTONELLA HENSELAE is the etiologic agent of bacillary angiomatosis (ANGIOMATOSIS
column6: BACILLARY) and is also one of the causes of CAT-SCRATCH DISEASE in immunocompetent patients.

column2: Bacillary*A reactive vascular proliferation that is characterized by the multiple tumor-like lesions in skin
column5: and other organs. Bacillary angiomatosis is caused by infection with gram-negative Bartonella bacilli (such as BARTONELLA HENSELAE)
column6: and is often seen in AIDS patients and other IMMUNOCOMPROMISED HOSTS.

column1: C01.252.400.126.100.150*D002372*Cat-Scratch Disease*A self-limiting bacterial infection of the regional lymph nodes caused by AFIPIA felis
column2: a gram-negative bacterium recently identified by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and by BARTONELLA HENSELAE. It usually arises one or more weeks following a feline scratch
column3: with raised inflammatory nodules at the site of the scratch being the primary symptom.

column1: C01.252.400.126.100.800*D014205*Trench Fever*An intermittent fever characterized by intervals of chills
column2: fever
column3: and splenomegaly each of which may last as long as 40 hours. It is caused by BARTONELLA QUINTANA and transmitted by the human louse.

column1: C01.252.400.143*D001885*Bordetella Infections*Infections with bacteria of the genus BORDETELLA.
C01.252.400.143.740*D014917*Whooping Cough*A respiratory infection caused by BORDETELLA PERTUSSIS and characterized by paroxysmal coughing ending in a prolonged crowing intake of breath.
C01.252.400.155*D001899*Borrelia Infections*Infections with bacteria of the genus BORRELIA.

column2: BORRELIA BURGDORFERI
column3: which is transmitted chiefly by Ixodes dammini (see IXODES) and pacificus ticks in the United States and Ixodes ricinis (see IXODES) in Europe. It is a disease with early and late cutaneous manifestations plus involvement of the nervous system
column6: and joints in variable combinations. The disease was formerly known as Lyme arthritis and first discovered at Old Lyme

column1: C01.252.400.155.569.200*D015787*Erythema Chronicum Migrans*A deep type of gyrate erythema that follows a bite by an ixodid tick; it is a stage-1 manifestation of LYME DISEASE. The site of the bite is characterized by a red papule that expands peripherally as a nonscaling
column2: palpable band that clears centrally. This condition is often associated with systemic symptoms such as chills

column1: C01.252.400.155.569.600*D020852*Lyme Neuroborreliosis*Nervous system infections caused by tick-borne spirochetes of the BORRELIA BURGDORFERI GROUP. The disease may affect elements of the central or peripheral nervous system in isolation or in combination. Common clinical manifestations include a lymphocytic meningitis
column2: cranial neuropathy (most often a facial neuropathy)
column4: and a mild loss of memory and other cognitive functions. Less often more extensive inflammation involving the central nervous system (encephalomyelitis) may occur. In the peripheral nervous system
column5: B. burgdorferi infection is associated with mononeuritis multiplex and polyradiculoneuritis. (From J Neurol Sci 1998 Jan 8;153(2):182-91)

column1: C01.252.400.155.644*D012061*Relapsing Fever*An acute infection characterized by recurrent episodes of PYREXIA alternating with asymptomatic intervals of apparent recovery. This condition is caused by SPIROCHETES of the genus BORRELIA. It is transmitted by the BITES of either the body louse (PEDICULUS humanus corporis)
column2: for which humans are the reservoir
column3: or by soft ticks of the genus ORNITHODOROS
column4: for which rodents and other animals are the principal reservoirs.

column1: C01.252.400.167*D002006*Brucellosis*Infection caused by bacteria of the genus BRUCELLA mainly involving the MONONUCLEAR PHAGOCYTE SYSTEM. This condition is characterized by fever
column2: weakness
Bovine*A disease of cattle caused by bacteria of the genus BRUCELLA leading to abortion in late pregnancy. BRUCELLA ABORTUS is the primary infective agent.

column1: C01.252.400.170*D019121*Burkholderia Infections*Infections with bacteria of the genus BURKHOLDERIA.

C01.252.400.170.400*D005896*Glanders*A contagious disease of horses that can be transmitted to humans. It is caused by BURKHOLDERIA MALLEI and characterized by ulceration of the respiratory mucosa and an eruption of nodules on the skin.

C01.252.400.170.531*D008554*Melioidosis*A disease of humans and animals that resembles GLANDERS. It is caused by BURKHOLDERIA PSEUDOMALLEI and may range from a dormant infection to a condition that causes multiple abscesses
column2: pneumonia

column1: C01.252.400.825.480.400*D015787*Erythema Chronicum Migrans*A deep type of gyrate erythema that follows a bite by an ixodid tick; it is a stage-1 manifestation of LYME DISEASE. The site of the bite is characterized by a red papule that expands peripherally as a nonscaling

column1: C01.252.400.825.480.700*D020852*Lyme Neuroborreliosis*Nervous system infections caused by tick-borne spirochetes of the BORRELIA BURGDORFERI GROUP. column5: B. burgdorferi infection is associated with mononeuritis multiplex and polyradiculoneuritis. (From J Neurol Sci 1998 Jan 8;153(2):182-91)

An aggressive variant in young children is endemic in some areas of Africa. A third form occurs in about 0.04% of kidney transplant patients. There is also a high incidence in AIDS patients. column1: C02.290.310.950*D014901*West Nile Fever*A mosquito-borne viral illness caused by the WEST NILE VIRUS

column1: C02.290.325*D020803*Encephalitis

column8: and periventricular necrosis. Manifestations of varicella encephalitis usually occur 5-7 days after onset of HERPES ZOSTER and include HEADACHE; VOMITING; lethargy; focal neurologic deficits; FEVER; and COMA. (From Joynt

column3: WESTERN EQUINE) may be transferred to humans via the bite of mosquitoes (CULEX tarsalis and others). Clinical manifestations include headache and influenza-like symptoms followed by alterations in mentation
column5: and COMA. DEATH occurs in a minority of cases. Survivors may recover fully or be left with residual neurologic dysfunction

column2: spinal cord
column3: or perimeningeal structures with the larval forms of the genus TAENIA (primarily T. solium in humans). Lesions formed by the organism are referred to as cysticerci. The infection may be subacute or chronic
column4: and the severity of symptoms depends on the severity of the host immune response and the location and number of lesions. SEIZURES represent the most common clinical manifestation although focal neurologic deficits may occur. (From Joynt

column1: C03.105.250.600*D020818*Neuroschistosomiasis*SCHISTOSOMIASIS of the brain

S. mansoni and S. haematobium nervous system infections are associated with acute transverse myelitis involving the lower portions of the spinal cord. (From Joynt

column1: C03.105.300*D020808*Central Nervous System Protozoal Infections*Infections of the brain

column2: Cerebral*A condition characterized by somnolence or coma in the presence of an acute infection with PLASMODIUM FALCIPARUM (and rarely other Plasmodium species). Pathologic features include cerebral capillaries filled with parasitized erythrocytes and multiple small foci of cortical and subcortical necrosis. (From Adams et al.

column1: C03.105.300.800*D016781*Toxoplasmosis

The infection may involve the brain diffusely or form discrete abscesses. Clinical manifestations include SEIZURES

column1: C03.202*D060085*Coinfection*Simultaneous infection of a host organism by two or more pathogens. In virology

column1: C03.300*D015822*Eye Infections
column2: Parasitic*Mild to severe infections of the eye and its adjacent structures (adnexa) by adult or larval protozoan or metazoan parasites.

column1: C03.300.125*D015823*Acanthamoeba Keratitis*Infection of the cornea by an ameboid protozoan which may cause corneal ulceration leading to blindness.
C03.300.562*D015827*Onchocerciasis
column2: Ocular*Filarial infection of the eyes transmitted from person to person by bites of Onchocerca volvulus-infected black flies. The microfilariae of Onchocerca are thus deposited beneath the skin. They migrate through various tissues including the eye. Those persons infected have impaired vision and up to 20% are blind. The incidence of eye lesions has been reported to be as high as 30% in Central America and parts of Africa.

column1: C03.300.781*D014126*Toxoplasmosis
column2: Ocular*Infection caused by the protozoan parasite TOXOPLASMA in which there is extensive connective tissue proliferation
column3: the retina surrounding the lesions remains normal
column4: and the ocular media remain clear. Chorioretinitis may be associated with all forms of toxoplasmosis
column5: but is usually a late sequel of congenital toxoplasmosis. The severe ocular lesions in infants may lead to blindness.

column1: C03.335*D006373*Helminthiasis*Infestation with parasitic worms of the helminth class.
C03.335.190*D002590*Cestode Infections*Infections with true tapeworms of the helminth subclass CESTODA.
C03.335.190.304*D004169*Diphyllobothriasis*Infection with tapeworms of the genus Diphyllobothrium.
C03.335.190.304.780*D013031*Sparganosis*Infection of animals
column2: including fish and man
column3: with a developmental stage of Diphyllobothrium. This stage has recently been referred to as a plerocercoid but the name sparganum has persisted. Therefore
column4: infection of fish or other animals with the plerocercoid larvae is sparganosis. Fish-eating mammals

column1: C03.335.190.396*D004443*Echinococcosis*An infection caused by the infestation of the larval form of tapeworms of the genus Echinococcus. The liver
column2: lungs
column3: and kidney are the most common areas of infestation.

column2: Hepatic*Liver disease caused by infections with parasitic tapeworms of the genus ECHINOCOCCUS
column3: such as Echinococcus granulosus or Echinococcus multilocularis. Ingested Echinococcus ova burrow into the intestinal mucosa. The larval migration to the liver via the PORTAL VEIN leads to watery vesicles (HYDATID CYST).

column2: Pulmonary*Helminth infection of the lung caused by Echinococcus granulosus or Echinococcus multilocularis.

column1: C03.335.190.519*D006925*Hymenolepiasis*Infection with tapeworms of the genus Hymenolepis.
C03.335.190.628*D008989*Monieziasis*Infection of ruminants with tapeworms of the genus Moniezia.
C03.335.190.902*D013622*Taeniasis*Infection with tapeworms of the genus Taenia.
C03.335.190.902.185*D003551*Cysticercosis*Infection with CYSTICERCUS
column2: the larval form of the various tapeworms of the genus Taenia (usually T. solium in man). In humans they penetrate the intestinal wall and invade subcutaneous tissue
column9: and peritoneum. Brain involvement results in NEUROCYSTICERCOSIS.

column1: C03.335.190.902.185.550*D020019*Neurocysticercosis*Infection of the brain
column2: spinal cord
column3: or perimeningeal structures with the larval forms of the genus TAENIA (primarily T. solium in humans). Lesions formed by the organism are referred to as cysticerci. The infection may be subacute or chronic
column4: and the severity of symptoms depends on the severity of the host immune response and the location and number of lesions. SEIZURES represent the most common clinical manifestation although focal neurologic deficits may occur. (From Joynt

column1: C03.335.349*D006374*Helminthiasis
column2: Animal*Infestation of animals with parasitic worms of the helminth class. The infestation may be experimental or veterinary.

column1: C03.335.349.315*D004022*Dictyocaulus Infections*Infection with nematodes of the genus DICTYOCAULUS. In deer
column2: cattle
column4: and horses the bronchi are the site of infestation.

column1: C03.335.349.320*D004184*Dirofilariasis*Infection with nematodes of the genus DIROFILARIA
column2: usually in animals

column1: C03.335.349.444*D005213*Fascioloidiasis*Infection of cattle and other herbivores with the giant liver fluke Fascioloides magna. It is characterized by extensive destruction of the liver parenchyma.
C03.335.349.656*D008989*Monieziasis*Infection of ruminants with tapeworms of the genus Moniezia.
C03.335.349.820*D012719*Setariasis*Infection with nematodes of the genus Setaria. This condition is usually seen in cattle and equines and is of little pathogenic significance
column2: although migration of the worm to the eye may lead to blindness.

column1: C03.335.349.840*D013319*Strongyle Infections
column2: Equine*Infection of horses with parasitic nematodes of the superfamily STRONGYLOIDEA. Characteristics include the development of hemorrhagic nodules on the abdominal peritoneum.

column1: C03.335.349.868*D014120*Toxocariasis*Infection by round worms of the genus TOXOCARA
column2: usually found in wild and domesticated cats and dogs and foxes
column4: which may produce visceral and ocular larva migrans in man.

column1: C03.335.508*D009349*Nematode Infections*Infections by nematodes
column2: general or unspecified.

column1: C03.335.508.100*D017188*Adenophorea Infections*Infections with nematodes of the subclass ADENOPHOREA.
C03.335.508.100.275*D017189*Enoplida Infections*Infections with nematodes of the order ENOPLIDA.

C03.335.508.100.275.882*D014235*Trichinellosis*An infection with TRICHINELLA. It is caused by eating raw or undercooked meat that is infected with larvae of nematode worms TRICHINELLA genus. All members of the TRICHINELLA genus can infect human in addition to TRICHINELLA SPIRALIS
column2: the traditional etiological agent. It is distributed throughout much of the world and is re-emerging in some parts as a public health hazard and a food safety problem.

column1: C03.335.508.100.275.895*D014257*Trichuriasis*Infection with nematodes of the genus TRICHURIS
column2: formerly called Trichocephalus.

column1: C03.335.508.523*D007815*Larva Migrans*Infections caused by nematode larvae which never develop into the adult stage and migrate through various body tissues. They commonly infect the skin
column2: eyes
column3: and viscera in man. Ancylostoma brasiliensis causes cutaneous larva migrans. Toxocara causes visceral larva migrans.

column2: Visceral*A condition produced in man by the prolonged migration of animal nematode larvae in extraintestinal tissues other than skin; characterized by persistent hypereosinophilia
column5: commonly caused by Toxocara canis and Toxocara cati.

column1: C03.335.508.700*D017190*Secernentea Infections*Infections with nematodes of the subclass SECERNENTEA.
C03.335.508.700.100*D017191*Ascaridida Infections*Infections with nematodes of the order ASCARIDIDA.

C03.335.508.700.100.060*D017129*Anisakiasis*Infection with roundworms of the genus ANISAKIS. Human infection results from the consumption of fish harboring roundworm larvae. The worms may cause acute NAUSEA; VOMITING; or penetrate into the wall of the DIGESTIVE TRACT where they give rise to EOSINOPHILIC GRANULOMA in the STOMACH; INTESTINES; or the OMENTUM.

C03.335.508.700.100.070*D001196*Ascariasis*Infection by nematodes of the genus ASCARIS. Ingestion of infective eggs causes diarrhea and pneumonitis. Its distribution is more prevalent in areas of poor sanitation and where human feces are used for fertilizer.
C03.335.508.700.100.080*D001198*Ascaridiasis*Infection with nematodes of the genus ASCARIDIA. This condition usually occurs in fowl
column2: often manifesting diarrhea.

column1: C03.335.508.700.100.850*D017227*Toxascariasis*Infections with nematodes of the genus TOXASCARIS.
C03.335.508.700.100.868*D014120*Toxocariasis*Infection by round worms of the genus TOXOCARA
column2: usually found in wild and domesticated cats and dogs and foxes
column4: which may produce visceral and ocular larva migrans in man.

column2: Visceral*A condition produced in man by the prolonged migration of animal nematode larvae in extraintestinal tissues other than skin; characterized by persistent hypereosinophilia
column5: commonly caused by Toxocara canis and Toxocara cati.

column1: C03.335.508.700.550*D017194*Oxyurida Infections*Infections with nematodes of the order OXYURIDA.
C03.335.508.700.550.550*D010123*Oxyuriasis*Infection with nematodes of the superfamily OXYUROIDEA.
C03.335.508.700.550.550.375*D017229*Enterobiasis*Infection with nematodes of the genus ENTEROBIUS; E. vermicularis
column2: the pinworm of man
column3: causes a crawling sensation and pruritus. This condition results in scratching the area

column1: C03.335.508.700.700*D017196*Rhabditida Infections*Infections with nematodes of the order RHABDITIDA.

C03.335.508.700.700.799*D013322*Strongyloidiasis*Infection with nematodes of the genus STRONGYLOIDES. The presence of larvae may produce pneumonitis and the presence of adult worms in the intestine could lead to moderate to severe diarrhea.
C03.335.508.700.750*D017205*Spirurida Infections*Infections with nematodes of the order SPIRURIDA.
C03.335.508.700.750.299*D004320*Dracunculiasis*Infection with nematodes of the genus Dracunculus. One or more worms may be seen at a time
column2: with the legs and feet being the most commonly infected areas. Symptoms include pruritus

column1: C03.335.508.700.750.361*D005368*Filariasis*Infections with nematodes of the superfamily FILARIOIDEA. The presence of living worms in the body is mainly asymptomatic but the death of adult worms leads to granulomatous inflammation and permanent fibrosis. Organisms of the genus Elaeophora infect wild elk and domestic sheep causing ischemic necrosis of the brain
column2: blindness

column1: C03.335.508.700.750.361.137*D063485*Acanthocheilonemiasis*A tropical infectious disease found mainly in Africa that is caused by the filarial parasite ACANTHOCHEILONEMA. Symptoms include skin rashes
column2: abdominal
column8: and elevated levels of white blood cells. The parasite is transmitted through the bite of small flies.

column1: C03.335.508.700.750.361.275*D004154*Dipetalonema Infections*Infections with nematodes of the genus DIPETALONEMA.
C03.335.508.700.750.361.290*D004184*Dirofilariasis*Infection with nematodes of the genus DIROFILARIA
column2: usually in animals
Filarial*Parasitic infestation of the human lymphatic system by WUCHERERIA BANCROFTI or BRUGIA MALAYI. It is also called lymphatic filariasis.

column1: C03.335.508.700.750.361.518*D008118*Loiasis*A parasitic infection caused by the nematode Loa loa. The vector in the transmission of this infection is the horsefly (Tabanus) or the deerfly or mango fly (Chrysops). The larvae may be seen just beneath the skin or passing through the conjunctiva. Eye lesions are not uncommon. The disease is generally mild and painless.
C03.335.508.700.750.361.588*D008368*Mansonelliasis*Infection with nematodes of the genus MANSONELLA. Symptoms include pruritus
column2: headache

column1: C03.335.508.700.750.361.699*D009855*Onchocerciasis*Infection with nematodes of the genus ONCHOCERCA. Characteristics include the presence of firm subcutaneous nodules filled with adult worms
column2: PRURITUS

Ocular*Filarial infection of the eyes transmitted from person to person by bites of Onchocerca volvulus-infected black flies. The microfilariae of Onchocerca are thus deposited beneath the skin. They migrate through various tissues including the eye. Those persons infected have impaired vision and up to 20% are blind. The incidence of eye lesions has been reported to be as high as 30% in Central America and parts of Africa.

column1: C03.335.508.700.750.361.852*D012719*Setariasis*Infection with nematodes of the genus Setaria. This condition is usually seen in cattle and equines and is of little pathogenic significance
column2: although migration of the worm to the eye may lead to blindness.

column1: C03.335.508.700.750.380*D058429*Gnathostomiasis*Infections with nematodes of the genus GNATHOSTOMA
column2: superfamily THELAZIOIDEA. Gnathostomiasis is a food-borne zoonosis caused by eating undercooked or raw fish or meat.

column1: C03.335.508.700.775*D017206*Strongylida Infections*Infections with nematodes of the order STRONGYLIDA.
C03.335.508.700.775.455*D006725*Hookworm Infections*Infection of humans or animals with hookworms other than those caused by the genus Ancylostoma or Necator
column2: for which the specific terms ANCYLOSTOMIASIS and NECATORIASIS are available.

column1: C03.335.508.700.775.455.154*D000724*Ancylostomiasis*Infection of humans or animals with hookworms of the genus ANCYLOSTOMA. Characteristics include anemia
column2: dyspepsia

column1: C03.335.508.700.775.455.683*D009332*Necatoriasis*Infection of humans or animals with hookworms of the genus NECATOR. The resulting anemia from this condition is less severe than that from ANCYLOSTOMIASIS.
C03.335.508.700.775.583*D009814*Oesophagostomiasis*Infection of the intestinal tract with worms of the genus OESOPHAGOSTOMUM. This condition occurs mainly in animals other than man.
C03.335.508.700.775.773*D013319*Strongyle Infections
column2: Equine*Infection of horses with parasitic nematodes of the superfamily STRONGYLOIDEA. Characteristics include the development of hemorrhagic nodules on the abdominal peritoneum.

column1: C03.335.508.700.775.825*D014252*Trichostrongyloidiasis*Infection by roundworms of the superfamily TRICHOSTRONGYLOIDEA
column2: including the genera TRICHOSTRONGYLUS; OSTERTAGIA; Cooperia

column1: C03.335.508.700.775.825.315*D004022*Dictyocaulus Infections*Infection with nematodes of the genus DICTYOCAULUS. In deer
column2: cattle
column4: and horses the bronchi are the site of infestation.

column1: C03.335.508.700.775.825.400*D006188*Haemonchiasis*Infection with nematodes of the genus HAEMONCHUS
column2: characterized by digestive abnormalities and anemia similar to that from hookworm infestation.

column1: C03.335.508.700.775.825.580*D010029*Ostertagiasis*A disease of herbivorous mammals
column2: particularly cattle and sheep
column3: caused by stomach worms of the genus OSTERTAGIA.

column1: C03.335.508.700.775.825.842*D014253*Trichostrongylosis*Infestation with nematode worms of the genus TRICHOSTRONGYLUS. Man and animals become infected by swallowing larvae
column2: usually with contaminated food or drink
column3: although the larvae may penetrate human skin.

column1: C03.335.865*D014201*Trematode Infections*Infections caused by infestation with worms of the class Trematoda.
C03.335.865.148*D003003*Clonorchiasis*Infection of the biliary passages with CLONORCHIS SINENSIS
column2: also called Opisthorchis sinensis. It may lead to inflammation of the biliary tract
column5: and sometimes bile duct carcinoma. Extension to the liver may lead to fatty changes and cirrhosis. (From Dorland

column1: C03.335.865.224*D004011*Dicrocoeliasis*Infection with flukes of the genus Dicrocoelium.
C03.335.865.282*D004451*Echinostomiasis*Infection by flukes of the genus Echinostoma.
C03.335.865.354*D005211*Fascioliasis*Liver disease caused by infections with parasitic flukes of the genus FASCIOLA
column2: such as FASCIOLA HEPATICA.

column1: C03.335.865.399*D005213*Fascioloidiasis*Infection of cattle and other herbivores with the giant liver fluke Fascioloides magna. It is characterized by extensive destruction of the liver parenchyma.
C03.335.865.685*D009889*Opisthorchiasis*Infection with flukes of the genus Opisthorchis.
C03.335.865.741*D010237*Paragonimiasis*Infection with TREMATODA of the genus PARAGONIMUS.

C03.335.865.859*D012552*Schistosomiasis*Infection with flukes (trematodes) of the genus SCHISTOSOMA. Three species produce the most frequent clinical diseases: SCHISTOSOMA HAEMATOBIUM (endemic in Africa and the Middle East)
column2: SCHISTOSOMA MANSONI (in Egypt
column11: Laos). S. mansoni is often seen in Puerto Ricans living in the United States.

column1: C03.335.865.859.213*D020818*Neuroschistosomiasis*SCHISTOSOMIASIS of the brain
column2: spinal cord
column3: or meninges caused by infections with trematodes of the genus SCHISTOSOMA (primarily SCHISTOSOMA JAPONICUM; SCHISTOSOMA MANSONI; and SCHISTOSOMA HAEMATOBIUM in humans). S. japonicum infections of the nervous system may cause an acute meningoencephalitis or a chronic encephalopathy. S. mansoni and S. haematobium nervous system infections are associated with acute transverse myelitis involving the lower portions of the spinal cord. (From Joynt

column1: C03.335.865.859.427*D012553*Schistosomiasis haematobia*A human disease caused by the infection of parasitic worms SCHISTOSOMA HAEMATOBIUM. It is endemic in AFRICA and parts of the MIDDLE EAST. Tissue damages most often occur in the URINARY TRACT
column2: specifically the URINARY BLADDER.

column1: C03.335.865.859.521*D012554*Schistosomiasis japonica*Schistosomiasis caused by Schistosoma japonicum. It is endemic in the Far East and affects the bowel
column2: liver

column1: C03.335.865.859.576*D012555*Schistosomiasis mansoni*Schistosomiasis caused by Schistosoma mansoni. It is endemic in Africa
column2: the Middle East
column4: and the Caribbean and affects mainly the bowel

column1: C03.432*D007411*Intestinal Diseases
column2: Parasitic*Infections of the INTESTINES with PARASITES
column3: commonly involving PARASITIC WORMS. Infections with roundworms (NEMATODE INFECTIONS) and tapeworms (CESTODE INFECTIONS) are also known as HELMINTHIASIS.

column1: C03.432.060*D017129*Anisakiasis*Infection with roundworms of the genus ANISAKIS. Human infection results from the consumption of fish harboring roundworm larvae. The worms may cause acute NAUSEA; VOMITING; or penetrate into the wall of the DIGESTIVE TRACT where they give rise to EOSINOPHILIC GRANULOMA in the STOMACH; INTESTINES; or the OMENTUM.
C03.432.146*D001447*Balantidiasis*Infection by parasites of the genus BALANTIDIUM. The presence of Balantidium in the LARGE INTESTINE leads to DIARRHEA; DYSENTERY; and occasionally ULCER.

C03.432.250*D016776*Blastocystis Infections*Infections with organisms of the genus BLASTOCYSTIS. The species B. hominis is responsible for most infections. Parasitologic surveys have generally found small numbers of this species in human stools
column2: but higher positivity rates and organism numbers in AIDS patients and other immunosuppressed patients (IMMUNOCOMPROMISED HOST). Symptoms include ABDOMINAL PAIN; DIARRHEA; CONSTIPATION; VOMITING; and FATIGUE.

column1: C03.432.269*D003457*Cryptosporidiosis*Intestinal infection with organisms of the genus CRYPTOSPORIDIUM. It occurs in both animals and humans. Symptoms include severe DIARRHEA.
C03.432.275*D004030*Dientamoebiasis*Gastrointestinal infection with organisms of the genus DIENTAMOEBA.

column2: Amebic*DYSENTERY caused by intestinal amebic infection
column3: chiefly with ENTAMOEBA HISTOLYTICA. This condition may be associated with amebic infection of the LIVER and other distant sites.

column1: C03.432.481*D005873*Giardiasis*An infection of the SMALL INTESTINE caused by the flagellated protozoan GIARDIA LAMBLIA. It is spread via contaminated food and water and by direct person-to-person contact.
C03.518*D008109*Liver Diseases
column2: Parasitic*Liver diseases caused by infections with PARASITES

column1: C03.518.424*D005211*Fascioliasis*Liver disease caused by infections with parasitic flukes of the genus FASCIOLA
column2: such as FASCIOLA HEPATICA.

column1: C03.518.600*D008101*Liver Abscess
column2: Amebic*Single or multiple areas of PUS due to infection by any ameboid protozoa (AMEBIASIS). A common form is caused by the ingestion of ENTAMOEBA HISTOLYTICA.

column1: C03.582*D008174*Lung Diseases
column2: Parasitic*Infections of the lungs with parasites

column1: C03.582.314*D004445*Echinococcosis
column2: Pulmonary*Helminth infection of the lung caused by Echinococcus granulosus or Echinococcus multilocularis.

column1: C03.600*D050738*Mesomycetozoea Infections*Infections by MESOMYCETOZOEA
column2: general or unspecified.

column1: C03.600.700*D012227*Rhinosporidiosis*Chronic
column2: localized granulomatous infection of mucocutaneous tissues
column4: and characterized by HYPERPLASIA and the development of POLYPS. It is found in humans and other animals and is caused by the mesomycetozoean organism RHINOSPORIDIUM SEEBERI.

column1: C03.684*D009894*Opportunistic Infections*An infection caused by an organism which becomes pathogenic under certain conditions
column2: e.g.

column1: C03.684.050*D017088*AIDS-Related Opportunistic Infections*Opportunistic infections found in patients who test positive for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). The most common include PNEUMOCYSTIS PNEUMONIA
column2: Kaposi's sarcoma

column1: C03.684.880*D015163*Superinfection*A frequent complication of drug therapy for microbial infection. It may result from opportunistic colonization following immunosuppression by the primary pathogen and can be influenced by the time interval between infections
column2: microbial physiology
column3: or host resistance. Experimental challenge and in vitro models are sometimes used in virulence and infectivity studies.

column2: which parasitize erythrocytes

column2: Bovine*Infection in cattle caused by various species of trypanosomes.

column1: C03.718*D015597*Pregnancy Complications

column3: mild diarrhea to fulminant dysentery may occur.

column1: C03.752.100*D020808*Central Nervous System Protozoal Infections*Infections of the brain
column2: spinal cord
column3: or meninges by single celled organisms of the former subkingdom known as protozoa. The central nervous system may be the primary or secondary site of protozoal infection. These diseases may occur as OPPORTUNISTIC INFECTIONS or arise in immunocompetent hosts.

column1: C03.752.200*D016770*Ciliophora Infections*Infections with protozoa of the phylum CILIOPHORA.

C03.752.250.269*D003457*Cryptosporidiosis*Intestinal infection with organisms of the genus CRYPTOSPORIDIUM. It occurs in both animals and humans. Symptoms include severe DIARRHEA.
C03.752.250.280*D021866*Cyclosporiasis*Infection with parasitic protozoa of the genus CYCLOSPORA. It is distributed globally and causes a diarrheal illness. Transmission is waterborne.

column2: producing intestinal disease. It is caused by ingestion of oocysts and can produce tissue cysts.

column1: C03.752.250.634*D012523*Sarcocystosis*Infection of the striated muscle of mammals by parasites of the genus SARCOCYSTIS. Disease symptoms such as vomiting

column5: a toxin produced by the organism.

column1: C03.752.250.800*D014123*Toxoplasmosis*The acquired form of infection by Toxoplasma gondii in animals and man.

column2: Animal*Acquired infection of non-human animals by organisms of the genus TOXOPLASMA.

Cerebral*Infections of the BRAIN caused by the protozoan TOXOPLASMA gondii that primarily arise in individuals with IMMUNOLOGIC DEFICIENCY SYNDROMES (see also AIDS-RELATED OPPORTUNISTIC INFECTIONS). The infection may involve the brain diffusely or form discrete abscesses. Clinical manifestations include SEIZURES

Congenital*Prenatal protozoal infection with TOXOPLASMA gondii which is associated with injury to the developing fetal nervous system. The severity of this condition is related to the stage of pregnancy during which the infection occurs; first trimester infections are associated with a greater degree of neurologic dysfunction. Clinical features include HYDROCEPHALUS; MICROCEPHALY; deafness; cerebral calcifications; SEIZURES; and psychomotor retardation. Signs of a systemic infection may also be present at birth
Ocular*Infection caused by the protozoan parasite TOXOPLASMA in which there is extensive connective tissue proliferation
column3: the retina surrounding the lesions remains normal
column4: and the ocular media remain clear. Chorioretinitis may be associated with all forms of toxoplasmosis
column5: but is usually a late sequel of congenital toxoplasmosis. The severe ocular lesions in infants may lead to blindness.

column1: C03.752.275*D004030*Dientamoebiasis*Gastrointestinal infection with organisms of the genus DIENTAMOEBA.

Cutaneous*An endemic disease that is characterized by the development of single or multiple localized lesions on exposed areas of skin that typically ulcerate. The disease has been divided into Old and New World forms. New World leishmaniasis
column4: occurs in South and Central America and is caused by species of the L. mexicana or L. braziliensis complexes.

column6: and L. mexicana in Central America. This disease is characterized by massive dissemination of skin lesions without visceral involvement.

column5: and buccal mucosa some time after the appearance of the initial cutaneous lesion. Nasal obstruction and epistaxis are frequent presenting symptoms.

column10: and an earth-gray color of the skin. The disease is classified into three main types according to geographic distribution: Indian

column1: C03.752.300.900.200.190*D002598*Chagas Cardiomyopathy*A disease of the CARDIAC MUSCLE developed subsequent to the initial protozoan infection by TRYPANOSOMA CRUZI. After infection

column1: C03.752.300.900.226*D004313*Dourine*A disease of horses and donkeys caused by Trypanosoma equiperdum. The disease occurs in Africa

column1: C03.752.400*D005873*Giardiasis*An infection of the SMALL INTESTINE caused by the flagellated protozoan GIARDIA LAMBLIA. It is spread via contaminated food and water and by direct person-to-person contact.

column2: Africa
column5: and certain Caribbean islands. It is characterized by extreme exhaustion associated with paroxysms of high FEVER; SWEATING; shaking CHILLS; and ANEMIA. Malaria in ANIMALS is caused by other species of plasmodia.

column2: Avian*Any of a group of infections of fowl caused by protozoa of the genera PLASMODIUM
column4: and Haemoproteus. The life cycles of these parasites and the disease produced bears strong resemblance to those observed in human malaria.

Pathologic features include cerebral capillaries filled with parasitized erythrocytes and multiple small foci of cortical and subcortical necrosis. (From Adams et al.

Falciparum*Malaria caused by PLASMODIUM FALCIPARUM. This is the severest form of malaria and is associated with the highest levels of parasites in the blood. This disease is characterized by irregularly recurring febrile paroxysms that in extreme cases occur with acute cerebral

C04.557.450.565.465.249*D034801*Mastocytoma*A solid tumor consisting of a dense infiltration of MAST CELLS. It is generally benign.

column2: Skin*A variant of cutaneous mastocytosis which occurs as a single lesion usually in infants. It is found mostly in the wrist and trunk and there is no atypical cytomorphology.
Cutaneous*Skin lesions due to abnormal infiltration of MAST CELLS. Cutaneous mastocytosis is confined to the skin without the involvement of other tissues or organs
column3: and is mostly found in children. The three major variants are: URTICARIA PIGMENTOSA; diffuse cutaneous mastocytosis; and SOLITARY MASTOCYTOMA OF SKIN.

column2: Skin*A variant of cutaneous mastocytosis which occurs as a single lesion usually in infants. It is found mostly in the wrist and trunk and there is no atypical cytomorphology.

column1: C04.557.450.565.465.500.850*D014582*Urticaria Pigmentosa*The most common form of cutaneous mastocytosis (MASTOCYTOSIS
column2: CUTANEOUS) that occurs primarily in children. It is characterized by the multiple small reddish-brown pigmented pruritic macules and papules.
Systemic*A group of disorders caused by the abnormal proliferation of MAST CELLS in a variety of extracutaneous tissues including bone marrow
column6: and gastrointestinal tract. Systemic mastocytosis is commonly seen in adults. These diseases are categorized on the basis of clinical features

column2: Mast-Cell*A form of systemic mastocytosis (MASTOCYTOSIS
column3: SYSTEMIC) characterized by the presence of large numbers of tissue MAST CELLS in the peripheral blood without skin lesions. It is a high-grade LEUKEMIA disease with bone marrow smear of >20% MAST CELLS
column4: multi-organ failure and a short survival.

column1: C04.557.450.565.540*D047708*Myofibroma*A benign tumor that consists chiefly of fibrous CONNECTIVE TISSUE

column1: C04.557.450.565.550.312*D056733*Carney Complex*Autosomal dominant syndrome characterized by cardiac and cutaneous MYXOMAS; LENTIGINOSIS (spotty pigmentation of the skin)
column2: and endocrinopathy and its associated endocrine tumors. The cardiac myxomas may lead to SUDDEN CARDIAC DEATH and other complications in Carney complex patients. The gene coding for the PRKAR1A protein is one of the causative genetic loci (type 1). A second locus is at chromosome 2p16 (type 2).

column2: Bone Tissue*Neoplasms composed of bony tissue

column2: Ossifying*A benign central bone tumor

column4: composed of fibrous connective tissue within which bone is formed.

column1: C04.557.450.565.575.610*D015831*Osteochondroma*A cartilage-capped benign tumor that often appears as a stalk on the surface of bone. It is probably a developmental malformation rather than a true neoplasm and is usually found in the metaphysis of the distal femur

column1: C04.557.450.565.575.625*D010016*Osteoma*A benign tumor composed of bone tissue or a hard tumor of bonelike structure developing on a bone (homoplastic osteoma) or on other structures (heteroplastic osteoma). (From Dorland

solid or cystic fibroepithelial (FIBROEPITHELIAL NEOPLASMS) tumor

column4: of children below the age of 10. The cells are smaller than those of other rhabdomyosarcomas and are of two basic cell types: spindle cells and round cells. This cancer is highly sensitive to chemotherapy and has a high cure rate with multi-modality therapy. (From Holland et al.

column1: C04.557.450.795.560*D009236*Myxosarcoma*A sarcoma
column2: usually a liposarcoma or malignant fibrous histiocytoma
column3: with an abundant component of myxoid tissue resembling primitive mesenchyme containing connective tissue mucin. (Stedman

column1: C04.557.450.795.620*D012516*Osteosarcoma*A sarcoma originating in bone-forming cells
column2: affecting the ends of long bones. It is the most common and most malignant of sarcomas of the bones
column3: and occurs chiefly among 10- to 25-year-old youths. (From Stedman

column2: Juxtacortical*A form of osteogenic sarcoma of relatively low malignancy
column3: probably arising from the periosteum and initially involving cortical bone and adjacent connective tissue. It occurs in middle-aged as well as young adults and most commonly affects the lower part of the femoral shaft. (Stedman

column2: Ewing*A malignant tumor of the bone which always arises in the medullary tissue
column3: occurring more often in cylindrical bones. The tumor occurs usually before the age of 20
column4: about twice as frequently in males as in females.

column1: C04.557.450.795.650*D003557*Phyllodes Tumor*A type of connective tissue neoplasm typically arising from intralobular stroma of the breast. It is characterized by the rapid enlargement of an asymmetric firm mobile mass. Histologically
column2: its leaf-like stromal clefts are lined by EPITHELIAL CELLS. Rare phyllodes tumor of the prostate is also known.
Alveolar Soft Part*A variety of rare sarcoma having a reticulated fibrous stroma enclosing groups of sarcoma cells
column3: which resemble epithelial cells and are enclosed in alveoli walled with connective tissue. It is a rare tumor
column4: usually occurring between 15 and 35 years of age. It appears in the muscles of the extremities in adults and most commonly in the head and neck regions of children. Though slow-growing
column5: it commonly metastasizes to the lungs
column8: and lymph nodes. (DeVita Jr et al.

column2: Clear Cell*A sarcoma of young
column4: adults of the lower extremities and acral regions
column5: intimately bound to tendons as circumscribed but unencapsulated melanin-bearing tumors of neuroectodermal origin. An ultrastructural finding simulates flattened and curved barrel staves
column6: corresponding to the internal structures of premelanosomes. There is a 45-60% mortality in clear cell sarcoma. (Segen

column2: Experimental*Experimentally induced neoplasms of CONNECTIVE TISSUE in animals to provide a model for studying human SARCOMA.

column1: C04.557.450.795.830.760*D012511*Sarcoma 37*An experimental sarcoma of mice.
C04.557.450.795.830.780*D012510*Sarcoma 180*An experimental sarcoma of mice.

column2: Avian*Connective tissue tumors
column4: that are usually caused by avian sarcoma viruses.

column2: Yoshida*An experimental sarcoma of rats.
Kaposi*A multicentric
column3: malignant neoplastic vascular proliferation characterized by the development of bluish-red cutaneous nodules
column5: most often on the toes or feet
column6: and slowly increasing in size and number and spreading to more proximal areas. The tumors have endothelium-lined channels and vascular spaces admixed with variably sized aggregates of spindle-shaped cells
column7: and often remain confined to the skin and subcutaneous tissue
column8: but widespread visceral involvement may occur. Kaposi's sarcoma occurs spontaneously in Jewish and Italian males in Europe and the United States. An aggressive variant in young children is endemic in some areas of Africa. A third form occurs in about 0.04% of kidney transplant patients. There is also a high incidence in AIDS patients. (From Dorland
column12: pp2105-7) HHV-8 is the suspected cause.

column2: Myeloid*An extramedullary tumor of immature MYELOID CELLS or MYELOBLASTS. Granulocytic sarcoma usually occurs with or follows the onset of ACUTE MYELOID LEUKEMIA.
Small Cell*A sarcoma characterized by the presence of small cells
column3: cells measuring 9-14 micrometers with a faint or indistinct rim of cytoplasm and an oval-to-elongated nucleus with relatively dense chromatin. (From Segen

column2: Synovial*A malignant neoplasm arising from tenosynovial tissue of the joints and in synovial cells of tendons and bursae. The legs are the most common site
column3: but the tumor can occur in the abdominal wall and other trunk muscles. There are two recognized types: the monophasic (characterized by sheaths of monotonous spindle cells) and the biphasic (characterized by slit-like spaces or clefts within the tumor
column4: lined by cuboidal or tall columnar epithelial cells). These sarcomas occur most commonly in the second and fourth decades of life. (From Dorland

column2: Germ Cell and Embryonal*Neoplasms composed of primordial GERM CELLS of embryonic GONADS or of elements of the germ layers of the EMBRYO
column3: MAMMALIAN. The concept does not refer to neoplasms located in the gonads or present in an embryo or FETUS.

column2: Embryonal*A highly malignant
column4: probably of germinal cell or teratomatous derivation
column5: usually arising in a gonad and rarely in other sites. It is rare in the female ovary
column6: but in the male it accounts for 20% of all testicular tumors. (From Dorland

column1: C04.557.465.220*D002817*Chordoma*A malignant tumor arising from the embryonic remains of the notochord. It is also called chordocarcinoma
column2: chordoepithelioma

column1: C04.557.465.330*D018237*Germinoma*A malignant neoplasm of the germinal tissue of the GONADS; MEDIASTINUM; or pineal region. Germinomas are uniform in appearance
column2: consisting of large
column3: round cells with vesicular nuclei and clear or finely granular eosinophilic-staining cytoplasm. (Stedman
column4: 265th ed; from DeVita Jr et al.

column1: C04.557.465.330.300*D004407*Dysgerminoma*A malignant ovarian neoplasm
column2: thought to be derived from primordial germ cells of the sexually undifferentiated embryonic gonad. It is the counterpart of the classical seminoma of the testis
column3: to which it is both grossly and histologically identical. Dysgerminomas comprise 16% of all germ cell tumors but are rare before the age of 10
column4: although nearly 50% occur before the age of 20. They are generally considered of low-grade malignancy but may spread if the tumor extends through its capsule and involves lymph nodes or blood vessels. (Dorland

column1: C04.557.465.330.800*D018239*Seminoma*A radiosensitive
column2: malignant neoplasm of the testis
column3: thought to be derived from primordial germ cells of the sexually undifferentiated embryonic gonad. There are three variants: classical (typical)
column4: the most common type; anaplastic; and spermatocytic. The classical seminoma is composed of fairly well differentiated sheets or cords of uniform polygonal or round cells (seminoma cells)
column5: each cell having abundant clear cytoplasm
column8: and one or more nucleoli. In the female
column9: a grossly and histologically identical neoplasm

column1: C04.557.465.420*D018238*Gonadoblastoma*A complex neoplasm composed of a mixture of gonadal elements
column2: such as large primordial GERM CELLS
column3: immature SERTOLI CELLS or GRANULOSA CELLS of the sex cord
column4: and gonadal stromal cells. Gonadoblastomas are most often associated with gonadal dysgenesis

column1: C04.557.465.510*D008649*Mesonephroma*A rare tumor of the female genital tract
column2: most often the ovary
column3: formerly considered to be derived from mesonephric rests. Two varieties are recognized: (1) clear cell carcinoma
column4: so called because of its histologic resemblance to renal cell carcinoma
column5: and now considered to be of muellerian duct derivation and (2) an embryonal tumor (called also ENDODERMAL SINUS TUMOR and yolk sac tumor)
column6: occurring chiefly in children. The latter variety may also arise in the testis. (Dorland

column1: C04.557.465.510.350*D018240*Endodermal Sinus Tumor*An unusual and aggressive tumor of germ-cell origin that reproduces the extraembryonic structures of the early embryo. It is the most common malignant germ cell tumor found in children. It is characterized by a labyrinthine glandular pattern of flat epithelial cells and rounded papillary processes with a central capillary (Schiller-Duval body). The tumor is rarely bilateral. Before the use of combination chemotherapy
column2: the tumor was almost invariably fatal. (From DeVita Jr et al.

column1: C04.557.465.625*D017599*Neuroectodermal Tumors*Malignant neoplasms arising in the neuroectoderm
column2: the portion of the ectoderm of the early embryo that gives rise to the central and peripheral nervous systems

column1: C04.557.465.625.200*D003397*Craniopharyngioma*A benign pituitary-region neoplasm that originates from Rathke's pouch. The two major histologic and clinical subtypes are adamantinous (or classical) craniopharyngioma and papillary craniopharyngioma. The adamantinous form presents in children and adolescents as an expanding cystic lesion in the pituitary region. The cystic cavity is filled with a black viscous substance and histologically the tumor is composed of adamantinomatous epithelium and areas of calcification and necrosis. Papillary craniopharyngiomas occur in adults
column2: and histologically feature a squamous epithelium with papillations. (From Joynt
Neuroepithelial*Neoplasms composed of neuroepithelial cells
column3: which have the capacity to differentiate into NEURONS
column5: and ASTROCYTES. The majority of craniospinal tumors are of neuroepithelial origin. (From Dev Biol 1998 Aug 1;200(1):1-5)

column1: C04.557.465.625.600.355*D005729*Ganglioneuroma*A benign neoplasm that usually arises from the sympathetic trunk in the mediastinum. Histologic features include spindle cell proliferation (resembling a neurofibroma) and the presence of large ganglion cells. The tumor may present clinically with HORNER SYNDROME or diarrhea due to ectopic production of vasoactive intestinal peptide. (From DeVita et al.
column2: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column1: C04.557.465.625.600.380*D005910*Glioma*Benign and malignant central nervous system neoplasms derived from glial cells (i.e.
column2: astrocytes
column4: and ependymocytes). Astrocytes may give rise to astrocytomas (ASTROCYTOMA) or glioblastoma multiforme (see GLIOBLASTOMA). Oligodendrocytes give rise to oligodendrogliomas (OLIGODENDROGLIOMA) and ependymocytes may undergo transformation to become EPENDYMOMA; CHOROID PLEXUS NEOPLASMS; or colloid cysts of the third ventricle. (From Escourolle et al.

column1: C04.557.465.625.600.380.080*D001254*Astrocytoma*Neoplasms of the brain and spinal cord derived from glial cells which vary from histologically benign forms to highly anaplastic and malignant tumors. Fibrillary astrocytomas are the most common type and may be classified in order of increasing malignancy (grades I through IV). In the first two decades of life
column2: astrocytomas tend to originate in the cerebellar hemispheres; in adults
column3: they most frequently arise in the cerebrum and frequently undergo malignant transformation. (From Devita et al.
column4: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column1: C04.557.465.625.600.380.080.335*D005909*Glioblastoma*A malignant form of astrocytoma histologically characterized by pleomorphism of cells
column2: nuclear atypia
column4: and necrosis. They may arise in any region of the central nervous system
column5: with a predilection for the cerebral hemispheres
column7: and commissural pathways. Clinical presentation most frequently occurs in the fifth or sixth decade of life with focal neurologic signs or seizures.

column1: C04.557.465.625.600.380.290*D004806*Ependymoma*Glioma derived from EPENDYMOGLIAL CELLS that tend to present as malignant intracranial tumors in children and as benign intraspinal neoplasms in adults. It may arise from any level of the ventricular system or central canal of the spinal cord. Intracranial ependymomas most frequently originate in the FOURTH VENTRICLE and histologically are densely cellular tumors which may contain ependymal tubules and perivascular pseudorosettes. Spinal ependymomas are usually benign papillary or myxopapillary tumors. (From DeVita et al.
column2: Principles and Practice of Oncology
Subependymal*Rare
column5: often asymptomatic and discovered incidentally. The tumors are classified histologically as ependymomas and demonstrate a proliferation of subependymal fibrillary astrocytes among the ependymal tumor cells. (From Clin Neurol Neurosurg 1997 Feb;99(1):17-22)

column1: C04.557.465.625.600.380.350*D018303*Ganglioglioma*Rare indolent tumors comprised of neoplastic glial and neuronal cells which occur primarily in children and young adults. Benign lesions tend to be associated with long survival unless the tumor degenerates into a histologically malignant form. They tend to occur in the optic nerve and white matter of the brain and spinal cord.
C04.557.465.625.600.380.400*D018316*Gliosarcoma*Rare mixed tumors of the brain and rarely the spinal cord which contain malignant neuroectodermal (glial) and mesenchymal components
column2: including spindle-shaped fibrosarcoma cells. These tumors are highly aggressive and present primarily in adults as rapidly expanding mass lesions. They may arise in tissue that has been previously irradiated. (From Br J Neurosurg 1995 Apr;9(2):171-8)

column1: C04.557.465.625.600.380.515*D008527*Medulloblastoma*A malignant neoplasm that may be classified either as a glioma or as a primitive neuroectodermal tumor of childhood (see NEUROECTODERMAL TUMOR
column2: PRIMITIVE). The tumor occurs most frequently in the first decade of life with the most typical location being the cerebellar vermis. Histologic features include a high degree of cellularity
column4: and a tendency for the cells to organize into sheets or form rosettes. Medulloblastoma have a high propensity to spread throughout the craniospinal intradural axis. (From DeVita et al.
column5: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column1: C04.557.465.625.600.380.590*D009837*Oligodendroglioma*A relatively slow-growing glioma that is derived from oligodendrocytes and tends to occur in the cerebral hemispheres
column2: thalamus
column3: or lateral ventricle. They may present at any age
column4: but are most frequent in the third to fifth decades
column5: with an earlier incidence peak in the first decade. Histologically
column8: and tend to form cysts and microcalcifications. Neoplastic cells tend to have small round nuclei surrounded by unstained nuclei. The tumors may vary from well-differentiated to highly anaplastic forms. (From DeVita et al.
column9: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column1: C04.557.465.625.600.380.795*D020339*Optic Nerve Glioma*Glial cell derived tumors arising from the optic nerve
column2: usually presenting in childhood.

column1: C04.557.465.625.600.580*D018306*Neurocytoma*A benign brain tumor composed of neural elements which most often arise from the SEPTUM PELLUCIDUM and the walls of the lateral ventricles. Immunohistochemistry and electron microscopy evaluations may reveal expression of neuron specific enolase and synaptophysin and cells containing microtubuli
column2: neurosecretory granules
column3: and presynaptic vesicles. (From Acta Med Port 1994 Feb;7(2):113-9)

column1: C04.557.465.625.600.590*D018242*Neuroectodermal Tumors
column2: Primitive*A group of malignant tumors of the nervous system that feature primitive cells with elements of neuronal and/or glial differentiation. Use of this term is limited by some authors to central nervous system tumors and others include neoplasms of similar origin which arise extracranially (i.e.
column5: PERIPHERAL). This term is also occasionally used as a synonym for MEDULLOBLASTOMA. In general
column6: these tumors arise in the first decade of life and tend to be highly malignant. (From DeVita et al.
column7: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column1: C04.557.465.625.600.590.500*D008527*Medulloblastoma*A malignant neoplasm that may be classified either as a glioma or as a primitive neuroectodermal tumor of childhood (see NEUROECTODERMAL TUMOR
column2: PRIMITIVE). The tumor occurs most frequently in the first decade of life with the most typical location being the cerebellar vermis. Histologic features include a high degree of cellularity
column4: and a tendency for the cells to organize into sheets or form rosettes. Medulloblastoma have a high propensity to spread throughout the craniospinal intradural axis. (From DeVita et al.
column5: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column1: C04.557.465.625.600.590.650*D018241*Neuroectodermal Tumors
column2: Primitive
column3: Peripheral*A group of highly cellular primitive round cell neoplasms which occur extracranially in soft tissue and bone and are derived from embryonal neural crest cells. These tumors occur primarily in children and adolescents and share a number of characteristics with EWING SARCOMA.

column1: C04.557.465.625.600.590.650.550*D009447*Neuroblastoma*A common neoplasm of early childhood arising from neural crest cells in the sympathetic nervous system
column2: and characterized by diverse clinical behavior
column3: ranging from spontaneous remission to rapid metastatic progression and death. This tumor is the most common intraabdominal malignancy of childhood
column4: but it may also arise from thorax
column6: or rarely occur in the central nervous system. Histologic features include uniform round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei arranged in nests and separated by fibrovascular septa. Neuroblastomas may be associated with the opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome. (From DeVita et al.
column7: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column2: Olfactory*A malignant olfactory neuroblastoma arising from the olfactory epithelium of the superior nasal cavity and cribriform plate. It is uncommon (3% of nasal tumors) and rarely is associated with the production of excess hormones (e.g.
column4: Cushing Syndrome). It has a high propensity for multiple local recurrences and bony metastases. (From Holland et al.

column1: C04.557.465.625.600.590.650.550.300*D018305*Ganglioneuroblastoma*A moderately malignant neoplasm composed of primitive neuroectodermal cells dispersed in myxomatous or fibrous stroma intermixed with mature ganglion cells. It may undergo transformation into a neuroblastoma. It arises from the sympathetic trunk or less frequently from the adrenal medulla
column2: cerebral cortex
column3: and other locations. Cervical ganglioneuroblastomas may be associated with HORNER SYNDROME and the tumor may occasionally secrete vasoactive intestinal peptide

column1: C04.557.465.625.600.657*D010871*Pinealoma*Neoplasms which originate from pineal parenchymal cells that tend to enlarge the gland and be locally invasive. The two major forms are pineocytoma and the more malignant pineoblastoma. Pineocytomas have moderate cellularity and tend to form rosette patterns. Pineoblastomas are highly cellular tumors containing small
column2: poorly differentiated cells. These tumors occasionally seed the neuroaxis or cause obstructive HYDROCEPHALUS or Parinaud's syndrome. GERMINOMA; CARCINOMA
column3: EMBRYONAL; GLIOMA; and other neoplasms may arise in the pineal region with germinoma being the most common pineal region tumor. (From DeVita et al.
column4: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column1: C04.557.465.625.600.725*D012175*Retinoblastoma*A malignant tumor arising from the nuclear layer of the retina that is the most common primary tumor of the eye in children. The tumor tends to occur in early childhood or infancy and may be present at birth. The majority are sporadic
column2: but the condition may be transmitted as an autosomal dominant trait. Histologic features include dense cellularity
column4: and areas of calcification and necrosis. An abnormal pupil reflex (leukokoria); NYSTAGMUS
column5: PATHOLOGIC; STRABISMUS; and visual loss represent common clinical characteristics of this condition. (From DeVita et al.
column6: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column1: C04.557.465.625.630*D017600*Neuroectodermal Tumor
column2: Melanotic*A benign
column4: deeply pigmented tumor of the jaw and occasionally of other sites
column5: consisting of an infiltrating mass of cells arranged in an alveolar pattern
column6: and occurring almost exclusively in infants. Its source of origin is in dispute
column7: the various theories giving rise to its several names. (Dorland

column1: C04.557.465.625.650*D018358*Neuroendocrine Tumors*Tumors whose cells possess secretory granules and originate from the neuroectoderm
column2: i.e.
column3: the cells of the ectoblast or epiblast that program the neuroendocrine system. Common properties across most neuroendocrine tumors include ectopic hormone production (often via APUD CELLS)

column2: Acidophil*A benign tumor
column3: usually found in the anterior lobe of the pituitary gland
column4: whose cells stain with acid dyes. Such pituitary tumors may give rise to excessive secretion of growth hormone
column5: resulting in gigantism or acromegaly. A specific type of acidophil adenoma may give rise to nonpuerperal galactorrhea. (Dorland

column2: Basophil*A small tumor of the anterior lobe of the pituitary gland whose cells stain with basic dyes. It may give rise to excessive secretion of ACTH
Chromophobe*A benign tumor of the anterior pituitary in which the cells do not stain with acidic or basic dyes.

column1: C04.557.465.625.650.135*D001079*Apudoma*A general term collectively applied to tumors associated with the APUD CELLS series
column2: irrespective of their specific identification.

column1: C04.557.465.625.650.200*D002276*Carcinoid Tumor*A usually small
column2: slow-growing neoplasm composed of islands of rounded
column4: or spindle-shaped cells of medium size
column6: and covered by intact mucosa with a yellow cut surface. The tumor can occur anywhere in the gastrointestinal tract (and in the lungs and other sites); approximately 90% arise in the appendix. It is now established that these tumors are of neuroendocrine origin and derive from a primitive stem cell. (From Stedman

column1: C04.557.465.625.650.200.500*D008303*Malignant Carcinoid Syndrome*A symptom complex associated with CARCINOID TUMOR and characterized by attacks of severe flushing of the skin
column2: diarrheal watery stools
column6: and ascites. The carcinoid tumors are usually located in the gastrointestinal tract and metastasize to the liver. Symptoms are caused by tumor secretion of serotonin
column8: and other biologically active substances. Cardiac manifestations constitute CARCINOID HEART DISEASE. (Dorland

column1: C04.557.465.625.650.200.500.205*D002275*Carcinoid Heart Disease*Cardiac manifestation of gastrointestinal CARCINOID TUMOR that metastasizes to the liver. Substances secreted by the tumor cells
column2: including SEROTONIN
column3: promote fibrous plaque formation in ENDOCARDIUM and its underlying layers. These deposits cause distortion of the TRICUSPID VALVE and the PULMONARY VALVE eventually leading to STENOSIS and valve regurgitation.

column2: Neuroendocrine*A group of carcinomas which share a characteristic morphology
column3: often being composed of clusters and trabecular sheets of round blue cells
column5: and an attenuated rim of poorly demarcated cytoplasm. Neuroendocrine tumors include carcinoids
column11: and pheochromocytoma. Neurosecretory granules are found within the tumor cells. (Segen

column2: Medullary*A carcinoma composed mainly of epithelial elements with little or no stroma. Medullary carcinomas of the breast constitute 5%-7% of all mammary carcinomas; medullary carcinomas of the thyroid comprise 3%-10% of all thyroid malignancies. (From Dorland

Merkel Cell*A carcinoma arising from MERKEL CELLS located in the basal layer of the epidermis and occurring most commonly as a primary neuroendocrine carcinoma of the skin. Merkel cells are tactile cells of neuroectodermal origin and histologically show neurosecretory granules. The skin of the head and neck are a common site of Merkel cell carcinoma
column3: occurring generally in elderly patients. (Holland et al.

column1: C04.557.465.625.650.240.695*D013005*Somatostatinoma*A SOMATOSTATIN-secreting tumor derived from the pancreatic delta cells (SOMATOSTATIN-SECRETING CELLS). It is also found in the INTESTINE. Somatostatinomas are associated with DIABETES MELLITUS; CHOLELITHIASIS; STEATORRHEA; and HYPOCHLORHYDRIA. The majority of somatostatinomas have the potential for METASTASIS.
C04.557.465.625.650.240.847*D003969*Vipoma*A tumor that secretes VASOACTIVE INTESTINAL PEPTIDE
column2: a neuropeptide that causes VASODILATION; relaxation of smooth muscles; watery DIARRHEA; HYPOKALEMIA; and HYPOCHLORHYDRIA. Vipomas
column3: derived from the pancreatic ISLET CELLS
column4: generally are malignant and can secrete other hormones. In most cases
column5: Vipomas are located in the PANCREAS but can be found in extrapancreatic sites.

column1: C04.557.465.625.650.510*D008545*Melanoma*A malignant neoplasm derived from cells that are capable of forming melanin
column2: which may occur in the skin of any part of the body
column6: in the mucous membranes of the genitalia
column9: or other sites. It occurs mostly in adults and may originate de novo or from a pigmented nevus or malignant lentigo. Melanomas frequently metastasize widely
column13: and brain are likely to be involved. The incidence of malignant skin melanomas is rising rapidly in all parts of the world. (Stedman

column1: C04.557.465.625.650.510.385*D018327*Hutchinson's Melanotic Freckle*A cellular subtype of malignant melanoma. It is a pigmented lesion composed of melanocytes occurring on sun-exposed skin
column2: usually the face and neck. The melanocytes are commonly multinucleated with a starburst appearance. It is considered by many to be the in situ phase of lentigo maligna melanoma.
Amelanotic*An unpigmented malignant melanoma. It is an anaplastic melanoma consisting of cells derived from melanoblasts but not forming melanin. (Dorland
Experimental*Experimentally induced tumor that produces MELANIN in animals to provide a model for studying human MELANOMA.

column1: C04.557.465.625.650.595*D009442*Neurilemmoma*A neoplasm that arises from SCHWANN CELLS of the cranial
column2: peripheral
column4: these tumors may present as a cranial neuropathy
column7: or with spinal cord compression. Histologically
column10: and composed of a homogenous pattern of biphasic fusiform-shaped cells that may have a palisaded appearance. (From DeVita Jr et al.

column2: Acoustic*A benign SCHWANNOMA of the eighth cranial nerve (VESTIBULOCOCHLEAR NERVE)
column3: mostly arising from the vestibular branch (VESTIBULAR NERVE) during the fifth or sixth decade of life. Clinical manifestations include HEARING LOSS; HEADACHE; VERTIGO; TINNITUS; and FACIAL PAIN. Bilateral acoustic neuromas are associated with NEUROFIBROMATOSIS 2. (From Adams et al.

column1: C04.557.465.625.650.595.610.500*D016518*Neurofibromatosis 2*An autosomal dominant disorder characterized by a high incidence of bilateral acoustic neuromas as well as schwannomas (NEURILEMMOMA) of other cranial and peripheral nerves
column2: and other benign intracranial tumors including meningiomas
column5: and gliomas. The disease has been linked to mutations of the NF2 gene (GENES
column6: NEUROFIBROMATOSIS 2) on chromosome 22 (22q12) and usually presents clinically in the first or second decade of life.

column1: C04.557.465.625.650.700*D010235*Paraganglioma*A neural crest tumor usually derived from the chromoreceptor tissue of a paraganglion
column2: such as the carotid body
column3: or medulla of the adrenal gland (usually called a chromaffinoma or pheochromocytoma). It is more common in women than in men. (Stedman

column2: Extra-Adrenal*A relatively rare
column3: usually benign neoplasm originating in the chemoreceptor tissue of the CAROTID BODY; GLOMUS JUGULARE; GLOMUS TYMPANICUM; AORTIC BODIES; and the female genital tract. It consists histologically of rounded or ovoid hyperchromatic cells that tend to be grouped in an alveolus-like pattern within a scant to moderate amount of fibrous stroma and a few large thin-walled vascular channels. (From Stedman

column1: C04.557.465.625.650.700.705.220*D002345*Carotid Body Tumor*Benign paraganglioma at the bifurcation of the COMMON CAROTID ARTERIES. It can encroach on the parapharyngeal space and produce dysphagia
column2: pain

column1: C04.557.465.625.650.700.705.340*D005925*Glomus Jugulare Tumor*A paraganglioma involving the glomus jugulare
column2: a microscopic collection of chemoreceptor tissue in the adventitia of the bulb of the jugular vein. It may cause paralysis of the vocal cords
column5: and nystagmus. It is not resectable but radiation therapy is effective. It regresses slowly
column6: but permanent control is regularly achieved. (From Dorland

column1: C04.557.465.625.650.700.705.360*D043604*Glomus Tympanicum Tumor*A rare PARAGANGLIOMA involving the GLOMUS TYMPANICUM
column2: a collection of chemoreceptor tissue adjacent to the TYMPANIC CAVITY. It can cause TINNITUS and conductive hearing loss (HEARING LOSS

column1: C04.557.465.625.650.700.725*D010673*Pheochromocytoma*A usually benign
column2: well-encapsulated
column4: vascular tumor of chromaffin tissue of the ADRENAL MEDULLA or sympathetic paraganglia. The cardinal symptom
column5: reflecting the increased secretion of EPINEPHRINE and NOREPINEPHRINE
column7: which may be persistent or intermittent. During severe attacks
column11: TREMOR; PALLOR or FLUSHING of the face
column13: pain in the CHEST and ABDOMEN
column14: and paresthesias of the extremities. The incidence of malignancy is as low as 5% but the pathologic distinction between benign and malignant pheochromocytomas is not clear. (Dorland

column1: C04.557.465.900*D018243*Teratocarcinoma*A malignant neoplasm consisting of elements of teratoma with those of embryonal carcinoma or choriocarcinoma

column1: C04.557.465.910*D013724*Teratoma*A true neoplasm composed of a number of different types of tissue

column3: characterized clinically by eczema-like inflammatory skin changes and histologically by infiltration of the dermis by malignant cells (Paget's cells).

column1: C04.557.470.200.240.250*D018290*Cervical Intraepithelial Neoplasia*A malignancy arising in uterine cervical epithelium and confined thereto
