column1: C04.557.470.200.240.500*D019048*Prostatic Intraepithelial Neoplasia*A premalignant change arising in the prostatic epithelium
column2: regarded as the most important and most likely precursor of prostatic adenocarcinoma. The neoplasia takes the form of an intra-acinar or ductal proliferation of secretory cells with unequivocal nuclear anaplasia
column3: which corresponds to nuclear grade 2 and 3 invasive prostate cancer.

column2: Krebs 2*A transplantable neoplasm of mice.
Large Cell*A tumor of undifferentiated (anaplastic) cells of large size. It is usually bronchogenic. (From Dorland

Lewis Lung*A carcinoma discovered by Dr. Margaret R. Lewis of the Wistar Institute in 1951. This tumor originated spontaneously as a carcinoma of the lung of a C57BL mouse. The tumor does not appear to be grossly hemorrhagic and the majority of the tumor tissue is a semifirm homogeneous mass. (From Cancer Chemother Rep 2 1972 Nov;(3)1:325) It is also called 3LL and LLC and is used as a transplantable malignancy.
Papillary*A malignant neoplasm characterized by the formation of numerous
column4: finger-like projections of fibrous stroma that is covered with a surface layer of neoplastic epithelial cells. (Stedman

column2: Small Cell*An anaplastic
column4: and usually bronchogenic carcinoma composed of small ovoid cells with scanty neoplasm. It is characterized by a dominant
column6: and absent or indistinct nucleoli. (From Stedman

column2: Squamous Cell*A carcinoma derived from stratified SQUAMOUS EPITHELIAL CELLS. It may also occur in sites where glandular or columnar epithelium is normally present. (From Stedman

column1: C04.557.470.200.400.130*D001913*Bowen's Disease*A persistent progressive non-elevated red scaly or crusted plaque which is due to an intradermal carcinoma and is potentially malignant. Atypical squamous cells proliferate through the whole thickness of the epidermis. The lesions may occur anywhere on the skin surface or on mucosal surfaces. The cause most frequently found is trivalent arsenic compounds. Freezing
column2: cauterization or diathermy coagulation is often effective. (From Rook et al.
Transitional Cell*A malignant neoplasm derived from TRANSITIONAL EPITHELIAL CELLS
column3: occurring chiefly in the URINARY BLADDER; URETERS; or RENAL PELVIS.

column2: Verrucous*A variant of well-differentiated epidermoid carcinoma that is most common in the oral cavity
column3: but also occurs in the larynx
column12: especially on the sole of the foot. Most intraoral cases occur in elderly male abusers of smokeless tobacco. The treatment is surgical resection. Radiotherapy is not indicated
column13: as up to 30% treated with radiation become highly aggressive within six months. (Segen

column1: C04.557.470.200.450.500*D062688*Buschke-Lowenstein Tumor*Exophytic tumor of the anogenital region associated with HPV infections. It becomes a large cauliflower-like
column2: hyperkeratotic
column3: verrucous mass that is locally destructive with little atypical cells. Histologically
column4: tumor cells are broad rete peg structures that tend to invade deeper than CONDYLOMATA ACUMINATA.

column1: C04.557.470.200.588*D000069295*Mammary Analogue Secretory Carcinoma*A malignant neoplasm of epithelial cells of the SALIVARY GLANDS
column2: with microcystic architecture

column1: C04.557.470.200.725*D065646*Thyroid Carcinoma
column2: Anaplastic*An aggressive THYROID GLAND malignancy which generally occurs in IODINE-deficient areas in people with previous thyroid pathology such as GOITER. It is associated with CELL DEDIFFERENTIATION of THYROID CARCINOMA (e.g.
column3: FOLLICULAR THYROID CARCINOMA; PAPILLARY THYROID CANCER). Typical initial presentation is a rapidly growing neck mass which upon metastasis is associated with DYSPHAGIA; NECK PAIN; bone pain; DYSPNEA; and NEUROLOGIC DEFICITS.

column2: Adnexal and Skin Appendage*Neoplasms composed of sebaceous or sweat gland tissue or tissue of other skin appendages. The concept does not refer to neoplasms located in the sebaceous or sweat glands or in the other skin appendages.
Sebaceous*A malignant tumor composed of cells showing differentiation toward sebaceous epithelium. The tumor is solitary
column6: and covered with normal or slightly verrucose epidermis. It may be yellow or orange. The face and scalp are the commonest sites. The growth can be slow or rapid but metastasis is uncommon. Surgery cures most of the cases. (From Rook et al.

column2: Sweat Gland*A benign neoplasm derived from epithelial cells of sweat glands. (Stedman

column1: C04.557.470.550.175.125*D018250*Acrospiroma*A rare cutaneous tumor of eccrine sweat gland origin. It is most commonly found on the extremities and is usually benign. There is no indication that heredity or external agents cause these tumors.
C04.557.470.550.175.125.600*D057091*Poroma*A benign adnexal neoplasm composed of EPITHELIAL CELLS. They typically manifest as solitary papules and occur only in the skin.
C04.557.470.550.175.375*D018251*Hidrocystoma*A cystic form of sweat gland adenoma (ADENOMA
column2: SWEAT GLAND). It is produced by the cystic proliferation of apocrine secretory glands. It is not uncommon
column3: occurring in adult life in no particular age group
column4: with males and females equally affected. The commonest site is around the eye
column5: particularly lateral to the outer canthus. It is cured by surgical removal. (Stedman

column1: C04.557.470.550.175.800*D018252*Syringoma*A benign tumor of the sweat glands which is usually multiple and results from malformation of sweat ducts. It is uncommon and more common in females than in males. It is most likely to appear at adolescence
column2: and further lesions may develop during adult life. It does not appear to be hereditary. (Rook et al.
Skin Appendage*A malignant tumor of the skin appendages
Basal Cell*Neoplasms composed of cells from the deepest layer of the epidermis. The concept does not refer to neoplasms located in the stratum basale.
Basal Cell*A malignant skin neoplasm that seldom metastasizes but has potentialities for local invasion and destruction. Clinically it is divided into types: nodular
column5: and erythematoid (pagetoid). They develop on hair-bearing skin
column6: most commonly on sun-exposed areas. Approximately 85% are found on the head and neck area and the remaining 15% on the trunk and limbs. (From DeVita Jr et al.

column1: C04.557.470.565.165.150*D001478*Basal Cell Nevus Syndrome*Hereditary disorder consisting of multiple basal cell carcinomas
column2: odontogenic keratocysts
column9: and cervicothoracic spina bifida. Genetic transmission is autosomal dominant.

column2: Basosquamous*A skin carcinoma that histologically exhibits both basal and squamous elements. (From Dorland

column1: C04.557.470.565.625*D018296*Pilomatrixoma*A tumor composed of cells resembling those of the hair matrix
column2: which undergo 'mummification' and may calcify. It is a relatively uncommon tumor
column3: which may occur at any age from infancy. The majority of patients are under 20
column4: and females are affected more than males. The lesion is usually a solitary deep dermal or subcutaneous tumor 3-30 mm in diameter
column7: or upper extremity. (From Rook et al.

column2: Cystic
column4: and Serous*Neoplasms containing cyst-like formations or producing mucin or serum.

column2: Mucinous*An adenocarcinoma producing mucin in significant amounts. (From Dorland
Mucoepidermoid*A tumor of both low- and high-grade malignancy. The low-grade grow slowly
column4: and are readily cured by excision. The high-grade behave aggressively
column5: widely infiltrate the salivary gland and produce lymph node and distant metastases. Mucoepidermoid carcinomas account for about 21% of the malignant tumors of the parotid gland and 10% of the sublingual gland. They are the most common malignant tumor of the parotid. (From DeVita Jr et al.

column2: Signet Ring Cell*A poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in which the nucleus is pressed to one side by a cytoplasmic droplet of mucus. It usually arises in the gastrointestinal system.

column1: C04.557.470.590.415.410*D007725*Krukenberg Tumor*Mucocellular carcinoma of the ovary
column2: usually metastatic from the gastrointestinal tract
column3: characterized by areas of mucoid degeneration and the presence of signet-ring-like cells. It accounts for 30%-40% of metastatic cancers to the ovaries and possibly 1%-2% of all malignant ovarian tumors. The lesions may not be discovered until the primary disease is advanced
column4: and most patients die of their disease within a year. In some cases
column5: a primary tumor is not found. (From Dorland

column1: C04.557.470.590.480*D003536*Cystadenocarcinoma*A malignant neoplasm derived from glandular epithelium
column2: in which cystic accumulations of retained secretions are formed. The neoplastic cells manifest varying degrees of anaplasia and invasiveness
column3: and local extension and metastases occur. Cystadenocarcinomas develop frequently in the ovaries
column4: where pseudomucinous and serous types are recognized. (Stedman

column1: C04.557.470.590.480.225*D018282*Cystadenocarcinoma
column2: Mucinous*A malignant cystic or semisolid tumor most often occurring in the ovary. Rarely
column3: one is solid. This tumor may develop from a mucinous cystadenoma
column4: or it may be malignant at the onset. The cysts are lined with tall columnar epithelial cells; in others
column5: the epithelium consists of many layers of cells that have lost normal structure entirely. In the more undifferentiated tumors
column6: one may see sheets and nests of tumor cells that have very little resemblance to the parent structure. (Hughes

column1: C04.557.470.590.480.230*D018283*Cystadenocarcinoma
column2: Papillary*An adenocarcinoma in which the tumor elements are arranged as finger-like processes or as a solid spherical nodule projecting from an epithelial surface.

column1: C04.557.470.590.480.240*D018284*Cystadenocarcinoma
column2: Serous*A malignant cystic or semicystic neoplasm. It often occurs in the ovary and usually bilaterally. The external surface is usually covered with papillary excrescences. Microscopically
column3: the papillary patterns are predominantly epithelial overgrowths with differentiated and undifferentiated papillary serous cystadenocarcinoma cells. Psammoma bodies may be present. The tumor generally adheres to surrounding structures and produces ascites. (From Hughes

column1: C04.557.470.590.482*D062625*Cystadenofibroma*Benign or borderline malignant neoplasm of the ovary and surrounding tissues. It is characterized by tumor(s) with cystic glands which are lined by cuboidal EPITHELIAL CELLS with clear cytoplasm
column2: resembling ENDOMETRIUM cells. The glands are separated by fibroblastic STROMAL CELLS.

column1: C04.557.470.590.485*D003537*Cystadenoma*A benign neoplasm derived from glandular epithelium
column2: in which cystic accumulations of retained secretions are formed. In some instances
Mucinous*A multilocular tumor with mucin secreting epithelium. They are most often found in the ovary
column3: but are also found in the pancreas
column6: retroperitoneal and in the urinary bladder. They are considered to have low-grade malignant potential.

column2: Papillary*A benign neoplasm of the ovary.
Serous*A cystic tumor of the ovary
column5: yellow serous fluid and varying amounts of solid tissue
column6: with a malignant potential several times greater than that of mucinous cystadenoma (CYSTADENOMA
column9: or multilocular. It is often bilateral and papillary. The cysts may vary greatly in size. (Dorland

column1: C04.557.470.590.580*D018298*Mucoepidermoid Tumor*A malignant epithelial tumor of glandular tissue
column2: especially the salivary glands
column3: characterized by acini with mucus-producing cells and by the presence of malignant squamous elements. Most mucoepidermoid tumors are low-grade lesions readily cured by adequate excision. They may appear in any age group. They grow slowly. If high-grade
column5: widely infiltrating the salivary gland and producing lymph node and distant metastases. (Dorland
column6: 27th ed; from DeVita Jr et al.

column1: C04.557.470.590.782*D011553*Pseudomyxoma Peritonei*A condition characterized by poorly-circumscribed gelatinous masses filled with malignant mucin-secreting cells. Forty-five percent of pseudomyxomas arise from the ovary
column2: usually in a mucinous cystadenocarcinoma (CYSTADENOCARCINOMA
column4: which has prognostic significance. Pseudomyxoma peritonei must be differentiated from mucinous spillage into the peritoneum by a benign mucocele of the appendix. (Segen

column2: Ductal
column6: located within the center of an organ or within small lobes
column7: and in the case of the breast
column8: intraductally. The emphasis of the name is on the location of the neoplastic tissue rather than on its histological type. Most cancers of this type are located in the breast.

column2: Ductal*Malignant neoplasms involving the ductal systems of any of a number of organs
Ductal
column3: Breast*An invasive (infiltrating) CARCINOMA of the mammary ductal system (MAMMARY GLANDS) in the human BREAST.

column2: Pancreatic Ductal*Carcinoma that arises from the PANCREATIC DUCTS. It accounts for the majority of cancers derived from the PANCREAS.
Intraductal

column2: Mammary*An intraductal in situ carcinoma of the breast

column2: Lobular*A type of BREAST CANCER where the abnormal malignant cells form in the lobules

Medullary*A carcinoma composed mainly of epithelial elements with little or no stroma. Medullary carcinomas of the breast constitute 5%-7% of all mammary carcinomas; medullary carcinomas of the thyroid comprise 3%-10% of all thyroid malignancies. (From Dorland
Extramammary*A rare cutaneous neoplasm that occurs in the elderly. It develops more frequently in women and predominantly involves apocrine gland-bearing areas
column5: and perianal areas. The lesions develop as erythematous scaly patches that progress to crusted
column7: erythematous plaques. The clinical differential diagnosis includes squamous cell carcinoma in situ and superficial fungal infection. It is generally thought to be an adenocarcinoma of the epidermis
column8: from which it extends into the contiguous epithelium of hair follicles and eccrine sweat ducts. (DeVita Jr et al.

column2: Intraductal*A small
column3: often impalpable benign papilloma arising in a lactiferous duct and frequently causing bleeding from the nipple. (Stedman

column2: Fibroepithelial*Neoplasms composed of fibrous and epithelial tissue. The concept does not refer to neoplasms located in fibrous tissue or epithelium.

column1: C04.557.470.625.050*D000232*Adenofibroma*A benign neoplasm composed of glandular and fibrous tissues
column2: with a relatively large proportion of glands. (Stedman

column1: C04.557.470.625.050.500*D062625*Cystadenofibroma*Benign or borderline malignant neoplasm of the ovary and surrounding tissues. It is characterized by tumor(s) with cystic glands which are lined by cuboidal EPITHELIAL CELLS with clear cytoplasm
column2: resembling ENDOMETRIUM cells. The glands are separated by fibroblastic STROMAL CELLS.

column1: C04.557.470.625.150*D001948*Brenner Tumor*A smooth
column2: solid or cystic fibroepithelial (FIBROEPITHELIAL NEOPLASMS) tumor
column3: usually found in the OVARIES but can also be found in the adnexal region and the KIDNEYS. It consists of a fibrous stroma with nests of epithelial cells that sometimes resemble the transitional cells lining the urinary bladder. Brenner tumors generally are benign and asymptomatic. Malignant Brenner tumors have been reported.

column1: C04.557.470.625.350*D018226*Fibroadenoma*An adenoma containing fibrous tissue. It should be differentiated from ADENOFIBROMA which is a tumor composed of connective tissue (fibroma) containing glandular (adeno-) structures. (From Dorland
column2: 27th ed)
Mesothelial*Neoplasms composed of tissue of the mesothelium
column5: which lines the body cavity of the embryo. In the adult it forms the simple squamous epithelium which covers all true serous membranes (peritoneum
column7: pleura). The concept does not refer to neoplasms located in these organs. (From Dorland

column1: C04.557.470.660.200*D018254*Adenomatoid Tumor*A small
column2: circumscribed
column3: benign tumor of the genital tract
column4: composed of small glandlike spaces lined by flattened or cuboidal mesothelium-like cells. (From Dorland

column1: C04.557.470.660.510*D008654*Mesothelioma*A tumor derived from mesothelial tissue (peritoneum
column2: pleura
column3: pericardium). It appears as broad sheets of cells
column5: sarcoma-like cells and other regions showing adenomatous patterns. Pleural mesotheliomas have been linked to exposure to asbestos. (Dorland

column2: Cystic*A peritoneal mesothelioma affecting mainly young females and producing cysts of variable size and number lined by a single layer of benign mesothelial cells. The disease follows a benign course and is compatible with a normal life expectancy
column3: requiring occasionally partial excision or decompression for relief of pain or other symptoms. Malignant potential is exceptional. (From Holland et al.

column2: Neuroepithelial*Neoplasms composed of neuroepithelial cells
column3: which have the capacity to differentiate into NEURONS
column5: and ASTROCYTES. The majority of craniospinal tumors are of neuroepithelial origin. (From Dev Biol 1998 Aug 1;200(1):1-5)

column1: C04.557.470.670.355*D005729*Ganglioneuroma*A benign neoplasm that usually arises from the sympathetic trunk in the mediastinum. Histologic features include spindle cell proliferation (resembling a neurofibroma) and the presence of large ganglion cells. The tumor may present clinically with HORNER SYNDROME or diarrhea due to ectopic production of vasoactive intestinal peptide. (From DeVita et al.
column2: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column1: C04.557.470.670.380*D005910*Glioma*Benign and malignant central nervous system neoplasms derived from glial cells (i.e.
column2: astrocytes
column4: and ependymocytes). Astrocytes may give rise to astrocytomas (ASTROCYTOMA) or glioblastoma multiforme (see GLIOBLASTOMA). Oligodendrocytes give rise to oligodendrogliomas (OLIGODENDROGLIOMA) and ependymocytes may undergo transformation to become EPENDYMOMA; CHOROID PLEXUS NEOPLASMS; or colloid cysts of the third ventricle. (From Escourolle et al.

column1: C04.557.470.670.380.080*D001254*Astrocytoma*Neoplasms of the brain and spinal cord derived from glial cells which vary from histologically benign forms to highly anaplastic and malignant tumors. Fibrillary astrocytomas are the most common type and may be classified in order of increasing malignancy (grades I through IV). In the first two decades of life
column2: astrocytomas tend to originate in the cerebellar hemispheres; in adults
column3: they most frequently arise in the cerebrum and frequently undergo malignant transformation. (From Devita et al.
column4: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column1: C04.557.470.670.380.080.335*D005909*Glioblastoma*A malignant form of astrocytoma histologically characterized by pleomorphism of cells
column2: nuclear atypia
column4: and necrosis. They may arise in any region of the central nervous system
column5: with a predilection for the cerebral hemispheres
column7: and commissural pathways. Clinical presentation most frequently occurs in the fifth or sixth decade of life with focal neurologic signs or seizures.

column1: C04.557.470.670.380.290*D004806*Ependymoma*Glioma derived from EPENDYMOGLIAL CELLS that tend to present as malignant intracranial tumors in children and as benign intraspinal neoplasms in adults. It may arise from any level of the ventricular system or central canal of the spinal cord. Intracranial ependymomas most frequently originate in the FOURTH VENTRICLE and histologically are densely cellular tumors which may contain ependymal tubules and perivascular pseudorosettes. Spinal ependymomas are usually benign papillary or myxopapillary tumors. (From DeVita et al.
column2: Principles and Practice of Oncology
Subependymal*Rare
column5: often asymptomatic and discovered incidentally. The tumors are classified histologically as ependymomas and demonstrate a proliferation of subependymal fibrillary astrocytes among the ependymal tumor cells. (From Clin Neurol Neurosurg 1997 Feb;99(1):17-22)

column1: C04.557.470.670.380.350*D018303*Ganglioglioma*Rare indolent tumors comprised of neoplastic glial and neuronal cells which occur primarily in children and young adults. Benign lesions tend to be associated with long survival unless the tumor degenerates into a histologically malignant form. They tend to occur in the optic nerve and white matter of the brain and spinal cord.
C04.557.470.670.380.400*D018316*Gliosarcoma*Rare mixed tumors of the brain and rarely the spinal cord which contain malignant neuroectodermal (glial) and mesenchymal components
column2: including spindle-shaped fibrosarcoma cells. These tumors are highly aggressive and present primarily in adults as rapidly expanding mass lesions. They may arise in tissue that has been previously irradiated. (From Br J Neurosurg 1995 Apr;9(2):171-8)

column1: C04.557.470.670.380.515*D008527*Medulloblastoma*A malignant neoplasm that may be classified either as a glioma or as a primitive neuroectodermal tumor of childhood (see NEUROECTODERMAL TUMOR
column2: PRIMITIVE). The tumor occurs most frequently in the first decade of life with the most typical location being the cerebellar vermis. Histologic features include a high degree of cellularity
column4: and a tendency for the cells to organize into sheets or form rosettes. Medulloblastoma have a high propensity to spread throughout the craniospinal intradural axis. (From DeVita et al.
column5: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column1: C04.557.470.670.380.590*D009837*Oligodendroglioma*A relatively slow-growing glioma that is derived from oligodendrocytes and tends to occur in the cerebral hemispheres
column2: thalamus
column3: or lateral ventricle. They may present at any age
column4: but are most frequent in the third to fifth decades
column5: with an earlier incidence peak in the first decade. Histologically
column8: and tend to form cysts and microcalcifications. Neoplastic cells tend to have small round nuclei surrounded by unstained nuclei. The tumors may vary from well-differentiated to highly anaplastic forms. (From DeVita et al.

column1: C04.557.470.670.380.795*D020339*Optic Nerve Glioma*Glial cell derived tumors arising from the optic nerve

column1: C04.557.470.670.580*D018306*Neurocytoma*A benign brain tumor composed of neural elements which most often arise from the SEPTUM PELLUCIDUM and the walls of the lateral ventricles. Immunohistochemistry and electron microscopy evaluations may reveal expression of neuron specific enolase and synaptophysin and cells containing microtubuli
column2: neurosecretory granules
column3: and presynaptic vesicles. (From Acta Med Port 1994 Feb;7(2):113-9)

column1: C04.557.470.670.590*D018242*Neuroectodermal Tumors
column2: Primitive*A group of malignant tumors of the nervous system that feature primitive cells with elements of neuronal and/or glial differentiation. Use of this term is limited by some authors to central nervous system tumors and others include neoplasms of similar origin which arise extracranially (i.e.

column6: these tumors arise in the first decade of life and tend to be highly malignant. (From DeVita et al.
column7: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column1: C04.557.470.670.590.500*D008527*Medulloblastoma*A malignant neoplasm that may be classified either as a glioma or as a primitive neuroectodermal tumor of childhood (see NEUROECTODERMAL TUMOR

column2: Primitive
column3: Peripheral*A group of highly cellular primitive round cell neoplasms which occur extracranially in soft tissue and bone and are derived from embryonal neural crest cells. These tumors occur primarily in children and adolescents and share a number of characteristics with EWING SARCOMA.

column1: C04.557.470.670.590.650.550*D009447*Neuroblastoma*A common neoplasm of early childhood arising from neural crest cells in the sympathetic nervous system
column2: and characterized by diverse clinical behavior
column3: ranging from spontaneous remission to rapid metastatic progression and death. This tumor is the most common intraabdominal malignancy of childhood

column6: or rarely occur in the central nervous system. Histologic features include uniform round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei arranged in nests and separated by fibrovascular septa. Neuroblastomas may be associated with the opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome. (From DeVita et al.

column2: Olfactory*A malignant olfactory neuroblastoma arising from the olfactory epithelium of the superior nasal cavity and cribriform plate. It is uncommon (3% of nasal tumors) and rarely is associated with the production of excess hormones (e.g.

column1: C04.557.470.670.590.650.550.300*D018305*Ganglioneuroblastoma*A moderately malignant neoplasm composed of primitive neuroectodermal cells dispersed in myxomatous or fibrous stroma intermixed with mature ganglion cells. It may undergo transformation into a neuroblastoma. It arises from the sympathetic trunk or less frequently from the adrenal medulla

column1: C04.557.470.670.657*D010871*Pinealoma*Neoplasms which originate from pineal parenchymal cells that tend to enlarge the gland and be locally invasive. The two major forms are pineocytoma and the more malignant pineoblastoma. Pineocytomas have moderate cellularity and tend to form rosette patterns. Pineoblastomas are highly cellular tumors containing small
column2: poorly differentiated cells. These tumors occasionally seed the neuroaxis or cause obstructive HYDROCEPHALUS or Parinaud's syndrome. GERMINOMA; CARCINOMA

column1: C04.557.470.670.725*D012175*Retinoblastoma*A malignant tumor arising from the nuclear layer of the retina that is the most common primary tumor of the eye in children. The tumor tends to occur in early childhood or infancy and may be present at birth. The majority are sporadic

Inverted*A mucosal tumor of the urinary bladder or nasal cavity in which proliferating epithelium is invaginated beneath the surface and is more smoothly rounded than in other papillomas. (Stedman

column3: not neoplasms located in the ovaries or testes. Gonadal tissues include GERM CELLS

column1: C04.557.475.395*D018238*Gonadoblastoma*A complex neoplasm composed of a mixture of gonadal elements

column3: immature SERTOLI CELLS or GRANULOSA CELLS of the sex cord
column4: and gonadal stromal cells. Gonadoblastomas are most often associated with gonadal dysgenesis

column1: C04.557.475.750*D018312*Sex Cord-Gonadal Stromal Tumors*Neoplasms derived from the primitive sex cord or gonadal stromal cells of the embryonic GONADS. They are classified by their presumed histogenesis and differentiation. From the sex cord
column2: there are SERTOLI CELL TUMOR and GRANULOSA CELL TUMOR; from the gonadal stroma
column3: LEYDIG CELL TUMOR and THECOMA. These tumors may be identified in either the OVARY or the TESTIS.

column1: C04.557.475.750.656*D006106*Granulosa Cell Tumor*A neoplasm composed entirely of GRANULOSA CELLS
column2: occurring mostly in the OVARY. In the adult form
column3: it may contain some THECA CELLS. This tumor often produces ESTRADIOL and INHIBIN. The excess estrogen exposure can lead to other malignancies in women and PRECOCIOUS PUBERTY in girls. In rare cases
column4: granulosa cell tumors have been identified in the TESTES.

column1: C04.557.475.750.751*D018311*Luteoma*An ovarian neoplasm composed of LUTEAL CELLS derived from luteinized GRANULOSA CELLS and THECA CELLS. Luteomas respond to GONADOTROPINS
column2: and vary in their hormone production (PROGESTERONE; ESTROGENS; or ANDROGENS). During PREGNANCY
column3: a transient type of luteoma may develop due to an exaggerated LUTEINIZATION of the OVARY.

column1: C04.557.475.750.847*D018310*Sertoli-Leydig Cell Tumor*A sex cord-gonadal stromal tumor consists of LEYDIG CELLS; SERTOLI CELLS; and FIBROBLASTS in varying proportions and degree of differentiation. Most such tumors produce ANDROGENS in the Leydig cells
column2: formerly known as androblastoma or arrhenoblastoma. Androblastomas occur in the TESTIS or the OVARY causing precocious masculinization in the males
column4: or virilization (VIRILISM) in the females. In some cases

column1: C04.557.475.750.847.249*D007984*Leydig Cell Tumor*Gonadal interstitial or stromal cell neoplasm composed of only LEYDIG CELLS. These tumors may produce one or more of the steroid hormones such as ANDROGENS; ESTROGENS; and CORTICOSTEROIDS. Clinical symptoms include testicular swelling
column2: GYNECOMASTIA

column1: C04.557.475.750.847.500*D012707*Sertoli Cell Tumor*Gonadal neoplasm composed entirely of SERTOLI CELLS or may have a component of GRANULOSA CELLS. Some of the Sertoli cell tumors produce ESTROGEN or ANDROGENS
column2: but seldom in sufficient quantity to cause clinical symptoms such as FEMINIZATION or masculinization (VIRILISM).

column1: C04.557.475.750.875*D013798*Thecoma*A gonadal stromal neoplasm composed only of THECA CELLS
column2: occurring mostly in the postmenopausal OVARY. It is filled with lipid-containing spindle cells and produces ESTROGENS that can lead to ENDOMETRIAL HYPERPLASIA; UTERINE HEMORRHAGE; or other malignancies in postmenopausal women and sexual precocity in girls. When tumors containing theca cells also contain FIBROBLASTS
column3: they are identified as thecoma-fibroma tumors with less active hormone production.

column2: Nerve Tissue*Neoplasms composed of nerve tissue. This concept does not refer to neoplasms located in the nervous system or its component nerves.

column1: C04.557.580.520*D008579*Meningioma*A relatively common neoplasm of the CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM that arises from arachnoidal cells. The majority are well differentiated vascular tumors which grow slowly and have a low potential to be invasive
column2: although malignant subtypes occur. Meningiomas have a predilection to arise from the parasagittal region
column6: and SPINAL CANAL. (From DeVita et al.
column7: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column1: C04.557.580.600*D018317*Nerve Sheath Neoplasms*Neoplasms which arise from nerve sheaths formed by SCHWANN CELLS in the PERIPHERAL NERVOUS SYSTEM or by OLIGODENDROCYTES in the CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM. Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors
column2: NEUROFIBROMA
column3: and NEURILEMMOMA are relatively common tumors in this category.

column1: C04.557.580.600.580*D009455*Neurofibroma*A moderately firm
column2: benign
column3: encapsulated tumor resulting from proliferation of SCHWANN CELLS and FIBROBLASTS that includes portions of nerve fibers. The tumors usually develop along peripheral or cranial nerves and are a central feature of NEUROFIBROMATOSIS 1
column4: where they may occur intracranially or involve spinal roots. Pathologic features include fusiform enlargement of the involved nerve. Microscopic examination reveals a disorganized and loose cellular pattern with elongated nuclei intermixed with fibrous strands. (From Adams et al.

column2: Plexiform*A type of neurofibroma manifesting as a diffuse overgrowth of subcutaneous tissue
column6: and chest but occasionally occurring in the abdomen or pelvis. The tumors tend to progress
column7: and may extend along nerve roots to eventually involve the spinal roots and spinal cord. This process is almost always a manifestation of NEUROFIBROMATOSIS 1. (From Adams et al.

column1: C04.557.580.600.580.590*D017253*Neurofibromatoses*A group of disorders characterized by an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance with high rates of spontaneous mutation and multiple neurofibromas or neurilemmomas. NEUROFIBROMATOSIS 1 (generalized neurofibromatosis) accounts for approximately 95% of cases
column2: although multiple additional subtypes (e.g.
column5: etc.) have been described. (From Neurochirurgie 1998 Nov;44(4):267-72)

column1: C04.557.580.600.580.590.650*D009456*Neurofibromatosis 1*An autosomal dominant inherited disorder (with a high frequency of spontaneous mutations) that features developmental changes in the nervous system
column2: muscles
column5: most notably in tissue derived from the embryonic NEURAL CREST. Multiple hyperpigmented skin lesions and subcutaneous tumors are the hallmark of this disease. Peripheral and central nervous system neoplasms occur frequently
column6: especially OPTIC NERVE GLIOMA and NEUROFIBROSARCOMA. NF1 is caused by mutations which inactivate the NF1 gene (GENES
column7: NEUROFIBROMATOSIS 1) on chromosome 17q. The incidence of learning disabilities is also elevated in this condition. (From Adams et al.
column10: pp1014-18) There is overlap of clinical features with NOONAN SYNDROME in a syndrome called neurofibromatosis-Noonan syndrome. Both the PTPN11 and NF1 gene products are involved in the SIGNAL TRANSDUCTION pathway of Ras (RAS PROTEINS).

column1: C04.557.580.600.580.590.655*D016518*Neurofibromatosis 2*An autosomal dominant disorder characterized by a high incidence of bilateral acoustic neuromas as well as schwannomas (NEURILEMMOMA) of other cranial and peripheral nerves
column2: and other benign intracranial tumors including meningiomas
column5: and gliomas. The disease has been linked to mutations of the NF2 gene (GENES
column6: NEUROFIBROMATOSIS 2) on chromosome 22 (22q12) and usually presents clinically in the first or second decade of life.

column1: C04.557.580.600.580.795*D018319*Neurofibrosarcoma*A malignant tumor that arises from small cutaneous nerves
column2: is locally aggressive
column3: and has a potential for metastasis. Characteristic histopathologic features include proliferating atypical spindle cells with slender wavy and pointed nuclei
column5: and areas featuring organized whorls of fibroblastic proliferation. The most common primary sites are the extremities
column7: and trunk. These tumors tend to present in childhood
column8: often in association with NEUROFIBROMATOSIS 1. (From DeVita et al.

column1: C04.557.580.600.610*D009463*Neuroma*A tumor made up of nerve cells and nerve fibers. (Dorland
column2: 27th ed)

column1: C04.557.580.600.610.595*D009442*Neurilemmoma*A neoplasm that arises from SCHWANN CELLS of the cranial
column2: peripheral
column4: these tumors may present as a cranial neuropathy
column7: or with spinal cord compression. Histologically
column10: and composed of a homogenous pattern of biphasic fusiform-shaped cells that may have a palisaded appearance. (From DeVita Jr et al.
column11: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column2: Acoustic*A benign SCHWANNOMA of the eighth cranial nerve (VESTIBULOCOCHLEAR NERVE)
column3: mostly arising from the vestibular branch (VESTIBULAR NERVE) during the fifth or sixth decade of life. Clinical manifestations include HEARING LOSS; HEADACHE; VERTIGO; TINNITUS; and FACIAL PAIN. Bilateral acoustic neuromas are associated with NEUROFIBROMATOSIS 2. (From Adams et al.

column1: C04.557.580.600.610.595.610.500*D016518*Neurofibromatosis 2*An autosomal dominant disorder characterized by a high incidence of bilateral acoustic neuromas as well as schwannomas (NEURILEMMOMA) of other cranial and peripheral nerves
column2: and other benign intracranial tumors including meningiomas
column5: and gliomas. The disease has been linked to mutations of the NF2 gene (GENES
column6: NEUROFIBROMATOSIS 2) on chromosome 22 (22q12) and usually presents clinically in the first or second decade of life.

column1: C04.557.580.600.625*D018321*Neurothekeoma*A benign myxoma of cutaneous nerve sheath origin. Theke is from the Greek theke
column2: sheath. (From Stedman

column1: C04.557.580.625*D017599*Neuroectodermal Tumors*Malignant neoplasms arising in the neuroectoderm
column2: the portion of the ectoderm of the early embryo that gives rise to the central and peripheral nervous systems

column1: C04.557.580.625.200*D003397*Craniopharyngioma*A benign pituitary-region neoplasm that originates from Rathke's pouch. The two major histologic and clinical subtypes are adamantinous (or classical) craniopharyngioma and papillary craniopharyngioma. The adamantinous form presents in children and adolescents as an expanding cystic lesion in the pituitary region. The cystic cavity is filled with a black viscous substance and histologically the tumor is composed of adamantinomatous epithelium and areas of calcification and necrosis. Papillary craniopharyngiomas occur in adults
column2: and histologically feature a squamous epithelium with papillations. (From Joynt
Neuroepithelial*Neoplasms composed of neuroepithelial cells
column3: which have the capacity to differentiate into NEURONS
column5: and ASTROCYTES. The majority of craniospinal tumors are of neuroepithelial origin. (From Dev Biol 1998 Aug 1;200(1):1-5)

column1: C04.557.580.625.600.355*D005729*Ganglioneuroma*A benign neoplasm that usually arises from the sympathetic trunk in the mediastinum. Histologic features include spindle cell proliferation (resembling a neurofibroma) and the presence of large ganglion cells. The tumor may present clinically with HORNER SYNDROME or diarrhea due to ectopic production of vasoactive intestinal peptide. (From DeVita et al.
column2: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column1: C04.557.580.625.600.380*D005910*Glioma*Benign and malignant central nervous system neoplasms derived from glial cells (i.e.
column2: astrocytes
column4: and ependymocytes). Astrocytes may give rise to astrocytomas (ASTROCYTOMA) or glioblastoma multiforme (see GLIOBLASTOMA). Oligodendrocytes give rise to oligodendrogliomas (OLIGODENDROGLIOMA) and ependymocytes may undergo transformation to become EPENDYMOMA; CHOROID PLEXUS NEOPLASMS; or colloid cysts of the third ventricle. (From Escourolle et al.

column1: C04.557.580.625.600.380.080*D001254*Astrocytoma*Neoplasms of the brain and spinal cord derived from glial cells which vary from histologically benign forms to highly anaplastic and malignant tumors. Fibrillary astrocytomas are the most common type and may be classified in order of increasing malignancy (grades I through IV). In the first two decades of life
column2: astrocytomas tend to originate in the cerebellar hemispheres; in adults
column3: they most frequently arise in the cerebrum and frequently undergo malignant transformation. (From Devita et al.
column4: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column1: C04.557.580.625.600.380.080.335*D005909*Glioblastoma*A malignant form of astrocytoma histologically characterized by pleomorphism of cells
column2: nuclear atypia
column4: and necrosis. They may arise in any region of the central nervous system
column5: with a predilection for the cerebral hemispheres
column7: and commissural pathways. Clinical presentation most frequently occurs in the fifth or sixth decade of life with focal neurologic signs or seizures.

column1: C04.557.580.625.600.380.290*D004806*Ependymoma*Glioma derived from EPENDYMOGLIAL CELLS that tend to present as malignant intracranial tumors in children and as benign intraspinal neoplasms in adults. It may arise from any level of the ventricular system or central canal of the spinal cord. Intracranial ependymomas most frequently originate in the FOURTH VENTRICLE and histologically are densely cellular tumors which may contain ependymal tubules and perivascular pseudorosettes. Spinal ependymomas are usually benign papillary or myxopapillary tumors. (From DeVita et al.
column2: Principles and Practice of Oncology
Subependymal*Rare
column5: often asymptomatic and discovered incidentally. The tumors are classified histologically as ependymomas and demonstrate a proliferation of subependymal fibrillary astrocytes among the ependymal tumor cells. (From Clin Neurol Neurosurg 1997 Feb;99(1):17-22)

column1: C04.557.580.625.600.380.350*D018303*Ganglioglioma*Rare indolent tumors comprised of neoplastic glial and neuronal cells which occur primarily in children and young adults. Benign lesions tend to be associated with long survival unless the tumor degenerates into a histologically malignant form. They tend to occur in the optic nerve and white matter of the brain and spinal cord.
C04.557.580.625.600.380.400*D018316*Gliosarcoma*Rare mixed tumors of the brain and rarely the spinal cord which contain malignant neuroectodermal (glial) and mesenchymal components
column2: including spindle-shaped fibrosarcoma cells. These tumors are highly aggressive and present primarily in adults as rapidly expanding mass lesions. They may arise in tissue that has been previously irradiated. (From Br J Neurosurg 1995 Apr;9(2):171-8)

column1: C04.557.580.625.600.380.515*D008527*Medulloblastoma*A malignant neoplasm that may be classified either as a glioma or as a primitive neuroectodermal tumor of childhood (see NEUROECTODERMAL TUMOR
column2: PRIMITIVE). The tumor occurs most frequently in the first decade of life with the most typical location being the cerebellar vermis. Histologic features include a high degree of cellularity
column4: and a tendency for the cells to organize into sheets or form rosettes. Medulloblastoma have a high propensity to spread throughout the craniospinal intradural axis. (From DeVita et al.
column5: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column1: C04.557.580.625.600.380.590*D009837*Oligodendroglioma*A relatively slow-growing glioma that is derived from oligodendrocytes and tends to occur in the cerebral hemispheres
column2: thalamus
column3: or lateral ventricle. They may present at any age
column4: but are most frequent in the third to fifth decades
column5: with an earlier incidence peak in the first decade. Histologically
column8: and tend to form cysts and microcalcifications. Neoplastic cells tend to have small round nuclei surrounded by unstained nuclei. The tumors may vary from well-differentiated to highly anaplastic forms. (From DeVita et al.
column9: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column1: C04.557.580.625.600.380.795*D020339*Optic Nerve Glioma*Glial cell derived tumors arising from the optic nerve
column2: usually presenting in childhood.

column1: C04.557.580.625.600.580*D018306*Neurocytoma*A benign brain tumor composed of neural elements which most often arise from the SEPTUM PELLUCIDUM and the walls of the lateral ventricles. Immunohistochemistry and electron microscopy evaluations may reveal expression of neuron specific enolase and synaptophysin and cells containing microtubuli
column2: neurosecretory granules
column3: and presynaptic vesicles. (From Acta Med Port 1994 Feb;7(2):113-9)

column1: C04.557.580.625.600.590*D018242*Neuroectodermal Tumors
column2: Primitive*A group of malignant tumors of the nervous system that feature primitive cells with elements of neuronal and/or glial differentiation. Use of this term is limited by some authors to central nervous system tumors and others include neoplasms of similar origin which arise extracranially (i.e.
column5: PERIPHERAL). This term is also occasionally used as a synonym for MEDULLOBLASTOMA. In general
column6: these tumors arise in the first decade of life and tend to be highly malignant. (From DeVita et al.
column7: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column1: C04.557.580.625.600.590.500*D008527*Medulloblastoma*A malignant neoplasm that may be classified either as a glioma or as a primitive neuroectodermal tumor of childhood (see NEUROECTODERMAL TUMOR
column2: PRIMITIVE). The tumor occurs most frequently in the first decade of life with the most typical location being the cerebellar vermis. Histologic features include a high degree of cellularity
column4: and a tendency for the cells to organize into sheets or form rosettes. Medulloblastoma have a high propensity to spread throughout the craniospinal intradural axis. (From DeVita et al.
column5: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column1: C04.557.580.625.600.590.650*D018241*Neuroectodermal Tumors
column2: Primitive
column3: Peripheral*A group of highly cellular primitive round cell neoplasms which occur extracranially in soft tissue and bone and are derived from embryonal neural crest cells. These tumors occur primarily in children and adolescents and share a number of characteristics with EWING SARCOMA.

column1: C04.557.580.625.600.590.650.550*D009447*Neuroblastoma*A common neoplasm of early childhood arising from neural crest cells in the sympathetic nervous system
column2: and characterized by diverse clinical behavior
column3: ranging from spontaneous remission to rapid metastatic progression and death. This tumor is the most common intraabdominal malignancy of childhood
column4: but it may also arise from thorax
column6: or rarely occur in the central nervous system. Histologic features include uniform round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei arranged in nests and separated by fibrovascular septa. Neuroblastomas may be associated with the opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome. (From DeVita et al.

column2: Olfactory*A malignant olfactory neuroblastoma arising from the olfactory epithelium of the superior nasal cavity and cribriform plate. It is uncommon (3% of nasal tumors) and rarely is associated with the production of excess hormones (e.g.
column4: Cushing Syndrome). It has a high propensity for multiple local recurrences and bony metastases. (From Holland et al.

column1: C04.557.580.625.600.590.650.550.300*D018305*Ganglioneuroblastoma*A moderately malignant neoplasm composed of primitive neuroectodermal cells dispersed in myxomatous or fibrous stroma intermixed with mature ganglion cells. It may undergo transformation into a neuroblastoma. It arises from the sympathetic trunk or less frequently from the adrenal medulla

column3: and other locations. Cervical ganglioneuroblastomas may be associated with HORNER SYNDROME and the tumor may occasionally secrete vasoactive intestinal peptide

column1: C04.557.580.625.600.657*D010871*Pinealoma*Neoplasms which originate from pineal parenchymal cells that tend to enlarge the gland and be locally invasive. The two major forms are pineocytoma and the more malignant pineoblastoma. Pineocytomas have moderate cellularity and tend to form rosette patterns. Pineoblastomas are highly cellular tumors containing small
column2: poorly differentiated cells. These tumors occasionally seed the neuroaxis or cause obstructive HYDROCEPHALUS or Parinaud's syndrome. GERMINOMA; CARCINOMA
column3: EMBRYONAL; GLIOMA; and other neoplasms may arise in the pineal region with germinoma being the most common pineal region tumor. (From DeVita et al.
column4: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column1: C04.557.580.625.600.725*D012175*Retinoblastoma*A malignant tumor arising from the nuclear layer of the retina that is the most common primary tumor of the eye in children. The tumor tends to occur in early childhood or infancy and may be present at birth. The majority are sporadic
column2: but the condition may be transmitted as an autosomal dominant trait. Histologic features include dense cellularity
column4: and areas of calcification and necrosis. An abnormal pupil reflex (leukokoria); NYSTAGMUS
column5: PATHOLOGIC; STRABISMUS; and visual loss represent common clinical characteristics of this condition. (From DeVita et al.

column1: C04.557.580.625.650*D018358*Neuroendocrine Tumors*Tumors whose cells possess secretory granules and originate from the neuroectoderm

column3: the cells of the ectoblast or epiblast that program the neuroendocrine system. Common properties across most neuroendocrine tumors include ectopic hormone production (often via APUD CELLS)

column2: Acidophil*A benign tumor

column4: whose cells stain with acid dyes. Such pituitary tumors may give rise to excessive secretion of growth hormone
column5: resulting in gigantism or acromegaly. A specific type of acidophil adenoma may give rise to nonpuerperal galactorrhea. (Dorland

column2: Basophil*A small tumor of the anterior lobe of the pituitary gland whose cells stain with basic dyes. It may give rise to excessive secretion of ACTH
Chromophobe*A benign tumor of the anterior pituitary in which the cells do not stain with acidic or basic dyes.

column1: C04.557.580.625.650.135*D001079*Apudoma*A general term collectively applied to tumors associated with the APUD CELLS series

column1: C04.557.580.625.650.200*D002276*Carcinoid Tumor*A usually small

column4: or spindle-shaped cells of medium size
column6: and covered by intact mucosa with a yellow cut surface. The tumor can occur anywhere in the gastrointestinal tract (and in the lungs and other sites); approximately 90% arise in the appendix. It is now established that these tumors are of neuroendocrine origin and derive from a primitive stem cell. (From Stedman

column1: C04.557.580.625.650.200.500*D008303*Malignant Carcinoid Syndrome*A symptom complex associated with CARCINOID TUMOR and characterized by attacks of severe flushing of the skin
column2: diarrheal watery stools
column6: and ascites. The carcinoid tumors are usually located in the gastrointestinal tract and metastasize to the liver. Symptoms are caused by tumor secretion of serotonin
column8: and other biologically active substances. Cardiac manifestations constitute CARCINOID HEART DISEASE. (Dorland

column1: C04.557.580.625.650.200.500.205*D002275*Carcinoid Heart Disease*Cardiac manifestation of gastrointestinal CARCINOID TUMOR that metastasizes to the liver. Substances secreted by the tumor cells
column2: including SEROTONIN
column3: promote fibrous plaque formation in ENDOCARDIUM and its underlying layers. These deposits cause distortion of the TRICUSPID VALVE and the PULMONARY VALVE eventually leading to STENOSIS and valve regurgitation.

column2: Neuroendocrine*A group of carcinomas which share a characteristic morphology
column3: often being composed of clusters and trabecular sheets of round blue cells
column5: and an attenuated rim of poorly demarcated cytoplasm. Neuroendocrine tumors include carcinoids
column11: and pheochromocytoma. Neurosecretory granules are found within the tumor cells. (Segen

column2: Medullary*A carcinoma composed mainly of epithelial elements with little or no stroma. Medullary carcinomas of the breast constitute 5%-7% of all mammary carcinomas; medullary carcinomas of the thyroid comprise 3%-10% of all thyroid malignancies. (From Dorland

Merkel Cell*A carcinoma arising from MERKEL CELLS located in the basal layer of the epidermis and occurring most commonly as a primary neuroendocrine carcinoma of the skin. Merkel cells are tactile cells of neuroectodermal origin and histologically show neurosecretory granules. The skin of the head and neck are a common site of Merkel cell carcinoma
column3: occurring generally in elderly patients. (Holland et al.

column1: C04.557.580.625.650.510*D008545*Melanoma*A malignant neoplasm derived from cells that are capable of forming melanin
column2: which may occur in the skin of any part of the body
column6: in the mucous membranes of the genitalia
column9: or other sites. It occurs mostly in adults and may originate de novo or from a pigmented nevus or malignant lentigo. Melanomas frequently metastasize widely
column13: and brain are likely to be involved. The incidence of malignant skin melanomas is rising rapidly in all parts of the world. (Stedman

column1: C04.557.580.625.650.510.385*D018327*Hutchinson's Melanotic Freckle*A cellular subtype of malignant melanoma. It is a pigmented lesion composed of melanocytes occurring on sun-exposed skin
column2: usually the face and neck. The melanocytes are commonly multinucleated with a starburst appearance. It is considered by many to be the in situ phase of lentigo maligna melanoma.
Amelanotic*An unpigmented malignant melanoma. It is an anaplastic melanoma consisting of cells derived from melanoblasts but not forming melanin. (Dorland
Experimental*Experimentally induced tumor that produces MELANIN in animals to provide a model for studying human MELANOMA.

column4: these tumors may present as a cranial neuropathy
column7: or with spinal cord compression. Histologically
column10: and composed of a homogenous pattern of biphasic fusiform-shaped cells that may have a palisaded appearance. (From DeVita Jr et al.

column2: Acoustic*A benign SCHWANNOMA of the eighth cranial nerve (VESTIBULOCOCHLEAR NERVE)

column1: C04.557.580.625.650.700*D010235*Paraganglioma*A neural crest tumor usually derived from the chromoreceptor tissue of a paraganglion

It consists histologically of rounded or ovoid hyperchromatic cells that tend to be grouped in an alveolus-like pattern within a scant to moderate amount of fibrous stroma and a few large thin-walled vascular channels. column1: C04.557.580.625.650.700.705.220*D002345*Carotid Body Tumor*Benign paraganglioma at the bifurcation of the COMMON CAROTID ARTERIES. It can encroach on the parapharyngeal space and produce dysphagia

column14: and paresthesias of the extremities. The incidence of malignancy is as low as 5% but the pathologic distinction between benign and malignant pheochromocytomas is not clear. (Dorland

column2: Plasma Cell*Neoplasms associated with a proliferation of a single clone of PLASMA CELLS and characterized by the secretion of PARAPROTEINS.

column1: C04.557.595.500*D009101*Multiple Myeloma*A malignancy of mature PLASMA CELLS engaging in monoclonal immunoglobulin production. It is characterized by hyperglobulinemia
column2: excess Bence-Jones proteins (free monoclonal IMMUNOGLOBULIN LIGHT CHAINS) in the urine
column5: and fractures. Other features include ANEMIA; HYPERCALCEMIA; and RENAL INSUFFICIENCY.

column2: Plasma Cell*A rare
column3: aggressive variant of MULTIPLE MYELOMA characterized by the circulation of excessive PLASMA CELLS in the peripheral blood. It can be a primary manifestation of multiple myeloma or develop as a terminal complication during the disease.

column1: C04.557.595.600*D010954*Plasmacytoma*Any discrete
column2: presumably solitary
column3: mass of neoplastic PLASMA CELLS either in BONE MARROW or various extramedullary sites.

column1: C04.557.595.925*D008258*Waldenstrom Macroglobulinemia*A lymphoproliferative disorder characterized by pleomorphic B-LYMPHOCYTES including PLASMA CELLS
column2: with increased levels of monoclonal serum IMMUNOGLOBULIN M. There is lymphoplasmacytic cells infiltration into bone marrow and often other tissues
column3: also known as lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma. Clinical features include ANEMIA; HEMORRHAGES; and hyperviscosity.

column2: Vascular Tissue*Neoplasms composed of vascular tissue. This concept does not refer to neoplasms located in blood vessels.

column1: C04.557.645.100*D018322*Angiofibroma*A benign neoplasm of fibrous tissue in which there are numerous small and large
column2: frequently dilated

column1: C04.557.645.115*D000794*Angiokeratoma*A vascular
column2: horny neoplasm of the skin characterized by TELANGIECTASIS and secondary epithelial changes including acanthosis and hyperkeratosis.

column1: C04.557.645.350*D005918*Glomus Tumor*A blue-red
column2: extremely painful vascular neoplasm involving a glomeriform arteriovenous anastomosis (glomus body)
column3: which may be found anywhere in the skin
column4: most often in the distal portion of the fingers and toes
column5: especially beneath the nail. It is composed of specialized pericytes (sometimes termed glomus cells)
column6: usually in single encapsulated nodular masses which may be several millimeters in diameter (From Stedman
column8: a tumor of NEURAL CREST origin
column9: is also sometimes called a glomus tumor.

column1: C04.557.645.375*D006391*Hemangioma*A vascular anomaly due to proliferation of BLOOD VESSELS that forms a tumor-like mass. The common types involve CAPILLARIES and VEINS. It can occur anywhere in the body but is most frequently noticed in the SKIN and SUBCUTANEOUS TISSUE. (from Stedman
column2: 27th ed

column1: C04.557.645.375.185*D020787*Central Nervous System Venous Angioma*A vascular anomaly characterized by a radial or wedge-shaped arrangement of dilated VEINS draining into a larger vein in the brain
column2: spinal cord
column3: or the meninges. Veins in a venous angioma are surrounded by normal nervous tissue
column4: unlike a CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM CAVERNOUS HEMANGIOMA that lacks intervening nervous tissue. Drainage of venous angioma is fully integrated with the body's venous system
column6: in most cases there is no clinical signs and rare bleeding.

column1: C04.557.645.375.370*D006390*Hemangioendothelioma*A neoplasm derived from blood vessels
column2: characterized by numerous prominent endothelial cells that occur singly
column4: and as the lining of congeries of vascular tubes or channels. Hemangioendotheliomas are relatively rare and are of intermediate malignancy (between benign hemangiomas and conventional angiosarcomas). They affect men and women about equally and rarely develop in childhood. (From Stedman

column1: C04.557.645.375.370.380*D018323*Hemangioendothelioma
column2: Epithelioid*A tumor of medium-to-large veins
column3: composed of plump-to-spindled endothelial cells that bulge into vascular spaces in a tombstone-like fashion. These tumors are thought to have borderline aggression
column5: but only rarely metastasize. It is unclear whether the epithelioid hemangioendothelioma is truly neoplastic or an exuberant tissue reaction
column6: nor is it clear if this is equivalent to Kimura's disease (see ANGIOLYMPHOID HYPERPLASIA WITH EOSINOPHILIA). (Segen

column2: Capillary*A dull red
column6: usually located on the head and neck
column7: which grows rapidly and generally undergoes regression and involution without scarring. It is caused by proliferation of immature capillary vessels in active stroma
column8: and is usually present at birth or occurs within the first two or three months of life. (Dorland

column1: C04.557.645.375.380.370*D018325*Hemangioblastoma*A benign tumor of the nervous system that may occur sporadically or in association with VON HIPPEL-LINDAU DISEASE. It accounts for approximately 2% of intracranial tumors
column2: arising most frequently in the cerebellar hemispheres and vermis. Histologically
column3: the tumors are composed of multiple capillary and sinusoidal channels lined with endothelial cells and clusters of lipid-laden pseudoxanthoma cells. Usually solitary
column4: these tumors can be multiple and may also occur in the brain stem
column7: and supratentorial compartment. Cerebellar hemangioblastomas usually present in the third decade with INTRACRANIAL HYPERTENSION
column9: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column2: Cavernous*A vascular anomaly that is a collection of tortuous BLOOD VESSELS and connective tissue. This tumor-like mass with the large vascular space is filled with blood and usually appears as a strawberry-like lesion in the subcutaneous areas of the face
column4: or other regions of the body including the central nervous system.

column2: Cavernous
column3: Central Nervous System*A vascular anomaly composed of a collection of large
column4: thin walled tortuous VEINS that can occur in any part of the central nervous system but lack intervening nervous tissue. Familial occurrence is common and has been associated with a number of genes mapped to 7q
column5: 7p and 3q. Clinical features include SEIZURES; HEADACHE; STROKE; and progressive neurological deficit.

column1: C04.557.645.375.617*D059885*Kasabach-Merritt Syndrome*Rapidly growing vascular lesion along the midline axis of the neck
column2: upper trunk
column3: and extremities that is characterized by CONSUMPTION COAGULOPATHY; THROMBOCYTOPENIA; and HEMOLYTIC ANEMIA. It is often associated with infantile Kaposiform HEMANGIOENDOTHELIOMA and other vascular tumors such as tufted ANGIOMA.

column1: C04.557.645.375.850*D013341*Sturge-Weber Syndrome*A non-inherited congenital condition with vascular and neurological abnormalities. It is characterized by facial vascular nevi (PORT-WINE STAIN)
column2: and capillary angiomatosis of intracranial membranes (MENINGES; CHOROID). Neurological features include EPILEPSY; cognitive deficits; GLAUCOMA; and visual defects.

column1: C04.557.645.380*D006393*Hemangiopericytoma*A tumor composed of spindle cells with a rich vascular network
column2: which apparently arises from pericytes
column3: cells of smooth muscle origin that lie around small vessels. Benign and malignant hemangiopericytomas exist
column4: and the rarity of these lesions has led to considerable confusion in distinguishing between benign and malignant variants. (From Dorland

column1: C04.557.645.390*D006394*Hemangiosarcoma*A rare malignant neoplasm characterized by rapidly proliferating
column2: extensively infiltrating
column3: anaplastic cells derived from blood vessels and lining irregular blood-filled or lumpy spaces. (Stedman

column1: C04.557.645.520*D008579*Meningioma*A relatively common neoplasm of the CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM that arises from arachnoidal cells. The majority are well differentiated vascular tumors which grow slowly and have a low potential to be invasive
column2: although malignant subtypes occur. Meningiomas have a predilection to arise from the parasagittal region
column6: and SPINAL CANAL. (From DeVita et al.
column7: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column2: Kaposi*A multicentric
column3: malignant neoplastic vascular proliferation characterized by the development of bluish-red cutaneous nodules
column5: most often on the toes or feet
column6: and slowly increasing in size and number and spreading to more proximal areas. The tumors have endothelium-lined channels and vascular spaces admixed with variably sized aggregates of spindle-shaped cells
column7: and often remain confined to the skin and subcutaneous tissue
column8: but widespread visceral involvement may occur. Kaposi's sarcoma occurs spontaneously in Jewish and Italian males in Europe and the United States. An aggressive variant in young children is endemic in some areas of Africa. A third form occurs in about 0.04% of kidney transplant patients. There is also a high incidence in AIDS patients. (From Dorland
column12: pp2105-7) HHV-8 is the suspected cause.

column1: C04.557.665*D018326*Nevi and Melanomas*A collective term for the various types of nevi and melanomas.
C04.557.665.510*D008545*Melanoma*A malignant neoplasm derived from cells that are capable of forming melanin
column2: which may occur in the skin of any part of the body
column6: in the mucous membranes of the genitalia
column9: or other sites. It occurs mostly in adults and may originate de novo or from a pigmented nevus or malignant lentigo. Melanomas frequently metastasize widely
column13: and brain are likely to be involved. The incidence of malignant skin melanomas is rising rapidly in all parts of the world. (Stedman

column1: C04.557.665.510.385*D018327*Hutchinson's Melanotic Freckle*A cellular subtype of malignant melanoma. It is a pigmented lesion composed of melanocytes occurring on sun-exposed skin
column2: usually the face and neck. The melanocytes are commonly multinucleated with a starburst appearance. It is considered by many to be the in situ phase of lentigo maligna melanoma.
Amelanotic*An unpigmented malignant melanoma. It is an anaplastic melanoma consisting of cells derived from melanoblasts but not forming melanin. (Dorland
Experimental*Experimentally induced tumor that produces MELANIN in animals to provide a model for studying human MELANOMA.

column1: C04.557.665.560*D009506*Nevus*A circumscribed stable malformation of the skin and occasionally of the oral mucosa
column2: which is not due to external causes and therefore presumed to be of hereditary origin.

column1: C04.557.665.560.260*D004416*Dysplastic Nevus Syndrome*Clinically atypical nevi (usually exceeding 5 mm in diameter and having variable pigmentation and ill defined borders) with an increased risk for development of non-familial cutaneous malignant melanoma. Biopsies show melanocytic dysplasia. Nevi are clinically and histologically identical to the precursor lesions for melanoma in the B-K mole syndrome. (Stedman
column2: 25th ed)
Halo*A benign skin lesion characterized by a zone of depigmentation surrounding the nevus.
Intradermal*A nevus in which nests of melanocytes are found in the dermis
column3: but not at the epidermal-dermal junction. Benign pigmented nevi in adults are most commonly intradermal. (Stedman

column2: Pigmented*A nevus containing melanin. The term is usually restricted to nevocytic nevi (round or oval collections of melanin-containing nevus cells occurring at the dermoepidermal junction of the skin or in the dermis proper) or moles
column3: but may be applied to other pigmented nevi.

column1: C04.557.665.560.615.530*D049328*Mongolian Spot*A bluish-gray to gray-brown benign
column2: melanocytic nevus found usually in the LUMBOSACRAL REGION of dark-skinned people
column3: especially those of East Asian ancestry. It is usually congenital or appears shortly after birth

column2: Blue*Usually a benign tumor
column3: that commonly presents as a solitary blue nodule with spindled MELANOCYTES covered by smooth SKIN. Several variants have been identified
column4: one variant being malignant. The blue color is caused by large
column5: densely packed melanocytes deep in the DERMIS of the nevus. In CHILDREN
column6: they usually occur on the BUTTOCKS and LUMBOSACRAL REGION and are referred to as cellular blue nevi. Malignant blue nevi are more commonly found on the SCALP.

column1: C04.557.665.560.615.585*D009507*Nevus of Ota*A macular lesion on the side of the FACE
column2: involving the CONJUNCTIVA and EYELIDS
column3: as well as the adjacent facial skin
column4: SCLERA; OCULOMOTOR MUSCLES; and PERIOSTEUM. Histological features vary from those of a MONGOLIAN SPOT to those of a BLUE NEVUS.

column2: Spindle Cell*A form of pigmented nevus showing intense melanocytic activity around the dermo-epidermal junction. Large numbers of spindle-shaped melanocytes proliferate downward toward the dermis and usually a large amount of pigment is present. It was first described in 1976 and the bulk of patients reported have been young females with the lesions presenting on the thighs. (From Rook et al.
Epithelioid and Spindle Cell*A benign compound nevus occurring most often in children before puberty
column3: composed of spindle and epithelioid cells located mainly in the dermis
column4: sometimes in association with large atypical cells and multinucleate cells
column5: and having a close histopathological resemblance to malignant melanoma. The tumor presents as a smooth to slightly scaly
column9: ranging in color from pink-tan to purplish red

column2: Sebaceous of Jadassohn*A syndrome characterized by lesions occurring on the face
column4: or neck which consist of congenital hypoplastic malformations of cutaneous structures and which over time undergo verrucous hyperplasia. Additionally it is associated with neurological symptoms and skeletal

column1: C04.557.695*D009808*Odontogenic Tumors*Neoplasms produced from tooth-forming tissues.

C04.557.695.065*D000564*Ameloblastoma*An immature epithelial tumor of the JAW originating from the epithelial rests of Malassez or from other epithelial remnants of the ENAMEL from the developmental period. It is a slowly growing tumor
column2: usually benign
column3: but displays a marked propensity for invasive growth.

column1: C04.557.695.210*D002485*Cementoma*An odontogenic fibroma in which cells have developed into cementoblasts and which consists largely of cementum.
C04.557.695.605*D018333*Odontogenic Cyst
column2: Calcifying*A mixed radiolucent-radiopaque lesion of the jaws with features of both a cyst and a solid neoplasm. It is characterized microscopically by an epithelial lining showing a palisaded layer of columnar basal cells

column1: C04.557.695.607*D051527*Odontogenic Tumor
column2: Squamous*A well-differentiated
column5: probably arising from the rests of Malassez.

column1: C04.557.695.610*D009810*Odontoma*A mixed tumor of odontogenic origin
column2: in which both the epithelial and mesenchymal cells exhibit complete differentiation
column3: resulting in the formation of tooth structures. (Jablonski

column1: C04.588*D009371*Neoplasms by Site*A collective term for precoordinated organ/neoplasm headings locating neoplasms by organ
column2: as BRAIN NEOPLASMS; DUODENAL NEOPLASMS; LIVER NEOPLASMS; etc.

column1: C04.588.033*D000008*Abdominal Neoplasms*New abnormal growth of tissue in the ABDOMEN.
C04.588.033.513*D010534*Peritoneal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the PERITONEUM.
C04.588.033.731*D012186*Retroperitoneal Neoplasms*New abnormal growth of tissue in the RETROPERITONEAL SPACE.
C04.588.033.740*D058288*Sister Mary Joseph's Nodule*Metastatic lesion of the UMBILICUS associated with intra-abdominal neoplasms especially of the GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT or OVARY.
C04.588.083*D000694*Anal Gland Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the anal gland.
C04.588.149*D001859*Bone Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer located in bone tissue or specific BONES.
C04.588.149.030*D050398*Adamantinoma*A locally aggressive
column2: osteolytic neoplasm of the long bones
column3: probably of epithelial origin and most often involving the TIBIA.

column1: C04.588.149.276*D005266*Femoral Neoplasms*New abnormal growth of tissue in the FEMUR.
C04.588.149.721*D012888*Skull Neoplasms*Neoplasms of the bony part of the skull.
C04.588.149.721.450*D007573*Jaw Neoplasms*Cancers or tumors of the MAXILLA or MANDIBLE unspecified. For neoplasms of the maxilla
column2: MAXILLARY NEOPLASMS is available and of the mandible

column1: C04.588.149.721.450.583*D008339*Mandibular Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the MANDIBLE.
C04.588.149.721.450.601*D008441*Maxillary Neoplasms*Cancer or tumors of the MAXILLA or upper jaw.
C04.588.149.721.450.692*D010157*Palatal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the PALATE
column2: including those of the hard palate

column1: C04.588.149.721.600*D009669*Nose Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the NOSE.
C04.588.149.721.656*D009918*Orbital Neoplasms*Neoplasms of the bony orbit and contents except the eyeball.
C04.588.149.721.828*D019292*Skull Base Neoplasms*Neoplasms of the base of the skull specifically
column2: differentiated from neoplasms of unspecified sites or bones of the skull (SKULL NEOPLASMS).

column1: C04.588.149.828*D013125*Spinal Neoplasms*New abnormal growth of tissue in the SPINE.
C04.588.180*D001943*Breast Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the human BREAST.
C04.588.180.130*D000071960*Breast Carcinoma In Situ*A condition in which abnormal cells have not spread outside the duct
column2: lobule
column3: or nipple to other tissues of the breast. There are 3 types of breast carcinoma in situ: DUCTAL CARCINOMA IN SITU; LOBULAR CARCINOMA IN SITU; and PAGET DISEASE OF THE NIPPLE

column1: C04.588.180.260*D018567*Breast Neoplasms
column2: Male*Any neoplasms of the male breast. These occur infrequently in males in developed countries
column3: the incidence being about 1% of that in females.

column2: Ductal
column3: Breast*An invasive (infiltrating) CARCINOMA of the mammary ductal system (MAMMARY GLANDS) in the human BREAST.

column2: Lobular*A type of BREAST CANCER where the abnormal malignant cells form in the lobules

column1: C04.588.180.483*D061325*Hereditary Breast and Ovarian Cancer Syndrome*Autosomal dominant HEREDITARY CANCER SYNDROME in which a mutation most often in either BRCA1 or BRCA2 is associated with a significantly increased risk for breast and ovarian cancers.

C04.588.180.576*D058922*Inflammatory Breast Neoplasms*Metastatic breast cancer characterized by EDEMA and ERYTHEMA of the affected breast due to LYMPHATIC METASTASIS and eventual obstruction of LYMPHATIC VESSELS by the cancer cells.
C04.588.180.682*D000069584*Unilateral Breast Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer found specifically in one human BREAST
column2: but not in both.

column1: C04.588.180.788*D064726*Triple Negative Breast Neoplasms*Breast neoplasms that do not express ESTROGEN RECEPTORS; PROGESTERONE RECEPTORS; and do not overexpress the NEU RECEPTOR/HER-2 PROTO-ONCOGENE PROTEIN.
C04.588.274*D004067*Digestive System Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the DIGESTIVE SYSTEM.
C04.588.274.120*D001661*Biliary Tract Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer in the BILIARY TRACT including the BILE DUCTS and the GALLBLADDER.
C04.588.274.120.250*D001650*Bile Duct Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the BILE DUCTS.
C04.588.274.120.250.250*D003138*Common Bile Duct Neoplasms*Tumor or cancer of the COMMON BILE DUCT including the AMPULLA OF VATER and the SPHINCTER OF ODDI.
C04.588.274.120.401*D005706*Gallbladder Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the gallbladder.
C04.588.274.476*D005770*Gastrointestinal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT
column2: from the MOUTH to the ANAL CANAL.

column1: C04.588.274.476.205*D004938*Esophageal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the ESOPHAGUS.
C04.588.274.476.411*D007414*Intestinal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the INTESTINES.
C04.588.274.476.411.184*D002430*Cecal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the CECUM.
C04.588.274.476.411.184.290*D001063*Appendiceal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the APPENDIX.

C04.588.274.476.411.307*D015179*Colorectal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the COLON or the RECTUM or both. Risk factors for colorectal cancer include chronic ULCERATIVE COLITIS; FAMILIAL POLYPOSIS COLI; exposure to ASBESTOS; and irradiation of the CERVIX UTERI.
C04.588.274.476.411.307.089*D011125*Adenomatous Polyposis Coli*A polyposis syndrome due to an autosomal dominant mutation of the APC genes (GENES
column2: APC) on CHROMOSOME 5. The syndrome is characterized by the development of hundreds of ADENOMATOUS POLYPS in the COLON and RECTUM of affected individuals by early adulthood.

column1: C04.588.274.476.411.307.089.393*D005736*Gardner Syndrome*A variant of ADENOMATOUS POLYPOSIS COLI caused by mutation in the APC gene (GENES
column2: APC) on CHROMOSOME 5. It is characterized by not only the presence of multiple colonic polyposis but also extracolonic ADENOMATOUS POLYPS in the UPPER GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT; the EYE; the SKIN; the SKULL; and the FACIAL BONES; as well as malignancy in organs other than the GI tract.

column1: C04.588.274.476.411.307.180*D003110*Colonic Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the COLON.
C04.588.274.476.411.307.180.800*D012811*Sigmoid Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the SIGMOID COLON.

column2: Hereditary Nonpolyposis*A group of autosomal-dominant inherited diseases in which COLON CANCER arises in discrete adenomas. Unlike FAMILIAL POLYPOSIS COLI with hundreds of polyps
column3: hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal neoplasms occur much later
column4: in the fourth and fifth decades. HNPCC has been associated with germline mutations in mismatch repair (MMR) genes. It has been subdivided into Lynch syndrome I or site-specific colonic cancer
column5: and LYNCH SYNDROME II which includes extracolonic cancer.

column1: C04.588.274.476.411.307.790*D012004*Rectal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the RECTUM.
C04.588.274.476.411.307.790.040*D001005*Anus Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the ANAL CANAL.
C04.588.274.476.411.307.790.040.040*D000694*Anal Gland Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the anal gland.
C04.588.274.476.411.445*D004379*Duodenal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the DUODENUM.
C04.588.274.476.411.501*D007078*Ileal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer in the ILEUM region of the small intestine (INTESTINE
column2: SMALL).

column1: C04.588.274.476.411.523*D007580*Jejunal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer in the JEJUNUM region of the small intestine (INTESTINE
column2: SMALL).

column1: C04.588.274.476.767*D013274*Stomach Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the STOMACH.
C04.588.274.623*D008113*Liver Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the LIVER.

column2: Liver Cell*A benign epithelial tumor of the LIVER.

Hepatocellular*A primary malignant neoplasm of epithelial liver cells. It ranges from a well-differentiated tumor with EPITHELIAL CELLS indistinguishable from normal HEPATOCYTES to a poorly differentiated neoplasm. The cells may be uniform or markedly pleomorphic
column3: or form GIANT CELLS. Several classification schemes have been suggested.

column2: Experimental*Experimentally induced tumors of the LIVER.

column1: C04.588.274.761*D010190*Pancreatic Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the PANCREAS. Depending on the types of ISLET CELLS present in the tumors
column2: various hormones can be secreted: GLUCAGON from PANCREATIC ALPHA CELLS; INSULIN from PANCREATIC BETA CELLS; and SOMATOSTATIN from the SOMATOSTATIN-SECRETING CELLS. Most are malignant except the insulin-producing tumors (INSULINOMA).
Islet Cell*A benign tumor of the pancreatic ISLET CELLS. Usually it involves the INSULIN-producing PANCREATIC BETA CELLS

column1: C04.588.274.761.249.500*D007340*Insulinoma*A benign tumor of the PANCREATIC BETA CELLS. Insulinoma secretes excess INSULIN resulting in HYPOGLYCEMIA.

column2: Islet Cell*A primary malignant neoplasm of the pancreatic ISLET CELLS. Usually it involves the non-INSULIN-producing cell types
column3: the PANCREATIC ALPHA CELLS and the pancreatic delta cells (SOMATOSTATIN-SECRETING CELLS) in GLUCAGONOMA and SOMATOSTATINOMA

column1: C04.588.274.761.500.124*D015408*Gastrinoma*A GASTRIN-secreting neuroendocrine tumor of the non-beta ISLET CELLS
column2: the GASTRIN-SECRETING CELLS. This type of tumor is primarily located in the PANCREAS or the DUODENUM. Majority of gastrinomas are malignant. They metastasize to the LIVER; LYMPH NODES; and BONE but rarely elsewhere. The presence of gastrinoma is one of three requirements to be met for identification of ZOLLINGER-ELLISON SYNDROME
column3: which sometimes occurs in families with MULTIPLE ENDOCRINE NEOPLASIA TYPE 1; (MEN 1).

column1: C04.588.274.761.500.249*D005935*Glucagonoma*An almost always malignant GLUCAGON-secreting tumor derived from the PANCREATIC ALPHA CELLS. It is characterized by a distinctive migratory ERYTHEMA; WEIGHT LOSS; STOMATITIS; GLOSSITIS; DIABETES MELLITUS; hypoaminoacidemia; and normochromic normocytic ANEMIA.

C04.588.274.761.500.500*D013005*Somatostatinoma*A SOMATOSTATIN-secreting tumor derived from the pancreatic delta cells (SOMATOSTATIN-SECRETING CELLS). It is also found in the INTESTINE. Somatostatinomas are associated with DIABETES MELLITUS; CHOLELITHIASIS; STEATORRHEA; and HYPOCHLORHYDRIA. The majority of somatostatinomas have the potential for METASTASIS.
C04.588.274.761.500.750*D003969*Vipoma*A tumor that secretes VASOACTIVE INTESTINAL PEPTIDE
column2: a neuropeptide that causes VASODILATION; relaxation of smooth muscles; watery DIARRHEA; HYPOKALEMIA; and HYPOCHLORHYDRIA. Vipomas
column3: derived from the pancreatic ISLET CELLS
column4: generally are malignant and can secrete other hormones. In most cases
column5: Vipomas are located in the PANCREAS but can be found in extrapancreatic sites.

column2: Pancreatic Ductal*Carcinoma that arises from the PANCREATIC DUCTS. It accounts for the majority of cancers derived from the PANCREAS.

column1: C04.588.274.780*D010534*Peritoneal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the PERITONEUM.
C04.588.322*D004701*Endocrine Gland Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the ENDOCRINE GLANDS.
C04.588.322.078*D000310*Adrenal Gland Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the ADRENAL GLANDS.
C04.588.322.078.265*D000306*Adrenal Cortex Neoplasms*Tumors or cancers of the ADRENAL CORTEX.
C04.588.322.078.265.500*D018246*Adrenocortical Adenoma*A benign neoplasm of the ADRENAL CORTEX. It is characterized by a well-defined nodular lesion
column2: usually less than 2.5 cm. Most adrenocortical adenomas are nonfunctional. The functional ones are yellow and contain LIPIDS. Depending on the cell type or cortical zone involved
