column3: they may produce ALDOSTERONE; HYDROCORTISONE; DEHYDROEPIANDROSTERONE; and/or ANDROSTENEDIONE.

column1: C04.588.322.078.265.750*D018268*Adrenocortical Carcinoma*A malignant neoplasm of the ADRENAL CORTEX. Adrenocortical carcinomas are unencapsulated anaplastic (ANAPLASIA) masses sometimes exceeding 20 cm or 200 g. They are more likely to be functional than nonfunctional
column2: and produce ADRENAL CORTEX HORMONES that may result in hypercortisolism (CUSHING SYNDROME); HYPERALDOSTERONISM; and/or VIRILISM.

column1: C04.588.322.400*D009377*Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia*A group of autosomal dominant diseases characterized by the combined occurrence of tumors involving two or more ENDOCRINE GLANDS that secrete PEPTIDE HORMONES or AMINES. These neoplasias are often benign but can be malignant. They are classified by the endocrine glands involved and the degree of aggressiveness. The two major forms are MEN1 and MEN2 with gene mutations on CHROMOSOME 11 and CHROMOSOME 10
column2: respectively.

column1: C04.588.322.400.500*D018761*Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 1*A form of multiple endocrine neoplasia that is characterized by the combined occurrence of tumors in the PARATHYROID GLANDS
column2: the PITUITARY GLAND
column3: and the PANCREATIC ISLETS. The resulting clinical signs include HYPERPARATHYROIDISM; HYPERCALCEMIA; HYPERPROLACTINEMIA; CUSHING DISEASE; GASTRINOMA; and ZOLLINGER-ELLISON SYNDROME. This disease is due to loss-of-function of the MEN1 gene

column1: C04.588.322.400.505*D018813*Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 2a*A form of multiple endocrine neoplasia characterized by the presence of medullary carcinoma (CARCINOMA
column2: MEDULLARY) of the THYROID GLAND
column3: and usually with the co-occurrence of PHEOCHROMOCYTOMA
column6: it can occur with hyperplasia or adenoma of the PARATHYROID GLANDS. This disease is due to gain-of-function mutations of the MEN2 gene on CHROMOSOME 10 (Locus: 10q11.2)
column7: also known as the RET proto-oncogene that encodes a RECEPTOR PROTEIN-TYROSINE KINASE. It is an autosomal dominant inherited disease.

column1: C04.588.322.400.510*D018814*Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 2b*Similar to MEN2A
column2: it is also caused by mutations of the MEN2 gene
column3: also known as the RET proto-oncogene. Its clinical symptoms include medullary carcinoma (CARCINOMA
column4: MEDULLARY) of THYROID GLAND and PHEOCHROMOCYTOMA of ADRENAL MEDULLA (50%). Unlike MEN2a
column5: MEN2b does not involve PARATHYROID NEOPLASMS. It can be distinguished from MEN2A by its neural abnormalities such as mucosal NEUROMAS on EYELIDS; LIP; and TONGUE
column6: and ganglioneuromatosis of GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT leading to MEGACOLON. It is an autosomal dominant inherited disease.

column1: C04.588.322.455*D010051*Ovarian Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the OVARY. These neoplasms can be benign or malignant. They are classified according to the tissue of origin
column2: such as the surface EPITHELIUM

column1: C04.588.322.455.398*D006106*Granulosa Cell Tumor*A neoplasm composed entirely of GRANULOSA CELLS
column2: occurring mostly in the OVARY. In the adult form
column3: it may contain some THECA CELLS. This tumor often produces ESTRADIOL and INHIBIN. The excess estrogen exposure can lead to other malignancies in women and PRECOCIOUS PUBERTY in girls. In rare cases
column4: granulosa cell tumors have been identified in the TESTES.

column1: C04.588.322.455.431*D061325*Hereditary Breast and Ovarian Cancer Syndrome*Autosomal dominant HEREDITARY CANCER SYNDROME in which a mutation most often in either BRCA1 or BRCA2 is associated with a significantly increased risk for breast and ovarian cancers.
C04.588.322.455.464*D018311*Luteoma*An ovarian neoplasm composed of LUTEAL CELLS derived from luteinized GRANULOSA CELLS and THECA CELLS. Luteomas respond to GONADOTROPINS
column2: and vary in their hormone production (PROGESTERONE; ESTROGENS; or ANDROGENS). During PREGNANCY
column3: a transient type of luteoma may develop due to an exaggerated LUTEINIZATION of the OVARY.

column1: C04.588.322.455.531*D008539*Meigs Syndrome*The triad of benign FIBROMA or other ovarian tumors with ASCITES
column2: and HYDROTHORAX due to large PLEURAL EFFUSIONS.

column1: C04.588.322.455.648*D018310*Sertoli-Leydig Cell Tumor*A sex cord-gonadal stromal tumor consists of LEYDIG CELLS; SERTOLI CELLS; and FIBROBLASTS in varying proportions and degree of differentiation. Most such tumors produce ANDROGENS in the Leydig cells
column2: formerly known as androblastoma or arrhenoblastoma. Androblastomas occur in the TESTIS or the OVARY causing precocious masculinization in the males
column4: or virilization (VIRILISM) in the females. In some cases

column1: C04.588.322.455.765*D013798*Thecoma*A gonadal stromal neoplasm composed only of THECA CELLS
column2: occurring mostly in the postmenopausal OVARY. It is filled with lipid-containing spindle cells and produces ESTROGENS that can lead to ENDOMETRIAL HYPERPLASIA; UTERINE HEMORRHAGE; or other malignancies in postmenopausal women and sexual precocity in girls. When tumors containing theca cells also contain FIBROBLASTS
column3: they are identified as thecoma-fibroma tumors with less active hormone production.

column1: C04.588.322.475*D010190*Pancreatic Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the PANCREAS. Depending on the types of ISLET CELLS present in the tumors
column2: various hormones can be secreted: GLUCAGON from PANCREATIC ALPHA CELLS; INSULIN from PANCREATIC BETA CELLS; and SOMATOSTATIN from the SOMATOSTATIN-SECRETING CELLS. Most are malignant except the insulin-producing tumors (INSULINOMA).
Islet Cell*A benign tumor of the pancreatic ISLET CELLS. Usually it involves the INSULIN-producing PANCREATIC BETA CELLS

column1: C04.588.322.475.249.500*D007340*Insulinoma*A benign tumor of the PANCREATIC BETA CELLS. Insulinoma secretes excess INSULIN resulting in HYPOGLYCEMIA.

column2: Islet Cell*A primary malignant neoplasm of the pancreatic ISLET CELLS. Usually it involves the non-INSULIN-producing cell types
column3: the PANCREATIC ALPHA CELLS and the pancreatic delta cells (SOMATOSTATIN-SECRETING CELLS) in GLUCAGONOMA and SOMATOSTATINOMA

column1: C04.588.322.475.500.124*D015408*Gastrinoma*A GASTRIN-secreting neuroendocrine tumor of the non-beta ISLET CELLS
column2: the GASTRIN-SECRETING CELLS. This type of tumor is primarily located in the PANCREAS or the DUODENUM. Majority of gastrinomas are malignant. They metastasize to the LIVER; LYMPH NODES; and BONE but rarely elsewhere. The presence of gastrinoma is one of three requirements to be met for identification of ZOLLINGER-ELLISON SYNDROME
column3: which sometimes occurs in families with MULTIPLE ENDOCRINE NEOPLASIA TYPE 1; (MEN 1).

column1: C04.588.322.475.500.249*D005935*Glucagonoma*An almost always malignant GLUCAGON-secreting tumor derived from the PANCREATIC ALPHA CELLS. It is characterized by a distinctive migratory ERYTHEMA; WEIGHT LOSS; STOMATITIS; GLOSSITIS; DIABETES MELLITUS; hypoaminoacidemia; and normochromic normocytic ANEMIA.

C04.588.322.475.500.500*D013005*Somatostatinoma*A SOMATOSTATIN-secreting tumor derived from the pancreatic delta cells (SOMATOSTATIN-SECRETING CELLS). It is also found in the INTESTINE. Somatostatinomas are associated with DIABETES MELLITUS; CHOLELITHIASIS; STEATORRHEA; and HYPOCHLORHYDRIA. The majority of somatostatinomas have the potential for METASTASIS.
C04.588.322.475.500.750*D003969*Vipoma*A tumor that secretes VASOACTIVE INTESTINAL PEPTIDE
column2: a neuropeptide that causes VASODILATION; relaxation of smooth muscles; watery DIARRHEA; HYPOKALEMIA; and HYPOCHLORHYDRIA. Vipomas
column3: derived from the pancreatic ISLET CELLS
column4: generally are malignant and can secrete other hormones. In most cases
column5: Vipomas are located in the PANCREAS but can be found in extrapancreatic sites.

column2: Pancreatic Ductal*Carcinoma that arises from the PANCREATIC DUCTS. It accounts for the majority of cancers derived from the PANCREAS.

column1: C04.588.322.490*D009384*Paraneoplastic Endocrine Syndromes*Syndromes resulting from inappropriate production of HORMONES or hormone-like materials by NEOPLASMS in non-endocrine tissues or not by the usual ENDOCRINE GLANDS. Such hormone outputs are called ectopic hormone (HORMONES
column2: ECTOPIC) secretion.

column1: C04.588.322.525*D010282*Parathyroid Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the PARATHYROID GLANDS.
C04.588.322.609*D010911*Pituitary Neoplasms*Neoplasms which arise from or metastasize to the PITUITARY GLAND. The majority of pituitary neoplasms are adenomas
column2: which are divided into non-secreting and secreting forms. Hormone producing forms are further classified by the type of hormone they secrete. Pituitary adenomas may also be characterized by their staining properties (see ADENOMA
column5: CHROMOPHOBE). Pituitary tumors may compress adjacent structures
column8: and the OPTIC CHIASM. Chiasmal compression may result in bitemporal HEMIANOPSIA.

column1: C04.588.322.609.145*D049913*ACTH-Secreting Pituitary Adenoma*A pituitary adenoma which secretes ADRENOCORTICOTROPIN
column2: leading to CUSHING DISEASE.

column1: C04.588.322.609.145.500*D009347*Nelson Syndrome*A syndrome characterized by HYPERPIGMENTATION
column2: enlarging pituitary mass
column3: visual defects secondary to compression of the OPTIC CHIASM
column4: and elevated serum ACTH. It is caused by the expansion of an underlying ACTH-SECRETING PITUITARY ADENOMA that grows in the absence of feedback inhibition by adrenal CORTICOSTEROIDS

column1: C04.588.322.609.292*D049912*Growth Hormone-Secreting Pituitary Adenoma*A pituitary tumor that secretes GROWTH HORMONE. In humans
column2: excess HUMAN GROWTH HORMONE leads to ACROMEGALY.

column1: C04.588.322.609.792*D015175*Prolactinoma*A pituitary adenoma which secretes PROLACTIN
column2: leading to HYPERPROLACTINEMIA. Clinical manifestations include AMENORRHEA; GALACTORRHEA; IMPOTENCE; HEADACHE; visual disturbances; and CEREBROSPINAL FLUID RHINORRHEA.

column1: C04.588.322.762*D013736*Testicular Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the TESTIS. Germ cell tumors (GERMINOMA) of the testis constitute 95% of all testicular neoplasms.

C04.588.322.762.500*D018310*Sertoli-Leydig Cell Tumor*A sex cord-gonadal stromal tumor consists of LEYDIG CELLS; SERTOLI CELLS; and FIBROBLASTS in varying proportions and degree of differentiation. Most such tumors produce ANDROGENS in the Leydig cells
column2: formerly known as androblastoma or arrhenoblastoma. Androblastomas occur in the TESTIS or the OVARY causing precocious masculinization in the males
column4: or virilization (VIRILISM) in the females. In some cases

column1: C04.588.322.762.500.249*D007984*Leydig Cell Tumor*Gonadal interstitial or stromal cell neoplasm composed of only LEYDIG CELLS. These tumors may produce one or more of the steroid hormones such as ANDROGENS; ESTROGENS; and CORTICOSTEROIDS. Clinical symptoms include testicular swelling
column2: GYNECOMASTIA

column1: C04.588.322.762.500.500*D012707*Sertoli Cell Tumor*Gonadal neoplasm composed entirely of SERTOLI CELLS or may have a component of GRANULOSA CELLS. Some of the Sertoli cell tumors produce ESTROGEN or ANDROGENS
column2: but seldom in sufficient quantity to cause clinical symptoms such as FEMINIZATION or masculinization (VIRILISM).

column1: C04.588.322.894*D013964*Thyroid Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the THYROID GLAND.

C04.588.322.894.800*D016606*Thyroid Nodule*A small circumscribed mass in the THYROID GLAND that can be of neoplastic growth or non-neoplastic abnormality. It lacks a well-defined capsule or glandular architecture. Thyroid nodules are often benign but can be malignant. The growth of nodules can lead to a multinodular goiter (GOITER
column2: NODULAR).

column1: C04.588.364*D005134*Eye Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the EYE.
C04.588.364.235*D003230*Conjunctival Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the CONJUNCTIVA.
C04.588.364.447*D064090*Intraocular Lymphoma*A form of malignant cancer which occurs within the eyeball.
C04.588.364.659*D009918*Orbital Neoplasms*Neoplasms of the bony orbit and contents except the eyeball.
C04.588.364.738*D059545*Paraneoplastic Syndromes
column2: Ocular*Ocular manifestations secondary to various NEOPLASMS in which antibodies to antigens of the primary tumor cross-react with ocular antigens. This autoimmune response often leads to visual loss and other ocular dysfunctions.

column1: C04.588.364.818*D019572*Retinal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the RETINA.

C04.588.364.818.760*D012175*Retinoblastoma*A malignant tumor arising from the nuclear layer of the retina that is the most common primary tumor of the eye in children. The tumor tends to occur in early childhood or infancy and may be present at birth. The majority are sporadic
column2: but the condition may be transmitted as an autosomal dominant trait. Histologic features include dense cellularity
column4: and areas of calcification and necrosis. An abnormal pupil reflex (leukokoria); NYSTAGMUS
column5: PATHOLOGIC; STRABISMUS; and visual loss represent common clinical characteristics of this condition. (From DeVita et al.
column6: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column1: C04.588.364.978*D014604*Uveal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the UVEA.

C04.588.364.978.223*D002830*Choroid Neoplasms*Tumors of the choroid; most common intraocular tumors are malignant melanomas of the choroid. These usually occur after puberty and increase in incidence with advancing age. Most malignant melanomas of the uveal tract develop from benign melanomas (nevi).

C04.588.364.978.400*D015811*Iris Neoplasms*Tumors of the iris characterized by increased pigmentation of melanocytes. Iris nevi are composed of proliferated melanocytes and are associated with neurofibromatosis and malignant melanoma of the choroid and ciliary body. Malignant melanoma of the iris often originates from preexisting nevi.

C04.588.443*D006258*Head and Neck Neoplasms*Soft tissue tumors or cancer arising from the mucosal surfaces of the LIP; oral cavity; PHARYNX; LARYNX; and cervical esophagus. Other sites included are the NOSE and PARANASAL SINUSES; SALIVARY GLANDS; THYROID GLAND and PARATHYROID GLANDS; and MELANOMA and non-melanoma skin cancers of the head and neck. (from Holland et al.
column2: Cancer Medicine

column1: C04.588.443.353*D004938*Esophageal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the ESOPHAGUS.
C04.588.443.392*D005153*Facial Neoplasms*New abnormal growth of tissue in the FACE.
C04.588.443.392.500*D005142*Eyelid Neoplasms*Tumors of cancer of the EYELIDS.
C04.588.443.591*D009062*Mouth Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the MOUTH.
C04.588.443.591.402*D005887*Gingival Neoplasms*New abnormal growth of tissue in the GINGIVA.

column2: Oral*A white patch seen on the oral mucosa. It is considered a premalignant condition and is often tobacco-induced. When evidence of Epstein-Barr virus is present
column3: the condition is called hairy leukoplakia (LEUKOPLAKIA

column2: Hairy*Epithelial hyperplasia of the oral mucosa associated with Epstein-Barr virus (HERPESVIRUS 4
column3: HUMAN) and found almost exclusively in persons with HIV infection. The lesion consists of a white patch that is often corrugated or hairy.

column1: C04.588.443.591.550*D008048*Lip Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the LIP.
C04.588.443.591.692*D010157*Palatal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the PALATE
column2: including those of the hard palate

column1: C04.588.443.591.824*D012468*Salivary Gland Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the SALIVARY GLANDS.
C04.588.443.591.824.695*D010307*Parotid Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the PAROTID GLAND.
C04.588.443.591.824.882*D013362*Sublingual Gland Neoplasms*Neoplasms of the sublingual glands.
C04.588.443.591.824.885*D013365*Submandibular Gland Neoplasms*New abnormal growth of tissue in the SUBMANDIBULAR GLAND.
C04.588.443.591.925*D014062*Tongue Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the TONGUE.

C04.588.443.665*D010039*Otorhinolaryngologic Neoplasms*A general concept for tumors or cancer of any part of the EAR; the NOSE; the THROAT; and the PHARYNX. It is used when there is no specific heading.
C04.588.443.665.312*D004428*Ear Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of any part of the hearing and equilibrium system of the body (the EXTERNAL EAR
column2: the MIDDLE EAR

column1: C04.588.443.665.481*D007822*Laryngeal Neoplasms*Cancers or tumors of the LARYNX or any of its parts: the GLOTTIS; EPIGLOTTIS; LARYNGEAL CARTILAGES; LARYNGEAL MUSCLES; and VOCAL CORDS.
C04.588.443.665.650*D009669*Nose Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the NOSE.
C04.588.443.665.650.693*D010255*Paranasal Sinus Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the PARANASAL SINUSES.
C04.588.443.665.650.693.575*D008444*Maxillary Sinus Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the MAXILLARY SINUS. They represent the majority of paranasal neoplasms.
C04.588.443.665.710*D010610*Pharyngeal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the PHARYNX.
C04.588.443.665.710.485*D007012*Hypopharyngeal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the HYPOPHARYNX.
C04.588.443.665.710.650*D009303*Nasopharyngeal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the NASOPHARYNX.
C04.588.443.665.710.684*D009959*Oropharyngeal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the OROPHARYNX.
C04.588.443.665.710.684.800*D014067*Tonsillar Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the PALATINE TONSIL.
C04.588.443.680*D010282*Parathyroid Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the PARATHYROID GLANDS.
C04.588.443.915*D013964*Thyroid Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the THYROID GLAND.

C04.588.443.915.800*D016606*Thyroid Nodule*A small circumscribed mass in the THYROID GLAND that can be of neoplastic growth or non-neoplastic abnormality. It lacks a well-defined capsule or glandular architecture. Thyroid nodules are often benign but can be malignant. The growth of nodules can lead to a multinodular goiter (GOITER
column2: NODULAR).

column1: C04.588.443.925*D014134*Tracheal Neoplasms*New abnormal growth of tissue in the TRACHEA.
C04.588.448*D019337*Hematologic Neoplasms*Neoplasms located in the blood and blood-forming tissue (the bone marrow and lymphatic tissue). The commonest forms are the various types of LEUKEMIA
column2: of LYMPHOMA
column4: life-threatening forms of the MYELODYSPLASTIC SYNDROMES.

column1: C04.588.448.200*D019046*Bone Marrow Neoplasms*Neoplasms located in the bone marrow. They are differentiated from neoplasms composed of bone marrow cells
column2: such as MULTIPLE MYELOMA. Most bone marrow neoplasms are metastatic.

column1: C04.588.448.200.500*D011087*Polycythemia Vera*A myeloproliferative disorder of unknown etiology
column2: characterized by abnormal proliferation of all hematopoietic bone marrow elements and an absolute increase in red cell mass and total blood volume
column5: and thrombocythemia. Hematopoiesis is also reactive in extramedullary sites (liver and spleen). In time myelofibrosis occurs.

column1: C04.588.531*D015674*Mammary Neoplasms
column2: Animal*Tumors or cancer of the MAMMARY GLAND in animals (MAMMARY GLANDS

column1: C04.588.531.500*D008325*Mammary Neoplasms
column2: Experimental*Experimentally induced mammary neoplasms in animals to provide a model for studying human BREAST NEOPLASMS.

column1: C04.588.614*D009423*Nervous System Neoplasms*Benign and malignant neoplastic processes arising from or involving components of the central
column2: peripheral
column5: and meninges. Included in this category are primary and metastatic nervous system neoplasms.

column1: C04.588.614.250*D016543*Central Nervous System Neoplasms*Benign and malignant neoplastic processes that arise from or secondarily involve the brain
column2: spinal cord

column1: C04.588.614.250.195*D001932*Brain Neoplasms*Neoplasms of the intracranial components of the central nervous system
column2: including the cerebral hemispheres
column7: and cerebellum. Brain neoplasms are subdivided into primary (originating from brain tissue) and secondary (i.e.
column8: metastatic) forms. Primary neoplasms are subdivided into benign and malignant forms. In general
column9: brain tumors may also be classified by age of onset
column11: or presenting location in the brain.

column1: C04.588.614.250.195.205*D002551*Cerebral Ventricle Neoplasms*Neoplasms located in the brain ventricles
column2: including the two lateral
column4: and the fourth ventricle. Ventricular tumors may be primary (e.g.
column8: or occur as extensions of locally invasive tumors from adjacent brain structures.

column1: C04.588.614.250.195.205.200*D016545*Choroid Plexus Neoplasms*Benign or malignant tumors which arise from the choroid plexus of the ventricles of the brain. Papillomas (see PAPILLOMA
column2: CHOROID PLEXUS) and carcinomas are the most common histologic subtypes
column3: and tend to seed throughout the ventricular and subarachnoid spaces. Clinical features include headaches
column5: primarily resulting from associated HYDROCEPHALUS. (From Devita et al.
column6: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column2: Choroid Plexus*A usually benign neoplasm that arises from the cuboidal epithelium of the choroid plexus and takes the form of an enlarged CHOROID PLEXUS
column3: which may be associated with oversecretion of CSF. The tumor usually presents in the first decade of life with signs of increased intracranial pressure including HEADACHES; ATAXIA; DIPLOPIA; and alterations of mental status. In children it is most common in the lateral ventricles and in adults it tends to arise in the fourth ventricle. Malignant transformation to choroid plexus carcinomas may rarely occur. (Adams et al.
column7: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column1: C04.588.614.250.195.411*D015192*Infratentorial Neoplasms*Intracranial tumors originating in the region of the brain inferior to the tentorium cerebelli
column2: which contains the cerebellum
column6: and related structures. Primary tumors of this region are more frequent in children
column7: and may present with ATAXIA; CRANIAL NERVE DISEASES; vomiting; HEADACHE; HYDROCEPHALUS; or other signs of neurologic dysfunction. Relatively frequent histologic subtypes include TERATOMA; MEDULLOBLASTOMA; GLIOBLASTOMA; ASTROCYTOMA; EPENDYMOMA; CRANIOPHARYNGIOMA; and choroid plexus papilloma (PAPILLOMA

column1: C04.588.614.250.195.411.100*D020295*Brain Stem Neoplasms*Benign and malignant intra-axial tumors of the MESENCEPHALON; PONS; or MEDULLA OBLONGATA of the BRAIN STEM. Primary and metastatic neoplasms may occur in this location. Clinical features include ATAXIA
column2: cranial neuropathies (see CRANIAL NERVE DISEASES)
column5: and quadriparesis. Primary brain stem neoplasms are more frequent in children. Histologic subtypes include GLIOMA; HEMANGIOBLASTOMA; GANGLIOGLIOMA; and EPENDYMOMA.

column1: C04.588.614.250.195.411.211*D002528*Cerebellar Neoplasms*Primary or metastatic neoplasms of the CEREBELLUM. Tumors in this location frequently present with ATAXIA or signs of INTRACRANIAL HYPERTENSION due to obstruction of the fourth ventricle. Common primary cerebellar tumors include fibrillary ASTROCYTOMA and cerebellar HEMANGIOBLASTOMA. The cerebellum is a relatively common site for tumor metastases from the lung
column2: breast
column3: and other distant organs. (From Okazaki & Scheithauer

column1: C04.588.614.250.195.648*D018306*Neurocytoma*A benign brain tumor composed of neural elements which most often arise from the SEPTUM PELLUCIDUM and the walls of the lateral ventricles. Immunohistochemistry and electron microscopy evaluations may reveal expression of neuron specific enolase and synaptophysin and cells containing microtubuli
column2: neurosecretory granules
column3: and presynaptic vesicles. (From Acta Med Port 1994 Feb;7(2):113-9)

column1: C04.588.614.250.195.766*D010871*Pinealoma*Neoplasms which originate from pineal parenchymal cells that tend to enlarge the gland and be locally invasive. The two major forms are pineocytoma and the more malignant pineoblastoma. Pineocytomas have moderate cellularity and tend to form rosette patterns. Pineoblastomas are highly cellular tumors containing small
column2: poorly differentiated cells. These tumors occasionally seed the neuroaxis or cause obstructive HYDROCEPHALUS or Parinaud's syndrome. GERMINOMA; CARCINOMA
column3: EMBRYONAL; GLIOMA; and other neoplasms may arise in the pineal region with germinoma being the most common pineal region tumor. (From DeVita et al.
column4: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column1: C04.588.614.250.195.885*D015173*Supratentorial Neoplasms*Primary and metastatic (secondary) tumors of the brain located above the tentorium cerebelli
column2: a fold of dura mater separating the CEREBELLUM and BRAIN STEM from the cerebral hemispheres and DIENCEPHALON (i.e.
column3: THALAMUS and HYPOTHALAMUS and related structures). In adults
column4: primary neoplasms tend to arise in the supratentorial compartment
column5: whereas in children they occur more frequently in the infratentorial space. Clinical manifestations vary with the location of the lesion
column6: but SEIZURES; APHASIA; HEMIANOPSIA; hemiparesis; and sensory deficits are relatively common features. Metastatic supratentorial neoplasms are frequently multiple at the time of presentation.

column1: C04.588.614.250.195.885.500*D007029*Hypothalamic Neoplasms*Benign and malignant tumors of the HYPOTHALAMUS. Pilocytic astrocytomas and hamartomas are relatively frequent histologic types. Neoplasms of the hypothalamus frequently originate from adjacent structures
column2: including the OPTIC CHIASM
column4: and pituitary gland (see PITUITARY NEOPLASMS). Relatively frequent clinical manifestations include visual loss
column7: and precocious puberty. (From Devita et al.
column8: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column1: C04.588.614.250.195.885.500.299*D054975*Pallister-Hall Syndrome*A pleiotropic disorder of human development that comprises hypothalamic HAMARTOMA; central and postaxial POLYDACTYLY; bifid EPIGLOTTIS; ANAL ATRESIA; and renal and other abnormalities. This disorder is associated with FRAMESHIFT MUTATIONS in the GLI3 gene which encodes the GLI3 protein
column2: a KRUPPEL-LIKE TRANSCRIPTION FACTORS family member.

column1: C04.588.614.250.195.885.500.600*D010911*Pituitary Neoplasms*Neoplasms which arise from or metastasize to the PITUITARY GLAND. The majority of pituitary neoplasms are adenomas
column2: which are divided into non-secreting and secreting forms. Hormone producing forms are further classified by the type of hormone they secrete. Pituitary adenomas may also be characterized by their staining properties (see ADENOMA
column5: CHROMOPHOBE). Pituitary tumors may compress adjacent structures
column8: and the OPTIC CHIASM. Chiasmal compression may result in bitemporal HEMIANOPSIA.

column1: C04.588.614.250.387*D020863*Central Nervous System Cysts*Congenital or acquired cysts of the brain
column2: spinal cord
column3: or meninges which may remain stable in size or undergo progressive enlargement.

column1: C04.588.614.250.387.100*D016080*Arachnoid Cysts*Intracranial or spinal cavities containing a cerebrospinal-like fluid
column2: the wall of which is composed of arachnoidal cells. They are most often developmental or related to trauma. Intracranial arachnoid cysts usually occur adjacent to arachnoidal cistern and may present with HYDROCEPHALUS; HEADACHE; SEIZURES; and focal neurologic signs. (From Joynt
congenital
column3: neuroepithelial cysts that are typically filled with a viscous mucus. They usually arise in the anterior portion of the THIRD VENTRICLE between the fornices.

column1: C04.588.614.250.580*D008577*Meningeal Neoplasms*Benign and malignant neoplastic processes that arise from or secondarily involve the meningeal coverings of the brain and spinal cord.

C04.588.614.250.580.150*D055756*Meningeal Carcinomatosis*Primary or secondary neoplasm in the ARACHNOID or SUBARACHNOID SPACE. It appears as a diffuse fibrotic thickening of the MENINGES associated with variable degrees of inflammation.

C04.588.614.250.580.500*D008579*Meningioma*A relatively common neoplasm of the CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM that arises from arachnoidal cells. The majority are well differentiated vascular tumors which grow slowly and have a low potential to be invasive
column2: although malignant subtypes occur. Meningiomas have a predilection to arise from the parasagittal region
column6: and SPINAL CANAL. (From DeVita et al.
column7: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column1: C04.588.614.250.803*D013120*Spinal Cord Neoplasms*Benign and malignant neoplasms which occur within the substance of the spinal cord (intramedullary neoplasms) or in the space between the dura and spinal cord (intradural extramedullary neoplasms). The majority of intramedullary spinal tumors are primary CNS neoplasms including ASTROCYTOMA; EPENDYMOMA; and LIPOMA. Intramedullary neoplasms are often associated with SYRINGOMYELIA. The most frequent histologic types of intradural-extramedullary tumors are MENINGIOMA and NEUROFIBROMA.

C04.588.614.250.803.342*D015174*Epidural Neoplasms*Neoplasms located in the space between the vertebral PERIOSTEUM and DURA MATER surrounding the SPINAL CORD. Tumors in this location are most often metastatic in origin and may cause neurologic deficits by mass effect on the spinal cord or nerve roots or by interfering with blood supply to the spinal cord.
C04.588.614.300*D003390*Cranial Nerve Neoplasms*Benign and malignant neoplasms that arise from one or more of the twelve cranial nerves.

column2: Acoustic*A benign SCHWANNOMA of the eighth cranial nerve (VESTIBULOCOCHLEAR NERVE)
column3: mostly arising from the vestibular branch (VESTIBULAR NERVE) during the fifth or sixth decade of life. Clinical manifestations include HEARING LOSS; HEADACHE; VERTIGO; TINNITUS; and FACIAL PAIN. Bilateral acoustic neuromas are associated with NEUROFIBROMATOSIS 2. (From Adams et al.

column1: C04.588.614.300.600*D019574*Optic Nerve Neoplasms*Benign and malignant neoplasms that arise from the optic nerve or its sheath. OPTIC NERVE GLIOMA is the most common histologic type. Optic nerve neoplasms tend to cause unilateral visual loss and an afferent pupillary defect and may spread via neural pathways to the brain.
C04.588.614.300.600.600*D020339*Optic Nerve Glioma*Glial cell derived tumors arising from the optic nerve
column2: usually presenting in childhood.

column1: C04.588.614.550*D020361*Paraneoplastic Syndromes
column2: Nervous System*Degenerative or inflammatory conditions affecting the central or peripheral nervous system that develop in association with a systemic neoplasm without direct invasion by tumor. They may be associated with circulating antibodies that react with the affected neural tissue. (Intern Med 1996 Dec;35(12):925-9)

column1: C04.588.614.550.112*D060426*Anti-N-Methyl-D-Aspartate Receptor Encephalitis*Disorder characterized by symptoms of CATATONIA; HYPOVENTILATION; DYSKINESIAS; ENCEPHALITIS; and SEIZURES followed by a reduced CONSCIOUSNESS. It is often followed by a viral-like prodrome. Many cases are self-limiting and respond well to IMMUNOMODULATORY THERAPIES against the NMDA RECEPTORS antibodies.
C04.588.614.550.225*D015624*Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome*An autoimmune disease characterized by weakness and fatigability of proximal muscles
column2: particularly of the pelvic girdle
column5: and shoulder girdle. There is relative sparing of extraocular and bulbar muscles. CARCINOMA
column6: SMALL CELL of the lung is a frequently associated condition
column7: although other malignancies and autoimmune diseases may be associated. Muscular weakness results from impaired impulse transmission at the NEUROMUSCULAR JUNCTION. Presynaptic calcium channel dysfunction leads to a reduced amount of acetylcholine being released in response to stimulation of the nerve. (From Adams et al.

column1: C04.588.614.550.450*D020363*Limbic Encephalitis*A paraneoplastic syndrome marked by degeneration of neurons in the LIMBIC SYSTEM. Clinical features include HALLUCINATIONS
column2: loss of EPISODIC MEMORY; ANOSMIA; AGEUSIA; TEMPORAL LOBE EPILEPSY; DEMENTIA; and affective disturbance (depression). Circulating anti-neuronal antibodies (e.g.
column3: anti-Hu; anti-Yo; anti-Ri; and anti-Ma2) and small cell lung carcinomas or testicular carcinoma are frequently associated with this syndrome.

column2: Transverse*Inflammation of a transverse portion of the spinal cord characterized by acute or subacute segmental demyelination or necrosis. The condition may occur sporadically
column4: or present as a paraneoplastic syndrome (see also ENCEPHALOMYELITIS
column5: ACUTE DISSEMINATED). Clinical manifestations include motor weakness

column1: C04.588.614.550.600*D053578*Opsoclonus-Myoclonus Syndrome*A neurological condition that is characterized by uncontrolled rapid irregular movements of the eye (OPSOCLONUS) and the muscle (MYOCLONUS) causing unsteady
column2: trembling gait. It is also known as dancing eyes-dancing feet syndrome and is often associated with neoplasms
column4: or autoimmune disorders involving the nervous system.

column1: C04.588.614.550.650*D020362*Paraneoplastic Cerebellar Degeneration*Cerebellar degeneration associated with a remote neoplasm. Clinical manifestations include progressive limb and GAIT ATAXIA; DYSARTHRIA; and NYSTAGMUS
column2: PATHOLOGIC. The histologic type of the associated neoplasm is usually carcinoma or lymphoma. Pathologically the cerebellar cortex and subcortical nuclei demonstrate diffuse degenerative changes. Anti-Purkinje cell antibodies (anti-Yo) are found in the serum of approximately 50% of affected individuals. (Adams et al.

column1: C04.588.614.550.700*D020364*Paraneoplastic Polyneuropathy*A diffuse or multifocal peripheral neuropathy related to the remote effects of a neoplasm
column2: most often carcinoma or lymphoma. Pathologically
column3: there are inflammatory changes in peripheral nerves. The most common clinical presentation is a symmetric distal mixed sensorimotor polyneuropathy. (Adams et al.

column1: C04.588.614.596*D010524*Peripheral Nervous System Neoplasms*Neoplasms which arise from peripheral nerve tissue. This includes NEUROFIBROMAS; SCHWANNOMAS; GRANULAR CELL TUMORS; and malignant peripheral NERVE SHEATH NEOPLASMS. (From DeVita Jr et al.
column2: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column1: C04.588.614.596.240*D003390*Cranial Nerve Neoplasms*Benign and malignant neoplasms that arise from one or more of the twelve cranial nerves.

column2: Acoustic*A benign SCHWANNOMA of the eighth cranial nerve (VESTIBULOCOCHLEAR NERVE)
column3: mostly arising from the vestibular branch (VESTIBULAR NERVE) during the fifth or sixth decade of life. Clinical manifestations include HEARING LOSS; HEADACHE; VERTIGO; TINNITUS; and FACIAL PAIN. Bilateral acoustic neuromas are associated with NEUROFIBROMATOSIS 2. (From Adams et al.

column1: C04.588.614.596.240.240*D019574*Optic Nerve Neoplasms*Benign and malignant neoplasms that arise from the optic nerve or its sheath. OPTIC NERVE GLIOMA is the most common histologic type. Optic nerve neoplasms tend to cause unilateral visual loss and an afferent pupillary defect and may spread via neural pathways to the brain.
C04.588.614.596.240.240.500*D020339*Optic Nerve Glioma*Glial cell derived tumors arising from the optic nerve
column2: usually presenting in childhood.

column1: C04.588.699*D010386*Pelvic Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the pelvic region.
C04.588.805*D012878*Skin Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the SKIN.
C04.588.805.040*D049309*Acanthoma*A neoplasm composed of squamous or epidermal cells.
C04.588.805.578*D012626*Sebaceous Gland Neoplasms*New abnormal growth of tissue in the SEBACEOUS GLANDS.

C04.588.805.578.500*D055653*Muir-Torre Syndrome*A form of LYNCH SYNDROME II associated with cutaneous SEBACEOUS GLAND NEOPLASMS. Muir-Torre syndrome is also associated with other visceral malignant diseases include colorectal
column2: endometrial

column1: C04.588.805.776*D013544*Sweat Gland Neoplasms*New abnormal growth of tissue in the SWEAT GLANDS.
C04.588.839*D012983*Soft Tissue Neoplasms*Neoplasms of whatever cell type or origin
column2: occurring in the extraskeletal connective tissue framework of the body including the organs of locomotion and their various component structures

column1: C04.588.839.500*D019042*Muscle Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer located in muscle tissue or specific muscles. They are differentiated from NEOPLASMS
column2: MUSCLE TISSUE which are neoplasms composed of skeletal

column1: C04.588.839.750*D019043*Vascular Neoplasms*Neoplasms located in the vasculature system
column2: such as ARTERIES and VEINS. They are differentiated from neoplasms of vascular tissue (NEOPLASMS

column1: C04.588.842*D013160*Splenic Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the SPLEEN.
C04.588.894*D013899*Thoracic Neoplasms*New abnormal growth of tissue in the THORAX.

C04.588.894.309*D006338*Heart Neoplasms*Tumors in any part of the heart. They include primary cardiac tumors and metastatic tumors to the heart. Their interference with normal cardiac functions can cause a wide variety of symptoms including HEART FAILURE; CARDIAC ARRHYTHMIAS; or EMBOLISM.
C04.588.894.309.500*D056733*Carney Complex*Autosomal dominant syndrome characterized by cardiac and cutaneous MYXOMAS; LENTIGINOSIS (spotty pigmentation of the skin)
column2: and endocrinopathy and its associated endocrine tumors. The cardiac myxomas may lead to SUDDEN CARDIAC DEATH and other complications in Carney complex patients. The gene coding for the PRKAR1A protein is one of the causative genetic loci (type 1). A second locus is at chromosome 2p16 (type 2).

column1: C04.588.894.479*D008479*Mediastinal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the MEDIASTINUM.
C04.588.894.797*D012142*Respiratory Tract Neoplasms*New abnormal growth of tissue in the RESPIRATORY SYSTEM.
C04.588.894.797.520*D008175*Lung Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the LUNG.
C04.588.894.797.520.109*D001984*Bronchial Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the BRONCHI.

column2: Bronchogenic*Malignant neoplasm arising from the epithelium of the BRONCHI. It represents a large group of epithelial lung malignancies which can be divided into two clinical groups: SMALL CELL LUNG CANCER and NON-SMALL-CELL LUNG CARCINOMA.
Non-Small-Cell Lung*A heterogeneous aggregate of at least three distinct histological types of lung cancer
column3: including SQUAMOUS CELL CARCINOMA; ADENOCARCINOMA; and LARGE CELL CARCINOMA. They are dealt with collectively because of their shared treatment strategy.

column1: C04.588.894.797.520.109.220.624*D055752*Small Cell Lung Carcinoma*A form of highly malignant lung cancer that is composed of small ovoid cells (SMALL CELL CARCINOMA).

C04.588.894.797.520.237*D055613*Multiple Pulmonary Nodules*A number of small lung lesions characterized by small round masses of 2- to 3-mm in diameter. They are usually detected by chest CT scans (COMPUTED TOMOGRAPHY
column2: X-RAY). Such nodules can be associated with metastases of malignancies inside or outside the lung

column1: C04.588.894.797.520.734*D010178*Pancoast Syndrome*A condition caused by an apical lung tumor (Pancoast tumor) with involvement of the nearby vertebral column and the BRACHIAL PLEXUS. Symptoms include pain in the shoulder and the arm
column2: and atrophy of the hand.

column1: C04.588.894.797.520.867*D018202*Pulmonary Blastoma*A malignant neoplasm of the lung composed chiefly or entirely of immature undifferentiated cells (i.e.
column2: blast forms) with little or virtually no stroma. (From Stedman

column1: C04.588.894.797.520.933*D047868*Pulmonary Sclerosing Hemangioma*A benign neoplasm of pneumocytes
column2: cells of the PULMONARY ALVEOLI. Originally considered to be vascular in origin
column3: it is now classified as an epithelial tumor with several elements
column7: and dilated blood-filled spaces resembling HEMANGIOMA.

column1: C04.588.894.797.640*D010997*Pleural Neoplasms*Neoplasms of the thin serous membrane that envelopes the lungs and lines the thoracic cavity. Pleural neoplasms are exceedingly rare and are usually not diagnosed until they are advanced because in the early stages they produce no symptoms.

column2: Malignant*Presence of fluid in the PLEURAL CAVITY as a complication of malignant disease. Malignant pleural effusions often contain actual malignant cells.

column1: C04.588.894.797.640.800*D054363*Solitary Fibrous Tumor
column2: Pleural*A rare neoplasm
column4: derived from mesenchymal fibroblasts located in the submesothelial lining of the PLEURA. It spite of its various synonyms
column5: it has no features of mesothelial cells and is not related to malignant MESOTHELIOMA or asbestos exposure.

column1: C04.588.894.797.760*D014134*Tracheal Neoplasms*New abnormal growth of tissue in the TRACHEA.
C04.588.894.949*D013953*Thymus Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the THYMUS GLAND.
C04.588.894.949.500*D013945*Thymoma*A neoplasm originating from thymic tissue
column2: usually benign
column3: and frequently encapsulated. Although it is occasionally invasive
column4: metastases are extremely rare. It consists of any type of thymic epithelial cell as well as lymphocytes that are usually abundant. Malignant lymphomas that involve the thymus
column8: should not be regarded as thymoma. (From Stedman

column1: C04.588.945*D014565*Urogenital Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the UROGENITAL SYSTEM in either the male or the female.
C04.588.945.418*D005833*Genital Neoplasms
column2: Female*Tumor or cancer of the female reproductive tract (GENITALIA

column1: C04.588.945.418.365*D005185*Fallopian Tube Neoplasms*Benign or malignant neoplasms of the FALLOPIAN TUBES. They are uncommon. If they develop
column2: they may be located in the wall or within the lumen as a growth attached to the wall by a stalk.

column1: C04.588.945.418.948*D014594*Uterine Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the UTERUS.
C04.588.945.418.948.585*D016889*Endometrial Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of ENDOMETRIUM
column2: the mucous lining of the UTERUS. These neoplasms can be benign or malignant. Their classification and grading are based on the various cell types and the percent of undifferentiated cells.

Endometrioid*An adenocarcinoma characterized by the presence of cells resembling the glandular cells of the ENDOMETRIUM. It is a common histological type of ovarian CARCINOMA and ENDOMETRIAL CARCINOMA. There is a high frequency of co-occurrence of this form of adenocarcinoma in both tissues.

column1: C04.588.945.418.948.850*D002583*Uterine Cervical Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the UTERINE CERVIX.
C04.588.945.418.955*D014625*Vaginal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the VAGINA.
C04.588.945.418.968*D014846*Vulvar Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the VULVA.
C04.588.945.440*D005834*Genital Neoplasms
column2: Male*Tumor or cancer of the MALE GENITALIA.

column1: C04.588.945.440.715*D010412*Penile Neoplasms*Cancers or tumors of the PENIS or of its component tissues.
C04.588.945.440.770*D011471*Prostatic Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the PROSTATE.
C04.588.945.440.770.500*D064129*Prostatic Neoplasms
column2: Castration-Resistant*Tumors or cancer of the PROSTATE which can grow in the presence of low or residual amount of androgen hormones such as TESTOSTERONE.

column1: C04.588.945.440.915*D013736*Testicular Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the TESTIS. Germ cell tumors (GERMINOMA) of the testis constitute 95% of all testicular neoplasms.

C04.588.945.440.915.500*D018310*Sertoli-Leydig Cell Tumor*A sex cord-gonadal stromal tumor consists of LEYDIG CELLS; SERTOLI CELLS; and FIBROBLASTS in varying proportions and degree of differentiation. Most such tumors produce ANDROGENS in the Leydig cells
column2: formerly known as androblastoma or arrhenoblastoma. Androblastomas occur in the TESTIS or the OVARY causing precocious masculinization in the males
column4: or virilization (VIRILISM) in the females. In some cases

column1: C04.588.945.440.915.500.249*D007984*Leydig Cell Tumor*Gonadal interstitial or stromal cell neoplasm composed of only LEYDIG CELLS. These tumors may produce one or more of the steroid hormones such as ANDROGENS; ESTROGENS; and CORTICOSTEROIDS. Clinical symptoms include testicular swelling
column2: GYNECOMASTIA

column1: C04.588.945.440.915.500.500*D012707*Sertoli Cell Tumor*Gonadal neoplasm composed entirely of SERTOLI CELLS or may have a component of GRANULOSA CELLS. Some of the Sertoli cell tumors produce ESTROGEN or ANDROGENS
column2: but seldom in sufficient quantity to cause clinical symptoms such as FEMINIZATION or masculinization (VIRILISM).

column1: C04.588.945.947*D014571*Urologic Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the URINARY TRACT in either the male or the female.
C04.588.945.947.535*D007680*Kidney Neoplasms*Tumors or cancers of the KIDNEY.

column2: Renal Cell*A heterogeneous group of sporadic or hereditary carcinoma derived from cells of the KIDNEYS. There are several subtypes including the clear cells

column1: C04.588.945.947.535.585*D009396*Wilms Tumor*A malignant kidney tumor
column2: caused by the uncontrolled multiplication of renal stem (blastemal)
column5: not all three are present in every case. Several genes or chromosomal areas have been associated with Wilms tumor which is usually found in childhood as a firm lump in a child's side or ABDOMEN.

column1: C04.588.945.947.535.585.220*D030321*Denys-Drash Syndrome*A disorder of sex development characterized by UROGENITAL ABNORMALITIES; GONADAL DYSGENESIS; and WILMS TUMOR. It is caused by a mutation in the Wilms tumor suppressor gene (GENES
column2: WILMS TUMOR) on chromosome 11.

column1: C04.588.945.947.535.585.950*D017624*WAGR Syndrome*A contiguous gene syndrome associated with hemizygous deletions of chromosome region 11p13. The condition is marked by the combination of WILMS TUMOR; ANIRIDIA; GENITOURINARY ABNORMALITIES; and INTELLECTUAL DISABILITY.

column2: Mesoblastic*A solid
column3: unencapsulated tumor of the KIDNEY composed of spindle mesenchymal cells that resemble FIBROBLASTS or muscle cells. The homogeneous mass typically extends into the renal parenchyma and replaces most of the kidney. In most cases
column4: mesoblastic nephroma is benign and occurs in the fetus or newborn
column5: and rarely in the older child or the adult.

column1: C04.588.945.947.940*D014516*Ureteral Neoplasms*Cancer or tumors of the URETER which may cause obstruction leading to hydroureter
column2: HYDRONEPHROSIS
column3: and PYELONEPHRITIS. HEMATURIA is a common symptom.

column1: C04.588.945.947.945*D014523*Urethral Neoplasms*Cancer or tumors of the URETHRA. Benign epithelial tumors of the urethra usually consist of squamous and transitional cells. Primary urethral carcinomas are rare and typically of squamous cells. Urethral carcinoma is the only urological malignancy that is more common in females than in males.
C04.588.945.947.960*D001749*Urinary Bladder Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the URINARY BLADDER.
C04.588.945.956*D014685*Venereal Tumors
column2: Veterinary*Tumors most commonly seen on or near the genitalia. They are venereal
column3: most likely transmitted through transplantation of cells by contact. Metastases have been reported. Spontaneous regression may occur.

column1: C04.619*D009374*Neoplasms
column2: Experimental*Experimentally induced new abnormal growth of TISSUES in animals to provide models for studying human neoplasms.
Walker*A transplantable carcinoma of the rat that originally appeared spontaneously in the mammary gland of a pregnant albino rat
column3: and which now resembles a carcinoma in young transplants and a sarcoma in older transplants. (Stedman

column2: Brown-Pearce*A transplantable EPITHELIAL CELL neoplasm of rabbits.
Ehrlich Tumor*A transplantable
column3: poorly differentiated malignant tumor which appeared originally as a spontaneous breast carcinoma in a mouse. It grows in both solid and ascitic forms.

column2: Krebs 2*A transplantable neoplasm of mice.

Lewis Lung*A carcinoma discovered by Dr. Margaret R. Lewis of the Wistar Institute in 1951. This tumor originated spontaneously as a carcinoma of the lung of a C57BL mouse. The tumor does not appear to be grossly hemorrhagic and the majority of the tumor tissue is a semifirm homogeneous mass. (From Cancer Chemother Rep 2 1972 Nov;(3)1:325) It is also called 3LL and LLC and is used as a transplantable malignancy.
Experimental*Leukemia induced experimentally in animals by exposure to leukemogenic agents
column3: such as VIRUSES; RADIATION; or by TRANSPLANTATION of leukemic tissues.

column1: C04.619.531.216*D001353*Avian Leukosis*A group of transmissible viral diseases of chickens and turkeys. Liver tumors are found in most forms
column2: but tumors can be found elsewhere.

column1: C04.619.531.594*D007939*Leukemia L1210*An experimental LYMPHOCYTIC LEUKEMIA of mice.
C04.619.531.602*D007940*Leukemia L5178*An experimental lymphocytic leukemia of mice.
C04.619.531.782*D007941*Leukemia P388*An experimental lymphocytic leukemia originally induced in DBA/2 mice by painting with methylcholanthrene.
C04.619.540*D008114*Liver Neoplasms
column2: Experimental*Experimentally induced tumors of the LIVER.

column1: C04.619.590*D008325*Mammary Neoplasms
column2: Experimental*Experimentally induced mammary neoplasms in animals to provide a model for studying human BREAST NEOPLASMS.
Experimental*Experimentally induced tumor that produces MELANIN in animals to provide a model for studying human MELANOMA.
Experimental*Experimentally induced neoplasms of CONNECTIVE TISSUE in animals to provide a model for studying human SARCOMA.

column1: C04.619.857.573*D012511*Sarcoma 37*An experimental sarcoma of mice.
C04.619.857.656*D012510*Sarcoma 180*An experimental sarcoma of mice.

column2: Avian*Connective tissue tumors
column4: that are usually caused by avian sarcoma viruses.

column2: Yoshida*An experimental sarcoma of rats.

column1: C04.626*D009376*Neoplasms
column2: Hormone-Dependent*Certain tumors that 1
column3: arise in organs that are normally dependent on specific hormones and 2
column4: are stimulated or caused to regress by manipulation of the endocrine environment.

column1: C04.651*D009378*Neoplasms
column2: Multiple Primary*Two or more abnormal growths of tissue occurring simultaneously and presumed to be of separate origin. The neoplasms may be histologically the same or different
column3: and may be found in the same or different sites.

column1: C04.651.435*D006223*Hamartoma Syndrome
column2: Multiple*A hereditary disease characterized by multiple ectodermal
column4: and endodermal nevoid and neoplastic anomalies. Facial trichilemmomas and papillomatous papules of the oral mucosa are the most characteristic lesions. Individuals with this syndrome have a high risk of BREAST CANCER; THYROID CANCER; and ENDOMETRIAL CANCER. This syndrome is associated with mutations in the gene for PTEN PHOSPHATASE.

column1: C04.651.435.500*D016715*Proteus Syndrome*Hamartoneoplastic malformation syndrome of uncertain etiology characterized by partial GIGANTISM of the hands and/or feet
column2: asymmetry of the limbs
column10: apparently suffered from Proteus syndrome and not NEUROFIBROMATOSIS

column1: C04.651.600*D009377*Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia*A group of autosomal dominant diseases characterized by the combined occurrence of tumors involving two or more ENDOCRINE GLANDS that secrete PEPTIDE HORMONES or AMINES. These neoplasias are often benign but can be malignant. They are classified by the endocrine glands involved and the degree of aggressiveness. The two major forms are MEN1 and MEN2 with gene mutations on CHROMOSOME 11 and CHROMOSOME 10
column2: respectively.

column1: C04.651.600.500*D018761*Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 1*A form of multiple endocrine neoplasia that is characterized by the combined occurrence of tumors in the PARATHYROID GLANDS
column2: the PITUITARY GLAND
column3: and the PANCREATIC ISLETS. The resulting clinical signs include HYPERPARATHYROIDISM; HYPERCALCEMIA; HYPERPROLACTINEMIA; CUSHING DISEASE; GASTRINOMA; and ZOLLINGER-ELLISON SYNDROME. This disease is due to loss-of-function of the MEN1 gene

column1: C04.651.600.505*D018813*Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 2a*A form of multiple endocrine neoplasia characterized by the presence of medullary carcinoma (CARCINOMA
column2: MEDULLARY) of the THYROID GLAND
column3: and usually with the co-occurrence of PHEOCHROMOCYTOMA
column6: it can occur with hyperplasia or adenoma of the PARATHYROID GLANDS. This disease is due to gain-of-function mutations of the MEN2 gene on CHROMOSOME 10 (Locus: 10q11.2)
column7: also known as the RET proto-oncogene that encodes a RECEPTOR PROTEIN-TYROSINE KINASE. It is an autosomal dominant inherited disease.

column1: C04.651.600.510*D018814*Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 2b*Similar to MEN2A
column2: it is also caused by mutations of the MEN2 gene
column3: also known as the RET proto-oncogene. Its clinical symptoms include medullary carcinoma (CARCINOMA
column4: MEDULLARY) of THYROID GLAND and PHEOCHROMOCYTOMA of ADRENAL MEDULLA (50%). Unlike MEN2a
column5: MEN2b does not involve PARATHYROID NEOPLASMS. It can be distinguished from MEN2A by its neural abnormalities such as mucosal NEUROMAS on EYELIDS; LIP; and TONGUE
column6: and ganglioneuromatosis of GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT leading to MEGACOLON. It is an autosomal dominant inherited disease.

column1: C04.651.800*D014402*Tuberous Sclerosis*Autosomal dominant neurocutaneous syndrome classically characterized by MENTAL RETARDATION; EPILEPSY; and skin lesions (e.g.
column2: adenoma sebaceum and hypomelanotic macules). There is
column4: considerable heterogeneity in the neurologic manifestations. It is also associated with cortical tuber and HAMARTOMAS formation throughout the body
column7: and eyes. Mutations in two loci TSC1 and TSC2 that encode hamartin and tuberin

column1: C04.666*D017169*Neoplasms
column2: Post-Traumatic*Tumors
column3: cancer or other neoplasms caused by or resulting from trauma or other non-radiation injuries.

column1: C04.682*D009381*Neoplasms
column2: Radiation-Induced*Tumors
column3: cancer or other neoplasms produced by exposure to ionizing or non-ionizing radiation.

column2: Radiation-Induced*Leukemia produced by exposure to IONIZING RADIATION or NON-IONIZING RADIATION.

column1: C04.692*D016609*Neoplasms
column2: Second Primary*Abnormal growths of tissue that follow a previous neoplasm but are not metastases of the latter. The second neoplasm may have the same or different histological type and can occur in the same or different organs as the previous neoplasm but in all cases arises from an independent oncogenic event. The development of the second neoplasm may or may not be related to the treatment for the previous neoplasm since genetic risk or predisposing factors may actually be the cause.

column1: C04.697*D009385*Neoplastic Processes*The pathological mechanisms and forms taken by tissue during degeneration into a neoplasm and its subsequent activity.
C04.697.045*D000708*Anaplasia*Loss of structural differentiation and useful function of neoplastic cells.
C04.697.098*D063646*Carcinogenesis*The origin
column2: production or development of cancer through genotypic and phenotypic changes which upset the normal balance between cell proliferation and cell death. Carcinogenesis generally requires a constellation of steps
column3: which may occur quickly or over a period of many years.

column1: C04.697.098.500*D002471*Cell Transformation
column2: Neoplastic*Cell changes manifested by escape from control mechanisms
column6: morphological and biochemical deviations from the norm
column7: and other attributes conferring the ability to invade

column1: C04.697.098.500.110*D001752*Blast Crisis*An advanced phase of chronic myelogenous leukemia
column2: characterized by a rapid increase in the proportion of immature white blood cells (blasts) in the blood and bone marrow to greater than 30%.

column1: C04.697.098.500.160*D002472*Cell Transformation
column2: Viral*An inheritable change in cells manifested by changes in cell division and growth and alterations in cell surface properties. It is induced by infection with a transforming virus.

column1: C04.697.098.875*D003043*Cocarcinogenesis*The combination of two or more different factors in the production of cancer.
C04.697.645*D009361*Neoplasm Invasiveness*Ability of neoplasms to infiltrate and actively destroy surrounding tissue.

C04.697.645.500*D017254*Leukemic Infiltration*A pathologic change in leukemia in which leukemic cells permeate various organs at any stage of the disease. All types of leukemia show various degrees of infiltration
column2: depending upon the type of leukemia. The degree of infiltration may vary from site to site. The liver and spleen are common sites of infiltration
column3: the greatest appearing in myelocytic leukemia
column4: but infiltration is seen also in the granulocytic and lymphocytic types. The kidney is also a common site and of the gastrointestinal system
column5: the stomach and ileum are commonly involved. In lymphocytic leukemia the skin is often infiltrated. The central nervous system too is a common site.

column1: C04.697.650*D009362*Neoplasm Metastasis*The transfer of a neoplasm from one organ or part of the body to another remote from the primary site.
C04.697.650.560*D008207*Lymphatic Metastasis*Transfer of a neoplasm from its primary site to lymph nodes or to distant parts of the body by way of the lymphatic system.
C04.697.650.695*D061206*Neoplasm Micrometastasis*Newly arising secondary tumors so small they are difficult to detect by physical examination or routine imaging techniques.
C04.697.650.830*D009366*Neoplasm Seeding*The local implantation of tumor cells by contamination of instruments and surgical equipment during and after surgical resection
column2: resulting in local growth of the cells and tumor formation.
Unknown Primary*Metastases in which the tissue of origin is unknown.

column1: C04.697.650.900*D009360*Neoplastic Cells
column2: Circulating*Exfoliate neoplastic cells circulating in the blood and associated with metastasizing tumors.

column1: C04.697.655*D009364*Neoplasm Recurrence
column2: Local*The local recurrence of a neoplasm following treatment. It arises from microscopic cells of the original neoplasm that have escaped therapeutic intervention and later become clinically visible at the original site.

column1: C04.697.670*D009365*Neoplasm Regression
column2: Spontaneous*Disappearance of a neoplasm or neoplastic state without the intervention of therapy.
Residual*Remnant of a tumor or cancer after primary

column1: C04.700*D009386*Neoplastic Syndromes
column2: Hereditary*The condition of a pattern of malignancies within a family
column3: but not every individual's necessarily having the same neoplasm. Characteristically the tumor tends to occur at an earlier than average age
column4: individuals may have more than one primary tumor
column6: usually more than 25 percent of the individuals in direct lineal descent from the proband are affected
column7: and the cancer predisposition in these families behaves as an autosomal dominant trait with about 60 percent penetrance.

column1: C04.700.100*D011125*Adenomatous Polyposis Coli*A polyposis syndrome due to an autosomal dominant mutation of the APC genes (GENES
column2: APC) on CHROMOSOME 5. The syndrome is characterized by the development of hundreds of ADENOMATOUS POLYPS in the COLON and RECTUM of affected individuals by early adulthood.

column1: C04.700.100.392*D005736*Gardner Syndrome*A variant of ADENOMATOUS POLYPOSIS COLI caused by mutation in the APC gene (GENES
column2: APC) on CHROMOSOME 5. It is characterized by not only the presence of multiple colonic polyposis but also extracolonic ADENOMATOUS POLYPS in the UPPER GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT; the EYE; the SKIN; the SKULL; and the FACIAL BONES; as well as malignancy in organs other than the GI tract.

column1: C04.700.175*D001478*Basal Cell Nevus Syndrome*Hereditary disorder consisting of multiple basal cell carcinomas
column2: odontogenic keratocysts
column9: and cervicothoracic spina bifida. Genetic transmission is autosomal dominant.

column1: C04.700.212*D058249*Birt-Hogg-Dube Syndrome*Autosomal dominant neoplastic syndrome characterised by genodermatosis
column2: lung cysts
column3: spontaneous and recurrent PNEUMOTHORAX; and RENAL CANCER. It is associated with mutations in the folliculin protein gene (FLCN protein).

column1: C04.700.250*D003123*Colorectal Neoplasms
column2: Hereditary Nonpolyposis*A group of autosomal-dominant inherited diseases in which COLON CANCER arises in discrete adenomas. Unlike FAMILIAL POLYPOSIS COLI with hundreds of polyps
column3: hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal neoplasms occur much later
column4: in the fourth and fifth decades. HNPCC has been associated with germline mutations in mismatch repair (MMR) genes. It has been subdivided into Lynch syndrome I or site-specific colonic cancer
column5: and LYNCH SYNDROME II which includes extracolonic cancer.

column1: C04.700.250.500*D055847*Lynch Syndrome II*Hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal neoplasms associated with other malignancies
column2: more commonly of ovarian or uterine origin. When also associated with SEBACEOUS GLAND NEOPLASMS

column1: C04.700.250.500.500*D055653*Muir-Torre Syndrome*A form of LYNCH SYNDROME II associated with cutaneous SEBACEOUS GLAND NEOPLASMS. Muir-Torre syndrome is also associated with other visceral malignant diseases include colorectal
column2: endometrial

column1: C04.700.305*D004416*Dysplastic Nevus Syndrome*Clinically atypical nevi (usually exceeding 5 mm in diameter and having variable pigmentation and ill defined borders) with an increased risk for development of non-familial cutaneous malignant melanoma. Biopsies show melanocytic dysplasia. Nevi are clinically and histologically identical to the precursor lesions for melanoma in the B-K mole syndrome. (Stedman
column2: 25th ed)

Multiple Hereditary*Hereditary disorder transmitted by an autosomal dominant gene and characterized by multiple exostoses (multiple osteochondromas) near the ends of long bones. The genetic abnormality results in a defect in the osteoclastic activity at the metaphyseal ends of the bone during the remodeling process in childhood or early adolescence. The metaphyses develop benign
column3: bony outgrowths often capped by cartilage. A small number undergo neoplastic transformation.

column1: C04.700.435*D006223*Hamartoma Syndrome
column2: Multiple*A hereditary disease characterized by multiple ectodermal
column4: and endodermal nevoid and neoplastic anomalies. Facial trichilemmomas and papillomatous papules of the oral mucosa are the most characteristic lesions. Individuals with this syndrome have a high risk of BREAST CANCER; THYROID CANCER; and ENDOMETRIAL CANCER. This syndrome is associated with mutations in the gene for PTEN PHOSPHATASE.

column1: C04.700.517*D061325*Hereditary Breast and Ovarian Cancer Syndrome*Autosomal dominant HEREDITARY CANCER SYNDROME in which a mutation most often in either BRCA1 or BRCA2 is associated with a significantly increased risk for breast and ovarian cancers.
C04.700.600*D016864*Li-Fraumeni Syndrome*Rare autosomal dominant syndrome characterized by mesenchymal and epithelial neoplasms at multiple sites. MUTATION of the p53 tumor suppressor gene
column2: a component of the DNA DAMAGE response pathway
column3: apparently predisposes family members who inherit it to develop certain cancers. The spectrum of cancers in the syndrome was shown to include
column4: in addition to BREAST CANCER and soft tissue sarcomas (SARCOMA); BRAIN TUMORS; OSTEOSARCOMA; LEUKEMIA; and ADRENOCORTICAL CARCINOMA.

column1: C04.700.630*D009377*Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia*A group of autosomal dominant diseases characterized by the combined occurrence of tumors involving two or more ENDOCRINE GLANDS that secrete PEPTIDE HORMONES or AMINES. These neoplasias are often benign but can be malignant. They are classified by the endocrine glands involved and the degree of aggressiveness. The two major forms are MEN1 and MEN2 with gene mutations on CHROMOSOME 11 and CHROMOSOME 10
column2: respectively.

column1: C04.700.630.500*D018761*Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 1*A form of multiple endocrine neoplasia that is characterized by the combined occurrence of tumors in the PARATHYROID GLANDS
column2: the PITUITARY GLAND
column3: and the PANCREATIC ISLETS. The resulting clinical signs include HYPERPARATHYROIDISM; HYPERCALCEMIA; HYPERPROLACTINEMIA; CUSHING DISEASE; GASTRINOMA; and ZOLLINGER-ELLISON SYNDROME. This disease is due to loss-of-function of the MEN1 gene

column1: C04.700.630.505*D018813*Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 2a*A form of multiple endocrine neoplasia characterized by the presence of medullary carcinoma (CARCINOMA
column2: MEDULLARY) of the THYROID GLAND
column3: and usually with the co-occurrence of PHEOCHROMOCYTOMA
column6: it can occur with hyperplasia or adenoma of the PARATHYROID GLANDS. This disease is due to gain-of-function mutations of the MEN2 gene on CHROMOSOME 10 (Locus: 10q11.2)
column7: also known as the RET proto-oncogene that encodes a RECEPTOR PROTEIN-TYROSINE KINASE. It is an autosomal dominant inherited disease.

column1: C04.700.630.510*D018814*Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 2b*Similar to MEN2A
column2: it is also caused by mutations of the MEN2 gene
column3: also known as the RET proto-oncogene. Its clinical symptoms include medullary carcinoma (CARCINOMA
column4: MEDULLARY) of THYROID GLAND and PHEOCHROMOCYTOMA of ADRENAL MEDULLA (50%). Unlike MEN2a
column5: MEN2b does not involve PARATHYROID NEOPLASMS. It can be distinguished from MEN2A by its neural abnormalities such as mucosal NEUROMAS on EYELIDS; LIP; and TONGUE
column6: and ganglioneuromatosis of GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT leading to MEGACOLON. It is an autosomal dominant inherited disease.

column1: C04.700.632*D014402*Tuberous Sclerosis*Autosomal dominant neurocutaneous syndrome classically characterized by MENTAL RETARDATION; EPILEPSY; and skin lesions (e.g.
column2: adenoma sebaceum and hypomelanotic macules). There is
column4: considerable heterogeneity in the neurologic manifestations. It is also associated with cortical tuber and HAMARTOMAS formation throughout the body
column7: and eyes. Mutations in two loci TSC1 and TSC2 that encode hamartin and tuberin

column1: C04.700.635*D009396*Wilms Tumor*A malignant kidney tumor
column2: caused by the uncontrolled multiplication of renal stem (blastemal)
column5: not all three are present in every case. Several genes or chromosomal areas have been associated with Wilms tumor which is usually found in childhood as a firm lump in a child's side or ABDOMEN.

column1: C04.700.635.220*D030321*Denys-Drash Syndrome*A disorder of sex development characterized by UROGENITAL ABNORMALITIES; GONADAL DYSGENESIS; and WILMS TUMOR. It is caused by a mutation in the Wilms tumor suppressor gene (GENES
column2: WILMS TUMOR) on chromosome 11.

column1: C04.700.635.950*D017624*WAGR Syndrome*A contiguous gene syndrome associated with hemizygous deletions of chromosome region 11p13. The condition is marked by the combination of WILMS TUMOR; ANIRIDIA; GENITOURINARY ABNORMALITIES; and INTELLECTUAL DISABILITY.

C04.700.645*D017253*Neurofibromatoses*A group of disorders characterized by an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance with high rates of spontaneous mutation and multiple neurofibromas or neurilemmomas. NEUROFIBROMATOSIS 1 (generalized neurofibromatosis) accounts for approximately 95% of cases
column2: although multiple additional subtypes (e.g.
column5: etc.) have been described. (From Neurochirurgie 1998 Nov;44(4):267-72)

column1: C04.700.645.650*D009456*Neurofibromatosis 1*An autosomal dominant inherited disorder (with a high frequency of spontaneous mutations) that features developmental changes in the nervous system
column2: muscles
column5: most notably in tissue derived from the embryonic NEURAL CREST. Multiple hyperpigmented skin lesions and subcutaneous tumors are the hallmark of this disease. Peripheral and central nervous system neoplasms occur frequently
column6: especially OPTIC NERVE GLIOMA and NEUROFIBROSARCOMA. NF1 is caused by mutations which inactivate the NF1 gene (GENES
column7: NEUROFIBROMATOSIS 1) on chromosome 17q. The incidence of learning disabilities is also elevated in this condition. (From Adams et al.
column10: pp1014-18) There is overlap of clinical features with NOONAN SYNDROME in a syndrome called neurofibromatosis-Noonan syndrome. Both the PTPN11 and NF1 gene products are involved in the SIGNAL TRANSDUCTION pathway of Ras (RAS PROTEINS).

column1: C04.700.645.655*D016518*Neurofibromatosis 2*An autosomal dominant disorder characterized by a high incidence of bilateral acoustic neuromas as well as schwannomas (NEURILEMMOMA) of other cranial and peripheral nerves
column2: and other benign intracranial tumors including meningiomas
column5: and gliomas. The disease has been linked to mutations of the NF2 gene (GENES
column6: NEUROFIBROMATOSIS 2) on chromosome 22 (22q12) and usually presents clinically in the first or second decade of life.

column1: C04.700.705*D010580*Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome*A hereditary disease caused by autosomal dominant mutations involving CHROMOSOME 19. It is characterized by the presence of INTESTINAL POLYPS
column2: consistently in the JEJUNUM
column3: and mucocutaneous pigmentation with MELANIN spots of the lips

column1: C04.730*D010257*Paraneoplastic Syndromes*In patients with neoplastic diseases a wide variety of clinical pictures which are indirect and usually remote effects produced by tumor cell metabolites or other products.

C04.730.713*D009384*Paraneoplastic Endocrine Syndromes*Syndromes resulting from inappropriate production of HORMONES or hormone-like materials by NEOPLASMS in non-endocrine tissues or not by the usual ENDOCRINE GLANDS. Such hormone outputs are called ectopic hormone (HORMONES
column2: ECTOPIC) secretion.
Ectopic*Symptom complex due to ACTH production by non-pituitary neoplasms.

column1: C04.730.713.988*D015043*Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome*A syndrome that is characterized by the triad of severe PEPTIC ULCER
column2: hypersecretion of GASTRIC ACID
column3: and GASTRIN-producing tumors of the PANCREAS or other tissue (GASTRINOMA). This syndrome may be sporadic or be associated with MULTIPLE ENDOCRINE NEOPLASIA TYPE 1.

column1: C04.730.856*D020361*Paraneoplastic Syndromes
column2: Nervous System*Degenerative or inflammatory conditions affecting the central or peripheral nervous system that develop in association with a systemic neoplasm without direct invasion by tumor. They may be associated with circulating antibodies that react with the affected neural tissue. (Intern Med 1996 Dec;35(12):925-9)

column1: C04.730.856.112*D060426*Anti-N-Methyl-D-Aspartate Receptor Encephalitis*Disorder characterized by symptoms of CATATONIA; HYPOVENTILATION; DYSKINESIAS; ENCEPHALITIS; and SEIZURES followed by a reduced CONSCIOUSNESS. It is often followed by a viral-like prodrome. Many cases are self-limiting and respond well to IMMUNOMODULATORY THERAPIES against the NMDA RECEPTORS antibodies.
C04.730.856.225*D015624*Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome*An autoimmune disease characterized by weakness and fatigability of proximal muscles
column2: particularly of the pelvic girdle
column5: and shoulder girdle. There is relative sparing of extraocular and bulbar muscles. CARCINOMA
column6: SMALL CELL of the lung is a frequently associated condition
column7: although other malignancies and autoimmune diseases may be associated. Muscular weakness results from impaired impulse transmission at the NEUROMUSCULAR JUNCTION. Presynaptic calcium channel dysfunction leads to a reduced amount of acetylcholine being released in response to stimulation of the nerve. (From Adams et al.

column1: C04.730.856.437*D020363*Limbic Encephalitis*A paraneoplastic syndrome marked by degeneration of neurons in the LIMBIC SYSTEM. Clinical features include HALLUCINATIONS
column2: loss of EPISODIC MEMORY; ANOSMIA; AGEUSIA; TEMPORAL LOBE EPILEPSY; DEMENTIA; and affective disturbance (depression). Circulating anti-neuronal antibodies (e.g.
column3: anti-Hu; anti-Yo; anti-Ri; and anti-Ma2) and small cell lung carcinomas or testicular carcinoma are frequently associated with this syndrome.

column2: Transverse*Inflammation of a transverse portion of the spinal cord characterized by acute or subacute segmental demyelination or necrosis. The condition may occur sporadically
column4: or present as a paraneoplastic syndrome (see also ENCEPHALOMYELITIS
column5: ACUTE DISSEMINATED). Clinical manifestations include motor weakness

column1: C04.730.856.596*D053578*Opsoclonus-Myoclonus Syndrome*A neurological condition that is characterized by uncontrolled rapid irregular movements of the eye (OPSOCLONUS) and the muscle (MYOCLONUS) causing unsteady
column2: trembling gait. It is also known as dancing eyes-dancing feet syndrome and is often associated with neoplasms
column4: or autoimmune disorders involving the nervous system.

column1: C04.730.856.650*D020362*Paraneoplastic Cerebellar Degeneration*Cerebellar degeneration associated with a remote neoplasm. Clinical manifestations include progressive limb and GAIT ATAXIA; DYSARTHRIA; and NYSTAGMUS
column2: PATHOLOGIC. The histologic type of the associated neoplasm is usually carcinoma or lymphoma. Pathologically the cerebellar cortex and subcortical nuclei demonstrate diffuse degenerative changes. Anti-Purkinje cell antibodies (anti-Yo) are found in the serum of approximately 50% of affected individuals. (Adams et al.

column1: C04.730.856.700*D020364*Paraneoplastic Polyneuropathy*A diffuse or multifocal peripheral neuropathy related to the remote effects of a neoplasm
column2: most often carcinoma or lymphoma. Pathologically
column3: there are inflammatory changes in peripheral nerves. The most common clinical presentation is a symmetric distal mixed sensorimotor polyneuropathy. (Adams et al.

column1: C04.730.900*D059545*Paraneoplastic Syndromes
column2: Ocular*Ocular manifestations secondary to various NEOPLASMS in which antibodies to antigens of the primary tumor cross-react with ocular antigens. This autoimmune response often leads to visual loss and other ocular dysfunctions.

column1: C04.834*D011230*Precancerous Conditions*Pathological processes that tend eventually to become malignant. (From Dorland
column2: 27th ed)

column1: C04.834.020*D058739*Aberrant Crypt Foci*Clusters of colonic crypts that appear different from the surrounding mucosa when visualized after staining. They are of interest as putative precursors to colorectal adenomas and potential biomarkers for colorectal carcinoma.
C04.834.288*D004919*Erythroplasia*A condition of the mucous membrane characterized by erythematous papular lesions. (Dorland
column2: 27th ed)
Actinic*White or pink lesions on the arms
column5: or scalp that arise from sun-induced DNA DAMAGE to KERATINOCYTES in exposed areas. They are considered precursor lesions to superficial SQUAMOUS CELL CARCINOMA.

column1: C04.834.512*D007971*Leukoplakia*A white patch lesion found on a MUCOUS MEMBRANE that cannot be scraped off. Leukoplakia is generally considered a precancerous condition
column2: however its appearance may also result from a variety of HEREDITARY DISEASES.
Oral*A white patch seen on the oral mucosa. It is considered a premalignant condition and is often tobacco-induced. When evidence of Epstein-Barr virus is present
column3: the condition is called hairy leukoplakia (LEUKOPLAKIA

column2: Hairy*Epithelial hyperplasia of the oral mucosa associated with Epstein-Barr virus (HERPESVIRUS 4
column3: HUMAN) and found almost exclusively in persons with HIV infection. The lesion consists of a white patch that is often corrugated or hairy.

column1: C04.834.567*D008230*Lymphomatoid Granulomatosis*An angiocentric and angiodestructive lymphoproliferative disorder primarily involving the lungs. It is caused by an Epstein-Barr virus-induced transformation of the B-cells
column2: in a T-cell rich environment. Clinically and pathologically it resembles EXTRANODAL NK-T-CELL LYMPHOMA.

column1: C04.834.770*D011289*Preleukemia*Conditions in which the abnormalities in the peripheral blood or bone marrow represent the early manifestations of acute leukemia
column2: but in which the changes are not of sufficient magnitude or specificity to permit a diagnosis of acute leukemia by the usual clinical criteria.

column1: C04.834.818*D002578*Uterine Cervical Dysplasia*Abnormal development of immature squamous EPITHELIAL CELLS of the UTERINE CERVIX
column2: a term used to describe premalignant cytological changes in the cervical EPITHELIUM. These atypical cells do not penetrate the epithelial BASEMENT MEMBRANE.

column1: C04.834.818.249*D065309*Atypical Squamous Cells of the Cervix*Morphological abnormalities of the cervical EPITHELIUM
column2: usually revealed in PAP SMEAR
column3: which do not meet the criteria for squamous CERVICAL INTRAEPITHELIAL NEOPLASIA or SQUAMOUS CELL CARCINOMAS of the CERVIX . It may be a sign of infection with certain types of human papillomavirus (HPV).or sign of a benign (not cancer) growth
column4: such as a cyst or polyp or
column6: of low hormone levels. More testing

column1: C04.834.818.500*D065310*Squamous Intraepithelial Lesions of the Cervix*A cytological test finding often from PAP SMEARS that shows abnormal lesions of SQUAMOUS EPITHELIAL CELLS of the CERVIX. It is a diagnostic criterion used in the Bethesda System for UTERINE CERVICAL NEOPLASMS and represents the PAP TEST result that is abnormal. Although squamous intraepithelial lesions test result does not mean UTERINE CERVICAL NEOPLASMS it requires follow-ups (e.g.
column2: HPV DNA TESTS; and COLPOSCOPY).

column1: C04.834.867*D014983*Xeroderma Pigmentosum*A rare
column2: pigmentary
column3: and atrophic autosomal recessive disease. It is manifested as an extreme photosensitivity to ULTRAVIOLET RAYS as the result of a deficiency in the enzyme that permits excisional repair of ultraviolet-damaged DNA.

column1: C04.850*D011252*Pregnancy Complications
column2: Neoplastic*The co-occurrence of pregnancy and NEOPLASMS. The neoplastic disease may precede or follow FERTILIZATION.

column1: C04.850.908*D014328*Trophoblastic Neoplasms*Trophoblastic growth
column2: which may be gestational or nongestational in origin. Trophoblastic neoplasia resulting from pregnancy is often described as gestational trophoblastic disease to distinguish it from germ cell tumors which frequently show trophoblastic elements
column3: and from the trophoblastic differentiation which sometimes occurs in a wide variety of epithelial cancers. Gestational trophoblastic growth has several forms
column4: including HYDATIDIFORM MOLE and CHORIOCARCINOMA. (From Holland et al.

column1: C04.850.908.208*D002822*Choriocarcinoma*A malignant metastatic form of trophoblastic tumors. Unlike the HYDATIDIFORM MOLE
column2: choriocarcinoma contains no CHORIONIC VILLI but rather sheets of undifferentiated cytotrophoblasts and syncytiotrophoblasts (TROPHOBLASTS). It is characterized by the large amounts of CHORIONIC GONADOTROPIN produced. Tissue origins can be determined by DNA analyses: placental (fetal) origin or non-placental origin (CHORIOCARCINOMA
Non-gestational*A highly malignant CHORIOCARCINOMA derived from the non-placental origin such as the totipotent cells in the TESTIS
column4: and the PINEAL GLAND. It produces high levels of CHORIONIC GONADOTROPIN and can metastasize widely through the bloodstream to the lungs
column8: and other viscera by the time of diagnosis.

column1: C04.850.908.208.875*D018245*Trophoblastic Tumor
column2: Placental Site*An uncommon variant of CHORIOCARCINOMA. It is composed almost entirely of mononuclear cytotrophoblasts (TROPHOBLASTS). Because its secretion of hCG (CHORIONIC GONADOTROPIN) is low
column3: a large tumor may develop before the hCG can be detected.
