column1: C04.850.908.416*D031901*Gestational Trophoblastic Disease*A group of diseases arising from pregnancy that are commonly associated with hyperplasia of trophoblasts (TROPHOBLAST) and markedly elevated human CHORIONIC GONADOTROPIN. They include HYDATIDIFORM MOLE
column2: invasive mole (HYDATIDIFORM MOLE
column6: and CHORIOCARCINOMA. These neoplasms have varying propensities for invasion and spread.

column1: C04.850.908.416.750*D006828*Hydatidiform Mole*Trophoblastic hyperplasia associated with normal gestation
column2: or molar pregnancy. It is characterized by the swelling of the CHORIONIC VILLI and elevated human CHORIONIC GONADOTROPIN. Hydatidiform moles or molar pregnancy may be categorized as complete or partial based on their gross morphology
Invasive*A uterine tumor derived from persistent gestational TROPHOBLASTS
column3: most likely after a molar pregnancy (HYDATIDIFORM MOLE). Invasive hyadatiform mole develops in about 15% of patients after evacuation of a complete mole and less frequently after other types of gestation. It may perforate the MYOMETRIUM and erode uterine vessels causing hemorrhage.

column1: C05*D009140*Musculoskeletal Diseases*Diseases of the muscles and their associated ligaments and other connective tissue and of the bones and cartilage viewed collectively.
C05.116*D001847*Bone Diseases*Diseases of BONES.

C05.116.070*D001845*Bone Cysts*Benign unilocular lytic areas in the proximal end of a long bone with well defined and narrow endosteal margins. The cysts contain fluid and the cyst walls may contain some giant cells. Bone cysts usually occur in males between the ages 3-15 years.

column2: Aneurysmal*Fibrous blood-filled cyst in the bone. Although benign it can be destructive causing deformity and fractures.

column1: C05.116.099*D001848*Bone Diseases
column2: Developmental*Diseases resulting in abnormal GROWTH or abnormal MORPHOGENESIS of BONES.

column1: C05.116.099.052*D030981*Acro-Osteolysis*A condition with congenital and acquired forms causing recurrent ulcers in the fingers and toes. The congenital form exhibits autosomal dominant inheritance; the acquired form is found in workers who handle VINYL CHLORIDE. When acro-osteolysis is accompanied by generalized OSTEOPOROSIS and skull deformations
column2: it is called HAJDU-CHENEY SYNDROME.

column1: C05.116.099.052.400*D031845*Hajdu-Cheney Syndrome*Rare
column2: autosomal dominant syndrome characterized by ACRO-OSTEOLYSIS

column1: C05.116.099.105*D001478*Basal Cell Nevus Syndrome*Hereditary disorder consisting of multiple basal cell carcinomas
column2: odontogenic keratocysts
column9: and cervicothoracic spina bifida. Genetic transmission is autosomal dominant.

column1: C05.116.099.343*D004392*Dwarfism*A genetic or pathological condition that is characterized by short stature and undersize. Abnormal skeletal growth usually results in an adult who is significantly below the average height.

C05.116.099.343.110*D000130*Achondroplasia*An autosomal dominant disorder that is the most frequent form of short-limb dwarfism. Affected individuals exhibit short stature caused by rhizomelic shortening of the limbs
column2: characteristic facies with frontal bossing and mid-face hypoplasia
column6: and trident hand. (Online Mendelian Inheritance in Man

column1: C05.116.099.343.110.500*D013796*Thanatophoric Dysplasia*A severe form of neonatal dwarfism with very short limbs. All cases have died at birth or later in the neonatal period.

C05.116.099.343.250*D003057*Cockayne Syndrome*A syndrome characterized by multiple system abnormalities including DWARFISM; PHOTOSENSITIVITY DISORDERS; PREMATURE AGING; and HEARING LOSS. It is caused by mutations of a number of autosomal recessive genes encoding proteins that involve transcriptional-coupled DNA REPAIR processes. Cockayne syndrome is classified by the severity and age of onset. Type I (classical; CSA) is early childhood onset in the second year of life; type II (congenital; CSB) is early onset at birth with severe symptoms; type III (xeroderma pigmentosum; XP) is late childhood onset with mild symptoms.

C05.116.099.343.347*D003409*Congenital Hypothyroidism*A condition in infancy or early childhood due to an in-utero deficiency of THYROID HORMONES that can be caused by genetic or environmental factors
column2: such as thyroid dysgenesis or HYPOTHYROIDISM in infants of mothers treated with THIOURACIL during pregnancy. Endemic cretinism is the result of iodine deficiency. Clinical symptoms include severe MENTAL RETARDATION
Pituitary*A form of dwarfism caused by complete or partial GROWTH HORMONE deficiency
column3: resulting from either the lack of GROWTH HORMONE-RELEASING FACTOR from the HYPOTHALAMUS or from the mutations in the growth hormone gene (GH1) in the PITUITARY GLAND. It is also known as Type I pituitary dwarfism. Human hypophysial dwarf is caused by a deficiency of HUMAN GROWTH HORMONE during development.

column1: C05.116.099.343.679*D046150*Laron Syndrome*An autosomal recessive disorder characterized by short stature
column2: defective GROWTH HORMONE RECEPTOR

column1: C05.116.099.343.796*D050336*Mulibrey Nanism*Growth failure from birth that is due to mutations in a gene (TRIM37) on chromosome 17q22-q23 which encodes a RING-B-box-coiled-coil protein.

column1: C05.651.310*D015673*Fatigue Syndrome

column1: C05.651.324*D005356*Fibromyalgia*A common nonarticular rheumatic syndrome characterized by myalgia and multiple points of focal muscle tenderness to palpation (trigger points). column1: C05.651.392*D020386*Isaacs Syndrome*A rare neuromuscular disorder with onset usually in late childhood or early adulthood

The continuous motor activity persists during sleep and general anesthesia (distinguishing this condition from STIFF-PERSON SYNDROME). column1: C05.651.460.620.530*D017243*MERRF Syndrome*A mitochondrial encephalomyopathy characterized clinically by a mixed seizure disorder

column9: and dementia may also occur. This condition tends to present in childhood and to be transmitted via maternal lineage. Muscle biopsies reveal ragged-red fibers and respiratory chain enzymatic defects. (From Adams et al.

column1: C05.651.460.700*D017246*Ophthalmoplegia

column4: and extraocular muscles. Ragged-red fibers and atrophy are found on muscle biopsy. Familial and sporadic forms may occur. Disease onset is usually in the first or second decade of life
column5: and the illness slowly progresses until usually all ocular motility is lost. (From Adams et al.

column1: C05.651.460.700.500*D007625*Kearns-Sayre Syndrome*A mitochondrial disorder featuring the triad of chronic progressive EXTERNAL OPHTHALMOPLEGIA

column3: and RETINITIS PIGMENTOSA. Disease onset is in the first or second decade. Elevated CSF protein
column6: and pyramidal signs may also be present. Ragged-red fibers are found on muscle biopsy. (Adams et al.

column1: C05.651.475*D009120*Muscle Cramp*A sustained and usually painful contraction of muscle fibers. This may occur as an isolated phenomenon or as a manifestation of an underlying disease process (e.g.
column2: UREMIA; HYPOTHYROIDISM; MOTOR NEURON DISEASE; etc.). (From Adams et al.

column1: C05.651.494*D019042*Muscle Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer located in muscle tissue or specific muscles. They are differentiated from NEOPLASMS

column1: C05.651.504*D009127*Muscle Rigidity*Continuous involuntary sustained muscle contraction which is often a manifestation of BASAL GANGLIA DISEASES. When an affected muscle is passively stretched

column1: C05.651.512*D009128*Muscle Spasticity*A form of muscle hypertonia associated with upper MOTOR NEURON DISEASE. Resistance to passive stretch of a spastic muscle results in minimal initial resistance (a free interval) followed by an incremental increase in muscle tone. Tone increases in proportion to the velocity of stretch. Spasticity is usually accompanied by HYPERREFLEXIA and variable degrees of MUSCLE WEAKNESS. (From Adams et al.

column1: C05.651.515*D018908*Muscle Weakness*A vague complaint of debility
column2: fatigue

column5: and is a manifestation of many muscle and neuromuscular diseases. (From Wyngaarden et al.

column1: C05.651.534*D020966*Muscular Disorders

column1: C05.651.534.500*D009136*Muscular Dystrophies*A heterogeneous group of inherited MYOPATHIES
column2: characterized by wasting and weakness of the SKELETAL MUSCLE. They are categorized by the sites of MUSCLE WEAKNESS; AGE OF ONSET; and INHERITANCE PATTERNS.

column1: C05.651.534.500.074*D049310*Distal Myopathies*A heterogeneous group of genetic disorders characterized by progressive MUSCULAR ATROPHY and MUSCLE WEAKNESS beginning in the hands
column2: the legs
column3: or the feet. Most are adult-onset autosomal dominant forms. Others are autosomal recessive.

column1: C05.651.534.500.149*D006014*Glycogen Storage Disease Type VII*An autosomal recessive glycogen storage disease in which there is deficient expression of 6-phosphofructose 1-kinase in muscle (PHOSPHOFRUCTOKINASE-1

column1: C05.651.534.500.280*D049288*Muscular Dystrophies
column2: Limb-Girdle*A heterogenous group of inherited muscular dystrophy that can be autosomal dominant or autosomal recessive. There are many forms (called LGMDs) involving genes encoding muscle membrane proteins such as the sarcoglycan (SARCOGLYCANS) complex that interacts with DYSTROPHIN. The disease is characterized by progressing wasting and weakness of the proximal muscles of arms and legs around the HIPS and SHOULDERS (the pelvic and shoulder girdles).

column1: C05.651.534.500.280.500*D058088*Sarcoglycanopathies*Deficiencies or mutations in the genes for the SARCOGLYCAN COMPLEX subunits. A variety of phenotypes are associated with these mutations including a subgroup of autosomal recessive limb girdle muscular dystrophies

column1: C05.651.534.500.300*D020388*Muscular Dystrophy
column2: Duchenne*An X-linked recessive muscle disease caused by an inability to synthesize DYSTROPHIN
column3: which is involved with maintaining the integrity of the sarcolemma. Muscle fibers undergo a process that features degeneration and regeneration. Clinical manifestations include proximal weakness in the first few years of life
column6: and an increased incidence of impaired mentation. Becker muscular dystrophy is a closely related condition featuring a later onset of disease (usually adolescence) and a slowly progressive course. (Adams et al.

column1: C05.651.534.500.350*D020389*Muscular Dystrophy
column2: Emery-Dreifuss*A heterogenous group of inherited muscular dystrophy without the involvement of nervous system. The disease is characterized by MUSCULAR ATROPHY; MUSCLE WEAKNESS; CONTRACTURE of the elbows; ACHILLES TENDON; and posterior cervical muscles; with or without cardiac features. There are several INHERITANCE PATTERNS including X-linked (X CHROMOSOME)

column1: C05.651.534.500.400*D020391*Muscular Dystrophy
column2: Facioscapulohumeral*An autosomal dominant degenerative muscle disease characterized by slowly progressive weakness of the muscles of the face
column4: and shoulder girdle. The onset of symptoms usually occurs in the first or second decade of life. Affected individuals usually present with impairment of upper extremity elevation. This tends to be followed by facial weakness
column5: primarily involving the orbicularis oris and orbicularis oculi muscles. (Neuromuscul Disord 1997;7(1):55-62; Adams et al.

column1: C05.651.534.500.450*D039141*Muscular Dystrophy
column2: Oculopharyngeal*An autosomal dominant hereditary disease that presents in late in life and is characterized by DYSPHAGIA and progressive ptosis of the eyelids. Mutations in the gene for POLY(A)-BINDING PROTEIN II have been associated with oculopharyngeal muscular dystrophy.

column1: C05.651.534.500.500*D009223*Myotonic Dystrophy*Neuromuscular disorder characterized by PROGRESSIVE MUSCULAR ATROPHY; MYOTONIA
column2: and various multisystem atrophies. Mild INTELLECTUAL DISABILITY may also occur. Abnormal TRINUCLEOTIDE REPEAT EXPANSION in the 3' UNTRANSLATED REGIONS of DMPK PROTEIN gene is associated with Myotonic Dystrophy 1. DNA REPEAT EXPANSION of zinc finger protein-9 gene intron is associated with Myotonic Dystrophy 2.

column1: C05.651.534.750*D016262*Postpoliomyelitis Syndrome*A syndrome characterized by new neuromuscular symptoms that occur at least 15 years after clinical stability has been attained in patients with a prior history of symptomatic poliomyelitis. Clinical features include new muscular weakness and atrophy of the limbs
column2: bulbar innervated musculature
column6: and reduced stamina. The process is marked by slow progression and periods of stabilization. (From Ann NY Acad Sci 1995 May 25;753:68-80)

column1: C05.651.538*D059352*Musculoskeletal Pain*Discomfort stemming from muscles
column2: LIGAMENTS

column1: C05.651.542*D063806*Myalgia*Painful sensation in the muscles.

column2: localized hardenings in skeletal muscle tissue. Pain is referred to a location distant from the trigger points. A prime example is the TEMPOROMANDIBULAR JOINT DYSFUNCTION SYNDROME.

column1: C05.651.550.905*D013706*Temporomandibular Joint Dysfunction Syndrome*A symptom complex consisting of pain
column2: muscle tenderness
column4: and limitation or alteration of mandibular movement. The symptoms are subjective and manifested primarily in the masticatory muscles rather than the temporomandibular joint itself. Etiologic factors are uncertain but include occlusal dysharmony and psychophysiologic factors.

column1: C05.651.575*D020914*Myopathies
column2: Structural
column3: Congenital*A heterogeneous group of diseases characterized by the early onset of hypotonia
column5: non-progressive weakness. Each of these disorders is associated with a specific histologic muscle fiber abnormality.

column2: Nemaline*A group of inherited congenital myopathic conditions characterized clinically by weakness
column4: and prominent hypoplasia of proximal muscles including the face. Muscle biopsy reveals large numbers of rod-shaped structures beneath the muscle fiber plasma membrane. This disorder is genetically heterogeneous and may occasionally present in adults. (Adams et al.

column2: Central Core*An inherited congenital myopathic condition characterized by weakness and hypotonia in infancy and delayed motor development. Muscle biopsy reveals a condensation of myofibrils and myofibrillar material in the central portion of each muscle fiber. (Adams et al.

column1: C05.651.594*D009220*Myositis*Inflammation of a muscle or muscle tissue.

column2: Inclusion Body*Progressive myopathies characterized by the presence of inclusion bodies on muscle biopsy. Sporadic and hereditary forms have been described. The sporadic form is an acquired
column3: adult-onset inflammatory vacuolar myopathy affecting proximal and distal muscles. Familial forms usually begin in childhood and lack inflammatory changes. Both forms feature intracytoplasmic and intranuclear inclusions in muscle tissue. (Adams et al.

column1: C05.651.594.638*D009221*Myositis Ossificans*A disease characterized by bony deposits or the ossification of muscle tissue.
C05.651.594.728*D055622*Orbital Myositis*Inflammation of the extraocular muscle of the eye. It is characterized by swelling which can lead to ischemia
column2: fibrosis

column1: C05.651.594.819*D017285*Polymyositis*Diseases characterized by inflammation involving multiple muscles. This may occur as an acute or chronic condition associated with medication toxicity (DRUG TOXICITY); CONNECTIVE TISSUE DISEASES; infections; malignant NEOPLASMS; and other disorders. The term polymyositis is frequently used to refer to a specific clinical entity characterized by subacute or slowly progressing symmetrical weakness primarily affecting the proximal limb and trunk muscles. The illness may occur at any age
column2: but is most frequent in the fourth to sixth decade of life. Weakness of pharyngeal and laryngeal muscles
column4: and inflammation of the myocardium may also occur. Muscle biopsy reveals widespread destruction of segments of muscle fibers and an inflammatory cellular response. (Adams et al.

column1: C05.651.594.819.500*D003882*Dermatomyositis*A subacute or chronic inflammatory disease of muscle and skin
column2: marked by proximal muscle weakness and a characteristic skin rash. The illness occurs with approximately equal frequency in children and adults. The skin lesions usually take the form of a purplish rash (or less often an exfoliative dermatitis) involving the nose
column6: and arms. The disease is associated with a complement mediated intramuscular microangiopathy
column10: and perifascicular atrophy. The childhood form of this disease tends to evolve into a systemic vasculitis. Dermatomyositis may occur in association with malignant neoplasms. (From Adams et al.

column1: C05.651.594.909*D052880*Pyomyositis*An intramuscular suppuration of the large skeletal muscle groups. It is associated with INFECTION such as STAPHYLOCOCCUS AUREUS and PYODERMA. It was known as a tropical disease but is increasing among the immunocompromised (IMMUNOCOMPROMISED HOST). Symptoms include muscle pain
column2: FEVER
column3: and leucocytosis. It has been diagnosed by MRI SCANS.

column1: C05.651.662*D020967*Myotonic Disorders*Diseases characterized by MYOTONIA
column2: which may be inherited or acquired. Myotonia may be restricted to certain muscles (e.g.
column3: intrinsic hand muscles) or occur as a generalized condition.

column1: C05.651.662.500*D009224*Myotonia Congenita*Inherited myotonic disorders with early childhood onset MYOTONIA. Muscular hypertrophy is common and myotonia may impair ambulation and other movements. It is classified as Thomsen (autosomal dominant) or Becker (autosomal recessive) generalized myotonia mainly based on the inheritance pattern. Becker type is also clinically more severe. An autosomal dominant variant with milder symptoms and later onset is known as myotonia levior. Mutations in the voltage-dependent skeletal muscle chloride channel are associated with the disorders.
C05.651.662.750*D009223*Myotonic Dystrophy*Neuromuscular disorder characterized by PROGRESSIVE MUSCULAR ATROPHY; MYOTONIA
column2: and various multisystem atrophies. Mild INTELLECTUAL DISABILITY may also occur. DNA REPEAT EXPANSION of zinc finger protein-9 gene intron is associated with Myotonic Dystrophy 2.

Familial Periodic*A heterogenous group of inherited disorders characterized by recurring attacks of rapidly progressive flaccid paralysis or myotonia. These conditions have in common a mutation of the gene encoding the alpha subunit of the sodium channel in skeletal muscle. They are frequently associated with fluctuations in serum potassium levels. Periodic paralysis may also occur as a non-familial process secondary to THYROTOXICOSIS and other conditions. (From Adams et al.

column1: C05.651.701.450*D020514*Hypokalemic Periodic Paralysis*An autosomal dominant familial disorder characterized by recurrent episodes of skeletal muscle weakness associated with falls in serum potassium levels. The condition usually presents in the first or second decade of life with attacks of trunk and leg paresis during sleep or shortly after awakening. Symptoms may persist for hours to days and generally are precipitated by exercise or a meal high in carbohydrates. (Adams et al.
column2: Principles of Neurology
Hyperkalemic Periodic*An autosomal dominant familial disorder which presents in infancy or childhood and is characterized by episodes of weakness associated with hyperkalemia. During attacks
column3: muscles of the lower extremities are initially affected
column4: followed by the lower trunk and arms. Episodes last from 15-60 minutes and typically occur after a period of rest following exercise. A defect in skeletal muscle sodium channels has been identified as the cause of this condition. Normokalemic periodic paralysis is a closely related disorder marked by a lack of alterations in potassium levels during attacks of weakness. (Adams et al.

column1: C05.651.742*D011111*Polymyalgia Rheumatica*A syndrome in the elderly characterized by proximal joint and muscle pain
column2: high erythrocyte sedimentation rate
column3: and a self-limiting course. Pain is usually accompanied by evidence of an inflammatory reaction. Women are affected twice as commonly as men and Caucasians more frequently than other groups. The condition is frequently associated with GIANT CELL ARTERITIS and some theories pose the possibility that the two diseases arise from a single etiology or even that they are the same entity.

column1: C05.651.807*D012206*Rhabdomyolysis*Necrosis or disintegration of skeletal muscle often followed by myoglobinuria.

C05.651.869.653*D000070676*Enthesopathy*A disorder occurring at the site of insertion of TENDONS or LIGAMENTS into bones or JOINT CAPSULES.

C05.651.869.816*D053682*Tendon Entrapment*Narrowing or stenosis of a tendon's retinacular sheath. It occurs most often in the hand or wrist but can also be found in the foot or ankle. The most common types are DE QUERVAIN DISEASE and TRIGGER FINGER DISORDER.

C05.651.869.816.200*D053684*De Quervain Disease*Stenosing tenosynovitis of the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons in the first dorsal wrist compartment. The presenting symptoms are usually pain and tenderness at the radial styloid. The cause is almost always related to OVERUSE INJURY or is associated with RHEUMATOID ARTHRITIS.

C05.651.869.816.800*D052582*Trigger Finger Disorder*A painful disability in the hand affecting the finger or thumb. It is caused by mechanical impingement of the digital flexor tendons as they pass through a narrowed retinacular pulley at the level of the metacarpal head. Thickening of the sheath and fibrocartilaginous metaplasia can occur
column2: and nodules can form. (From Green's Operative Hand Surgery

column1: C05.651.869.870*D013717*Tenosynovitis*Inflammation of the synovial lining of a tendon sheath. Causes include trauma

column6: and gout. Common sites are the hand
column11: and Achilles tendon. The tendon sheaths become inflamed and painful
column12: and accumulate fluid. Joint mobility is usually reduced.

column1: C05.660*D009139*Musculoskeletal Abnormalities*Congenital structural abnormalities and deformities of the musculoskeletal system.

column1: C05.660.207.103*D058165*22q11 Deletion Syndrome*Condition with a variable constellation of phenotypes due to deletion polymorphisms at chromosome location 22q11. It encompasses several syndromes with overlapping abnormalities including the DIGEORGE SYNDROME

C05.660.207.240*D003398*Craniosynostoses*Premature closure of one or more CRANIAL SUTURES. It often results in plagiocephaly. Craniosynostoses that involve multiple sutures are sometimes associated with congenital syndromes such as ACROCEPHALOSYNDACTYLIA; and CRANIOFACIAL DYSOSTOSIS.
C05.660.207.240.100*D000168*Acrocephalosyndactylia*Congenital craniostenosis with syndactyly.

Alobar prosencephaly is the most severe form and features anophthalmia; cyclopia; severe INTELLECTUAL DISABILITY; CLEFT LIP; CLEFT PALATE; SEIZURES; and microcephaly. column1: C05.660.207.525*D044542*LEOPARD Syndrome*An autosomal dominant disorder with an acronym of its seven features (LENTIGO; ELECTROCARDIOGRAM abnormalities; ocular HYPERTELORISM; PULMONARY STENOSIS; abnormal genitalia; retardation of growth; and DEAFNESS or SENSORINEURAL HEARING LOSS). column1: C05.660.207.532*D055947*Loeys-Dietz Syndrome*An autosomal dominant aneurysm with multisystem abnormalities caused by increased TGF-BETA signaling due to mutations in type I or II of TGF-BETA RECEPTOR. C05.660.207.536*D058627*Megalencephaly*A congenital abnormality in which the occipitofrontal circumference is greater than two standard deviations above the mean for a given age. It is associated with HYDROCEPHALUS; SUBDURAL EFFUSION; ARACHNOID CYSTS; or is part of a genetic condition (e.g.

C06.198.439*D006627*Hirschsprung Disease*Congenital MEGACOLON resulting from the absence of ganglion cells (aganglionosis) in a distal segment of the LARGE INTESTINE. The aganglionic segment is permanently contracted thus causing dilatation proximal to it. In most cases
column2: the aganglionic segment is within the RECTUM and SIGMOID COLON.

column1: C06.198.719*D007409*Intestinal Atresia*Congenital obliteration of the lumen of the intestine
column2: with the ILEUM involved in 50% of the cases and the JEJUNUM and DUODENUM following in frequency. It is the most frequent cause of INTESTINAL OBSTRUCTION in NEWBORNS. (From Stedman

column1: C06.198.859*D008467*Meckel Diverticulum*A congenital abnormality characterized by the outpouching or sac formation in the ILEUM. It is a remnant of the embryonic YOLK SAC in which the VITELLINE DUCT failed to close.
C06.267*D016154*Digestive System Fistula*An abnormal passage communicating between any components of the digestive system
column2: or between any part of the digestive system and surrounding organ(s).

column1: C06.267.150*D001658*Biliary Fistula*Abnormal passage in any organ of the biliary tract or between biliary organs and other organs.
C06.267.250*D004937*Esophageal Fistula*Abnormal passage communicating with the ESOPHAGUS. The most common type is TRACHEOESOPHAGEAL FISTULA between the esophagus and the TRACHEA.
C06.267.250.725*D014138*Tracheoesophageal Fistula*Abnormal passage between the ESOPHAGUS and the TRACHEA
column2: acquired or congenital

column1: C06.267.375*D005747*Gastric Fistula*Abnormal passage communicating with the STOMACH.
C06.267.550*D007412*Intestinal Fistula*An abnormal anatomical passage between the INTESTINE
column2: and another segment of the intestine or other organs. External intestinal fistula is connected to the SKIN (enterocutaneous fistula). Internal intestinal fistula can be connected to a number of organs
column5: or the URINARY BLADDER of the URINARY TRACT (colovesical fistula). Risk factors include inflammatory processes

column1: C06.267.550.600*D012003*Rectal Fistula*An abnormal anatomical passage connecting the RECTUM to the outside
column2: with an orifice at the site of drainage.

column1: C06.267.550.600.650*D012006*Rectovaginal Fistula*An abnormal anatomical passage between the RECTUM and the VAGINA.
C06.267.775*D010185*Pancreatic Fistula*Abnormal passage communicating with the PANCREAS.
C06.301*D004067*Digestive System Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the DIGESTIVE SYSTEM.
C06.301.120*D001661*Biliary Tract Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer in the BILIARY TRACT including the BILE DUCTS and the GALLBLADDER.
C06.301.120.250*D001650*Bile Duct Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the BILE DUCTS.
C06.301.120.250.250*D003138*Common Bile Duct Neoplasms*Tumor or cancer of the COMMON BILE DUCT including the AMPULLA OF VATER and the SPHINCTER OF ODDI.
C06.301.120.401*D005706*Gallbladder Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the gallbladder.
C06.301.371*D005770*Gastrointestinal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT
column2: from the MOUTH to the ANAL CANAL.

column1: C06.301.371.205*D004938*Esophageal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the ESOPHAGUS.

C06.301.371.308*D046152*Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumors*All tumors in the GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT arising from mesenchymal cells (MESODERM) except those of smooth muscle cells (LEIOMYOMA) or Schwann cells (SCHWANNOMA).
C06.301.371.411*D007414*Intestinal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the INTESTINES.
C06.301.371.411.184*D002430*Cecal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the CECUM.
C06.301.371.411.184.290*D001063*Appendiceal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the APPENDIX.

C06.301.371.411.307*D015179*Colorectal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the COLON or the RECTUM or both. Risk factors for colorectal cancer include chronic ULCERATIVE COLITIS; FAMILIAL POLYPOSIS COLI; exposure to ASBESTOS; and irradiation of the CERVIX UTERI.
C06.301.371.411.307.090*D011125*Adenomatous Polyposis Coli*A polyposis syndrome due to an autosomal dominant mutation of the APC genes (GENES
column2: APC) on CHROMOSOME 5. The syndrome is characterized by the development of hundreds of ADENOMATOUS POLYPS in the COLON and RECTUM of affected individuals by early adulthood.

column1: C06.301.371.411.307.090.500*D005736*Gardner Syndrome*A variant of ADENOMATOUS POLYPOSIS COLI caused by mutation in the APC gene (GENES
column2: APC) on CHROMOSOME 5. It is characterized by not only the presence of multiple colonic polyposis but also extracolonic ADENOMATOUS POLYPS in the UPPER GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT; the EYE; the SKIN; the SKULL; and the FACIAL BONES; as well as malignancy in organs other than the GI tract.

column1: C06.301.371.411.307.180*D003110*Colonic Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the COLON.
C06.301.371.411.307.180.800*D012811*Sigmoid Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the SIGMOID COLON.
C06.301.371.411.307.190*D003123*Colorectal Neoplasms
column2: Hereditary Nonpolyposis*A group of autosomal-dominant inherited diseases in which COLON CANCER arises in discrete adenomas. Unlike FAMILIAL POLYPOSIS COLI with hundreds of polyps
column3: hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal neoplasms occur much later
column4: in the fourth and fifth decades. HNPCC has been associated with germline mutations in mismatch repair (MMR) genes. It has been subdivided into Lynch syndrome I or site-specific colonic cancer
column5: and LYNCH SYNDROME II which includes extracolonic cancer.

column1: C06.301.371.411.307.790*D012004*Rectal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the RECTUM.
C06.301.371.411.307.790.040*D001005*Anus Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the ANAL CANAL.
C06.301.371.411.307.790.040.040*D000694*Anal Gland Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the anal gland.
C06.301.371.411.445*D004379*Duodenal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the DUODENUM.
C06.301.371.411.501*D007078*Ileal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer in the ILEUM region of the small intestine (INTESTINE
column2: SMALL).

column1: C06.301.371.411.512*D007161*Immunoproliferative Small Intestinal Disease*A condition that is caused by HYPERPLASIA of LYMPHOCYTES in the small intestine (INTESTINE
column2: SMALL) and the mesenteric LYMPH NODES. These lymphocytes produce an anomalous alpha heavy chain protein. Generally
column3: these IPSID patients have either concurrent LYMPHOMA or develop lymphoma within a few years. The disease was first described in the Mediterranean region and is characterized by malabsorption; WEIGHT LOSS; DIARRHEA; and STEATORRHEA.

column1: C06.301.371.411.523*D007580*Jejunal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer in the JEJUNUM region of the small intestine (INTESTINE
column2: SMALL).

column1: C06.301.371.767*D013274*Stomach Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the STOMACH.
C06.301.371.883*D015043*Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome*A syndrome that is characterized by the triad of severe PEPTIC ULCER
column2: hypersecretion of GASTRIC ACID
column3: and GASTRIN-producing tumors of the PANCREAS or other tissue (GASTRINOMA). This syndrome may be sporadic or be associated with MULTIPLE ENDOCRINE NEOPLASIA TYPE 1.

column1: C06.301.623*D008113*Liver Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the LIVER.

column2: Liver Cell*A benign epithelial tumor of the LIVER.

Hepatocellular*A primary malignant neoplasm of epithelial liver cells. It ranges from a well-differentiated tumor with EPITHELIAL CELLS indistinguishable from normal HEPATOCYTES to a poorly differentiated neoplasm. The cells may be uniform or markedly pleomorphic
column3: or form GIANT CELLS. Several classification schemes have been suggested.

column1: C06.301.623.460*D008114*Liver Neoplasms
column2: Experimental*Experimentally induced tumors of the LIVER.

column1: C06.301.761*D010190*Pancreatic Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the PANCREAS. Depending on the types of ISLET CELLS present in the tumors
column2: various hormones can be secreted: GLUCAGON from PANCREATIC ALPHA CELLS; INSULIN from PANCREATIC BETA CELLS; and SOMATOSTATIN from the SOMATOSTATIN-SECRETING CELLS. Most are malignant except the insulin-producing tumors (INSULINOMA).
Islet Cell*A benign tumor of the pancreatic ISLET CELLS. Usually it involves the INSULIN-producing PANCREATIC BETA CELLS

column1: C06.301.761.249.500*D007340*Insulinoma*A benign tumor of the PANCREATIC BETA CELLS. Insulinoma secretes excess INSULIN resulting in HYPOGLYCEMIA.

column2: Islet Cell*A primary malignant neoplasm of the pancreatic ISLET CELLS. Usually it involves the non-INSULIN-producing cell types
column3: the PANCREATIC ALPHA CELLS and the pancreatic delta cells (SOMATOSTATIN-SECRETING CELLS) in GLUCAGONOMA and SOMATOSTATINOMA

column1: C06.301.761.500.124*D015408*Gastrinoma*A GASTRIN-secreting neuroendocrine tumor of the non-beta ISLET CELLS
column2: the GASTRIN-SECRETING CELLS. This type of tumor is primarily located in the PANCREAS or the DUODENUM. Majority of gastrinomas are malignant. They metastasize to the LIVER; LYMPH NODES; and BONE but rarely elsewhere. The presence of gastrinoma is one of three requirements to be met for identification of ZOLLINGER-ELLISON SYNDROME
column3: which sometimes occurs in families with MULTIPLE ENDOCRINE NEOPLASIA TYPE 1; (MEN 1).

column1: C06.301.761.500.249*D005935*Glucagonoma*An almost always malignant GLUCAGON-secreting tumor derived from the PANCREATIC ALPHA CELLS. It is characterized by a distinctive migratory ERYTHEMA; WEIGHT LOSS; STOMATITIS; GLOSSITIS; DIABETES MELLITUS; hypoaminoacidemia; and normochromic normocytic ANEMIA.

C06.301.761.500.500*D013005*Somatostatinoma*A SOMATOSTATIN-secreting tumor derived from the pancreatic delta cells (SOMATOSTATIN-SECRETING CELLS). It is also found in the INTESTINE. Somatostatinomas are associated with DIABETES MELLITUS; CHOLELITHIASIS; STEATORRHEA; and HYPOCHLORHYDRIA. The majority of somatostatinomas have the potential for METASTASIS.
C06.301.761.500.750*D003969*Vipoma*A tumor that secretes VASOACTIVE INTESTINAL PEPTIDE
column2: a neuropeptide that causes VASODILATION; relaxation of smooth muscles; watery DIARRHEA; HYPOKALEMIA; and HYPOCHLORHYDRIA. Vipomas
column3: derived from the pancreatic ISLET CELLS
column4: generally are malignant and can secrete other hormones. In most cases
column5: Vipomas are located in the PANCREAS but can be found in extrapancreatic sites.

column2: Pancreatic Ductal*Carcinoma that arises from the PANCREATIC DUCTS. It accounts for the majority of cancers derived from the PANCREAS.

column1: C06.301.780*D010534*Peritoneal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the PERITONEUM.
C06.405*D005767*Gastrointestinal Diseases*Diseases in any segment of the GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT from ESOPHAGUS to RECTUM.
C06.405.117*D004935*Esophageal Diseases*Pathological processes in the ESOPHAGUS.
C06.405.117.102*D001471*Barrett Esophagus*A condition with damage to the lining of the lower ESOPHAGUS resulting from chronic acid reflux (ESOPHAGITIS
column2: REFLUX). Through the process of metaplasia
column3: the squamous cells are replaced by a columnar epithelium with cells resembling those of the INTESTINE or the salmon-pink mucosa of the STOMACH. Barrett's columnar epithelium is a marker for severe reflux and precursor to ADENOCARCINOMA of the esophagus.

column1: C06.405.117.119*D003680*Deglutition Disorders*Difficulty in SWALLOWING which may result from neuromuscular disorder or mechanical obstruction. Dysphagia is classified into two distinct types: oropharyngeal dysphagia due to malfunction of the PHARYNX and UPPER ESOPHAGEAL SPHINCTER; and esophageal dysphagia due to malfunction of the ESOPHAGUS.
C06.405.117.119.500*D015154*Esophageal Motility Disorders*Disorders affecting the motor function of the UPPER ESOPHAGEAL SPHINCTER; LOWER ESOPHAGEAL SPHINCTER; the ESOPHAGUS body
column2: or a combination of these parts. The failure of the sphincters to maintain a tonic pressure may result in gastric reflux of food and acid into the esophagus (GASTROESOPHAGEAL REFLUX). Other disorders include hypermotility (spastic disorders) and markedly increased amplitude in contraction (nutcracker esophagus).

column1: C06.405.117.119.500.204*D017675*CREST Syndrome*A mild form of LIMITED SCLERODERMA
column2: a multi-system disorder. Its features include symptoms of CALCINOSIS; RAYNAUD DISEASE; ESOPHAGEAL MOTILITY DISORDERS; sclerodactyly
column3: and TELANGIECTASIS. When the defect in esophageal function is not prominent
column4: it is known as CRST syndrome.

column1: C06.405.117.119.500.432*D004931*Esophageal Achalasia*A motility disorder of the ESOPHAGUS in which the LOWER ESOPHAGEAL SPHINCTER (near the CARDIA) fails to relax resulting in functional obstruction of the esophagus
column2: and DYSPHAGIA. Achalasia is characterized by a grossly contorted and dilated esophagus (megaesophagus).
Diffuse*A hypermotility disorder of the ESOPHAGUS that is characterized by spastic non-peristaltic responses to SWALLOWING; CHEST PAIN; and DYSPHAGIA.

column1: C06.405.117.119.500.484*D005764*Gastroesophageal Reflux*Retrograde flow of gastric juice (GASTRIC ACID) and/or duodenal contents (BILE ACIDS; PANCREATIC JUICE) into the distal ESOPHAGUS
column2: commonly due to incompetence of the LOWER ESOPHAGEAL SPHINCTER.

column1: C06.405.117.119.500.484.500*D057045*Laryngopharyngeal Reflux*Back flow of gastric contents to the LARYNGOPHARYNX where it comes in contact with tissues of the upper aerodigestive tract. Laryngopharyngeal reflux is an extraesophageal manifestation of GASTROESOPHAGEAL REFLUX.
C06.405.117.119.500.484.500.500*D063466*Respiratory Aspiration of Gastric Contents*Inhaling refluxed gastric or duodenal contents.

C06.405.117.119.500.742*D011004*Plummer-Vinson Syndrome*A syndrome of DYSPHAGIA with IRON-DEFICIENCY ANEMIA that is due to congenital anomalies in the ESOPHAGUS (such as cervical esophageal webs). It is known as Patterson-Kelly syndrome in the United Kingdom.
C06.405.117.136*D045723*Diverticulosis
column2: Esophageal*A pathological condition characterized by the presence of a number of ESOPHAGEAL DIVERTICULA in the ESOPHAGUS.

column1: C06.405.117.240*D004932*Esophageal and Gastric Varices*Dilated blood vessels in the ESOPHAGUS or GASTRIC FUNDUS that shunt blood from the portal circulation (PORTAL SYSTEM) to the systemic venous circulation. Often they are observed in individuals with portal hypertension (HYPERTENSION
column2: PORTAL).

column1: C06.405.117.260*D004933*Esophageal Atresia*Congenital abnormality characterized by the lack of full development of the ESOPHAGUS that commonly occurs with TRACHEOESOPHAGEAL FISTULA. Symptoms include excessive SALIVATION; GAGGING; CYANOSIS; and DYSPNEA.
C06.405.117.316*D004934*Esophageal Cyst*Any fluid-filled closed cavity or sac (CYSTS) that is lined by an EPITHELIUM and found in the ESOPHAGUS region.
C06.405.117.367*D004937*Esophageal Fistula*Abnormal passage communicating with the ESOPHAGUS. The most common type is TRACHEOESOPHAGEAL FISTULA between the esophagus and the TRACHEA.
C06.405.117.367.725*D014138*Tracheoesophageal Fistula*Abnormal passage between the ESOPHAGUS and the TRACHEA
column2: acquired or congenital

column1: C06.405.117.430*D004938*Esophageal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the ESOPHAGUS.
C06.405.117.468*D004939*Esophageal Perforation*An opening or hole in the ESOPHAGUS that is caused by TRAUMA
column2: injury

column1: C06.405.117.468.524*D008309*Mallory-Weiss Syndrome*A condition characterized by mucosal tears at the ESOPHAGOGASTRIC JUNCTION
column2: sometimes with HEMATEMESIS. Typically it is caused by forceful bouts of retching or VOMITING.

column1: C06.405.117.544*D004940*Esophageal Stenosis*A stricture of the ESOPHAGUS. Most are acquired but can be congenital.
C06.405.117.620*D004941*Esophagitis*INFLAMMATION
column2: acute or chronic
column3: of the ESOPHAGUS caused by BACTERIA

column1: C06.405.117.620.209*D057765*Eosinophilic Esophagitis*Chronic ESOPHAGITIS characterized by esophageal mucosal EOSINOPHILIA. It is diagnosed when an increase in EOSINOPHILS are present over the entire esophagus. The reflux symptoms fail to respond to PROTON PUMP INHIBITORS treatment
column2: unlike in GASTROESOPHAGEAL REFLUX DISEASE. The symptoms are associated with IgE-mediated hypersensitivity to food or inhalant allergens.
Peptic*INFLAMMATION of the ESOPHAGUS that is caused by the reflux of GASTRIC JUICE with contents of the STOMACH and DUODENUM.

column1: C06.405.205*D005759*Gastroenteritis*INFLAMMATION of any segment of the GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT from ESOPHAGUS to RECTUM. Causes of gastroenteritis are many including genetic
column2: infection

column1: C06.405.205.099*D001064*Appendicitis*Acute inflammation of the APPENDIX. Acute appendicitis is classified as simple
column2: gangrenous

column1: C06.405.205.200*D017688*Cholera Morbus*An old term that is no longer used in the scientific literature. Cholera morbus refers to acute GASTROENTERITIS occurring in summer or autumn; characterized by severe cramps
column2: diarrhea

column1: C06.405.205.265*D003092*Colitis*Inflammation of the COLON section of the large intestine (INTESTINE
column2: LARGE)
column3: usually with symptoms such as DIARRHEA (often with blood and mucus)

column2: Ischemic*Inflammation of the COLON due to colonic ISCHEMIA resulting from alterations in systemic circulation or local vasculature.
Microscopic*A condition characterized by chronic watery DIARRHEA of unknown origin
column3: a normal COLONOSCOPY but abnormal histopathology on BIOPSY. This syndrome was first described in 1980 by Read and associates. Subtypes include COLLAGENOUS COLITIS and LYMPHOCYTIC COLITIS. Both have similar clinical symptoms and are distinguishable only by histology.

column2: Collagenous*A subtype of MICROSCOPIC COLITIS
column3: characterized by chronic watery DIARRHEA of unknown origin
column4: a normal COLONOSCOPY but abnormal histopathology on BIOPSY. Microscopic examination of biopsy samples taken from the COLON show larger-than-normal band of subepithelial COLLAGEN.

column2: Lymphocytic*A subtype of MICROSCOPIC COLITIS
column3: characterized by chronic watery DIARRHEA of unknown origin
column4: a normal COLONOSCOPY but abnormal histopathology on BIOPSY. Microscopic examination of biopsy samples taken from the COLON show infiltration of LYMPHOCYTES in the superficial EPITHELIUM and the underlying connective tissue (lamina propria).

column2: Ulcerative*Inflammation of the COLON that is predominantly confined to the MUCOSA. Its major symptoms include DIARRHEA

column1: C06.405.205.265.767*D011350*Proctocolitis*Inflammation of the RECTUM and the distal portion of the COLON.
C06.405.205.298*D004238*Diverticulitis*Inflammation of a DIVERTICULUM or diverticula.
C06.405.205.331*D004403*Dysentery*Acute inflammation of the intestine associated with infectious DIARRHEA of various etiologies
column2: generally acquired by eating contaminated food containing TOXINS
column3: BIOLOGICAL derived from BACTERIA or other microorganisms. Dysentery is characterized initially by watery FECES then by bloody mucoid stools. It is often associated with ABDOMINAL PAIN; FEVER; and DEHYDRATION.

column2: Amebic*DYSENTERY caused by intestinal amebic infection
column3: chiefly with ENTAMOEBA HISTOLYTICA. This condition may be associated with amebic infection of the LIVER and other distant sites.

column2: Bacillary*DYSENTERY caused by gram-negative rod-shaped enteric bacteria (ENTEROBACTERIACEAE)
column3: most often by the genus SHIGELLA. Shigella dysentery
column5: is classified into subgroups according to syndrome severity and the infectious species. Group A: SHIGELLA DYSENTERIAE (severest); Group B: SHIGELLA FLEXNERI; Group C: SHIGELLA BOYDII; and Group D: SHIGELLA SONNEI (mildest).

column1: C06.405.205.462*D004751*Enteritis*Inflammation of any segment of the SMALL INTESTINE.
C06.405.205.462.249*D004382*Duodenitis*Inflammation of the DUODENUM section of the small intestine (INTESTINE
column2: SMALL). Erosive duodenitis may cause bleeding in the UPPER GI TRACT and PEPTIC ULCER.

column1: C06.405.205.462.624*D007079*Ileitis*Inflammation of any segment of the ILEUM and the ILEOCECAL VALVE.

C06.405.205.462.624.500*D019449*Pouchitis*Acute INFLAMMATION in the INTESTINAL MUCOSA of the continent ileal reservoir (or pouch) in patients who have undergone ILEOSTOMY and restorative proctocolectomy (PROCTOCOLECTOMY
column2: RESTORATIVE).

column1: C06.405.205.596*D004760*Enterocolitis*Inflammation of the MUCOSA of both the SMALL INTESTINE and the LARGE INTESTINE. Etiology includes ISCHEMIA
column2: infections
Necrotizing*ENTEROCOLITIS with extensive ulceration (ULCER) and NECROSIS. It is observed primarily in LOW BIRTH WEIGHT INFANT.
Neutropenic*A syndrome characterized by inflammation in the ILEUM
column4: and the ASCENDING COLON. It is observed in cancer patients with CHEMOTHERAPY-induced NEUTROPENIA or in other immunocompromised individuals (IMMUNOCOMPROMISED HOST).

column2: Pseudomembranous*An acute inflammation of the INTESTINAL MUCOSA that is characterized by the presence of pseudomembranes or plaques in the SMALL INTESTINE (pseudomembranous enteritis) and the LARGE INTESTINE (pseudomembranous colitis). It is commonly associated with antibiotic therapy and CLOSTRIDIUM DIFFICILE colonization.

column1: C06.405.205.663*D004941*Esophagitis*INFLAMMATION
column2: acute or chronic
column3: of the ESOPHAGUS caused by BACTERIA

column1: C06.405.205.663.209*D057765*Eosinophilic Esophagitis*Chronic ESOPHAGITIS characterized by esophageal mucosal EOSINOPHILIA. It is diagnosed when an increase in EOSINOPHILS are present over the entire esophagus. The reflux symptoms fail to respond to PROTON PUMP INHIBITORS treatment
column2: unlike in GASTROESOPHAGEAL REFLUX DISEASE. The symptoms are associated with IgE-mediated hypersensitivity to food or inhalant allergens.
Peptic*INFLAMMATION of the ESOPHAGUS that is caused by the reflux of GASTRIC JUICE with contents of the STOMACH and DUODENUM.

column1: C06.405.205.697*D005756*Gastritis*Inflammation of the GASTRIC MUCOSA
column2: a lesion observed in a number of unrelated disorders.
Atrophic*GASTRITIS with atrophy of the GASTRIC MUCOSA
column4: and the mucosal glands leading to ACHLORHYDRIA. Atrophic gastritis usually progresses from chronic gastritis.

column2: Hypertrophic*GASTRITIS with HYPERTROPHY of the GASTRIC MUCOSA. It is characterized by giant gastric folds
column5: and HYPOPROTEINEMIA. Symptoms include VOMITING; DIARRHEA; and WEIGHT LOSS.

column1: C06.405.205.731*D015212*Inflammatory Bowel Diseases*Chronic
column2: non-specific inflammation of the GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT. Etiology may be genetic or environmental. This term includes CROHN DISEASE and ULCERATIVE COLITIS.
Ulcerative*Inflammation of the COLON that is predominantly confined to the MUCOSA. Its major symptoms include DIARRHEA

column1: C06.405.205.731.500*D003424*Crohn Disease*A chronic transmural inflammation that may involve any part of the DIGESTIVE TRACT from MOUTH to ANUS
column2: mostly found in the ILEUM
column4: and the COLON. In Crohn disease
column6: extending through the intestinal wall from the MUCOSA to the serosa
column7: is characteristically asymmetric and segmental. Epithelioid GRANULOMAS may be seen in some patients.

column1: C06.405.205.798*D052016*Mucositis*An INFLAMMATION of the MUCOSA with burning or tingling sensation. It is characterized by atrophy of the squamous EPITHELIUM
column2: vascular damage
column4: and ulceration. It usually occurs at the mucous lining of the MOUTH
column5: the GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT or the airway due to chemical irritations

column1: C06.405.205.865*D011349*Proctitis*INFLAMMATION of the MUCOUS MEMBRANE of the RECTUM
column2: the distal end of the large intestine (INTESTINE

column1: C06.405.205.865.790*D011350*Proctocolitis*Inflammation of the RECTUM and the distal portion of the COLON.
C06.405.205.932*D053706*Typhlitis*Necrotizing inflammation of the CECUM (typhlon in Greek)
column2: sometimes spreading to the APPENDIX and/or the ILEUM. Symptoms include ABDOMINAL PAIN and DIARRHEA. Its pathogenesis is multifactorial. Typhlitis is often associated with NEUTROPENIA and chemotherapy in immunocompromised individuals (IMMUNOCOMPROMISED HOST).

column1: C06.405.227*D006471*Gastrointestinal Hemorrhage*Bleeding in any segment of the GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT from ESOPHAGUS to RECTUM.
C06.405.227.400*D006396*Hematemesis*Vomiting of blood that is either fresh bright red
column2: or older coffee-ground in character. It generally indicates bleeding of the UPPER GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT.

column1: C06.405.227.600*D008551*Melena*The black
column2: tarry
column3: foul-smelling FECES that contain degraded blood.

column1: C06.405.227.700*D010438*Peptic Ulcer Hemorrhage*Bleeding from a PEPTIC ULCER that can be located in any segment of the GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT.
C06.405.249*D005770*Gastrointestinal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT
column2: from the MOUTH to the ANAL CANAL.

column1: C06.405.249.205*D004938*Esophageal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the ESOPHAGUS.

C06.405.249.308*D046152*Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumors*All tumors in the GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT arising from mesenchymal cells (MESODERM) except those of smooth muscle cells (LEIOMYOMA) or Schwann cells (SCHWANNOMA).
C06.405.249.411*D007414*Intestinal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the INTESTINES.
C06.405.249.411.184*D002430*Cecal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the CECUM.
C06.405.249.411.184.290*D001063*Appendiceal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the APPENDIX.

C06.405.249.411.307*D015179*Colorectal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the COLON or the RECTUM or both. Risk factors for colorectal cancer include chronic ULCERATIVE COLITIS; FAMILIAL POLYPOSIS COLI; exposure to ASBESTOS; and irradiation of the CERVIX UTERI.
C06.405.249.411.307.090*D011125*Adenomatous Polyposis Coli*A polyposis syndrome due to an autosomal dominant mutation of the APC genes (GENES
column2: APC) on CHROMOSOME 5. The syndrome is characterized by the development of hundreds of ADENOMATOUS POLYPS in the COLON and RECTUM of affected individuals by early adulthood.

column1: C06.405.249.411.307.090.500*D005736*Gardner Syndrome*A variant of ADENOMATOUS POLYPOSIS COLI caused by mutation in the APC gene (GENES
column2: APC) on CHROMOSOME 5. It is characterized by not only the presence of multiple colonic polyposis but also extracolonic ADENOMATOUS POLYPS in the UPPER GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT; the EYE; the SKIN; the SKULL; and the FACIAL BONES; as well as malignancy in organs other than the GI tract.

column1: C06.405.249.411.307.180*D003110*Colonic Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the COLON.
C06.405.249.411.307.180.800*D012811*Sigmoid Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the SIGMOID COLON.
C06.405.249.411.307.190*D003123*Colorectal Neoplasms
column2: Hereditary Nonpolyposis*A group of autosomal-dominant inherited diseases in which COLON CANCER arises in discrete adenomas. Unlike FAMILIAL POLYPOSIS COLI with hundreds of polyps
column3: hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal neoplasms occur much later
column4: in the fourth and fifth decades. HNPCC has been associated with germline mutations in mismatch repair (MMR) genes. It has been subdivided into Lynch syndrome I or site-specific colonic cancer
column5: and LYNCH SYNDROME II which includes extracolonic cancer.

column1: C06.405.249.411.307.790*D012004*Rectal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the RECTUM.

C06.405.249.411.501*D007078*Ileal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer in the ILEUM region of the small intestine (INTESTINE
column2: SMALL).

column1: C06.405.249.411.512*D007161*Immunoproliferative Small Intestinal Disease*A condition that is caused by HYPERPLASIA of LYMPHOCYTES in the small intestine (INTESTINE
column2: SMALL) and the mesenteric LYMPH NODES. These lymphocytes produce an anomalous alpha heavy chain protein. Generally
column3: these IPSID patients have either concurrent LYMPHOMA or develop lymphoma within a few years. The disease was first described in the Mediterranean region and is characterized by malabsorption; WEIGHT LOSS; DIARRHEA; and STEATORRHEA.

column1: C06.405.249.411.523*D007580*Jejunal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer in the JEJUNUM region of the small intestine (INTESTINE
column2: SMALL).

column1: C06.405.249.767*D013274*Stomach Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the STOMACH.
C06.405.249.883*D015043*Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome*A syndrome that is characterized by the triad of severe PEPTIC ULCER
column2: hypersecretion of GASTRIC ACID
column3: and GASTRIN-producing tumors of the PANCREAS or other tissue (GASTRINOMA). This syndrome may be sporadic or be associated with MULTIPLE ENDOCRINE NEOPLASIA TYPE 1.

column1: C06.405.469*D007410*Intestinal Diseases*Pathological processes in any segment of the INTESTINE from DUODENUM to RECTUM.
C06.405.469.110*D002429*Cecal Diseases*Pathological developments in the CECUM.
C06.405.469.110.207*D001064*Appendicitis*Acute inflammation of the APPENDIX. Acute appendicitis is classified as simple
column2: gangrenous

column1: C06.405.469.110.417*D002430*Cecal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the CECUM.
C06.405.469.110.417.290*D001063*Appendiceal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the APPENDIX.
C06.405.469.110.708*D053706*Typhlitis*Necrotizing inflammation of the CECUM (typhlon in Greek)
column2: sometimes spreading to the APPENDIX and/or the ILEUM. Symptoms include ABDOMINAL PAIN and DIARRHEA. Its pathogenesis is multifactorial. Typhlitis is often associated with NEUTROPENIA and chemotherapy in immunocompromised individuals (IMMUNOCOMPROMISED HOST).

column1: C06.405.469.158*D003108*Colonic Diseases*Pathological processes in the COLON region of the large intestine (INTESTINE
column2: LARGE).

column1: C06.405.469.158.093*D059269*Chilaiditi Syndrome*Interposition of a portion of the colon (e.g.
column2: SIGMOID COLON) between the liver and the diaphragm. It is associated with abdominal pain
column5: anorexia and volvulus. Chilaiditi anomaly refers to asymptomatic interposition.

column1: C06.405.469.158.188*D003092*Colitis*Inflammation of the COLON section of the large intestine (INTESTINE
column2: LARGE)
column3: usually with symptoms such as DIARRHEA (often with blood and mucus)

column2: Ischemic*Inflammation of the COLON due to colonic ISCHEMIA resulting from alterations in systemic circulation or local vasculature.
Microscopic*A condition characterized by chronic watery DIARRHEA of unknown origin
column3: a normal COLONOSCOPY but abnormal histopathology on BIOPSY. This syndrome was first described in 1980 by Read and associates. Subtypes include COLLAGENOUS COLITIS and LYMPHOCYTIC COLITIS. Both have similar clinical symptoms and are distinguishable only by histology.

column2: Collagenous*A subtype of MICROSCOPIC COLITIS
column3: characterized by chronic watery DIARRHEA of unknown origin
column4: a normal COLONOSCOPY but abnormal histopathology on BIOPSY. Microscopic examination of biopsy samples taken from the COLON show larger-than-normal band of subepithelial COLLAGEN.

column2: Lymphocytic*A subtype of MICROSCOPIC COLITIS
column3: characterized by chronic watery DIARRHEA of unknown origin
column4: a normal COLONOSCOPY but abnormal histopathology on BIOPSY. Microscopic examination of biopsy samples taken from the COLON show infiltration of LYMPHOCYTES in the superficial EPITHELIUM and the underlying connective tissue (lamina propria).

column2: Ulcerative*Inflammation of the COLON that is predominantly confined to the MUCOSA. Its major symptoms include DIARRHEA

column1: C06.405.469.158.188.767*D011350*Proctocolitis*Inflammation of the RECTUM and the distal portion of the COLON.

column2: Functional*Chronic or recurrent colonic disorders without an identifiable structural or biochemical explanation. The widely recognized IRRITABLE BOWEL SYNDROME falls into this category.

column1: C06.405.469.158.272.217*D003112*Colonic Pseudo-Obstruction*Functional obstruction of the COLON leading to MEGACOLON in the absence of obvious COLONIC DISEASES or mechanical obstruction. When this condition is acquired
column2: acute
column3: and coexisting with another medical condition (trauma

column1: C06.405.469.158.272.608*D043183*Irritable Bowel Syndrome*A disorder with chronic or recurrent colonic symptoms without a clearcut etiology. This condition is characterized by chronic or recurrent ABDOMINAL PAIN
column2: bloating
column4: and an erratic disturbance of DEFECATION.

column1: C06.405.469.158.272.804*D055496*Neurogenic Bowel*Loss or absence of normal intestinal function due to nerve damage or birth defects. It is characterized by the inability to control the elimination of stool from the body.

C06.405.469.158.356*D015179*Colorectal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the COLON or the RECTUM or both. Risk factors for colorectal cancer include chronic ULCERATIVE COLITIS; FAMILIAL POLYPOSIS COLI; exposure to ASBESTOS; and irradiation of the CERVIX UTERI.

column2: Hereditary Nonpolyposis*A group of autosomal-dominant inherited diseases in which COLON CANCER arises in discrete adenomas. Unlike FAMILIAL POLYPOSIS COLI with hundreds of polyps
column3: hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal neoplasms occur much later
column4: in the fourth and fifth decades. HNPCC has been associated with germline mutations in mismatch repair (MMR) genes. It has been subdivided into Lynch syndrome I or site-specific colonic cancer
column5: and LYNCH SYNDROME II which includes extracolonic cancer.

column2: Colonic*A pathological condition characterized by the presence of a number of COLONIC DIVERTICULA in the COLON. Its pathogenesis is multifactorial
Colonic*Inflammation of the COLONIC DIVERTICULA
column3: generally with abscess formation and subsequent perforation.

column1: C06.405.469.158.701*D008531*Megacolon*Dilatation of the COLON
column2: often to alarming dimensions. There are various types of megacolon including congenital megacolon in HIRSCHSPRUNG DISEASE

column1: C06.405.469.158.701.439*D006627*Hirschsprung Disease*Congenital MEGACOLON resulting from the absence of ganglion cells (aganglionosis) in a distal segment of the LARGE INTESTINE. The aganglionic segment is permanently contracted thus causing dilatation proximal to it. In most cases
column2: the aganglionic segment is within the RECTUM and SIGMOID COLON.
Toxic*An acute form of MEGACOLON
column3: severe pathological dilatation of the COLON. It is associated with clinical conditions such as ULCERATIVE COLITIS; CROHN DISEASE; AMEBIC DYSENTERY; or CLOSTRIDIUM ENTEROCOLITIS.

column1: C06.405.469.158.850*D012810*Sigmoid Diseases*Pathological processes in the SIGMOID COLON region of the large intestine (INTESTINE
column2: LARGE).

column1: C06.405.469.158.850.790*D011350*Proctocolitis*Inflammation of the RECTUM and the distal portion of the COLON.
C06.405.469.158.850.850*D012811*Sigmoid Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the SIGMOID COLON.
C06.405.469.275*D004378*Duodenal Diseases*Pathological conditions in the DUODENUM region of the small intestine (INTESTINE
column2: SMALL).

column1: C06.405.469.275.270*D004379*Duodenal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the DUODENUM.
C06.405.469.275.395*D004380*Duodenal Obstruction*Hindrance of the passage of luminal contents in the DUODENUM. Duodenal obstruction can be partial or complete
column2: and caused by intrinsic or extrinsic factors. Simple obstruction is associated with diminished or stopped flow of luminal contents. Strangulating obstruction is associated with impaired blood flow to the duodenum in addition to obstructed flow of luminal contents.

column1: C06.405.469.275.395.890*D013478*Superior Mesenteric Artery Syndrome*DUODENAL OBSTRUCTION by the superior mesenteric artery (MESENTERIC ARTERY
column2: SUPERIOR) which travels in the root of the MESENTERY and crosses over the DUODENUM. The syndrome is characterized by the dilated proximal duodenum and STOMACH
column5: and VOMITING. Often it is observed in patient with body casts after spinal surgery.

column1: C06.405.469.275.600*D004382*Duodenitis*Inflammation of the DUODENUM section of the small intestine (INTESTINE
column2: SMALL). Erosive duodenitis may cause bleeding in the UPPER GI TRACT and PEPTIC ULCER.

column1: C06.405.469.275.700*D004383*Duodenogastric Reflux*Retrograde flow of duodenal contents (BILE ACIDS; PANCREATIC JUICE) into the STOMACH.

C06.405.469.275.800*D010437*Peptic Ulcer*Ulcer that occurs in the regions of the GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT which come into contact with GASTRIC JUICE containing PEPSIN and GASTRIC ACID. It occurs when there are defects in the MUCOSA barrier. The common forms of peptic ulcers are associated with HELICOBACTER PYLORI and the consumption of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDS).
C06.405.469.275.800.348*D004381*Duodenal Ulcer*A PEPTIC ULCER located in the DUODENUM.

column2: Peptic*INFLAMMATION of the ESOPHAGUS that is caused by the reflux of GASTRIC JUICE with contents of the STOMACH and DUODENUM.

column1: C06.405.469.275.800.698*D010439*Peptic Ulcer Perforation*Penetration of a PEPTIC ULCER through the wall of DUODENUM or STOMACH allowing the leakage of luminal contents into the PERITONEAL CAVITY.

C06.405.469.275.800.849*D013276*Stomach Ulcer*Ulceration of the GASTRIC MUCOSA due to contact with GASTRIC JUICE. It is often associated with HELICOBACTER PYLORI infection or consumption of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDS).
C06.405.469.275.800.924*D015043*Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome*A syndrome that is characterized by the triad of severe PEPTIC ULCER
column2: hypersecretion of GASTRIC ACID
column3: and GASTRIN-producing tumors of the PANCREAS or other tissue (GASTRINOMA). This syndrome may be sporadic or be associated with MULTIPLE ENDOCRINE NEOPLASIA TYPE 1.

column1: C06.405.469.300*D004403*Dysentery*Acute inflammation of the intestine associated with infectious DIARRHEA of various etiologies
column2: generally acquired by eating contaminated food containing TOXINS
column3: BIOLOGICAL derived from BACTERIA or other microorganisms. Dysentery is characterized initially by watery FECES then by bloody mucoid stools. It is often associated with ABDOMINAL PAIN; FEVER; and DEHYDRATION.

column2: Amebic*DYSENTERY caused by intestinal amebic infection
column3: chiefly with ENTAMOEBA HISTOLYTICA. This condition may be associated with amebic infection of the LIVER and other distant sites.

column2: Bacillary*DYSENTERY caused by gram-negative rod-shaped enteric bacteria (ENTEROBACTERIACEAE)
column3: most often by the genus SHIGELLA. Shigella dysentery
column5: is classified into subgroups according to syndrome severity and the infectious species. Group A: SHIGELLA DYSENTERIAE (severest); Group B: SHIGELLA FLEXNERI; Group C: SHIGELLA BOYDII; and Group D: SHIGELLA SONNEI (mildest).

column1: C06.405.469.326*D004751*Enteritis*Inflammation of any segment of the SMALL INTESTINE.
C06.405.469.326.750*D004382*Duodenitis*Inflammation of the DUODENUM section of the small intestine (INTESTINE
column2: SMALL). Erosive duodenitis may cause bleeding in the UPPER GI TRACT and PEPTIC ULCER.

column1: C06.405.469.326.875*D007079*Ileitis*Inflammation of any segment of the ILEUM and the ILEOCECAL VALVE.

C06.405.469.326.875.500*D019449*Pouchitis*Acute INFLAMMATION in the INTESTINAL MUCOSA of the continent ileal reservoir (or pouch) in patients who have undergone ILEOSTOMY and restorative proctocolectomy (PROCTOCOLECTOMY
column2: RESTORATIVE).

column1: C06.405.469.363*D004760*Enterocolitis*Inflammation of the MUCOSA of both the SMALL INTESTINE and the LARGE INTESTINE. Etiology includes ISCHEMIA
column2: infections
Necrotizing*ENTEROCOLITIS with extensive ulceration (ULCER) and NECROSIS. It is observed primarily in LOW BIRTH WEIGHT INFANT.
Neutropenic*A syndrome characterized by inflammation in the ILEUM
column4: and the ASCENDING COLON. It is observed in cancer patients with CHEMOTHERAPY-induced NEUTROPENIA or in other immunocompromised individuals (IMMUNOCOMPROMISED HOST).

column2: Pseudomembranous*An acute inflammation of the INTESTINAL MUCOSA that is characterized by the presence of pseudomembranes or plaques in the SMALL INTESTINE (pseudomembranous enteritis) and the LARGE INTESTINE (pseudomembranous colitis). It is commonly associated with antibiotic therapy and CLOSTRIDIUM DIFFICILE colonization.

column1: C06.405.469.400*D019053*HIV Enteropathy*A syndrome characterized by chronic
column2: well-established DIARRHEA (greater than one month in duration) without an identified infectious cause after thorough evaluation
column3: in an HIV-positive individual. It is thought to be due to direct or indirect effects of HIV on the enteric mucosa. HIV enteropathy is a diagnosis of exclusion and can be made only after other forms of diarrheal illness have been ruled out. (Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine

column1: C06.405.469.420*D007077*Ileal Diseases*Pathological development in the ILEUM including the ILEOCECAL VALVE.

column2: RESTORATIVE).

column1: C06.405.469.432*D015212*Inflammatory Bowel Diseases*Chronic
column2: non-specific inflammation of the GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT. Etiology may be genetic or environmental. This term includes CROHN DISEASE and ULCERATIVE COLITIS.
Ulcerative*Inflammation of the COLON that is predominantly confined to the MUCOSA. Its major symptoms include DIARRHEA

column1: C06.405.469.432.500*D003424*Crohn Disease*A chronic transmural inflammation that may involve any part of the DIGESTIVE TRACT from MOUTH to ANUS
column2: mostly found in the ILEUM
column4: and the COLON. In Crohn disease
column6: extending through the intestinal wall from the MUCOSA to the serosa
column7: is characteristically asymmetric and segmental. Epithelioid GRANULOMAS may be seen in some patients.

column1: C06.405.469.445*D007409*Intestinal Atresia*Congenital obliteration of the lumen of the intestine
column2: with the ILEUM involved in 50% of the cases and the JEJUNUM and DUODENUM following in frequency. It is the most frequent cause of INTESTINAL OBSTRUCTION in NEWBORNS. (From Stedman

column1: C06.405.469.452*D007411*Intestinal Diseases
column2: Parasitic*Infections of the INTESTINES with PARASITES
column3: commonly involving PARASITIC WORMS. Infections with roundworms (NEMATODE INFECTIONS) and tapeworms (CESTODE INFECTIONS) are also known as HELMINTHIASIS.

column1: C06.405.469.452.060*D017129*Anisakiasis*Infection with roundworms of the genus ANISAKIS. Human infection results from the consumption of fish harboring roundworm larvae. The worms may cause acute NAUSEA; VOMITING; or penetrate into the wall of the DIGESTIVE TRACT where they give rise to EOSINOPHILIC GRANULOMA in the STOMACH; INTESTINES; or the OMENTUM.
C06.405.469.452.146*D001447*Balantidiasis*Infection by parasites of the genus BALANTIDIUM. The presence of Balantidium in the LARGE INTESTINE leads to DIARRHEA; DYSENTERY; and occasionally ULCER.

C06.405.469.452.250*D016776*Blastocystis Infections*Infections with organisms of the genus BLASTOCYSTIS. The species B. hominis is responsible for most infections. Parasitologic surveys have generally found small numbers of this species in human stools
column2: but higher positivity rates and organism numbers in AIDS patients and other immunosuppressed patients (IMMUNOCOMPROMISED HOST). Symptoms include ABDOMINAL PAIN; DIARRHEA; CONSTIPATION; VOMITING; and FATIGUE.

column1: C06.405.469.452.269*D003457*Cryptosporidiosis*Intestinal infection with organisms of the genus CRYPTOSPORIDIUM. It occurs in both animals and humans. Symptoms include severe DIARRHEA.
C06.405.469.452.275*D004030*Dientamoebiasis*Gastrointestinal infection with organisms of the genus DIENTAMOEBA.

column2: Amebic*DYSENTERY caused by intestinal amebic infection
column3: chiefly with ENTAMOEBA HISTOLYTICA. This condition may be associated with amebic infection of the LIVER and other distant sites.

column1: C06.405.469.452.481*D005873*Giardiasis*An infection of the SMALL INTESTINE caused by the flagellated protozoan GIARDIA LAMBLIA. It is spread via contaminated food and water and by direct person-to-person contact.

column1: C06.405.469.471.600*D012003*Rectal Fistula*An abnormal anatomical passage connecting the RECTUM to the outside
