column1: C06.405.469.531.568*D045822*Intestinal Volvulus*A twisting in the intestine (INTESTINES) that can cause INTESTINAL OBSTRUCTION.
C06.405.469.531.577*D007443*Intussusception*A form of intestinal obstruction caused by the PROLAPSE of a part of the intestine into the adjoining intestinal lumen. There are four types: colic
column2: involving segments of the LARGE INTESTINE; enteric
column3: involving only the SMALL INTESTINE; ileocecal
column4: in which the ILEOCECAL VALVE prolapses into the CECUM
column5: drawing the ILEUM along with it; and ileocolic
column6: in which the ileum prolapses through the ileocecal valve into the COLON.

column1: C06.405.469.557*D007416*Intestinal Perforation*Opening or penetration through the wall of the INTESTINES.
C06.405.469.578*D044483*Intestinal Polyposis*The growth of INTESTINAL POLYPS. Growth processes include neoplastic (ADENOMA and CARCINOMA) and non-neoplastic (hyperplastic
column2: mucosal

column1: C06.405.469.578.249*D011125*Adenomatous Polyposis Coli*A polyposis syndrome due to an autosomal dominant mutation of the APC genes (GENES
column2: APC) on CHROMOSOME 5. The syndrome is characterized by the development of hundreds of ADENOMATOUS POLYPS in the COLON and RECTUM of affected individuals by early adulthood.

column1: C06.405.469.578.249.393*D005736*Gardner Syndrome*A variant of ADENOMATOUS POLYPOSIS COLI caused by mutation in the APC gene (GENES
column2: APC) on CHROMOSOME 5. It is characterized by not only the presence of multiple colonic polyposis but also extracolonic ADENOMATOUS POLYPS in the UPPER GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT; the EYE; the SKIN; the SKULL; and the FACIAL BONES; as well as malignancy in organs other than the GI tract.

column1: C06.405.469.578.750*D010580*Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome*A hereditary disease caused by autosomal dominant mutations involving CHROMOSOME 19. It is characterized by the presence of INTESTINAL POLYPS
column2: consistently in the JEJUNUM
column3: and mucocutaneous pigmentation with MELANIN spots of the lips

column1: C06.405.469.600*D007579*Jejunal Diseases*Pathological development in the JEJUNUM region of the SMALL INTESTINE.
C06.405.469.600.523*D007580*Jejunal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer in the JEJUNUM region of the small intestine (INTESTINE
column2: SMALL).

column1: C06.405.469.637*D008286*Malabsorption Syndromes*General term for a group of MALNUTRITION syndromes caused by failure of normal INTESTINAL ABSORPTION of nutrients.
C06.405.469.637.145*D001765*Blind Loop Syndrome*A malabsorption syndrome that is associated with a blind loop in the upper SMALL INTESTINE that is characterized by the lack of peristaltic movement
column2: stasis of INTESTINAL CONTENTS
column3: and the overgrowth of BACTERIA. Such bacterial overgrowth interferes with BILE SALTS action
column6: and the ABSORPTION of nutrients such as VITAMIN B12 and FOLIC ACID.

column1: C06.405.469.637.250*D002446*Celiac Disease*A malabsorption syndrome that is precipitated by the ingestion of foods containing GLUTEN
column2: such as wheat
column4: and barley. It is characterized by INFLAMMATION of the SMALL INTESTINE

column1: C06.405.469.637.378*D064068*Collagenous Sprue*A malabsorption syndrome characterized by collagenous mucosal lesions of the SMALL INTESTINE
column2: atrophy of MICROVILLI
column5: and MALNUTRITION often refractory to a gluten-free diet.

column1: C06.405.469.637.506*D007787*Lactose Intolerance*The condition resulting from the absence or deficiency of LACTASE in the MUCOSA cells of the GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT
column2: and the inability to break down LACTOSE in milk for ABSORPTION. Bacterial fermentation of the unabsorbed lactose leads to symptoms that range from a mild indigestion (DYSPEPSIA) to severe DIARRHEA. Lactose intolerance may be an inborn error or acquired.

column1: C06.405.469.637.832*D012778*Short Bowel Syndrome*A malabsorption syndrome resulting from extensive operative resection of the SMALL INTESTINE
column2: the absorptive region of the GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT.
Tropical*A chronic malabsorption syndrome
column3: occurring mainly in residents of or visitors to the tropics or subtropics. The failed INTESTINAL ABSORPTION of nutrients from the SMALL INTESTINE results in MALNUTRITION and ANEMIA that is due to FOLIC ACID deficiency.

column1: C06.405.469.637.887*D045602*Steatorrhea*A condition that is characterized by chronic fatty DIARRHEA
column2: a result of abnormal DIGESTION and/or INTESTINAL ABSORPTION of FATS.

column1: C06.405.469.637.925*D008061*Whipple Disease*A chronic systemic infection by a gram-positive bacterium
column2: Tropheryma whippelii
column3: mainly affecting the SMALL INTESTINE but also the JOINTS; CARDIOVASCULAR SYSTEM; and the CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM. The disease is characterized by fat deposits in the INTESTINAL MUCOSA and LYMPH NODES

column1: C06.405.469.656*D065666*Mesenteric Ischemia*Ischemic tissue injury produced by insufficient perfusion of intestinal tissue by the MESENTERIC CIRCULATION (i.e.
column2: CELIAC ARTERY; SUPERIOR MESENTERIC ARTERY; INFERERIOR MESENTERIC ARTERY; and MESENTERIC VEINS). It can progress from ISCHEMIA; EDEMA; and GANGRENE of the bowel wall to PERITONITIS and cardiovascular collapse.

column1: C06.405.469.675*D008641*Mesenteric Vascular Occlusion*Obstruction of the flow in the SPLANCHNIC CIRCULATION by ATHEROSCLEROSIS; EMBOLISM; THROMBOSIS; STENOSIS; TRAUMA; and compression or intrinsic pressure from adjacent tumors. Rare causes are drugs
column2: intestinal parasites
column3: and vascular immunoinflammatory diseases such as PERIARTERITIS NODOSA and THROMBOANGIITIS OBLITERANS. (From Juergens et al.

column1: C06.405.469.778*D011006*Pneumatosis Cystoides Intestinalis*A condition characterized by the presence of multiple gas-filled cysts in the intestinal wall
column2: the submucosa and/or subserosa of the INTESTINE. The majority of the cysts are found in the JEJUNUM and the ILEUM.

column1: C06.405.469.818*D011504*Protein-Losing Enteropathies*Pathological conditions in the INTESTINES that are characterized by the gastrointestinal loss of serum proteins
column2: including SERUM ALBUMIN; IMMUNOGLOBULINS; and at times LYMPHOCYTES. Severe condition can result in HYPOGAMMAGLOBULINEMIA or LYMPHOPENIA. Protein-losing enteropathies are associated with a number of diseases including INTESTINAL LYMPHANGIECTASIS; WHIPPLE'S DISEASE; and NEOPLASMS of the SMALL INTESTINE.

column1: C06.405.469.860*D012002*Rectal Diseases*Pathological developments in the RECTUM region of the large intestine (INTESTINE
column2: LARGE).

column1: C06.405.469.860.101*D001004*Anus Diseases*Diseases involving the ANUS.
C06.405.469.860.101.163*D001005*Anus Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the ANAL CANAL.
C06.405.469.860.101.163.083*D000694*Anal Gland Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the anal gland.

C06.405.469.860.101.430*D005401*Fissure in Ano*A painful linear ulcer at the margin of the anus. It appears as a crack or slit in the mucous membrane of the anus and is very painful and difficult to heal. (Dorland
column2: 27th ed & Stedman

column1: C06.405.469.860.101.752*D011538*Pruritus Ani*Intense chronic itching in the anal area.

C06.405.469.860.180*D015179*Colorectal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the COLON or the RECTUM or both. Risk factors for colorectal cancer include chronic ULCERATIVE COLITIS; FAMILIAL POLYPOSIS COLI; exposure to ASBESTOS; and irradiation of the CERVIX UTERI.
C06.405.469.860.180.500*D012004*Rectal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the RECTUM.
C06.405.469.860.180.500.040*D001005*Anus Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the ANAL CANAL.
C06.405.469.860.180.500.040.040*D000694*Anal Gland Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the anal gland.
C06.405.469.860.300*D005242*Fecal Incontinence*Failure of voluntary control of the anal sphincters
column2: with involuntary passage of feces and flatus.

column1: C06.405.469.860.401*D006484*Hemorrhoids*Swollen veins in the lower part of the RECTUM or ANUS. Hemorrhoids can be inside the anus (internal)
column2: under the skin around the anus (external)
column3: or protruding from inside to outside of the anus. People with hemorrhoids may or may not exhibit symptoms which include bleeding

column1: C06.405.469.860.622*D011349*Proctitis*INFLAMMATION of the MUCOUS MEMBRANE of the RECTUM
column2: the distal end of the large intestine (INTESTINE

column1: C06.405.469.860.622.790*D011350*Proctocolitis*Inflammation of the RECTUM and the distal portion of the COLON.
C06.405.469.860.752*D012003*Rectal Fistula*An abnormal anatomical passage connecting the RECTUM to the outside
column2: with an orifice at the site of drainage.

column1: C06.405.469.860.752.650*D012006*Rectovaginal Fistula*An abnormal anatomical passage between the RECTUM and the VAGINA.

C06.405.469.860.800*D012005*Rectal Prolapse*Protrusion of the rectal mucous membrane through the anus. There are various degrees: incomplete with no displacement of the anal sphincter muscle; complete with displacement of the anal sphincter muscle; complete with no displacement of the anal sphincter muscle but with herniation of the bowel; and internal complete with rectosigmoid or upper rectum intussusception into the lower rectum.
C06.405.469.860.810*D020047*Rectocele*Herniation of the RECTUM into the VAGINA.
C06.405.469.965*D015043*Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome*A syndrome that is characterized by the triad of severe PEPTIC ULCER
column2: hypersecretion of GASTRIC ACID
column3: and GASTRIN-producing tumors of the PANCREAS or other tissue (GASTRINOMA). This syndrome may be sporadic or be associated with MULTIPLE ENDOCRINE NEOPLASIA TYPE 1.

column1: C06.405.748*D013272*Stomach Diseases*Pathological processes involving the STOMACH.
C06.405.748.045*D000126*Achlorhydria*A lack of HYDROCHLORIC ACID in GASTRIC JUICE despite stimulation of gastric secretion.
C06.405.748.142*D045724*Diverticulosis
column2: Stomach*A pathological condition characterized by the presence of a number of GASTRIC DIVERTICULA in the STOMACH.

column1: C06.405.748.240*D004383*Duodenogastric Reflux*Retrograde flow of duodenal contents (BILE ACIDS; PANCREATIC JUICE) into the STOMACH.

C06.405.748.240.140*D001655*Bile Reflux*Retrograde bile flow. Reflux of bile can be from the duodenum to the stomach (DUODENOGASTRIC REFLUX); to the esophagus (GASTROESOPHAGEAL REFLUX); or to the PANCREAS.

C06.405.748.280*D020252*Gastric Antral Vascular Ectasia*A distinct vascular lesion in the PYLORIC ANTRUM that is characterized by tortuous dilated blood vessels (ectasia) radiating outward from the PYLORUS. The vessel pattern resembles the stripes on the surface of a watermelon. This lesion causes both acute and chronic GASTROINTESTINAL HEMORRHAGE.

C06.405.748.300*D013271*Gastric Dilatation*Abnormal distention of the STOMACH due to accumulation of gastric contents that may reach 10 to 15 liters. Gastric dilatation may be the result of GASTRIC OUTLET OBSTRUCTION; ILEUS; GASTROPARESIS; or denervation.

C06.405.748.340*D017219*Gastric Outlet Obstruction*The hindering of output from the STOMACH into the SMALL INTESTINE. This obstruction may be of mechanical or functional origin such as EDEMA from PEPTIC ULCER; NEOPLASMS; FOREIGN BODIES; or AGING.
C06.405.748.340.690*D011707*Pyloric Stenosis*Narrowing of the pyloric canal with varied etiology. A common form is due to muscle hypertrophy (PYLORIC STENOSIS
column2: HYPERTROPHIC) seen in infants.
Hypertrophic*Narrowing of the pyloric canal due to HYPERTROPHY of the surrounding circular muscle. It is usually seen in infants or young children.

column1: C06.405.748.398*D005756*Gastritis*Inflammation of the GASTRIC MUCOSA
column2: a lesion observed in a number of unrelated disorders.
Atrophic*GASTRITIS with atrophy of the GASTRIC MUCOSA
column4: and the mucosal glands leading to ACHLORHYDRIA. Atrophic gastritis usually progresses from chronic gastritis.

column2: Hypertrophic*GASTRITIS with HYPERTROPHY of the GASTRIC MUCOSA. It is characterized by giant gastric folds
column5: and HYPOPROTEINEMIA. Symptoms include VOMITING; DIARRHEA; and WEIGHT LOSS.

column1: C06.405.748.543*D018589*Gastroparesis*Chronic delayed gastric emptying. Gastroparesis may be caused by motor dysfunction or paralysis of STOMACH muscles or may be associated with other systemic diseases such as DIABETES MELLITUS.

C06.405.748.586*D010437*Peptic Ulcer*Ulcer that occurs in the regions of the GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT which come into contact with GASTRIC JUICE containing PEPSIN and GASTRIC ACID. It occurs when there are defects in the MUCOSA barrier. The common forms of peptic ulcers are associated with HELICOBACTER PYLORI and the consumption of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDS).
C06.405.748.586.349*D004381*Duodenal Ulcer*A PEPTIC ULCER located in the DUODENUM.

column2: Peptic*INFLAMMATION of the ESOPHAGUS that is caused by the reflux of GASTRIC JUICE with contents of the STOMACH and DUODENUM.

column1: C06.405.748.586.698*D010439*Peptic Ulcer Perforation*Penetration of a PEPTIC ULCER through the wall of DUODENUM or STOMACH allowing the leakage of luminal contents into the PERITONEAL CAVITY.

C06.405.748.586.849*D013276*Stomach Ulcer*Ulceration of the GASTRIC MUCOSA due to contact with GASTRIC JUICE. It is often associated with HELICOBACTER PYLORI infection or consumption of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDS).
C06.405.748.586.924*D015043*Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome*A syndrome that is characterized by the triad of severe PEPTIC ULCER
column2: hypersecretion of GASTRIC ACID
column3: and GASTRIN-producing tumors of the PANCREAS or other tissue (GASTRINOMA). This syndrome may be sporadic or be associated with MULTIPLE ENDOCRINE NEOPLASIA TYPE 1.

column1: C06.405.748.630*D011178*Postgastrectomy Syndromes*Sequelae of gastrectomy from the second week after operation on. Include recurrent or anastomotic ulcer
column2: postprandial syndromes (DUMPING SYNDROME and late postprandial hypoglycemia)

column1: C06.405.748.630.310*D004377*Dumping Syndrome*Gastrointestinal symptoms resulting from an absent or nonfunctioning pylorus.
C06.405.748.789*D013274*Stomach Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the STOMACH.
C06.405.748.824*D013275*Stomach Rupture*Bursting of the STOMACH.
C06.405.748.895*D013277*Stomach Volvulus*Twisting of the STOMACH that may result in gastric ISCHEMIA and GASTRIC OUTLET OBSTRUCTION. It is often associated with DIAPHRAGMATIC HERNIA.
C06.405.748.947*D015043*Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome*A syndrome that is characterized by the triad of severe PEPTIC ULCER
column2: hypersecretion of GASTRIC ACID
column3: and GASTRIN-producing tumors of the PANCREAS or other tissue (GASTRINOMA). This syndrome may be sporadic or be associated with MULTIPLE ENDOCRINE NEOPLASIA TYPE 1.

column1: C06.405.874*D014385*Tuberculosis
column2: Gastrointestinal*TUBERCULOSIS that involves any region of the GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT
column3: mostly in the distal ILEUM and the CECUM. In most cases
column4: MYCOBACTERIUM TUBERCULOSIS is the pathogen. Clinical features include ABDOMINAL PAIN; FEVER; and palpable mass in the ileocecal area.

column1: C06.405.937*D014782*Visceral Prolapse*The prolapse or downward displacement of the VISCERA.
C06.552*D008107*Liver Diseases*Pathological processes of the LIVER.
C06.552.074*D019896*alpha 1-Antitrypsin Deficiency*Deficiency of the protease inhibitor ALPHA 1-ANTITRYPSIN that manifests primarily as PULMONARY EMPHYSEMA and LIVER CIRRHOSIS.
C06.552.150*D002780*Cholestasis
column2: Intrahepatic*Impairment of bile flow due to injury to the HEPATOCYTES; BILE CANALICULI; or the intrahepatic bile ducts (BILE DUCTS

column1: C06.552.150.125*D016738*Alagille Syndrome*A multisystem disorder that is characterized by aplasia of intrahepatic bile ducts (BILE DUCTS
column2: INTRAHEPATIC)
column3: and malformations in the cardiovascular system
column6: and the facies. Major clinical features include JAUNDICE
column7: and congenital heart disease with peripheral PULMONARY STENOSIS. Alagille syndrome may result from heterogeneous gene mutations
column8: including mutations in JAG1 on CHROMOSOME 20 (Type 1) and NOTCH2 on CHROMOSOME 1 (Type 2).

column1: C06.552.150.250*D008105*Liver Cirrhosis
column2: Biliary*FIBROSIS of the hepatic parenchyma due to obstruction of BILE flow (CHOLESTASIS) in the intrahepatic or extrahepatic bile ducts (BILE DUCTS
column4: EXTRAHEPATIC). Primary biliary cirrhosis involves the destruction of small intra-hepatic bile ducts and bile secretion. Secondary biliary cirrhosis is produced by prolonged obstruction of large intrahepatic or extrahepatic bile ducts from a variety of causes.

column1: C06.552.195*D056486*Chemical and Drug Induced Liver Injury*A spectrum of clinical liver diseases ranging from mild biochemical abnormalities to ACUTE LIVER FAILURE
column2: caused by drugs
column4: herbal and dietary supplements and chemicals from the environment.

column1: C06.552.195.200*D056487*Drug-Induced Liver Injury
column2: Chronic*Liver disease lasting six months or more
column3: caused by an adverse drug effect. The adverse effect may result from a direct toxic effect of a drug or metabolite
column4: or an idiosyncratic response to a drug or metabolite.

column1: C06.552.241*D005234*Fatty Liver*Lipid infiltration of the hepatic parenchymal cells resulting in a yellow-colored liver. The abnormal lipid accumulation is usually in the form of TRIGLYCERIDES
column2: either as a single large droplet or multiple small droplets. Fatty liver is caused by an imbalance in the metabolism of FATTY ACIDS.
Alcoholic*Lipid infiltration of the hepatic parenchymal cells that is due to ALCOHOL ABUSE. The fatty changes in the alcoholic fatty liver may be reversible
column3: depending on the amounts of TRIGLYCERIDES accumulated.

column1: C06.552.241.519*D065626*Non-alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease*Fatty liver finding without excessive ALCOHOL CONSUMPTION.
C06.552.241.649*D012202*Reye Syndrome*A form of encephalopathy with fatty infiltration of the LIVER
column2: characterized by brain EDEMA and VOMITING that may rapidly progress to SEIZURES; COMA; and DEATH. It is caused by a generalized loss of mitochondrial function leading to disturbances in fatty acid and CARNITINE metabolism.

column1: C06.552.270*D020518*Focal Nodular Hyperplasia*Solitary or multiple benign hepatic vascular tumors
column2: usually occurring in women of 20-50 years of age. The nodule
column4: consists of a central stellate fibrous scar and normal liver elements such as HEPATOCYTES
column6: and KUPFFER CELLS among the intervening fibrous septa. The pale colored central scar represents large blood vessels with hyperplastic fibromuscular layer and narrowing lumen.

column1: C06.552.308*D048550*Hepatic Insufficiency*Conditions in which the LIVER functions fall below the normal ranges. Severe hepatic insufficiency may cause LIVER FAILURE or DEATH. Treatment may include LIVER TRANSPLANTATION.
C06.552.308.500*D017093*Liver Failure*Severe inability of the LIVER to perform its normal metabolic functions
column2: as evidenced by severe JAUNDICE and abnormal serum levels of AMMONIA; BILIRUBIN; ALKALINE PHOSPHATASE; ASPARTATE AMINOTRANSFERASE; LACTATE DEHYDROGENASES; and albumin/globulin ratio. (Blakiston's Gould Medical Dictionary

column1: C06.552.308.500.177*D058625*End Stage Liver Disease*Final stage of a liver disease when the liver failure is irreversible and LIVER TRANSPLANTATION is needed.
C06.552.308.500.356*D006501*Hepatic Encephalopathy*A syndrome characterized by central nervous system dysfunction in association with LIVER FAILURE
column2: including portal-systemic shunts. Clinical features include lethargy and CONFUSION (frequently progressing to COMA); ASTERIXIS; NYSTAGMUS
column3: PATHOLOGIC; brisk oculovestibular reflexes; decorticate and decerebrate posturing; MUSCLE SPASTICITY; and bilateral extensor plantar reflexes (see REFLEX
column4: BABINSKI). ELECTROENCEPHALOGRAPHY may demonstrate triphasic waves. (From Adams et al.

column2: Acute*A form of rapid-onset LIVER FAILURE
column3: also known as fulminant hepatic failure
column4: caused by severe liver injury or massive loss of HEPATOCYTES. It is characterized by sudden development of liver dysfunction and JAUNDICE. Acute liver failure may progress to exhibit cerebral dysfunction even HEPATIC COMA depending on the etiology that includes hepatic ISCHEMIA
column7: and viral hepatitis such as post-transfusion HEPATITIS B and HEPATITIS C.

column1: C06.552.308.500.750.249*D065290*Acute-On-Chronic Liver Failure*Sudden liver failure in the presence of underlying compensated chronic LIVER DISEASE (e.g.
column2: LIVER CIRRHOSIS; HEPATITIS; and liver injury and failure) due to a precipitating acute hepatic insult.

column1: C06.552.308.500.750.500*D047508*Massive Hepatic Necrosis*Extensive and rapid death of parenchymal cells in the LIVER
column2: often due to exposure to toxic materials. It is characterized by a soft
column5: and shrunken liver. It was called acute yellow atrophy.

column1: C06.552.347*D006502*Budd-Chiari Syndrome*A condition in which the hepatic venous outflow is obstructed anywhere from the small HEPATIC VEINS to the junction of the INFERIOR VENA CAVA and the RIGHT ATRIUM. Usually the blockage is extrahepatic and caused by blood clots (THROMBUS) or fibrous webs. Parenchymal FIBROSIS is uncommon.
C06.552.360*D006504*Hepatic Veno-Occlusive Disease*Liver disease that is caused by injuries to the ENDOTHELIAL CELLS of the vessels and subendothelial EDEMA
column2: but not by THROMBOSIS. Extracellular matrix
column4: is usually deposited around the HEPATIC VEINS leading to venous outflow occlusion and sinusoidal obstruction.

column1: C06.552.380*D006505*Hepatitis*INFLAMMATION of the LIVER.

column2: Alcoholic*INFLAMMATION of the LIVER due to ALCOHOL ABUSE. It is characterized by NECROSIS of HEPATOCYTES
column4: and deposit of MALLORY BODIES. Depending on its severity
column5: the inflammatory lesion may be reversible or progress to LIVER CIRRHOSIS.

column2: Animal*INFLAMMATION of the LIVER in non-human animals.
Viral
column3: Animal*INFLAMMATION of the LIVER in animals due to viral infection.

column2: Infectious Canine*A contagious disease caused by canine adenovirus (ADENOVIRUSES
column8: and bears. Symptoms include FEVER; EDEMA; VOMITING; and DIARRHEA.

column1: C06.552.380.315.430.812*D012295*Rift Valley Fever*An acute infection caused by the RIFT VALLEY FEVER VIRUS
column2: an RNA arthropod-borne virus
column3: affecting domestic animals and humans. In animals
column6: symptoms range from those of a flu-like disease to hemorrhagic fever

column2: Chronic*INFLAMMATION of the LIVER with ongoing hepatocellular injury for 6 months or more
column3: characterized by NECROSIS of HEPATOCYTES and inflammatory cell (LEUKOCYTES) infiltration. Chronic hepatitis can be caused by viruses

column2: Autoimmune*A chronic self-perpetuating hepatocellular INFLAMMATION of unknown cause
column3: usually with HYPERGAMMAGLOBULINEMIA and serum AUTOANTIBODIES.

column2: Chronic*INFLAMMATION of the LIVER in humans caused by HEPATITIS B VIRUS lasting six months or more. It is primarily transmitted by parenteral exposure
column3: such as transfusion of contaminated blood or blood products
column4: but can also be transmitted via sexual or intimate personal contact.

column2: Chronic*INFLAMMATION of the LIVER in humans that is caused by HEPATITIS C VIRUS lasting six months or more. Chronic hepatitis C can lead to LIVER CIRRHOSIS.
Chronic*INFLAMMATION of the LIVER in humans caused by HEPATITIS DELTA VIRUS in conjunction with HEPATITIS B VIRUS and lasting six months or more.
Viral
column3: Human*INFLAMMATION of the LIVER in humans due to infection by VIRUSES. There are several significant types of human viral hepatitis with infection caused by enteric-transmission (HEPATITIS A; HEPATITIS E) or blood transfusion (HEPATITIS B; HEPATITIS C; and HEPATITIS D).

column1: C06.552.380.705.422*D006506*Hepatitis A*INFLAMMATION of the LIVER in humans caused by a member of the HEPATOVIRUS genus
column2: HUMAN HEPATITIS A VIRUS. It can be transmitted through fecal contamination of food or water.

column1: C06.552.380.705.437*D006509*Hepatitis B*INFLAMMATION of the LIVER in humans caused by a member of the ORTHOHEPADNAVIRUS genus
column2: HEPATITIS B VIRUS. It is primarily transmitted by parenteral exposure
column3: such as transfusion of contaminated blood or blood products
column4: but can also be transmitted via sexual or intimate personal contact.

column2: Chronic*INFLAMMATION of the LIVER in humans caused by HEPATITIS B VIRUS lasting six months or more. It is primarily transmitted by parenteral exposure
column3: such as transfusion of contaminated blood or blood products
column4: but can also be transmitted via sexual or intimate personal contact.

column1: C06.552.380.705.440*D006526*Hepatitis C*INFLAMMATION of the LIVER in humans caused by HEPATITIS C VIRUS
column2: a single-stranded RNA virus. Its incubation period is 30-90 days. Hepatitis C is transmitted primarily by contaminated blood parenterally
column3: and is often associated with transfusion and intravenous drug abuse. However
column4: in a significant number of cases
column5: the source of hepatitis C infection is unknown.

column2: Chronic*INFLAMMATION of the LIVER in humans that is caused by HEPATITIS C VIRUS lasting six months or more. Chronic hepatitis C can lead to LIVER CIRRHOSIS.

column1: C06.552.380.705.450*D003699*Hepatitis D*INFLAMMATION of the LIVER in humans caused by HEPATITIS DELTA VIRUS
column2: a defective RNA virus that can only infect HEPATITIS B patients. For its viral coating
column3: hepatitis delta virus requires the HEPATITIS B SURFACE ANTIGENS produced by these patients. Hepatitis D can occur either concomitantly with (coinfection) or subsequent to (superinfection) hepatitis B infection. Similar to hepatitis B
column4: it is primarily transmitted by parenteral exposure
column5: such as transfusion of contaminated blood or blood products
column6: but can also be transmitted via sexual or intimate personal contact.

column2: Chronic*INFLAMMATION of the LIVER in humans caused by HEPATITIS DELTA VIRUS in conjunction with HEPATITIS B VIRUS and lasting six months or more.

column1: C06.552.380.705.470*D016751*Hepatitis E*Acute INFLAMMATION of the LIVER in humans; caused by HEPATITIS E VIRUS
column2: a non-enveloped single-stranded RNA virus. Similar to HEPATITIS A
column3: its incubation period is 15-60 days and is enterically transmitted

column1: C06.552.413*D006527*Hepatolenticular Degeneration*A rare autosomal recessive disease characterized by the deposition of copper in the BRAIN; LIVER; CORNEA; and other organs. It is caused by defects in the ATP7B gene encoding copper-transporting ATPase 2 (EC 3.6.3.4)
column2: also known as the Wilson disease protein. The overload of copper inevitably leads to progressive liver and neurological dysfunction such as LIVER CIRRHOSIS; TREMOR; ATAXIA and intellectual deterioration. Hepatic dysfunction may precede neurologic dysfunction by several years.

column1: C06.552.416*D006529*Hepatomegaly*Enlargement of the liver.
C06.552.455*D020065*Hepatopulmonary Syndrome*A syndrome characterized by the clinical triad of advanced chronic liver disease
column2: pulmonary vascular dilatations
column3: and reduced arterial oxygenation (HYPOXEMIA) in the absence of intrinsic cardiopulmonary disease. This syndrome is common in the patients with LIVER CIRRHOSIS or portal hypertension (HYPERTENSION

column1: C06.552.465*D006530*Hepatorenal Syndrome*Functional KIDNEY FAILURE in patients with liver disease
column2: usually LIVER CIRRHOSIS or portal hypertension (HYPERTENSION
column4: and in the absence of intrinsic renal disease or kidney abnormality. It is characterized by intense renal vasculature constriction

column1: C06.552.494*D006975*Hypertension
column2: Portal*Abnormal increase of resistance to blood flow within the hepatic PORTAL SYSTEM
column3: frequently seen in LIVER CIRRHOSIS and conditions with obstruction of the PORTAL VEIN.

column1: C06.552.494.414*D004932*Esophageal and Gastric Varices*Dilated blood vessels in the ESOPHAGUS or GASTRIC FUNDUS that shunt blood from the portal circulation (PORTAL SYSTEM) to the systemic venous circulation. Often they are observed in individuals with portal hypertension (HYPERTENSION
column2: PORTAL).

column1: C06.552.597*D008100*Liver Abscess*Solitary or multiple collections of PUS within the liver as a result of infection by bacteria
column2: protozoa
Amebic*Single or multiple areas of PUS due to infection by any ameboid protozoa (AMEBIASIS). A common form is caused by the ingestion of ENTAMOEBA HISTOLYTICA.
Pyogenic*Single or multiple areas of PUS due to bacterial infection within the hepatic parenchyma. It can be caused by a variety of BACTERIA
column3: local or disseminated from infections elsewhere such as in APPENDICITIS; CHOLECYSTITIS; PERITONITIS; and after LIVER TRANSPLANTATION.

column1: C06.552.630*D008103*Liver Cirrhosis*Liver disease in which the normal microcirculation
column2: the gross vascular anatomy
column3: and the hepatic architecture have been variably destroyed and altered with fibrous septa surrounding regenerated or regenerating parenchymal nodules.

column1: C06.552.630.380*D008104*Liver Cirrhosis
column2: Alcoholic*FIBROSIS of the hepatic parenchyma due to chronic excess ALCOHOL DRINKING.

column1: C06.552.630.400*D008105*Liver Cirrhosis
column2: Biliary*FIBROSIS of the hepatic parenchyma due to obstruction of BILE flow (CHOLESTASIS) in the intrahepatic or extrahepatic bile ducts (BILE DUCTS
column4: EXTRAHEPATIC). Primary biliary cirrhosis involves the destruction of small intra-hepatic bile ducts and bile secretion. Secondary biliary cirrhosis is produced by prolonged obstruction of large intrahepatic or extrahepatic bile ducts from a variety of causes.

column1: C06.552.630.467*D008106*Liver Cirrhosis
column2: Experimental*Experimentally induced chronic injuries to the parenchymal cells in the liver to achieve a model for LIVER CIRRHOSIS.

column1: C06.552.645*D008108*Liver Diseases
column2: Alcoholic*Liver diseases associated with ALCOHOLISM. It usually refers to the coexistence of two or more subentities
column4: ALCOHOLIC FATTY LIVER; ALCOHOLIC HEPATITIS; and ALCOHOLIC CIRRHOSIS.

column2: Alcoholic*Lipid infiltration of the hepatic parenchymal cells that is due to ALCOHOL ABUSE. The fatty changes in the alcoholic fatty liver may be reversible
column3: depending on the amounts of TRIGLYCERIDES accumulated.

column2: Alcoholic*INFLAMMATION of the LIVER due to ALCOHOL ABUSE. It is characterized by NECROSIS of HEPATOCYTES
column4: and deposit of MALLORY BODIES. Depending on its severity
column5: the inflammatory lesion may be reversible or progress to LIVER CIRRHOSIS.

column1: C06.552.645.590*D008104*Liver Cirrhosis
column2: Alcoholic*FIBROSIS of the hepatic parenchyma due to chronic excess ALCOHOL DRINKING.

column1: C06.552.664*D008109*Liver Diseases
column2: Parasitic*Liver diseases caused by infections with PARASITES

column1: C06.552.664.272*D004444*Echinococcosis
column2: Hepatic*Liver disease caused by infections with parasitic tapeworms of the genus ECHINOCOCCUS
column3: such as Echinococcus granulosus or Echinococcus multilocularis. Ingested Echinococcus ova burrow into the intestinal mucosa. The larval migration to the liver via the PORTAL VEIN leads to watery vesicles (HYDATID CYST).

column1: C06.552.664.424*D005211*Fascioliasis*Liver disease caused by infections with parasitic flukes of the genus FASCIOLA
column2: such as FASCIOLA HEPATICA.
Amebic*Single or multiple areas of PUS due to infection by any ameboid protozoa (AMEBIASIS). A common form is caused by the ingestion of ENTAMOEBA HISTOLYTICA.

column1: C06.552.697*D008113*Liver Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the LIVER.

column2: Liver Cell*A benign epithelial tumor of the LIVER.

Hepatocellular*A primary malignant neoplasm of epithelial liver cells. It ranges from a well-differentiated tumor with EPITHELIAL CELLS indistinguishable from normal HEPATOCYTES to a poorly differentiated neoplasm. The cells may be uniform or markedly pleomorphic
column3: or form GIANT CELLS. Several classification schemes have been suggested.

column1: C06.552.697.580*D008114*Liver Neoplasms
column2: Experimental*Experimentally induced tumors of the LIVER.

column1: C06.552.802*D010382*Peliosis Hepatis*A vascular disease of the LIVER characterized by the occurrence of multiple blood-filled CYSTS or cavities. The cysts are lined with ENDOTHELIAL CELLS; the cavities lined with hepatic parenchymal cells (HEPATOCYTES). Peliosis hepatis has been associated with use of anabolic steroids (ANABOLIC AGENTS) and certain drugs.
C06.552.830*D017094*Porphyrias
column2: Hepatic*A group of metabolic diseases due to deficiency of one of a number of LIVER enzymes in the biosynthetic pathway of HEME. They are characterized by the accumulation and increased excretion of PORPHYRINS or its precursors. Clinical features include neurological symptoms (PORPHYRIA
column4: cutaneous lesions due to photosensitivity (PORPHYRIA CUTANEA TARDA)
column5: or both (HEREDITARY COPROPORPHYRIA). Hepatic porphyrias can be hereditary or acquired as a result of toxicity to the hepatic tissues.

column1: C06.552.830.074*D046349*Coproporphyria
column2: Hereditary*An autosomal dominant porphyria that is due to a deficiency of COPROPORPHYRINOGEN OXIDASE in the LIVER
column3: the sixth enzyme in the 8-enzyme biosynthetic pathway of HEME. Clinical features include both neurological symptoms and cutaneous lesions. Patients excrete increased levels of porphyrin precursors

column2: Acute Intermittent*An autosomal dominant porphyria that is due to a deficiency of HYDROXYMETHYLBILANE SYNTHASE in the LIVER
column3: the third enzyme in the 8-enzyme biosynthetic pathway of HEME. Clinical features are recurrent and life-threatening neurologic disturbances
column5: and elevated level of AMINOLEVULINIC ACID and PORPHOBILINOGEN in the urine.

column1: C06.552.830.250*D017119*Porphyria Cutanea Tarda*An autosomal dominant or acquired porphyria due to a deficiency of UROPORPHYRINOGEN DECARBOXYLASE in the LIVER. It is characterized by photosensitivity and cutaneous lesions with little or no neurologic symptoms. Type I is the acquired form and is strongly associated with liver diseases and hepatic toxicities caused by alcohol or estrogenic steroids. Type II is the familial form.

column2: Hepatoerythropoietic*An autosomal recessive cutaneous porphyria that is due to a deficiency of UROPORPHYRINOGEN DECARBOXYLASE in both the LIVER and the BONE MARROW. Similar to PORPHYRIA CUTANEA TARDA
column3: this disorder is caused by defects in the fifth enzyme in the 8-enzyme biosynthetic pathway of HEME
column4: but is a homozygous enzyme deficiency with less than 10% of the normal enzyme activity. Cutaneous lesions are severe and mutilating.

column2: Variegate*An autosomal dominant porphyria that is due to a deficiency of protoporphyrinogen oxidase (EC 1.3.3.4) in the LIVER
column3: the seventh enzyme in the 8-enzyme biosynthetic pathway of HEME. Clinical features include both neurological symptoms and cutaneous lesions. Patients excrete increased levels of porphyrin precursors

column1: C06.552.830.812*D046351*Protoporphyria
column2: Erythropoietic*An autosomal dominant porphyria that is due to a deficiency of FERROCHELATASE (heme synthetase) in both the LIVER and the BONE MARROW
column3: the last enzyme in the 8-enzyme biosynthetic pathway of HEME. Clinical features include mainly neurological symptoms
column5: and elevated levels of protoporphyrin and COPROPORPHYRINS in the feces.

column1: C06.552.933*D014386*Tuberculosis
column2: Hepatic*Infection of the LIVER with species of MYCOBACTERIUM
column3: most often MYCOBACTERIUM TUBERCULOSIS. It is characterized by localized small tuberculous miliary lesions or tumor-like mass (TUBERCULOMA)
column4: and abnormalities in liver function tests.

column1: C06.552.970*D015211*Zellweger Syndrome*An autosomal recessive disorder due to defects in PEROXISOME biogenesis which involves more than 13 genes encoding peroxin proteins of the peroxisomal membrane and matrix. Zellweger syndrome is typically seen in the neonatal period with features such as dysmorphic skull; MUSCLE HYPOTONIA; SENSORINEURAL HEARING LOSS; visual compromise; SEIZURES; progressive degeneration of the KIDNEYS and the LIVER. Zellweger-like syndrome refers to phenotypes resembling the neonatal Zellweger syndrome but seen in children or adults with apparently intact peroxisome biogenesis.
C06.689*D010182*Pancreatic Diseases*Pathological processes of the PANCREAS.
C06.689.150*D044903*Congenital Hyperinsulinism*A familial
column2: nontransient HYPOGLYCEMIA with defects in negative feedback of GLUCOSE-regulated INSULIN release. Clinical phenotypes include HYPOGLYCEMIA; HYPERINSULINEMIA; SEIZURES; COMA; and often large BIRTH WEIGHT. Several sub-types exist with the most common
column4: associated with mutations on an ATP-BINDING CASSETTE TRANSPORTERS (subfamily C

column1: C06.689.150.500*D046768*Nesidioblastosis*An inherited autosomal recessive syndrome characterized by the disorganized formation of new islets in the PANCREAS and CONGENITAL HYPERINSULINISM. It is due to focal hyperplasia of pancreatic ISLET CELLS budding off from the ductal structures and forming new islets of Langerhans. Mutations in the islet cells involve the potassium channel gene KCNJ11 or the ATP-binding cassette transporter gene ABCC8
column2: both on CHROMOSOME 11.

column1: C06.689.202*D003550*Cystic Fibrosis*An autosomal recessive genetic disease of the EXOCRINE GLANDS. It is caused by mutations in the gene encoding the CYSTIC FIBROSIS TRANSMEMBRANE CONDUCTANCE REGULATOR expressed in several organs including the LUNG
column2: the PANCREAS
column4: and the SWEAT GLANDS. Cystic fibrosis is characterized by epithelial secretory dysfunction associated with ductal obstruction resulting in AIRWAY OBSTRUCTION; chronic RESPIRATORY INFECTIONS; PANCREATIC INSUFFICIENCY; maldigestion; salt depletion; and HEAT PROSTRATION.

column1: C06.689.276*D010188*Exocrine Pancreatic Insufficiency*A malabsorption condition resulting from greater than 10% reduction in the secretion of pancreatic digestive enzymes (LIPASE; PROTEASES; and AMYLASE) by the EXOCRINE PANCREAS into the DUODENUM. This condition is often associated with CYSTIC FIBROSIS and with chronic PANCREATITIS.
C06.689.500*D010181*Pancreatic Cyst*A true cyst of the PANCREAS
column2: distinguished from the much more common PANCREATIC PSEUDOCYST by possessing a lining of mucous EPITHELIUM. Pancreatic cysts are categorized as congenital
column7: or dermoid. Congenital cysts occur more frequently as solitary cysts but may be multiple. Retention cysts are gross enlargements of PANCREATIC DUCTS secondary to ductal obstruction. (From Bockus Gastroenterology

column1: C06.689.500.692*D010192*Pancreatic Pseudocyst*Cyst-like space not lined by EPITHELIUM and contained within the PANCREAS. Pancreatic pseudocysts account for most of the cystic collections in the pancreas and are often associated with chronic PANCREATITIS.
C06.689.583*D010185*Pancreatic Fistula*Abnormal passage communicating with the PANCREAS.
C06.689.667*D010190*Pancreatic Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the PANCREAS. Depending on the types of ISLET CELLS present in the tumors
column2: various hormones can be secreted: GLUCAGON from PANCREATIC ALPHA CELLS; INSULIN from PANCREATIC BETA CELLS; and SOMATOSTATIN from the SOMATOSTATIN-SECRETING CELLS. Most are malignant except the insulin-producing tumors (INSULINOMA).
Islet Cell*A benign tumor of the pancreatic ISLET CELLS. Usually it involves the INSULIN-producing PANCREATIC BETA CELLS

column1: C06.689.667.249.500*D007340*Insulinoma*A benign tumor of the PANCREATIC BETA CELLS. Insulinoma secretes excess INSULIN resulting in HYPOGLYCEMIA.

column2: Islet Cell*A primary malignant neoplasm of the pancreatic ISLET CELLS. Usually it involves the non-INSULIN-producing cell types
column3: the PANCREATIC ALPHA CELLS and the pancreatic delta cells (SOMATOSTATIN-SECRETING CELLS) in GLUCAGONOMA and SOMATOSTATINOMA

column1: C06.689.667.500.124*D015408*Gastrinoma*A GASTRIN-secreting neuroendocrine tumor of the non-beta ISLET CELLS
column2: the GASTRIN-SECRETING CELLS. This type of tumor is primarily located in the PANCREAS or the DUODENUM. Majority of gastrinomas are malignant. They metastasize to the LIVER; LYMPH NODES; and BONE but rarely elsewhere. The presence of gastrinoma is one of three requirements to be met for identification of ZOLLINGER-ELLISON SYNDROME
column3: which sometimes occurs in families with MULTIPLE ENDOCRINE NEOPLASIA TYPE 1; (MEN 1).

column1: C06.689.667.500.249*D005935*Glucagonoma*An almost always malignant GLUCAGON-secreting tumor derived from the PANCREATIC ALPHA CELLS. It is characterized by a distinctive migratory ERYTHEMA; WEIGHT LOSS; STOMATITIS; GLOSSITIS; DIABETES MELLITUS; hypoaminoacidemia; and normochromic normocytic ANEMIA.

C06.689.667.500.500*D013005*Somatostatinoma*A SOMATOSTATIN-secreting tumor derived from the pancreatic delta cells (SOMATOSTATIN-SECRETING CELLS). It is also found in the INTESTINE. Somatostatinomas are associated with DIABETES MELLITUS; CHOLELITHIASIS; STEATORRHEA; and HYPOCHLORHYDRIA. The majority of somatostatinomas have the potential for METASTASIS.
C06.689.667.500.750*D003969*Vipoma*A tumor that secretes VASOACTIVE INTESTINAL PEPTIDE
column2: a neuropeptide that causes VASODILATION; relaxation of smooth muscles; watery DIARRHEA; HYPOKALEMIA; and HYPOCHLORHYDRIA. Vipomas
column3: derived from the pancreatic ISLET CELLS
column4: generally are malignant and can secrete other hormones. In most cases
column5: Vipomas are located in the PANCREAS but can be found in extrapancreatic sites.

column2: Pancreatic Ductal*Carcinoma that arises from the PANCREATIC DUCTS. It accounts for the majority of cancers derived from the PANCREAS.

column1: C06.689.750*D010195*Pancreatitis*INFLAMMATION of the PANCREAS. Pancreatitis is classified as acute unless there are computed tomographic or endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatographic findings of CHRONIC PANCREATITIS (International Symposium on Acute Pancreatitis
column2: Atlanta
column3: 1992). The two most common forms of acute pancreatitis are ALCOHOLIC PANCREATITIS and gallstone pancreatitis.

column2: Acute Necrotizing*A severe form of acute INFLAMMATION of the PANCREAS characterized by one or more areas of NECROSIS in the pancreas with varying degree of involvement of the surrounding tissues or organ systems. Massive pancreatic necrosis may lead to DIABETES MELLITUS

Alcoholic*Acute or chronic INFLAMMATION of the PANCREAS due to excessive ALCOHOL DRINKING. Alcoholic pancreatitis usually presents as an acute episode but it is a chronic progressive disease in alcoholics.

Chronic*INFLAMMATION of the PANCREAS that is characterized by recurring or persistent ABDOMINAL PAIN with or without STEATORRHEA or DIABETES MELLITUS. It is characterized by the irregular destruction of the pancreatic parenchyma which may be focal

Graft*An inflammatory disease and serious complication of PANCREAS TRANSPLANTATION. It is caused by a premature activation of pancreatic proenzymes leading to autodigestion of the gland and can be attributed to immunological or nonimmunological causes.

column1: C06.844*D010532*Peritoneal Diseases*Pathological processes involving the PERITONEUM.
C06.844.200*D002915*Chylous Ascites*Presence of milky lymph (CHYLE) in the PERITONEAL CAVITY
column2: with or without infection.

column1: C06.844.400*D006465*Hemoperitoneum*Accumulations of blood in the PERITONEAL CAVITY due to internal HEMORRHAGE.
C06.844.460*D065666*Mesenteric Ischemia*Ischemic tissue injury produced by insufficient perfusion of intestinal tissue by the MESENTERIC CIRCULATION (i.e.
column2: CELIAC ARTERY; SUPERIOR MESENTERIC ARTERY; INFERERIOR MESENTERIC ARTERY; and MESENTERIC VEINS). It can progress from ISCHEMIA; EDEMA; and GANGRENE of the bowel wall to PERITONITIS and cardiovascular collapse.

column1: C06.844.520*D008640*Mesenteric Lymphadenitis*INFLAMMATION of LYMPH NODES in the MESENTERY.

C06.844.550*D008641*Mesenteric Vascular Occlusion*Obstruction of the flow in the SPLANCHNIC CIRCULATION by ATHEROSCLEROSIS; EMBOLISM; THROMBOSIS; STENOSIS; TRAUMA; and compression or intrinsic pressure from adjacent tumors. Rare causes are drugs
column2: intestinal parasites
column3: and vascular immunoinflammatory diseases such as PERIARTERITIS NODOSA and THROMBOANGIITIS OBLITERANS. (From Juergens et al.

column1: C06.844.600*D015436*Panniculitis
column2: Peritoneal*INFLAMMATION of the underlying layer of ADIPOSE TISSUE (panniculus) of the PERITONEUM
column3: usually of the MESENTERY or the OMENTUM. There are several forms with various names and are usually characterized by infiltration of LYMPHOCYTES and NEUTROPHILS

column1: C06.844.610*D056627*Peritoneal Fibrosis*Disorder characterized by a wide range of structural changes in PERITONEUM
column2: resulting from fibrogenic or inflammatory processes. Peritoneal fibrosis is a common complication in patients receiving PERITONEAL DIALYSIS and contributes to its gradual decrease in efficiency.

column1: C06.844.620*D010534*Peritoneal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the PERITONEUM.
C06.844.620.500*D008639*Mesenteric Cyst*A rare intra-abdominal tumor in the MESENTERY. Mesenteric cysts are usually benign and can be very large fluid-filled (2000 mL) lesions.
C06.844.640*D010538*Peritonitis*INFLAMMATION of the PERITONEUM lining the ABDOMINAL CAVITY as the result of infectious
column2: autoimmune
column3: or chemical processes. Primary peritonitis is due to infection of the PERITONEAL CAVITY via hematogenous or lymphatic spread and without intra-abdominal source. Secondary peritonitis arises from the ABDOMINAL CAVITY itself through RUPTURE or ABSCESS of intra-abdominal organs.

column2: Tuberculous*A form of PERITONITIS seen in patients with TUBERCULOSIS
column3: characterized by lesion either as a miliary form or as a pelvic mass on the peritoneal surfaces. Most patients have ASCITES
column6: and other systemic symptoms such as FEVER; WEIGHT LOSS; and ANEMIA.

column1: C06.844.640.500*D013369*Subphrenic Abscess*Accumulation of purulent EXUDATES beneath the DIAPHRAGM
column2: also known as upper abdominal abscess. It is usually associated with PERITONITIS or postoperative infections.

column1: C06.844.670*D011027*Pneumoperitoneum*A condition with trapped gas or air in the PERITONEAL CAVITY
column2: usually secondary to perforation of the internal organs such as the LUNG and the GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT
column3: or to recent surgery. Pneumoperitoneum may be purposely introduced to aid radiological examination.

column1: C07*D009057*Stomatognathic Diseases*General or unspecified diseases of the stomatognathic system
column2: comprising the mouth

column1: C07.160*D000072676*Ankyloglossia*A severe congenital restriction of TONGUE movement
column2: resulting from fusion or adherence of the tongue to the floor of the mouth. In partial ankyloglossia (tongue-tie) the LINGUAL FRENUM is abnormally short
column3: or is attached too close to the tip of the tongue. OMIM: 106280

column1: C07.320*D007571*Jaw Diseases*Diseases involving the JAW.
C07.320.086*D059266*Bisphosphonate-Associated Osteonecrosis of the Jaw*Necrotic jaws or other maxillofacial skeleton necrosis associated with bisphosphonate use (see BISPHOSPHONATES). Injury
column2: dental procedures
column3: and trauma can trigger the necrotic process.

column1: C07.320.173*D002636*Cherubism*A fibro-osseous hereditary disease of the jaws. The swollen jaws and raised eyes give a cherubic appearance; multiple radiolucencies are evident upon radiographic examination.

column2: Giant Cell*A non-neoplastic inflammatory lesion
column3: usually of the jaw or gingiva
column5: multinucleated cells. It includes reparative giant cell granuloma. Peripheral giant cell granuloma refers to the gingiva (giant cell epulis); central refers to the jaw.

column1: C07.320.440*D007569*Jaw Abnormalities*Congenital absence of or defects in structures of the jaw.
C07.320.440.185*D002972*Cleft Palate*Congenital fissure of the soft and/or hard palate
column2: due to faulty fusion.

column1: C07.320.440.457*D008844*Micrognathism*Abnormally small jaw.

C07.320.440.606*D010855*Pierre Robin Syndrome*Congenital malformation characterized by MICROGNATHIA or RETROGNATHIA; GLOSSOPTOSIS and CLEFT PALATE. The mandibular abnormalities often result in difficulties in sucking and swallowing. The syndrome may be isolated or associated with other syndromes (e.g.
column2: ANDERSEN SYNDROME; CAMPOMELIC DYSPLASIA). Developmental mis-expression of SOX9 TRANSCRIPTION FACTOR gene on chromosome 17q and its surrounding region is associated with the syndrome.

column1: C07.320.440.655*D011378*Prognathism*A condition marked by abnormal protrusion of the mandible. (Dorland
column2: 27th ed)

column1: C07.320.440.827*D063173*Retrognathia*A physical misalignment of the upper (maxilla) and lower (mandibular) jaw bones in which either or both recede relative to the frontal plane of the forehead.
C07.320.450*D007570*Jaw Cysts*Saccular lesions lined with epithelium and contained within pathologically formed cavities in the jaw; also nonepithelial cysts (pseudocysts) as they apply to the jaw
column2: e.g.
column5: and aneurysmal bone cyst. True jaw cysts are classified as odontogenic or nonodontogenic.

column1: C07.320.450.640*D009631*Nonodontogenic Cysts*Cysts formed from epithelial inclusions in the lines of fusion of the embryonic processes which form the jaws. They include nasopalatine or incisive canal cyst
column2: incisive papilla cyst

column1: C07.320.450.670*D009807*Odontogenic Cysts*Cysts found in the jaws and arising from epithelium involved in tooth formation. They include follicular cysts (e.g.
column2: primordial cyst
column6: and radicular cysts. They may become keratinized (odontogenic keratocysts). Follicular cysts may give rise to ameloblastomas and

column1: C07.320.450.670.130*D001478*Basal Cell Nevus Syndrome*Hereditary disorder consisting of multiple basal cell carcinomas
column2: odontogenic keratocysts
column9: and cervicothoracic spina bifida. Genetic transmission is autosomal dominant.

column1: C07.320.450.670.275*D003803*Dentigerous Cyst*Most common follicular odontogenic cyst. Occurs in relation to a partially erupted or unerupted tooth with at least the crown of the tooth to which the cyst is attached protruding into the cystic cavity. May give rise to an ameloblastoma and
column2: in rare instances

Calcifying*A mixed radiolucent-radiopaque lesion of the jaws with features of both a cyst and a solid neoplasm. It is characterized microscopically by an epithelial lining showing a palisaded layer of columnar basal cells

column1: C07.320.450.670.513*D010509*Periodontal Cyst*An epithelium-lined sac containing fluid; usually found at the apex of a pulp-involved tooth. The lateral type occurs less frequently along the side of the root.
C07.320.450.670.513.811*D011842*Radicular Cyst*Slow-growing fluid-filled epithelial sac at the apex of a tooth with a nonvital pulp or defective root canal filling.

column2: Edentulous*The total absence of teeth from either the mandible or the maxilla
column3: but not both. Total absence of teeth from both is MOUTH
column4: EDENTULOUS. Partial absence of teeth in either is JAW

column2: Edentulous
column3: Partially*Absence of teeth from a portion of the mandible and/or maxilla.

column1: C07.320.515*D007573*Jaw Neoplasms*Cancers or tumors of the MAXILLA or MANDIBLE unspecified. For neoplasms of the maxilla
column2: MAXILLARY NEOPLASMS is available and of the mandible

column1: C07.320.515.583*D008339*Mandibular Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the MANDIBLE.

C07.320.515.692*D010157*Palatal Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the PALATE
column2: including those of the hard palate

column1: C07.320.610*D008336*Mandibular Diseases*Diseases involving the MANDIBLE.
C07.320.610.291*D017271*Craniomandibular Disorders*Diseases or disorders of the muscles of the head and neck
column2: with special reference to the masticatory muscles. The most notable examples are TEMPOROMANDIBULAR JOINT DISORDERS and TEMPOROMANDIBULAR JOINT DYSFUNCTION SYNDROME.

column1: C07.320.610.291.897*D013705*Temporomandibular Joint Disorders*A variety of conditions affecting the anatomic and functional characteristics of the temporomandibular joint. Factors contributing to the complexity of temporomandibular diseases are its relation to dentition and mastication and the symptomatic effects in other areas which account for referred pain to the joint and the difficulties in applying traditional diagnostic procedures to temporomandibular joint pathology where tissue is rarely obtained and x-rays are often inadequate or nonspecific. Common diseases are developmental abnormalities
column2: trauma

column1: C07.320.610.291.897.897*D013706*Temporomandibular Joint Dysfunction Syndrome*A symptom complex consisting of pain
column2: muscle tenderness
column4: and limitation or alteration of mandibular movement. The symptoms are subjective and manifested primarily in the masticatory muscles rather than the temporomandibular joint itself. Etiologic factors are uncertain but include occlusal dysharmony and psychophysiologic factors.

column1: C07.320.610.583*D008339*Mandibular Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the MANDIBLE.
C07.320.610.655*D011378*Prognathism*A condition marked by abnormal protrusion of the mandible. (Dorland
column2: 27th ed)

column1: C07.320.610.827*D063173*Retrognathia*A physical misalignment of the upper (maxilla) and lower (mandibular) jaw bones in which either or both recede relative to the frontal plane of the forehead.
C07.320.660*D008439*Maxillary Diseases*Diseases involving the MAXILLA.
C07.320.660.601*D008441*Maxillary Neoplasms*Cancer or tumors of the MAXILLA or upper jaw.

column1: C08.381.540*D008175*Lung Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the LUNG.

column2: Bronchogenic*Malignant neoplasm arising from the epithelium of the BRONCHI. It represents a large group of epithelial lung malignancies which can be divided into two clinical groups: SMALL CELL LUNG CANCER and NON-SMALL-CELL LUNG CARCINOMA.

column1: C08.381.540.140.750*D055752*Small Cell Lung Carcinoma*A form of highly malignant lung cancer that is composed of small ovoid cells (SMALL CELL CARCINOMA).

column1: C08.381.677.540.530*D048089*Pneumonia of Calves

column1: C08.381.677.540.540*D045729*Pneumonia of Swine

column4: infectious pneumonia of PIGS caused by MYCOPLASMA HYOPNEUMONIAE. The disease can be associated with porcine respiratory disease complex. PASTEURELLA MULTOCIDA is often found as a secondary infection.

column2: Pneumococcal*A febrile disease caused by STREPTOCOCCUS PNEUMONIAE.

column2: Ventilator-Associated*Serious INFLAMMATION of the LUNG in patients who required the use of PULMONARY VENTILATOR. It is usually caused by cross bacterial infections in hospitals (NOSOCOMIAL INFECTIONS).

column2: Allergic

C08.618.923*D058088*Sarcoglycanopathies*Deficiencies or mutations in the genes for the SARCOGLYCAN COMPLEX subunits. A variety of phenotypes are associated with these mutations including a subgroup of autosomal recessive limb girdle muscular dystrophies

C08.618.980.500*D007826*Laryngismus*A disorder in which the adductor muscles of the VOCAL CORDS exhibit increased activity leading to laryngeal spasm. Laryngismus causes closure of the VOCAL FOLDS and airflow obstruction during inspiration.

column1: C08.674.055.365*D005203*Farmer's Lung*A form of alveolitis or pneumonitis due to an acquired hypersensitivity to inhaled antigens associated with farm environment. Antigens in the farm dust are commonly from bacteria actinomycetes (SACCHAROPOLYSPORA and THERMOACTINOMYCES)

column2: Aspirin-Induced*Asthmatic adverse reaction (e.g.
column3: BRONCHOCONSTRICTION) to conventional NSAIDS including aspirin use.

column2: Exercise-Induced*Asthma attacks following a period of exercise. Usually the induced attack is short-lived and regresses spontaneously. The magnitude of postexertional airway obstruction is strongly influenced by the environment in which exercise is performed (i.e. inhalation of cold air during physical exertion markedly augments the severity of the airway obstruction; conversely
column3: warm humid air blunts or abolishes it).

column2: Occupational*Asthma attacks caused

Allergic

column2: Allergic

column4: and regarded as an allergic condition triggered by specific ALLERGENS.

column1: C09.218.458.341*D034381*Hearing Loss*A general term for the complete or partial loss of the ability to hear from one or both ears.
C09.218.458.341.186*D003638*Deafness*A general term for the complete loss of the ability to hear from both ears.
C09.218.458.341.186.500*D054062*Deaf-Blind Disorders*The absence of both hearing and vision.

C09.218.458.341.186.500.500*D052245*Usher Syndromes*Autosomal recessive hereditary disorders characterized by congenital SENSORINEURAL HEARING LOSS and RETINITIS PIGMENTOSA. Genetically and symptomatically heterogeneous
column2: clinical classes include type I
column5: age of onset of retinitis pigmentosa and the degree of vestibular dysfunction are variable.

column1: C09.218.458.341.186.500.750*D014929*Wolfram Syndrome*A hereditary condition characterized by multiple symptoms including those of DIABETES INSIPIDUS; DIABETES MELLITUS; OPTIC ATROPHY; and DEAFNESS. This syndrome is also known as DIDMOAD (first letter of each word) and is usually associated with VASOPRESSIN deficiency. It is caused by mutations in gene WFS1 encoding wolframin
column2: a 100-kDa transmembrane protein.
Bilateral*Partial hearing loss in both ears.

Conductive*Hearing loss due to interference with the mechanical reception or amplification of sound to the COCHLEA. The interference is in the outer or middle ear involving the EAR CANAL; TYMPANIC MEMBRANE; or EAR OSSICLES.
Functional*Hearing loss without a physical basis. Often observed in patients with psychological or behavioral disorders.
High-Frequency*Hearing loss in frequencies above 1000 hertz.
Mixed Conductive-Sensorineural*Hearing loss due to damage or impairment of both the conductive elements (HEARING LOSS
column3: CONDUCTIVE) and the sensorineural elements (HEARING LOSS

column2: Sensorineural*Hearing loss resulting from damage to the COCHLEA and the sensorineural elements which lie internally beyond the oval and round windows. These elements include the AUDITORY NERVE and its connections in the BRAINSTEM.
Central*Hearing loss due to disease of the AUDITORY PATHWAYS (in the CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM) which originate in the COCHLEAR NUCLEI of the PONS and then ascend bilaterally to the MIDBRAIN
column4: and then the AUDITORY CORTEX in the TEMPORAL LOBE. Bilateral lesions of the auditory pathways are usually required to cause central hearing loss. Cortical deafness refers to loss of hearing due to bilateral auditory cortex lesions. Unilateral BRAIN STEM lesions involving the cochlear nuclei may result in unilateral hearing loss.

column2: Noise-Induced*Hearing loss due to exposure to explosive loud noise or chronic exposure to sound level greater than 85 dB. The hearing loss is often in the frequency range 4000-6000 hertz.

column1: C09.218.458.341.887.772*D011304*Presbycusis*Gradual bilateral hearing loss associated with aging that is due to progressive degeneration of cochlear structures and central auditory pathways. Hearing loss usually begins with the high frequencies then progresses to sounds of middle and low frequencies.

C09.218.458.341.887.886*D052245*Usher Syndromes*Autosomal recessive hereditary disorders characterized by congenital SENSORINEURAL HEARING LOSS and RETINITIS PIGMENTOSA. Genetically and symptomatically heterogeneous
column2: clinical classes include type I
column5: age of onset of retinitis pigmentosa and the degree of vestibular dysfunction are variable.

column2: Sudden*Sensorineural hearing loss which develops suddenly over a period of hours or a few days. It varies in severity from mild to total deafness. Sudden deafness can be due to head trauma
column5: or can appear without obvious cause or warning.

column2: Unilateral*Partial or complete hearing loss in one ear.

column1: C09.218.458.505*D012001*Hyperacusis*An abnormally disproportionate increase in the sensation of loudness in response to auditory stimuli of normal volume. COCHLEAR DISEASES; VESTIBULOCOCHLEAR NERVE DISEASES; FACIAL NERVE DISEASES; STAPES SURGERY; and other disorders may be associated with this condition.
C09.218.458.670*D014012*Tinnitus*A nonspecific symptom of hearing disorder characterized by the sensation of buzzing
column2: ringing
column5: and other noises in the ear. Objective tinnitus refers to noises generated from within the ear or adjacent structures that can be heard by other individuals. The term subjective tinnitus is used when the sound is audible only to the affected individual. Tinnitus may occur as a manifestation of COCHLEAR DISEASES; VESTIBULOCOCHLEAR NERVE DISEASES; INTRACRANIAL HYPERTENSION; CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA; and other conditions.

column1: C09.218.513*D016697*Herpes Zoster Oticus*A syndrome characterized by facial palsy in association with a herpetic eruption of the external auditory meatus. This may occasionally be associated with tinnitus
column2: vertigo
column5: and inflammation of the pinna. The condition is caused by reactivation of a latent HERPESVIRUS 3
column6: HUMAN infection which causes inflammation of the facial and vestibular nerves
column7: and may occasionally involve additional cranial nerves. (From Adams et al.

column1: C09.218.568*D007759*Labyrinth Diseases*Pathological processes of the inner ear (LABYRINTH) which contains the essential apparatus of hearing (COCHLEA) and balance (SEMICIRCULAR CANALS).
C09.218.568.120*D015834*Cochlear Diseases*Pathological processes of the snail-like structure (COCHLEA) of the inner ear (LABYRINTH) which can involve its nervous tissue
column2: blood vessels

column1: C09.218.568.217*D018159*Endolymphatic Hydrops*An accumulation of ENDOLYMPH in the inner ear (LABYRINTH) leading to buildup of pressure and distortion of intralabyrinthine structures
column2: such as COCHLEA and SEMICIRCULAR CANALS. It is characterized by SENSORINEURAL HEARING LOSS; TINNITUS; and sometimes VERTIGO.

column1: C09.218.568.217.500*D008575*Meniere Disease*A disease of the inner ear (LABYRINTH) that is characterized by fluctuating SENSORINEURAL HEARING LOSS; TINNITUS; episodic VERTIGO; and aural fullness. It is the most common form of endolymphatic hydrops.
C09.218.568.558*D007762*Labyrinthitis*Inflammation of the inner ear (LABYRINTH).

C09.218.568.900*D015837*Vestibular Diseases*Pathological processes of the VESTIBULAR LABYRINTH which contains part of the balancing apparatus. Patients with vestibular diseases show instability and are at risk of frequent falls.
C09.218.568.900.442*D000071699*Bilateral Vestibulopathy*Impairment of the vestibular function of both inner ears which can cause difficulties with balance
column2: gait

column1: C09.218.568.900.883*D014717*Vertigo*An illusion of movement
column2: either of the external world revolving around the individual or of the individual revolving in space. Vertigo may be associated with disorders of the inner ear (EAR
column3: INNER); VESTIBULAR NERVE; BRAINSTEM; or CEREBRAL CORTEX. Lesions in the TEMPORAL LOBE and PARIETAL LOBE may be associated with FOCAL SEIZURES that may feature vertigo as an ictal manifestation. (From Adams et al.

column1: C09.218.568.900.883.500*D065635*Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo*Idiopathic recurrent VERTIGO associated with POSITIONAL NYSTAGMUS. It is associated with a vestibular loss without other neurological or auditory signs. Unlike in LABYRINTHITIS and VESTIBULAR NEURONITIS
column2: inflammation in the ear is not observed.

column1: C09.218.636*D063371*Myringosclerosis*The formation of dense connective tissue in the TYMPANIC MEMBRANE that does not necessarily cause or lead to loss of hearing.
C09.218.705*D010031*Otitis*Inflammation of the ear
column2: which may be marked by pain (EARACHE)
column5: and VERTIGO. Inflammation of the external ear is OTITIS EXTERNA; of the middle ear
column6: OTITIS MEDIA; of the inner ear

column1: C09.218.705.371*D007762*Labyrinthitis*Inflammation of the inner ear (LABYRINTH).
C09.218.705.496*D010032*Otitis Externa*Inflammation of the OUTER EAR including the external EAR CANAL
column2: cartilages of the auricle (EAR CARTILAGE)

column1: C09.218.705.663*D010033*Otitis Media*Inflammation of the MIDDLE EAR including the AUDITORY OSSICLES and the EUSTACHIAN TUBE.
C09.218.705.663.652*D008417*Mastoiditis*Inflammation of the honeycomb-like MASTOID BONE in the skull just behind the ear. It is usually a complication of OTITIS MEDIA.

column2: Suppurative*Inflammation of the middle ear with purulent discharge.

column1: C09.218.705.663.683*D010034*Otitis Media with Effusion*Inflammation of the middle ear with a clear pale yellow-colored transudate.
C09.218.705.663.841*D059270*Petrositis*Inflammation of PETROUS BONE.
C09.218.736*D059249*Otomycosis*Fungus infection of the external ear
column2: usually by ASPERGILLUS species

column1: C09.218.768*D010040*Otosclerosis*Formation of spongy bone in the labyrinth capsule which can progress toward the STAPES (stapedial fixation) or anteriorly toward the COCHLEA leading to conductive
column2: sensorineural
column3: or mixed HEARING LOSS. Several genes are associated with familial otosclerosis with varied clinical signs.

column1: C09.218.807*D012181*Retrocochlear Diseases*Pathological processes involving the VESTIBULOCOCHLEAR NERVE; BRAINSTEM; or CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM. When hearing loss is due to retrocochlear pathology
column2: it is called retrocochlear hearing loss.

column1: C09.218.807.186*D001304*Auditory Diseases
column2: Central*Disorders of hearing or auditory perception due to pathological processes of the AUDITORY PATHWAYS in the CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM. These include CENTRAL HEARING LOSS and AUDITORY PERCEPTUAL DISORDERS.

column1: C09.218.807.186.094*D001308*Auditory Perceptual Disorders*Acquired or developmental cognitive disorders of AUDITORY PERCEPTION characterized by a reduced ability to perceive information contained in auditory stimuli despite intact auditory pathways. Affected individuals have difficulty with speech perception
column2: sound localization
column3: and comprehending the meaning of inflections of speech.

column2: Central*Hearing loss due to disease of the AUDITORY PATHWAYS (in the CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM) which originate in the COCHLEAR NUCLEI of the PONS and then ascend bilaterally to the MIDBRAIN
column4: and then the AUDITORY CORTEX in the TEMPORAL LOBE. Bilateral lesions of the auditory pathways are usually required to cause central hearing loss. Cortical deafness refers to loss of hearing due to bilateral auditory cortex lesions. Unilateral BRAIN STEM lesions involving the cochlear nuclei may result in unilateral hearing loss.

column1: C09.218.807.800*D000160*Vestibulocochlear Nerve Diseases*Pathological processes of the VESTIBULOCOCHLEAR NERVE
column2: including the branches of COCHLEAR NERVE and VESTIBULAR NERVE. Common examples are VESTIBULAR NEURITIS
column4: and ACOUSTIC NEUROMA. Clinical signs are varying degree of HEARING LOSS; VERTIGO; and TINNITUS.

column2: Acoustic*A benign SCHWANNOMA of the eighth cranial nerve (VESTIBULOCOCHLEAR NERVE)
column3: mostly arising from the vestibular branch (VESTIBULAR NERVE) during the fifth or sixth decade of life. Clinical manifestations include HEARING LOSS; HEADACHE; VERTIGO; TINNITUS; and FACIAL PAIN. Bilateral acoustic neuromas are associated with NEUROFIBROMATOSIS 2. (From Adams et al.

column1: C09.218.807.800.675.500*D016518*Neurofibromatosis 2*An autosomal dominant disorder characterized by a high incidence of bilateral acoustic neuromas as well as schwannomas (NEURILEMMOMA) of other cranial and peripheral nerves
column2: and other benign intracranial tumors including meningiomas
column5: and gliomas. The disease has been linked to mutations of the NF2 gene (GENES
column6: NEUROFIBROMATOSIS 2) on chromosome 22 (22q12) and usually presents clinically in the first or second decade of life.

column1: C09.218.807.800.837*D020338*Vestibular Neuronitis*Idiopathic inflammation of the VESTIBULAR NERVE
column2: characterized clinically by the acute or subacute onset of VERTIGO; NAUSEA; and imbalance. The COCHLEAR NERVE is typically spared and HEARING LOSS and TINNITUS do not usually occur. Symptoms usually resolve over a period of days to weeks. (Adams et al.

column1: C09.218.807.800.918*D061285*Vestibulocochlear Nerve Injuries*Traumatic injuries to the VESTIBULOCOCHLEAR NERVE.
C09.218.855*D055955*Susac Syndrome*A rare disorder consisting of microangiopathy of brain
column2: retina
column3: and inner ear ARTERIOLES. It is characterized by the clinical triad of encephalopathy
column4: BRANCH RETINAL ARTERY OCCLUSION and VERTIGO/hearing loss.

column1: C09.218.903*D018058*Tympanic Membrane Perforation*A temporary or persistent opening in the eardrum (TYMPANIC MEMBRANE). Clinical signs depend on the size
column2: location

column1: C09.400*D007818*Laryngeal Diseases*Pathological processes involving any part of the LARYNX which coordinates many functions such as voice production
column2: breathing
Laryngeal*A tumor-like nodule or mass of inflammatory granulation tissue projecting into the lumen of the LARYNX.

column1: C09.400.313*D007819*Laryngeal Edema*Abnormal accumulation of fluid in tissues of any part of the LARYNX
column2: commonly associated with laryngeal injuries and allergic reactions.

column1: C09.400.369*D007822*Laryngeal Neoplasms*Cancers or tumors of the LARYNX or any of its parts: the GLOTTIS; EPIGLOTTIS; LARYNGEAL CARTILAGES; LARYNGEAL MUSCLES; and VOCAL CORDS.
C09.400.424*D061224*Laryngeal Nerve Injuries*Traumatic injuries to the LARYNGEAL NERVE.
C09.400.424.500*D061226*Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve Injuries*Traumatic injuries to the RECURRENT LARYNGEAL NERVE that may result in vocal cord dysfunction.
C09.400.535*D007827*Laryngitis*Inflammation of the LARYNGEAL MUCOSA
column2: including the VOCAL CORDS. Laryngitis is characterized by irritation
column4: and reduced pliability of the mucosa leading to VOICE DISORDERS such as APHONIA and HOARSENESS.

column1: C09.400.535.365*D003440*Croup*Inflammation involving the GLOTTIS or VOCAL CORDS and the subglottic larynx. Croup is characterized by a barking cough
column2: HOARSENESS
column3: and persistent inspiratory STRIDOR (a high-pitched breathing sound). It occurs chiefly in infants and children.

column1: C09.400.549*D059608*Laryngocele*Congenital anomalous dilitation of the laryngeal saccule that may extend internally into the airway or externally through the thyrohyoid membrane.

C09.400.563*D055092*Laryngomalacia*A congenital or acquired condition of underdeveloped or degeneration of CARTILAGE in the LARYNX. This results in a floppy laryngeal wall making patency difficult to maintain.
C09.400.591*D007829*Laryngostenosis*Developmental or acquired stricture or narrowing of the LARYNX. Symptoms of respiratory difficulty depend on the degree of laryngeal narrowing.

C09.400.840*D059525*Supraglottitis*Inflammation of the EPIGLOTTIS and supraglottic structures including the PHARYNX; UVULA; base of tongue; and aryepiglottic folds. It is usually caused by HAEMOPHILUS INFLUENZAE in children but often by different organisms in adults.
C09.400.860*D014387*Tuberculosis
column2: Laryngeal*Tuberculosis involving the larynx
column3: producing ulceration of the VOCAL CORDS and the LARYNGEAL MUCOSA.

column1: C09.400.895*D064706*Vocal Cord Dysfunction*A disorder characterized by an intermittent abnormal VOCAL CORDS movement toward the midline during inspiration or expiration resulting in upper AIRWAY OBSTRUCTION.

C09.400.895.500*D007826*Laryngismus*A disorder in which the adductor muscles of the VOCAL CORDS exhibit increased activity leading to laryngeal spasm. Laryngismus causes closure of the VOCAL FOLDS and airflow obstruction during inspiration.
C09.400.931*D014826*Vocal Cord Paralysis*Congenital or acquired paralysis of one or both VOCAL CORDS. This condition is caused by defects in the CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM
column2: the VAGUS NERVE and branches of LARYNGEAL NERVES. Common symptoms are VOICE DISORDERS including HOARSENESS or APHONIA.

column1: C09.400.940*D014832*Voice Disorders*Pathological processes that affect voice production
column2: usually involving VOCAL CORDS and the LARYNGEAL MUCOSA. Voice disorders can be caused by organic (anatomical)
column3: or functional (emotional or psychological) factors leading to DYSPHONIA; APHONIA; and defects in VOICE QUALITY

column1: C09.400.940.160*D001044*Aphonia*Complete loss of phonation due to organic disease of the larynx or to nonorganic (i.e.
column2: psychogenic) causes.

column1: C09.400.940.325*D055154*Dysphonia*Difficulty and/or pain in PHONATION or speaking.
C09.400.940.490*D006685*Hoarseness*An unnaturally deep or rough quality of voice.
C09.603*D009668*Nose Diseases*Disorders of the nose
column2: general or unspecified.

column1: C09.603.171*D002754*Choanal Atresia*A congenital abnormality that is characterized by a blocked CHOANAE
column2: the opening between the nose and the NASOPHARYNX. Blockage can be unilateral or bilateral; bony or membranous.

column1: C09.603.261*D004844*Epistaxis*Bleeding from the nose.

column2: Lethal Midline*A condition that is characterized by inflammation
column4: and perforation of the nose and the PALATE with progressive destruction of midline facial structures. This syndrome can be manifested in several diseases including the nasal type of EXTRANODAL NK-T-CELL LYMPHOMA and GRANULOMATOSIS WITH POLYANGIITIS.

column1: C09.603.525*D015508*Nasal Obstruction*Any hindrance to the passage of air into and out of the nose. The obstruction may be unilateral or bilateral
column2: and may involve any part of the NASAL CAVITY.

column1: C09.603.557*D009298*Nasal Polyps*Focal accumulations of EDEMA fluid in the NASAL MUCOSA accompanied by HYPERPLASIA of the associated submucosal connective tissue. Polyps may be NEOPLASMS
column2: foci of INFLAMMATION

column1: C09.603.588*D061270*Nasal Septal Perforation*An opening or hole in the NASAL SEPTUM that is caused by TRAUMA
column2: injury

column1: C09.603.619*D009667*Nose Deformities
column2: Acquired*Abnormalities of the nose acquired after birth from injury or disease.

column1: C09.603.669*D009669*Nose Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the NOSE.
C09.603.669.693*D010255*Paranasal Sinus Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the PARANASAL SINUSES.
C09.603.669.693.575*D008444*Maxillary Sinus Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the MAXILLARY SINUS. They represent the majority of paranasal neoplasms.
C09.603.692*D010254*Paranasal Sinus Diseases*Diseases affecting or involving the PARANASAL SINUSES and generally manifesting as inflammation
column2: abscesses

column1: C09.603.692.503*D010255*Paranasal Sinus Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the PARANASAL SINUSES.
C09.603.692.503.503*D008444*Maxillary Sinus Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the MAXILLARY SINUS. They represent the majority of paranasal neoplasms.
C09.603.692.752*D012852*Sinusitis*Inflammation of the NASAL MUCOSA in one or more of the PARANASAL SINUSES.
C09.603.692.752.267*D015521*Ethmoid Sinusitis*Inflammation of the NASAL MUCOSA in the ETHMOID SINUS. It may present itself as an acute (infectious) or chronic (allergic) condition.
C09.603.692.752.387*D015522*Frontal Sinusitis*Inflammation of the NASAL MUCOSA in the FRONTAL SINUS. In many cases
column2: it is caused by an infection of the bacteria STREPTOCOCCUS PNEUMONIAE or HAEMOPHILUS INFLUENZAE.

column1: C09.603.692.752.578*D015523*Maxillary Sinusitis*Inflammation of the NASAL MUCOSA in the MAXILLARY SINUS. In many cases
column2: it is caused by an infection of the bacteria HAEMOPHILUS INFLUENZAE; STREPTOCOCCUS PNEUMONIAE; or STAPHYLOCOCCUS AUREUS.

column1: C09.603.692.752.827*D015524*Sphenoid Sinusitis*Inflammation of the NASAL MUCOSA in the SPHENOID SINUS. Isolated sphenoid sinusitis is uncommon. It usually occurs in conjunction with other paranasal sinusitis.
C09.603.799*D012220*Rhinitis*Inflammation of the NASAL MUCOSA
column2: the mucous membrane lining the NASAL CAVITIES.
Allergic*An inflammation of the NASAL MUCOSA triggered by ALLERGENS.
Allergic
column3: Perennial*Inflammation of the mucous membrane of the nose similar to that found in hay fever except that symptoms persist throughout the year. The causes are usually air-borne allergens

column2: Allergic
column3: Seasonal*Allergic rhinitis that occurs at the same time every year. It is characterized by acute CONJUNCTIVITIS with lacrimation and ITCHING
column4: and regarded as an allergic condition triggered by specific ALLERGENS.

column2: Atrophic*A chronic inflammation in which the NASAL MUCOSA gradually changes from a functional to a non-functional lining without mucociliary clearance. It is often accompanied by degradation of the bony TURBINATES
column3: and the foul-smelling mucus which forms a greenish crust (ozena).

column2: Vasomotor*A form of non-allergic rhinitis that is characterized by nasal congestion and posterior pharyngeal drainage.

column1: C09.603.850*D012226*Rhinoscleroma*A granulomatous disease caused by KLEBSIELLA RHINOSCLEROMATIS infection. Despite its name
column2: this disease is not limited to the nose and NASOPHARYNX but may affect any part of the RESPIRATORY TRACT
column3: sometimes with extension to the lip and the skin.

column1: C09.647*D010039*Otorhinolaryngologic Neoplasms*A general concept for tumors or cancer of any part of the EAR; the NOSE; the THROAT; and the PHARYNX. It is used when there is no specific heading.
C09.647.312*D004428*Ear Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of any part of the hearing and equilibrium system of the body (the EXTERNAL EAR
column2: the MIDDLE EAR

column2: Acoustic*A benign SCHWANNOMA of the eighth cranial nerve (VESTIBULOCOCHLEAR NERVE)
column3: mostly arising from the vestibular branch (VESTIBULAR NERVE) during the fifth or sixth decade of life. Clinical manifestations include HEARING LOSS; HEADACHE; VERTIGO; TINNITUS; and FACIAL PAIN. Bilateral acoustic neuromas are associated with NEUROFIBROMATOSIS 2. (From Adams et al.

column1: C09.647.675.500*D016518*Neurofibromatosis 2*An autosomal dominant disorder characterized by a high incidence of bilateral acoustic neuromas as well as schwannomas (NEURILEMMOMA) of other cranial and peripheral nerves
column2: and other benign intracranial tumors including meningiomas
column5: and gliomas. The disease has been linked to mutations of the NF2 gene (GENES
column6: NEUROFIBROMATOSIS 2) on chromosome 22 (22q12) and usually presents clinically in the first or second decade of life.

column1: C09.647.685*D009669*Nose Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the NOSE.
C09.647.685.693*D010255*Paranasal Sinus Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the PARANASAL SINUSES.

C09.775*D010608*Pharyngeal Diseases*Pathological processes involving the PHARYNX.

C09.775.174*D003680*Deglutition Disorders*Difficulty in SWALLOWING which may result from neuromuscular disorder or mechanical obstruction. Dysphagia is classified into two distinct types: oropharyngeal dysphagia due to malfunction of the PHARYNX and UPPER ESOPHAGEAL SPHINCTER; and esophageal dysphagia due to malfunction of the ESOPHAGUS.
C09.775.262*D057831*Lemierre Syndrome*A superinfection of the damaged oropharyngeal mucosa by FUSOBACTERIUM NECROPHORUM leading to the secondary septic THROMBOPHLEBITIS of the internal jugular vein.
C09.775.350*D009302*Nasopharyngeal Diseases*Pathological processes involving the NASOPHARYNX.
