column2: characterized by a global disruption of axons throughout the brain. Associated clinical features may include NEUROBEHAVIORAL MANIFESTATIONS; PERSISTENT VEGETATIVE STATE; DEMENTIA; and other disorders.
Traumatic*A form of acquired brain injury which occurs when a sudden trauma causes damage to the brain.

column1: C10.228.140.199.444.250*D001924*Brain Concussion*A nonspecific term used to describe transient alterations or loss of consciousness following closed head injuries. The duration of UNCONSCIOUSNESS generally lasts a few seconds
column2: but may persist for several hours. Concussions may be classified as mild
column4: and severe. Prolonged periods of unconsciousness (often defined as greater than 6 hours in duration) may be referred to as post-traumatic coma (COMA

column1: C10.228.140.199.444.375*D000070624*Brain Contusion*A bruise of the brain from an impact of the skull.

C10.228.140.199.444.500*D000070627*Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy*Degenerative brain disease linked to repetitive brain trauma. Progressive symptoms may include MEMORY LOSS; AGGRESSION; or DEPRESSION.

column2: Chronic*Conditions characterized by persistent brain damage or dysfunction as sequelae of cranial trauma. This disorder may result from DIFFUSE AXONAL INJURY; INTRACRANIAL HEMORRHAGES; BRAIN EDEMA; and other conditions. Clinical features may include DEMENTIA; focal neurologic deficits; PERSISTENT VEGETATIVE STATE; AKINETIC MUTISM; or COMA.

column1: C10.228.140.199.500.500*D000070627*Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy*Degenerative brain disease linked to repetitive brain trauma. Progressive symptoms may include MEMORY LOSS; AGGRESSION; or DEPRESSION.

column2: Post-Traumatic*Recurrent seizures causally related to CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA. Seizure onset may be immediate but is typically delayed for several days after the injury and may not occur for up to two years. The majority of seizures have a focal onset that correlates clinically with the site of brain injury. Cerebral cortex injuries caused by a penetrating foreign object (CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA
column3: PENETRATING) are more likely than closed head injuries (HEAD INJURIES
column4: CLOSED) to be associated with epilepsy. Concussive convulsions are nonepileptic phenomena that occur immediately after head injury and are characterized by tonic and clonic movements. (From Rev Neurol 1998 Feb;26(150):256-261; Sports Med 1998 Feb;25(2):131-6)

column1: C10.228.140.199.700*D011007*Pneumocephalus*Presence of air or gas within the intracranial cavity (e.g.
column2: epidural space
column5: etc.) which may result from traumatic injuries
column7: erosions of the skull from NEOPLASMS or infection

column1: C10.228.140.211*D001932*Brain Neoplasms*Neoplasms of the intracranial components of the central nervous system
column2: including the cerebral hemispheres
column7: and cerebellum. Brain neoplasms are subdivided into primary (originating from brain tissue) and secondary (i.e.
column8: metastatic) forms. Primary neoplasms are subdivided into benign and malignant forms. In general
column9: brain tumors may also be classified by age of onset
column11: or presenting location in the brain.

column1: C10.228.140.211.280*D002551*Cerebral Ventricle Neoplasms*Neoplasms located in the brain ventricles
column2: including the two lateral
column4: and the fourth ventricle. Ventricular tumors may be primary (e.g.
column8: or occur as extensions of locally invasive tumors from adjacent brain structures.

column1: C10.228.140.211.280.300*D016545*Choroid Plexus Neoplasms*Benign or malignant tumors which arise from the choroid plexus of the ventricles of the brain. Papillomas (see PAPILLOMA
column2: CHOROID PLEXUS) and carcinomas are the most common histologic subtypes
column3: and tend to seed throughout the ventricular and subarachnoid spaces. Clinical features include headaches
column5: primarily resulting from associated HYDROCEPHALUS. (From Devita et al.
column6: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column2: Choroid Plexus*A usually benign neoplasm that arises from the cuboidal epithelium of the choroid plexus and takes the form of an enlarged CHOROID PLEXUS
column3: which may be associated with oversecretion of CSF. The tumor usually presents in the first decade of life with signs of increased intracranial pressure including HEADACHES; ATAXIA; DIPLOPIA; and alterations of mental status. In children it is most common in the lateral ventricles and in adults it tends to arise in the fourth ventricle. Malignant transformation to choroid plexus carcinomas may rarely occur. (Adams et al.
column7: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column1: C10.228.140.211.500*D015192*Infratentorial Neoplasms*Intracranial tumors originating in the region of the brain inferior to the tentorium cerebelli
column2: which contains the cerebellum
column6: and related structures. Primary tumors of this region are more frequent in children
column7: and may present with ATAXIA; CRANIAL NERVE DISEASES; vomiting; HEADACHE; HYDROCEPHALUS; or other signs of neurologic dysfunction. Relatively frequent histologic subtypes include TERATOMA; MEDULLOBLASTOMA; GLIOBLASTOMA; ASTROCYTOMA; EPENDYMOMA; CRANIOPHARYNGIOMA; and choroid plexus papilloma (PAPILLOMA

column1: C10.228.140.211.500.100*D020295*Brain Stem Neoplasms*Benign and malignant intra-axial tumors of the MESENCEPHALON; PONS; or MEDULLA OBLONGATA of the BRAIN STEM. Primary and metastatic neoplasms may occur in this location. Clinical features include ATAXIA
column2: cranial neuropathies (see CRANIAL NERVE DISEASES)
column5: and quadriparesis. Primary brain stem neoplasms are more frequent in children. Histologic subtypes include GLIOMA; HEMANGIOBLASTOMA; GANGLIOGLIOMA; and EPENDYMOMA.

column1: C10.228.140.211.500.200*D002528*Cerebellar Neoplasms*Primary or metastatic neoplasms of the CEREBELLUM. Tumors in this location frequently present with ATAXIA or signs of INTRACRANIAL HYPERTENSION due to obstruction of the fourth ventricle. Common primary cerebellar tumors include fibrillary ASTROCYTOMA and cerebellar HEMANGIOBLASTOMA. The cerebellum is a relatively common site for tumor metastases from the lung
column2: breast
column3: and other distant organs. (From Okazaki & Scheithauer

column1: C10.228.140.211.692*D018306*Neurocytoma*A benign brain tumor composed of neural elements which most often arise from the SEPTUM PELLUCIDUM and the walls of the lateral ventricles. Immunohistochemistry and electron microscopy evaluations may reveal expression of neuron specific enolase and synaptophysin and cells containing microtubuli
column2: neurosecretory granules
column3: and presynaptic vesicles. (From Acta Med Port 1994 Feb;7(2):113-9)

column1: C10.228.140.211.788*D010871*Pinealoma*Neoplasms which originate from pineal parenchymal cells that tend to enlarge the gland and be locally invasive. The two major forms are pineocytoma and the more malignant pineoblastoma. Pineocytomas have moderate cellularity and tend to form rosette patterns. Pineoblastomas are highly cellular tumors containing small
column2: poorly differentiated cells. These tumors occasionally seed the neuroaxis or cause obstructive HYDROCEPHALUS or Parinaud's syndrome. GERMINOMA; CARCINOMA
column3: EMBRYONAL; GLIOMA; and other neoplasms may arise in the pineal region with germinoma being the most common pineal region tumor. (From DeVita et al.
column4: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column1: C10.228.140.211.885*D015173*Supratentorial Neoplasms*Primary and metastatic (secondary) tumors of the brain located above the tentorium cerebelli
column2: a fold of dura mater separating the CEREBELLUM and BRAIN STEM from the cerebral hemispheres and DIENCEPHALON (i.e.
column3: THALAMUS and HYPOTHALAMUS and related structures). In adults
column4: primary neoplasms tend to arise in the supratentorial compartment
column5: whereas in children they occur more frequently in the infratentorial space. Clinical manifestations vary with the location of the lesion
column6: but SEIZURES; APHASIA; HEMIANOPSIA; hemiparesis; and sensory deficits are relatively common features. Metastatic supratentorial neoplasms are frequently multiple at the time of presentation.

column1: C10.228.140.211.885.500*D007029*Hypothalamic Neoplasms*Benign and malignant tumors of the HYPOTHALAMUS. Pilocytic astrocytomas and hamartomas are relatively frequent histologic types. Neoplasms of the hypothalamus frequently originate from adjacent structures
column2: including the OPTIC CHIASM
column4: and pituitary gland (see PITUITARY NEOPLASMS). Relatively frequent clinical manifestations include visual loss
column7: and precocious puberty. (From Devita et al.
column8: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column1: C10.228.140.211.885.500.299*D054975*Pallister-Hall Syndrome*A pleiotropic disorder of human development that comprises hypothalamic HAMARTOMA; central and postaxial POLYDACTYLY; bifid EPIGLOTTIS; ANAL ATRESIA; and renal and other abnormalities. This disorder is associated with FRAMESHIFT MUTATIONS in the GLI3 gene which encodes the GLI3 protein
column2: a KRUPPEL-LIKE TRANSCRIPTION FACTORS family member.

column1: C10.228.140.211.885.500.600*D010911*Pituitary Neoplasms*Neoplasms which arise from or metastasize to the PITUITARY GLAND. The majority of pituitary neoplasms are adenomas
column2: which are divided into non-secreting and secreting forms. Hormone producing forms are further classified by the type of hormone they secrete. Pituitary adenomas may also be characterized by their staining properties (see ADENOMA
column5: CHROMOPHOBE). Pituitary tumors may compress adjacent structures
column8: and the OPTIC CHIASM. Chiasmal compression may result in bitemporal HEMIANOPSIA.

column1: C10.228.140.252*D002526*Cerebellar Diseases*Diseases that affect the structure or function of the cerebellum. Cardinal manifestations of cerebellar dysfunction include dysmetria
column2: GAIT ATAXIA

column1: C10.228.140.252.190*D002524*Cerebellar Ataxia*Incoordination of voluntary movements that occur as a manifestation of CEREBELLAR DISEASES. Characteristic features include a tendency for limb movements to overshoot or undershoot a target (dysmetria)
column2: a tremor that occurs during attempted movements (intention TREMOR)
column3: impaired force and rhythm of diadochokinesis (rapidly alternating movements)
column4: and GAIT ATAXIA. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.228.140.252.190.530*D020754*Spinocerebellar Ataxias*A group of dominantly inherited
column2: predominately late-onset
column3: cerebellar ataxias which have been divided into multiple subtypes based on clinical features and genetic mapping. Progressive ataxia is a central feature of these conditions
column4: and in certain subtypes POLYNEUROPATHY; DYSARTHRIA; visual loss; and other disorders may develop. (From Joynt
column8: pp 12-17; J Neuropathol Exp Neurol 1998 Jun;57(6):531-43)

column1: C10.228.140.252.190.530.060*D001260*Ataxia Telangiectasia*An autosomal recessive inherited disorder characterized by choreoathetosis beginning in childhood
column2: progressive CEREBELLAR ATAXIA; TELANGIECTASIS of CONJUNCTIVA and SKIN; DYSARTHRIA; B- and T-cell immunodeficiency
column3: and RADIOSENSITIVITY to IONIZING RADIATION. Affected individuals are prone to recurrent sinobronchopulmonary infections
column5: and other malignancies. Serum ALPHA-FETOPROTEINS are usually elevated. (Menkes
column8: p688) The gene for this disorder (ATM) encodes a cell cycle checkpoint protein kinase and has been mapped to chromosome 11 (11q22-q23).

column1: C10.228.140.252.190.530.530*D017827*Machado-Joseph Disease*A dominantly-inherited ATAXIA first described in people of Azorean and Portuguese descent
column2: and subsequently identified in Brazil
column5: and Australia. This disorder is classified as one of the SPINOCEREBELLAR ATAXIAS (Type 3) and has been associated with a mutation of the MJD1 gene on chromosome 14. Clinical features include progressive ataxia
column10: and facial FASCICULATIONS. DYSTONIA is prominent in younger patients (referred to as Type I Machado-Joseph Disease). Type II features ataxia and ocular signs; Type III features MUSCULAR ATROPHY and a sensorimotor neuropathy; and Type IV features extrapyramidal signs combined with a sensorimotor neuropathy. (From Clin Neurosci 1995;3(1):17-22; Ann Neurol 1998 Mar;43(3):288-96)

column1: C10.228.140.252.200*D002528*Cerebellar Neoplasms*Primary or metastatic neoplasms of the CEREBELLUM. Tumors in this location frequently present with ATAXIA or signs of INTRACRANIAL HYPERTENSION due to obstruction of the fourth ventricle. Common primary cerebellar tumors include fibrillary ASTROCYTOMA and cerebellar HEMANGIOBLASTOMA. The cerebellum is a relatively common site for tumor metastases from the lung
column2: breast
column3: and other distant organs. (From Okazaki & Scheithauer

column1: C10.228.140.252.300*D003616*Dandy-Walker Syndrome*A congenital abnormality of the central nervous system marked by failure of the midline structures of the cerebellum to develop
column2: dilation of the fourth ventricle
column3: and upward displacement of the transverse sinuses
column5: and torcula. Clinical features include occipital bossing

column1: C10.228.140.252.500*D019846*Miller Fisher Syndrome*A variant of the GUILLAIN-BARRE SYNDROME characterized by the acute onset of oculomotor dysfunction
column2: ataxia
column3: and loss of deep tendon reflexes with relative sparing of strength in the extremities and trunk. The ataxia is produced by peripheral sensory nerve dysfunction and not by cerebellar injury. Facial weakness and sensory loss may also occur. The process is mediated by autoantibodies directed against a component of myelin found in peripheral nerves. (Adams et al.

column1: C10.228.140.252.620*D020362*Paraneoplastic Cerebellar Degeneration*Cerebellar degeneration associated with a remote neoplasm. Clinical manifestations include progressive limb and GAIT ATAXIA; DYSARTHRIA; and NYSTAGMUS
column2: PATHOLOGIC. The histologic type of the associated neoplasm is usually carcinoma or lymphoma. Pathologically the cerebellar cortex and subcortical nuclei demonstrate diffuse degenerative changes. Anti-Purkinje cell antibodies (anti-Yo) are found in the serum of approximately 50% of affected individuals. (Adams et al.

column1: C10.228.140.252.700*D013132*Spinocerebellar Degenerations*A heterogenous group of degenerative syndromes marked by progressive cerebellar dysfunction either in isolation or combined with other neurologic manifestations. Sporadic and inherited subtypes occur. Inheritance patterns include autosomal dominant
column2: autosomal recessive

column1: C10.228.140.252.700.150*D005621*Friedreich Ataxia*An autosomal recessive disease
column2: usually of childhood onset
column3: characterized pathologically by degeneration of the spinocerebellar tracts
column5: and to a lesser extent the corticospinal tracts. Clinical manifestations include GAIT ATAXIA
column11: congestive heart failure (secondary to a cardiomyopathy)
column12: and lower extremity weakness. Most forms of this condition are associated with a mutation in a gene on chromosome 9
column14: which codes for the mitochondrial protein frataxin. (From Adams et al.
column17: p1081; N Engl J Med 1996 Oct 17;335(16):1169-75) The severity of Friedreich ataxia associated with expansion of GAA repeats in the first intron of the frataxin gene correlates with the number of trinucleotide repeats. (From Durr et al

column1: C10.228.140.252.700.250*D002527*Myoclonic Cerebellar Dyssynergia*A condition marked by progressive CEREBELLAR ATAXIA combined with MYOCLONUS usually presenting in the third decade of life or later. Additional clinical features may include generalized and focal SEIZURES
column2: spasticity
column3: and DYSKINESIAS. Autosomal recessive and autosomal dominant patterns of inheritance have been reported. Pathologically
column4: the dentate nucleus and brachium conjunctivum of the CEREBELLUM are atrophic
column5: with variable involvement of the spinal cord

column1: C10.228.140.252.700.650*D009849*Olivopontocerebellar Atrophies*A group of inherited and sporadic disorders which share progressive ataxia in combination with atrophy of the CEREBELLUM; PONS; and inferior olivary nuclei. Additional clinical features may include MUSCLE RIGIDITY; NYSTAGMUS
column2: PATHOLOGIC; RETINAL DEGENERATION; MUSCLE SPASTICITY; DEMENTIA; URINARY INCONTINENCE; and OPHTHALMOPLEGIA. The familial form has an earlier onset (second decade) and may feature spinal cord atrophy. The sporadic form tends to present in the fifth or sixth decade
column3: and is considered a clinical subtype of MULTIPLE SYSTEM ATROPHY. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.228.140.252.700.700*D020754*Spinocerebellar Ataxias*A group of dominantly inherited
column2: predominately late-onset
column3: cerebellar ataxias which have been divided into multiple subtypes based on clinical features and genetic mapping. Progressive ataxia is a central feature of these conditions
column4: and in certain subtypes POLYNEUROPATHY; DYSARTHRIA; visual loss; and other disorders may develop. (From Joynt
column8: pp 12-17; J Neuropathol Exp Neurol 1998 Jun;57(6):531-43)

column1: C10.228.140.252.700.700.500*D017827*Machado-Joseph Disease*A dominantly-inherited ATAXIA first described in people of Azorean and Portuguese descent
column2: and subsequently identified in Brazil
column5: and Australia. This disorder is classified as one of the SPINOCEREBELLAR ATAXIAS (Type 3) and has been associated with a mutation of the MJD1 gene on chromosome 14. Clinical features include progressive ataxia
column10: and facial FASCICULATIONS. DYSTONIA is prominent in younger patients (referred to as Type I Machado-Joseph Disease). Type II features ataxia and ocular signs; Type III features MUSCULAR ATROPHY and a sensorimotor neuropathy; and Type IV features extrapyramidal signs combined with a sensorimotor neuropathy. (From Clin Neurosci 1995;3(1):17-22; Ann Neurol 1998 Mar;43(3):288-96)

column1: C10.228.140.300*D002561*Cerebrovascular Disorders*A spectrum of pathological conditions of impaired blood flow in the brain. They can involve vessels (ARTERIES or VEINS) in the CEREBRUM
column2: the CEREBELLUM
column3: and the BRAIN STEM. Major categories include INTRACRANIAL ARTERIOVENOUS MALFORMATIONS; BRAIN ISCHEMIA; CEREBRAL HEMORRHAGE; and others.

column1: C10.228.140.300.100*D020144*Basal Ganglia Cerebrovascular Disease*A pathological condition caused by impaired blood flow in the basal regions of cerebral hemispheres (BASAL GANGLIA)
column2: such as INFARCTION; HEMORRHAGE; or ISCHEMIA in vessels of this brain region including the lateral lenticulostriate arteries. Primary clinical manifestations include involuntary movements (DYSKINESIAS) and muscle weakness (HEMIPARESIS).

column1: C10.228.140.300.100.200*D020145*Basal Ganglia Hemorrhage*Bleeding within the subcortical regions of cerebral hemispheres (BASAL GANGLIA). It is often associated with HYPERTENSION or ARTERIOVENOUS MALFORMATIONS. Clinical manifestations may include HEADACHE; DYSKINESIAS; and HEMIPARESIS.
C10.228.140.300.100.200.500*D020146*Putaminal Hemorrhage*Intracranial bleeding into the PUTAMEN
column2: a BASAL GANGLIA nucleus. This is associated with HYPERTENSION and lipohyalinosis of small blood vessels in the putamen. Clinical manifestations vary with the size of hemorrhage
column3: but include HEMIPARESIS; HEADACHE; and alterations of consciousness.

column1: C10.228.140.300.150*D002545*Brain Ischemia*Localized reduction of blood flow to brain tissue due to arterial obstruction or systemic hypoperfusion. This frequently occurs in conjunction with brain hypoxia (HYPOXIA
column2: BRAIN). Prolonged ischemia is associated with BRAIN INFARCTION.

column1: C10.228.140.300.150.477*D020520*Brain Infarction*Tissue NECROSIS in any area of the brain
column2: including the CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES
column4: and the BRAIN STEM. Brain infarction is the result of a cascade of events initiated by inadequate blood flow through the brain that is followed by HYPOXIA and HYPOGLYCEMIA in brain tissue. Damage may be temporary

column1: C10.228.140.300.150.477.100*D020526*Brain Stem Infarctions*Infarctions that occur in the BRAIN STEM which is comprised of the MIDBRAIN; PONS; and MEDULLA OBLONGATA. There are several named syndromes characterized by their distinctive clinical manifestations and specific sites of ischemic injury.

C10.228.140.300.150.477.100.500*D014854*Lateral Medullary Syndrome*INFARCTION of the dorsolateral aspect of MEDULLA OBLONGATA in the BRAIN STEM. It is caused by occlusion of the VERTEBRAL ARTERY and/or the posterior inferior cerebellar artery. Clinical manifestations vary with the size of infarction
column2: but may include loss of pain and temperature sensation in the ipsilateral face and contralateral body below the chin; ipsilateral HORNER SYNDROME; ipsilateral ATAXIA; DYSARTHRIA; VERTIGO; nausea
column3: hiccup; dysphagia; and VOCAL CORD PARALYSIS. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.228.140.300.150.477.200*D002544*Cerebral Infarction*The formation of an area of NECROSIS in the CEREBRUM caused by an insufficiency of arterial or venous blood flow. Infarcts of the cerebrum are generally classified by hemisphere (i.e.
column2: left vs. right)
Multi-Infarct*Loss of higher cortical functions with retained awareness due to multiple cortical or subcortical CEREBRAL INFARCTION. Memory
column5: and impulse control are often impaired
column6: and may be accompanied by PSEUDOBULBAR PALSY; HEMIPARESIS; reflex abnormalities
column7: and other signs of localized neurologic dysfunction. (From Adams et al.

column2: Anterior Cerebral Artery*NECROSIS occurring in the ANTERIOR CEREBRAL ARTERY system
column3: including branches such as Heubner's artery. These arteries supply blood to the medial and superior parts of the CEREBRAL HEMISPHERE
column4: Infarction in the anterior cerebral artery usually results in sensory and motor impairment in the lower body.

column2: Middle Cerebral Artery*NECROSIS occurring in the MIDDLE CEREBRAL ARTERY distribution system which brings blood to the entire lateral aspects of each CEREBRAL HEMISPHERE. Clinical signs include impaired cognition; APHASIA; AGRAPHIA; weak and numbness in the face and arms
column3: contralaterally or bilaterally depending on the infarction.

column2: Posterior Cerebral Artery*NECROSIS induced by ISCHEMIA in the POSTERIOR CEREBRAL ARTERY distribution system which supplies portions of the BRAIN STEM; the THALAMUS; TEMPORAL LOBE
column3: and OCCIPITAL LOBE. Depending on the size and location of infarction
column4: clinical features include OLFACTION DISORDERS and visual problems (AGNOSIA; ALEXIA; HEMIANOPSIA).

column2: Brain*A disorder characterized by a reduction of oxygen in the blood combined with reduced blood flow (ISCHEMIA) to the brain from a localized obstruction of a cerebral artery or from systemic hypoperfusion. Prolonged hypoxia-ischemia is associated with ISCHEMIC ATTACK
column3: TRANSIENT; BRAIN INFARCTION; BRAIN EDEMA; COMA; and other conditions.

column2: Transient*Brief reversible episodes of focal
column3: nonconvulsive ischemic dysfunction of the brain having a duration of less than 24 hours
column4: and usually less than one hour
column5: caused by transient thrombotic or embolic blood vessel occlusion or stenosis. Events may be classified by arterial distribution
column8: embolic vs. thrombotic). (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.228.140.300.150.956*D014715*Vertebrobasilar Insufficiency*Localized or diffuse reduction in blood flow through the vertebrobasilar arterial system
column2: which supplies the BRAIN STEM; CEREBELLUM; OCCIPITAL LOBE; medial TEMPORAL LOBE; and THALAMUS. Characteristic clinical features include SYNCOPE; lightheadedness; visual disturbances; and VERTIGO. BRAIN STEM INFARCTIONS or other BRAIN INFARCTION may be associated.

column1: C10.228.140.300.150.956.700*D013349*Subclavian Steal Syndrome*A clinically significant reduction in blood supply to the BRAIN STEM and CEREBELLUM (i.e.
column2: VERTEBROBASILAR INSUFFICIENCY) resulting from reversal of blood flow through the VERTEBRAL ARTERY from occlusion or stenosis of the proximal subclavian or brachiocephalic artery. Common symptoms include VERTIGO; SYNCOPE; and INTERMITTENT CLAUDICATION of the involved upper extremity. Subclavian steal may also occur in asymptomatic individuals. (From J Cardiovasc Surg 1994;35(1):11-4; Acta Neurol Scand 1994;90(3):174-8)

column1: C10.228.140.300.200*D002340*Carotid Artery Diseases*Pathological conditions involving the CAROTID ARTERIES
column2: including the common
column4: and external carotid arteries. ATHEROSCLEROSIS and TRAUMA are relatively frequent causes of carotid artery pathology.

column1: C10.228.140.300.200.345*D020212*Carotid Artery Injuries*Damages to the CAROTID ARTERIES caused either by blunt force or penetrating trauma
column2: such as CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA; THORACIC INJURIES; and NECK INJURIES. Damaged carotid arteries can lead to CAROTID ARTERY THROMBOSIS; CAROTID-CAVERNOUS SINUS FISTULA; pseudoaneurysm formation; and INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY DISSECTION. (From Am J Forensic Med Pathol 1997
Internal
column3: Dissection*The splitting of the vessel wall in one or both (left and right) internal carotid arteries (CAROTID ARTERY
column4: INTERNAL). Interstitial hemorrhage into the media of the vessel wall can lead to occlusion of the internal carotid artery and aneurysm formation.

column1: C10.228.140.300.200.355*D002341*Carotid Artery Thrombosis*Blood clot formation in any part of the CAROTID ARTERIES. This may produce CAROTID STENOSIS or occlusion of the vessel
column2: leading to TRANSIENT ISCHEMIC ATTACK; CEREBRAL INFARCTION; or AMAUROSIS FUGAX.

column1: C10.228.140.300.200.360*D016893*Carotid Stenosis*Narrowing or stricture of any part of the CAROTID ARTERIES
column2: most often due to atherosclerotic plaque formation. Ulcerations may form in atherosclerotic plaques and induce THROMBUS formation. Platelet or cholesterol emboli may arise from stenotic carotid lesions and induce a TRANSIENT ISCHEMIC ATTACK; CEREBROVASCULAR ACCIDENT; or temporary blindness (AMAUROSIS FUGAX). (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.228.140.300.510.600*D002532*Intracranial Aneurysm*Abnormal outpouching in the wall of intracranial blood vessels. Most common are the saccular (berry) aneurysms located at branch points in CIRCLE OF WILLIS at the base of the brain. Vessel rupture results in SUBARACHNOID HEMORRHAGE or INTRACRANIAL HEMORRHAGES. Giant aneurysms (>2.5 cm in diameter) may compress adjacent structures
column2: including the OCULOMOTOR NERVE. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.228.140.300.510.800*D002537*Intracranial Arteriosclerosis*Vascular diseases characterized by thickening and hardening of the walls of ARTERIES inside the SKULL. There are three subtypes: (1) atherosclerosis with fatty deposits in the ARTERIAL INTIMA; (2) Monckeberg's sclerosis with calcium deposits in the media and (3) arteriolosclerosis involving the small caliber arteries. Clinical signs include HEADACHE; CONFUSION; transient blindness (AMAUROSIS FUGAX); speech impairment; and HEMIPARESIS.

column1: C10.228.140.300.520*D002538*Intracranial Arteriovenous Malformations*Congenital vascular anomalies in the brain characterized by direct communication between an artery and a vein without passing through the CAPILLARIES. The locations and size of the shunts determine the symptoms including HEADACHES; SEIZURES; STROKE; INTRACRANIAL HEMORRHAGES; mass effect; and vascular steal effect.
C10.228.140.300.520.500*D054080*Vein of Galen Malformations*Congenital arteriovenous malformation involving the VEIN OF GALEN
column2: a large deep vein at the base of the brain. The rush of arterial blood directly into the vein of Galen
column4: can overwhelm the heart and lead to CONGESTIVE HEART FAILURE.

column1: C10.228.140.300.525*D002542*Intracranial Embolism and Thrombosis*Embolism or thrombosis involving blood vessels which supply intracranial structures. Emboli may originate from extracranial or intracranial sources. Thrombosis may occur in arterial or venous structures.

C10.228.140.300.525.400*D020766*Intracranial Embolism*Blocking of a blood vessel in the SKULL by an EMBOLUS which can be a blood clot (THROMBUS) or other undissolved material in the blood stream. Most emboli are of cardiac origin and are associated with HEART DISEASES. Other non-cardiac sources of emboli are usually associated with VASCULAR DISEASES.

C10.228.140.300.525.425*D020767*Intracranial Thrombosis*Formation or presence of a blood clot (THROMBUS) in a blood vessel within the SKULL. Intracranial thrombosis can lead to thrombotic occlusions and BRAIN INFARCTION. The majority of the thrombotic occlusions are associated with ATHEROSCLEROSIS.

column2: Intracranial*Formation or presence of a blood clot (THROMBUS) in the CRANIAL SINUSES
column3: large endothelium-lined venous channels situated within the SKULL. Intracranial sinuses
column9: and many others. Cranial sinus thrombosis can lead to severe HEADACHE; SEIZURE; and other neurological defects.

column1: C10.228.140.300.525.425.500.375*D020226*Cavernous Sinus Thrombosis*Formation or presence of a blood clot (THROMBUS) in the CAVERNOUS SINUS of the brain. Infections of the paranasal sinuses and adjacent structures
column2: CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA
column3: and THROMBOPHILIA are associated conditions. Clinical manifestations include dysfunction of cranial nerves III
column10: and visual loss. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.228.140.300.525.425.500.562*D020227*Lateral Sinus Thrombosis*Formation or presence of a blood clot (THROMBUS) in the LATERAL SINUSES. This condition is often associated with ear infections (OTITIS MEDIA or MASTOIDITIS) without antibiotic treatment. In developed nations
column2: lateral sinus thrombosis can result from CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA; BRAIN NEOPLASMS; NEUROSURGICAL PROCEDURES; THROMBOPHILIA; and other conditions. Clinical features include HEADACHE; VERTIGO; and increased intracranial pressure.

column1: C10.228.140.300.525.425.500.750*D020225*Sagittal Sinus Thrombosis*Formation or presence of a blood clot (THROMBUS) in the SUPERIOR SAGITTAL SINUS or the inferior sagittal sinus. Sagittal sinus thrombosis can result from infections
column2: hematological disorders
column3: CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA; and NEUROSURGICAL PROCEDURES. Clinical features are primarily related to the increased intracranial pressure causing HEADACHE; NAUSEA; and VOMITING. Severe cases can evolve to SEIZURES or COMA.

column1: C10.228.140.300.535*D020300*Intracranial Hemorrhages*Bleeding within the SKULL

column1: C10.228.140.300.535.200*D002543*Cerebral Hemorrhage*Bleeding into one or both CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES including the BASAL GANGLIA and the CEREBRAL CORTEX. It is often associated with HYPERTENSION and CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA.

C10.228.140.300.535.200.150*D020145*Basal Ganglia Hemorrhage*Bleeding within the subcortical regions of cerebral hemispheres (BASAL GANGLIA). It is often associated with HYPERTENSION or ARTERIOVENOUS MALFORMATIONS. Clinical manifestations may include HEADACHE; DYSKINESIAS; and HEMIPARESIS.
C10.228.140.300.535.200.150.500*D020146*Putaminal Hemorrhage*Intracranial bleeding into the PUTAMEN
column2: a BASAL GANGLIA nucleus. This is associated with HYPERTENSION and lipohyalinosis of small blood vessels in the putamen. Clinical manifestations vary with the size of hemorrhage
column3: but include HEMIPARESIS; HEADACHE; and alterations of consciousness.

column2: Traumatic*Bleeding into one or both CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES due to TRAUMA. Hemorrhage may involve any part of the CEREBRAL CORTEX and the BASAL GANGLIA. Depending on the severity of bleeding
column3: clinical features may include SEIZURES; APHASIA; VISION DISORDERS; MOVEMENT DISORDERS; PARALYSIS; and COMA.

column1: C10.228.140.300.535.325*D020299*Intracranial Hemorrhage
column2: Hypertensive*Bleeding within the SKULL that is caused by systemic HYPERTENSION
column3: usually in association with INTRACRANIAL ARTERIOSCLEROSIS. Hypertensive hemorrhages are most frequent in the BASAL GANGLIA; CEREBELLUM; PONS; and THALAMUS; but may also involve the CEREBRAL CORTEX

column1: C10.228.140.300.535.450*D020198*Intracranial Hemorrhage
column2: Traumatic*Bleeding within the SKULL induced by penetrating and nonpenetrating traumatic injuries
column3: including hemorrhages into the tissues of CEREBRUM; BRAIN STEM; and CEREBELLUM; as well as into the epidural
column4: subdural and subarachnoid spaces of the MENINGES.

column2: Traumatic*Bleeding within the brain as a result of penetrating and nonpenetrating CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA. Traumatically induced hemorrhages may occur in any area of the brain

column2: Traumatic*Bleeding into structures of BRAIN STEM
column3: including the MIDBRAIN; PONS; or MEDULLA OBLONGATA
column4: as the result of CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA. DIFFUSE AXONAL INJURY is commonly associated. Clinical manifestations may include OCULAR MOTILITY DISORDERS; ATAXIA; PARALYSIS; PERSISTENT VEGETATIVE STATE; and COMA.

column2: Traumatic*Bleeding into one or both CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES due to TRAUMA. Hemorrhage may involve any part of the CEREBRAL CORTEX and the BASAL GANGLIA. Depending on the severity of bleeding
column3: clinical features may include SEIZURES; APHASIA; VISION DISORDERS; MOVEMENT DISORDERS; PARALYSIS; and COMA.

column2: Epidural
column3: Cranial*Accumulation of blood in the EPIDURAL SPACE between the SKULL and the DURA MATER
column4: often as a result of bleeding from the MENINGEAL ARTERIES associated with a temporal or parietal bone fracture. Epidural hematoma tends to expand rapidly
column5: compressing the dura and underlying brain. Clinical features may include HEADACHE; VOMITING; HEMIPARESIS; and impaired mental function.

column2: Subdural*Accumulation of blood in the SUBDURAL SPACE between the DURA MATER and the arachnoidal layer of the MENINGES. This condition primarily occurs over the surface of a CEREBRAL HEMISPHERE
column3: but may develop in the spinal canal (HEMATOMA
column5: SPINAL). Subdural hematoma can be classified as the acute or the chronic form
column6: with immediate or delayed symptom onset
column7: respectively. Symptoms may include loss of consciousness

column2: Subdural
column3: Acute*Accumulation of blood in the SUBDURAL SPACE with acute onset of neurological symptoms. Symptoms may include loss of consciousness

column2: Subdural
column3: Chronic*Accumulation of blood in the SUBDURAL SPACE with delayed onset of neurological symptoms. Symptoms may include loss of consciousness

column2: Subdural
column3: Intracranial*Accumulation of blood in the SUBDURAL SPACE over the CEREBRAL HEMISPHERE.

column1: C10.228.140.300.535.450.650*D020206*Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
column2: Traumatic*Bleeding into the SUBARACHNOID SPACE due to CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA. Minor hemorrhages may be asymptomatic; moderate to severe hemorrhages may be associated with INTRACRANIAL HYPERTENSION and VASOSPASM

column1: C10.228.140.300.535.625*D010899*Pituitary Apoplexy*The sudden loss of blood supply to the PITUITARY GLAND
column2: leading to tissue NECROSIS and loss of function (PANHYPOPITUITARISM). The most common cause is hemorrhage or INFARCTION of a PITUITARY ADENOMA. It can also result from acute hemorrhage into SELLA TURCICA due to HEAD TRAUMA; INTRACRANIAL HYPERTENSION; or other acute effects of central nervous system hemorrhage. Clinical signs include severe HEADACHE; HYPOTENSION; bilateral visual disturbances; UNCONSCIOUSNESS; and COMA.

column1: C10.228.140.300.535.800*D013345*Subarachnoid Hemorrhage*Bleeding into the intracranial or spinal SUBARACHNOID SPACE
column2: most resulting from INTRACRANIAL ANEURYSM rupture. It can occur after traumatic injuries (SUBARACHNOID HEMORRHAGE
column3: TRAUMATIC). Clinical features include HEADACHE; NAUSEA; VOMITING
column5: variable neurological deficits and reduced mental status.

column1: C10.228.140.300.535.800.700*D020206*Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
column2: Traumatic*Bleeding into the SUBARACHNOID SPACE due to CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA. Minor hemorrhages may be asymptomatic; moderate to severe hemorrhages may be associated with INTRACRANIAL HYPERTENSION and VASOSPASM

Periventricular*Degeneration of white matter adjacent to the CEREBRAL VENTRICLES following cerebral hypoxia or BRAIN ISCHEMIA in neonates. The condition primarily affects white matter in the perfusion zone between superficial and deep branches of the MIDDLE CEREBRAL ARTERY. Clinical manifestations include VISION DISORDERS; CEREBRAL PALSY; PARAPLEGIA; SEIZURES; and cognitive disorders. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.228.140.300.750*D018860*Sneddon Syndrome*A systemic non-inflammatory arteriopathy primarily of middle-aged females characterized by the association of livedo reticularis
column2: multiple thrombotic CEREBRAL INFARCTION; CORONARY DISEASE
column3: and HYPERTENSION. Elevation of antiphospholipid antibody titers (see also ANTIPHOSPHOLIPID SYNDROME)
column6: TRANSIENT; SEIZURES; DEMENTIA; and chronic ischemia of the extremities may also occur. Pathologic examination of affected arteries reveals non-inflammatory adventitial fibrosis
column8: and changes in the media. (From Jablonski

column1: C10.228.140.300.775*D020521*Stroke*A group of pathological conditions characterized by sudden
column2: non-convulsive loss of neurological function due to BRAIN ISCHEMIA or INTRACRANIAL HEMORRHAGES. Stroke is classified by the type of tissue NECROSIS
column7: and hemorrhagic vs. non-hemorrhagic nature. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.228.140.300.775.200*D020520*Brain Infarction*Tissue NECROSIS in any area of the brain
column2: including the CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES
column4: and the BRAIN STEM. Brain infarction is the result of a cascade of events initiated by inadequate blood flow through the brain that is followed by HYPOXIA and HYPOGLYCEMIA in brain tissue. Damage may be temporary

column1: C10.228.140.300.775.200.100*D020526*Brain Stem Infarctions*Infarctions that occur in the BRAIN STEM which is comprised of the MIDBRAIN; PONS; and MEDULLA OBLONGATA. There are several named syndromes characterized by their distinctive clinical manifestations and specific sites of ischemic injury.

C10.228.140.300.775.200.100.500*D014854*Lateral Medullary Syndrome*INFARCTION of the dorsolateral aspect of MEDULLA OBLONGATA in the BRAIN STEM. It is caused by occlusion of the VERTEBRAL ARTERY and/or the posterior inferior cerebellar artery. Clinical manifestations vary with the size of infarction
column2: but may include loss of pain and temperature sensation in the ipsilateral face and contralateral body below the chin; ipsilateral HORNER SYNDROME; ipsilateral ATAXIA; DYSARTHRIA; VERTIGO; nausea
column3: hiccup; dysphagia; and VOCAL CORD PARALYSIS. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.228.140.300.775.200.200*D002544*Cerebral Infarction*The formation of an area of NECROSIS in the CEREBRUM caused by an insufficiency of arterial or venous blood flow. Infarcts of the cerebrum are generally classified by hemisphere (i.e.
column2: left vs. right)
Multi-Infarct*Loss of higher cortical functions with retained awareness due to multiple cortical or subcortical CEREBRAL INFARCTION. Memory
column5: and impulse control are often impaired
column6: and may be accompanied by PSEUDOBULBAR PALSY; HEMIPARESIS; reflex abnormalities
column7: and other signs of localized neurologic dysfunction. (From Adams et al.

column2: Anterior Cerebral Artery*NECROSIS occurring in the ANTERIOR CEREBRAL ARTERY system
column3: including branches such as Heubner's artery. These arteries supply blood to the medial and superior parts of the CEREBRAL HEMISPHERE
column4: Infarction in the anterior cerebral artery usually results in sensory and motor impairment in the lower body.

column2: Middle Cerebral Artery*NECROSIS occurring in the MIDDLE CEREBRAL ARTERY distribution system which brings blood to the entire lateral aspects of each CEREBRAL HEMISPHERE. Clinical signs include impaired cognition; APHASIA; AGRAPHIA; weak and numbness in the face and arms
column3: contralaterally or bilaterally depending on the infarction.

column2: Posterior Cerebral Artery*NECROSIS induced by ISCHEMIA in the POSTERIOR CEREBRAL ARTERY distribution system which supplies portions of the BRAIN STEM; the THALAMUS; TEMPORAL LOBE
column3: and OCCIPITAL LOBE. Depending on the size and location of infarction
column4: clinical features include OLFACTION DISORDERS and visual problems (AGNOSIA; ALEXIA; HEMIANOPSIA).

column2: Lacunar*Stroke caused by lacunar infarction or other small vessel diseases of the brain. It features hemiparesis (see PARESIS)

column1: C10.228.140.300.787*D055955*Susac Syndrome*A rare disorder consisting of microangiopathy of brain
column2: retina
column3: and inner ear ARTERIOLES. It is characterized by the clinical triad of encephalopathy
column4: BRANCH RETINAL ARTERY OCCLUSION and VERTIGO/hearing loss.

column1: C10.228.140.300.800*D014653*Vascular Headaches*Secondary headache disorders attributed to a variety of cranial or cervical vascular disorders
column2: such as BRAIN ISCHEMIA; INTRACRANIAL HEMORRHAGES; and CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM VASCULAR MALFORMATIONS.
Central Nervous System*Inflammation of blood vessels within the central nervous system. Primary vasculitis is usually caused by autoimmune or idiopathic factors
column3: while secondary vasculitis is caused by existing disease process. Clinical manifestations are highly variable but include HEADACHE; SEIZURES; behavioral alterations; INTRACRANIAL HEMORRHAGES; TRANSIENT ISCHEMIC ATTACK; and BRAIN INFARCTION. (From Adams et al.

column2: Central Nervous System*Inflammation of ARTERIES in the CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM that occurs in patients with ACQUIRED IMMUNODEFICIENCY SYNDROME or AIDS-RELATED OPPORTUNISTIC INFECTIONS.

column1: C10.228.140.300.850.500*D013700*Giant Cell Arteritis*A systemic autoimmune disorder that typically affects medium and large ARTERIES
column2: usually leading to occlusive granulomatous vasculitis with transmural infiltrate containing multinucleated GIANT CELLS. The TEMPORAL ARTERY is commonly involved. This disorder appears primarily in people over the age of 50. Symptoms include FEVER; FATIGUE; HEADACHE; visual impairment; pain in the jaw and tongue; and aggravation of pain by cold temperatures. (From Adams et al.

Central Nervous System*Central nervous system vasculitis that is associated with SYSTEMIC LUPUS ERYTHEMATOSUS. Clinical manifestations may include DEMENTIA; SEIZURES; CRANIAL NERVE DISEASES; HEMIPARESIS; BLINDNESS; DYSPHASIA; and other neurological disorders.
Intracranial*Constriction of arteries in the SKULL due to sudden
column4: and often persistent smooth muscle contraction in blood vessels. Intracranial vasospasm results in reduced vessel lumen caliber
column5: restricted blood flow to the brain
column6: and BRAIN ISCHEMIA that may lead to hypoxic-ischemic brain injury (HYPOXIA-ISCHEMIA

column1: C10.228.140.380*D003704*Dementia*An acquired organic mental disorder with loss of intellectual abilities of sufficient severity to interfere with social or occupational functioning. The dysfunction is multifaceted and involves memory
column2: behavior
column9: and other executive functions. The intellectual decline is usually progressive
column10: and initially spares the level of consciousness.

column1: C10.228.140.380.070*D015526*AIDS Dementia Complex*A neurologic condition associated with the ACQUIRED IMMUNODEFICIENCY SYNDROME and characterized by impaired concentration and memory
column2: slowness of hand movements
column6: and gait difficulties associated with HIV-1 viral infection of the central nervous system. Pathologic examination of the brain reveals white matter rarefaction
column9: and multinucleated giant cells. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.228.140.380.100*D000544*Alzheimer Disease*A degenerative disease of the BRAIN characterized by the insidious onset of DEMENTIA. Impairment of MEMORY
column2: judgment
column4: and problem solving skills are followed by severe APRAXIAS and a global loss of cognitive abilities. The condition primarily occurs after age 60
column5: and is marked pathologically by severe cortical atrophy and the triad of SENILE PLAQUES; NEUROFIBRILLARY TANGLES; and NEUROPIL THREADS. (From Adams et al.

column2: Primary Progressive*A progressive form of dementia characterized by the global loss of language abilities and initial preservation of other cognitive functions. Fluent and nonfluent subtypes have been described. Eventually a pattern of global cognitive dysfunction
column5: there are no Alzheimer or PICK DISEASE like changes
column7: spongiform changes of cortical layers II and III are present in the TEMPORAL LOBE and FRONTAL LOBE. (From Brain 1998 Jan;121(Pt 1):115-26)

column1: C10.228.140.380.132.600*D057178*Primary Progressive Nonfluent Aphasia*A form of frontotemporal lobar degeneration and a progressive form of dementia characterized by motor speech impairment and AGRAMMATISM
column2: with relative sparing of single word comprehension and semantic memory.

column1: C10.228.140.380.165*D007562*Creutzfeldt-Jakob Syndrome*A rare transmissible encephalopathy most prevalent between the ages of 50 and 70 years. Affected individuals may present with sleep disturbances
column2: personality changes
column9: and death within one year of disease onset. A familial form exhibiting autosomal dominant inheritance and a new variant CJD (potentially associated with ENCEPHALOPATHY
column10: BOVINE SPONGIFORM) have been described. Pathological features include prominent cerebellar and cerebral cortical spongiform degeneration and the presence of PRIONS. (From N Engl J Med

column2: Vascular*An imprecise term referring to dementia associated with CEREBROVASCULAR DISORDERS
column4: and conditions associated with chronic BRAIN ISCHEMIA. Diffuse
column6: and subcortical subtypes have been described. (From Gerontol Geriatr 1998 Feb;31(1):36-44)

column2: cerebral arteriopathy mapped to chromosome 19q12
column3: and characterized by the presence of granular deposits in small CEREBRAL ARTERIES producing ischemic STROKE; PSEUDOBULBAR PALSY; and multiple subcortical infarcts (CEREBRAL INFARCTION). CADASIL is an acronym for Cerebral Autosomal Dominant Arteriopathy with Subcortical Infarcts and Leukoencephalopathy. CADASIL differs from BINSWANGER DISEASE by the presence of MIGRAINE WITH AURA and usually by the lack of history of arterial HYPERTENSION. (From Bradley et al

column2: Multi-Infarct*Loss of higher cortical functions with retained awareness due to multiple cortical or subcortical CEREBRAL INFARCTION. Memory
column5: and impulse control are often impaired
column6: and may be accompanied by PSEUDOBULBAR PALSY; HEMIPARESIS; reflex abnormalities
column7: and other signs of localized neurologic dysfunction. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.228.140.380.254*D055956*Diffuse Neurofibrillary Tangles with Calcification*A form of presenile DEMENTIA characterized by cortical dementia
column2: NEUROFIBRILLARY TANGLES without SENILE PLAQUES
column4: and ATROPHY in frontotemporal or TEMPORAL LOBE.

column1: C10.228.140.380.266*D057174*Frontotemporal Lobar Degeneration*Heterogeneous group of neurodegenerative disorders characterized by frontal and temporal lobe atrophy associated with neuronal loss
column2: gliosis
column3: and dementia. Patients exhibit progressive changes in social
column5: and/or language function. Multiple subtypes or forms are recognized based on presence or absence of TAU PROTEIN inclusions. FTLD includes three clinical syndromes: FRONTOTEMPORAL DEMENTIA

column1: C10.228.140.380.266.299*D057180*Frontotemporal Dementia*The most common clinical form of FRONTOTEMPORAL LOBAR DEGENERATION
column2: this dementia presents with personality and behavioral changes often associated with disinhibition

column1: C10.228.140.380.266.299.500*D020774*Pick Disease of the Brain*A rare form of DEMENTIA that is sometimes familial. Clinical features include APHASIA; APRAXIA; CONFUSION; ANOMIA; memory loss; and personality deterioration. This pattern is consistent with the pathologic findings of circumscribed atrophy of the poles of the FRONTAL LOBE and TEMPORAL LOBE. Neuronal loss is maximal in the HIPPOCAMPUS
column2: entorhinal cortex
column3: and AMYGDALA. Some ballooned cortical neurons contain argentophylic (Pick) bodies. (From Brain Pathol 1998 Apr;8(2):339-54; Adams et al.

column1: C10.228.140.380.266.600*D057178*Primary Progressive Nonfluent Aphasia*A form of frontotemporal lobar degeneration and a progressive form of dementia characterized by motor speech impairment and AGRAMMATISM
column2: with relative sparing of single word comprehension and semantic memory.

column1: C10.228.140.380.278*D006816*Huntington Disease*A familial disorder inherited as an autosomal dominant trait and characterized by the onset of progressive CHOREA and DEMENTIA in the fourth or fifth decade of life. Common initial manifestations include paranoia; poor impulse control; DEPRESSION; HALLUCINATIONS; and DELUSIONS. Eventually intellectual impairment; loss of fine motor control; ATHETOSIS; and diffuse chorea involving axial and limb musculature develops
column2: leading to a vegetative state within 10-15 years of disease onset. The juvenile variant has a more fulminant course including SEIZURES; ATAXIA; dementia; and chorea. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.228.140.380.326*D020232*Kluver-Bucy Syndrome*A neurobehavioral syndrome associated with bilateral medial temporal lobe dysfunction. Clinical manifestations include oral exploratory behavior; tactile exploratory behavior; hypersexuality; BULIMIA; MEMORY DISORDERS; placidity; and an inability to recognize objects or faces. This disorder may result from a variety of conditions
column2: including CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA; infections; ALZHEIMER DISEASE; PICK DISEASE OF THE BRAIN; and CEREBROVASCULAR DISORDERS.

column1: C10.228.140.380.422*D020961*Lewy Body Disease*A neurodegenerative disease characterized by dementia
column2: mild parkinsonism
column3: and fluctuations in attention and alertness. The neuropsychiatric manifestations tend to precede the onset of bradykinesia
column5: and other extrapyramidal signs. DELUSIONS and visual HALLUCINATIONS are relatively frequent in this condition. Histologic examination reveals LEWY BODIES in the CEREBRAL CORTEX and BRAIN STEM. SENILE PLAQUES and other pathologic features characteristic of ALZHEIMER DISEASE may also be present. (From Neurology 1997;48:376-380; Neurology 1996;47:1113-1124)

column1: C10.228.140.400*D002549*Diffuse Cerebral Sclerosis of Schilder*A rare central nervous system demyelinating condition affecting children and young adults. Pathologic findings include a large
column2: sharply defined
column3: asymmetric focus of myelin destruction that may involve an entire lobe or cerebral hemisphere. The clinical course tends to be progressive and includes dementia
column7: and pseudobulbar palsy. Concentric sclerosis of Balo is differentiated from diffuse cerebral sclerosis of Schilder by the pathologic finding of alternating bands of destruction and preservation of myelin in concentric rings. Alpers' Syndrome refers to a heterogeneous group of diseases that feature progressive cerebral deterioration and liver disease. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.228.140.430*D004660*Encephalitis*Inflammation of the BRAIN due to infection
column2: autoimmune processes
column4: and other conditions. Viral infections (see ENCEPHALITIS
column5: VIRAL) are a relatively frequent cause of this condition.

column1: C10.228.140.430.124*D060426*Anti-N-Methyl-D-Aspartate Receptor Encephalitis*Disorder characterized by symptoms of CATATONIA; HYPOVENTILATION; DYSKINESIAS; ENCEPHALITIS; and SEIZURES followed by a reduced CONSCIOUSNESS. It is often followed by a viral-like prodrome. Many cases are self-limiting and respond well to IMMUNOMODULATORY THERAPIES against the NMDA RECEPTORS antibodies.
C10.228.140.430.249*D058565*Cerebral Ventriculitis*Inflammation of CEREBRAL VENTRICLES.
C10.228.140.430.520*D000069544*Infectious Encephalitis*Brain inflammation caused by an infectious agent..

column2: Viral*Inflammation of brain parenchymal tissue as a result of viral infection. Encephalitis may occur as primary or secondary manifestation of TOGAVIRIDAE INFECTIONS; HERPESVIRIDAE INFECTIONS; ADENOVIRIDAE INFECTIONS; FLAVIVIRIDAE INFECTIONS; BUNYAVIRIDAE INFECTIONS; PICORNAVIRIDAE INFECTIONS; PARAMYXOVIRIDAE INFECTIONS; ORTHOMYXOVIRIDAE INFECTIONS; RETROVIRIDAE INFECTIONS; and ARENAVIRIDAE INFECTIONS.
Arbovirus*Infections of the brain caused by arthropod-borne viruses (i.e.
column3: arboviruses) primarily from the families TOGAVIRIDAE; FLAVIVIRIDAE; BUNYAVIRIDAE; REOVIRIDAE; and RHABDOVIRIDAE. Life cycles of these viruses are characterized by ZOONOSES
column4: with birds and lower mammals serving as intermediate hosts. The virus is transmitted to humans by the bite of mosquitoes (CULICIDAE) or TICKS. Clinical manifestations include fever
column8: and COMA. (From Clin Microbiol Rev 1994 Jan;7(1):89-116; Walton
column9: Brain's Diseases of the Nervous System

column2: California*A viral infection of the brain caused by serotypes of California encephalitis virus (ENCEPHALITIS VIRUS
column3: CALIFORNIA) transmitted to humans by the mosquito AEDES triseriatus. The majority of cases are caused by the LA CROSSE VIRUS. This condition is endemic to the midwestern United States and primarily affects children between 5-10 years of age. Clinical manifestations include FEVER; VOMITING; HEADACHE; and abdominal pain followed by SEIZURES

column2: Japanese*A mosquito-borne encephalitis caused by the Japanese B encephalitis virus (ENCEPHALITIS VIRUS
column3: JAPANESE) occurring throughout Eastern Asia and Australia. The majority of infections occur in children and are subclinical or have features limited to transient fever and gastrointestinal symptoms. Inflammation of the brain
column5: and meninges may occur and lead to transient or permanent neurologic deficits (including a POLIOMYELITIS-like presentation); SEIZURES; COMA; and death. (From Adams et al.

column2: St. Louis*A viral encephalitis caused by the St. Louis encephalitis virus (ENCEPHALITIS VIRUS
column4: a FLAVIVIRUS. It is transmitted to humans and other vertebrates primarily by mosquitoes of the genus CULEX. The primary animal vectors are wild birds and the disorder is endemic to the midwestern and southeastern United States. Infections may be limited to an influenza-like illness or present as an ASEPTIC MENINGITIS or ENCEPHALITIS. Clinical manifestations of the encephalitic presentation may include SEIZURES

column2: Tick-Borne*Encephalitis caused by neurotropic viruses that are transmitted via the bite of TICKS. In Europe
column3: the diseases are caused by ENCEPHALITIS VIRUSES
column5: which give rise to Russian spring-summer encephalitis
column8: and related disorders. Powassan encephalitis occurs in North America and Russia and is caused by the Powassan virus. ASEPTIC MENINGITIS and rarely encephalitis may complicate COLORADO TICK FEVER which is endemic to mountainous regions of the western United States. (From Joynt

column1: C10.228.140.430.520.750.300.887*D014901*West Nile Fever*A mosquito-borne viral illness caused by the WEST NILE VIRUS
column2: a FLAVIVIRUS and endemic to regions of Africa
column4: and Europe. Common clinical features include HEADACHE; FEVER; maculopapular rash; gastrointestinal symptoms; and lymphadenopathy. MENINGITIS; ENCEPHALITIS; and MYELITIS may also occur. The disease may occasionally be fatal or leave survivors with residual neurologic deficits. (From Joynt

column2: Herpes Simplex*An acute (or rarely chronic) inflammatory process of the brain caused by SIMPLEXVIRUS infections which may be fatal. The majority of infections are caused by human herpesvirus 1 (HERPESVIRUS 1
column3: HUMAN) and less often by human herpesvirus 2 (HERPESVIRUS 2
column4: HUMAN). Clinical manifestations include FEVER; HEADACHE; SEIZURES; HALLUCINATIONS; behavioral alterations; APHASIA; hemiparesis; and COMA. Pathologically
column5: the condition is marked by a hemorrhagic necrosis involving the medial and inferior TEMPORAL LOBE and orbital regions of the FRONTAL LOBE. (From Adams et al.

column2: Varicella Zoster*Inflammation of brain tissue caused by infection with the varicella-zoster virus (HERPESVIRUS 3
column3: HUMAN). This condition is associated with immunocompromised states
column4: including the ACQUIRED IMMUNODEFICIENCY SYNDROME. Pathologically
column5: the virus tends to induce a vasculopathy and infect oligodendrocytes and ependymal cells
column8: and periventricular necrosis. Manifestations of varicella encephalitis usually occur 5-7 days after onset of HERPES ZOSTER and include HEADACHE; VOMITING; lethargy; focal neurologic deficits; FEVER; and COMA. (From Joynt

column2: Equine*A group of ALPHAVIRUS INFECTIONS which affect horses and man
column3: transmitted via the bites of mosquitoes. Disorders in this category are endemic to regions of South America and North America. In humans
column4: clinical manifestations vary with the type of infection
column5: and range from a mild influenza-like syndrome to a fulminant encephalitis. (From Joynt

column2: Eastern Equine*A form of arboviral encephalitis (primarily affecting equines) endemic to eastern regions of North America. The causative organism (ENCEPHALOMYELITIS VIRUS
column3: EASTERN EQUINE) may be transmitted to humans via the bite of AEDES mosquitoes. Clinical manifestations include the acute onset of fever
column6: and SEIZURES followed by coma. The condition is fatal in up to 50% of cases. Recovery may be marked by residual neurologic deficits and EPILEPSY. (From Joynt

column2: Venezuelan Equine*A form of arboviral encephalitis endemic to Central America and the northern latitudes of South America. The causative organism (ENCEPHALITIS VIRUS
column3: VENEZUELAN EQUINE) is transmitted to humans and horses via the bite of several mosquito species. Human viral infection may be asymptomatic or remain restricted to a mild influenza-like illness. Encephalitis
column5: occurs in a small percentage of cases and may rarely feature SEIZURES and COMA. (From Joynt

column2: Western Equine*A form of arboviral encephalitis (which primarily affects horses) endemic to western and central regions of NORTH AMERICA. The causative organism (ENCEPHALOMYELITIS VIRUS
column3: WESTERN EQUINE) may be transferred to humans via the bite of mosquitoes (CULEX tarsalis and others). Clinical manifestations include headache and influenza-like symptoms followed by alterations in mentation
column5: and COMA. DEATH occurs in a minority of cases. Survivors may recover fully or be left with residual neurologic dysfunction

column2: Progressive Multifocal*An opportunistic viral infection of the central nervous system associated with conditions that impair cell-mediated immunity (e.g.
column3: ACQUIRED IMMUNODEFICIENCY SYNDROME and other IMMUNOLOGIC DEFICIENCY SYNDROMES; HEMATOLOGIC NEOPLASMS; IMMUNOSUPPRESSION; and COLLAGEN DISEASES). The causative organism is JC Polyomavirus (JC VIRUS) which primarily affects oligodendrocytes
column4: resulting in multiple areas of demyelination. Clinical manifestations include DEMENTIA; ATAXIA; visual disturbances; and other focal neurologic deficits
column5: generally progressing to a vegetative state within 6 months. (From Joynt

column1: C10.228.140.430.520.750.600*D013344*Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis*A rare
column2: slowly progressive encephalitis caused by chronic infection with the MEASLES VIRUS. The condition occurs primarily in children and young adults

A gradual decline in intellectual abilities and behavioral alterations are followed by progressive MYOCLONUS; MUSCLE SPASTICITY; SEIZURES; DEMENTIA; autonomic dysfunction; and ATAXIA. DEATH usually occurs 1-3 years after disease onset. Pathologic features include perivascular cuffing
column6: and fibrous gliosis. It is caused by the SSPE virus
column7: which is a defective variant of MEASLES VIRUS. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.228.140.430.525*D020363*Limbic Encephalitis*A paraneoplastic syndrome marked by degeneration of neurons in the LIMBIC SYSTEM. Clinical features include HALLUCINATIONS
column2: loss of EPISODIC MEMORY; ANOSMIA; AGEUSIA; TEMPORAL LOBE EPILEPSY; DEMENTIA; and affective disturbance (depression). Circulating anti-neuronal antibodies (e.g.
column3: anti-Hu; anti-Yo; anti-Ri; and anti-Ma2) and small cell lung carcinomas or testicular carcinoma are frequently associated with this syndrome.

column1: C10.228.140.430.550*D008590*Meningoencephalitis*An inflammatory process involving the brain (ENCEPHALITIS) and meninges (MENINGITIS)
column2: most often produced by pathogenic organisms which invade the central nervous system

Central Nervous System*Central nervous system vasculitis that is associated with SYSTEMIC LUPUS ERYTHEMATOSUS. Clinical manifestations may include DEMENTIA; SEIZURES; CRANIAL NERVE DISEASES; HEMIPARESIS; BLINDNESS; DYSPHASIA; and other neurological disorders.

column1: C10.228.140.461*D004678*Encephalomalacia*Softening or loss of brain tissue following CEREBRAL INFARCTION; cerebral ischemia (see BRAIN ISCHEMIA)
column2: infection
column4: or other injury. The term is often used during gross pathologic inspection to describe blurred cortical margins and decreased consistency of brain tissue following infarction. Multicystic encephalomalacia refers to the formation of multiple cystic cavities of various sizes in the cerebral cortex of neonates and infants following injury
column5: most notably perinatal hypoxia-ischemic events. (From Davis et al.

column2: Periventricular*Degeneration of white matter adjacent to the CEREBRAL VENTRICLES following cerebral hypoxia or BRAIN ISCHEMIA in neonates. The condition primarily affects white matter in the perfusion zone between superficial and deep branches of the MIDDLE CEREBRAL ARTERY. Clinical manifestations include VISION DISORDERS; CEREBRAL PALSY; PARAPLEGIA; SEIZURES; and cognitive disorders. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.228.140.490*D004827*Epilepsy*A disorder characterized by recurrent episodes of paroxysmal brain dysfunction due to a sudden
column2: disorderly
column3: and excessive neuronal discharge. Epilepsy classification systems are generally based upon: (1) clinical features of the seizure episodes (e.g.
column9: (4) tendency to spread to other structures in the brain

column1: C10.228.140.490.125*D000069279*Drug Resistant Epilepsy*Epileptic condition in which adequate trials of two tolerated and appropriately chosen and used ANTIEPILEPTIC DRUGS schedules to achieve sustained seizure freedom failed.

column2: Myoclonic*A clinically diverse group of epilepsy syndromes characterized either by myoclonic seizures or by myoclonus in association with other seizure types. Myoclonic epilepsy syndromes are divided into three subtypes based on etiology: familial
column5: occurring secondary to known disease processes such as infections

column1: C10.228.140.490.250.650*D020191*Myoclonic Epilepsies
