column5: and subjective cognitive impairment of 6 months duration or longer. Symptoms are not caused by ongoing exertion; are not relieved by rest; and result in a substantial reduction of previous levels of occupational
column8: or personal activities. Minor alterations of immune
column10: and autonomic function may be associated with this syndrome. There is also considerable overlap between this condition and FIBROMYALGIA. (From Semin Neurol 1998;18(2):237-42; Ann Intern Med 1994 Dec 15;121(12): 953-9)

column1: C10.228.566*D006610*High Pressure Neurological Syndrome*A syndrome related to increased atmospheric pressure and characterized by tremors
column2: nausea
column5: and SEIZURES. This condition may occur in those who dive deeply (c. 1000 ft) usually while breathing a mixture of oxygen and helium. The condition is associated with a neuroexcitatory effect of helium.

column1: C10.228.590*D000071017*Hyperekplexia*A neurological disorder characterized by an excessive startle reaction with ABNORMAL REFLEX;  MYOCLONIC JERKS; and MUSCLE HYPERTONIA.
C10.228.614*D008581*Meningitis*Inflammation of the coverings of the brain and/or spinal cord
column2: which consist of the PIA MATER; ARACHNOID; and DURA MATER. Infections (viral
column4: and fungal) are the most common causes of this condition
column10: and other inflammatory conditions may produce this syndrome. (From Joynt

column1: C10.228.614.097*D001100*Arachnoiditis*Acute or chronic inflammation of the arachnoid membrane of the meninges most often involving the spinal cord or base of the brain. This term generally refers to a persistent inflammatory process characterized by thickening of the ARACHNOID membrane and dural adhesions. Associated conditions include prior surgery
column2: infections
column5: and chemical irritation. Clinical features vary with the site of inflammation

column2: Aseptic*A syndrome characterized by headache
column5: and CSF lymphocytic pleocytosis in the absence of an acute bacterial pathogen. Viral meningitis is the most frequent cause although MYCOPLASMA INFECTIONS; RICKETTSIA INFECTIONS; diagnostic or therapeutic procedures; NEOPLASTIC PROCESSES; septic perimeningeal foci; and other conditions may result in this syndrome. (From Adams et al.

column2: Bacterial*Bacterial infections of the leptomeninges and subarachnoid space
Escherichia coli*A form of gram-negative meningitis that tends to occur in neonates
column3: in association with anatomical abnormalities (which feature communication between the meninges and cutaneous structures) or as OPPORTUNISTIC INFECTIONS in association with IMMUNOLOGIC DEFICIENCY SYNDROMES. In premature neonates the clinical presentation may be limited to ANOREXIA; VOMITING; lethargy; or respiratory distress. Full-term infants may have as additional features FEVER; SEIZURES; and bulging of the anterior fontanelle. (From Menkes

column2: Haemophilus*Infections of the nervous system caused by bacteria of the genus HAEMOPHILUS
column3: and marked by prominent inflammation of the MENINGES. HAEMOPHILUS INFLUENZAE TYPE B is the most common causative organism. The condition primarily affects children under 6 years of age but may occur in adults.

column2: Listeria*Inflammation of the meninges caused by LISTERIA MONOCYTOGENES infection
column3: usually occurring in individuals under the age of 3 years or over the age of 50 years. It may occur at any age in individuals with IMMUNOLOGIC DEFICIENCY SYNDROMES. Clinical manifestations include FEVER

column2: Meningococcal*A fulminant infection of the meninges and subarachnoid fluid by the bacterium NEISSERIA MENINGITIDIS
column3: producing diffuse inflammation and peri-meningeal venous thromboses. Clinical manifestations include FEVER
column11: and COMA. The organism is usually transmitted via nasopharyngeal secretions and is a leading cause of meningitis in children and young adults. Organisms from Neisseria meningitidis serogroups A
column15: and W-135 have been reported to cause meningitis. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.228.614.280.505.904*D014884*Waterhouse-Friderichsen Syndrome*A condition of HEMORRHAGE and NECROSIS of the ADRENAL GLAND. It is characterized by rapidly developing ADRENAL INSUFFICIENCY; HYPOTENSION; and widespread cutaneous PURPURA.

column2: Pneumococcal*An acute purulent infection of the meninges and subarachnoid space caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae
column3: most prevalent in children and adults over the age of 60. This illness may be associated with OTITIS MEDIA; MASTOIDITIS; SINUSITIS; RESPIRATORY TRACT INFECTIONS; sickle cell disease (ANEMIA
column4: SICKLE CELL); skull fractures; and other disorders. Clinical manifestations include FEVER; HEADACHE; neck stiffness; and somnolence followed by SEIZURES; focal neurologic deficits (notably DEAFNESS); and COMA. (From Miller et al.

column2: Meningeal*A form of bacterial meningitis caused by MYCOBACTERIUM TUBERCULOSIS or rarely MYCOBACTERIUM BOVIS. The organism seeds the meninges and forms microtuberculomas which subsequently rupture. The clinical course tends to be subacute
column3: with progressions occurring over a period of several days or longer. Headache and meningeal irritation may be followed by SEIZURES
column7: and eventually COMA. The illness may occur in immunocompetent individuals or as an OPPORTUNISTIC INFECTION in the ACQUIRED IMMUNODEFICIENCY SYNDROME and other immunodeficiency syndromes. (From Adams et al.

column2: Fungal*Meningitis caused by fungal agents which may occur as OPPORTUNISTIC INFECTIONS or arise in immunocompetent hosts.
Cryptococcal*Meningeal inflammation produced by CRYPTOCOCCUS NEOFORMANS
column3: an encapsulated yeast that tends to infect individuals with ACQUIRED IMMUNODEFICIENCY SYNDROME and other immunocompromised states. The organism enters the body through the respiratory tract
column4: but symptomatic infections are usually limited to the lungs and nervous system. The organism may also produce parenchymal brain lesions (torulomas). Clinically
column5: the course is subacute and may feature HEADACHE; NAUSEA; PHOTOPHOBIA; focal neurologic deficits; SEIZURES; cranial neuropathies; and HYDROCEPHALUS. (From Adams et al.

column2: Viral*Viral infections of the leptomeninges and subarachnoid space. TOGAVIRIDAE INFECTIONS; FLAVIVIRIDAE INFECTIONS; RUBELLA; BUNYAVIRIDAE INFECTIONS; ORBIVIRUS infections; PICORNAVIRIDAE INFECTIONS; ORTHOMYXOVIRIDAE INFECTIONS; RHABDOVIRIDAE INFECTIONS; ARENAVIRIDAE INFECTIONS; HERPESVIRIDAE INFECTIONS; ADENOVIRIDAE INFECTIONS; JC VIRUS infections; and RETROVIRIDAE INFECTIONS may cause this form of meningitis. Clinical manifestations include fever
column7: and signs of meningeal irritation. (From Joynt

column1: C10.228.614.400.500*D008216*Lymphocytic Choriomeningitis*A form of meningitis caused by LYMPHOCYTIC CHORIOMENINGITIS VIRUS. MICE and other rodents serve as the natural hosts
column2: and infection in humans usually occurs through inhalation or ingestion of infectious particles. Clinical manifestations include an influenza-like syndrome followed by stiff neck
column5: and incontinence. Maternal infections may result in fetal malformations and injury

column1: C10.228.614.500*D008590*Meningoencephalitis*An inflammatory process involving the brain (ENCEPHALITIS) and meninges (MENINGITIS)
column2: most often produced by pathogenic organisms which invade the central nervous system

Central Nervous System*Central nervous system vasculitis that is associated with SYSTEMIC LUPUS ERYTHEMATOSUS. Clinical manifestations may include DEMENTIA; SEIZURES; CRANIAL NERVE DISEASES; HEMIPARESIS; BLINDNESS; DYSPHASIA; and other neurological disorders.

column1: C10.228.662*D009069*Movement Disorders*Syndromes which feature DYSKINESIAS as a cardinal manifestation of the disease process. Included in this category are degenerative
column2: hereditary
Drug-Induced*A condition associated with the use of certain medications and characterized by an internal sense of motor restlessness often described as an inability to resist the urge to move.

column1: C10.228.662.075*D017204*Angelman Syndrome*A syndrome characterized by multiple abnormalities
column2: MENTAL RETARDATION
column3: and movement disorders. Present usually are skull and other abnormalities
column5: INFANTILE); easily provoked and prolonged paroxysms of laughter (hence happy); jerky puppetlike movements (hence puppet); continuous tongue protrusion; motor retardation; ATAXIA; MUSCLE HYPOTONIA; and a peculiar facies. It is associated with maternal deletions of chromosome 15q11-13 and other genetic abnormalities. (From Am J Med Genet 1998 Dec 4;80(4):385-90; Hum Mol Genet 1999 Jan;8(1):129-35)

column1: C10.228.662.262*D020820*Dyskinesias*Abnormal involuntary movements which primarily affect the extremities
column2: trunk
column3: or jaw that occur as a manifestation of an underlying disease process. Conditions which feature recurrent or persistent episodes of dyskinesia as a primary manifestation of disease may be referred to as dyskinesia syndromes (see MOVEMENT DISORDERS). Dyskinesias are also a relatively common manifestation of BASAL GANGLIA DISEASES.

column1: C10.228.662.262.249*D002819*Chorea*Involuntary
column2: forcible
column4: jerky movements that may be subtle or become confluent
column5: markedly altering normal patterns of movement. Hypotonia and pendular reflexes are often associated. Conditions which feature recurrent or persistent episodes of chorea as a primary manifestation of disease are referred to as CHOREATIC DISORDERS. Chorea is also a frequent manifestation of BASAL GANGLIA DISEASES.

column1: C10.228.662.262.249.500*D020150*Chorea Gravidarum*A rare movement disorder developed during PREGNANCY
column2: characterized by involuntary jerky motion (CHOREA) and inability to maintain stable position of body parts (ATHETOSIS). RHEUMATIC FEVER and collagen vascular disorders are frequently associated with this disease. Chorea may vary from mild to severe and occurs in approximately 1 per 2

column1: C10.228.662.262.249.750*D006816*Huntington Disease*A familial disorder inherited as an autosomal dominant trait and characterized by the onset of progressive CHOREA and DEMENTIA in the fourth or fifth decade of life. Common initial manifestations include paranoia; poor impulse control; DEPRESSION; HALLUCINATIONS; and DELUSIONS. Eventually intellectual impairment; loss of fine motor control; ATHETOSIS; and diffuse chorea involving axial and limb musculature develops
column2: leading to a vegetative state within 10-15 years of disease onset. The juvenile variant has a more fulminant course including SEIZURES; ATAXIA; dementia; and chorea. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.228.662.262.249.937*D054546*Neuroacanthocytosis*An inherited autosomal disorder that is characterized by neurodegeneration; orofacial and buccal DYSKINESIAS; CHOREA; and thorny-looking red cells (ACANTHOCYTES). This disorder is due to mutations of chorein which is important in protein trafficking and is encoded by Vps13a on chromosome 9q21.

column2: Drug-Induced*Abnormal movements
column3: including HYPERKINESIS; HYPOKINESIA; TREMOR; and DYSTONIA
column4: associated with the use of certain medications or drugs. Muscles of the face
column7: and extremities are most commonly affected. Tardive dyskinesia refers to abnormal hyperkinetic movements of the muscles of the face
column9: and neck associated with the use of neuroleptic agents (see ANTIPSYCHOTIC AGENTS). (Adams et al.

column1: C10.228.662.262.500.500*D000071057*Tardive Dyskinesia*Drug-related movement disorder characterized by uncontrollable movements in certain muscles. It is associated with a long-term exposure to certain neuroleptic medications (e.g.
column2: METOCLOPRAMIDE).

column1: C10.228.662.300*D020821*Dystonic Disorders*Acquired and inherited conditions that feature DYSTONIA as a primary manifestation of disease. These disorders are generally divided into generalized dystonias (e.g.
column2: dystonia musculorum deformans) and focal dystonias (e.g.
column3: writer's cramp). They are also classified by patterns of inheritance and by age of onset.

column1: C10.228.662.300.200*D004422*Dystonia Musculorum Deformans*A condition characterized by focal DYSTONIA that progresses to involuntary spasmodic contractions of the muscles of the legs
column2: trunk
column4: and face. The hands are often spared
column6: sustained axial and limb contractions may lead to a state where the body is grossly contorted. Onset is usually in the first or second decade. Familial patterns of inheritance
column7: primarily autosomal dominant with incomplete penetrance

column1: C10.228.662.300.500*D008538*Meige Syndrome*A syndrome characterized by orofacial DYSTONIA; including BLEPHAROSPASM; forceful jaw opening; lip retraction; platysma muscle spasm; and tongue protrusion. It primarily affects older adults
column2: with an incidence peak in the seventh decade of life. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.228.662.300.750*D014103*Torticollis*A symptom
column2: not a disease
column3: of a twisted neck. In most instances
column4: the head is tipped toward one side and the chin rotated toward the other. The involuntary muscle contractions in the neck region of patients with torticollis can be due to congenital defects

column1: C10.228.662.350*D020329*Essential Tremor*A relatively common disorder characterized by a fairly specific pattern of tremors which are most prominent in the upper extremities and neck
column2: inducing titubations of the head. The tremor is usually mild
column3: but when severe may be disabling. An autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance may occur in some families (i.e.

column1: C10.228.662.400*D006527*Hepatolenticular Degeneration*A rare autosomal recessive disease characterized by the deposition of copper in the BRAIN; LIVER; CORNEA; and other organs. It is caused by defects in the ATP7B gene encoding copper-transporting ATPase 2 (EC 3.6.3.4)
column2: also known as the Wilson disease protein. The overload of copper inevitably leads to progressive liver and neurological dysfunction such as LIVER CIRRHOSIS; TREMOR; ATAXIA and intellectual deterioration. Hepatic dysfunction may precede neurologic dysfunction by several years.

column1: C10.228.662.550*D019578*Multiple System Atrophy*A syndrome complex composed of three conditions which represent clinical variants of the same disease process: STRIATONIGRAL DEGENERATION; SHY-DRAGER SYNDROME; and the sporadic form of OLIVOPONTOCEREBELLAR ATROPHIES. Clinical features include autonomic
column2: cerebellar
column3: and basal ganglia dysfunction. Pathologic examination reveals atrophy of the basal ganglia
column7: with prominent loss of autonomic neurons in the brain stem and spinal cord. (From Adams et al.
column10: p1076; Baillieres Clin Neurol 1997 Apr;6(1):187-204; Med Clin North Am 1999 Mar;83(2):381-92)

column1: C10.228.662.550.600*D009849*Olivopontocerebellar Atrophies*A group of inherited and sporadic disorders which share progressive ataxia in combination with atrophy of the CEREBELLUM; PONS; and inferior olivary nuclei. Additional clinical features may include MUSCLE RIGIDITY; NYSTAGMUS
column2: PATHOLOGIC; RETINAL DEGENERATION; MUSCLE SPASTICITY; DEMENTIA; URINARY INCONTINENCE; and OPHTHALMOPLEGIA. The familial form has an earlier onset (second decade) and may feature spinal cord atrophy. The sporadic form tends to present in the fifth or sixth decade
column3: and is considered a clinical subtype of MULTIPLE SYSTEM ATROPHY. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.228.662.550.700*D012791*Shy-Drager Syndrome*A progressive neurodegenerative condition of the central and autonomic nervous systems characterized by atrophy of the preganglionic lateral horn neurons of the thoracic spinal cord. This disease is generally considered a clinical variant of MULTIPLE SYSTEM ATROPHY. Affected individuals present in the fifth or sixth decade with ORTHOSTASIS and bladder dysfunction; and later develop FECAL INCONTINENCE; anhidrosis; ATAXIA; IMPOTENCE; and alterations of tone suggestive of basal ganglia dysfunction. (From Adams et al.
column2: Principles of Neurology

column1: C10.228.662.550.800*D020955*Striatonigral Degeneration*A sporadic neurodegenerative disease with onset in middle-age characterized clinically by Parkinsonian features (e.g.
column2: MUSCLE RIGIDITY; HYPOKINESIA; stooped posture) and HYPOTENSION. This condition is considered a clinical variant of MULTIPLE SYSTEM ATROPHY. Pathologic features include a prominent loss of neurons in the zona compacta of the SUBSTANTIA NIGRA and PUTAMEN. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.228.662.575*D006211*Pantothenate Kinase-Associated Neurodegeneration*A rare autosomal recessive degenerative disorder which usually presents in late childhood or adolescence. Clinical manifestations include progressive MUSCLE SPASTICITY; hyperreflexia; MUSCLE RIGIDITY; DYSTONIA; DYSARTHRIA; and intellectual deterioration which progresses to severe dementia over several years. (From Adams et al.
column2: Principles of Neurology

column1: C10.228.662.600*D020734*Parkinsonian Disorders*A group of disorders which feature impaired motor control characterized by bradykinesia
column2: MUSCLE RIGIDITY; TREMOR; and postural instability. Parkinsonian diseases are generally divided into primary parkinsonism (see PARKINSON DISEASE)
column4: SECONDARY) and inherited forms. These conditions are associated with dysfunction of dopaminergic or closely related motor integration neuronal pathways in the BASAL GANGLIA.

column1: C10.228.662.600.200*D020961*Lewy Body Disease*A neurodegenerative disease characterized by dementia
column2: mild parkinsonism
column3: and fluctuations in attention and alertness. The neuropsychiatric manifestations tend to precede the onset of bradykinesia
column5: and other extrapyramidal signs. DELUSIONS and visual HALLUCINATIONS are relatively frequent in this condition. Histologic examination reveals LEWY BODIES in the CEREBRAL CORTEX and BRAIN STEM. SENILE PLAQUES and other pathologic features characteristic of ALZHEIMER DISEASE may also be present. (From Neurology 1997;48:376-380; Neurology 1996;47:1113-1124)

column1: C10.228.662.600.400*D010300*Parkinson Disease*A progressive
column2: degenerative neurologic disease characterized by a TREMOR that is maximal at rest
column3: retropulsion (i.e. a tendency to fall backwards)
column7: and a masklike facial expression. Pathologic features include loss of melanin containing neurons in the substantia nigra and other pigmented nuclei of the brainstem. LEWY BODIES are present in the substantia nigra and locus coeruleus but may also be found in a related condition (LEWY BODY DISEASE
column8: DIFFUSE) characterized by dementia in combination with varying degrees of parkinsonism. (Adams et al.

column1: C10.228.662.600.700*D010302*Parkinson Disease
column2: Secondary*Conditions which feature clinical manifestations resembling primary Parkinson disease that are caused by a known or suspected condition. Examples include parkinsonism caused by vascular injury
column7: infections and degenerative or hereditary conditions. Clinical features may include bradykinesia
column11: tremor is less prominent in secondary parkinsonism than in the primary form. (From Joynt

column1: C10.228.662.600.700.250*D020267*MPTP Poisoning*A condition caused by the neurotoxin MPTP which causes selective destruction of nigrostriatal dopaminergic neurons. Clinical features include irreversible parkinsonian signs including rigidity and bradykinesia (PARKINSON DISEASE
column2: SECONDARY). MPTP toxicity is also used as an animal model for the study of PARKINSON DISEASE. (Adams et al.
Postencephalitic*Parkinsonism following encephalitis
column3: historically seen as a sequella of encephalitis lethargica (Von Economo Encephalitis). The early age of onset
column4: the rapid progression of symptoms followed by stabilization
column5: and the presence of a variety of other neurological disorders (e.g.
column6: sociopathic behavior; TICS; MUSCLE SPASMS; oculogyric crises; hyperphagia; and bizarre movements) distinguish this condition from primary PARKINSON DISEASE. Pathologic features include neuronal loss and gliosis concentrated in the MESENCEPHALON; SUBTHALAMUS; and HYPOTHALAMUS. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.228.662.700*D013494*Supranuclear Palsy
column2: Progressive*A degenerative disease of the central nervous system characterized by balance difficulties; OCULAR MOTILITY DISORDERS (supranuclear ophthalmoplegia); DYSARTHRIA; swallowing difficulties; and axial DYSTONIA. Onset is usually in the fifth decade and disease progression occurs over several years. Pathologic findings include neurofibrillary degeneration and neuronal loss in the dorsal MESENCEPHALON; SUBTHALAMIC NUCLEUS; RED NUCLEUS; pallidum; dentate nucleus; and vestibular nuclei. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.228.662.825*D013981*Tic Disorders*Disorders characterized by recurrent TICS that may interfere with speech and other activities. Tics are sudden
column2: rapid
column4: stereotyped motor movements or vocalizations which may be exacerbated by stress and are generally attenuated during absorbing activities. Tic disorders are distinguished from conditions which feature other types of abnormal movements that may accompany another another condition. (From DSM-IV

column1: C10.228.662.825.800*D005879*Tourette Syndrome*A neuropsychological disorder related to alterations in DOPAMINE metabolism and neurotransmission involving frontal-subcortical neuronal circuits. Both multiple motor and one or more vocal tics need to be present with TICS occurring many times a day
column2: nearly daily
column3: over a period of more than one year. The onset is before age 18 and the disturbance is not due to direct physiological effects of a substance or a another medical condition. The disturbance causes marked distress or significant impairment in social
column5: or other important areas of functioning. (From DSM-IV

column1: C10.228.758*D015835*Ocular Motility Disorders*Disorders that feature impairment of eye movements as a primary manifestation of disease. These conditions may be divided into infranuclear
column2: nuclear
column3: and supranuclear disorders. Diseases of the eye muscles or oculomotor cranial nerves (III
column5: and VI) are considered infranuclear. Nuclear disorders are caused by disease of the oculomotor
column7: or abducens nuclei in the BRAIN STEM. Supranuclear disorders are produced by dysfunction of higher order sensory and motor systems that control eye movements
column8: including neural networks in the CEREBRAL CORTEX; BASAL GANGLIA; CEREBELLUM; and BRAIN STEM. Ocular torticollis refers to a head tilt that is caused by an ocular misalignment. Opsoclonus refers to rapid
column9: conjugate oscillations of the eyes in multiple directions
column10: which may occur as a parainfectious or paraneoplastic condition (e.g.

column1: C10.228.758.500*D053578*Opsoclonus-Myoclonus Syndrome*A neurological condition that is characterized by uncontrolled rapid irregular movements of the eye (OPSOCLONUS) and the muscle (MYOCLONUS) causing unsteady
column2: trembling gait. It is also known as dancing eyes-dancing feet syndrome and is often associated with neoplasms
column4: or autoimmune disorders involving the nervous system.

column1: C10.228.806*D011007*Pneumocephalus*Presence of air or gas within the intracranial cavity (e.g.
column2: epidural space
column5: etc.) which may result from traumatic injuries
column7: erosions of the skull from NEOPLASMS or infection

column1: C10.228.854*D013118*Spinal Cord Diseases*Pathologic conditions which feature SPINAL CORD damage or dysfunction
column2: including disorders involving the meninges and perimeningeal spaces surrounding the spinal cord. Traumatic injuries
column5: and inflammatory/autoimmune processes may affect the spinal cord.

column1: C10.228.854.139*D000690*Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis*A degenerative disorder affecting upper MOTOR NEURONS in the brain and lower motor neurons in the brain stem and SPINAL CORD. Disease onset is usually after the age of 50 and the process is usually fatal within 3 to 6 years. Clinical manifestations include progressive weakness
column2: atrophy
column7: and eventual paralysis of respiratory function. Pathologic features include the replacement of motor neurons with fibrous ASTROCYTES and atrophy of anterior SPINAL NERVE ROOTS and corticospinal tracts. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.228.854.303*D020802*Epidural Abscess*Circumscribed collections of suppurative material occurring in the spinal or intracranial EPIDURAL SPACE. The majority of epidural abscesses occur in the spinal canal and are associated with OSTEOMYELITIS of a vertebral body; ANALGESIA
column2: EPIDURAL; and other conditions. Clinical manifestations include local and radicular pain
column6: and FECAL INCONTINENCE. Cranial epidural abscesses are usually associated with OSTEOMYELITIS of a cranial bone
column8: or OTITIS MEDIA. (From Adams et al.
column11: p710 and pp1240-1; J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 1998 Aug;65(2):209-12)

column1: C10.228.854.468*D009134*Muscular Atrophy
column2: Spinal*A group of disorders marked by progressive degeneration of motor neurons in the spinal cord resulting in weakness and muscular atrophy
column3: usually without evidence of injury to the corticospinal tracts. Diseases in this category include Werdnig-Hoffmann disease and later onset SPINAL MUSCULAR ATROPHIES OF CHILDHOOD
column4: most of which are hereditary. (Adams et al.

column1: C10.228.854.468.399*D055534*Bulbo-Spinal Atrophy
column2: X-Linked*An X-linked recessive form of spinal muscular atrophy. It is due to a mutation of the gene encoding the ANDROGEN RECEPTOR.

column1: C10.228.854.468.800*D014897*Spinal Muscular Atrophies of Childhood*A group of recessive inherited diseases that feature progressive muscular atrophy and hypotonia. They are classified as type I (Werdnig-Hoffman disease)
column2: type II (intermediate form)
column3: and type III (Kugelberg-Welander disease). Type I is fatal in infancy
column4: type II has a late infantile onset and is associated with survival into the second or third decade. Type III has its onset in childhood
column5: and is slowly progressive. (J Med Genet 1996 Apr:33(4):281-3)

column1: C10.228.854.525*D009187*Myelitis*Inflammation of the spinal cord. Relatively common etiologies include infections; AUTOIMMUNE DISEASES; SPINAL CORD; and ischemia (see also SPINAL CORD VASCULAR DISEASES). Clinical features generally include weakness
column2: sensory loss
column5: and other signs of autonomic dysfunction.

column2: Transverse*Inflammation of a transverse portion of the spinal cord characterized by acute or subacute segmental demyelination or necrosis. The condition may occur sporadically
column4: or present as a paraneoplastic syndrome (see also ENCEPHALOMYELITIS
column5: ACUTE DISSEMINATED). Clinical manifestations include motor weakness

column2: Tropical Spastic*A subacute paralytic myeloneuropathy occurring endemically in tropical areas such as the Caribbean
column6: as well as in the southwestern region of Japan; associated with infection by HUMAN T-CELL LEUKEMIA VIRUS I. Clinical manifestations include a slowly progressive spastic weakness of the legs
column10: and loss of vibratory and position sensation. On pathologic examination inflammatory
column12: and necrotic lesions may be found in the spinal cord. (Adams et al.

column1: C10.228.854.525.850*D011051*Poliomyelitis*An acute infectious disease of humans
column2: particularly children
column3: caused by any of three serotypes of human poliovirus (POLIOVIRUS). Usually the infection is limited to the gastrointestinal tract and nasopharynx
column4: and is often asymptomatic. The central nervous system
column8: coarse FASCICULATION and hyporeflexia. Motor neurons are primarily affected. Encephalitis may also occur. The virus replicates in the nervous system
column9: and may cause significant neuronal loss
column10: most notably in the spinal cord. A rare related condition
column12: may result from infections with nonpoliovirus enteroviruses. (From Adams et al.

column2: Bulbar*A form of paralytic poliomyelitis affecting neurons of the MEDULLA OBLONGATA of the brain stem. Clinical features include impaired respiration
column5: and dysphagia. Weakness and atrophy of the limbs and trunk due to spinal cord involvement is usually associated. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.228.854.525.850.750*D016262*Postpoliomyelitis Syndrome*A syndrome characterized by new neuromuscular symptoms that occur at least 15 years after clinical stability has been attained in patients with a prior history of symptomatic poliomyelitis. Clinical features include new muscular weakness and atrophy of the limbs
column2: bulbar innervated musculature
column6: and reduced stamina. The process is marked by slow progression and periods of stabilization. (From Ann NY Acad Sci 1995 May 25;753:68-80)

column1: C10.228.854.583*D063205*Pneumorrhachis*Presence of air or gas within the spinal canal cavity (EPIDURAL SPACE; or SUBARACHNOID SPACE). It may result from traumatic injuries
column2: emphysema
column3: infection and other conditions. It can also develop as a complication of various SURGICAL PROCEDURES (e.g.

column1: C10.228.854.761*D013117*Spinal Cord Compression*Acute and chronic conditions characterized by external mechanical compression of the SPINAL CORD due to extramedullary neoplasm; EPIDURAL ABSCESS; SPINAL FRACTURES; bony deformities of the vertebral bodies; and other conditions. Clinical manifestations vary with the anatomic site of the lesion and may include localized pain
column2: weakness

column1: C10.228.854.765*D013120*Spinal Cord Neoplasms*Benign and malignant neoplasms which occur within the substance of the spinal cord (intramedullary neoplasms) or in the space between the dura and spinal cord (intradural extramedullary neoplasms). The majority of intramedullary spinal tumors are primary CNS neoplasms including ASTROCYTOMA; EPENDYMOMA; and LIPOMA. Intramedullary neoplasms are often associated with SYRINGOMYELIA. The most frequent histologic types of intradural-extramedullary tumors are MENINGIOMA and NEUROFIBROMA.

C10.228.854.765.342*D015174*Epidural Neoplasms*Neoplasms located in the space between the vertebral PERIOSTEUM and DURA MATER surrounding the SPINAL CORD. Tumors in this location are most often metastatic in origin and may cause neurologic deficits by mass effect on the spinal cord or nerve roots or by interfering with blood supply to the spinal cord.
C10.228.854.770*D013119*Spinal Cord Injuries*Penetrating and non-penetrating injuries to the spinal cord resulting from traumatic external forces (e.g.

column1: C10.228.854.770.500*D020210*Central Cord Syndrome*A syndrome associated with traumatic injury to the cervical or upper thoracic regions of the spinal cord characterized by weakness in the arms with relative sparing of the legs and variable sensory loss. This condition is associated with ischemia
column2: hemorrhage
column3: or necrosis involving the central portions of the spinal cord. Corticospinal fibers destined for the legs are spared due to their more external location in the spinal cord. This clinical pattern may emerge during recovery from spinal shock. Deficits may be transient or permanent.

column1: C10.228.854.785*D020758*Spinal Cord Vascular Diseases*Pathological processes involving any of the BLOOD VESSELS feeding the SPINAL CORD
column2: such as the anterior and paired posterior spinal arteries or their many branches. Disease processes may include ATHEROSCLEROSIS; EMBOLISM; and ARTERIOVENOUS MALFORMATIONS leading to ISCHEMIA or HEMORRHAGE into the spinal cord (hematomyelia).

column1: C10.228.854.785.650*D020760*Spinal Cord Ischemia*Reduced blood flow to the spinal cord which is supplied by the anterior spinal artery and the paired posterior spinal arteries. This condition may be associated with ARTERIOSCLEROSIS
column2: trauma
column5: and other disorders. Prolonged ischemia may lead to INFARCTION of spinal cord tissue.

column1: C10.228.854.785.650.100*D020759*Anterior Spinal Artery Syndrome*Ischemia or infarction of the spinal cord in the distribution of the anterior spinal artery
column2: which supplies the ventral two-thirds of the spinal cord. This condition is usually associated with ATHEROSCLEROSIS of the aorta and may result from dissection of an AORTIC ANEURYSM or rarely dissection of the anterior spinal artery. Clinical features include weakness and loss of pain and temperature sensation below the level of injury
column3: with relative sparing of position and vibratory sensation. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.228.854.787*D013132*Spinocerebellar Degenerations*A heterogenous group of degenerative syndromes marked by progressive cerebellar dysfunction either in isolation or combined with other neurologic manifestations. column2: autosomal recessive

column1: C10.228.854.787.200*D005621*Friedreich Ataxia*An autosomal recessive disease

column5: and to a lesser extent the corticospinal tracts. Clinical manifestations include GAIT ATAXIA
column11: congestive heart failure (secondary to a cardiomyopathy)

column17: p1081; N Engl J Med 1996 Oct 17;335(16):1169-75) The severity of Friedreich ataxia associated with expansion of GAA repeats in the first intron of the frataxin gene correlates with the number of trinucleotide repeats. (From Durr et al

column1: C10.228.854.787.500*D002527*Myoclonic Cerebellar Dyssynergia*A condition marked by progressive CEREBELLAR ATAXIA combined with MYOCLONUS usually presenting in the third decade of life or later. Additional clinical features may include generalized and focal SEIZURES

column3: and DYSKINESIAS. Autosomal recessive and autosomal dominant patterns of inheritance have been reported. Pathologically

column5: with variable involvement of the spinal cord

column1: C10.228.854.787.750*D009849*Olivopontocerebellar Atrophies*A group of inherited and sporadic disorders which share progressive ataxia in combination with atrophy of the CEREBELLUM; PONS; and inferior olivary nuclei. Additional clinical features may include MUSCLE RIGIDITY; NYSTAGMUS
column2: PATHOLOGIC; RETINAL DEGENERATION; MUSCLE SPASTICITY; DEMENTIA; URINARY INCONTINENCE; and OPHTHALMOPLEGIA. The familial form has an earlier onset (second decade) and may feature spinal cord atrophy. The sporadic form tends to present in the fifth or sixth decade
column3: and is considered a clinical subtype of MULTIPLE SYSTEM ATROPHY. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.228.854.787.875*D020754*Spinocerebellar Ataxias*A group of dominantly inherited

column3: cerebellar ataxias which have been divided into multiple subtypes based on clinical features and genetic mapping. Progressive ataxia is a central feature of these conditions

column8: pp 12-17; J Neuropathol Exp Neurol 1998 Jun;57(6):531-43)

column1: C10.228.854.787.875.500*D017827*Machado-Joseph Disease*A dominantly-inherited ATAXIA first described in people of Azorean and Portuguese descent
column2: and subsequently identified in Brazil
column5: and Australia. This disorder is classified as one of the SPINOCEREBELLAR ATAXIAS (Type 3) and has been associated with a mutation of the MJD1 gene on chromosome 14. Clinical features include progressive ataxia
column10: and facial FASCICULATIONS. DYSTONIA is prominent in younger patients (referred to as Type I Machado-Joseph Disease). Type II features ataxia and ocular signs; Type III features MUSCULAR ATROPHY and a sensorimotor neuropathy; and Type IV features extrapyramidal signs combined with a sensorimotor neuropathy. (From Clin Neurosci 1995;3(1):17-22; Ann Neurol 1998 Mar;43(3):288-96)

column1: C10.228.854.811*D052879*Subacute Combined Degeneration*A neuropathy due to VITAMIN B 12 DEFICIENCY or to excessive NITROUS OXIDE inhalation. It is associated with overproduction of the myelinolytic TUMOR NECROSIS FACTOR-ALPHA.

column1: C10.292*D003389*Cranial Nerve Diseases*Disorders of one or more of the twelve cranial nerves. With the exception of the optic and olfactory nerves

column2: Pathologic*Involuntary movements of the eye that are divided into two types

column1: C10.314.350.500*D009103*Multiple Sclerosis*An autoimmune disorder mainly affecting young adults and characterized by destruction of myelin in the central nervous system. C10.314.500*D017590*Myelinolysis

The rapid medical correction of hyponatremia has been cited as a cause of this condition. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.314.750*D011129*Polyradiculoneuropathy*Diseases characterized by injury or dysfunction involving multiple peripheral nerves and nerve roots. column2: CHRONIC INFLAMMATORY DEMYELINATING. Polyradiculoneuritis refers to inflammation of multiple peripheral nerves and spinal nerve roots.

column1: C10.314.750.450*D020275*Guillain-Barre Syndrome*An acute inflammatory autoimmune neuritis caused by T cell- mediated cellular immune response directed towards peripheral myelin. column7: and loss of deep tendon reflexes. Weakness of respiratory muscles and autonomic dysfunction may occur. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.314.750.700*D020277*Polyradiculoneuropathy

GUILLAIN-BARRE SYNDROME features a relatively rapid progression of disease which distinguishes it from this condition. (Adams et al.

column1: C10.314.875*D052879*Subacute Combined Degeneration*A neuropathy due to VITAMIN B 12 DEFICIENCY or to excessive NITROUS OXIDE inhalation. It is associated with overproduction of the myelinolytic TUMOR NECROSIS FACTOR-ALPHA.
C10.500*D009421*Nervous System Malformations*Structural abnormalities of the central or peripheral nervous system resulting primarily from defects of embryogenesis.
C10.500.034*D061085*Agenesis of Corpus Callosum*Birth defect that results in a partial or complete absence of the CORPUS CALLOSUM. It may be isolated or a part of a syndrome (e.g.

column2: and growth retardation.

Alobar prosencephaly is the most severe form and features anophthalmia; cyclopia; severe INTELLECTUAL DISABILITY; CLEFT LIP; CLEFT PALATE; SEIZURES; and microcephaly. Semilobar holoprosencepaly is characterized by hypotelorism

column4: and HMSN VII refers to HMSN associated with retinitis pigmentosa. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.500.300.099*D056769*Alstrom Syndrome*Rare autosomal recessive disease characterized by multiple organ dysfunction. The key clinical features include retinal degeneration (NYSTAGMUS
column2: PATHOLOGIC; RETINITIS PIGMENTOSA; and eventual blindness)
column5: and normal mental development. Endocrinologic complications include TYPE 2 DIABETES MELLITUS; HYPERINSULINEMIA; ACANTHOSIS NIGRICANS; HYPOTHYROIDISM; and progressive renal and hepatic failures. The disease is caused by mutations in the ALMS1 gene.

column1: C10.500.300.200*D002607*Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disease*A hereditary motor and sensory neuropathy transmitted most often as an autosomal dominant trait and characterized by progressive distal wasting and loss of reflexes in the muscles of the legs (and occasionally involving the arms). Onset is usually in the second to fourth decade of life. This condition has been divided into two subtypes
column2: hereditary motor and sensory neuropathy (HMSN) types I and II. HMSN I is associated with abnormal nerve conduction velocities and nerve hypertrophy
column3: features not seen in HMSN II. (Adams et al.

column1: C10.500.300.490*D056768*Giant Axonal Neuropathy*Rare autosomal recessive disorder of INTERMEDIATE FILAMENT PROTEINS. The disease is caused by mutations in the gene that codes gigaxonin protein. The mutations result in disorganization of axonal NEUROFILAMENT PROTEINS
column2: formation of the characteristic giant axons
column3: and progressive neuropathy. The clinical features of the disease include early-onset progressive peripheral motor and sensory neuropathies often associated with central nervous system involvement (INTELLECTUAL DISABILITY

column1: C10.500.300.780*D012035*Refsum Disease*An autosomal recessive familial disorder that usually presents in childhood with POLYNEUROPATHY; SENSORINEURAL HEARING LOSS; ICHTHYOSIS; ATAXIA; RETINITIS PIGMENTOSA; and CARDIOMYOPATHIES. (From Joynt
column2: Clinical Neurology
column5: p58-9; Rev Med Interne 1996;17(5):391-8) This condition can be caused by mutation in the genes encoding peroxisomal phytanoyl-CoA hydroxylase or proteins associated peroxisomal membrane
column6: leading to impaired catabolism of PHYTANIC ACID in PEROXISOMES.

column1: C10.500.300.820*D015419*Spastic Paraplegia
column2: Hereditary*A group of inherited diseases that share similar phenotypes but are genetically diverse. Different genetic loci for autosomal recessive
column4: and x-linked forms of hereditary spastic paraplegia have been identified. Clinically
column5: patients present with slowly progressive distal limb weakness and lower extremity spasticity. Peripheral sensory neurons may be affected in the later stages of the disease. (J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 1998 Jan;64(1):61-6; Curr Opin Neurol 1997 Aug;10(4):313-8)

column1: C10.500.310*D009477*Hereditary Sensory and Autonomic Neuropathies*A group of inherited disorders characterized by degeneration of dorsal root and autonomic ganglion cells
column2: and clinically by loss of sensation and autonomic dysfunction. There are five subtypes. Type I features autosomal dominant inheritance and distal sensory involvement. Type II is characterized by autosomal inheritance and distal and proximal sensory loss. Type III is DYSAUTONOMIA
column3: FAMILIAL. Type IV features insensitivity to pain
column5: and mental deficiency. Type V is characterized by a selective loss of pain with intact light touch and vibratory sensation. (From Joynt

column2: Familial*An autosomal disorder of the peripheral and autonomic nervous systems limited to individuals of Ashkenazic Jewish descent. Clinical manifestations are present at birth and include diminished lacrimation
column8: loss of pain and temperature sensation
column9: and absent reflexes. Pathologic features include reduced numbers of small diameter peripheral nerve fibers and autonomic ganglion neurons. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.500.450*D006832*Hydranencephaly*A congenital condition where the greater portions of the cerebral hemispheres and CORPUS STRIATUM are replaced by CSF and glial tissue. The meninges and the skull are well formed
column2: which is consistent with earlier normal embryogenesis of the telencephalon. Bilateral occlusions of the internal carotid arteries in utero is a potential mechanism. Clinical features include intact brainstem reflexes without evidence of higher cortical activity. (Menkes

column1: C10.500.507*D054220*Malformations of Cortical Development*Abnormalities in the development of the CEREBRAL CORTEX. These include malformations arising from abnormal neuronal and glial CELL PROLIFERATION or APOPTOSIS (Group I); abnormal neuronal migration (Group II); and abnormal establishment of cortical organization (Group III). Many INBORN METABOLIC BRAIN DISORDERS affecting CNS formation are often associated with cortical malformations. They are common causes of EPILEPSY and developmental delay.
C10.500.507.400*D065703*Malformations of Cortical Development
column2: Group I*Cortical malformations secondary to abnormal neuronal and glial CELL PROLIFERATION or APOPTOSIS in NEUROGENESIS. This group includes congenital MICROCEPHALIES; MICROLISSENCEPHALIES
column4: HEMIMEGALENCEPHALIES and cortical dysplasias with balloon cells.

column1: C10.500.507.400.249*D058627*Megalencephaly*A congenital abnormality in which the occipitofrontal circumference is greater than two standard deviations above the mean for a given age. It is associated with HYDROCEPHALUS; SUBDURAL EFFUSION; ARACHNOID CYSTS; or is part of a genetic condition (e.g.
column2: ALEXANDER DISEASE; SOTOS SYNDROME).

column1: C10.500.507.400.249.500*D065705*Hemimegalencephaly*Rare MALFORMATIONS OF CORTICAL DEVELOPMENT
column2: GROUP I characterized by the enlargement of one side of the brain. It is associated with seizures

column1: C10.500.507.400.500*D008831*Microcephaly*A congenital abnormality in which the CEREBRUM is underdeveloped
column2: the fontanels close prematurely
column5: the head is small. (Desk Reference for Neuroscience

column1: C10.500.507.400.750*D014402*Tuberous Sclerosis*Autosomal dominant neurocutaneous syndrome classically characterized by MENTAL RETARDATION; EPILEPSY; and skin lesions (e.g.
column2: adenoma sebaceum and hypomelanotic macules). There is
column4: considerable heterogeneity in the neurologic manifestations. It is also associated with cortical tuber and HAMARTOMAS formation throughout the body
column7: and eyes. Mutations in two loci TSC1 and TSC2 that encode hamartin and tuberin

column1: C10.500.507.450*D054081*Malformations of Cortical Development
column2: Group II*Cortical malformations secondary to abnormal neuronal CELL MIGRATION in NEUROGENESIS. This group includes COBBLESTONE LISSENCEPHALY and PERIVENTRICULAR NODULAR HETEROTOPIA.

column1: C10.500.507.450.230*D054221*Classical Lissencephalies and Subcortical Band Heterotopias*Disorders comprising a spectrum of brain malformations representing the paradigm of a diffuse neuronal migration disorder. They result in cognitive impairment; SEIZURES; and HYPOTONIA or spasticity. Mutations of two genes
column2: LIS1
column3: the gene for the non-catalytic subunit of PLATELET-ACTIVATING FACTOR ACETYLHYDROLASE IB; and DCX or XLIS
column5: have been identified as the most common causes of disorders in this spectrum. Additional variants of classical (Type I) lissencephaly have been linked to RELN
column8: the gene for aristaless related homeobox protein. (From Leventer
column11: Mol Med Today. 2000 Jul;6(7):277-84 and Barkovich

column1: C10.500.507.450.249*D054222*Cobblestone Lissencephaly*The smooth pebbled appearance of the CEREBRAL CORTEX with a thickened cortex and reduced and abnormal white matter
column2: which results from migration of heterotopic neurons beyond the marginal zone into the leptomeninges through gaps in the external BASEMENT MEMBRANE. There is also enlarged ventricles
column4: and absence of the CORPUS CALLOSUM. These abnormalities occur as a syndrome without other birth defects (cobblestone complex) or in other syndromes associated with congenital MUSCULAR DYSTROPHY

column1: C10.500.507.450.499*D054082*Lissencephaly*A smooth brain malformation of the CEREBRAL CORTEX resulting from the abnormal location of developing neurons during corticogenesis. It is characterized by an absence of normal convoluted indentations on the surface of the brain (agyria)
column2: or fewer and shallower indentations (pachygryia). There is a reduced number of cortical layers
column5: and reduced cerebral white matter that is a reversal of the normal ratio of cerebral white matter to cortex.

column1: C10.500.507.450.499.230*D054221*Classical Lissencephalies and Subcortical Band Heterotopias*Disorders comprising a spectrum of brain malformations representing the paradigm of a diffuse neuronal migration disorder. They result in cognitive impairment; SEIZURES; and HYPOTONIA or spasticity. Mutations of two genes
column2: LIS1
column3: the gene for the non-catalytic subunit of PLATELET-ACTIVATING FACTOR ACETYLHYDROLASE IB; and DCX or XLIS
column5: have been identified as the most common causes of disorders in this spectrum. Additional variants of classical (Type I) lissencephaly have been linked to RELN
column8: the gene for aristaless related homeobox protein. (From Leventer
column11: Mol Med Today. 2000 Jul;6(7):277-84 and Barkovich

column1: C10.500.507.450.499.249*D054222*Cobblestone Lissencephaly*The smooth pebbled appearance of the CEREBRAL CORTEX with a thickened cortex and reduced and abnormal white matter
column2: which results from migration of heterotopic neurons beyond the marginal zone into the leptomeninges through gaps in the external BASEMENT MEMBRANE. There is also enlarged ventricles
column4: and absence of the CORPUS CALLOSUM. These abnormalities occur as a syndrome without other birth defects (cobblestone complex) or in other syndromes associated with congenital MUSCULAR DYSTROPHY

column1: C10.500.507.450.499.249.500*D058494*Walker-Warburg Syndrome*Rare autosomal recessive lissencephaly type 2 associated with congenital MUSCULAR DYSTROPHY and eye anomalies (e.g.
column2: RETINAL DETACHMENT; CATARACT; MICROPHTHALMOS). It is often associated with additional brain malformations such as HYDROCEPHALY and cerebellar hypoplasia and is the most severe form of the group of related syndromes (alpha-dystroglycanopathies) with common congenital abnormalities in the brain

column1: C10.500.507.450.750*D054091*Periventricular Nodular Heterotopia*A disorder resulting from a defect in the pattern of neuronal migration in which ectopic collections of neurons lie along the lateral ventricles of the brain or just beneath
column2: contiguously or in isolated patches.

column1: C10.500.507.500*D065704*Malformations of Cortical Development
column2: Group III*Cortical malformations secondary to abnormal cortical maturation after CELL MIGRATION in NEUROGENESIS. This group includes injury to the cortex during later stages of cortical development such as POLYMICROGYRIA and focal cortical dysplasias.

column1: C10.500.507.500.500*D065706*Polymicrogyria*Heterogeneous disorders of cortical malformation characterized by excessive and small fused gyri and shallow sulci of the CORTEX with abnormal cortical lamination. It is considered a malformation secondary to abnormal post-migrational development of the neurons during cerebral cortical development and is associated with EPILEPSY and learning difficulties.

C10.500.507.500.625*D065708*Porencephaly*Cortical malformations characterized by white matter-lined cleft or cyst associated with ISCHEMIA and hemorrhagic insults. Symptoms include delayed growth and development
column2: HYPOTONIA; SEIZURES; SPASTIC HEMIPLEGIA and MACROCEPHALY; MICROCEPHALY; or HYDROCEPHALUS. Mutations in the genes encoding COLLAGEN TYPE IV are associated with familial types.

column1: C10.500.507.500.750*D065707*Schizencephaly*Cortical malformations characterized by grey matter-lined cleft or cyst that extends from the EPENDYMA often to the PIA MATER outer surface. The grey matter that lines the cleft is often POLYMICROGYRIA. It is associated with developmental delay
column2: motor disturbance and seizures.

column1: C10.500.680*D009436*Neural Tube Defects*Congenital malformations of the central nervous system and adjacent structures related to defective neural tube closure during the first trimester of pregnancy generally occurring between days 18-29 of gestation. Ectodermal and mesodermal malformations (mainly involving the skull and vertebrae) may occur as a result of defects of neural tube closure. (From Joynt
column2: Clinical Neurology

column1: C10.500.680.196*D000757*Anencephaly*A malformation of the nervous system caused by failure of the anterior neuropore to close. Infants are born with intact spinal cords
column2: cerebellums
column4: but lack formation of neural structures above this level. The skull is only partially formed but the eyes are usually normal. This condition may be associated with folate deficiency. Affected infants are only capable of primitive (brain stem) reflexes and usually do not survive for more than two weeks. (From Menkes

column1: C10.500.680.291*D001139*Arnold-Chiari Malformation*A group of congenital malformations involving the brainstem
column2: cerebellum
column4: and surrounding bony structures. Type II is the most common
column5: and features compression of the medulla and cerebellar tonsils into the upper cervical spinal canal and an associated MENINGOMYELOCELE. Type I features similar
column6: but less severe malformations and is without an associated meningomyelocele. Type III has the features of type II with an additional herniation of the entire cerebellum through the bony defect involving the foramen magnum
column7: forming an ENCEPHALOCELE. Type IV is a form a cerebellar hypoplasia. Clinical manifestations of types I-III include TORTICOLLIS; opisthotonus; HEADACHE; VERTIGO; VOCAL CORD PARALYSIS; APNEA; NYSTAGMUS
column8: CONGENITAL; swallowing difficulties; and ATAXIA. (From Menkes

column1: C10.500.680.488*D004677*Encephalocele*Brain tissue herniation through a congenital or acquired defect in the skull. The majority of congenital encephaloceles occur in the occipital or frontal regions. Clinical features include a protuberant mass that may be pulsatile. The quantity and location of protruding neural tissue determines the type and degree of neurologic deficit. Visual defects
column2: psychomotor developmental delay
column3: and persistent motor deficits frequently occur.

column1: C10.500.680.598*D008588*Meningocele*A congenital or acquired protrusion of the meninges
column2: unaccompanied by neural tissue
column3: through a bony defect in the skull or vertebral column.

column1: C10.500.680.610*D008591*Meningomyelocele*Congenital
column2: or rarely acquired
column3: herniation of meningeal and spinal cord tissue through a bony defect in the vertebral column. The majority of these defects occur in the lumbosacral region. Clinical features include PARAPLEGIA
column4: loss of sensation in the lower body
column5: and incontinence. This condition may be associated with the ARNOLD-CHIARI MALFORMATION and HYDROCEPHALUS. (From Joynt

column1: C10.500.680.705*D058502*Pentalogy of Cantrell*Rare congenital deformity syndrome characterized by a combination of five anomalies as a result of neural tube defect. The five anomalies are a midline supraumbilical abdominal wall defect (e.g.
column2: OMPHALOCELE)
column7: PERICARDIAL EFFUSION). Variants with incomplete and variable combinations of the defects are known. ECTOPIA CORDIS; CLEFT LIP; and CLEFT PALATE are often associated with the syndrome.

column1: C10.500.680.800*D016135*Spinal Dysraphism*Congenital defects of closure of one or more vertebral arches
column2: which may be associated with malformations of the spinal cord
column6: and congenital cysts. These malformations range from mild (e.g.
column8: including rachischisis where there is complete failure of neural tube and spinal cord fusion
column9: resulting in exposure of the spinal cord at the surface. Spinal dysraphism includes all forms of spina bifida. The open form is called SPINA BIFIDA CYSTICA and the closed form is SPINA BIFIDA OCCULTA. (From Joynt

column1: C10.500.680.800.730*D016137*Spina Bifida Cystica*A form of spinal dysraphism associated with a protruding cyst made up of either meninges (i.e.
column2: a MENINGOCELE) or meninges in combination with spinal cord tissue (i.e.
column3: a MENINGOMYELOCELE). These lesions are frequently associated with spinal cord dysfunction

column1: C10.500.680.800.750*D016136*Spina Bifida Occulta*A common congenital midline defect of fusion of the vertebral arch without protrusion of the spinal cord or meninges. The lesion is also covered by skin. L5 and S1 are the most common vertebrae involved. The condition may be associated with an overlying area of hyperpigmented skin
column2: a dermal sinus
column3: or an abnormal patch of hair. The majority of individuals with this malformation are asymptomatic although there is an increased incidence of tethered cord syndrome and lumbar SPONDYLOSIS. (From Joynt

column1: C10.500.840*D025962*Septo-Optic Dysplasia*A condition resulting from congenital malformations involving the brain. The syndrome of septo-optic dysplasia combines hypoplasia or agenesis of the SEPTUM PELLUCIDUM and the OPTIC NERVE. The extent of the abnormalities can vary. Septo-optic dysplasia is often associated with abnormalities of the hypothalamic and other diencephalic structures
column2: and HYPOPITUITARISM.

column1: C10.551*D009423*Nervous System Neoplasms*Benign and malignant neoplastic processes arising from or involving components of the central
column2: peripheral
column5: and meninges. Included in this category are primary and metastatic nervous system neoplasms.

column1: C10.551.240*D016543*Central Nervous System Neoplasms*Benign and malignant neoplastic processes that arise from or secondarily involve the brain
column2: spinal cord

column1: C10.551.240.250*D001932*Brain Neoplasms*Neoplasms of the intracranial components of the central nervous system
column2: including the cerebral hemispheres
column7: and cerebellum. Brain neoplasms are subdivided into primary (originating from brain tissue) and secondary (i.e.
column8: metastatic) forms. Primary neoplasms are subdivided into benign and malignant forms. In general
column9: brain tumors may also be classified by age of onset
column11: or presenting location in the brain.

column1: C10.551.240.250.200*D002551*Cerebral Ventricle Neoplasms*Neoplasms located in the brain ventricles
column2: including the two lateral
column4: and the fourth ventricle. Ventricular tumors may be primary (e.g.
column8: or occur as extensions of locally invasive tumors from adjacent brain structures.

column1: C10.551.240.250.200.200*D016545*Choroid Plexus Neoplasms*Benign or malignant tumors which arise from the choroid plexus of the ventricles of the brain. Papillomas (see PAPILLOMA
column2: CHOROID PLEXUS) and carcinomas are the most common histologic subtypes
column3: and tend to seed throughout the ventricular and subarachnoid spaces. Clinical features include headaches
column5: primarily resulting from associated HYDROCEPHALUS. (From Devita et al.
column6: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column2: Choroid Plexus*A usually benign neoplasm that arises from the cuboidal epithelium of the choroid plexus and takes the form of an enlarged CHOROID PLEXUS
column3: which may be associated with oversecretion of CSF. The tumor usually presents in the first decade of life with signs of increased intracranial pressure including HEADACHES; ATAXIA; DIPLOPIA; and alterations of mental status. In children it is most common in the lateral ventricles and in adults it tends to arise in the fourth ventricle. Malignant transformation to choroid plexus carcinomas may rarely occur. (Adams et al.
column7: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column1: C10.551.240.250.400*D015192*Infratentorial Neoplasms*Intracranial tumors originating in the region of the brain inferior to the tentorium cerebelli
column2: which contains the cerebellum
column6: and related structures. Primary tumors of this region are more frequent in children
column7: and may present with ATAXIA; CRANIAL NERVE DISEASES; vomiting; HEADACHE; HYDROCEPHALUS; or other signs of neurologic dysfunction. Relatively frequent histologic subtypes include TERATOMA; MEDULLOBLASTOMA; GLIOBLASTOMA; ASTROCYTOMA; EPENDYMOMA; CRANIOPHARYNGIOMA; and choroid plexus papilloma (PAPILLOMA

column1: C10.551.240.250.400.200*D020295*Brain Stem Neoplasms*Benign and malignant intra-axial tumors of the MESENCEPHALON; PONS; or MEDULLA OBLONGATA of the BRAIN STEM. Primary and metastatic neoplasms may occur in this location. Clinical features include ATAXIA
column2: cranial neuropathies (see CRANIAL NERVE DISEASES)
column5: and quadriparesis. Primary brain stem neoplasms are more frequent in children. Histologic subtypes include GLIOMA; HEMANGIOBLASTOMA; GANGLIOGLIOMA; and EPENDYMOMA.

column1: C10.551.240.250.400.300*D002528*Cerebellar Neoplasms*Primary or metastatic neoplasms of the CEREBELLUM. Tumors in this location frequently present with ATAXIA or signs of INTRACRANIAL HYPERTENSION due to obstruction of the fourth ventricle. Common primary cerebellar tumors include fibrillary ASTROCYTOMA and cerebellar HEMANGIOBLASTOMA. The cerebellum is a relatively common site for tumor metastases from the lung
column2: breast
column3: and other distant organs. (From Okazaki & Scheithauer

column1: C10.551.240.250.550*D018306*Neurocytoma*A benign brain tumor composed of neural elements which most often arise from the SEPTUM PELLUCIDUM and the walls of the lateral ventricles. Immunohistochemistry and electron microscopy evaluations may reveal expression of neuron specific enolase and synaptophysin and cells containing microtubuli
column2: neurosecretory granules
column3: and presynaptic vesicles. (From Acta Med Port 1994 Feb;7(2):113-9)

column1: C10.551.240.250.625*D010871*Pinealoma*Neoplasms which originate from pineal parenchymal cells that tend to enlarge the gland and be locally invasive. The two major forms are pineocytoma and the more malignant pineoblastoma. Pineocytomas have moderate cellularity and tend to form rosette patterns. Pineoblastomas are highly cellular tumors containing small
column2: poorly differentiated cells. These tumors occasionally seed the neuroaxis or cause obstructive HYDROCEPHALUS or Parinaud's syndrome. GERMINOMA; CARCINOMA
column3: EMBRYONAL; GLIOMA; and other neoplasms may arise in the pineal region with germinoma being the most common pineal region tumor. (From DeVita et al.
column4: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column1: C10.551.240.250.700*D015173*Supratentorial Neoplasms*Primary and metastatic (secondary) tumors of the brain located above the tentorium cerebelli
column2: a fold of dura mater separating the CEREBELLUM and BRAIN STEM from the cerebral hemispheres and DIENCEPHALON (i.e.
column3: THALAMUS and HYPOTHALAMUS and related structures). In adults
column4: primary neoplasms tend to arise in the supratentorial compartment
column5: whereas in children they occur more frequently in the infratentorial space. Clinical manifestations vary with the location of the lesion
column6: but SEIZURES; APHASIA; HEMIANOPSIA; hemiparesis; and sensory deficits are relatively common features. Metastatic supratentorial neoplasms are frequently multiple at the time of presentation.

column1: C10.551.240.250.700.500*D007029*Hypothalamic Neoplasms*Benign and malignant tumors of the HYPOTHALAMUS. Pilocytic astrocytomas and hamartomas are relatively frequent histologic types. Neoplasms of the hypothalamus frequently originate from adjacent structures
column2: including the OPTIC CHIASM
column4: and pituitary gland (see PITUITARY NEOPLASMS). Relatively frequent clinical manifestations include visual loss
column7: and precocious puberty. (From Devita et al.
column8: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column1: C10.551.240.250.700.500.249*D054975*Pallister-Hall Syndrome*A pleiotropic disorder of human development that comprises hypothalamic HAMARTOMA; central and postaxial POLYDACTYLY; bifid EPIGLOTTIS; ANAL ATRESIA; and renal and other abnormalities. This disorder is associated with FRAMESHIFT MUTATIONS in the GLI3 gene which encodes the GLI3 protein
column2: a KRUPPEL-LIKE TRANSCRIPTION FACTORS family member.

column1: C10.551.240.250.700.500.500*D010911*Pituitary Neoplasms*Neoplasms which arise from or metastasize to the PITUITARY GLAND. The majority of pituitary neoplasms are adenomas
column2: which are divided into non-secreting and secreting forms. Hormone producing forms are further classified by the type of hormone they secrete. Pituitary adenomas may also be characterized by their staining properties (see ADENOMA
column5: CHROMOPHOBE). Pituitary tumors may compress adjacent structures
column8: and the OPTIC CHIASM. Chiasmal compression may result in bitemporal HEMIANOPSIA.

column1: C10.551.240.375*D020863*Central Nervous System Cysts*Congenital or acquired cysts of the brain
column2: spinal cord
column3: or meninges which may remain stable in size or undergo progressive enlargement.

column1: C10.551.240.375.100*D016080*Arachnoid Cysts*Intracranial or spinal cavities containing a cerebrospinal-like fluid
column2: the wall of which is composed of arachnoidal cells. They are most often developmental or related to trauma. Intracranial arachnoid cysts usually occur adjacent to arachnoidal cistern and may present with HYDROCEPHALUS; HEADACHE; SEIZURES; and focal neurologic signs. (From Joynt

column1: C10.551.240.375.200*D056364*Colloid Cysts*Benign
column2: congenital
column3: neuroepithelial cysts that are typically filled with a viscous mucus. They usually arise in the anterior portion of the THIRD VENTRICLE between the fornices.

column1: C10.551.240.500*D008577*Meningeal Neoplasms*Benign and malignant neoplastic processes that arise from or secondarily involve the meningeal coverings of the brain and spinal cord.

C10.551.240.500.150*D055756*Meningeal Carcinomatosis*Primary or secondary neoplasm in the ARACHNOID or SUBARACHNOID SPACE. It appears as a diffuse fibrotic thickening of the MENINGES associated with variable degrees of inflammation.

C10.551.240.500.500*D008579*Meningioma*A relatively common neoplasm of the CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM that arises from arachnoidal cells. The majority are well differentiated vascular tumors which grow slowly and have a low potential to be invasive
column2: although malignant subtypes occur. Meningiomas have a predilection to arise from the parasagittal region
column6: and SPINAL CANAL. (From DeVita et al.
column7: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column1: C10.551.240.750*D013120*Spinal Cord Neoplasms*Benign and malignant neoplasms which occur within the substance of the spinal cord (intramedullary neoplasms) or in the space between the dura and spinal cord (intradural extramedullary neoplasms). The majority of intramedullary spinal tumors are primary CNS neoplasms including ASTROCYTOMA; EPENDYMOMA; and LIPOMA. Intramedullary neoplasms are often associated with SYRINGOMYELIA. The most frequent histologic types of intradural-extramedullary tumors are MENINGIOMA and NEUROFIBROMA.

C10.551.240.750.200*D015174*Epidural Neoplasms*Neoplasms located in the space between the vertebral PERIOSTEUM and DURA MATER surrounding the SPINAL CORD. Tumors in this location are most often metastatic in origin and may cause neurologic deficits by mass effect on the spinal cord or nerve roots or by interfering with blood supply to the spinal cord.
C10.551.360*D003390*Cranial Nerve Neoplasms*Benign and malignant neoplasms that arise from one or more of the twelve cranial nerves.

C10.551.360.500*D019574*Optic Nerve Neoplasms*Benign and malignant neoplasms that arise from the optic nerve or its sheath. OPTIC NERVE GLIOMA is the most common histologic type. Optic nerve neoplasms tend to cause unilateral visual loss and an afferent pupillary defect and may spread via neural pathways to the brain.
C10.551.360.500.500*D020339*Optic Nerve Glioma*Glial cell derived tumors arising from the optic nerve
column2: usually presenting in childhood.

column1: C10.551.775*D010524*Peripheral Nervous System Neoplasms*Neoplasms which arise from peripheral nerve tissue. This includes NEUROFIBROMAS; SCHWANNOMAS; GRANULAR CELL TUMORS; and malignant peripheral NERVE SHEATH NEOPLASMS. (From DeVita Jr et al.
column2: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column1: C10.551.775.250*D003390*Cranial Nerve Neoplasms*Benign and malignant neoplasms that arise from one or more of the twelve cranial nerves.

C10.551.775.250.500*D019574*Optic Nerve Neoplasms*Benign and malignant neoplasms that arise from the optic nerve or its sheath. OPTIC NERVE GLIOMA is the most common histologic type. Optic nerve neoplasms tend to cause unilateral visual loss and an afferent pupillary defect and may spread via neural pathways to the brain.
C10.551.775.250.500.500*D020339*Optic Nerve Glioma*Glial cell derived tumors arising from the optic nerve
column2: usually presenting in childhood.

column1: C10.551.775.500*D018317*Nerve Sheath Neoplasms*Neoplasms which arise from nerve sheaths formed by SCHWANN CELLS in the PERIPHERAL NERVOUS SYSTEM or by OLIGODENDROCYTES in the CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM. Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors
column2: NEUROFIBROMA
column3: and NEURILEMMOMA are relatively common tumors in this category.

column1: C10.551.775.500.750*D009455*Neurofibroma*A moderately firm
column2: benign
column3: encapsulated tumor resulting from proliferation of SCHWANN CELLS and FIBROBLASTS that includes portions of nerve fibers. The tumors usually develop along peripheral or cranial nerves and are a central feature of NEUROFIBROMATOSIS 1
column4: where they may occur intracranially or involve spinal roots. Pathologic features include fusiform enlargement of the involved nerve. Microscopic examination reveals a disorganized and loose cellular pattern with elongated nuclei intermixed with fibrous strands. (From Adams et al.

Cockayne syndrome is classified by the severity and age of onset. Type I (classical; CSA) is early childhood onset in the second year of life; type II (congenital; CSB) is early onset at birth with severe symptoms; type III (xeroderma pigmentosum; XP) is late childhood onset with mild symptoms.

column1: C10.574.625*D019578*Multiple System Atrophy*A syndrome complex composed of three conditions which represent clinical variants of the same disease process: STRIATONIGRAL DEGENERATION; SHY-DRAGER SYNDROME; and the sporadic form of OLIVOPONTOCEREBELLAR ATROPHIES. Clinical features include autonomic
column2: cerebellar
column3: and basal ganglia dysfunction. Pathologic examination reveals atrophy of the basal ganglia

column1: C10.574.625.600*D009849*Olivopontocerebellar Atrophies*A group of inherited and sporadic disorders which share progressive ataxia in combination with atrophy of the CEREBELLUM; PONS; and inferior olivary nuclei. Additional clinical features may include MUSCLE RIGIDITY; NYSTAGMUS

column1: C10.574.625.700*D012791*Shy-Drager Syndrome*A progressive neurodegenerative condition of the central and autonomic nervous systems characterized by atrophy of the preganglionic lateral horn neurons of the thoracic spinal cord. column1: C10.574.625.800*D020955*Striatonigral Degeneration*A sporadic neurodegenerative disease with onset in middle-age characterized clinically by Parkinsonian features (e.g.

column1: C10.574.781*D020361*Paraneoplastic Syndromes

column1: C10.574.781.249*D060426*Anti-N-Methyl-D-Aspartate Receptor Encephalitis*Disorder characterized by symptoms of CATATONIA; HYPOVENTILATION; DYSKINESIAS; ENCEPHALITIS; and SEIZURES followed by a reduced CONSCIOUSNESS. column5: and shoulder girdle. There is relative sparing of extraocular and bulbar muscles. CARCINOMA

column5: ACUTE DISSEMINATED). Clinical manifestations include motor weakness
