Autoimmune
column3: Experimental*An experimental animal model for the demyelinating disease of GUILLAINE-BARRE SYNDROME. In the most frequently used protocol
column4: animals are injected with a peripheral nerve tissue protein homogenate. After approximately 2 weeks the animals develop a neuropathy secondary to a T cell-mediated autoimmune response directed towards the MYELIN P2 PROTEIN in peripheral nerves. Pathologic findings include a perivascular accumulation of macrophages and T lymphocytes in the peripheral nervous system
column5: similar to that seen in the Guillaine-Barre syndrome. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.668.829.675*D009456*Neurofibromatosis 1*An autosomal dominant inherited disorder (with a high frequency of spontaneous mutations) that features developmental changes in the nervous system
column2: muscles
column5: most notably in tissue derived from the embryonic NEURAL CREST. Multiple hyperpigmented skin lesions and subcutaneous tumors are the hallmark of this disease. Peripheral and central nervous system neoplasms occur frequently
column6: especially OPTIC NERVE GLIOMA and NEUROFIBROSARCOMA. NF1 is caused by mutations which inactivate the NF1 gene (GENES
column7: NEUROFIBROMATOSIS 1) on chromosome 17q. The incidence of learning disabilities is also elevated in this condition. (From Adams et al.
column10: pp1014-18) There is overlap of clinical features with NOONAN SYNDROME in a syndrome called neurofibromatosis-Noonan syndrome. Both the PTPN11 and NF1 gene products are involved in the SIGNAL TRANSDUCTION pathway of Ras (RAS PROTEINS).

column1: C10.668.829.700*D000699*Pain Insensitivity
column2: Congenital*A syndrome characterized by indifference to PAIN despite the ability to distinguish noxious from non-noxious stimuli. Absent corneal reflexes and INTELLECTUAL DISABILITY may be associated. Familial forms with autosomal recessive and autosomal dominant patterns of inheritance have been described. (Adams et al.

column1: C10.668.829.712*D059348*Peripheral Nerve Injuries*Injuries to the PERIPHERAL NERVES.

C10.668.829.725*D010524*Peripheral Nervous System Neoplasms*Neoplasms which arise from peripheral nerve tissue. This includes NEUROFIBROMAS; SCHWANNOMAS; GRANULAR CELL TUMORS; and malignant peripheral NERVE SHEATH NEOPLASMS. (From DeVita Jr et al.
column2: Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology

column1: C10.668.829.725.500*D018317*Nerve Sheath Neoplasms*Neoplasms which arise from nerve sheaths formed by SCHWANN CELLS in the PERIPHERAL NERVOUS SYSTEM or by OLIGODENDROCYTES in the CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM. Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors
column2: NEUROFIBROMA
column3: and NEURILEMMOMA are relatively common tumors in this category.

column1: C10.668.829.725.500.600*D009455*Neurofibroma*A moderately firm
column2: benign
column3: encapsulated tumor resulting from proliferation of SCHWANN CELLS and FIBROBLASTS that includes portions of nerve fibers. The tumors usually develop along peripheral or cranial nerves and are a central feature of NEUROFIBROMATOSIS 1
column4: where they may occur intracranially or involve spinal roots. Pathologic features include fusiform enlargement of the involved nerve. Microscopic examination reveals a disorganized and loose cellular pattern with elongated nuclei intermixed with fibrous strands. (From Adams et al.

column2: Plexiform*A type of neurofibroma manifesting as a diffuse overgrowth of subcutaneous tissue
column6: and chest but occasionally occurring in the abdomen or pelvis. The tumors tend to progress
column7: and may extend along nerve roots to eventually involve the spinal roots and spinal cord. This process is almost always a manifestation of NEUROFIBROMATOSIS 1. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.668.829.725.500.600.600*D018319*Neurofibrosarcoma*A malignant tumor that arises from small cutaneous nerves
column2: is locally aggressive
column3: and has a potential for metastasis. Characteristic histopathologic features include proliferating atypical spindle cells with slender wavy and pointed nuclei
column5: and areas featuring organized whorls of fibroblastic proliferation. The most common primary sites are the extremities
column7: and trunk. These tumors tend to present in childhood
column8: often in association with NEUROFIBROMATOSIS 1. (From DeVita et al.

column1: C10.668.829.800*D011115*Polyneuropathies*Diseases of multiple peripheral nerves simultaneously. Polyneuropathies usually are characterized by symmetrical
column2: bilateral distal motor and sensory impairment with a graded increase in severity distally. The pathological processes affecting peripheral nerves include degeneration of the axon
column3: myelin or both. The various forms of polyneuropathy are categorized by the type of nerve affected (e.g.
column7: by the distribution of nerve injury (e.g.

column1: C10.668.829.800.050*D020269*Alcoholic Neuropathy*A condition where damage to the peripheral nervous system (including the peripheral elements of the autonomic nervous system) is associated with chronic ingestion of alcoholic beverages. The disorder may be caused by a direct effect of alcohol
column2: an associated nutritional deficiency
column3: or a combination of factors. Clinical manifestations include variable degrees of weakness; ATROPHY; PARESTHESIAS; pain; loss of reflexes; sensory loss; diaphoresis; and postural hypotension. (From Arch Neurol 1995;52(1):45-51; Adams et al.

column1: C10.668.829.800.175*D009477*Hereditary Sensory and Autonomic Neuropathies*A group of inherited disorders characterized by degeneration of dorsal root and autonomic ganglion cells
column2: and clinically by loss of sensation and autonomic dysfunction. There are five subtypes. Type I features autosomal dominant inheritance and distal sensory involvement. Type II is characterized by autosomal inheritance and distal and proximal sensory loss. Type III is DYSAUTONOMIA
column3: FAMILIAL. Type IV features insensitivity to pain
column5: and mental deficiency. Type V is characterized by a selective loss of pain with intact light touch and vibratory sensation. (From Joynt

column2: Familial*An autosomal disorder of the peripheral and autonomic nervous systems limited to individuals of Ashkenazic Jewish descent. Clinical manifestations are present at birth and include diminished lacrimation
column8: loss of pain and temperature sensation
column9: and absent reflexes. Pathologic features include reduced numbers of small diameter peripheral nerve fibers and autonomic ganglion neurons. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.668.829.800.300*D015417*Hereditary Sensory and Motor Neuropathy*A group of slowly progressive inherited disorders affecting motor and sensory peripheral nerves. Subtypes include HMSNs I-VII. HMSN I and II both refer to CHARCOT-MARIE-TOOTH DISEASE. HMSN III refers to hypertrophic neuropathy of infancy. HMSN IV refers to REFSUM DISEASE. HMSN V refers to a condition marked by a hereditary motor and sensory neuropathy associated with spastic paraplegia (see SPASTIC PARAPLEGIA
column2: HEREDITARY). HMSN VI refers to HMSN associated with an inherited optic atrophy (OPTIC ATROPHIES
column4: and HMSN VII refers to HMSN associated with retinitis pigmentosa. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.668.829.800.300.099*D056769*Alstrom Syndrome*Rare autosomal recessive disease characterized by multiple organ dysfunction. The key clinical features include retinal degeneration (NYSTAGMUS
column2: PATHOLOGIC; RETINITIS PIGMENTOSA; and eventual blindness)
column5: and normal mental development. Endocrinologic complications include TYPE 2 DIABETES MELLITUS; HYPERINSULINEMIA; ACANTHOSIS NIGRICANS; HYPOTHYROIDISM; and progressive renal and hepatic failures. The disease is caused by mutations in the ALMS1 gene.

column1: C10.668.829.800.300.200*D002607*Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disease*A hereditary motor and sensory neuropathy transmitted most often as an autosomal dominant trait and characterized by progressive distal wasting and loss of reflexes in the muscles of the legs (and occasionally involving the arms). Onset is usually in the second to fourth decade of life. This condition has been divided into two subtypes
column2: hereditary motor and sensory neuropathy (HMSN) types I and II. HMSN I is associated with abnormal nerve conduction velocities and nerve hypertrophy
column3: features not seen in HMSN II. (Adams et al.

column1: C10.668.829.800.300.490*D056768*Giant Axonal Neuropathy*Rare autosomal recessive disorder of INTERMEDIATE FILAMENT PROTEINS. The disease is caused by mutations in the gene that codes gigaxonin protein. The mutations result in disorganization of axonal NEUROFILAMENT PROTEINS
column2: formation of the characteristic giant axons
column3: and progressive neuropathy. The clinical features of the disease include early-onset progressive peripheral motor and sensory neuropathies often associated with central nervous system involvement (INTELLECTUAL DISABILITY

column1: C10.668.829.800.300.780*D012035*Refsum Disease*An autosomal recessive familial disorder that usually presents in childhood with POLYNEUROPATHY; SENSORINEURAL HEARING LOSS; ICHTHYOSIS; ATAXIA; RETINITIS PIGMENTOSA; and CARDIOMYOPATHIES. (From Joynt
column2: Clinical Neurology
column5: p58-9; Rev Med Interne 1996;17(5):391-8) This condition can be caused by mutation in the genes encoding peroxisomal phytanoyl-CoA hydroxylase or proteins associated peroxisomal membrane
column6: leading to impaired catabolism of PHYTANIC ACID in PEROXISOMES.

column2: Hereditary*A group of inherited diseases that share similar phenotypes but are genetically diverse. Different genetic loci for autosomal recessive
column4: and x-linked forms of hereditary spastic paraplegia have been identified. Clinically
column5: patients present with slowly progressive distal limb weakness and lower extremity spasticity. Peripheral sensory neurons may be affected in the later stages of the disease. (J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 1998 Jan;64(1):61-6; Curr Opin Neurol 1997 Aug;10(4):313-8)

column1: C10.668.829.800.662*D020364*Paraneoplastic Polyneuropathy*A diffuse or multifocal peripheral neuropathy related to the remote effects of a neoplasm
column2: most often carcinoma or lymphoma. Pathologically
column3: there are inflammatory changes in peripheral nerves. The most common clinical presentation is a symmetric distal mixed sensorimotor polyneuropathy. (Adams et al.

column1: C10.668.829.800.700*D016878*POEMS Syndrome*A multisystemic disorder characterized by a sensorimotor polyneuropathy (POLYNEUROPATHIES)
column2: organomegaly
column5: and pigmentary skin changes. Other clinical features which may be present include EDEMA; CACHEXIA; microangiopathic glomerulopathy; pulmonary hypertension (HYPERTENSION
column6: PULMONARY); cutaneous necrosis; THROMBOCYTOSIS; and POLYCYTHEMIA. This disorder is frequently associated with osteosclerotic myeloma. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.668.829.800.750*D011129*Polyradiculoneuropathy*Diseases characterized by injury or dysfunction involving multiple peripheral nerves and nerve roots. The process may primarily affect myelin or nerve axons. Two of the more common demyelinating forms are acute inflammatory polyradiculopathy (GUILLAIN-BARRE SYNDROME) and POLYRADICULONEUROPATHY
column2: CHRONIC INFLAMMATORY DEMYELINATING. Polyradiculoneuritis refers to inflammation of multiple peripheral nerves and spinal nerve roots.

column1: C10.668.829.800.750.300*D020275*Guillain-Barre Syndrome*An acute inflammatory autoimmune neuritis caused by T cell- mediated cellular immune response directed towards peripheral myelin. Demyelination occurs in peripheral nerves and nerve roots. The process is often preceded by a viral or bacterial infection
column2: surgery
column5: or exposure to toxins. Common clinical manifestations include progressive weakness
column7: and loss of deep tendon reflexes. Weakness of respiratory muscles and autonomic dysfunction may occur. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.668.829.800.750.300.500*D019846*Miller Fisher Syndrome*A variant of the GUILLAIN-BARRE SYNDROME characterized by the acute onset of oculomotor dysfunction
column2: ataxia
column3: and loss of deep tendon reflexes with relative sparing of strength in the extremities and trunk. The ataxia is produced by peripheral sensory nerve dysfunction and not by cerebellar injury. Facial weakness and sensory loss may also occur. The process is mediated by autoantibodies directed against a component of myelin found in peripheral nerves. (Adams et al.

column1: C10.668.829.800.750.600*D020277*Polyradiculoneuropathy
column2: Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating*A slowly progressive autoimmune demyelinating disease of peripheral nerves and nerve roots. Clinical manifestations include weakness and sensory loss in the extremities and enlargement of peripheral nerves. The course may be relapsing-remitting or demonstrate a step-wise progression. Protein is usually elevated in the spinal fluid and cranial nerves are typically spared. GUILLAIN-BARRE SYNDROME features a relatively rapid progression of disease which distinguishes it from this condition. (Adams et al.

column1: C10.668.829.800.750.700*D011128*Polyradiculopathy*Disease or injury involving multiple SPINAL NERVE ROOTS. Polyradiculitis refers to inflammation of multiple spinal nerve roots.

C10.668.829.800.875*D013631*Tangier Disease*An autosomal recessively inherited disorder caused by mutation of ATP-BINDING CASSETTE TRANSPORTERS involved in cellular cholesterol removal (reverse-cholesterol transport). It is characterized by near absence of ALPHA-LIPOPROTEINS (high-density lipoproteins) in blood. The massive tissue deposition of cholesterol esters results in HEPATOMEGALY; SPLENOMEGALY; RETINITIS PIGMENTOSA; large orange tonsils; and often sensory POLYNEUROPATHY. The disorder was first found among inhabitants of Tangier Island in the Chesapeake Bay
column2: MD.

column1: C10.668.829.820*D011843*Radiculopathy*Disease involving a spinal nerve root (see SPINAL NERVE ROOTS) which may result from compression related to INTERVERTEBRAL DISK DISPLACEMENT; SPINAL CORD INJURIES; SPINAL DISEASES; and other conditions. Clinical manifestations include radicular pain
column2: weakness
column3: and sensory loss referable to structures innervated by the involved nerve root.

column1: C10.668.829.860*D000071075*Small Fiber Neuropathy*Disorder of the peripheral nerves that primarily impair small nerve fibers. The affected small nerve fibers include myelinated A-delta fibers (see A FIBERS) and unmyelinated C FIBERS. Because these small fibers innervate skin and help control autonomic function
column2: their neuropathy presents with neuropathic pain
column4: and autonomic dysfunction (e.g. abnormal sweating or facial flushing). Small fiber neuropathy can be idiopathic or associated with underlying diseases (e.g.
column5: AMYLOIDOSIS; DIABETES MELLITUS; SARCOIDOSIS; or VASCULITIS).

column1: C10.668.829.900*D052958*Tarlov Cysts*Perineurial cysts commonly found in the SACRAL REGION. They arise from the PERINEURIUM membrane within the SPINAL NERVE ROOTS. The distinctive feature of the cysts is the presence of spinal nerve root fibers within the cyst wall
column2: or the cyst cavity itself.

column1: C10.668.864*D011051*Poliomyelitis*An acute infectious disease of humans
column2: particularly children
column3: caused by any of three serotypes of human poliovirus (POLIOVIRUS). Usually the infection is limited to the gastrointestinal tract and nasopharynx
column4: and is often asymptomatic. The central nervous system
column8: coarse FASCICULATION and hyporeflexia. Motor neurons are primarily affected. Encephalitis may also occur. The virus replicates in the nervous system
column9: and may cause significant neuronal loss
column10: most notably in the spinal cord. A rare related condition
column12: may result from infections with nonpoliovirus enteroviruses. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.668.864.250*D011052*Poliomyelitis
column2: Bulbar*A form of paralytic poliomyelitis affecting neurons of the MEDULLA OBLONGATA of the brain stem. Clinical features include impaired respiration
column5: and dysphagia. Weakness and atrophy of the limbs and trunk due to spinal cord involvement is usually associated. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.668.864.500*D016262*Postpoliomyelitis Syndrome*A syndrome characterized by new neuromuscular symptoms that occur at least 15 years after clinical stability has been attained in patients with a prior history of symptomatic poliomyelitis. Clinical features include new muscular weakness and atrophy of the limbs
column2: bulbar innervated musculature
column6: and reduced stamina. The process is marked by slow progression and periods of stabilization. (From Ann NY Acad Sci 1995 May 25;753:68-80)

column1: C10.668.900*D016750*Stiff-Person Syndrome*A condition characterized by persistent spasms (SPASM) involving multiple muscles
column2: primarily in the lower limbs and trunk. The illness tends to occur in the fourth to sixth decade of life
column3: presenting with intermittent spasms that become continuous. Minor sensory stimuli
column4: such as noise and light touch
column5: precipitate severe spasms. Spasms do not occur during sleep and only rarely involve cranial muscles. Respiration may become impaired in advanced cases. (Adams et al.

column1: C10.720*D020258*Neurotoxicity Syndromes*Neurologic disorders caused by exposure to toxic substances through ingestion
column2: injection
column4: or other method. This includes conditions caused by biologic

column2: Drug-Induced*A condition associated with the use of certain medications and characterized by an internal sense of motor restlessness often described as an inability to resist the urge to move.

column1: C10.720.112*D020268*Alcohol-Induced Disorders
column2: Nervous System*Acute and chronic neurologic disorders associated with the various neurologic effects of ETHANOL. Primary sites of injury include the brain and peripheral nerves.

column1: C10.720.112.100*D000425*Alcohol Amnestic Disorder*A mental disorder associated with chronic ethanol abuse (ALCOHOLISM) and nutritional deficiencies characterized by short term memory loss
column2: confabulations
column3: and disturbances of attention. (Adams et al.

column1: C10.720.112.100.500*D020915*Korsakoff Syndrome*An acquired cognitive disorder characterized by inattentiveness and the inability to form short term memories. This disorder is frequently associated with chronic ALCOHOLISM; but it may also result from dietary deficiencies; CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA; NEOPLASMS; CEREBROVASCULAR DISORDERS; ENCEPHALITIS; EPILEPSY; and other conditions. (Adams et al.
column2: Principles of Neurology

column1: C10.720.112.200*D000430*Alcohol Withdrawal Delirium*An acute organic mental disorder induced by cessation or reduction in chronic alcohol consumption. Clinical characteristics include CONFUSION; DELUSIONS; vivid HALLUCINATIONS; TREMOR; agitation; insomnia; and signs of autonomic hyperactivity (e.g.
column2: elevated blood pressure and heart rate
column4: and diaphoresis). This condition may occasionally be fatal. It was formerly called delirium tremens. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.720.112.300*D020270*Alcohol Withdrawal Seizures*A condition where seizures occur in association with ethanol abuse (ALCOHOLISM) without other identifiable causes. Seizures usually occur within the first 6-48 hours after the cessation of alcohol intake
column2: but may occur during periods of alcohol intoxication. Single generalized tonic-clonic motor seizures are the most common subtype
column4: STATUS EPILEPTICUS may occur. (Adams et al.

column1: C10.720.112.400*D020269*Alcoholic Neuropathy*A condition where damage to the peripheral nervous system (including the peripheral elements of the autonomic nervous system) is associated with chronic ingestion of alcoholic beverages. The disorder may be caused by a direct effect of alcohol
column2: an associated nutritional deficiency
column3: or a combination of factors. Clinical manifestations include variable degrees of weakness; ATROPHY; PARESTHESIAS; pain; loss of reflexes; sensory loss; diaphoresis; and postural hypotension. (From Arch Neurol 1995;52(1):45-51; Adams et al.

column1: C10.720.150*D001906*Botulism*A disease caused by potent protein NEUROTOXINS produced by CLOSTRIDIUM BOTULINUM which interfere with the presynaptic release of ACETYLCHOLINE at the NEUROMUSCULAR JUNCTION. Clinical features include abdominal pain
column2: vomiting
column5: and DIPLOPIA. Botulism may be classified into several subtypes (e.g.

column1: C10.720.312*D004409*Dyskinesia
column2: Drug-Induced*Abnormal movements
column3: including HYPERKINESIS; HYPOKINESIA; TREMOR; and DYSTONIA
column4: associated with the use of certain medications or drugs. Muscles of the face
column7: and extremities are most commonly affected. Tardive dyskinesia refers to abnormal hyperkinetic movements of the muscles of the face
column9: and neck associated with the use of neuroleptic agents (see ANTIPSYCHOTIC AGENTS). (Adams et al.

column1: C10.720.475*D020260*Heavy Metal Poisoning
column2: Nervous System*Conditions associated with damage or dysfunction of the nervous system caused by exposure to heavy metals
column3: which may cause a variety of central

column1: C10.720.475.150*D020261*Arsenic Poisoning*Disorders associated with acute or chronic exposure to compounds containing ARSENIC (ARSENICALS) which may be fatal. Acute oral ingestion is associated with gastrointestinal symptoms and an encephalopathy which may manifest as SEIZURES
column2: mental status changes
column3: and COMA. Chronic exposure is associated with mucosal irritation
column7: and white transverse (Mees) lines in the fingernails. (Adams et al.

column1: C10.720.475.400*D020263*Lead Poisoning
column2: Nervous System*Injury to the nervous system secondary to exposure to lead compounds. Two distinct clinical patterns occur in children (LEAD POISONING
column7: lead poisoning typically produces an encephalopathy. In adults
column8: exposure to toxic levels of lead is associated with a peripheral neuropathy.

column2: Nervous System
column3: Adult*Neurologic conditions in adults associated with acute or chronic exposure to lead or any of its salts. The most common lead related neurologic syndrome in adults consists of a polyneuropathy involving motor fibers. This tends to affect distal nerves and may present as wrist drop due to RADIAL NEUROPATHY. Additional features of chronic lead exposure include ANEMIA; CONSTIPATION; colicky abdominal pain; a bluish lead line of the gums; interstitial nephritis (NEPHRITIS
column4: INTERSTITIAL); and saturnine gout. An encephalopathy may rarely occur. (From Adams et al.

column2: Nervous System
column3: Childhood*Neurologic disorders occurring in children following lead exposure. The most frequent manifestation of childhood lead toxicity is an encephalopathy associated with chronic ingestion of lead that usually presents between the ages of 1 and 3 years. Clinical manifestations include behavioral changes followed by lethargy; CONVULSIONS; HALLUCINATIONS; DELIRIUM; ATAXIA; and vomiting. Elevated intracranial pressure (HYPERTENSION
column4: INTRACRANIAL) and CEREBRAL EDEMA may occur. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.720.475.500*D020149*Manganese Poisoning*Manganese poisoning is associated with chronic inhalation of manganese particles by individuals who work with manganese ore. Clinical features include CONFUSION; HALLUCINATIONS; and an extrapyramidal syndrome (PARKINSON DISEASE
column2: SECONDARY) that includes rigidity; DYSTONIA; retropulsion; and TREMOR. (Adams

column1: C10.720.475.600*D020262*Mercury Poisoning
column2: Nervous System*Neurologic disorders associated with exposure to inorganic and organic forms of MERCURY. Acute intoxication may be associated with gastrointestinal disturbances
column4: and PARAPARESIS. Chronic exposure to inorganic mercury usually occurs in industrial workers
column8: and NEURITIS. Alkyl mercury poisoning may occur through ingestion of contaminated seafood or grain
column9: and its characteristic features include POLYNEUROPATHY; ATAXIA; vision loss; NYSTAGMUS

column1: C10.720.475.600.150*D000170*Acrodynia*A condition seen primarily in childhood
column2: most often resulting from chronic exposure to MERCURY COMPOUNDS which may result in encephalopathy and POLYNEUROPATHY. Clinical features include pain
column3: swelling and pinkish discoloration of the fingers and toes
column7: and alterations in level of consciousness. (From Menkes

column1: C10.720.606*D020267*MPTP Poisoning*A condition caused by the neurotoxin MPTP which causes selective destruction of nigrostriatal dopaminergic neurons. Clinical features include irreversible parkinsonian signs including rigidity and bradykinesia (PARKINSON DISEASE
column2: SECONDARY). MPTP toxicity is also used as an animal model for the study of PARKINSON DISEASE. (Adams et al.

column1: C10.720.737*D009459*Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome*A potentially fatal syndrome associated primarily with the use of neuroleptic agents (see ANTIPSYCHOTIC AGENTS) which are in turn associated with dopaminergic receptor blockade (see RECEPTORS
column2: DOPAMINE) in the BASAL GANGLIA and HYPOTHALAMUS
column3: and sympathetic dysregulation. Clinical features include diffuse MUSCLE RIGIDITY; TREMOR; high FEVER; diaphoresis; labile blood pressure; cognitive dysfunction; and autonomic disturbances. Serum CPK level elevation and a leukocytosis may also be present. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.803*D012148*Restless Legs Syndrome*A disorder characterized by aching or burning sensations in the lower and rarely the upper extremities that occur prior to sleep or may awaken the patient from sleep.

column4: extrinsic (secondary to environmental conditions or various pathologic conditions)
column5: and disturbances of circadian rhythm. (From Thorpy

column1: C10.886.425.175*D012892*Sleep Deprivation*The state of being deprived of sleep under experimental conditions
column2: due to life events
column3: or from a wide variety of pathophysiologic causes such as medication effect

column1: C10.886.425.200*D020178*Sleep Disorders
column2: Circadian Rhythm*Dyssomnias associated with disruption of the normal 24 hour sleep wake cycle secondary to travel (e.g.

column1: C10.886.425.200.500*D020179*Jet Lag Syndrome*A chronobiologic disorder resulting from rapid travel across a number of time zones

column1: C10.886.425.800*D020919*Sleep Disorders
column2: Intrinsic*Dyssomnias (i.e.
column3: insomnias or hypersomnias) associated with dysfunction of internal sleep mechanisms or secondary to a sleep-related medical disorder (e.g.

column1: C10.886.425.800.200*D006970*Disorders of Excessive Somnolence*Disorders characterized by hypersomnolence during normal waking hours that may impair cognitive functioning. Subtypes include primary hypersomnia disorders (e.g.
column2: IDIOPATHIC HYPERSOMNOLENCE; NARCOLEPSY; and KLEINE-LEVIN SYNDROME) and secondary hypersomnia disorders where excessive somnolence can be attributed to a known cause (e.g.
column5: and SLEEP APNEA SYNDROME). (From J Neurol Sci 1998 Jan 8;153(2):192-202; Thorpy
column6: Principles and Practice of Sleep Medicine

column2: Idiopathic*A sleep disorder of central nervous system origin characterized by prolonged nocturnal sleep and periods of daytime drowsiness. Affected individuals experience difficulty with awakening in the morning and may have associated sleep drunkenness
column4: and memory disturbances. This condition differs from narcolepsy in that daytime sleep periods are longer
column5: there is no association with CATAPLEXY
column6: and the multiple sleep latency onset test does not record sleep-onset rapid eye movement sleep. (From Chokroverty

column1: C10.886.425.800.200.500*D017593*Kleine-Levin Syndrome*A rare condition characterized by recurrent hypersomnias associated with hyperphagia
column2: occurring primarily in males in the second to third decade of life. Clinical features include mental confusion
column3: excessive sleep requirements (approximately 18 hours per day)
column5: and in some cases hallucinations. Episodes have a duration of days to weeks
column6: and may recur several times per year. This condition may resolve spontaneously over several years. (From Adams

column1: C10.886.425.800.200.750*D009290*Narcolepsy*A condition characterized by recurrent episodes of daytime somnolence and lapses in consciousness (microsomnias) that may be associated with automatic behaviors and AMNESIA. CATAPLEXY; SLEEP PARALYSIS
column2: and hypnagogic HALLUCINATIONS frequently accompany narcolepsy. The pathophysiology of this disorder includes sleep-onset rapid eye movement (REM) sleep
column3: which normally follows stage III or IV sleep. (From Neurology 1998 Feb;50(2 Suppl 1):S2-S7)

column1: C10.886.425.800.200.750.500*D002385*Cataplexy*A condition characterized by transient weakness or paralysis of somatic musculature triggered by an emotional stimulus or physical exertion. Cataplexy is frequently associated with NARCOLEPSY. During a cataplectic attack
column2: there is a marked reduction in muscle tone similar to the normal physiologic hypotonia that accompanies rapid eye movement sleep (SLEEP

column1: C10.886.425.800.600*D020189*Nocturnal Myoclonus Syndrome*Excessive periodic leg movements during sleep that cause micro-arousals and interfere with the maintenance of sleep. This condition induces a state of relative sleep deprivation which manifests as excessive daytime hypersomnolence. The movements are characterized by repetitive contractions of the tibialis anterior muscle
column2: extension of the toe
column3: and intermittent flexion of the hip

column1: C10.886.425.800.700*D012148*Restless Legs Syndrome*A disorder characterized by aching or burning sensations in the lower and rarely the upper extremities that occur prior to sleep or may awaken the patient from sleep.

C10.886.425.800.750*D012891*Sleep Apnea Syndromes*Disorders characterized by multiple cessations of respirations during sleep that induce partial arousals and interfere with the maintenance of sleep. Sleep apnea syndromes are divided into central (see SLEEP APNEA
column2: CENTRAL)
Central*A condition associated with multiple episodes of sleep apnea which are distinguished from obstructive sleep apnea (SLEEP APNEA
column3: OBSTRUCTIVE) by the complete cessation of efforts to breathe. This disorder is associated with dysfunction of central nervous system centers that regulate respiration.

column2: Obstructive*A disorder characterized by recurrent apneas during sleep despite persistent respiratory efforts. It is due to upper airway obstruction. The respiratory pauses may induce HYPERCAPNIA or HYPOXIA. Cardiac arrhythmias and elevation of systemic and pulmonary arterial pressures may occur. Frequent partial arousals occur throughout sleep
column3: resulting in relative SLEEP DEPRIVATION and daytime tiredness. Associated conditions include OBESITY; ACROMEGALY; MYXEDEMA; micrognathia; MYOTONIC DYSTROPHY; adenotonsilar dystrophy; and NEUROMUSCULAR DISEASES. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.886.425.800.750.850.500*D010845*Obesity Hypoventilation Syndrome*HYPOVENTILATION syndrome in very obese persons with excessive ADIPOSE TISSUE around the ABDOMEN and DIAPHRAGM. It is characterized by diminished to absent ventilatory chemoresponsiveness; chronic HYPOXIA; HYPERCAPNIA; POLYCYTHEMIA; and long periods of sleep during day and night (HYPERSOMNOLENCE). It is a condition often related to OBSTRUCTIVE SLEEP APNEA but can occur separately.

C10.886.425.800.800*D007319*Sleep Initiation and Maintenance Disorders*Disorders characterized by impairment of the ability to initiate or maintain sleep. This may occur as a primary disorder or in association with another medical or psychiatric condition.

column2: Fatal Familial*An autosomal dominant disorder characterized by degeneration of the THALAMUS and progressive insomnia. It is caused by a mutation in the prion protein (PRIONS).

column1: C10.886.659*D020447*Parasomnias*Movements or behaviors associated with sleep
column2: sleep stages
column3: or partial arousals from sleep that may impair sleep maintenance. Parasomnias are generally divided into four groups: arousal disorders

column1: C10.886.659.618*D020189*Nocturnal Myoclonus Syndrome*Excessive periodic leg movements during sleep that cause micro-arousals and interfere with the maintenance of sleep. This condition induces a state of relative sleep deprivation which manifests as excessive daytime hypersomnolence. The movements are characterized by repetitive contractions of the tibialis anterior muscle
column2: extension of the toe
column3: and intermittent flexion of the hip

column1: C10.886.659.627*D020183*Nocturnal Paroxysmal Dystonia*A parasomnia characterized by paroxysmal episodes of choreoathetotic
column2: ballistic
column4: and semipurposeful activity. The episodes occur during non-rapid eye movement sleep and typically recur several times per night. (Neurology 1992 Jul;42(7 Suppl 6):61-67; Adams et al.

column1: C10.886.659.633*D020923*REM Sleep Parasomnias*Abnormal behavioral or physiologic events that are associated with REM sleep
column2: including REM SLEEP BEHAVIOR DISORDER.

column1: C10.886.659.633.700*D020187*REM Sleep Behavior Disorder*A disorder characterized by episodes of vigorous and often violent motor activity during REM sleep (SLEEP
column2: REM). The affected individual may inflict self injury or harm others
column3: and is difficult to awaken from this condition. Episodes are usually followed by a vivid recollection of a dream that is consistent with the aggressive behavior. This condition primarily affects adult males. (From Adams et al.

column1: C10.886.659.633.800*D020188*Sleep Paralysis*A common condition characterized by transient partial or total paralysis of skeletal muscles and areflexia that occurs upon awakening from sleep or less often while falling asleep. Stimuli such as touch or sound may terminate the episode
column2: which usually has a duration of seconds to minutes. This condition may occur in normal subjects or be associated with NARCOLEPSY; CATAPLEXY; and hypnagogic HALLUCINATIONS. The pathophysiology of this condition is closely related to the normal hypotonia that occur during REM sleep. (From Adv Neurol 1995;67:245-271)

column1: C10.886.659.634*D012148*Restless Legs Syndrome*A disorder characterized by aching or burning sensations in the lower and rarely the upper extremities that occur prior to sleep or may awaken the patient from sleep.
C10.886.659.635*D020921*Sleep Arousal Disorders*Sleep disorders characterized by impaired arousal from the deeper stages of sleep (generally stage III or IV sleep).

C10.886.659.635.600*D020184*Night Terrors*A disorder characterized by incomplete arousals from sleep associated with behavior suggesting extreme fright. This condition primarily affects children and young adults and the individual generally has no recall of the event. Episodes tend to occur during stage III or IV. SOMNAMBULISM is frequently associated with this condition. (Adams et al.
column2: Principles of Neurology

column1: C10.886.659.635.700*D013009*Somnambulism*A parasomnia characterized by a partial arousal that occurs during stage IV of non-REM sleep. Affected individuals exhibit semipurposeful behaviors such as ambulation and are difficult to fully awaken. Children are primarily affected
column2: with a peak age range of 4-6 years.

column1: C10.886.659.637*D020186*Sleep Bruxism*A sleep disorder characterized by grinding and clenching of the teeth and forceful lateral or protrusive jaw movements. Sleep bruxism may be associated with TOOTH INJURIES; TEMPOROMANDIBULAR JOINT DISORDERS; sleep disturbances; and other conditions.

C10.886.659.700*D020922*Sleep-Wake Transition Disorders*Parasomnias characterized by behavioral abnormalities that occur during the transition between wakefulness and sleep (or between sleep and wakefulness).

column2: Nervous System*Traumatic injuries to the brain

column1: C10.900.250*D020214*Cerebrovascular Trauma*Penetrating and nonpenetrating traumatic injuries to an extracranial or intracranial blood vessel that supplies the brain. This includes the CAROTID ARTERIES; VERTEBRAL ARTERIES; MENINGEAL ARTERIES; CEREBRAL ARTERIES; veins
column2: and venous sinuses.

column1: C10.900.250.300*D020212*Carotid Artery Injuries*Damages to the CAROTID ARTERIES caused either by blunt force or penetrating trauma
column2: such as CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA; THORACIC INJURIES; and NECK INJURIES. Damaged carotid arteries can lead to CAROTID ARTERY THROMBOSIS; CAROTID-CAVERNOUS SINUS FISTULA; pseudoaneurysm formation; and INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY DISSECTION. (From Am J Forensic Med Pathol 1997
Internal
column3: Dissection*The splitting of the vessel wall in one or both (left and right) internal carotid arteries (CAROTID ARTERY
column4: INTERNAL). Interstitial hemorrhage into the media of the vessel wall can lead to occlusion of the internal carotid artery and aneurysm formation.

column1: C10.900.250.300.400*D020216*Carotid-Cavernous Sinus Fistula*An acquired or spontaneous abnormality in which there is communication between CAVERNOUS SINUS

column5: BASILAR). Clinical signs often include VISION DISORDERS and INTRACRANIAL HYPERTENSION.

column3: or THROMBOEMBOLISM. Vertebral artery dissection is often associated with TRAUMA and injuries to the head-neck region but can occur spontaneously.

column1: C10.900.300*D006259*Craniocerebral Trauma*Traumatic injuries involving the cranium and intracranial structures (i.e.
column2: BRAIN; CRANIAL NERVES; MENINGES; and other structures). Injuries may be classified by whether or not the skull is penetrated (i.e.
column3: penetrating vs. nonpenetrating) or whether there is an associated hemorrhage.

column1: C10.900.300.087*D001930*Brain Injuries*Acute and chronic (see also BRAIN INJURIES
column2: CHRONIC) injuries to the brain
column5: and BRAIN STEM. Clinical manifestations depend on the nature of injury. Diffuse trauma to the brain is frequently associated with DIFFUSE AXONAL INJURY or COMA

column2: Traumatic*Bleeding within the brain as a result of penetrating and nonpenetrating CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA. Traumatically induced hemorrhages may occur in any area of the brain
column3: including the CEREBRUM; BRAIN STEM (see BRAIN STEM HEMORRHAGE

column1: C10.900.300.087.187.200*D020203*Brain Stem Hemorrhage

column1: C10.900.300.087.187.300*D020202*Cerebral Hemorrhage

column2: Post-Traumatic*Recurrent seizures causally related to CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA. Seizure onset may be immediate but is typically delayed for several days after the injury and may not occur for up to two years. The majority of seizures have a focal onset that correlates clinically with the site of brain injury. Cerebral cortex injuries caused by a penetrating foreign object (CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA

column4: CLOSED) to be associated with epilepsy. Concussive convulsions are nonepileptic phenomena that occur immediately after head injury and are characterized by tonic and clonic movements. (From Rev Neurol 1998 Feb;26(150):256-261; Sports Med 1998 Feb;25(2):131-6)

column4: and extraocular muscles. Ragged-red fibers and atrophy are found on muscle biopsy. Familial and sporadic forms may occur. Disease onset is usually in the first or second decade of life

column1: C11.590.472.250.500*D007625*Kearns-Sayre Syndrome*A mitochondrial disorder featuring the triad of chronic progressive EXTERNAL OPHTHALMOPLEGIA

column3: and RETINITIS PIGMENTOSA. Disease onset is in the first or second decade. Elevated CSF protein
column6: and pyramidal signs may also be present. Ragged-red fibers are found on muscle biopsy. (Adams et al.

column1: C11.590.472.375*D060486*Ophthalmoplegic Migraine*Childhood-onset of recurrent headaches with an oculomotor cranial nerve palsy. Typically
column2: ABDUCENS NERVE; OCULOMOTOR NERVE; and TROCHLEAR NERVE are involved with DIPLOPIA and BLEPHAROPTOSIS.

column1: C11.590.472.500*D013494*Supranuclear Palsy
column2: Progressive*A degenerative disease of the central nervous system characterized by balance difficulties; OCULAR MOTILITY DISORDERS (supranuclear ophthalmoplegia); DYSARTHRIA; swallowing difficulties; and axial DYSTONIA. Onset is usually in the fifth decade and disease progression occurs over several years. Pathologic findings include neurofibrillary degeneration and neuronal loss in the dorsal MESENCEPHALON; SUBTHALAMIC NUCLEUS; RED NUCLEUS; pallidum; dentate nucleus; and vestibular nuclei. (From Adams et al.

column1: C11.590.725*D053578*Opsoclonus-Myoclonus Syndrome*A neurological condition that is characterized by uncontrolled rapid irregular movements of the eye (OPSOCLONUS) and the muscle (MYOCLONUS) causing unsteady
column2: trembling gait. It is also known as dancing eyes-dancing feet syndrome and is often associated with neoplasms
column4: or autoimmune disorders involving the nervous system.

column1: C11.590.810*D013285*Strabismus*Misalignment of the visual axes of the eyes. In comitant strabismus the degree of ocular misalignment does not vary with the direction of gaze. In noncomitant strabismus the degree of misalignment varies depending on direction of gaze or which eye is fixating on the target. (Miller
column2: Walsh & Hoyt's Clinical Neuro-Ophthalmology

column1: C11.590.810.400*D004948*Esotropia*A form of ocular misalignment characterized by an excessive convergence of the visual axes
column2: resulting in a cross-eye appearance. An example of this condition occurs when paralysis of the lateral rectus muscle causes an abnormal inward deviation of one eye on attempted gaze.

column1: C11.590.810.440*D005099*Exotropia*A form of ocular misalignment where the visual axes diverge inappropriately. For example
column2: medial rectus muscle weakness may produce this condition as the affected eye will deviate laterally upon attempted forward gaze. An exotropia occurs due to the relatively unopposed force exerted on the eye by the lateral rectus muscle
column3: which pulls the eye in an outward direction.

column1: C11.590.905*D020333*Tolosa-Hunt Syndrome*An idiopathic syndrome characterized by the formation of granulation tissue in the anterior cavernous sinus or superior orbital fissure
column2: producing a painful ophthalmoplegia. (Adams et al.

column1: C11.640*D009901*Optic Nerve Diseases*Conditions which produce injury or dysfunction of the second cranial or optic nerve
column2: which is generally considered a component of the central nervous system. Damage to optic nerve fibers may occur at or near their origin in the retina
column7: or lateral geniculate nuclei. Clinical manifestations may include decreased visual acuity and contrast sensitivity

column1: C11.640.225*D057066*Low Tension Glaucoma*A form of GLAUCOMA in which chronic optic nerve damage and loss of vision normally attributable to buildup of intraocular pressure occurs despite prevailing conditions of normal intraocular pressure.

C11.640.451*D009896*Optic Atrophy*Atrophy of the optic disk which may be congenital or acquired. This condition indicates a deficiency in the number of nerve fibers which arise in the RETINA and converge to form the OPTIC DISK; OPTIC NERVE; OPTIC CHIASM; and optic tracts. GLAUCOMA; ISCHEMIA; inflammation
column2: a chronic elevation of intracranial pressure
column6: HEREDITARY) are relatively common causes of this condition.

column1: C11.640.451.451*D015418*Optic Atrophies
column2: Hereditary*Hereditary conditions that feature progressive visual loss in association with optic atrophy. Relatively common forms include autosomal dominant optic atrophy (OPTIC ATROPHY
column3: AUTOSOMAL DOMINANT) and Leber hereditary optic atrophy (OPTIC ATROPHY

column2: Autosomal Dominant*Dominant optic atrophy is a hereditary optic neuropathy causing decreased visual acuity
column5: and optic nerve pallor (Hum. Genet. 1998; 102: 79-86). Mutations leading to this condition have been mapped to the OPA1 gene at chromosome 3q28-q29. OPA1 codes for a dynamin-related GTPase that localizes to mitochondria.

column2: Hereditary
column3: Leber*A maternally linked genetic disorder that presents in mid-life as acute or subacute central vision loss leading to central scotoma and blindness. The disease has been associated with missense mutations in the mtDNA
column7: that can act autonomously or in association with each other to cause the disease. (from Online Mendelian Inheritance in Man

column1: C11.640.451.451.980*D014929*Wolfram Syndrome*A hereditary condition characterized by multiple symptoms including those of DIABETES INSIPIDUS; DIABETES MELLITUS; OPTIC ATROPHY; and DEAFNESS. This syndrome is also known as DIDMOAD (first letter of each word) and is usually associated with VASOPRESSIN deficiency. It is caused by mutations in gene WFS1 encoding wolframin
column2: a 100-kDa transmembrane protein.

column1: C11.640.513*D015594*Optic Disk Drusen*Optic disk bodies composed primarily of acid mucopolysaccharides that may produce pseudopapilledema (elevation of the optic disk without associated INTRACRANIAL HYPERTENSION) and visual field deficits. Drusen may also occur in the retina (see RETINAL DRUSEN). (Miller et al.
column2: Clinical Neuro-Ophthalmology

column1: C11.640.530*D020221*Optic Nerve Injuries*Injuries to the optic nerve induced by a trauma to the face or head. These may occur with closed or penetrating injuries. Relatively minor compression of the superior aspect of orbit may also result in trauma to the optic nerve. Clinical manifestations may include visual loss
column2: PAPILLEDEMA

column1: C11.640.544*D019574*Optic Nerve Neoplasms*Benign and malignant neoplasms that arise from the optic nerve or its sheath. OPTIC NERVE GLIOMA is the most common histologic type. Optic nerve neoplasms tend to cause unilateral visual loss and an afferent pupillary defect and may spread via neural pathways to the brain.
C11.640.544.500*D020339*Optic Nerve Glioma*Glial cell derived tumors arising from the optic nerve
column2: usually presenting in childhood.

column1: C11.640.576*D009902*Optic Neuritis*Inflammation of the optic nerve. Commonly associated conditions include autoimmune disorders such as MULTIPLE SCLEROSIS
column2: infections
column3: and granulomatous diseases. Clinical features include retro-orbital pain that is aggravated by eye movement
column5: and contrast sensitivity that may progress to severe visual loss
column7: and in some instances optic disc hyperemia and swelling. Inflammation may occur in the portion of the nerve within the globe (neuropapillitis or anterior optic neuritis) or the portion behind the globe (retrobulbar neuritis or posterior optic neuritis).

column1: C11.640.576.695*D009471*Neuromyelitis Optica*A syndrome characterized by acute OPTIC NEURITIS; MYELITIS
column2: TRANSVERSE; demyelinating and/or necrotizing lesions in the OPTIC NERVES and SPINAL CORD; and presence of specific autoantibodies to AQUAPORIN 4.

column1: C11.640.643*D018917*Optic Neuropathy
column2: Ischemic*Ischemic injury to the OPTIC NERVE which usually affects the OPTIC DISK (optic neuropathy
column3: anterior ischemic) and less frequently the retrobulbar portion of the nerve (optic neuropathy
column4: posterior ischemic). The injury results from occlusion of arterial blood supply which may result from TEMPORAL ARTERITIS; ATHEROSCLEROSIS; COLLAGEN DISEASES; EMBOLISM; DIABETES MELLITUS; and other conditions. The disease primarily occurs in the sixth decade or later and presents with the sudden onset of painless and usually severe monocular visual loss. Anterior ischemic optic neuropathy also features optic disk edema with microhemorrhages. The optic disk appears normal in posterior ischemic optic neuropathy. (Glaser

column1: C11.640.710*D010211*Papilledema*Swelling of the OPTIC DISK

column7: and engorgement of retinal veins. Chronic papilledema may cause OPTIC ATROPHY and visual loss. (Miller et al.

column1: C11.675*D009916*Orbital Diseases*Diseases of the bony orbit and contents except the eyeball.

C11.675.349*D005094*Exophthalmos*Abnormal protrusion of both eyes; may be caused by endocrine gland malfunction
column2: malignancy
column4: or paralysis of the extrinsic muscles of the eye.

column1: C11.675.349.500*D006111*Graves Disease*A common form of hyperthyroidism with a diffuse hyperplastic GOITER. It is an autoimmune disorder that produces antibodies against the THYROID STIMULATING HORMONE RECEPTOR. These autoantibodies activate the TSH receptor
column2: thereby stimulating the THYROID GLAND and hypersecretion of THYROID HORMONES. These autoantibodies can also affect the eyes (GRAVES OPHTHALMOPATHY) and the skin (Graves dermopathy).

column1: C11.675.349.500.500*D049970*Graves Ophthalmopathy*An autoimmune disorder of the EYE
column2: occurring in patients with Graves disease. Subtypes include congestive (inflammation of the orbital connective tissue)
column3: myopathic (swelling and dysfunction of the extraocular muscles)

column1: C11.675.387*D054517*Orbital Cellulitis*Inflammation of the loose connective tissues around the ORBIT
column2: bony structure around the eyeball. It is characterized by PAIN; EDEMA of the CONJUNCTIVA; swelling of the EYELIDS; EXOPHTHALMOS; limited eye movement; and loss of vision.

column1: C11.675.426*D055622*Orbital Myositis*Inflammation of the extraocular muscle of the eye. It is characterized by swelling which can lead to ischemia
column2: fibrosis

column1: C11.675.659*D009918*Orbital Neoplasms*Neoplasms of the bony orbit and contents except the eyeball.

C11.675.679*D016727*Orbital Pseudotumor*A nonspecific tumor-like inflammatory lesion in the ORBIT of the eye. It is usually composed of mature LYMPHOCYTES; PLASMA CELLS; MACROPHAGES; LEUKOCYTES with varying degrees of FIBROSIS. Orbital pseudotumors are often associated with inflammation of the extraocular muscles (ORBITAL MYOSITIS) or inflammation of the lacrimal glands (DACRYOADENITIS).

C11.675.689*D059369*Pott Puffy Tumor*Infection of the FRONTAL BONE often as a complication of FRONTAL SINUSITIS or trauma to the frontal bone and skull. It is characterized by subperiosteal abscess with OSTEOMYELITIS.
C11.675.700*D019315*Retrobulbar Hemorrhage*Hemorrhage within the orbital cavity
column2: posterior to the eyeball.

column1: C11.710*D011681*Pupil Disorders*Conditions which affect the structure or function of the pupil of the eye
column2: including disorders of innervation to the pupillary constrictor or dilator muscles

column1: C11.710.090*D015875*Anisocoria*Unequal pupil size
column2: which may represent a benign physiologic variant or a manifestation of disease. Pathologic anisocoria reflects an abnormality in the musculature of the iris (IRIS DISEASES) or in the parasympathetic or sympathetic pathways that innervate the pupil. Physiologic anisocoria refers to an asymmetry of pupil diameter
column4: that is not associated with disease.

column1: C11.710.528*D015877*Miosis*Pupillary constriction. This may result from congenital absence of the dilatator pupillary muscle
column2: defective sympathetic innervation
column3: or irritation of the CONJUNCTIVA or CORNEA.

column1: C11.710.528.500*D006732*Horner Syndrome*A syndrome associated with defective sympathetic innervation to one side of the face
column2: including the eye. Clinical features include MIOSIS; mild BLEPHAROPTOSIS; and hemifacial ANHIDROSIS (decreased sweating)(see HYPOHIDROSIS). Lesions of the BRAIN STEM; cervical SPINAL CORD; first thoracic nerve root; apex of the LUNG; CAROTID ARTERY; CAVERNOUS SINUS; and apex of the ORBIT may cause this condition. (From Miller et al.

column1: C11.710.570*D015878*Mydriasis*Dilation of pupils to greater than 6 mm combined with failure of the pupils to constrict when stimulated with light. This condition may occur due to injury of the pupillary fibers in the oculomotor nerve
column2: in acute angle-closure glaucoma

column1: C11.710.800*D015845*Tonic Pupil*A pupillary abnormality characterized by a poor pupillary light reaction
column2: reduced accommodation
column4: an enhanced pupillary response to near effort that results in a prolonged
column6: and slow pupillary redilation. This condition is associated with injury to the postganglionic parasympathetic innervation to the pupil. (From Miller et al.

column1: C11.710.800.180*D000270*Adie Syndrome*A syndrome characterized by a TONIC PUPIL that occurs in combination with decreased lower extremity reflexes. The affected pupil will respond more briskly to accommodation than to light (light-near dissociation) and is supersensitive to dilute pilocarpine eye drops
column2: which induce pupillary constriction. Pathologic features include degeneration of the ciliary ganglion and postganglionic parasympathetic fibers that innervate the pupillary constrictor muscle. (From Adams et al.

column1: C11.744*D012030*Refractive Errors*Deviations from the average or standard indices of refraction of the eye through its dioptric or refractive apparatus.
C11.744.116*D000839*Aniseikonia*A condition in which the ocular image of an object as seen by one eye differs in size and shape from that seen by the other.
C11.744.126*D015858*Anisometropia*A condition of an inequality of refractive power of the two eyes.

C11.744.212*D001251*Astigmatism*Unequal curvature of the refractive surfaces of the eye. Thus a point source of light cannot be brought to a point focus on the retina but is spread over a more or less diffuse area. This results from the radius of curvature in one plane being longer or shorter than the radius at right angles to it. (Dorland
column2: 27th ed)

column1: C11.744.345*D057108*Corneal Wavefront Aberration*Asymmetries in the topography and refractive index of the corneal surface that affect visual acuity.
C11.744.479*D006956*Hyperopia*A refractive error in which rays of light entering the eye parallel to the optic axis are brought to a focus behind the retina
column2: as a result of the eyeball being too short from front to back. It is also called farsightedness because the near point is more distant than it is in emmetropia with an equal amplitude of accommodation. (Dorland

column1: C11.744.636*D009216*Myopia*A refractive error in which rays of light entering the EYE parallel to the optic axis are brought to a focus in front of the RETINA when accommodation (ACCOMMODATION
column2: OCULAR) is relaxed. This results from an overly curved CORNEA or from the eyeball being too long from front to back. It is also called nearsightedness.
Degenerative*Excessive axial myopia associated with complications (especially posterior staphyloma and CHOROIDAL NEOVASCULARIZATION) that can lead to BLINDNESS.

column1: C11.744.786*D011305*Presbyopia*The normal decreasing elasticity of the crystalline lens that leads to loss of accommodation.
C11.768*D012164*Retinal Diseases*Diseases involving the RETINA.
C11.768.094*D000793*Angioid Streaks*Small breaks in the elastin-filled tissue of the retina.
C11.768.175*D056833*Central Serous Chorioretinopathy*A visual impairment characterized by the accumulation of fluid under the retina through a defect in the retinal pigment epithelium.
C11.768.257*D003930*Diabetic Retinopathy*Disease of the RETINA as a complication of DIABETES MELLITUS. It is characterized by the progressive microvascular complications

column1: C11.768.328*D019773*Epiretinal Membrane*A membrane on the vitreal surface of the retina resulting from the proliferation of one or more of three retinal elements: (1) fibrous astrocytes; (2) fibrocytes; and (3) retinal pigment epithelial cells. Localized epiretinal membranes may occur at the posterior pole of the eye without clinical signs or may cause marked loss of vision as a result of covering
column2: distorting
column3: or detaching the fovea centralis. Epiretinal membranes may cause vascular leakage and secondary retinal edema. In younger individuals some membranes appear to be developmental in origin and occur in otherwise normal eyes. The majority occur in association with retinal holes

column1: C11.768.346*D058437*Hypertensive Retinopathy*Degenerative changes to the RETINA due to HYPERTENSION.

C11.768.364*D057130*Leber Congenital Amaurosis*A rare degenerative inherited eye disease that appears at birth or in the first few months of life that results in a loss of vision. Not to be confused with LEBER HEREDITARY OPTIC NEUROPATHY
column2: the disease is thought to be caused by abnormal development of PHOTORECEPTOR CELLS in the RETINA
column3: or by the extremely premature degeneration of retinal cells.

column1: C11.768.400*D015356*Retinal Artery Occlusion*Sudden ISCHEMIA in the RETINA due to blocked blood flow through the CENTRAL RETINAL ARTERY or its branches leading to sudden complete or partial loss of vision
column2: respectively

column1: C11.768.400.500*D055955*Susac Syndrome*A rare disorder consisting of microangiopathy of brain

column1: C11.768.585.439*D008268*Macular Degeneration*Degenerative changes in the RETINA usually of older adults which results in a loss of vision in the center of the visual field (the MACULA LUTEA) because of damage to the retina. It occurs in dry and wet forms.

C11.768.585.439.122*D057092*Geographic Atrophy*A form of MACULAR DEGENERATION also known as dry macular degeneration marked by occurrence of a well-defined progressive lesion or atrophy in the central part of the RETINA called the MACULA LUTEA. C11.768.585.439.245*D008269*Macular Edema*Fluid accumulation in the outer layer of the MACULA LUTEA that results from intraocular or systemic insults. Although macular edema may be associated with various underlying conditions

column5: and posterior segment inflammatory disease. (From Survey of Ophthalmology 2004; 49(5) 470-90)

column1: C11.768.585.439.433*D057826*Vitelliform Macular Dystrophy*Autosomal dominant hereditary maculopathy with childhood-onset accumulation of LIPOFUSION in RETINAL PIGMENT EPITHELIUM. Affected individuals develop progressive central acuity loss
column2: and distorted vision (METAMORPHOPSIA). It is associated with mutations in bestrophin

column1: C11.768.585.439.622*D057135*Wet Macular Degeneration*A form of RETINAL DEGENERATION in which abnormal CHOROIDAL NEOVASCULARIZATION occurs under the RETINA and MACULA LUTEA

column1: C11.768.585.585*D015593*Retinal Drusen*Colloid or hyaline bodies lying beneath the retinal pigment epithelium. They may occur either secondary to changes in the choroid that affect the pigment epithelium or as an autosomal dominant disorder of the retinal pigment epithelium.
C11.768.585.658*D058499*Retinal Dystrophies*A group of disorders involving predominantly the posterior portion of the ocular fundus

column1: C11.768.585.658.250*D000071700*Cone-Rod Dystrophies*Genetically heterogeneous and sometimes syndromic (e.g.
column2: BARDET BIEDL SYNDROME; and SPINOCEREBELLAR ATAXIA TYPE 7) retinopathies with initial RETINAL CONE involvement. They are characterized by decreased VISUAL ACUITY; COLOR VISION DEFECTS; progressive loss of peripheral vision and night blindness.

column1: C11.768.585.658.500*D012174*Retinitis Pigmentosa*Hereditary
column2: progressive degeneration of the retina due to death of ROD PHOTORECEPTORS initially and subsequent death of CONE PHOTORECEPTORS. It is characterized by deposition of pigment in the retina.

column1: C11.768.585.658.500.627*D007625*Kearns-Sayre Syndrome*A mitochondrial disorder featuring the triad of chronic progressive EXTERNAL OPHTHALMOPLEGIA

column1: C11.768.585.658.500.813*D052245*Usher Syndromes*Autosomal recessive hereditary disorders characterized by congenital SENSORINEURAL HEARING LOSS and RETINITIS PIGMENTOSA. Genetically and symptomatically heterogeneous

column5: age of onset of retinitis pigmentosa and the degree of vestibular dysfunction are variable.

column1: C11.768.585.865*D041441*Retinoschisis*A vitreoretinal dystrophy characterized by splitting of the neuroretinal layers. It occurs in two forms: degenerative retinoschisis and X chromosome-linked juvenile retinoschisis.
C11.768.648*D012163*Retinal Detachment*Separation of the inner layers of the retina (neural retina) from the pigment epithelium. Retinal detachment occurs more commonly in men than in women

column3: retinal abnormality characterized by the arrangement of outer nuclear retinal cells in a palisading or radiating pattern surrounding a central ocular space. This disorder is sometimes hereditary.

column1: C11.768.710*D012166*Retinal Hemorrhage*Bleeding from the vessels of the retina.

C11.768.717.760*D012175*Retinoblastoma*A malignant tumor arising from the nuclear layer of the retina that is the most common primary tumor of the eye in children. The tumor tends to occur in early childhood or infancy and may be present at birth. The majority are sporadic
column2: but the condition may be transmitted as an autosomal dominant trait. Histologic features include dense cellularity
column4: and areas of calcification and necrosis. An abnormal pupil reflex (leukokoria); NYSTAGMUS
column5: PATHOLOGIC; STRABISMUS; and visual loss represent common clinical characteristics of this condition. (From DeVita et al.

column1: C11.768.725*D015861*Retinal Neovascularization*Formation of new blood vessels originating from the retinal veins and extending along the inner (vitreal) surface of the retina.

column1: C11.768.760*D012170*Retinal Vein Occlusion*Blockage of the RETINAL VEIN. Those at high risk for this condition include patients with HYPERTENSION; DIABETES MELLITUS; ATHEROSCLEROSIS; and other CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES.
C11.768.773*D012173*Retinitis*Inflammation of the RETINA. It is rarely limited to the retina

column1: C11.768.773.348*D002825*Chorioretinitis*Inflammation of the choroid in which the sensory retina becomes edematous and opaque. The inflammatory cells and exudate may burst through the sensory retina to cloud the vitreous body.

column4: and retinal edema. Cytomegalovirus retinitis is a major opportunistic infection in AIDS patients and can cause blindness.

column1: C11.768.773.674*D015882*Retinal Necrosis Syndrome
column2: Acute*Mild to fulminant necrotizing vaso-occlusive retinitis associated with a high incidence of retinal detachment and poor vision outcome.

column1: C11.768.890*D018630*Vitreoretinopathy

column1: C11.790*D015422*Scleral Diseases*General disorders of the sclera or white of the eye. They may include anatomic

column1: C11.790.500*D015423*Scleritis*Refers to any inflammation of the sclera including episcleritis

column6: particularly in necrotizing form. Its characteristic symptom is severe and general head pain. Scleritis has also been associated with systemic collagen disease. Etiology is unknown but is thought to involve a local immune response. Treatment is difficult and includes administration of anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive agents such as corticosteroids. Inflammation of the sclera may also be secondary to inflammation of adjacent tissues

column1: C11.941*D014603*Uveal Diseases*Diseases of the uvea.

column1: C11.941.160.177*D002832*Choroid Hemorrhage*Hemorrhage from the vessels of the choroid.

C11.941.160.238*D002830*Choroid Neoplasms*Tumors of the choroid; most common intraocular tumors are malignant melanomas of the choroid. These usually occur after puberty and increase in incidence with advancing age. Most malignant melanomas of the uveal tract develop from benign melanomas (nevi).
C11.941.160.244*D020256*Choroidal Neovascularization*A pathological process consisting of the formation of new blood vessels in the CHOROID.

C11.941.160.478.700*D015868*Pars Planitis*Form of granulomatous uveitis occurring in the region of the pars plana. This disorder is a common condition with no detectable focal pathology. It causes fibrovascular proliferation at the inferior ora serrata.

C12.777.419.570*D009393*Nephritis*Inflammation of any part of the KIDNEY.
C12.777.419.570.363*D005921*Glomerulonephritis*Inflammation of the renal glomeruli (KIDNEY GLOMERULUS) that can be classified by the type of glomerular injuries including antibody deposition

column4: and glomerulosclerosis. These structural and functional abnormalities usually lead to HEMATURIA; PROTEINURIA; HYPERTENSION; and RENAL INSUFFICIENCY.

column1: C12.777.419.570.363.304*D019867*Anti-Glomerular Basement Membrane Disease*An autoimmune disease of the KIDNEY and the LUNG. column1: C12.777.419.570.363.608*D005922*Glomerulonephritis

column1: C12.777.419.570.363.615*D015432*Glomerulonephritis

column1: C12.777.419.570.363.625*D015433*Glomerulonephritis
column2: Membranous*A type of glomerulonephritis that is characterized by the accumulation of immune deposits (COMPLEMENT MEMBRANE ATTACK COMPLEX) on the outer aspect of the GLOMERULAR BASEMENT MEMBRANE. It progresses from subepithelial dense deposits

column1: C12.777.419.570.363.660*D005923*Glomerulosclerosis
