column3: primary or secondary. Clinical features include PROTEINURIA
column5: and EDEMA. Kidney biopsy initially indicates focal segmental glomerular consolidation (hyalinosis) or scarring which can progress to globally sclerotic glomeruli leading to eventual KIDNEY FAILURE.

column1: C12.777.419.570.363.680*D008181*Lupus Nephritis*Glomerulonephritis associated with autoimmune disease SYSTEMIC LUPUS ERYTHEMATOSUS. Lupus nephritis is histologically classified into 6 classes: class I - normal glomeruli
column2: class II - pure mesangial alterations
column6: and class VI - advanced sclerosing glomerulonephritis (The World Health Organization classification 1982).

column2: Hereditary*A group of inherited conditions characterized initially by HEMATURIA and slowly progressing to RENAL INSUFFICIENCY. The most common form is the Alport syndrome (hereditary nephritis with HEARING LOSS) which is caused by mutations in genes for TYPE IV COLLAGEN and defective GLOMERULAR BASEMENT MEMBRANE.

Interstitial*Inflammation of the interstitial tissue of the kidney. This term is generally used for primary inflammation of KIDNEY TUBULES and/or surrounding interstitium. For primary inflammation of glomerular interstitium
column3: see GLOMERULONEPHRITIS. Infiltration of the inflammatory cells into the interstitial compartment results in EDEMA

column1: C12.777.419.570.643.150*D001449*Balkan Nephropathy*A form of chronic interstitial nephritis that is endemic to limited areas of BULGARIA
column2: the former YUGOSLAVIA
column3: and ROMANIA. It is characterized by a progressive shrinking of the KIDNEYS that is often associated with uroepithelial tumors.

column1: C12.777.419.570.643.790*D011704*Pyelonephritis*Inflammation of the KIDNEY involving the renal parenchyma (the NEPHRONS); KIDNEY PELVIS; and KIDNEY CALICES. It is characterized by ABDOMINAL PAIN; FEVER; NAUSEA; VOMITING; and occasionally DIARRHEA.

column2: Xanthogranulomatous*A chronic inflammatory condition of the KIDNEY resulting in diffuse renal destruction
column3: a grossly enlarged and nonfunctioning kidney associated with NEPHROLITHIASIS and KIDNEY STONES.

column1: C12.777.419.570.821*D011702*Pyelitis*Inflammation of the KIDNEY PELVIS and KIDNEY CALICES where urine is collected before discharge
column2: but does not involve the renal parenchyma (the NEPHRONS) where urine is processed.

column1: C12.777.419.570.821.358*D053653*Pyelocystitis*Inflammation of the KIDNEY PELVIS and the URINARY BLADDER.

C12.777.419.570.821.717*D011704*Pyelonephritis*Inflammation of the KIDNEY involving the renal parenchyma (the NEPHRONS); KIDNEY PELVIS; and KIDNEY CALICES. It is characterized by ABDOMINAL PAIN; FEVER; NAUSEA; VOMITING; and occasionally DIARRHEA.

column2: Xanthogranulomatous*A chronic inflammatory condition of the KIDNEY resulting in diffuse renal destruction
column3: a grossly enlarged and nonfunctioning kidney associated with NEPHROLITHIASIS and KIDNEY STONES.

column1: C12.777.419.590*D009397*Nephrocalcinosis*A condition characterized by calcification of the renal tissue itself. It is usually seen in distal RENAL TUBULAR ACIDOSIS with calcium deposition in the DISTAL KIDNEY TUBULES and the surrounding interstitium. Nephrocalcinosis causes RENAL INSUFFICIENCY.
C12.777.419.600*D053040*Nephrolithiasis*Formation of stones in the KIDNEY.
C12.777.419.600.500*D007669*Kidney Calculi*Stones in the KIDNEY
column2: usually formed in the urine-collecting area of the kidney (KIDNEY PELVIS). Their sizes vary and most contains CALCIUM OXALATE.

column1: C12.777.419.600.500.500*D000069856*Staghorn Calculi*Renal calculi with a characteristic shape like antlers of a deer
column2: formed as it extends into multiple calices of the RENAL PELVIS. A large number of staghorn calculi as well as other URINARY CALCULI are composed of STRUVITE.

column1: C12.777.419.610*D009400*Nephrosclerosis*Hardening of the KIDNEY due to infiltration by fibrous connective tissue (FIBROSIS)
column2: usually caused by renovascular diseases or chronic HYPERTENSION. Nephrosclerosis leads to renal ISCHEMIA.

column1: C12.777.419.630*D009401*Nephrosis*Pathological processes of the KIDNEY without inflammatory or neoplastic components. Nephrosis may be a primary disorder or secondary complication of other diseases. It is characterized by the NEPHROTIC SYNDROME indicating the presence of PROTEINURIA and HYPOALBUMINEMIA with accompanying EDEMA.

column2: Lipoid*A kidney disease with no or minimal histological glomerular changes on light microscopy and with no immune deposits. It is characterized by lipid accumulation in the epithelial cells of KIDNEY TUBULES and in the URINE. Patients usually show NEPHROTIC SYNDROME indicating the presence of PROTEINURIA with accompanying EDEMA.

column1: C12.777.419.630.643*D009404*Nephrotic Syndrome*A condition characterized by severe PROTEINURIA
column2: greater than 3.5 g/day in an average adult. The substantial loss of protein in the urine results in complications such as HYPOPROTEINEMIA; generalized EDEMA; HYPERTENSION; and HYPERLIPIDEMIAS. Diseases associated with nephrotic syndrome generally cause chronic kidney dysfunction.

column1: C12.777.419.685*D010501*Perinephritis*Inflammation of the connective and adipose tissues surrounding the KIDNEY.
C12.777.419.775*D012078*Renal Artery Obstruction*Narrowing or occlusion of the RENAL ARTERY or arteries. It is due usually to ATHEROSCLEROSIS; FIBROMUSCULAR DYSPLASIA; THROMBOSIS; EMBOLISM
column2: or external pressure. The reduced renal perfusion can lead to renovascular hypertension (HYPERTENSION

column1: C12.777.419.780*D051437*Renal Insufficiency*Conditions in which the KIDNEYS perform below the normal level in the ability to remove wastes
column2: concentrate URINE
column3: and maintain ELECTROLYTE BALANCE; BLOOD PRESSURE; and CALCIUM metabolism. Renal insufficiency can be classified by the degree of kidney damage (as measured by the level of PROTEINURIA) and reduction in GLOMERULAR FILTRATION RATE.

column1: C12.777.419.780.050*D058186*Acute Kidney Injury*Abrupt reduction in kidney function. Acute kidney injury encompasses the entire spectrum of the syndrome including acute kidney failure; ACUTE KIDNEY TUBULAR NECROSIS; and other less severe conditions.
C12.777.419.780.050.500*D007683*Kidney Tubular Necrosis
column2: Acute*Acute kidney failure resulting from destruction of EPITHELIAL CELLS of the KIDNEY TUBULES. It is commonly attributed to exposure to toxic agents or renal ISCHEMIA following severe TRAUMA.

column1: C12.777.419.780.400*D059347*Cardio-Renal Syndrome*Condition where a primary dysfunction of either heart or kidney results in failure of the other organ (e.g.
column2: HEART FAILURE with worsening RENAL INSUFFICIENCY).

column1: C12.777.419.780.750*D051436*Renal Insufficiency
column2: Chronic*Conditions in which the KIDNEYS perform below the normal level for more than three months. Chronic kidney insufficiency is classified by five stages according to the decline in GLOMERULAR FILTRATION RATE and the degree of kidney damage (as measured by the level of PROTEINURIA). The most severe form is the end-stage renal disease (CHRONIC KIDNEY FAILURE). (Kidney Foundation: Kidney Disease Outcome Quality Initiative

Chronic*The end-stage of CHRONIC RENAL INSUFFICIENCY. It is characterized by the severe irreversible kidney damage (as measured by the level of PROTEINURIA) and the reduction in GLOMERULAR FILTRATION RATE to less than 15 ml per min (Kidney Foundation: Kidney Disease Outcome Quality Initiative
column3: 2002). These patients generally require HEMODIALYSIS or KIDNEY TRANSPLANTATION.

column1: C12.777.419.780.750.500.500*D052159*Frasier Syndrome*A syndrome characterized by CHRONIC KIDNEY FAILURE and GONADAL DYSGENESIS in phenotypic females with karyotype of 46
column2: XY or female individual with a normal 46
column3: XX karyotype. It is caused by donor splice-site mutations of Wilms tumor suppressor gene (GENES

column1: C12.777.419.787*D059228*Renal Nutcracker Syndrome*Left RENAL VEIN compression between the AORTA
column2: ABDOMINAL and the SUPERIOR MESENTERIC ARTERY. Variable symptoms include HYPERTENSION

column1: C12.777.419.795*D012080*Chronic Kidney Disease-Mineral and Bone Disorder*Decalcification of bone or abnormal bone development due to chronic KIDNEY DISEASES
column2: in which 1
column3: 25-DIHYDROXYVITAMIN D3 synthesis by the kidneys is impaired
column4: leading to reduced negative feedback on PARATHYROID HORMONE. The resulting SECONDARY HYPERPARATHYROIDISM eventually leads to bone disorders.

column1: C12.777.419.815*D015499*Renal Tubular Transport
column2: Inborn Errors*Genetic defects in the selective or non-selective transport functions of the KIDNEY TUBULES.
Renal Tubular*A group of genetic disorders of the KIDNEY TUBULES characterized by the accumulation of metabolically produced acids with elevated plasma chloride
column3: hyperchloremic metabolic ACIDOSIS. Defective renal acidification of URINE (proximal tubules) or low renal acid excretion (distal tubules) can lead to complications such as HYPOKALEMIA

column1: C12.777.419.815.279*D001477*Bartter Syndrome*A group of disorders caused by defective salt reabsorption in the ascending LOOP OF HENLE. It is characterized by severe salt-wasting
column2: HYPOKALEMIA; HYPERCALCIURIA; metabolic ALKALOSIS
column3: and hyper-reninemic HYPERALDOSTERONISM without HYPERTENSION. There are several subtypes including ones due to mutations in the renal specific SODIUM-POTASSIUM-CHLORIDE SYMPORTERS.

column1: C12.777.419.815.364*D057973*Dent Disease*X-linked recessive NEPHROLITHIASIS characterized by HYPERCALCIURIA; HYPOPHOSPHATEMIA; NEPHROCALCINOSIS; and PROTEINURIA. It is associated with mutations in the voltage-gated chloride channel
column2: CLC-5 (Dent Disease I). Another group of mutations associated with this disease is in phosphatidylinositol 4

column1: C12.777.419.815.450*D005198*Fanconi Syndrome*A hereditary or acquired form of generalized dysfunction of the PROXIMAL KIDNEY TUBULE without primary involvement of the KIDNEY GLOMERULUS. It is usually characterized by the tubular wasting of nutrients and salts (GLUCOSE; AMINO ACIDS; PHOSPHATES; and BICARBONATES) resulting in HYPOKALEMIA; ACIDOSIS; HYPERCALCIURIA; and PROTEINURIA.

C12.777.419.815.491*D053579*Gitelman Syndrome*An inherited renal disorder characterized by defective NaCl reabsorption in the convoluted DISTAL KIDNEY TUBULE leading to HYPOKALEMIA. In contrast with BARTTER SYNDROME
column2: Gitelman syndrome includes hypomagnesemia and normocalcemic hypocalciuria
column3: and is caused by mutations in the thiazide-sensitive SODIUM-POTASSIUM-CHLORIDE SYMPORTERS.

column2: Renal*An autosomal inherited disorder due to defective reabsorption of GLUCOSE by the PROXIMAL RENAL TUBULES. The urinary loss of glucose can reach beyond 50 g/day. It is attributed to the mutations in the SODIUM-GLUCOSE TRANSPORTER 2 encoded by the SLC5A2 gene.

column1: C12.777.419.815.647*D007015*Hypophosphatemia
column2: Familial*An inherited condition of abnormally low serum levels of PHOSPHATES (below 1 mg/liter) which can occur in a number of genetic diseases with defective reabsorption of inorganic phosphorus by the PROXIMAL RENAL TUBULES. This leads to phosphaturia
column4: and disturbances of cellular and organ functions such as those in X-LINKED HYPOPHOSPHATEMIC RICKETS; OSTEOMALACIA; and FANCONI SYNDROME.

column1: C12.777.419.815.647.500*D053098*Familial Hypophosphatemic Rickets*A hereditary disorder characterized by HYPOPHOSPHATEMIA; RICKETS; OSTEOMALACIA; renal defects in phosphate reabsorption and vitamin D metabolism; and growth retardation. Autosomal and X-linked dominant and recessive variants have been reported.

C12.777.419.815.683*D056929*Liddle Syndrome*Familial pseudoaldosteronism characterized by autosomal dominant inheritance of hypertension with HYPOKALEMIA; ALKALOSIS; RENIN and ALDOSTERONE level decreases. It is caused by mutations in EPITHELIAL SODIUM CHANNELS beta and gamma subunits. Different mutations in the same EPITHELIAL SODIUM CHANNELS subunits can cause PSEUDOHYPOALDOSTERONISM
column2: TYPE I

column1: C12.777.419.815.720*D009800*Oculocerebrorenal Syndrome*A sex-linked recessive disorder affecting multiple systems including the EYE
column2: the NERVOUS SYSTEM
column3: and the KIDNEY. Clinical features include congenital CATARACT; MENTAL RETARDATION; and renal tubular dysfunction (FANCONI SYNDROME; RENAL TUBULAR ACIDOSIS; X-LINKED HYPOPHOSPHATEMIA or vitamin-D-resistant rickets) and SCOLIOSIS. This condition is due to a deficiency of phosphatidylinositol 4
column4: 5-bisphosphate-5-phosphatase leading to defects in PHOSPHATIDYLINOSITOL metabolism and INOSITOL signaling pathway. (from Menkes
column7: p60; Am J Hum Genet 1997 Jun;60(6):1384-8)

column1: C12.777.419.815.770*D011546*Pseudohypoaldosteronism*A heterogeneous group of disorders characterized by renal electrolyte transport dysfunctions. Congenital forms are rare autosomal disorders characterized by neonatal hypertension
column2: HYPERKALEMIA
column3: increased RENIN activity and ALDOSTERONE concentration. The Type I features HYPERKALEMIA with sodium wasting; Type II
column4: HYPERKALEMIA without sodium wasting. Pseudohypoaldosteronism can be the result of a defective renal electrolyte transport protein or acquired after KIDNEY TRANSPLANTATION.

column1: C12.777.419.815.885*D000608*Renal Aminoacidurias*A group of inherited kidney disorders characterized by the abnormally elevated levels of AMINO ACIDS in URINE. Genetic mutations of transport proteins result in the defective reabsorption of free amino acids at the PROXIMAL RENAL TUBULES. Renal aminoaciduria are classified by the specific amino acid or acids involved.

C12.777.419.815.885.250*D003555*Cystinuria*An inherited disorder due to defective reabsorption of CYSTINE and other BASIC AMINO ACIDS by the PROXIMAL RENAL TUBULES. This form of aminoaciduria is characterized by the abnormally high urinary levels of cystine; LYSINE; ARGININE; and ORNITHINE. Mutations involve the amino acid transport protein gene SLC3A1.

C12.777.419.815.885.457*D006250*Hartnup Disease*An autosomal recessive disorder due to defective absorption of NEUTRAL AMINO ACIDS by both the intestine and the PROXIMAL RENAL TUBULES. The abnormal urinary loss of TRYPTOPHAN
column2: a precursor of NIACIN
column7: and aminoaciduria. Mutations involve the neurotransmitter transporter gene SLC6A19.

column2: Renal*Infection of the KIDNEY with species of MYCOBACTERIUM.

column1: C12.777.419.936*D014511*Uremia*A clinical syndrome associated with the retention of renal waste products or uremic toxins in the blood. It is usually the result of RENAL INSUFFICIENCY. Most uremic toxins are end products of protein or nitrogen CATABOLISM
column2: such as UREA or CREATININE. Severe uremia can lead to multiple organ dysfunctions with a constellation of symptoms.

column1: C12.777.419.936.231*D053099*Azotemia*A biochemical abnormality referring to an elevation of BLOOD UREA NITROGEN and CREATININE. Azotemia can be produced by KIDNEY DISEASES or other extrarenal disorders. When azotemia becomes associated with a constellation of clinical signs
column2: it is termed UREMIA.

column1: C12.777.419.936.463*D006463*Hemolytic-Uremic Syndrome*A syndrome that is associated with microvascular diseases of the KIDNEY
column2: such as RENAL CORTICAL NECROSIS. It is characterized by hemolytic anemia (ANEMIA
column3: HEMOLYTIC); THROMBOCYTOPENIA; and ACUTE RENAL FAILURE.

column1: C12.777.419.936.463.500*D065766*Atypical Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome*An hereditary hemolytic uremic syndrome associated with variations in the gene that encodes COMPLEMENT FACTOR H
column2: or the related proteins CFHR1 and CFHR3. Disease often progresses to CHRONIC KIDNEY FAILURE without the prodromal symptoms of ENTEROCOLITIS and DIARRHEA that characterize typical hemolytic uremic syndrome.

column1: C12.777.419.978*D015211*Zellweger Syndrome*An autosomal recessive disorder due to defects in PEROXISOME biogenesis which involves more than 13 genes encoding peroxin proteins of the peroxisomal membrane and matrix. Zellweger syndrome is typically seen in the neonatal period with features such as dysmorphic skull; MUSCLE HYPOTONIA; SENSORINEURAL HEARING LOSS; visual compromise; SEIZURES; progressive degeneration of the KIDNEYS and the LIVER. Zellweger-like syndrome refers to phenotypes resembling the neonatal Zellweger syndrome but seen in children or adults with apparently intact peroxisome biogenesis.
C12.777.725*D014515*Ureteral Diseases*Pathological processes involving the URETERS.
C12.777.725.676*D014516*Ureteral Neoplasms*Cancer or tumors of the URETER which may cause obstruction leading to hydroureter
column2: HYDRONEPHROSIS
column3: and PYELONEPHRITIS. HEMATURIA is a common symptom.

column1: C12.777.725.776*D014517*Ureteral Obstruction*Blockage in any part of the URETER causing obstruction of urine flow from the kidney to the URINARY BLADDER. The obstruction may be congenital
column2: acquired
column8: or chronic. Depending on the degree and duration of the obstruction
column9: clinical features vary greatly such as HYDRONEPHROSIS and obstructive nephropathy.

column1: C12.777.725.876*D014518*Ureterocele*A cystic dilatation of the end of a URETER as it enters into the URINARY BLADDER. It is characterized by the ballooning of the ureteral orifice into the lumen of the bladder and may obstruct urine flow.
C12.777.725.938*D053039*Ureterolithiasis*Formation of stones in the URETER.

C12.777.725.938.500*D014514*Ureteral Calculi*Stones in the URETER that are formed in the KIDNEY. They are rarely more than 5 mm in diameter for larger renal stones cannot enter ureters. They are often lodged at the ureteral narrowing and can cause excruciating renal colic.
C12.777.767*D014522*Urethral Diseases*Pathological processes involving the URETHRA.
C12.777.767.374*D004842*Epispadias*A birth defect due to malformation of the URETHRA in which the urethral opening is above its normal location. In the male
column2: the malformed urethra generally opens on the top or the side of the PENIS
column3: but the urethra can also be open the entire length of the penis. In the female
column4: the malformed urethral opening is often between the CLITORIS and the labia

column1: C12.777.767.601*D014523*Urethral Neoplasms*Cancer or tumors of the URETHRA. Benign epithelial tumors of the urethra usually consist of squamous and transitional cells. Primary urethral carcinomas are rare and typically of squamous cells. Urethral carcinoma is the only urological malignancy that is more common in females than in males.

C12.777.767.700*D014524*Urethral Obstruction*Partial or complete blockage in any part of the URETHRA that can lead to difficulty or inability to empty the URINARY BLADDER. It is characterized by an enlarged
column2: often damaged
column3: bladder with frequent urges to void.

column1: C12.777.767.700.700*D014525*Urethral Stricture*Narrowing of any part of the URETHRA. It is characterized by decreased urinary stream and often other obstructive voiding symptoms.
C12.777.767.700.962*D001748*Urinary Bladder Neck Obstruction*Blocked urine flow through the bladder neck
column2: the narrow internal urethral opening at the base of the URINARY BLADDER. Narrowing or strictures of the URETHRA can be congenital or acquired. It is often observed in males with enlarged PROSTATE glands.

column1: C12.777.767.851*D014526*Urethritis*Inflammation involving the URETHRA. Similar to CYSTITIS
column2: clinical symptoms range from vague discomfort to painful urination (DYSURIA)

column1: C12.777.829*D001745*Urinary Bladder Diseases*Pathological processes of the URINARY BLADDER.
C12.777.829.132*D001746*Bladder Exstrophy*A birth defect in which the URINARY BLADDER is malformed and exposed
column2: inside out
column3: and protruded through the ABDOMINAL WALL. It is caused by closure defects involving the top front surface of the bladder
column4: as well as the lower abdominal wall; SKIN; MUSCLES; and the pubic bone.

column1: C12.777.829.495*D003556*Cystitis*Inflammation of the URINARY BLADDER
column2: either from bacterial or non-bacterial causes. Cystitis is usually associated with painful urination (dysuria)

Interstitial*A condition with recurring discomfort or pain in the URINARY BLADDER and the surrounding pelvic region without an identifiable disease. Severity of pain in interstitial cystitis varies greatly and often is accompanied by increased urination frequency and urgency.

column1: C12.777.829.495.750*D053653*Pyelocystitis*Inflammation of the KIDNEY PELVIS and the URINARY BLADDER.

C12.777.829.707*D052858*Cystocele*A HERNIA-like condition in which the weakened pelvic muscles cause the URINARY BLADDER to drop from its normal position. Fallen urinary bladder is more common in females with the bladder dropping into the VAGINA and less common in males with the bladder dropping into the SCROTUM.
C12.777.829.720*D001744*Urinary Bladder Calculi*Stones in the URINARY BLADDER; also known as vesical calculi
column2: bladder stones

column1: C12.777.829.733*D001747*Urinary Bladder Fistula*An abnormal passage in the URINARY BLADDER or between the bladder and any surrounding organ.
C12.777.829.760*D001748*Urinary Bladder Neck Obstruction*Blocked urine flow through the bladder neck
column2: the narrow internal urethral opening at the base of the URINARY BLADDER. Narrowing or strictures of the URETHRA can be congenital or acquired. It is often observed in males with enlarged PROSTATE glands.

column1: C12.777.829.813*D001749*Urinary Bladder Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the URINARY BLADDER.
C12.777.829.839*D001750*Urinary Bladder
column2: Neurogenic*Dysfunction of the URINARY BLADDER due to disease of the central or peripheral nervous system pathways involved in the control of URINATION. This is often associated with SPINAL CORD DISEASES
column3: but may also be caused by BRAIN DISEASES or PERIPHERAL NERVE DISEASES.

column1: C12.777.829.866*D053201*Urinary Bladder
column2: Overactive*Symptom of overactive detrusor muscle of the URINARY BLADDER that contracts with abnormally high frequency and urgency. Overactive bladder is characterized by the frequent feeling of needing to urinate during the day
column4: or both. URINARY INCONTINENCE may or may not be present.

column1: C12.777.829.920*D014718*Vesico-Ureteral Reflux*Retrograde flow of urine from the URINARY BLADDER into the URETER. This is often due to incompetence of the vesicoureteral valve leading to ascending bacterial infection into the KIDNEY.

C12.777.892*D014552*Urinary Tract Infections*Inflammatory responses of the epithelium of the URINARY TRACT to microbial invasions. They are often bacterial infections with associated BACTERIURIA and PYURIA.

C12.777.892.219*D001437*Bacteriuria*The presence of bacteria in the urine which is normally bacteria-free. These bacteria are from the URINARY TRACT and are not contaminants of the surrounding tissues. Bacteriuria can be symptomatic or asymptomatic. Significant bacteriuria is an indicator of urinary tract infection.

C12.777.892.719*D011776*Pyuria*The presence of white blood cells (LEUKOCYTES) in the urine. It is often associated with bacterial infections of the urinary tract. Pyuria without BACTERIURIA can be caused by TUBERCULOSIS
column2: stones

column1: C12.777.892.775*D012553*Schistosomiasis haematobia*A human disease caused by the infection of parasitic worms SCHISTOSOMA HAEMATOBIUM. It is endemic in AFRICA and parts of the MIDDLE EAST. Tissue damages most often occur in the URINARY TRACT
column2: specifically the URINARY BLADDER.

column1: C12.777.934*D014555*Urination Disorders*Abnormalities in the process of URINE voiding
column2: including bladder control
column4: as well as the volume and composition of URINE.

column1: C12.777.934.141*D001002*Anuria*Absence of urine formation. It is usually associated with complete bilateral ureteral (URETER) obstruction
column2: complete lower urinary tract obstruction
column3: or unilateral ureteral obstruction when a solitary kidney is present.

column1: C12.777.934.284*D004775*Enuresis*Involuntary discharge of URINE after expected age of completed development of urinary control. This can happen during the daytime (DIURNAL ENURESIS) while one is awake or during sleep (NOCTURNAL ENURESIS). Enuresis can be in children or in adults (as persistent primary enuresis and secondary adult-onset enuresis).
C12.777.934.284.249*D053207*Diurnal Enuresis*Involuntary discharge of URINE during the daytime while one is awake.
C12.777.934.284.500*D053206*Nocturnal Enuresis*Involuntary discharge of URINE during sleep at night after expected age of completed development of urinary control.
C12.777.934.363*D006029*Glycosuria*The appearance of an abnormally large amount of GLUCOSE in the urine
column2: such as more than 500 mg/day in adults. It can be due to HYPERGLYCEMIA or genetic defects in renal reabsorption (RENAL GLYCOSURIA).

Renal*An autosomal inherited disorder due to defective reabsorption of GLUCOSE by the PROXIMAL RENAL TUBULES. The urinary loss of glucose can reach beyond 50 g/day. It is attributed to the mutations in the SODIUM-GLUCOSE TRANSPORTER 2 encoded by the SLC5A2 gene.

column1: C12.777.934.442*D006417*Hematuria*Presence of blood in the urine.
C12.777.934.600*D009846*Oliguria*Decreased URINE output that is below the normal range. Oliguria can be defined as urine output of less than or equal to 0.5 or 1 ml/kg/hr depending on the age.
C12.777.934.616*D011141*Polyuria*Urination of a large volume of urine with an increase in urinary frequency
column2: commonly seen in diabetes (DIABETES MELLITUS; DIABETES INSIPIDUS).

column1: C12.777.934.734*D011507*Proteinuria*The presence of proteins in the urine
column2: an indicator of KIDNEY DISEASES.

column1: C12.777.934.734.269*D000419*Albuminuria*The presence of albumin in the urine
column2: an indicator of KIDNEY DISEASES.

column1: C12.777.934.734.634*D006456*Hemoglobinuria*The presence of free HEMOGLOBIN in the URINE
column2: indicating hemolysis of ERYTHROCYTES within the vascular system. After saturating the hemoglobin-binding proteins (HAPTOGLOBINS)
column3: free hemoglobin begins to appear in the urine.

column1: C12.777.934.852*D014549*Urinary Incontinence*Involuntary loss of URINE
column2: such as leaking of urine. It is a symptom of various underlying pathological processes. Major types of incontinence include URINARY URGE INCONTINENCE and URINARY STRESS INCONTINENCE.

column1: C12.777.934.852.249*D014550*Urinary Incontinence
column2: Stress*Involuntary discharge of URINE as a result of physical activities that increase abdominal pressure on the URINARY BLADDER without detrusor contraction or overdistended bladder. The subtypes are classified by the degree of leakage
column3: descent and opening of the bladder neck and URETHRA without bladder contraction

column1: C12.777.934.852.500*D053202*Urinary Incontinence
column2: Urge*Involuntary discharge of URINE that is associated with an abrupt and strong desire to void. It is usually related to the involuntary contractions of the detrusor muscle of the bladder (detrusor hyperreflexia or detrusor instability).

column1: C12.777.934.880*D016055*Urinary Retention*Inability to empty the URINARY BLADDER with voiding (URINATION).
C12.777.967*D052878*Urolithiasis*Formation of stones in any part of the URINARY TRACT
column2: usually in the KIDNEY; URINARY BLADDER; or the URETER.

column1: C12.777.967.249*D053040*Nephrolithiasis*Formation of stones in the KIDNEY.

column2: Endometrioid*An adenocarcinoma characterized by the presence of cells resembling the glandular cells of the ENDOMETRIUM.
