C13.351.968.419.570.363*D005921*Glomerulonephritis*Inflammation of the renal glomeruli (KIDNEY GLOMERULUS) that can be classified by the type of glomerular injuries including antibody deposition
column2: complement activation
column4: and glomerulosclerosis. These structural and functional abnormalities usually lead to HEMATURIA; PROTEINURIA; HYPERTENSION; and RENAL INSUFFICIENCY.

column1: C13.351.968.419.570.363.304*D019867*Anti-Glomerular Basement Membrane Disease*An autoimmune disease of the KIDNEY and the LUNG. It is characterized by the presence of circulating autoantibodies targeting the epitopes in the non-collagenous domains of COLLAGEN TYPE IV in the basement membranes of kidney glomeruli (KIDNEY GLOMERULUS) and lung alveoli (PULMONARY ALVEOLI)
column2: and the subsequent destruction of these basement membranes. Clinical features include pulmonary alveolar hemorrhage and glomerulonephritis.

IGA*A chronic form of glomerulonephritis characterized by deposits of predominantly IMMUNOGLOBULIN A in the mesangial area (GLOMERULAR MESANGIUM). Deposits of COMPLEMENT C3 and IMMUNOGLOBULIN G are also often found. Clinical features may progress from asymptomatic HEMATURIA to END-STAGE KIDNEY DISEASE.
Membranoproliferative*Chronic glomerulonephritis characterized histologically by proliferation of MESANGIAL CELLS
column3: increase in the MESANGIAL EXTRACELLULAR MATRIX
column4: and a thickening of the glomerular capillary walls. This may appear as a primary disorder or secondary to other diseases including infections and autoimmune disease SYSTEMIC LUPUS ERYTHEMATOSUS. Various subtypes are classified by their abnormal ultrastructures and immune deposits. Hypocomplementemia is a characteristic feature of all types of MPGN.

column2: Membranous*A type of glomerulonephritis that is characterized by the accumulation of immune deposits (COMPLEMENT MEMBRANE ATTACK COMPLEX) on the outer aspect of the GLOMERULAR BASEMENT MEMBRANE. It progresses from subepithelial dense deposits
column3: to basement membrane reaction and eventual thickening of the basement membrane.

column2: Focal Segmental*A clinicopathological syndrome or diagnostic term for a type of glomerular injury that has multiple causes
column3: primary or secondary. Clinical features include PROTEINURIA
column5: and EDEMA. Kidney biopsy initially indicates focal segmental glomerular consolidation (hyalinosis) or scarring which can progress to globally sclerotic glomeruli leading to eventual KIDNEY FAILURE.

column1: C13.351.968.419.570.363.680*D008181*Lupus Nephritis*Glomerulonephritis associated with autoimmune disease SYSTEMIC LUPUS ERYTHEMATOSUS. Lupus nephritis is histologically classified into 6 classes: class I - normal glomeruli
column2: class II - pure mesangial alterations
column6: and class VI - advanced sclerosing glomerulonephritis (The World Health Organization classification 1982).

column2: Hereditary*A group of inherited conditions characterized initially by HEMATURIA and slowly progressing to RENAL INSUFFICIENCY. The most common form is the Alport syndrome (hereditary nephritis with HEARING LOSS) which is caused by mutations in genes for TYPE IV COLLAGEN and defective GLOMERULAR BASEMENT MEMBRANE.

Interstitial*Inflammation of the interstitial tissue of the kidney. This term is generally used for primary inflammation of KIDNEY TUBULES and/or surrounding interstitium. For primary inflammation of glomerular interstitium
column3: see GLOMERULONEPHRITIS. Infiltration of the inflammatory cells into the interstitial compartment results in EDEMA

column1: C13.351.968.419.570.643.150*D001449*Balkan Nephropathy*A form of chronic interstitial nephritis that is endemic to limited areas of BULGARIA
column2: the former YUGOSLAVIA
column3: and ROMANIA. It is characterized by a progressive shrinking of the KIDNEYS that is often associated with uroepithelial tumors.

column1: C13.351.968.419.570.643.790*D011704*Pyelonephritis*Inflammation of the KIDNEY involving the renal parenchyma (the NEPHRONS); KIDNEY PELVIS; and KIDNEY CALICES. It is characterized by ABDOMINAL PAIN; FEVER; NAUSEA; VOMITING; and occasionally DIARRHEA.

column2: Xanthogranulomatous*A chronic inflammatory condition of the KIDNEY resulting in diffuse renal destruction
column3: a grossly enlarged and nonfunctioning kidney associated with NEPHROLITHIASIS and KIDNEY STONES.

column1: C13.351.968.419.570.821*D011702*Pyelitis*Inflammation of the KIDNEY PELVIS and KIDNEY CALICES where urine is collected before discharge
column2: but does not involve the renal parenchyma (the NEPHRONS) where urine is processed.

column1: C13.351.968.419.570.821.358*D053653*Pyelocystitis*Inflammation of the KIDNEY PELVIS and the URINARY BLADDER.

C13.351.968.419.570.821.717*D011704*Pyelonephritis*Inflammation of the KIDNEY involving the renal parenchyma (the NEPHRONS); KIDNEY PELVIS; and KIDNEY CALICES. It is characterized by ABDOMINAL PAIN; FEVER; NAUSEA; VOMITING; and occasionally DIARRHEA.

column2: Xanthogranulomatous*A chronic inflammatory condition of the KIDNEY resulting in diffuse renal destruction
column3: a grossly enlarged and nonfunctioning kidney associated with NEPHROLITHIASIS and KIDNEY STONES.

column1: C13.351.968.419.590*D009397*Nephrocalcinosis*A condition characterized by calcification of the renal tissue itself. It is usually seen in distal RENAL TUBULAR ACIDOSIS with calcium deposition in the DISTAL KIDNEY TUBULES and the surrounding interstitium. Nephrocalcinosis causes RENAL INSUFFICIENCY.
C13.351.968.419.600*D053040*Nephrolithiasis*Formation of stones in the KIDNEY.
C13.351.968.419.600.500*D007669*Kidney Calculi*Stones in the KIDNEY
column2: usually formed in the urine-collecting area of the kidney (KIDNEY PELVIS). Their sizes vary and most contains CALCIUM OXALATE.

column1: C13.351.968.419.600.500.500*D000069856*Staghorn Calculi*Renal calculi with a characteristic shape like antlers of a deer
column2: formed as it extends into multiple calices of the RENAL PELVIS. A large number of staghorn calculi as well as other URINARY CALCULI are composed of STRUVITE.

column1: C13.351.968.419.610*D009400*Nephrosclerosis*Hardening of the KIDNEY due to infiltration by fibrous connective tissue (FIBROSIS)
column2: usually caused by renovascular diseases or chronic HYPERTENSION. Nephrosclerosis leads to renal ISCHEMIA.

column1: C13.351.968.419.630*D009401*Nephrosis*Pathological processes of the KIDNEY without inflammatory or neoplastic components. Nephrosis may be a primary disorder or secondary complication of other diseases. It is characterized by the NEPHROTIC SYNDROME indicating the presence of PROTEINURIA and HYPOALBUMINEMIA with accompanying EDEMA.

column2: Lipoid*A kidney disease with no or minimal histological glomerular changes on light microscopy and with no immune deposits. It is characterized by lipid accumulation in the epithelial cells of KIDNEY TUBULES and in the URINE. Patients usually show NEPHROTIC SYNDROME indicating the presence of PROTEINURIA with accompanying EDEMA.

column1: C13.351.968.419.630.643*D009404*Nephrotic Syndrome*A condition characterized by severe PROTEINURIA
column2: greater than 3.5 g/day in an average adult. The substantial loss of protein in the urine results in complications such as HYPOPROTEINEMIA; generalized EDEMA; HYPERTENSION; and HYPERLIPIDEMIAS. Diseases associated with nephrotic syndrome generally cause chronic kidney dysfunction.

column1: C13.351.968.419.685*D010501*Perinephritis*Inflammation of the connective and adipose tissues surrounding the KIDNEY.
C13.351.968.419.775*D012078*Renal Artery Obstruction*Narrowing or occlusion of the RENAL ARTERY or arteries. It is due usually to ATHEROSCLEROSIS; FIBROMUSCULAR DYSPLASIA; THROMBOSIS; EMBOLISM
column2: or external pressure. The reduced renal perfusion can lead to renovascular hypertension (HYPERTENSION

column1: C13.351.968.419.780*D051437*Renal Insufficiency*Conditions in which the KIDNEYS perform below the normal level in the ability to remove wastes
column2: concentrate URINE
column3: and maintain ELECTROLYTE BALANCE; BLOOD PRESSURE; and CALCIUM metabolism. Renal insufficiency can be classified by the degree of kidney damage (as measured by the level of PROTEINURIA) and reduction in GLOMERULAR FILTRATION RATE.

column1: C13.351.968.419.780.050*D058186*Acute Kidney Injury*Abrupt reduction in kidney function. Acute kidney injury encompasses the entire spectrum of the syndrome including acute kidney failure; ACUTE KIDNEY TUBULAR NECROSIS; and other less severe conditions.
C13.351.968.419.780.050.500*D007683*Kidney Tubular Necrosis
column2: Acute*Acute kidney failure resulting from destruction of EPITHELIAL CELLS of the KIDNEY TUBULES. It is commonly attributed to exposure to toxic agents or renal ISCHEMIA following severe TRAUMA.

column1: C13.351.968.419.780.400*D059347*Cardio-Renal Syndrome*Condition where a primary dysfunction of either heart or kidney results in failure of the other organ (e.g.
column2: HEART FAILURE with worsening RENAL INSUFFICIENCY).

column1: C13.351.968.419.780.750*D051436*Renal Insufficiency
column2: Chronic*Conditions in which the KIDNEYS perform below the normal level for more than three months. Chronic kidney insufficiency is classified by five stages according to the decline in GLOMERULAR FILTRATION RATE and the degree of kidney damage (as measured by the level of PROTEINURIA). The most severe form is the end-stage renal disease (CHRONIC KIDNEY FAILURE). (Kidney Foundation: Kidney Disease Outcome Quality Initiative

Chronic*The end-stage of CHRONIC RENAL INSUFFICIENCY. It is characterized by the severe irreversible kidney damage (as measured by the level of PROTEINURIA) and the reduction in GLOMERULAR FILTRATION RATE to less than 15 ml per min (Kidney Foundation: Kidney Disease Outcome Quality Initiative
column3: 2002). These patients generally require HEMODIALYSIS or KIDNEY TRANSPLANTATION.

column1: C13.351.968.419.780.750.500.500*D052159*Frasier Syndrome*A syndrome characterized by CHRONIC KIDNEY FAILURE and GONADAL DYSGENESIS in phenotypic females with karyotype of 46
column2: XY or female individual with a normal 46
column3: XX karyotype. It is caused by donor splice-site mutations of Wilms tumor suppressor gene (GENES

column1: C13.351.968.419.787*D059228*Renal Nutcracker Syndrome*Left RENAL VEIN compression between the AORTA
column2: ABDOMINAL and the SUPERIOR MESENTERIC ARTERY. Variable symptoms include HYPERTENSION

column1: C13.351.968.419.795*D012080*Chronic Kidney Disease-Mineral and Bone Disorder*Decalcification of bone or abnormal bone development due to chronic KIDNEY DISEASES
column2: in which 1
column3: 25-DIHYDROXYVITAMIN D3 synthesis by the kidneys is impaired
column4: leading to reduced negative feedback on PARATHYROID HORMONE. The resulting SECONDARY HYPERPARATHYROIDISM eventually leads to bone disorders.

column1: C13.351.968.419.815*D015499*Renal Tubular Transport
column2: Inborn Errors*Genetic defects in the selective or non-selective transport functions of the KIDNEY TUBULES.
Renal Tubular*A group of genetic disorders of the KIDNEY TUBULES characterized by the accumulation of metabolically produced acids with elevated plasma chloride
column3: hyperchloremic metabolic ACIDOSIS. Defective renal acidification of URINE (proximal tubules) or low renal acid excretion (distal tubules) can lead to complications such as HYPOKALEMIA

column1: C13.351.968.419.815.279*D001477*Bartter Syndrome*A group of disorders caused by defective salt reabsorption in the ascending LOOP OF HENLE. It is characterized by severe salt-wasting
column2: HYPOKALEMIA; HYPERCALCIURIA; metabolic ALKALOSIS
column3: and hyper-reninemic HYPERALDOSTERONISM without HYPERTENSION. There are several subtypes including ones due to mutations in the renal specific SODIUM-POTASSIUM-CHLORIDE SYMPORTERS.

column1: C13.351.968.419.815.364*D057973*Dent Disease*X-linked recessive NEPHROLITHIASIS characterized by HYPERCALCIURIA; HYPOPHOSPHATEMIA; NEPHROCALCINOSIS; and PROTEINURIA. It is associated with mutations in the voltage-gated chloride channel
column2: CLC-5 (Dent Disease I). Another group of mutations associated with this disease is in phosphatidylinositol 4

column1: C13.351.968.419.815.450*D005198*Fanconi Syndrome*A hereditary or acquired form of generalized dysfunction of the PROXIMAL KIDNEY TUBULE without primary involvement of the KIDNEY GLOMERULUS. It is usually characterized by the tubular wasting of nutrients and salts (GLUCOSE; AMINO ACIDS; PHOSPHATES; and BICARBONATES) resulting in HYPOKALEMIA; ACIDOSIS; HYPERCALCIURIA; and PROTEINURIA.

C13.351.968.419.815.491*D053579*Gitelman Syndrome*An inherited renal disorder characterized by defective NaCl reabsorption in the convoluted DISTAL KIDNEY TUBULE leading to HYPOKALEMIA. In contrast with BARTTER SYNDROME
column2: Gitelman syndrome includes hypomagnesemia and normocalcemic hypocalciuria
column3: and is caused by mutations in the thiazide-sensitive SODIUM-POTASSIUM-CHLORIDE SYMPORTERS.

column2: Renal*An autosomal inherited disorder due to defective reabsorption of GLUCOSE by the PROXIMAL RENAL TUBULES. The urinary loss of glucose can reach beyond 50 g/day. It is attributed to the mutations in the SODIUM-GLUCOSE TRANSPORTER 2 encoded by the SLC5A2 gene.

Familial*An inherited condition of abnormally low serum levels of PHOSPHATES (below 1 mg/liter) which can occur in a number of genetic diseases with defective reabsorption of inorganic phosphorus by the PROXIMAL RENAL TUBULES. This leads to phosphaturia
column4: and disturbances of cellular and organ functions such as those in X-LINKED HYPOPHOSPHATEMIC RICKETS; OSTEOMALACIA; and FANCONI SYNDROME.

column1: C13.351.968.419.815.647.500*D053098*Familial Hypophosphatemic Rickets*A hereditary disorder characterized by HYPOPHOSPHATEMIA; RICKETS; OSTEOMALACIA; renal defects in phosphate reabsorption and vitamin D metabolism; and growth retardation. Autosomal and X-linked dominant and recessive variants have been reported.

C13.351.968.419.815.683*D056929*Liddle Syndrome*Familial pseudoaldosteronism characterized by autosomal dominant inheritance of hypertension with HYPOKALEMIA; ALKALOSIS; RENIN and ALDOSTERONE level decreases. It is caused by mutations in EPITHELIAL SODIUM CHANNELS beta and gamma subunits. Different mutations in the same EPITHELIAL SODIUM CHANNELS subunits can cause PSEUDOHYPOALDOSTERONISM
column2: TYPE I

column1: C13.351.968.419.815.720*D009800*Oculocerebrorenal Syndrome*A sex-linked recessive disorder affecting multiple systems including the EYE
column2: the NERVOUS SYSTEM
column3: and the KIDNEY. Clinical features include congenital CATARACT; MENTAL RETARDATION; and renal tubular dysfunction (FANCONI SYNDROME; RENAL TUBULAR ACIDOSIS; X-LINKED HYPOPHOSPHATEMIA or vitamin-D-resistant rickets) and SCOLIOSIS. This condition is due to a deficiency of phosphatidylinositol 4
column4: 5-bisphosphate-5-phosphatase leading to defects in PHOSPHATIDYLINOSITOL metabolism and INOSITOL signaling pathway. (from Menkes
column7: p60; Am J Hum Genet 1997 Jun;60(6):1384-8)

column1: C13.351.968.419.815.770*D011546*Pseudohypoaldosteronism*A heterogeneous group of disorders characterized by renal electrolyte transport dysfunctions. Congenital forms are rare autosomal disorders characterized by neonatal hypertension
column2: HYPERKALEMIA
column3: increased RENIN activity and ALDOSTERONE concentration. The Type I features HYPERKALEMIA with sodium wasting; Type II
column4: HYPERKALEMIA without sodium wasting. Pseudohypoaldosteronism can be the result of a defective renal electrolyte transport protein or acquired after KIDNEY TRANSPLANTATION.

column1: C13.351.968.419.815.885*D000608*Renal Aminoacidurias*A group of inherited kidney disorders characterized by the abnormally elevated levels of AMINO ACIDS in URINE. Genetic mutations of transport proteins result in the defective reabsorption of free amino acids at the PROXIMAL RENAL TUBULES. Renal aminoaciduria are classified by the specific amino acid or acids involved.

C13.351.968.419.815.885.250*D003555*Cystinuria*An inherited disorder due to defective reabsorption of CYSTINE and other BASIC AMINO ACIDS by the PROXIMAL RENAL TUBULES. This form of aminoaciduria is characterized by the abnormally high urinary levels of cystine; LYSINE; ARGININE; and ORNITHINE. Mutations involve the amino acid transport protein gene SLC3A1.

C13.351.968.419.815.885.625*D006250*Hartnup Disease*An autosomal recessive disorder due to defective absorption of NEUTRAL AMINO ACIDS by both the intestine and the PROXIMAL RENAL TUBULES. The abnormal urinary loss of TRYPTOPHAN
column2: a precursor of NIACIN
column7: and aminoaciduria. Mutations involve the neurotransmitter transporter gene SLC6A19.

column2: Renal*Infection of the KIDNEY with species of MYCOBACTERIUM.

column1: C13.351.968.419.936*D014511*Uremia*A clinical syndrome associated with the retention of renal waste products or uremic toxins in the blood. It is usually the result of RENAL INSUFFICIENCY. Most uremic toxins are end products of protein or nitrogen CATABOLISM
column2: such as UREA or CREATININE. Severe uremia can lead to multiple organ dysfunctions with a constellation of symptoms.

column1: C13.351.968.419.936.231*D053099*Azotemia*A biochemical abnormality referring to an elevation of BLOOD UREA NITROGEN and CREATININE. Azotemia can be produced by KIDNEY DISEASES or other extrarenal disorders. When azotemia becomes associated with a constellation of clinical signs
column2: it is termed UREMIA.

column1: C13.351.968.419.936.463*D006463*Hemolytic-Uremic Syndrome*A syndrome that is associated with microvascular diseases of the KIDNEY
column2: such as RENAL CORTICAL NECROSIS. It is characterized by hemolytic anemia (ANEMIA
column3: HEMOLYTIC); THROMBOCYTOPENIA; and ACUTE RENAL FAILURE.

column1: C13.351.968.419.936.463.500*D065766*Atypical Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome*An hereditary hemolytic uremic syndrome associated with variations in the gene that encodes COMPLEMENT FACTOR H
column2: or the related proteins CFHR1 and CFHR3. Disease often progresses to CHRONIC KIDNEY FAILURE without the prodromal symptoms of ENTEROCOLITIS and DIARRHEA that characterize typical hemolytic uremic syndrome.

column1: C13.351.968.419.978*D015211*Zellweger Syndrome*An autosomal recessive disorder due to defects in PEROXISOME biogenesis which involves more than 13 genes encoding peroxin proteins of the peroxisomal membrane and matrix. Zellweger syndrome is typically seen in the neonatal period with features such as dysmorphic skull; MUSCLE HYPOTONIA; SENSORINEURAL HEARING LOSS; visual compromise; SEIZURES; progressive degeneration of the KIDNEYS and the LIVER. Zellweger-like syndrome refers to phenotypes resembling the neonatal Zellweger syndrome but seen in children or adults with apparently intact peroxisome biogenesis.
C13.351.968.725*D014515*Ureteral Diseases*Pathological processes involving the URETERS.
C13.351.968.725.676*D014516*Ureteral Neoplasms*Cancer or tumors of the URETER which may cause obstruction leading to hydroureter
column2: HYDRONEPHROSIS
column3: and PYELONEPHRITIS. HEMATURIA is a common symptom.

column1: C13.351.968.725.776*D014517*Ureteral Obstruction*Blockage in any part of the URETER causing obstruction of urine flow from the kidney to the URINARY BLADDER. The obstruction may be congenital
column2: acquired
column8: or chronic. Depending on the degree and duration of the obstruction
column9: clinical features vary greatly such as HYDRONEPHROSIS and obstructive nephropathy.

column1: C13.351.968.725.876*D014518*Ureterocele*A cystic dilatation of the end of a URETER as it enters into the URINARY BLADDER. It is characterized by the ballooning of the ureteral orifice into the lumen of the bladder and may obstruct urine flow.
C13.351.968.725.938*D053039*Ureterolithiasis*Formation of stones in the URETER.

C13.351.968.725.938.500*D014514*Ureteral Calculi*Stones in the URETER that are formed in the KIDNEY. They are rarely more than 5 mm in diameter for larger renal stones cannot enter ureters. They are often lodged at the ureteral narrowing and can cause excruciating renal colic.
C13.351.968.767*D014522*Urethral Diseases*Pathological processes involving the URETHRA.
C13.351.968.767.374*D004842*Epispadias*A birth defect due to malformation of the URETHRA in which the urethral opening is above its normal location. In the male
column2: the malformed urethra generally opens on the top or the side of the PENIS
column3: but the urethra can also be open the entire length of the penis. In the female
column4: the malformed urethral opening is often between the CLITORIS and the labia

column1: C13.351.968.767.601*D014523*Urethral Neoplasms*Cancer or tumors of the URETHRA. Benign epithelial tumors of the urethra usually consist of squamous and transitional cells. Primary urethral carcinomas are rare and typically of squamous cells. Urethral carcinoma is the only urological malignancy that is more common in females than in males.

C13.351.968.767.700*D014524*Urethral Obstruction*Partial or complete blockage in any part of the URETHRA that can lead to difficulty or inability to empty the URINARY BLADDER. It is characterized by an enlarged
column2: often damaged
column3: bladder with frequent urges to void.

column1: C13.351.968.767.700.700*D014525*Urethral Stricture*Narrowing of any part of the URETHRA. It is characterized by decreased urinary stream and often other obstructive voiding symptoms.
C13.351.968.767.700.850*D001748*Urinary Bladder Neck Obstruction*Blocked urine flow through the bladder neck
column2: the narrow internal urethral opening at the base of the URINARY BLADDER. Narrowing or strictures of the URETHRA can be congenital or acquired. It is often observed in males with enlarged PROSTATE glands.

column1: C13.351.968.767.851*D014526*Urethritis*Inflammation involving the URETHRA. Similar to CYSTITIS
column2: clinical symptoms range from vague discomfort to painful urination (DYSURIA)

column1: C13.351.968.829*D001745*Urinary Bladder Diseases*Pathological processes of the URINARY BLADDER.
C13.351.968.829.132*D001746*Bladder Exstrophy*A birth defect in which the URINARY BLADDER is malformed and exposed
column2: inside out
column3: and protruded through the ABDOMINAL WALL. It is caused by closure defects involving the top front surface of the bladder
column4: as well as the lower abdominal wall; SKIN; MUSCLES; and the pubic bone.

column1: C13.351.968.829.495*D003556*Cystitis*Inflammation of the URINARY BLADDER
column2: either from bacterial or non-bacterial causes. Cystitis is usually associated with painful urination (dysuria)

Interstitial*A condition with recurring discomfort or pain in the URINARY BLADDER and the surrounding pelvic region without an identifiable disease. Severity of pain in interstitial cystitis varies greatly and often is accompanied by increased urination frequency and urgency.

column1: C13.351.968.829.495.750*D053653*Pyelocystitis*Inflammation of the KIDNEY PELVIS and the URINARY BLADDER.

C13.351.968.829.508*D052858*Cystocele*A HERNIA-like condition in which the weakened pelvic muscles cause the URINARY BLADDER to drop from its normal position. Fallen urinary bladder is more common in females with the bladder dropping into the VAGINA and less common in males with the bladder dropping into the SCROTUM.
C13.351.968.829.521*D001744*Urinary Bladder Calculi*Stones in the URINARY BLADDER; also known as vesical calculi
column2: bladder stones

column1: C13.351.968.829.548*D001747*Urinary Bladder Fistula*An abnormal passage in the URINARY BLADDER or between the bladder and any surrounding organ.
C13.351.968.829.548.733*D014719*Vesicovaginal Fistula*An abnormal anatomical passage between the URINARY BLADDER and the VAGINA.
C13.351.968.829.601*D001748*Urinary Bladder Neck Obstruction*Blocked urine flow through the bladder neck
column2: the narrow internal urethral opening at the base of the URINARY BLADDER. Narrowing or strictures of the URETHRA can be congenital or acquired. It is often observed in males with enlarged PROSTATE glands.

column1: C13.351.968.829.707*D001749*Urinary Bladder Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the URINARY BLADDER.

column2: Neurogenic*Dysfunction of the URINARY BLADDER due to disease of the central or peripheral nervous system pathways involved in the control of URINATION. This is often associated with SPINAL CORD DISEASES
column3: but may also be caused by BRAIN DISEASES or PERIPHERAL NERVE DISEASES.

column2: Overactive*Symptom of overactive detrusor muscle of the URINARY BLADDER that contracts with abnormally high frequency and urgency. Overactive bladder is characterized by the frequent feeling of needing to urinate during the day
column4: or both. URINARY INCONTINENCE may or may not be present.

column1: C13.351.968.829.920*D014718*Vesico-Ureteral Reflux*Retrograde flow of urine from the URINARY BLADDER into the URETER. This is often due to incompetence of the vesicoureteral valve leading to ascending bacterial infection into the KIDNEY.

C13.351.968.892*D014552*Urinary Tract Infections*Inflammatory responses of the epithelium of the URINARY TRACT to microbial invasions. They are often bacterial infections with associated BACTERIURIA and PYURIA.

C13.351.968.892.219*D001437*Bacteriuria*The presence of bacteria in the urine which is normally bacteria-free. These bacteria are from the URINARY TRACT and are not contaminants of the surrounding tissues. Bacteriuria can be symptomatic or asymptomatic. Significant bacteriuria is an indicator of urinary tract infection.

C13.351.968.892.719*D011776*Pyuria*The presence of white blood cells (LEUKOCYTES) in the urine. It is often associated with bacterial infections of the urinary tract. Pyuria without BACTERIURIA can be caused by TUBERCULOSIS
column2: stones

column1: C13.351.968.892.775*D012553*Schistosomiasis haematobia*A human disease caused by the infection of parasitic worms SCHISTOSOMA HAEMATOBIUM. It is endemic in AFRICA and parts of the MIDDLE EAST. Tissue damages most often occur in the URINARY TRACT
column2: specifically the URINARY BLADDER.

column1: C13.351.968.934*D014555*Urination Disorders*Abnormalities in the process of URINE voiding
column2: including bladder control
column4: as well as the volume and composition of URINE.

column1: C13.351.968.934.070*D001002*Anuria*Absence of urine formation. It is usually associated with complete bilateral ureteral (URETER) obstruction
column2: complete lower urinary tract obstruction
column3: or unilateral ureteral obstruction when a solitary kidney is present.

column1: C13.351.968.934.252*D004775*Enuresis*Involuntary discharge of URINE after expected age of completed development of urinary control. This can happen during the daytime (DIURNAL ENURESIS) while one is awake or during sleep (NOCTURNAL ENURESIS). Enuresis can be in children or in adults (as persistent primary enuresis and secondary adult-onset enuresis).
C13.351.968.934.252.249*D053207*Diurnal Enuresis*Involuntary discharge of URINE during the daytime while one is awake.
C13.351.968.934.252.500*D053206*Nocturnal Enuresis*Involuntary discharge of URINE during sleep at night after expected age of completed development of urinary control.
C13.351.968.934.363*D006029*Glycosuria*The appearance of an abnormally large amount of GLUCOSE in the urine
column2: such as more than 500 mg/day in adults. It can be due to HYPERGLYCEMIA or genetic defects in renal reabsorption (RENAL GLYCOSURIA).

Renal*An autosomal inherited disorder due to defective reabsorption of GLUCOSE by the PROXIMAL RENAL TUBULES. The urinary loss of glucose can reach beyond 50 g/day. It is attributed to the mutations in the SODIUM-GLUCOSE TRANSPORTER 2 encoded by the SLC5A2 gene.

column1: C13.351.968.934.442*D006417*Hematuria*Presence of blood in the urine.
C13.351.968.934.600*D009846*Oliguria*Decreased URINE output that is below the normal range. Oliguria can be defined as urine output of less than or equal to 0.5 or 1 ml/kg/hr depending on the age.
C13.351.968.934.616*D011141*Polyuria*Urination of a large volume of urine with an increase in urinary frequency
column2: commonly seen in diabetes (DIABETES MELLITUS; DIABETES INSIPIDUS).

column1: C13.351.968.934.734*D011507*Proteinuria*The presence of proteins in the urine
column2: an indicator of KIDNEY DISEASES.

column1: C13.351.968.934.734.269*D000419*Albuminuria*The presence of albumin in the urine
column2: an indicator of KIDNEY DISEASES.

column1: C13.351.968.934.734.634*D006456*Hemoglobinuria*The presence of free HEMOGLOBIN in the URINE
column2: indicating hemolysis of ERYTHROCYTES within the vascular system. After saturating the hemoglobin-binding proteins (HAPTOGLOBINS)
column3: free hemoglobin begins to appear in the urine.

column1: C13.351.968.934.814*D014549*Urinary Incontinence*Involuntary loss of URINE
column2: such as leaking of urine. It is a symptom of various underlying pathological processes. Major types of incontinence include URINARY URGE INCONTINENCE and URINARY STRESS INCONTINENCE.

column1: C13.351.968.934.814.500*D014550*Urinary Incontinence
column2: Stress*Involuntary discharge of URINE as a result of physical activities that increase abdominal pressure on the URINARY BLADDER without detrusor contraction or overdistended bladder. The subtypes are classified by the degree of leakage
column3: descent and opening of the bladder neck and URETHRA without bladder contraction

column1: C13.351.968.934.814.750*D053202*Urinary Incontinence
column2: Urge*Involuntary discharge of URINE that is associated with an abrupt and strong desire to void. It is usually related to the involuntary contractions of the detrusor muscle of the bladder (detrusor hyperreflexia or detrusor instability).

column1: C13.351.968.934.880*D016055*Urinary Retention*Inability to empty the URINARY BLADDER with voiding (URINATION).
C13.351.968.967*D052878*Urolithiasis*Formation of stones in any part of the URINARY TRACT
column2: usually in the KIDNEY; URINARY BLADDER; or the URETER.

column1: C13.351.968.967.249*D053040*Nephrolithiasis*Formation of stones in the KIDNEY.
C13.351.968.967.249.500*D007669*Kidney Calculi*Stones in the KIDNEY
column2: usually formed in the urine-collecting area of the kidney (KIDNEY PELVIS). Their sizes vary and most contains CALCIUM OXALATE.

column1: C13.351.968.967.249.500.500*D000069856*Staghorn Calculi*Renal calculi with a characteristic shape like antlers of a deer
column2: formed as it extends into multiple calices of the RENAL PELVIS. A large number of staghorn calculi as well as other URINARY CALCULI are composed of STRUVITE.

column1: C13.351.968.967.374*D053039*Ureterolithiasis*Formation of stones in the URETER.

C13.351.968.967.374.500*D014514*Ureteral Calculi*Stones in the URETER that are formed in the KIDNEY. They are rarely more than 5 mm in diameter for larger renal stones cannot enter ureters. They are often lodged at the ureteral narrowing and can cause excruciating renal colic.
C13.351.968.967.500*D014545*Urinary Calculi*Low-density crystals or stones in any part of the URINARY TRACT. Their chemical compositions often include CALCIUM OXALATE
column2: magnesium ammonium phosphate (struvite)

column1: C13.351.968.967.500.503*D007669*Kidney Calculi*Stones in the KIDNEY
column2: usually formed in the urine-collecting area of the kidney (KIDNEY PELVIS). Their sizes vary and most contains CALCIUM OXALATE.

column1: C13.351.968.967.500.503.500*D000069856*Staghorn Calculi*Renal calculi with a characteristic shape like antlers of a deer
column2: formed as it extends into multiple calices of the RENAL PELVIS. A large number of staghorn calculi as well as other URINARY CALCULI are composed of STRUVITE.

column1: C13.351.968.967.500.851*D014514*Ureteral Calculi*Stones in the URETER that are formed in the KIDNEY. They are rarely more than 5 mm in diameter for larger renal stones cannot enter ureters. They are often lodged at the ureteral narrowing and can cause excruciating renal colic.
C13.351.968.967.500.925*D001744*Urinary Bladder Calculi*Stones in the URINARY BLADDER; also known as vesical calculi
column2: bladder stones

column1: C13.703*D011248*Pregnancy Complications*Conditions or pathological processes associated with pregnancy. They can occur during or after pregnancy
column2: and range from minor discomforts to serious diseases that require medical interventions. They include diseases in pregnant females
column3: and pregnancies in females with diseases.

column2: Spontaneous*Expulsion of the product of FERTILIZATION before completing the term of GESTATION and without deliberate interference.
Habitual*Three or more consecutive spontaneous abortions.

column1: C13.703.039.089.339*D002581*Uterine Cervical Incompetence*Incompetent UTERINE CERVIX is usually diagnosed in the second trimester of PREGNANCY. It is characterized by passive painless cervical dilation in the absence of UTERINE CONTRACTION; BLEEDING; INFECTION; and sometimes with the amniotic sac (AMNIOTIC MEMBRANE) bulging through the partially dilated cervix. Left untreated
column2: this condition may lead to premature pregnancy loss
Incomplete*Premature loss of PREGNANCY in which not all the products of CONCEPTION have been expelled.
Missed*The retention in the UTERUS of a dead FETUS two months or more after its DEATH.
Septic*Any type of abortion
column4: that is associated with infection of the UTERUS and its appendages. It is characterized by FEVER

column2: Threatened*UTERINE BLEEDING from a GESTATION of less than 20 weeks without any CERVICAL DILATATION. It is characterized by vaginal bleeding
column4: or midline pelvic cramping and a risk factor for MISCARRIAGE.

column2: Veterinary*Premature expulsion of the FETUS in animals.

column1: C13.703.039.711*D020964*Embryo Loss*Early pregnancy loss during the EMBRYO
column2: MAMMALIAN stage of development. In the human
column3: this period comprises the second through eighth week after fertilization.

column1: C13.703.141*D020150*Chorea Gravidarum*A rare movement disorder developed during PREGNANCY
column2: characterized by involuntary jerky motion (CHOREA) and inability to maintain stable position of body parts (ATHETOSIS). RHEUMATIC FEVER and collagen vascular disorders are frequently associated with this disease. Chorea may vary from mild to severe and occurs in approximately 1 per 2

Gestational*Diabetes mellitus induced by PREGNANCY but resolved at the end of pregnancy. It does not include previously diagnosed diabetics who become pregnant (PREGNANCY IN DIABETICS). Gestational diabetes usually develops in late pregnancy when insulin antagonistic hormones peaks leading to INSULIN RESISTANCE; GLUCOSE INTOLERANCE; and HYPERGLYCEMIA.

column1: C13.703.170.500*D005320*Fetal Macrosomia*A condition of fetal overgrowth leading to a large-for-gestational-age FETUS. It is defined as BIRTH WEIGHT greater than 4
column2: 000 grams or above the 90th percentile for population and sex-specific growth curves. It is commonly seen in GESTATIONAL DIABETES; PROLONGED PREGNANCY; and pregnancies complicated by pre-existing diabetes mellitus.

column1: C13.703.223*D005313*Fetal Death*Death of the developing young in utero. BIRTH of a dead FETUS is STILLBIRTH.
C13.703.223.300*D005327*Fetal Resorption*The disintegration and assimilation of the dead FETUS in the UTERUS at any stage after the completion of organogenesis which
column2: in humans
column3: is after the 9th week of GESTATION. It does not include embryo resorption (see EMBRYO LOSS).

column1: C13.703.223.650*D050497*Stillbirth*The event that a FETUS is born dead or stillborn.
C13.703.277*D005315*Fetal Diseases*Pathophysiological conditions of the FETUS in the UTERUS. Some fetal diseases may be treated with FETAL THERAPIES.

C13.703.277.030*D002821*Chorioamnionitis*INFLAMMATION of the placental membranes (CHORION; AMNION) and connected tissues such as fetal BLOOD VESSELS and UMBILICAL CORD. It is often associated with intrauterine ascending infections during PREGNANCY.
C13.703.277.050*D058535*Echogenic Bowel*A PRENATAL ULTRASONOGRAPHY finding of excessively dense fetal bowel due to MECONIUM buildup.
C13.703.277.060*D004899*Erythroblastosis
column2: Fetal*A condition characterized by the abnormal presence of ERYTHROBLASTS in the circulation of the FETUS or NEWBORNS. It is a disorder due to BLOOD GROUP INCOMPATIBILITY
column3: such as the maternal alloimmunization by fetal antigen RH FACTORS leading to HEMOLYSIS of ERYTHROCYTES

column1: C13.703.277.060.480*D015160*Hydrops Fetalis*Abnormal accumulation of serous fluid in two or more fetal compartments
column2: such as SKIN; PLEURA; PERICARDIUM; PLACENTA; PERITONEUM; AMNIOTIC FLUID. General fetal EDEMA may be of non-immunologic origin
column3: or of immunologic origin as in the case of ERYTHROBLASTOSIS FETALIS.

column1: C13.703.277.220*D063647*Fetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorders*An umbrella term used to describe a pattern of disabilities and abnormalities that result from fetal exposure to ETHANOL during pregnancy. It encompasses a phenotypic range that can vary greatly between individuals
column2: but reliably includes one or more of the following: characteristic facial dysmorphism
column6: BIRTH DEFECTS. The level of maternal alcohol consumption does not necessarily correlate directly with disease severity.

column1: C13.703.277.370*D005317*Fetal Growth Retardation*The failure of a FETUS to attain its expected FETAL GROWTH at any GESTATIONAL AGE.
C13.703.277.390*D005311*Fetal Hypoxia*Deficient oxygenation of FETAL BLOOD.
C13.703.277.570*D005320*Fetal Macrosomia*A condition of fetal overgrowth leading to a large-for-gestational-age FETUS. It is defined as BIRTH WEIGHT greater than 4
column2: 000 grams or above the 90th percentile for population and sex-specific growth curves. It is commonly seen in GESTATIONAL DIABETES; PROLONGED PREGNANCY; and pregnancies complicated by pre-existing diabetes mellitus.

column1: C13.703.277.677*D048070*Fetal Nutrition Disorders*Disorders caused by nutritional imbalance
column2: either overnutrition or undernutrition

column1: C13.703.277.785*D008471*Meconium Aspiration Syndrome*A condition caused by inhalation of MECONIUM into the LUNG of FETUS or NEWBORN
column2: usually due to vigorous respiratory movements during difficult PARTURITION or respiratory system abnormalities. Meconium aspirate may block small airways leading to difficulties in PULMONARY GAS EXCHANGE and ASPIRATION PNEUMONIA.

column1: C13.703.277.838*D058536*Pyelectasis*Dilation of fetal KIDNEY PELVIS. It is a common PRENATAL ULTRASONOGRAPHY finding with no significant long-term sequelae.
C13.703.395*D046110*Hypertension
column2: Pregnancy-Induced*A condition in pregnant women with elevated systolic (>140 mm Hg) and diastolic (>90 mm Hg) blood pressure on at least two occasions 6 h apart. HYPERTENSION complicates 8-10% of all pregnancies
column3: generally after 20 weeks of gestation. Gestational hypertension can be divided into several broad categories according to the complexity and associated symptoms
column4: such as EDEMA; PROTEINURIA; SEIZURES; abnormalities in BLOOD COAGULATION and liver functions.

column1: C13.703.395.124*D004461*Eclampsia*Onset of HYPERREFLEXIA; SEIZURES; or COMA in a previously diagnosed pre-eclamptic patient (PRE-ECLAMPSIA).
C13.703.395.186*D017359*HELLP Syndrome*A syndrome of HEMOLYSIS
column2: elevated liver ENZYMES
column3: and low blood platelets count (THROMBOCYTOPENIA). HELLP syndrome is observed in pregnant women with PRE-ECLAMPSIA or ECLAMPSIA who also exhibit LIVER damage and abnormalities in BLOOD COAGULATION.

column1: C13.703.395.249*D011225*Pre-Eclampsia*A complication of PREGNANCY
column2: characterized by a complex of symptoms including maternal HYPERTENSION and PROTEINURIA with or without pathological EDEMA. Symptoms may range between mild and severe. Pre-eclampsia usually occurs after the 20th week of gestation
column3: but may develop before this time in the presence of trophoblastic disease.

column1: C13.703.401*D063130*Maternal Death*The death of the female parent.

C13.703.407*D048968*Morning Sickness*Symptoms of NAUSEA and VOMITING in pregnant women that usually occur in the morning during the first 2 to 3 months of PREGNANCY. Severe persistent vomiting during pregnancy is called HYPEREMESIS GRAVIDARUM.
C13.703.407.500*D006939*Hyperemesis Gravidarum*Intractable VOMITING that develops in early PREGNANCY and persists. This can lead to DEHYDRATION and WEIGHT LOSS.
C13.703.413*D053589*Nuchal Cord*A complication of pregnancy in which the UMBILICAL CORD wraps around the fetal neck once or multiple times. In some cases
column2: cord entanglement around fetal neck may not affect pregnancy outcome significantly. In others
column3: the nuchal cord may lead to restricted fetal blood flow

column1: C13.703.420*D007744*Obstetric Labor Complications*Medical problems associated with OBSTETRIC LABOR
column2: such as BREECH PRESENTATION; PREMATURE OBSTETRIC LABOR; HEMORRHAGE; or others. These complications can affect the well-being of the mother

column1: C13.703.420.078*D000037*Abruptio Placentae*Premature separation of the normally implanted PLACENTA from the UTERUS. Signs of varying degree of severity include UTERINE BLEEDING
column2: uterine MUSCLE HYPERTONIA
column3: and FETAL DISTRESS or FETAL DEATH.

column1: C13.703.420.183*D001946*Breech Presentation*A malpresentation of the FETUS at near term or during OBSTETRIC LABOR with the fetal cephalic pole in the fundus of the UTERUS. There are three types of breech: the complete breech with flexed hips and knees; the incomplete breech with one or both hips partially or fully extended; the frank breech with flexed hips and extended knees.
C13.703.420.235*D052178*Cephalopelvic Disproportion*A condition in which the HEAD of the FETUS is larger than the mother's PELVIS through which the fetal head must pass during a vaginal delivery.
C13.703.420.288*D004420*Dystocia*Slow or difficult OBSTETRIC LABOR or CHILDBIRTH.
C13.703.420.288.728*D014593*Uterine Inertia*Failure of the UTERUS to contract with normal strength
column2: duration
column4: OBSTETRIC). It is also called uterine atony.

column1: C13.703.420.339*D005322*Fetal Membranes
column2: Premature Rupture*Spontaneous tearing of the membranes surrounding the FETUS any time before the onset of OBSTETRIC LABOR. Preterm PROM is membrane rupture before 37 weeks of GESTATION.

column1: C13.703.420.339.260*D002821*Chorioamnionitis*INFLAMMATION of the placental membranes (CHORION; AMNION) and connected tissues such as fetal BLOOD VESSELS and UMBILICAL CORD. It is often associated with intrauterine ascending infections during PREGNANCY.
C13.703.420.491*D007752*Obstetric Labor
column2: Premature*Onset of OBSTETRIC LABOR before term (TERM BIRTH) but usually after the FETUS has become viable. In humans
column3: it occurs sometime during the 29th through 38th week of PREGNANCY. TOCOLYSIS inhibits premature labor and can prevent the BIRTH of premature infants (INFANT

column1: C13.703.420.491.500*D047928*Premature Birth*CHILDBIRTH before 37 weeks of PREGNANCY (259 days from the first day of the mother's last menstrual period
column2: or 245 days after FERTILIZATION).

column1: C13.703.420.643*D010921*Placenta Accreta*Abnormal placentation in which all or parts of the PLACENTA are attached directly to the MYOMETRIUM due to a complete or partial absence of DECIDUA. It is associated with POSTPARTUM HEMORRHAGE because of the failure of placental separation.

C13.703.420.714*D010923*Placenta Previa*Abnormal placentation in which the PLACENTA implants in the lower segment of the UTERUS (the zone of dilation) and may cover part or all of the opening of the CERVIX. It is often associated with serious antepartum bleeding and PREMATURE LABOR.

C13.703.420.725*D006473*Postpartum Hemorrhage*Excess blood loss from uterine bleeding associated with OBSTETRIC LABOR or CHILDBIRTH. It is defined as blood loss greater than 500 ml or of the amount that adversely affects the maternal physiology
column2: such as BLOOD PRESSURE and HEMATOCRIT. Postpartum hemorrhage is divided into two categories
column3: immediate (within first 24 hours after birth) or delayed (after 24 hours postpartum).

column1: C13.703.420.814*D019687*Uterine Inversion*A complication of OBSTETRIC LABOR in which the corpus of the UTERUS is forced completely or partially through the UTERINE CERVIX. This can occur during the late stages of labor and is associated with IMMEDIATE POSTPARTUM HEMORRHAGE.
C13.703.420.904*D014597*Uterine Rupture*A complete separation or tear in the wall of the UTERUS with or without expulsion of the FETUS. It may be due to injuries
column2: multiple pregnancies

column1: C13.703.420.952*D055949*Vasa Previa*Pregnancy complication where fetal blood vessels
column2: normally inside the umbilical cord
column3: are left unprotected and cross FETAL MEMBRANES. It is associated with antepartum bleeding and FETAL DEATH and STILLBIRTH due to exsanguination.

column1: C13.703.560*D016104*Oligohydramnios*A condition of abnormally low AMNIOTIC FLUID volume. Principal causes include malformations of fetal URINARY TRACT; FETAL GROWTH RETARDATION; GESTATIONAL HYPERTENSION; nicotine poisoning; and PROLONGED PREGNANCY.
C13.703.565*D059952*Pelvic Floor Disorders*Injury
column2: weakening
column3: or PROLAPSE of the pelvic muscles
column4: surrounding connective tissues or ligaments (PELVIC FLOOR).

column1: C13.703.570*D006559*Pemphigoid Gestationis*An itching
column2: autoimmune
column3: bullous SKIN disease that occurs during the last two trimesters of PREGNANCY and PUERPERIUM. It also affects non-pregnant females with tissue of PLACENTA origin
column4: such as CHORIOCARCINOMA; or HYDATIDIFORM MOLE. It exhibits antigenic and clinical similarity to bullous pemphigoid (PEMPHIGOID
column5: BULLOUS). This disease does not involve herpes viruses (old name

column1: C13.703.572*D066087*Perinatal Death*The death of a FETUS of GESTATIONAL AGE 28 weeks or more
column2: or the death of a live-born INFANT less than 28 days of age.

column1: C13.703.575*D017042*Phenylketonuria
column2: Maternal*A condition occurring in untreated or partially treated females with PHENYLKETONURIA when they become pregnant. This may result in damages to the FETUS
column3: including MICROCEPHALY; MENTAL RETARDATION; congenital heart disease; FETAL GROWTH RETARDATION; and CRANIOFACIAL ABNORMALITIES. (From Am J Med Genet 1997 Mar 3;69(1):89-95)

column1: C13.703.590*D010922*Placenta Diseases*Pathological processes or abnormal functions of the PLACENTA.
C13.703.590.132*D000037*Abruptio Placentae*Premature separation of the normally implanted PLACENTA from the UTERUS. Signs of varying degree of severity include UTERINE BLEEDING
column2: uterine MUSCLE HYPERTONIA
column3: and FETAL DISTRESS or FETAL DEATH.

column1: C13.703.590.268*D002821*Chorioamnionitis*INFLAMMATION of the placental membranes (CHORION; AMNION) and connected tissues such as fetal BLOOD VESSELS and UMBILICAL CORD. It is often associated with intrauterine ascending infections during PREGNANCY.

C13.703.590.609*D010921*Placenta Accreta*Abnormal placentation in which all or parts of the PLACENTA are attached directly to the MYOMETRIUM due to a complete or partial absence of DECIDUA. It is associated with POSTPARTUM HEMORRHAGE because of the failure of placental separation.

C13.703.590.734*D010923*Placenta Previa*Abnormal placentation in which the PLACENTA implants in the lower segment of the UTERUS (the zone of dilation) and may cover part or all of the opening of the CERVIX. It is often associated with serious antepartum bleeding and PREMATURE LABOR.

column2: Retained*A placenta that fails to be expelled after BIRTH of the FETUS. A PLACENTA is retained when the UTERUS fails to contract after the delivery of its content
column3: or when the placenta is abnormally attached to the MYOMETRIUM.

column1: C13.703.590.800*D010927*Placental Insufficiency*Failure of the PLACENTA to deliver an adequate supply of nutrients and OXYGEN to the FETUS.
C13.703.610*D006831*Polyhydramnios*A condition of abnormally high AMNIOTIC FLUID volume
column2: such as greater than 2
column3: 000 ml in the LAST TRIMESTER and usually diagnosed by ultrasonographic criteria (AMNIOTIC FLUID INDEX). It is associated with maternal DIABETES MELLITUS; MULTIPLE PREGNANCY; CHROMOSOMAL DISORDERS; and congenital abnormalities.

column1: C13.703.634*D011249*Pregnancy Complications
column2: Cardiovascular*The co-occurrence of pregnancy and a cardiovascular disease. The disease may precede or follow FERTILIZATION and it may or may not have a deleterious effect on the pregnant woman or FETUS.

Amniotic Fluid*Blocking of maternal circulation by AMNIOTIC FLUID that is forced into uterine VEINS by strong UTERINE CONTRACTION near the end of pregnancy. It is characterized by the sudden onset of severe respiratory distress and HYPOTENSION that can lead to maternal DEATH.

column1: C13.703.667*D011250*Pregnancy Complications
column2: Hematologic*The co-occurrence of pregnancy and a blood disease (HEMATOLOGIC DISEASES) which involves BLOOD CELLS or COAGULATION FACTORS. The hematologic disease may precede or follow FERTILIZATION and it may or may not have a deleterious effect on the pregnant woman or FETUS.

column1: C13.703.700*D011251*Pregnancy Complications
column2: Infectious*The co-occurrence of pregnancy and an INFECTION. The infection may precede or follow FERTILIZATION.
Septic*Any type of abortion
column4: that is associated with infection of the UTERUS and its appendages. It is characterized by FEVER

column1: C13.703.700.680*D015597*Pregnancy Complications
column2: Parasitic*The co-occurrence of pregnancy and parasitic diseases. The parasitic infection may precede or follow FERTILIZATION.

column1: C13.703.700.715*D011645*Puerperal Infection*An infection occurring in PUERPERIUM
column2: the period of 6-8 weeks after giving birth.

column1: C13.703.720*D011252*Pregnancy Complications
column2: Neoplastic*The co-occurrence of pregnancy and NEOPLASMS. The neoplastic disease may precede or follow FERTILIZATION.

column1: C13.703.720.949*D014328*Trophoblastic Neoplasms*Trophoblastic growth
column2: which may be gestational or nongestational in origin. Trophoblastic neoplasia resulting from pregnancy is often described as gestational trophoblastic disease to distinguish it from germ cell tumors which frequently show trophoblastic elements
column3: and from the trophoblastic differentiation which sometimes occurs in a wide variety of epithelial cancers. Gestational trophoblastic growth has several forms
column4: including HYDATIDIFORM MOLE and CHORIOCARCINOMA. (From Holland et al.

column1: C13.703.720.949.208*D002822*Choriocarcinoma*A malignant metastatic form of trophoblastic tumors. Unlike the HYDATIDIFORM MOLE
column2: choriocarcinoma contains no CHORIONIC VILLI but rather sheets of undifferentiated cytotrophoblasts and syncytiotrophoblasts (TROPHOBLASTS). It is characterized by the large amounts of CHORIONIC GONADOTROPIN produced. Tissue origins can be determined by DNA analyses: placental (fetal) origin or non-placental origin (CHORIOCARCINOMA
Non-gestational*A highly malignant CHORIOCARCINOMA derived from the non-placental origin such as the totipotent cells in the TESTIS
column4: and the PINEAL GLAND. It produces high levels of CHORIONIC GONADOTROPIN and can metastasize widely through the bloodstream to the lungs
column8: and other viscera by the time of diagnosis.

column1: C13.703.720.949.208.875*D018245*Trophoblastic Tumor
column2: Placental Site*An uncommon variant of CHORIOCARCINOMA. It is composed almost entirely of mononuclear cytotrophoblasts (TROPHOBLASTS). Because its secretion of hCG (CHORIONIC GONADOTROPIN) is low
column3: a large tumor may develop before the hCG can be detected.

column1: C13.703.720.949.416*D031901*Gestational Trophoblastic Disease*A group of diseases arising from pregnancy that are commonly associated with hyperplasia of trophoblasts (TROPHOBLAST) and markedly elevated human CHORIONIC GONADOTROPIN. They include HYDATIDIFORM MOLE
column2: invasive mole (HYDATIDIFORM MOLE
column6: and CHORIOCARCINOMA. These neoplasms have varying propensities for invasion and spread.

column1: C13.703.720.949.416.875*D006828*Hydatidiform Mole*Trophoblastic hyperplasia associated with normal gestation
column2: or molar pregnancy. It is characterized by the swelling of the CHORIONIC VILLI and elevated human CHORIONIC GONADOTROPIN. Hydatidiform moles or molar pregnancy may be categorized as complete or partial based on their gross morphology
Invasive*A uterine tumor derived from persistent gestational TROPHOBLASTS
column3: most likely after a molar pregnancy (HYDATIDIFORM MOLE). Invasive hyadatiform mole develops in about 15% of patients after evacuation of a complete mole and less frequently after other types of gestation. It may perforate the MYOMETRIUM and erode uterine vessels causing hemorrhage.

column1: C13.703.726*D011254*Pregnancy in Diabetics*The state of PREGNANCY in women with DIABETES MELLITUS. This does not include either symptomatic diabetes or GLUCOSE INTOLERANCE induced by pregnancy (DIABETES
column2: GESTATIONAL) which resolves at the end of pregnancy.

column1: C13.703.726.570*D005320*Fetal Macrosomia*A condition of fetal overgrowth leading to a large-for-gestational-age FETUS. It is defined as BIRTH WEIGHT greater than 4
column2: 000 grams or above the 90th percentile for population and sex-specific growth curves. It is commonly seen in GESTATIONAL DIABETES; PROLONGED PREGNANCY; and pregnancies complicated by pre-existing diabetes mellitus.
Ectopic*A potentially life-threatening condition in which EMBRYO IMPLANTATION occurs outside the cavity of the UTERUS. Most ectopic pregnancies (>96%) occur in the FALLOPIAN TUBES
column3: known as TUBAL PREGNANCY. They can be in other locations
column4: such as UTERINE CERVIX; OVARY; and abdominal cavity (PREGNANCY

column2: Abdominal*A type of ectopic pregnancy in which the EMBRYO
column3: MAMMALIAN implants in the ABDOMINAL CAVITY instead of in the ENDOMETRIUM of the UTERUS.

column2: Angular*A rare type of abnormal pregnancy in which EMBRYO IMPLANTATION occurs at a lateral angle of the UTERUS
column3: medial to the uterotubal junction and the ROUND LIGAMENT OF UTERUS.

column2: Cornual*A type of pregnancy in which the EMBRYO IMPLANTATION occurs in the horn of the UTERUS instead of in the uterine cavity
column3: i.e. at the junction of the uterus and one of the FALLOPIAN TUBES.

column2: Heterotopic*MULTIPLE PREGNANCY with EMBRYO IMPLANTATION occuring at different locations

Postpartum*Depression in POSTPARTUM WOMEN

column1: C13.703.844.506.389.500*D002640*Chiari-Frommel Syndrome*A POSTPARTUM condition consists of persistent lactation (GALACTORRHEA) and AMENORRHEA in patients not BREAST FEEDING.

column1: C13.703.844.700*D006473*Postpartum Hemorrhage*Excess blood loss from uterine bleeding associated with OBSTETRIC LABOR or CHILDBIRTH. It is defined as blood loss greater than 500 ml or of the amount that adversely affects the maternal physiology

column3: then return to euthyroid state by 1 year postpartum.

column1: C13.703.844.728*D046548*Pubic Symphysis Diastasis*Separation of the PUBIC SYMPHYSIS. It is an uncommon complication of CHILDBIRTH causing postpartum PAIN

column1: C14.240.400.021*D058165*22q11 Deletion Syndrome*Condition with a variable constellation of phenotypes due to deletion polymorphisms at chromosome location 22q11. It encompasses several syndromes with overlapping abnormalities including the DIGEORGE SYNDROME

column1: C14.240.400.090*D001017*Aortic Coarctation*A birth defect characterized by the narrowing of the AORTA that can be of varying degree and at any point from the transverse arch to the iliac bifurcation. column1: C14.240.400.200*D003310*Cor Triatriatum*A malformation of the heart in which the embryonic common PULMONARY VEIN was not incorporated into the LEFT ATRIUM leaving behind a perforated fibromuscular membrane bisecting the left atrium

Other features include hypoplasia of the TRICUSPID VALVE and RIGHT VENTRICLE.
C14.240.400.280*D003914*Dextrocardia*A congenital defect in which the heart is located on the right side of the THORAX instead of on the left side (levocardia

column1: C14.240.400.280.500*D007619*Kartagener Syndrome*An autosomal recessive disorder characterized by a triad of DEXTROCARDIA; INFERTILITY; and SINUSITIS. The syndrome is caused by mutations of DYNEIN genes encoding motility proteins which are components of sperm tails

column1: C14.240.400.340*D004374*Ductus Arteriosus

column1: C14.240.400.560*D006343*Heart Septal Defects*Abnormalities in any part of the HEART SEPTUM resulting in abnormal communication between the left and the right chambers of the heart. The abnormal blood flow inside the heart may be caused by defects in the ATRIAL SEPTUM

column1: C14.240.400.560.375.518*D008185*Lutembacher Syndrome*A condition characterized by a combination of OSTIUM SECUNDUM ATRIAL SEPTAL DEFECT and an acquired MITRAL VALVE STENOSIS.
