column1: C14.907.109.139.175*D001019*Aortic Rupture*The tearing or bursting of the wall along any portion of the AORTA
column2: such as thoracic or abdominal. It may result from the rupture of an aneurysm or it may be due to TRAUMA.

column1: C14.907.109.139.587*D055947*Loeys-Dietz Syndrome*An autosomal dominant aneurysm with multisystem abnormalities caused by increased TGF-BETA signaling due to mutations in type I or II of TGF-BETA RECEPTOR. Additional craniofacial features include CLEFT PALATE; CRANIOSYNOSTOSIS; HYPERTELORISM; or bifid uvula. Phenotypes closely resemble MARFAN SYNDROME; Marfanoid craniosynostosis syndrome (Shprintzen-Goldberg syndrome); and EHLERS-DANLOS SYNDROME.
C14.907.109.239*D001015*Aortic Arch Syndromes*Conditions resulting from abnormalities in the arteries branching from the ASCENDING AORTA
column2: the curved portion of the aorta. These syndromes are results of occlusion or abnormal blood flow to the head-neck or arm region leading to neurological defects and weakness in an arm. These syndromes are associated with vascular malformations; ATHEROSCLEROSIS; TRAUMA; and blood clots.

column1: C14.907.109.239.650*D013625*Takayasu Arteritis*A chronic inflammatory process that affects the AORTA and its primary branches
column2: such as the brachiocephalic artery (BRACHIOCEPHALIC TRUNK) and CAROTID ARTERIES. It results in progressive arterial stenosis
column4: and aneurysm formation. The pulse in the arm is hard to detect. Patients with aortitis syndrome often exhibit retinopathy.

column1: C14.907.109.320*D001025*Aortitis*Inflammation of the wall of the AORTA.
C14.907.109.661*D007925*Leriche Syndrome*A condition caused by occlusion of terminal aorta
column2: the primary branches of the ABDOMINAL AORTA
column3: as in aortoiliac obstruction. Leriche syndrome usually occurs in males and is characterized by IMPOTENCE
column4: absence of a pulse in the femoral arteries
column5: weakness and numbness in the lower back

column1: C14.907.137*D001157*Arterial Occlusive Diseases*Pathological processes which result in the partial or complete obstruction of ARTERIES. They are characterized by greatly reduced or absence of blood flow through these vessels. They are also known as arterial insufficiency.
C14.907.137.126*D001161*Arteriosclerosis*Thickening and loss of elasticity of the walls of ARTERIES of all sizes. There are many forms classified by the types of lesions and arteries involved
column2: such as ATHEROSCLEROSIS with fatty lesions in the ARTERIAL INTIMA of medium and large muscular arteries.

column1: C14.907.137.126.056*D050379*Arteriolosclerosis*Thickening of the walls of small ARTERIES or ARTERIOLES due to cell proliferation or HYALINE deposition.

C14.907.137.126.114*D001162*Arteriosclerosis Obliterans*Common occlusive arterial disease which is caused by ATHEROSCLEROSIS. It is characterized by lesions in the innermost layer (ARTERIAL INTIMA) of arteries including the AORTA and its branches to the extremities. Risk factors include smoking
column2: HYPERLIPIDEMIA

column1: C14.907.137.126.307*D050197*Atherosclerosis*A thickening and loss of elasticity of the walls of ARTERIES that occurs with formation of ATHEROSCLEROTIC PLAQUES within the ARTERIAL INTIMA.
C14.907.137.126.307.500*D058729*Peripheral Arterial Disease*Lack of perfusion in the EXTREMITIES resulting from atherosclerosis. It is characterized by INTERMITTENT CLAUDICATION
column2: and an ANKLE BRACHIAL INDEX of 0.9 or less.

column1: C14.907.137.126.339*D003324*Coronary Artery Disease*Pathological processes of CORONARY ARTERIES that may derive from a congenital abnormality
column2: atherosclerotic

column1: C14.907.137.126.372*D002537*Intracranial Arteriosclerosis*Vascular diseases characterized by thickening and hardening of the walls of ARTERIES inside the SKULL. There are three subtypes: (1) atherosclerosis with fatty deposits in the ARTERIAL INTIMA; (2) Monckeberg's sclerosis with calcium deposits in the media and (3) arteriolosclerosis involving the small caliber arteries. Clinical signs include HEADACHE; CONFUSION; transient blindness (AMAUROSIS FUGAX); speech impairment; and HEMIPARESIS.

column2: Vascular*An imprecise term referring to dementia associated with CEREBROVASCULAR DISORDERS
column4: and conditions associated with chronic BRAIN ISCHEMIA. Diffuse
column6: and subcortical subtypes have been described. (From Gerontol Geriatr 1998 Feb;31(1):36-44)

column1: C14.907.137.126.669*D007383*Intermittent Claudication*A symptom complex characterized by pain and weakness in SKELETAL MUSCLE group associated with exercise
column2: such as leg pain and weakness brought on by walking. Such muscle limpness disappears after a brief rest and is often relates to arterial STENOSIS; muscle ISCHEMIA; and accumulation of LACTATE.

column1: C14.907.137.230*D016893*Carotid Stenosis*Narrowing or stricture of any part of the CAROTID ARTERIES
column2: most often due to atherosclerotic plaque formation. Ulcerations may form in atherosclerotic plaques and induce THROMBUS formation. Platelet or cholesterol emboli may arise from stenotic carotid lesions and induce a TRANSIENT ISCHEMIC ATTACK; CEREBROVASCULAR ACCIDENT; or temporary blindness (AMAUROSIS FUGAX). (From Adams et al.

column1: C14.907.137.372*D005352*Fibromuscular Dysplasia*An idiopathic
column2: segmental
column3: nonatheromatous disease of the musculature of arterial walls
column4: leading to STENOSIS of small and medium-sized arteries. There is true proliferation of SMOOTH MUSCLE CELLS and fibrous tissue. Fibromuscular dysplasia lesions are smooth stenosis and occur most often in the renal and carotid arteries. They may also occur in other peripheral arteries of the extremity.

column1: C14.907.137.427*D007925*Leriche Syndrome*A condition caused by occlusion of terminal aorta
column2: the primary branches of the ABDOMINAL AORTA
column3: as in aortoiliac obstruction. Leriche syndrome usually occurs in males and is characterized by IMPOTENCE
column4: absence of a pulse in the femoral arteries
column5: weakness and numbness in the lower back

column1: C14.907.137.520*D054853*Malignant Atrophic Papulosis*Variously described as a vasculopathy
column2: endovasculitis
column4: this condition occurs in a benign cutaneous form and a lethal multiorgan systemic variant. It is characterized by a narrowing and occlusion of the lumen of small to medium-sized blood vessels
column5: leading to ischemia and infarction in the involved organ systems. The etiology and pathophysiology are unknown.

column1: C14.907.137.534*D008641*Mesenteric Vascular Occlusion*Obstruction of the flow in the SPLANCHNIC CIRCULATION by ATHEROSCLEROSIS; EMBOLISM; THROMBOSIS; STENOSIS; TRAUMA; and compression or intrinsic pressure from adjacent tumors. Rare causes are drugs
column2: intestinal parasites
column3: and vascular immunoinflammatory diseases such as PERIARTERITIS NODOSA and THROMBOANGIITIS OBLITERANS. (From Juergens et al.

column1: C14.907.137.615*D009072*Moyamoya Disease*A noninflammatory
column2: progressive occlusion of the intracranial CAROTID ARTERIES and the formation of netlike collateral arteries arising from the CIRCLE OF WILLIS. Cerebral angiogram shows the puff-of-smoke (moyamoya) collaterals at the base of the brain. It is characterized by endothelial HYPERPLASIA and FIBROSIS with thickening of arterial walls. This disease primarily affects children but can also occur in adults.

column1: C14.907.137.727*D012078*Renal Artery Obstruction*Narrowing or occlusion of the RENAL ARTERY or arteries. It is due usually to ATHEROSCLEROSIS; FIBROMUSCULAR DYSPLASIA; THROMBOSIS; EMBOLISM
column2: or external pressure. The reduced renal perfusion can lead to renovascular hypertension (HYPERTENSION

column1: C14.907.137.780*D015356*Retinal Artery Occlusion*Sudden ISCHEMIA in the RETINA due to blocked blood flow through the CENTRAL RETINAL ARTERY or its branches leading to sudden complete or partial loss of vision
column2: respectively

column1: C14.907.137.780.500*D055955*Susac Syndrome*A rare disorder consisting of microangiopathy of brain
column2: retina
column3: and inner ear ARTERIOLES. It is characterized by the clinical triad of encephalopathy
column4: BRANCH RETINAL ARTERY OCCLUSION and VERTIGO/hearing loss.

column2: Pulmonary Artery*Narrowing of the PULMONARY ARTERIES.

column1: C14.907.137.870*D013919*Thromboangiitis Obliterans*A non-atherosclerotic
column2: inflammatory thrombotic disease that commonly involves small and medium-sized arteries or veins in the extremities. It is characterized by occlusive THROMBOSIS and FIBROSIS in the vascular wall leading to digital and limb ISCHEMIA and ulcerations. Thromboangiitis obliterans is highly associated with tobacco smoking.

column1: C14.907.150*D001165*Arteriovenous Malformations*Abnormal formation of blood vessels that shunt arterial blood directly into veins without passing through the CAPILLARIES. They usually are crooked
column2: dilated
column3: and with thick vessel walls. A common type is the congenital arteriovenous fistula. The lack of blood flow and oxygen in the capillaries can lead to tissue damage in the affected areas.

column1: C14.907.150.125*D001164*Arteriovenous Fistula*An abnormal direct communication between an artery and a vein without passing through the CAPILLARIES. An A-V fistula usually leads to the formation of a dilated sac-like connection
column2: arteriovenous aneurysm. The locations and size of the shunts determine the degree of effects on the cardiovascular functions such as BLOOD PRESSURE and HEART RATE.

column1: C14.907.150.125.500*D020216*Carotid-Cavernous Sinus Fistula*An acquired or spontaneous abnormality in which there is communication between CAVERNOUS SINUS
column2: a venous structure
column3: and the CAROTID ARTERIES. It is often associated with HEAD TRAUMA
column5: BASILAR). Clinical signs often include VISION DISORDERS and INTRACRANIAL HYPERTENSION.

column1: C14.907.150.295*D002538*Intracranial Arteriovenous Malformations*Congenital vascular anomalies in the brain characterized by direct communication between an artery and a vein without passing through the CAPILLARIES. The locations and size of the shunts determine the symptoms including HEADACHES; SEIZURES; STROKE; INTRACRANIAL HEMORRHAGES; mass effect; and vascular steal effect.
C14.907.150.295.500*D054080*Vein of Galen Malformations*Congenital arteriovenous malformation involving the VEIN OF GALEN
column2: a large deep vein at the base of the brain. The rush of arterial blood directly into the vein of Galen
column4: can overwhelm the heart and lead to CONGESTIVE HEART FAILURE.

column1: C14.907.218*D019559*Capillary Leak Syndrome*A condition characterized by recurring episodes of fluid leaking from capillaries into extra-vascular compartments causing hematocrit to rise precipitously. If not treated
column2: generalized vascular leak can lead to generalized EDEMA; SHOCK; cardiovascular collapse; and MULTIPLE ORGAN FAILURE.

column1: C14.907.253*D002561*Cerebrovascular Disorders*A spectrum of pathological conditions of impaired blood flow in the brain. They can involve vessels (ARTERIES or VEINS) in the CEREBRUM
column2: the CEREBELLUM
column3: and the BRAIN STEM. Major categories include INTRACRANIAL ARTERIOVENOUS MALFORMATIONS; BRAIN ISCHEMIA; CEREBRAL HEMORRHAGE; and others.

column1: C14.907.253.061*D020144*Basal Ganglia Cerebrovascular Disease*A pathological condition caused by impaired blood flow in the basal regions of cerebral hemispheres (BASAL GANGLIA)
column2: such as INFARCTION; HEMORRHAGE; or ISCHEMIA in vessels of this brain region including the lateral lenticulostriate arteries. Primary clinical manifestations include involuntary movements (DYSKINESIAS) and muscle weakness (HEMIPARESIS).

column1: C14.907.253.061.200*D020145*Basal Ganglia Hemorrhage*Bleeding within the subcortical regions of cerebral hemispheres (BASAL GANGLIA). It is often associated with HYPERTENSION or ARTERIOVENOUS MALFORMATIONS. Clinical manifestations may include HEADACHE; DYSKINESIAS; and HEMIPARESIS.
C14.907.253.061.200.500*D020146*Putaminal Hemorrhage*Intracranial bleeding into the PUTAMEN
column2: a BASAL GANGLIA nucleus. This is associated with HYPERTENSION and lipohyalinosis of small blood vessels in the putamen. Clinical manifestations vary with the size of hemorrhage
column3: but include HEMIPARESIS; HEADACHE; and alterations of consciousness.

column1: C14.907.253.092*D002545*Brain Ischemia*Localized reduction of blood flow to brain tissue due to arterial obstruction or systemic hypoperfusion. This frequently occurs in conjunction with brain hypoxia (HYPOXIA
column2: BRAIN). Prolonged ischemia is associated with BRAIN INFARCTION.

column1: C14.907.253.092.477*D020520*Brain Infarction*Tissue NECROSIS in any area of the brain
column2: including the CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES
column4: and the BRAIN STEM. Brain infarction is the result of a cascade of events initiated by inadequate blood flow through the brain that is followed by HYPOXIA and HYPOGLYCEMIA in brain tissue. Damage may be temporary

column1: C14.907.253.092.477.100*D020526*Brain Stem Infarctions*Infarctions that occur in the BRAIN STEM which is comprised of the MIDBRAIN; PONS; and MEDULLA OBLONGATA. There are several named syndromes characterized by their distinctive clinical manifestations and specific sites of ischemic injury.

C14.907.253.092.477.100.500*D014854*Lateral Medullary Syndrome*INFARCTION of the dorsolateral aspect of MEDULLA OBLONGATA in the BRAIN STEM. It is caused by occlusion of the VERTEBRAL ARTERY and/or the posterior inferior cerebellar artery. Clinical manifestations vary with the size of infarction
column2: but may include loss of pain and temperature sensation in the ipsilateral face and contralateral body below the chin; ipsilateral HORNER SYNDROME; ipsilateral ATAXIA; DYSARTHRIA; VERTIGO; nausea
column3: hiccup; dysphagia; and VOCAL CORD PARALYSIS. (From Adams et al.

column1: C14.907.253.092.477.200*D002544*Cerebral Infarction*The formation of an area of NECROSIS in the CEREBRUM caused by an insufficiency of arterial or venous blood flow. Infarcts of the cerebrum are generally classified by hemisphere (i.e.
column2: left vs. right)
Multi-Infarct*Loss of higher cortical functions with retained awareness due to multiple cortical or subcortical CEREBRAL INFARCTION. Memory
column5: and impulse control are often impaired
column6: and may be accompanied by PSEUDOBULBAR PALSY; HEMIPARESIS; reflex abnormalities
column7: and other signs of localized neurologic dysfunction. (From Adams et al.

column2: Anterior Cerebral Artery*NECROSIS occurring in the ANTERIOR CEREBRAL ARTERY system
column3: including branches such as Heubner's artery. These arteries supply blood to the medial and superior parts of the CEREBRAL HEMISPHERE
column4: Infarction in the anterior cerebral artery usually results in sensory and motor impairment in the lower body.

column2: Middle Cerebral Artery*NECROSIS occurring in the MIDDLE CEREBRAL ARTERY distribution system which brings blood to the entire lateral aspects of each CEREBRAL HEMISPHERE. Clinical signs include impaired cognition; APHASIA; AGRAPHIA; weak and numbness in the face and arms
column3: contralaterally or bilaterally depending on the infarction.

column2: Posterior Cerebral Artery*NECROSIS induced by ISCHEMIA in the POSTERIOR CEREBRAL ARTERY distribution system which supplies portions of the BRAIN STEM; the THALAMUS; TEMPORAL LOBE
column3: and OCCIPITAL LOBE. Depending on the size and location of infarction
column4: clinical features include OLFACTION DISORDERS and visual problems (AGNOSIA; ALEXIA; HEMIANOPSIA).

column2: Brain*A disorder characterized by a reduction of oxygen in the blood combined with reduced blood flow (ISCHEMIA) to the brain from a localized obstruction of a cerebral artery or from systemic hypoperfusion. Prolonged hypoxia-ischemia is associated with ISCHEMIC ATTACK
column3: TRANSIENT; BRAIN INFARCTION; BRAIN EDEMA; COMA; and other conditions.

column2: Transient*Brief reversible episodes of focal
column3: nonconvulsive ischemic dysfunction of the brain having a duration of less than 24 hours
column4: and usually less than one hour
column5: caused by transient thrombotic or embolic blood vessel occlusion or stenosis. Events may be classified by arterial distribution
column8: embolic vs. thrombotic). (From Adams et al.

column1: C14.907.253.092.956*D014715*Vertebrobasilar Insufficiency*Localized or diffuse reduction in blood flow through the vertebrobasilar arterial system
column2: which supplies the BRAIN STEM; CEREBELLUM; OCCIPITAL LOBE; medial TEMPORAL LOBE; and THALAMUS. Characteristic clinical features include SYNCOPE; lightheadedness; visual disturbances; and VERTIGO. BRAIN STEM INFARCTIONS or other BRAIN INFARCTION may be associated.

column1: C14.907.253.092.956.700*D013349*Subclavian Steal Syndrome*A clinically significant reduction in blood supply to the BRAIN STEM and CEREBELLUM (i.e.
column2: VERTEBROBASILAR INSUFFICIENCY) resulting from reversal of blood flow through the VERTEBRAL ARTERY from occlusion or stenosis of the proximal subclavian or brachiocephalic artery. Common symptoms include VERTIGO; SYNCOPE; and INTERMITTENT CLAUDICATION of the involved upper extremity. Subclavian steal may also occur in asymptomatic individuals. (From J Cardiovasc Surg 1994;35(1):11-4; Acta Neurol Scand 1994;90(3):174-8)

column1: C14.907.253.123*D002340*Carotid Artery Diseases*Pathological conditions involving the CAROTID ARTERIES
column2: including the common
column4: and external carotid arteries. ATHEROSCLEROSIS and TRAUMA are relatively frequent causes of carotid artery pathology.

column1: C14.907.253.123.345*D020212*Carotid Artery Injuries*Damages to the CAROTID ARTERIES caused either by blunt force or penetrating trauma
column2: such as CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA; THORACIC INJURIES; and NECK INJURIES. Damaged carotid arteries can lead to CAROTID ARTERY THROMBOSIS; CAROTID-CAVERNOUS SINUS FISTULA; pseudoaneurysm formation; and INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY DISSECTION. (From Am J Forensic Med Pathol 1997
Internal
column3: Dissection*The splitting of the vessel wall in one or both (left and right) internal carotid arteries (CAROTID ARTERY
column4: INTERNAL). Interstitial hemorrhage into the media of the vessel wall can lead to occlusion of the internal carotid artery and aneurysm formation.

column1: C14.907.253.123.355*D002341*Carotid Artery Thrombosis*Blood clot formation in any part of the CAROTID ARTERIES. This may produce CAROTID STENOSIS or occlusion of the vessel
column2: leading to TRANSIENT ISCHEMIC ATTACK; CEREBRAL INFARCTION; or AMAUROSIS FUGAX.

column1: C14.907.253.123.357*D020216*Carotid-Cavernous Sinus Fistula*An acquired or spontaneous abnormality in which there is communication between CAVERNOUS SINUS
column2: a venous structure
column3: and the CAROTID ARTERIES. It is often associated with HEAD TRAUMA
column5: BASILAR). Clinical signs often include VISION DISORDERS and INTRACRANIAL HYPERTENSION.

column1: C14.907.253.123.360*D016893*Carotid Stenosis*Narrowing or stricture of any part of the CAROTID ARTERIES
column2: most often due to atherosclerotic plaque formation. Ulcerations may form in atherosclerotic plaques and induce THROMBUS formation. Platelet or cholesterol emboli may arise from stenotic carotid lesions and induce a TRANSIENT ISCHEMIC ATTACK; CEREBROVASCULAR ACCIDENT; or temporary blindness (AMAUROSIS FUGAX). (From Adams et al.

column1: C14.907.253.123.620*D009072*Moyamoya Disease*A noninflammatory
column2: progressive occlusion of the intracranial CAROTID ARTERIES and the formation of netlike collateral arteries arising from the CIRCLE OF WILLIS. Cerebral angiogram shows the puff-of-smoke (moyamoya) collaterals at the base of the brain. It is characterized by endothelial HYPERPLASIA and FIBROSIS with thickening of arterial walls. This disease primarily affects children but can also occur in adults.

column1: C14.907.253.329*D059345*Cerebral Small Vessel Diseases*Pathological processes or diseases where cerebral MICROVESSELS show abnormalities. They are often associated with aging
column2: hypertension and risk factors for lacunar infarcts (see LACUNAR INFARCTION); LEUKOARAIOSIS; and CEREBRAL HEMORRHAGE.

column1: C14.907.253.329.249*D046589*CADASIL*A familial
column2: cerebral arteriopathy mapped to chromosome 19q12
column3: and characterized by the presence of granular deposits in small CEREBRAL ARTERIES producing ischemic STROKE; PSEUDOBULBAR PALSY; and multiple subcortical infarcts (CEREBRAL INFARCTION). CADASIL is an acronym for Cerebral Autosomal Dominant Arteriopathy with Subcortical Infarcts and Leukoencephalopathy. CADASIL differs from BINSWANGER DISEASE by the presence of MIGRAINE WITH AURA and usually by the lack of history of arterial HYPERTENSION. (From Bradley et al

column2: Familial*A familial disorder marked by AMYLOID deposits in the walls of small and medium sized blood vessels of CEREBRAL CORTEX and MENINGES.

column1: C14.907.253.329.374*D000795*Fabry Disease*An X-linked inherited metabolic disease caused by a deficiency of lysosomal ALPHA-GALACTOSIDASE A. It is characterized by intralysosomal accumulation of globotriaosylceramide and other GLYCOSPHINGOLIPIDS in blood vessels throughout the body leading to multi-system complications including renal
column2: cardiac

column1: C14.907.253.329.500*D017241*MELAS Syndrome*A mitochondrial disorder characterized by focal or generalized seizures

column3: and ragged-red fibers on muscle biopsy. Affected individuals tend to be normal at birth through early childhood
column6: and recurrent cerebral insults resulting in visual loss and hemiparesis. The cortical lesions tend to occur in the parietal and occipital lobes and are not associated with vascular occlusion. VASCULAR HEADACHE is frequently associated and the disorder tends to be familial. (From Joynt

column1: C14.907.253.329.600*D055953*Microscopic Polyangiitis*A primary systemic vasculitis of small- and some medium-sized vessels. It is characterized by a tropism for kidneys and lungs
column2: positive association with anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA)
column3: and a paucity of immunoglobulin deposits in vessel walls.

column2: Lacunar*Stroke caused by lacunar infarction or other small vessel diseases of the brain. It features hemiparesis (see PARESIS)

column2: and venous sinuses.

column1: C14.907.253.535.800*D020217*Vertebral Artery Dissection*Splitting of the vessel wall in the VERTEBRAL ARTERY. Interstitial hemorrhage into the media of the vessel wall can lead to occlusion of the vertebral artery
column2: aneurysm formation
column3: or THROMBOEMBOLISM. Vertebral artery dissection is often associated with TRAUMA and injuries to the head-neck region but can occur spontaneously.

column5: and associated structures. They include atherosclerotic

column1: C14.907.253.560.200*D002539*Cerebral Arterial Diseases*Pathological conditions of intracranial ARTERIES supplying the CEREBRUM. These diseases often are due to abnormalities or pathological processes in the ANTERIOR CEREBRAL ARTERY; MIDDLE CEREBRAL ARTERY; and POSTERIOR CEREBRAL ARTERY.

column1: C14.907.253.560.200.200*D016657*Cerebral Amyloid Angiopathy*A heterogeneous group of sporadic or familial disorders characterized by AMYLOID deposits in the walls of small and medium sized blood vessels of CEREBRAL CORTEX and MENINGES. Clinical features include multiple

Amyloidogenic peptides in this condition are nearly always the same ones found in ALZHEIMER DISEASE. (from Kumar: Robbins and Cotran: Pathologic Basis of Disease

column1: C14.907.253.560.200.737*D009072*Moyamoya Disease*A noninflammatory
column2: progressive occlusion of the intracranial CAROTID ARTERIES and the formation of netlike collateral arteries arising from the CIRCLE OF WILLIS. Cerebral angiogram shows the puff-of-smoke (moyamoya) collaterals at the base of the brain. It is characterized by endothelial HYPERPLASIA and FIBROSIS with thickening of arterial walls. This disease primarily affects children but can also occur in adults.

column1: C14.907.253.560.300*D002532*Intracranial Aneurysm*Abnormal outpouching in the wall of intracranial blood vessels. Most common are the saccular (berry) aneurysms located at branch points in CIRCLE OF WILLIS at the base of the brain. Vessel rupture results in SUBARACHNOID HEMORRHAGE or INTRACRANIAL HEMORRHAGES. Giant aneurysms (>2.5 cm in diameter) may compress adjacent structures
column2: including the OCULOMOTOR NERVE. (From Adams et al.

column1: C14.907.253.560.350*D002537*Intracranial Arteriosclerosis*Vascular diseases characterized by thickening and hardening of the walls of ARTERIES inside the SKULL. There are three subtypes: (1) atherosclerosis with fatty deposits in the ARTERIAL INTIMA; (2) Monckeberg's sclerosis with calcium deposits in the media and (3) arteriolosclerosis involving the small caliber arteries. Clinical signs include HEADACHE; CONFUSION; transient blindness (AMAUROSIS FUGAX); speech impairment; and HEMIPARESIS.

column2: Vascular*An imprecise term referring to dementia associated with CEREBROVASCULAR DISORDERS
column4: and conditions associated with chronic BRAIN ISCHEMIA. Diffuse
column6: and subcortical subtypes have been described. (From Gerontol Geriatr 1998 Feb;31(1):36-44)

column1: C14.907.253.560.400*D002538*Intracranial Arteriovenous Malformations*Congenital vascular anomalies in the brain characterized by direct communication between an artery and a vein without passing through the CAPILLARIES. The locations and size of the shunts determine the symptoms including HEADACHES; SEIZURES; STROKE; INTRACRANIAL HEMORRHAGES; mass effect; and vascular steal effect.
C14.907.253.560.400.500*D054080*Vein of Galen Malformations*Congenital arteriovenous malformation involving the VEIN OF GALEN
column2: a large deep vein at the base of the brain. The rush of arterial blood directly into the vein of Galen
column4: can overwhelm the heart and lead to CONGESTIVE HEART FAILURE.

column1: C14.907.253.566*D002542*Intracranial Embolism and Thrombosis*Embolism or thrombosis involving blood vessels which supply intracranial structures. Emboli may originate from extracranial or intracranial sources. Thrombosis may occur in arterial or venous structures.
C14.907.253.566.206*D002341*Carotid Artery Thrombosis*Blood clot formation in any part of the CAROTID ARTERIES. This may produce CAROTID STENOSIS or occlusion of the vessel
column2: leading to TRANSIENT ISCHEMIC ATTACK; CEREBRAL INFARCTION; or AMAUROSIS FUGAX.

column1: C14.907.253.566.300*D020766*Intracranial Embolism*Blocking of a blood vessel in the SKULL by an EMBOLUS which can be a blood clot (THROMBUS) or other undissolved material in the blood stream. Most emboli are of cardiac origin and are associated with HEART DISEASES. Other non-cardiac sources of emboli are usually associated with VASCULAR DISEASES.

C14.907.253.566.350*D020767*Intracranial Thrombosis*Formation or presence of a blood clot (THROMBUS) in a blood vessel within the SKULL. Intracranial thrombosis can lead to thrombotic occlusions and BRAIN INFARCTION. The majority of the thrombotic occlusions are associated with ATHEROSCLEROSIS.

column2: Intracranial*Formation or presence of a blood clot (THROMBUS) in the CRANIAL SINUSES
column3: large endothelium-lined venous channels situated within the SKULL. Intracranial sinuses
column9: and many others. Cranial sinus thrombosis can lead to severe HEADACHE; SEIZURE; and other neurological defects.

column1: C14.907.253.566.350.500.375*D020226*Cavernous Sinus Thrombosis*Formation or presence of a blood clot (THROMBUS) in the CAVERNOUS SINUS of the brain. Infections of the paranasal sinuses and adjacent structures
column2: CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA
column3: and THROMBOPHILIA are associated conditions. Clinical manifestations include dysfunction of cranial nerves III
column10: and visual loss. (From Adams et al.

column1: C14.907.253.566.350.500.562*D020227*Lateral Sinus Thrombosis*Formation or presence of a blood clot (THROMBUS) in the LATERAL SINUSES. This condition is often associated with ear infections (OTITIS MEDIA or MASTOIDITIS) without antibiotic treatment. In developed nations
column2: lateral sinus thrombosis can result from CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA; BRAIN NEOPLASMS; NEUROSURGICAL PROCEDURES; THROMBOPHILIA; and other conditions. Clinical features include HEADACHE; VERTIGO; and increased intracranial pressure.

column1: C14.907.253.566.350.500.750*D020225*Sagittal Sinus Thrombosis*Formation or presence of a blood clot (THROMBUS) in the SUPERIOR SAGITTAL SINUS or the inferior sagittal sinus. Sagittal sinus thrombosis can result from infections
column2: hematological disorders
column3: CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA; and NEUROSURGICAL PROCEDURES. Clinical features are primarily related to the increased intracranial pressure causing HEADACHE; NAUSEA; and VOMITING. Severe cases can evolve to SEIZURES or COMA.

column1: C14.907.253.573*D020300*Intracranial Hemorrhages*Bleeding within the SKULL
column2: including hemorrhages in the brain and the three membranes of MENINGES. The escape of blood often leads to the formation of HEMATOMA in the cranial epidural

column1: C14.907.253.573.200*D002543*Cerebral Hemorrhage*Bleeding into one or both CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES including the BASAL GANGLIA and the CEREBRAL CORTEX. It is often associated with HYPERTENSION and CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA.

C14.907.253.573.200.150*D020145*Basal Ganglia Hemorrhage*Bleeding within the subcortical regions of cerebral hemispheres (BASAL GANGLIA). It is often associated with HYPERTENSION or ARTERIOVENOUS MALFORMATIONS. Clinical manifestations may include HEADACHE; DYSKINESIAS; and HEMIPARESIS.
C14.907.253.573.200.150.500*D020146*Putaminal Hemorrhage*Intracranial bleeding into the PUTAMEN
column2: a BASAL GANGLIA nucleus. This is associated with HYPERTENSION and lipohyalinosis of small blood vessels in the putamen. Clinical manifestations vary with the size of hemorrhage
column3: but include HEMIPARESIS; HEADACHE; and alterations of consciousness.

column1: C14.907.253.573.200.200*D020202*Cerebral Hemorrhage
column2: Traumatic*Bleeding into one or both CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES due to TRAUMA. Hemorrhage may involve any part of the CEREBRAL CORTEX and the BASAL GANGLIA. Depending on the severity of bleeding
column3: clinical features may include SEIZURES; APHASIA; VISION DISORDERS; MOVEMENT DISORDERS; PARALYSIS; and COMA.

column1: C14.907.253.573.350*D020299*Intracranial Hemorrhage
column2: Hypertensive*Bleeding within the SKULL that is caused by systemic HYPERTENSION
column3: usually in association with INTRACRANIAL ARTERIOSCLEROSIS. Hypertensive hemorrhages are most frequent in the BASAL GANGLIA; CEREBELLUM; PONS; and THALAMUS; but may also involve the CEREBRAL CORTEX

column1: C14.907.253.573.400*D020198*Intracranial Hemorrhage
column2: Traumatic*Bleeding within the SKULL induced by penetrating and nonpenetrating traumatic injuries
column3: including hemorrhages into the tissues of CEREBRUM; BRAIN STEM; and CEREBELLUM; as well as into the epidural
column4: subdural and subarachnoid spaces of the MENINGES.

column2: Traumatic*Bleeding within the brain as a result of penetrating and nonpenetrating CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA. Traumatically induced hemorrhages may occur in any area of the brain
column3: including the CEREBRUM; BRAIN STEM (see BRAIN STEM HEMORRHAGE

column2: Traumatic*Bleeding into structures of BRAIN STEM

column4: as the result of CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA. DIFFUSE AXONAL INJURY is commonly associated. Clinical manifestations may include OCULAR MOTILITY DISORDERS; ATAXIA; PARALYSIS; PERSISTENT VEGETATIVE STATE; and COMA.

column2: Traumatic*Bleeding into one or both CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES due to TRAUMA. Hemorrhage may involve any part of the CEREBRAL CORTEX and the BASAL GANGLIA. Depending on the severity of bleeding

column2: Epidural

column2: Subdural*Accumulation of blood in the SUBDURAL SPACE between the DURA MATER and the arachnoidal layer of the MENINGES. This condition primarily occurs over the surface of a CEREBRAL HEMISPHERE
column3: but may develop in the spinal canal (HEMATOMA
column5: SPINAL). Subdural hematoma can be classified as the acute or the chronic form

column2: Subdural

column2: Subdural

column2: Subdural
column3: Intracranial*Accumulation of blood in the SUBDURAL SPACE over the CEREBRAL HEMISPHERE.

column1: C14.907.253.573.400.700*D020206*Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
column2: Traumatic*Bleeding into the SUBARACHNOID SPACE due to CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA. Minor hemorrhages may be asymptomatic; moderate to severe hemorrhages may be associated with INTRACRANIAL HYPERTENSION and VASOSPASM

column1: C14.907.253.573.600*D010899*Pituitary Apoplexy*The sudden loss of blood supply to the PITUITARY GLAND
column2: leading to tissue NECROSIS and loss of function (PANHYPOPITUITARISM). The most common cause is hemorrhage or INFARCTION of a PITUITARY ADENOMA. It can also result from acute hemorrhage into SELLA TURCICA due to HEAD TRAUMA; INTRACRANIAL HYPERTENSION; or other acute effects of central nervous system hemorrhage. Clinical signs include severe HEADACHE; HYPOTENSION; bilateral visual disturbances; UNCONSCIOUSNESS; and COMA.

column1: C14.907.253.573.800.700*D020206*Subarachnoid Hemorrhage

Periventricular*Degeneration of white matter adjacent to the CEREBRAL VENTRICLES following cerebral hypoxia or BRAIN ISCHEMIA in neonates. The condition primarily affects white matter in the perfusion zone between superficial and deep branches of the MIDDLE CEREBRAL ARTERY. Clinical manifestations include VISION DISORDERS; CEREBRAL PALSY; PARAPLEGIA; SEIZURES; and cognitive disorders. (From Adams et al.

column8: and changes in the media. (From Jablonski

column1: C14.907.253.855.200.100*D020526*Brain Stem Infarctions*Infarctions that occur in the BRAIN STEM which is comprised of the MIDBRAIN; PONS; and MEDULLA OBLONGATA. There are several named syndromes characterized by their distinctive clinical manifestations and specific sites of ischemic injury.

C14.907.253.855.200.100.500*D014854*Lateral Medullary Syndrome*INFARCTION of the dorsolateral aspect of MEDULLA OBLONGATA in the BRAIN STEM. It is caused by occlusion of the VERTEBRAL ARTERY and/or the posterior inferior cerebellar artery. Clinical manifestations vary with the size of infarction
column2: but may include loss of pain and temperature sensation in the ipsilateral face and contralateral body below the chin; ipsilateral HORNER SYNDROME; ipsilateral ATAXIA; DYSARTHRIA; VERTIGO; nausea
column3: hiccup; dysphagia; and VOCAL CORD PARALYSIS. (From Adams et al.

column1: C14.907.253.855.200.200*D002544*Cerebral Infarction*The formation of an area of NECROSIS in the CEREBRUM caused by an insufficiency of arterial or venous blood flow. Infarcts of the cerebrum are generally classified by hemisphere (i.e.
column2: left vs. right)
Multi-Infarct*Loss of higher cortical functions with retained awareness due to multiple cortical or subcortical CEREBRAL INFARCTION. Memory
column5: and impulse control are often impaired
column6: and may be accompanied by PSEUDOBULBAR PALSY; HEMIPARESIS; reflex abnormalities
column7: and other signs of localized neurologic dysfunction. (From Adams et al.

column2: Anterior Cerebral Artery*NECROSIS occurring in the ANTERIOR CEREBRAL ARTERY system
column3: including branches such as Heubner's artery. These arteries supply blood to the medial and superior parts of the CEREBRAL HEMISPHERE
column4: Infarction in the anterior cerebral artery usually results in sensory and motor impairment in the lower body.

column2: Middle Cerebral Artery*NECROSIS occurring in the MIDDLE CEREBRAL ARTERY distribution system which brings blood to the entire lateral aspects of each CEREBRAL HEMISPHERE. Clinical signs include impaired cognition; APHASIA; AGRAPHIA; weak and numbness in the face and arms
column3: contralaterally or bilaterally depending on the infarction.

column2: Posterior Cerebral Artery*NECROSIS induced by ISCHEMIA in the POSTERIOR CEREBRAL ARTERY distribution system which supplies portions of the BRAIN STEM; the THALAMUS; TEMPORAL LOBE
column3: and OCCIPITAL LOBE. Depending on the size and location of infarction
column4: clinical features include OLFACTION DISORDERS and visual problems (AGNOSIA; ALEXIA; HEMIANOPSIA).

column2: Lacunar*Stroke caused by lacunar infarction or other small vessel diseases of the brain. It features hemiparesis (see PARESIS)

column1: C14.907.253.937*D014653*Vascular Headaches*Secondary headache disorders attributed to a variety of cranial or cervical vascular disorders
column2: such as BRAIN ISCHEMIA; INTRACRANIAL HEMORRHAGES; and CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM VASCULAR MALFORMATIONS.
Central Nervous System*Inflammation of blood vessels within the central nervous system. Primary vasculitis is usually caused by autoimmune or idiopathic factors
column3: while secondary vasculitis is caused by existing disease process. Clinical manifestations are highly variable but include HEADACHE; SEIZURES; behavioral alterations; INTRACRANIAL HEMORRHAGES; TRANSIENT ISCHEMIC ATTACK; and BRAIN INFARCTION. (From Adams et al.

column2: Central Nervous System*Inflammation of ARTERIES in the CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM that occurs in patients with ACQUIRED IMMUNODEFICIENCY SYNDROME or AIDS-RELATED OPPORTUNISTIC INFECTIONS.

column1: C14.907.253.946.700*D013700*Giant Cell Arteritis*A systemic autoimmune disorder that typically affects medium and large ARTERIES
column2: usually leading to occlusive granulomatous vasculitis with transmural infiltrate containing multinucleated GIANT CELLS. The TEMPORAL ARTERY is commonly involved. This disorder appears primarily in people over the age of 50. Symptoms include FEVER; FATIGUE; HEADACHE; visual impairment; pain in the jaw and tongue; and aggravation of pain by cold temperatures. (From Adams et al.

Central Nervous System*Central nervous system vasculitis that is associated with SYSTEMIC LUPUS ERYTHEMATOSUS. Clinical manifestations may include DEMENTIA; SEIZURES; CRANIAL NERVE DISEASES; HEMIPARESIS; BLINDNESS; DYSPHASIA; and other neurological disorders.
Intracranial*Constriction of arteries in the SKULL due to sudden
column4: and often persistent smooth muscle contraction in blood vessels. Intracranial vasospasm results in reduced vessel lumen caliber
column5: restricted blood flow to the brain
column6: and BRAIN ISCHEMIA that may lead to hypoxic-ischemic brain injury (HYPOXIA-ISCHEMIA

column2: Ischemic*Inflammation of the COLON due to colonic ISCHEMIA resulting from alterations in systemic circulation or local vasculature.

column1: C14.907.303*D003161*Compartment Syndromes*Conditions in which increased pressure within a limited space compromises the BLOOD CIRCULATION and function of tissue within that space. Some of the causes of increased pressure are TRAUMA
column2: tight dressings
column4: and exercise. Sequelae include nerve compression (NERVE COMPRESSION SYNDROMES); PARALYSIS; and ISCHEMIC CONTRACTURE.

column1: C14.907.303.063*D000868*Anterior Compartment Syndrome*Rapid swelling
column2: increased tension
column4: and ischemic necrosis of the muscles of the anterior tibial compartment of the leg

column1: C14.907.303.297*D059325*Intra-Abdominal Hypertension*Pathological elevation of intra-abdominal pressure (>12 mm Hg). It may develop as a result of SEPSIS; PANCREATITIS; capillary leaks
column2: burns
column3: or surgery. When the pressure is higher than 20 mm Hg
column5: it is referred to as abdominal compartment syndrome.

column1: C14.907.303.531*D054061*Ischemic Contracture*A type of permanent damage to muscles and nerves that results from prolonged lack blood flow to those tissues. It is characterized by shortening and stiffening of the muscles.
C14.907.320*D003925*Diabetic Angiopathies*VASCULAR DISEASES that are associated with DIABETES MELLITUS.
C14.907.320.191*D017719*Diabetic Foot*Common foot problems in persons with DIABETES MELLITUS
column2: caused by any combination of factors such as DIABETIC NEUROPATHIES; PERIPHERAL VASCULAR DISEASES; and INFECTION. With the loss of sensation and poor circulation
column3: injuries and infections often lead to severe foot ulceration

column1: C14.907.320.382*D003930*Diabetic Retinopathy*Disease of the RETINA as a complication of DIABETES MELLITUS. It is characterized by the progressive microvascular complications
column2: such as ANEURYSM

column1: C14.907.355*D016769*Embolism and Thrombosis*A collective term for pathological conditions which are caused by the formation of a blood clot (THROMBUS) in a blood vessel
column2: or by blocking of a blood vessel with an EMBOLUS
column3: undissolved materials in the blood stream.

column1: C14.907.355.350*D004617*Embolism*Blocking of a blood vessel by an embolus which can be a blood clot or other undissolved material in the blood stream.

column2: Air*Blocking of a blood vessel by air bubbles that enter the circulatory system

Amniotic Fluid*Blocking of maternal circulation by AMNIOTIC FLUID that is forced into uterine VEINS by strong UTERINE CONTRACTION near the end of pregnancy. It is characterized by the sudden onset of severe respiratory distress and HYPOTENSION that can lead to maternal DEATH.
Fat*Blocking of a blood vessel by fat deposits in the circulation. It is often seen after fractures of large bones or after administration of CORTICOSTEROIDS.
Cholesterol*Blocking of a blood vessel by CHOLESTEROL-rich atheromatous deposits
column3: generally occurring in the flow from a large artery to small arterial branches. It is also called arterial-arterial embolization or atheroembolism which may be spontaneous or iatrogenic. Patients with spontaneous atheroembolism often have painful

column1: C14.907.355.350.454.500.200*D018438*Blue Toe Syndrome*A condition that is caused by recurring atheroembolism in the lower extremities. It is characterized by cyanotic discoloration of the toes
column2: usually the first
column4: and fifth toes. Discoloration may extend to the lateral aspect of the foot. Despite the gangrene-like appearance
column5: blue toes may respond to conservative therapy without amputation.

column1: C14.907.355.350.700*D011655*Pulmonary Embolism*Blocking of the PULMONARY ARTERY or one of its branches by an EMBOLUS.

C14.907.355.350.700.500*D054060*Pulmonary Infarction*NECROSIS of lung tissue that is cause by the lack of OXYGEN or blood supply. The most common cause of pulmonary infarction is a blood clot in the lung.
C14.907.355.590*D013923*Thromboembolism*Obstruction of a blood vessel (embolism) by a blood clot (THROMBUS) in the blood stream.

C14.907.355.590.213*D002542*Intracranial Embolism and Thrombosis*Embolism or thrombosis involving blood vessels which supply intracranial structures. Emboli may originate from extracranial or intracranial sources. Thrombosis may occur in arterial or venous structures.
C14.907.355.590.213.206*D002341*Carotid Artery Thrombosis*Blood clot formation in any part of the CAROTID ARTERIES. This may produce CAROTID STENOSIS or occlusion of the vessel
column2: leading to TRANSIENT ISCHEMIC ATTACK; CEREBRAL INFARCTION; or AMAUROSIS FUGAX.

column1: C14.907.355.590.213.300*D020766*Intracranial Embolism*Blocking of a blood vessel in the SKULL by an EMBOLUS which can be a blood clot (THROMBUS) or other undissolved material in the blood stream. Most emboli are of cardiac origin and are associated with HEART DISEASES. Other non-cardiac sources of emboli are usually associated with VASCULAR DISEASES.

C14.907.355.590.213.350*D020767*Intracranial Thrombosis*Formation or presence of a blood clot (THROMBUS) in a blood vessel within the SKULL. Intracranial thrombosis can lead to thrombotic occlusions and BRAIN INFARCTION. The majority of the thrombotic occlusions are associated with ATHEROSCLEROSIS.

column2: Intracranial*Formation or presence of a blood clot (THROMBUS) in the CRANIAL SINUSES
column3: large endothelium-lined venous channels situated within the SKULL. Intracranial sinuses
column9: and many others. Cranial sinus thrombosis can lead to severe HEADACHE; SEIZURE; and other neurological defects.

column1: C14.907.355.590.213.350.500.375*D020226*Cavernous Sinus Thrombosis*Formation or presence of a blood clot (THROMBUS) in the CAVERNOUS SINUS of the brain. Infections of the paranasal sinuses and adjacent structures
column2: CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA
column3: and THROMBOPHILIA are associated conditions. Clinical manifestations include dysfunction of cranial nerves III
column10: and visual loss. (From Adams et al.

column1: C14.907.355.590.213.350.500.562*D020227*Lateral Sinus Thrombosis*Formation or presence of a blood clot (THROMBUS) in the LATERAL SINUSES. This condition is often associated with ear infections (OTITIS MEDIA or MASTOIDITIS) without antibiotic treatment. In developed nations
column2: lateral sinus thrombosis can result from CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA; BRAIN NEOPLASMS; NEUROSURGICAL PROCEDURES; THROMBOPHILIA; and other conditions. Clinical features include HEADACHE; VERTIGO; and increased intracranial pressure.

column1: C14.907.355.590.213.350.500.750*D020225*Sagittal Sinus Thrombosis*Formation or presence of a blood clot (THROMBUS) in the SUPERIOR SAGITTAL SINUS or the inferior sagittal sinus. Sagittal sinus thrombosis can result from infections
column2: hematological disorders
column3: CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA; and NEUROSURGICAL PROCEDURES. Clinical features are primarily related to the increased intracranial pressure causing HEADACHE; NAUSEA; and VOMITING. Severe cases can evolve to SEIZURES or COMA.

column2: Paradoxical*Blockage of an artery due to passage of a clot (THROMBUS) from a systemic vein to a systemic artery without its passing through the lung which acts as a filter to remove blood clots from entering the arterial circulation. Paradoxical embolism occurs when there is a defect that allows a clot to cross directly from the right to the left side of the heart as in the cases of ATRIAL SEPTAL DEFECTS or open FORAMEN OVALE. Once in the arterial circulation
column3: a clot can travel to the brain

column1: C14.907.355.590.700*D054556*Venous Thromboembolism*Obstruction of a vein or VEINS (embolism) by a blood clot (THROMBUS) in the blood stream.
C14.907.355.830*D013927*Thrombosis*Formation and development of a thrombus or blood clot in the blood vessel.
C14.907.355.830.220*D003328*Coronary Thrombosis*Coagulation of blood in any of the CORONARY VESSELS. The presence of a blood clot (THROMBUS) often leads to MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION.
C14.907.355.830.925*D020246*Venous Thrombosis*The formation or presence of a blood clot (THROMBUS) within a vein.

C14.907.355.830.925.275*D006502*Budd-Chiari Syndrome*A condition in which the hepatic venous outflow is obstructed anywhere from the small HEPATIC VEINS to the junction of the INFERIOR VENA CAVA and the RIGHT ATRIUM. Usually the blockage is extrahepatic and caused by blood clots (THROMBUS) or fibrous webs. Parenchymal FIBROSIS is uncommon.
C14.907.355.830.925.462*D054070*Postthrombotic Syndrome*A condition caused by one or more episodes of DEEP VEIN THROMBOSIS
column2: usually the blood clots are lodged in the legs. Clinical features include EDEMA; PAIN; aching; heaviness; and MUSCLE CRAMP in the leg. When severe leg swelling leads to skin breakdown
column3: it is called venous STASIS ULCER.

column1: C14.907.355.830.925.650*D012170*Retinal Vein Occlusion*Blockage of the RETINAL VEIN. Those at high risk for this condition include patients with HYPERTENSION; DIABETES MELLITUS; ATHEROSCLEROSIS; and other CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES.
C14.907.355.830.925.770*D013924*Thrombophlebitis*Inflammation of a vein associated with a blood clot (THROMBUS).

C14.907.355.830.925.770.500*D057831*Lemierre Syndrome*A superinfection of the damaged oropharyngeal mucosa by FUSOBACTERIUM NECROPHORUM leading to the secondary septic THROMBOPHLEBITIS of the internal jugular vein.
C14.907.355.830.925.885*D056824*Upper Extremity Deep Vein Thrombosis*DEEP VEIN THROMBOSIS of an upper extremity vein (e.g.
column2: AXILLARY VEIN; SUBCLAVIAN VEIN; and JUGULAR VEINS). It is associated with mechanical factors (Upper Extremity Deep Vein Thrombosis
column3: Primary) secondary to other anatomic factors (Upper Extremity Deep Vein Thrombosis
column4: Secondary). Symptoms may include sudden onset of pain

column1: C14.907.440*D053421*Hand-Arm Vibration Syndrome*An occupational disorder resulting from prolonged exposure to vibration
column2: affecting the fingers
column4: and forearms. It occurs in workers who regularly use vibrating tools such as jackhammers
column7: etc. Symptoms include episodic finger blanching

column1: C14.907.449*D006484*Hemorrhoids*Swollen veins in the lower part of the RECTUM or ANUS. Hemorrhoids can be inside the anus (internal)
column2: under the skin around the anus (external)
column3: or protruding from inside to outside of the anus. People with hemorrhoids may or may not exhibit symptoms which include bleeding

column1: C14.907.454*D020141*Hemostatic Disorders*Pathological processes involving the integrity of blood circulation. Hemostasis depends on the integrity of BLOOD VESSELS
column2: blood fluidity
column3: and BLOOD COAGULATION. Majority of the hemostatic disorders are caused by disruption of the normal interaction between the VASCULAR ENDOTHELIUM
column4: the plasma proteins (including BLOOD COAGULATION FACTORS)

column1: C14.907.454.140*D003449*Cryoglobulinemia*A condition characterized by the presence of abnormal quantities of CRYOGLOBULINS in the blood. Upon cold exposure
column2: these abnormal proteins precipitate into the microvasculature leading to restricted blood flow in the exposed areas.

column1: C14.907.454.240*D004535*Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome*A heterogeneous group of autosomally inherited COLLAGEN DISEASES caused by defects in the synthesis or structure of FIBRILLAR COLLAGEN. There are numerous subtypes: classical
column2: hypermobility
column4: and others. Common clinical features include hyperextensible skin and joints
column5: skin fragility and reduced wound healing capability.

column2: Cavernous*A vascular anomaly that is a collection of tortuous BLOOD VESSELS and connective tissue. This tumor-like mass with the large vascular space is filled with blood and usually appears as a strawberry-like lesion in the subcutaneous areas of the face
column4: or other regions of the body including the central nervous system.

column2: Cavernous
column3: Central Nervous System*A vascular anomaly composed of a collection of large
column4: thin walled tortuous VEINS that can occur in any part of the central nervous system but lack intervening nervous tissue. Familial occurrence is common and has been associated with a number of genes mapped to 7q
column5: 7p and 3q. Clinical features include SEIZURES; HEADACHE; STROKE; and progressive neurological deficit.

column1: C14.907.454.460*D009101*Multiple Myeloma*A malignancy of mature PLASMA CELLS engaging in monoclonal immunoglobulin production. It is characterized by hyperglobulinemia
column2: excess Bence-Jones proteins (free monoclonal IMMUNOGLOBULIN LIGHT CHAINS) in the urine
column5: and fractures. Other features include ANEMIA; HYPERCALCEMIA; and RENAL INSUFFICIENCY.

column1: C14.907.454.530*D011561*Pseudoxanthoma Elasticum*An inherited disorder of connective tissue with extensive degeneration and calcification of ELASTIC TISSUE primarily in the skin
column2: eye
column3: and vasculature. At least two forms exist
column4: autosomal recessive and autosomal dominant. This disorder is caused by mutations of one of the ATP-BINDING CASSETTE TRANSPORTERS. Patients are predisposed to MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION and GASTROINTESTINAL HEMORRHAGE.

column2: Hyperglobulinemic*Purplish or brownish red discoloration of the skin associated with increase in circulating polyclonal globulins
column3: usually GAMMA-GLOBULINS. This syndrome often occurs on the legs of women aged 20 to 40 years.

column1: C14.907.454.800*D012614*Scurvy*An acquired blood vessel disorder caused by severe deficiency of vitamin C (ASCORBIC ACID) in the diet leading to defective collagen formation in small blood vessels. Scurvy is characterized by bleeding in any tissue
column2: weakness
column5: and a brawny induration of the muscles of the calves and legs.

column1: C14.907.454.810*D012790*Shwartzman Phenomenon*Hemorrhagic necrosis that was first demonstrated in rabbits with a two-step reaction
column2: an initial local (intradermal) or general (intravenous) injection of a priming endotoxin (ENDOTOXINS) followed by a second intravenous endotoxin injection (provoking agent) 24 h later. The acute inflammation damages the small blood vessels. The following intravascular coagulation leads to capillary and venous THROMBOSIS and NECROSIS. Shwartzman phenomenon can also occur in other species with a single injection of a provoking agent
column3: and during infections or pregnancy. Its susceptibility depends on the status of IMMUNE SYSTEM

column1: C14.907.454.900*D013683*Telangiectasia
column2: Hereditary Hemorrhagic*An autosomal dominant vascular anomaly characterized by telangiectases of the skin and mucous membranes and by recurrent gastrointestinal bleeding. This disorder is caused by mutations of a gene (on chromosome 9q3) which encodes endoglin
column3: a membrane glycoprotein that binds TRANSFORMING GROWTH FACTOR BETA.

column1: C14.907.454.960*D008258*Waldenstrom Macroglobulinemia*A lymphoproliferative disorder characterized by pleomorphic B-LYMPHOCYTES including PLASMA CELLS
column2: with increased levels of monoclonal serum IMMUNOGLOBULIN M. There is lymphoplasmacytic cells infiltration into bone marrow and often other tissues
column3: also known as lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma. Clinical features include ANEMIA; HEMORRHAGES; and hyperviscosity.

column1: C14.907.460*D006504*Hepatic Veno-Occlusive Disease*Liver disease that is caused by injuries to the ENDOTHELIAL CELLS of the vessels and subendothelial EDEMA
column2: but not by THROMBOSIS. Extracellular matrix
column4: is usually deposited around the HEPATIC VEINS leading to venous outflow occlusion and sinusoidal obstruction.

column1: C14.907.474*D006940*Hyperemia*The presence of an increased amount of blood in a body part or an organ leading to congestion or engorgement of blood vessels. Hyperemia can be due to increase of blood flow into the area (active or arterial)
column2: or due to obstruction of outflow of blood from the area (passive or venous).

column1: C14.907.489*D006973*Hypertension*Persistently high systemic arterial BLOOD PRESSURE. Based on multiple readings (BLOOD PRESSURE DETERMINATION)
column2: hypertension is currently defined as when SYSTOLIC PRESSURE is consistently greater than 140 mm Hg or when DIASTOLIC PRESSURE is consistently 90 mm Hg or more.
Malignant*A condition of markedly elevated BLOOD PRESSURE with DIASTOLIC PRESSURE usually greater than 120 mm Hg. Malignant hypertension is characterized by widespread vascular damage

Pregnancy-Induced*A condition in pregnant women with elevated systolic (>140 mm Hg) and diastolic (>90 mm Hg) blood pressure on at least two occasions 6 h apart. HYPERTENSION complicates 8-10% of all pregnancies
column3: generally after 20 weeks of gestation. Gestational hypertension can be divided into several broad categories according to the complexity and associated symptoms
column4: such as EDEMA; PROTEINURIA; SEIZURES; abnormalities in BLOOD COAGULATION and liver functions.

column2: Renal*Persistent high BLOOD PRESSURE due to KIDNEY DISEASES
column3: such as those involving the renal parenchyma

column2: Renovascular*Hypertension due to RENAL ARTERY OBSTRUCTION or compression.

column1: C14.907.489.815*D058437*Hypertensive Retinopathy*Degenerative changes to the RETINA due to HYPERTENSION.
C14.907.489.861*D059468*Masked Hypertension*Phenomenon where increased BLOOD PRESSURE readings taken in non-clinical settings (e.g.
column2: HOME BLOOD PRESSURE MONITORING) do not replicate in clinical settings.

column1: C14.907.489.907*D059466*White Coat Hypertension*Phenomenon where BLOOD PRESSURE readings are elevated only when taken in clinical settings.

C14.907.514*D007022*Hypotension*Abnormally low BLOOD PRESSURE that can result in inadequate blood flow to the brain and other vital organs. Common symptom is DIZZINESS but greater negative impacts on the body occur when there is prolonged depravation of oxygen and nutrients.

column2: Orthostatic*A significant drop in BLOOD PRESSURE after assuming a standing position. Orthostatic hypotension is a finding
column3: and defined as a 20-mm Hg decrease in systolic pressure or a 10-mm Hg decrease in diastolic pressure 3 minutes after the person has risen from supine to standing. Symptoms generally include DIZZINESS

column1: C14.907.514.611*D057774*Post-Exercise Hypotension*Transient reduction in blood pressure levels immediately after exercises that lasts 2-12 hours. The reduction varies but is typically 5-20 mm Hg when compared to pre-exercise levels. It exists both in normotensive and hypertensive individuals and may play a role in excercise related PHYSIOLOGIC ADAPTATION.

C14.907.514.741*D012791*Shy-Drager Syndrome*A progressive neurodegenerative condition of the central and autonomic nervous systems characterized by atrophy of the preganglionic lateral horn neurons of the thoracic spinal cord. This disease is generally considered a clinical variant of MULTIPLE SYSTEM ATROPHY. Affected individuals present in the fifth or sixth decade with ORTHOSTASIS and bladder dysfunction; and later develop FECAL INCONTINENCE; anhidrosis; ATAXIA; IMPOTENCE; and alterations of tone suggestive of basal ganglia dysfunction. (From Adams et al.
column2: Principles of Neurology

column1: C14.907.549*D065666*Mesenteric Ischemia*Ischemic tissue injury produced by insufficient perfusion of intestinal tissue by the MESENTERIC CIRCULATION (i.e.
column2: CELIAC ARTERY; SUPERIOR MESENTERIC ARTERY; INFERERIOR MESENTERIC ARTERY; and MESENTERIC VEINS). It can progress from ISCHEMIA; EDEMA; and GANGRENE of the bowel wall to PERITONITIS and cardiovascular collapse.

column1: C14.907.585*D017202*Myocardial Ischemia*A disorder of cardiac function caused by insufficient blood flow to the muscle tissue of the heart. The decreased blood flow may be due to narrowing of the coronary arteries (CORONARY ARTERY DISEASE)
column2: to obstruction by a thrombus (CORONARY THROMBOSIS)
column4: to diffuse narrowing of arterioles and other small vessels within the heart. Severe interruption of the blood supply to the myocardial tissue may result in necrosis of cardiac muscle (MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION).

column1: C14.907.585.124*D054058*Acute Coronary Syndrome*An episode of MYOCARDIAL ISCHEMIA that generally lasts longer than a transient anginal episode that ultimately may lead to MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION.
C14.907.585.187*D000787*Angina Pectoris*The symptom of paroxysmal pain consequent to MYOCARDIAL ISCHEMIA usually of distinctive character
column2: location and radiation. It is thought to be provoked by a transient stressful situation during which the oxygen requirements of the MYOCARDIUM exceed that supplied by the CORONARY CIRCULATION.
Unstable*Precordial pain at rest
column3: which may precede a MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION.

column2: Variant*A clinical syndrome characterized by the development of CHEST PAIN at rest with concomitant transient ST segment elevation in the ELECTROCARDIOGRAM

Stable*Persistent and reproducible chest discomfort usually precipitated by a physical exertion that dissipates upon cessation of such an activity. The symptoms are manifestations of MYOCARDIAL ISCHEMIA.

column1: C14.907.585.187.575*D017566*Microvascular Angina*ANGINA PECTORIS or angina-like chest pain with a normal coronary arteriogram and positive EXERCISE TEST. The cause of the syndrome is unknown. While its recognition is of clinical importance
column2: its prognosis is excellent. (Braunwald
column5: p1346; Jablonski Dictionary of Syndromes & Eponymic Diseases
column6: 2d ed). It is different from METABOLIC SYNDROME X
column7: a syndrome characterized by INSULIN RESISTANCE and HYPERINSULINEMIA
column8: that has increased risk for cardiovascular disease.

column1: C14.907.585.250*D003327*Coronary Disease*An imbalance between myocardial functional requirements and the capacity of the CORONARY VESSELS to supply sufficient blood flow. It is a form of MYOCARDIAL ISCHEMIA (insufficient blood supply to the heart muscle) caused by a decreased capacity of the coronary vessels.
C14.907.585.250.250*D003323*Coronary Aneurysm*Abnormal balloon- or sac-like dilatation in the wall of CORONARY VESSELS. Most coronary aneurysms are due to CORONARY ATHEROSCLEROSIS
column2: and the rest are due to inflammatory diseases

column1: C14.907.585.250.260*D003324*Coronary Artery Disease*Pathological processes of CORONARY ARTERIES that may derive from a congenital abnormality
column2: atherosclerotic

column1: C14.907.585.250.272*D054059*Coronary Occlusion*Complete blockage of blood flow through one of the CORONARY ARTERIES
column2: usually from CORONARY ATHEROSCLEROSIS.

column1: C14.907.585.250.285*D023921*Coronary Stenosis*Narrowing or constriction of a coronary artery.
C14.907.585.250.285.200*D023903*Coronary Restenosis*Recurrent narrowing or constriction of a coronary artery following surgical procedures performed to alleviate a prior obstruction.
C14.907.585.250.290*D003328*Coronary Thrombosis*Coagulation of blood in any of the CORONARY VESSELS. The presence of a blood clot (THROMBUS) often leads to MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION.
C14.907.585.250.295*D003329*Coronary Vasospasm*Spasm of the large- or medium-sized coronary arteries.

C14.907.585.250.647*D058686*Coronary-Subclavian Steal Syndrome*A complication of INTERNAL MAMMARY-CORONARY ARTERY ANASTOMOSIS whereby an occlusion or stenosis of the proximal SUBCLAVIAN ARTERY causes a reversal of the blood flow away from the CORONARY CIRCULATION
column2: through the grafted INTERNAL MAMMARY ARTERY (internal thoracic artery)
column3: and back to the distal subclavian distribution.

column1: C14.907.585.500*D009203*Myocardial Infarction*NECROSIS of the MYOCARDIUM caused by an obstruction of the blood supply to the heart (CORONARY CIRCULATION).

C14.907.585.500.093*D056988*Anterior Wall Myocardial Infarction*MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION in which the anterior wall of the heart is involved. Anterior wall myocardial infarction is often caused by occlusion of the left anterior descending coronary artery. It can be categorized as anteroseptal or anterolateral wall myocardial infarction.

C14.907.585.500.187*D056989*Inferior Wall Myocardial Infarction*MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION in which the inferior wall of the heart is involved. It is often caused by occlusion of the right coronary artery.
C14.907.585.500.562*D054318*No-Reflow Phenomenon*Markedly reduced or absent REPERFUSION in an infarct zone following the removal of an obstruction or constriction of an artery.

column1: C14.907.585.500.875*D000072657*ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction*A clinical syndrome defined by MYOCARDIAL ISCHEMIA symptoms; persistent elevation in the ST segments of the ELECTROCARDIOGRAM; and release of BIOMARKERS of myocardial NECROSIS (e.g.

column1: C14.907.617.718*D010689*Phlebitis*Inflammation of a vein

column1: C14.907.653*D058246*Prehypertension*Blood pressure levels that are between normotension and hypertension. Individuals with prehypertension are at a higher risk for developing cardiovascular diseases. Generally

column5: and other disorders. Prolonged ischemia may lead to INFARCTION of spinal cord tissue.

column2: Hemolytic
column3: Congenital*Hemolytic anemia due to various intrinsic defects of the erythrocyte.

column3: Congenital*A familial disorder characterized by ANEMIA with multinuclear ERYTHROBLASTS

column6: and various nuclear abnormalities of bone marrow erythrocyte precursors (ERYTHROID PRECURSOR CELLS). Type II is the most common of the 3 types; it is often referred to as HEMPAS
column7: based on the Hereditary Erythroblast Multinuclearity with Positive Acidified Serum test.

column2: Hemolytic
column3: Congenital Nonspherocytic*Any one of a group of congenital hemolytic anemias in which there is no abnormal hemoglobin or spherocytosis and in which there is a defect of glycolysis in the erythrocyte. Common causes include deficiencies in GLUCOSE-6-PHOSPHATE ISOMERASE; PYRUVATE KINASE; and GLUCOSE-6-PHOSPHATE DEHYDROGENASE.

column2: Sickle Cell*A disease characterized by chronic hemolytic anemia
column4: and pathologic involvement of many organs. It is the clinical expression of homozygosity for hemoglobin S.

column1: C15.378.071.141.150.150.440*D006450*Hemoglobin SC Disease*One of the sickle cell disorders characterized by the presence of both hemoglobin S and hemoglobin C. It is similar to

column1: C15.378.071.141.150.150.670*D012805*Sickle Cell Trait*The condition of being heterozygous for hemoglobin S.

column1: C15.378.071.141.150.480.370*D005236*Favism*Hemolytic anemia due to the ingestion of fava beans or after inhalation of pollen from the Vicia fava plant by persons with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficient erythrocytes.

Hereditary*A group of familial congenital hemolytic anemias characterized by numerous abnormally shaped erythrocytes which are generally spheroidal. The erythrocytes have increased osmotic fragility and are abnormally permeable to sodium ions.

column1: C15.378.071.141.150.875*D013789*Thalassemia*A group of hereditary hemolytic anemias in which there is decreased synthesis of one or more hemoglobin polypeptide chains. There are several genetic types with clinical pictures ranging from barely detectable hematologic abnormality to severe and fatal anemia.

C15.378.071.141.150.875.100*D017085*alpha-Thalassemia*A disorder characterized by reduced synthesis of the alpha chains of hemoglobin. The severity of this condition can vary from mild anemia to death

column1: C15.378.071.141.150.875.150*D017086*beta-Thalassemia*A disorder characterized by reduced synthesis of the beta chains of hemoglobin. There is retardation of hemoglobin A synthesis in the heterozygous form (thalassemia minor)
column2: which is asymptomatic
column3: while in the homozygous form (thalassemia major
column7: which can result in severe complications and even death

column1: C15.378.071.141.150.875.575*D055538*delta-Thalassemia*A hereditary disorder characterized by reduced or absent DELTA-GLOBIN thus effecting the level of HEMOGLOBIN A2

column1: C15.378.071.141.370*D005236*Favism*Hemolytic anemia due to the ingestion of fava beans or after inhalation of pollen from the Vicia fava plant by persons with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficient erythrocytes.

column2: Paroxysmal*A condition characterized by the recurrence of HEMOGLOBINURIA caused by intravascular HEMOLYSIS. In cases occurring upon cold exposure (paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria)

column1: C15.378.071.141.610*D006463*Hemolytic-Uremic Syndrome*A syndrome that is associated with microvascular diseases of the KIDNEY

column4: the mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration is less than normal. The individual cells contain less hemoglobin than they could have under optimal conditions. Hypochromic anemia may be caused by iron deficiency from a low iron intake
column6: or excessive iron loss. It can also be caused by infections or other diseases

column2: Iron-Deficiency*Anemia characterized by decreased or absent iron stores
column5: and low hemoglobin concentration or hematocrit value. The erythrocytes are hypochromic and microcytic and the iron binding capacity is increased.

column2: Macrocytic*Anemia characterized by larger than normal erythrocytes

column2: Megaloblastic*A disorder characterized by the presence of ANEMIA

column1: C15.378.071.363.511*D005331*Fetomaternal Transfusion*Transplacental passage of fetal blood into the circulation of the maternal organism. (Dorland

column4: and/or thrombocytopenia. Myeloblasts and progranulocytes constitute 5 to 40 percent of the nucleated marrow cells.

column1: C15.378.071.750*D012010*Red-Cell Aplasia

column3: B-Cell*A neoplasm of prolymphocytes affecting the blood

column2: that presents either neonatally or progressively. Often
column3: the RIGHT VENTRICLE is also affected. CONGESTIVE HEART FAILURE; PULMONARY EMBOLISM; and ventricular ARRHYTHMIA are commonly seen.

column1: C16.131.077.509*D007849*Laurence-Moon Syndrome*An autosomal recessive condition characterized by hypogonadism; spinocerebellar degeneration; MENTAL RETARDATION; RETINITIS PIGMENTOSA; and OBESITY. column1: C16.131.621.207.525*D044542*LEOPARD Syndrome*An autosomal dominant disorder with an acronym of its seven features (LENTIGO; ELECTROCARDIOGRAM abnormalities; ocular HYPERTELORISM; PULMONARY STENOSIS; abnormal genitalia; retardation of growth; and DEAFNESS or SENSORINEURAL HEARING LOSS). column1: C16.131.666.190.100*D020787*Central Nervous System Venous Angioma*A vascular anomaly characterized by a radial or wedge-shaped arrangement of dilated VEINS draining into a larger vein in the brain
column2: spinal cord
column3: or the meninges. Veins in a venous angioma are surrounded by normal nervous tissue

column2: Cavernous
column3: Central Nervous System*A vascular anomaly composed of a collection of large
column4: thin walled tortuous VEINS that can occur in any part of the central nervous system but lack intervening nervous tissue. Familial occurrence is common and has been associated with a number of genes mapped to 7q

column1: C16.131.666.190.500*D002538*Intracranial Arteriovenous Malformations*Congenital vascular anomalies in the brain characterized by direct communication between an artery and a vein without passing through the CAPILLARIES. C16.131.666.190.500.500*D054080*Vein of Galen Malformations*Congenital arteriovenous malformation involving the VEIN OF GALEN

column1: C16.131.666.190.800*D020779*Sinus Pericranii*Rare vascular anomaly involving a communication between the intracranial and extracranial venous circulation via diploe
column2: the central spongy layer of cranial bone. It is often characterized by dilated venous structures on the scalp due to abnormal drainage from the intracranial venous sinuses. Sinus pericranii can be congenital or traumatic in origin.

column1: C16.131.666.300*D015417*Hereditary Sensory and Motor Neuropathy*A group of slowly progressive inherited disorders affecting motor and sensory peripheral nerves. Subtypes include HMSNs I-VII. HMSN I and II both refer to CHARCOT-MARIE-TOOTH DISEASE. HMSN III refers to hypertrophic neuropathy of infancy. HMSN IV refers to REFSUM DISEASE. HMSN V refers to a condition marked by a hereditary motor and sensory neuropathy associated with spastic paraplegia (see SPASTIC PARAPLEGIA
column2: HEREDITARY). HMSN VI refers to HMSN associated with an inherited optic atrophy (OPTIC ATROPHIES
column4: and HMSN VII refers to HMSN associated with retinitis pigmentosa. (From Adams et al.

column1: C16.131.666.300.099*D056769*Alstrom Syndrome*Rare autosomal recessive disease characterized by multiple organ dysfunction. The key clinical features include retinal degeneration (NYSTAGMUS
column2: PATHOLOGIC; RETINITIS PIGMENTOSA; and eventual blindness)
column5: and normal mental development. Endocrinologic complications include TYPE 2 DIABETES MELLITUS; HYPERINSULINEMIA; ACANTHOSIS NIGRICANS; HYPOTHYROIDISM; and progressive renal and hepatic failures. The disease is caused by mutations in the ALMS1 gene.

column1: C16.131.666.300.200*D002607*Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disease*A hereditary motor and sensory neuropathy transmitted most often as an autosomal dominant trait and characterized by progressive distal wasting and loss of reflexes in the muscles of the legs (and occasionally involving the arms). Onset is usually in the second to fourth decade of life. This condition has been divided into two subtypes
column2: hereditary motor and sensory neuropathy (HMSN) types I and II. HMSN I is associated with abnormal nerve conduction velocities and nerve hypertrophy
column3: features not seen in HMSN II. (Adams et al.

column1: C16.131.666.300.490*D056768*Giant Axonal Neuropathy*Rare autosomal recessive disorder of INTERMEDIATE FILAMENT PROTEINS. The disease is caused by mutations in the gene that codes gigaxonin protein. The mutations result in disorganization of axonal NEUROFILAMENT PROTEINS

column1: C16.131.666.300.780*D012035*Refsum Disease*An autosomal recessive familial disorder that usually presents in childhood with POLYNEUROPATHY; SENSORINEURAL HEARING LOSS; ICHTHYOSIS; ATAXIA; RETINITIS PIGMENTOSA; and CARDIOMYOPATHIES. (From Joynt
column2: Clinical Neurology

column1: C16.131.666.310*D009477*Hereditary Sensory and Autonomic Neuropathies*A group of inherited disorders characterized by degeneration of dorsal root and autonomic ganglion cells

column5: and mental deficiency. Type V is characterized by a selective loss of pain with intact light touch and vibratory sensation. (From Joynt

column2: Familial*An autosomal disorder of the peripheral and autonomic nervous systems limited to individuals of Ashkenazic Jewish descent. Clinical manifestations are present at birth and include diminished lacrimation
column8: loss of pain and temperature sensation
column9: and absent reflexes. Pathologic features include reduced numbers of small diameter peripheral nerve fibers and autonomic ganglion neurons. (From Adams et al.

column2: which is consistent with earlier normal embryogenesis of the telencephalon. Bilateral occlusions of the internal carotid arteries in utero is a potential mechanism. Clinical features include intact brainstem reflexes without evidence of higher cortical activity. (Menkes

column1: C16.131.666.507*D054220*Malformations of Cortical Development*Abnormalities in the development of the CEREBRAL CORTEX. column2: ALEXANDER DISEASE; SOTOS SYNDROME).

column5: the head is small. (Desk Reference for Neuroscience

column2: or fewer and shallower indentations (pachygryia). There is a reduced number of cortical layers
column5: and reduced cerebral white matter that is a reversal of the normal ratio of cerebral white matter to cortex.

column1: C16.131.666.507.500*D065704*Malformations of Cortical Development

column1: C16.131.666.507.500.500*D065706*Polymicrogyria*Heterogeneous disorders of cortical malformation characterized by excessive and small fused gyri and shallow sulci of the CORTEX with abnormal cortical lamination. C16.131.666.507.500.625*D065708*Porencephaly*Cortical malformations characterized by white matter-lined cleft or cyst associated with ISCHEMIA and hemorrhagic insults. Symptoms include delayed growth and development
column2: HYPOTONIA; SEIZURES; SPASTIC HEMIPLEGIA and MACROCEPHALY; MICROCEPHALY; or HYDROCEPHALUS. Mutations in the genes encoding COLLAGEN TYPE IV are associated with familial types.

column1: C16.131.666.507.500.750*D065707*Schizencephaly*Cortical malformations characterized by grey matter-lined cleft or cyst that extends from the EPENDYMA often to the PIA MATER outer surface. The grey matter that lines the cleft is often POLYMICROGYRIA. It is associated with developmental delay

column1: C16.131.666.680*D009436*Neural Tube Defects*Congenital malformations of the central nervous system and adjacent structures related to defective neural tube closure during the first trimester of pregnancy generally occurring between days 18-29 of gestation. Ectodermal and mesodermal malformations (mainly involving the skull and vertebrae) may occur as a result of defects of neural tube closure. (From Joynt
column2: Clinical Neurology

column1: C16.131.666.680.196*D000757*Anencephaly*A malformation of the nervous system caused by failure of the anterior neuropore to close. Infants are born with intact spinal cords
column2: cerebellums
column4: but lack formation of neural structures above this level. The skull is only partially formed but the eyes are usually normal. This condition may be associated with folate deficiency. Affected infants are only capable of primitive (brain stem) reflexes and usually do not survive for more than two weeks. (From Menkes

column1: C16.131.666.680.291*D001139*Arnold-Chiari Malformation*A group of congenital malformations involving the brainstem
