Choline is known as a lipotropic agent because it has been shown to promote the transport of excess fat from the liver under certain conditions in laboratory animals. Combined deficiency of choline (included in the B vitamin complex) and all other methyl group donors causes liver cirrhosis in some animals. Unlike compounds normally considered as vitamins
column2: choline does not serve as a cofactor in enzymatic reactions. (From Saunders Dictionary & Encyclopedia of Laboratory Medicine and Technology

column1: C18.654.521.500.133.699.308*D005494*Folic Acid Deficiency*A nutritional condition produced by a deficiency of FOLIC ACID in the diet. Many plant and animal tissues contain folic acid
column2: abundant in green leafy vegetables
column5: and mushrooms but destroyed by long-term cooking. Alcohol interferes with its intermediate metabolism and absorption. Folic acid deficiency may develop in long-term anticonvulsant therapy or with use of oral contraceptives. This deficiency causes anemia
column7: and megaloblastic anemia. It is indistinguishable from vitamin B 12 deficiency in peripheral blood and bone marrow findings
column8: but the neurologic lesions seen in B 12 deficiency do not occur. (Merck Manual

column1: C18.654.521.500.133.699.418*D020138*Hyperhomocysteinemia*Condition in which the plasma levels of homocysteine and related metabolites are elevated (>13.9 _mol/l). Hyperhomocysteinemia can be familial or acquired. Development of the acquired hyperhomocysteinemia is mostly associated with vitamins B and/or folate deficiency (e.g.
column2: PERNICIOUS ANEMIA
column3: vitamin malabsorption). Familial hyperhomocysteinemia often results in a more severe elevation of total homocysteine and excretion into the urine
column4: resulting in HOMOCYSTINURIA. Hyperhomocysteinemia is a risk factor for cardiovascular and neurodegenerative diseases
column5: osteoporotic fractures and complications during pregnancy.

column1: C18.654.521.500.133.699.529*D010383*Pellagra*A disease due to deficiency of NIACIN
column2: a B-complex vitamin
column3: or its precursor TRYPTOPHAN. It is characterized by scaly DERMATITIS which is often associated with DIARRHEA and DEMENTIA (the three D's).

column1: C18.654.521.500.133.699.713*D012257*Riboflavin Deficiency*A dietary deficiency of riboflavin causing a syndrome chiefly marked by cheilitis
column2: angular stomatitis
column3: glossitis associated with a purplish red or magenta-colored tongue that may show fissures

column1: C18.654.521.500.133.699.827*D013832*Thiamine Deficiency*A nutritional condition produced by a deficiency of THIAMINE in the diet
column2: characterized by anorexia
column8: and tachycardia. In addition to being caused by a poor diet
column9: thiamine deficiency in the United States most commonly occurs as a result of alcoholism
column10: since ethanol interferes with thiamine absorption. In countries relying on polished rice as a dietary staple
column11: BERIBERI prevalence is very high. (From Cecil Textbook of Medicine

column1: C18.654.521.500.133.699.827.223*D001602*Beriberi*A disease caused by a deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1) and characterized by polyneuritis
column2: cardiac pathology
column3: and edema. The epidemic form is found primarily in areas in which white (polished) rice is the staple food
column8: and other countries of southeast Asia. (Dorland

column1: C18.654.521.500.133.699.827.822*D014899*Wernicke Encephalopathy*An acute neurological disorder characterized by the triad of ophthalmoplegia
column2: ataxia
column3: and disturbances of mental activity or consciousness. Eye movement abnormalities include nystagmus
column5: and reduced conjugate gaze. THIAMINE DEFICIENCY and chronic ALCOHOLISM are associated conditions. Pathologic features include periventricular petechial hemorrhages and neuropil breakdown in the diencephalon and brainstem. Chronic thiamine deficiency may lead to KORSAKOFF SYNDROME. (Adams et al.

column1: C18.654.521.500.133.699.901*D026681*Vitamin B 6 Deficiency*A nutritional condition produced by a deficiency of VITAMIN B 6 in the diet
column2: characterized by dermatitis
column5: and stomatitis. Marked deficiency causes irritability
column10: and seizures. In infants and children typical manifestations are diarrhea
column12: and seizures. Deficiency can be caused by certain medications

column1: C18.654.521.500.133.699.923*D014806*Vitamin B 12 Deficiency*A nutritional condition produced by a deficiency of VITAMIN B 12 in the diet
column2: characterized by megaloblastic anemia. Since vitamin B 12 is not present in plants
column3: humans have obtained their supply from animal products
column4: from multivitamin supplements in the form of pills
column5: and as additives to food preparations. A wide variety of neuropsychiatric abnormalities is also seen in vitamin B 12 deficiency and appears to be due to an undefined defect involving myelin synthesis. (From Cecil Textbook of Medicine

column2: Pernicious*A megaloblastic anemia occurring in children but more commonly in later life
column4: in which the laboratory and clinical manifestations are based on malabsorption of vitamin B 12 due to a failure of the gastric mucosa to secrete adequate and potent intrinsic factor. (Dorland

column1: C18.654.521.500.133.699.923.640*D052879*Subacute Combined Degeneration*A neuropathy due to VITAMIN B 12 DEFICIENCY or to excessive NITROUS OXIDE inhalation. It is associated with overproduction of the myelinolytic TUMOR NECROSIS FACTOR-ALPHA.
C18.654.521.500.133.770*D014808*Vitamin D Deficiency*A nutritional condition produced by a deficiency of VITAMIN D in the diet
column2: insufficient production of vitamin D in the skin
column3: inadequate absorption of vitamin D from the diet
column4: or abnormal conversion of vitamin D to its bioactive metabolites. It is manifested clinically as RICKETS in children and OSTEOMALACIA in adults. (From Cecil Textbook of Medicine

column1: C18.654.521.500.133.770.734*D012279*Rickets*Disorders caused by interruption of BONE MINERALIZATION manifesting as OSTEOMALACIA in adults and characteristic deformities in infancy and childhood due to disturbances in normal BONE FORMATION. The mineralization process may be interrupted by disruption of VITAMIN D; PHOSPHORUS; or CALCIUM homeostasis
column2: resulting from dietary deficiencies

column1: C18.654.521.500.133.770.734.640*D010018*Osteomalacia*Disorder caused by an interruption of the mineralization of organic bone matrix leading to bone softening
column2: bone pain
column3: and weakness. It is the adult form of rickets resulting from disruption of VITAMIN D; PHOSPHORUS; or CALCIUM homeostasis.

column1: C18.654.521.500.133.770.734.750*D012080*Chronic Kidney Disease-Mineral and Bone Disorder*Decalcification of bone or abnormal bone development due to chronic KIDNEY DISEASES
column2: in which 1
column3: 25-DIHYDROXYVITAMIN D3 synthesis by the kidneys is impaired
column4: leading to reduced negative feedback on PARATHYROID HORMONE. The resulting SECONDARY HYPERPARATHYROIDISM eventually leads to bone disorders.

column2: Hypophosphatemic*A disorder characterized by HYPOPHOSPHATEMIA; RICKETS; OSTEOMALACIA; resulting from lack of phosphate reabsorption by the kidneys and possible defects in vitamin D metabolism.

column1: C18.654.521.500.133.770.734.875.500*D053098*Familial Hypophosphatemic Rickets*A hereditary disorder characterized by HYPOPHOSPHATEMIA; RICKETS; OSTEOMALACIA; renal defects in phosphate reabsorption and vitamin D metabolism; and growth retardation. Autosomal and X-linked dominant and recessive variants have been reported.
C18.654.521.500.133.841*D014811*Vitamin E Deficiency*A nutritional condition produced by a deficiency of VITAMIN E in the diet
column2: characterized by posterior column and spinocerebellar tract abnormalities
column7: and vibration. In premature infants vitamin E deficiency is associated with hemolytic anemia
column11: and increasing risk of retrolental fibroplasia and bronchopulmonary dysplasia. An apparent inborn error of vitamin E metabolism
column12: named familial isolated vitamin E deficiency
column13: has recently been identified. (Cecil Textbook of Medicine

column1: C18.654.521.500.133.841.682*D013231*Steatitis*A disease of cats and mink characterized by a marked inflammation of adipose tissue and the deposition of ceroid pigment in the interstices of the adipose cells. It is believed to be caused by feeding diets containing too much unsaturated fatty acid and too little vitamin E. (Merck Veterinary Manual
column2: 5th ed; Stedman

column1: C18.654.521.500.133.912*D014813*Vitamin K Deficiency*A nutritional condition produced by a deficiency of VITAMIN K in the diet
column2: characterized by an increased tendency to hemorrhage (HEMORRHAGIC DISORDERS). Such bleeding episodes may be particularly severe in newborn infants. (From Cecil Textbook of Medicine

column1: C18.654.521.500.133.912.360*D006475*Vitamin K Deficiency Bleeding*Hemorrhage caused by vitamin K deficiency.
C18.654.521.500.439*D008275*Magnesium Deficiency*A nutritional condition produced by a deficiency of magnesium in the diet
column2: characterized by anorexia
column11: possibly requiring months to appear. Deficiency of body magnesium can exist even when serum values are normal. In addition
column13: since certain tissues become deficient before others. (Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine

column1: C18.654.521.500.617*D011191*Potassium Deficiency*A condition due to decreased dietary intake of potassium
column2: as in starvation or failure to administer in intravenous solutions
column3: or to gastrointestinal loss in diarrhea
column7: or bowel diversion. Severe potassium deficiency may produce muscular weakness and lead to paralysis and respiratory failure. Muscular malfunction may result in hypoventilation
column12: and rhabomyolysis. Nephropathy from potassium deficit impairs the concentrating mechanism
column13: producing POLYURIA and decreased maximal urinary concentrating ability with secondary POLYDIPSIA. (Merck Manual

column1: C18.654.521.500.708*D011488*Protein Deficiency*A nutritional condition produced by a deficiency of proteins in the diet
column2: characterized by adaptive enzyme changes in the liver
column5: thus conserving nitrogen and reducing its loss in the urine. Growth
column8: and production of enzymes and hormones are all impaired in severe protein deficiency. Protein deficiency may also arise in the face of adequate protein intake if the protein is of poor quality (i.e.
column9: the content of one or more amino acids is inadequate and thus becomes the limiting factor in protein utilization). (From Merck Manual
column10: 16th ed; Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine

column1: C18.654.521.500.708.626*D011502*Protein-Energy Malnutrition*The lack of sufficient energy or protein to meet the body's metabolic demands
column2: as a result of either an inadequate dietary intake of protein
column3: intake of poor quality dietary protein

column1: C18.654.521.500.857*D013540*Swayback*Congenital locomotor ataxia of lambs
column2: thought to be associated with copper deficiency. It is characterized clinically by progressive incoordination of the hind limbs and pathologically by disruption of neuron and myelin development in the central nervous system. It is caused by a deficiency of metabolizable copper in the ewe during the last half of her pregnancy. (Dorland

column1: C18.654.521.625*D048070*Fetal Nutrition Disorders*Disorders caused by nutritional imbalance
column2: either overnutrition or undernutrition

column1: C18.654.521.687*D055677*Refeeding Syndrome*A condition of metabolic imbalance that is caused by complications of initially feeding a severely malnourished patient too aggressively. Usually occurring within the first 5 days of refeeding
column2: this syndrome is characterized by WATER-ELECTROLYTE IMBALANCE; GLUCOSE INTOLERANCE; CARDIAC ARRHYTHMIAS; and DIARRHEA.

column1: C18.654.521.719*D000067011*Severe Acute Malnutrition*Acute form of MALNUTRITION which usually affects children
column2: characterized by a very low weight for height (below -3z scores of the median World Health Organization standards)
column4: or occurrence of nutritional EDEMA.  It can be a direct or indirect cause of fatality in children suffering from DIARRHEA and PNEUMONIA. Do not confuse with starvation
column5: a condition in which the body is not getting enough food
column6: usually for extended periods of time.

column1: C18.654.521.719.500*D007732*Kwashiorkor*A syndrome produced by severe protein deficiency
column2: characterized by retarded growth
column3: changes in skin and hair pigment
column5: and pathologic changes in the liver
column8: and fibrosis. The word is a local name in Gold Coast
column10: meaning displaced child. Although first reported from Africa
column11: kwashiorkor is now known throughout the world
column12: but mainly in the tropics and subtropics. It is considered to be related to marasmus. (From Dorland

column1: C18.654.521.750*D013217*Starvation*Lengthy and continuous deprivation of food. (Stedman
column2: 25th ed)

column1: C18.654.726*D044343*Overnutrition*An imbalanced NUTRITIONAL STATUS resulting from excessive intake of nutrients. Generally
column2: overnutrition generates an energy imbalance between food consumption and energy expenditure leading to disorders such as OBESITY.

column1: C18.654.726.500*D009765*Obesity*A status with BODY WEIGHT that is grossly above the acceptable or desirable weight
column2: usually due to accumulation of excess FATS in the body. The standards may vary with age
column4: genetic or cultural background. In the BODY MASS INDEX
column5: a BMI greater than 30.0 kg/m2 is considered obese
column6: and a BMI greater than 40.0 kg/m2 is considered morbidly obese (MORBID OBESITY).

column1: C18.654.726.500.695*D010845*Obesity Hypoventilation Syndrome*HYPOVENTILATION syndrome in very obese persons with excessive ADIPOSE TISSUE around the ABDOMEN and DIAPHRAGM. It is characterized by diminished to absent ventilatory chemoresponsiveness; chronic HYPOXIA; HYPERCAPNIA; POLYCYTHEMIA; and long periods of sleep during day and night (HYPERSOMNOLENCE). It is a condition often related to OBSTRUCTIVE SLEEP APNEA but can occur separately.

column2: Abdominal*A condition of having excess fat in the abdomen. Abdominal obesity is typically defined as waist circumferences of 40 inches or more in men and 35 inches or more in women. Abdominal obesity raises the risk of developing disorders
Metabolically Benign*A sub-PHENOTYPE of obese individuals who have a risk for CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES between that of healthy individuals with normal weight and unhealthy individuals with obesity.
Morbid*The condition of weighing two
column4: or more times the ideal weight
column5: so called because it is associated with many serious and life-threatening disorders. In the BODY MASS INDEX
column6: morbid obesity is defined as having a BMI greater than 40.0 kg/m2.

column1: C18.654.726.500.720*D063766*Pediatric Obesity*BODY MASS INDEX in children (ages 2-12) and in adolescents (ages 13-18) that is grossly above the recommended cut-off for a specific age and sex. For infants less than 2 years of age
column2: obesity is determined based on standard weight-for-length percentile measures.

column1: C18.654.726.500.740*D011218*Prader-Willi Syndrome*An autosomal dominant disorder caused by deletion of the proximal long arm of the paternal chromosome 15 (15q11-q13) or by inheritance of both of the pair of chromosomes 15 from the mother (UNIPARENTAL DISOMY) which are imprinted (GENETIC IMPRINTING) and hence silenced. Clinical manifestations include MENTAL RETARDATION; MUSCULAR HYPOTONIA; HYPERPHAGIA; OBESITY; short stature; HYPOGONADISM; STRABISMUS; and HYPERSOMNOLENCE. (Menkes
column2: Textbook of Child Neurology

column1: C18.654.940*D019282*Wasting Syndrome*A condition of involuntary weight loss of greater then 10% of baseline body weight. It is characterized by atrophy of muscles and depletion of lean body mass. Wasting is a sign of MALNUTRITION as a result of inadequate dietary intake
column2: malabsorption

column1: C18.654.940.520*D019247*HIV Wasting Syndrome*Involuntary weight loss of greater than 10 percent associated with intermittent or constant fever and chronic diarrhea or fatigue for more than 30 days in the absence of a defined cause other than HIV infection. A constant feature is major muscle wasting with scattered myofiber degeneration. A variety of etiologies
column2: which vary among patients
column3: contributes to this syndrome. (From Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine

column1: C19*D004700*Endocrine System Diseases*Pathological processes of the ENDOCRINE GLANDS
column2: and diseases resulting from abnormal level of available HORMONES.

column1: C19.053*D000307*Adrenal Gland Diseases*Pathological processes of the ADRENAL GLANDS.
C19.053.098*D000303*Adrenal Cortex Diseases*Pathological processes of the ADRENAL CORTEX.
C19.053.098.265*D000306*Adrenal Cortex Neoplasms*Tumors or cancers of the ADRENAL CORTEX.
C19.053.098.265.500*D018246*Adrenocortical Adenoma*A benign neoplasm of the ADRENAL CORTEX. It is characterized by a well-defined nodular lesion
column2: usually less than 2.5 cm. Most adrenocortical adenomas are nonfunctional. The functional ones are yellow and contain LIPIDS. Depending on the cell type or cortical zone involved
column3: they may produce ALDOSTERONE; HYDROCORTISONE; DEHYDROEPIANDROSTERONE; and/or ANDROSTENEDIONE.

column1: C19.053.098.265.750*D018268*Adrenocortical Carcinoma*A malignant neoplasm of the ADRENAL CORTEX. Adrenocortical carcinomas are unencapsulated anaplastic (ANAPLASIA) masses sometimes exceeding 20 cm or 200 g. They are more likely to be functional than nonfunctional
column2: and produce ADRENAL CORTEX HORMONES that may result in hypercortisolism (CUSHING SYNDROME); HYPERALDOSTERONISM; and/or VIRILISM.

column1: C19.053.347*D000310*Adrenal Gland Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the ADRENAL GLANDS.
C19.053.347.500*D000306*Adrenal Cortex Neoplasms*Tumors or cancers of the ADRENAL CORTEX.
C19.053.347.500.500*D018246*Adrenocortical Adenoma*A benign neoplasm of the ADRENAL CORTEX. It is characterized by a well-defined nodular lesion
column2: usually less than 2.5 cm. Most adrenocortical adenomas are nonfunctional. The functional ones are yellow and contain LIPIDS. Depending on the cell type or cortical zone involved
column3: they may produce ALDOSTERONE; HYDROCORTISONE; DEHYDROEPIANDROSTERONE; and/or ANDROSTENEDIONE.

column1: C19.053.347.500.750*D018268*Adrenocortical Carcinoma*A malignant neoplasm of the ADRENAL CORTEX. Adrenocortical carcinomas are unencapsulated anaplastic (ANAPLASIA) masses sometimes exceeding 20 cm or 200 g. They are more likely to be functional than nonfunctional
column2: and produce ADRENAL CORTEX HORMONES that may result in hypercortisolism (CUSHING SYNDROME); HYPERALDOSTERONISM; and/or VIRILISM.

column1: C19.053.440*D000312*Adrenal Hyperplasia
column2: Congenital*A group of inherited disorders of the ADRENAL GLANDS
column3: caused by enzyme defects in the synthesis of cortisol (HYDROCORTISONE) and/or ALDOSTERONE leading to accumulation of precursors for ANDROGENS. Depending on the hormone imbalance
column4: congenital adrenal hyperplasia can be classified as salt-wasting
column7: or feminizing. Defects in STEROID 21-HYDROXYLASE; STEROID 11-BETA-HYDROXYLASE; STEROID 17-ALPHA-HYDROXYLASE; 3-beta-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase (3-HYDROXYSTEROID DEHYDROGENASES); TESTOSTERONE 5-ALPHA-REDUCTASE; or steroidogenic acute regulatory protein; among others

column1: C19.053.500*D000309*Adrenal Insufficiency*Conditions in which the production of adrenal CORTICOSTEROIDS falls below the requirement of the body. Adrenal insufficiency can be caused by defects in the ADRENAL GLANDS
column2: the PITUITARY GLAND

column1: C19.053.500.263*D000224*Addison Disease*An adrenal disease characterized by the progressive destruction of the ADRENAL CORTEX
column2: resulting in insufficient production of ALDOSTERONE and HYDROCORTISONE. Clinical symptoms include ANOREXIA; NAUSEA; WEIGHT LOSS; MUSCLE WEAKNESS; and HYPERPIGMENTATION of the SKIN due to increase in circulating levels of ACTH precursor hormone which stimulates MELANOCYTES.

column1: C19.053.500.270*D000326*Adrenoleukodystrophy*An X-linked recessive disorder characterized by the accumulation of saturated very long chain fatty acids in the LYSOSOMES of ADRENAL CORTEX and the white matter of CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM. This disease occurs almost exclusively in the males. Clinical features include the childhood onset of ATAXIA; NEUROBEHAVIORAL MANIFESTATIONS; HYPERPIGMENTATION; ADRENAL INSUFFICIENCY; SEIZURES; MUSCLE SPASTICITY; and DEMENTIA. The slowly progressive adult form is called adrenomyeloneuropathy. The defective gene ABCD1 is located at Xq28
column2: and encodes the adrenoleukodystrophy protein (ATP-BINDING CASSETTE TRANSPORTERS).

column1: C19.053.500.480*D006994*Hypoaldosteronism*A congenital or acquired condition of insufficient production of ALDOSTERONE by the ADRENAL CORTEX leading to diminished aldosterone-mediated synthesis of Na(+)-K(+)-EXCHANGING ATPASE in renal tubular cells. Clinical symptoms include HYPERKALEMIA
column2: sodium-wasting

column1: C19.053.500.740*D014884*Waterhouse-Friderichsen Syndrome*A condition of HEMORRHAGE and NECROSIS of the ADRENAL GLAND. It is characterized by rapidly developing ADRENAL INSUFFICIENCY; HYPOTENSION; and widespread cutaneous PURPURA.

C19.053.800*D000308*Adrenocortical Hyperfunction*Excess production of ADRENAL CORTEX HORMONES such as ALDOSTERONE; HYDROCORTISONE; DEHYDROEPIANDROSTERONE; and/or ANDROSTENEDIONE. Hyperadrenal syndromes include CUSHING SYNDROME; HYPERALDOSTERONISM; and VIRILISM.

C19.053.800.367*D003480*Cushing Syndrome*A condition caused by prolonged exposure to excess levels of cortisol (HYDROCORTISONE) or other GLUCOCORTICOIDS from endogenous or exogenous sources. It is characterized by upper body OBESITY; OSTEOPOROSIS; HYPERTENSION; DIABETES MELLITUS; HIRSUTISM; AMENORRHEA; and excess body fluid. Endogenous Cushing syndrome or spontaneous hypercortisolism is divided into two groups
column2: those due to an excess of ADRENOCORTICOTROPIN and those that are ACTH-independent.

column1: C19.053.800.604*D006929*Hyperaldosteronism*A condition caused by the overproduction of ALDOSTERONE. It is characterized by sodium retention and potassium excretion with resultant HYPERTENSION and HYPOKALEMIA.
C19.053.800.604.249*D001477*Bartter Syndrome*A group of disorders caused by defective salt reabsorption in the ascending LOOP OF HENLE. It is characterized by severe salt-wasting
column2: HYPOKALEMIA; HYPERCALCIURIA; metabolic ALKALOSIS
column3: and hyper-reninemic HYPERALDOSTERONISM without HYPERTENSION. There are several subtypes including ones due to mutations in the renal specific SODIUM-POTASSIUM-CHLORIDE SYMPORTERS.

column1: C19.149*D001849*Bone Diseases
column2: Endocrine*Diseases of the bones related to hyperfunction or hypofunction of the endocrine glands.

column1: C19.246*D003920*Diabetes Mellitus*A heterogeneous group of disorders characterized by HYPERGLYCEMIA and GLUCOSE INTOLERANCE.

C19.246.099*D048909*Diabetes Complications*Conditions or pathological processes associated with the disease of diabetes mellitus. Due to the impaired control of BLOOD GLUCOSE level in diabetic patients
column2: pathological processes develop in numerous tissues and organs including the EYE

column1: C19.246.099.500*D003925*Diabetic Angiopathies*VASCULAR DISEASES that are associated with DIABETES MELLITUS.
C19.246.099.500.191*D017719*Diabetic Foot*Common foot problems in persons with DIABETES MELLITUS
column2: caused by any combination of factors such as DIABETIC NEUROPATHIES; PERIPHERAL VASCULAR DISEASES; and INFECTION. With the loss of sensation and poor circulation
column3: injuries and infections often lead to severe foot ulceration

column1: C19.246.099.500.382*D003930*Diabetic Retinopathy*Disease of the RETINA as a complication of DIABETES MELLITUS. It is characterized by the progressive microvascular complications
column2: such as ANEURYSM

column1: C19.246.099.625*D058065*Diabetic Cardiomyopathies*Diabetes complications in which VENTRICULAR REMODELING in the absence of CORONARY ATHEROSCLEROSIS and hypertension results in cardiac dysfunctions
column2: typically LEFT VENTRICULAR DYSFUNCTION. The changes also result in myocardial hypertrophy
column4: and collagen deposition due to impaired glucose tolerance.

column1: C19.246.099.750*D003926*Diabetic Coma*A state of unconsciousness as a complication of diabetes mellitus. It occurs in cases of extreme HYPERGLYCEMIA or extreme HYPOGLYCEMIA as a complication of INSULIN therapy.

C19.246.099.750.490*D006944*Hyperglycemic Hyperosmolar Nonketotic Coma*A serious complication of TYPE 2 DIABETES MELLITUS. It is characterized by extreme HYPERGLYCEMIA; DEHYDRATION; serum hyperosmolarity; and depressed consciousness leading to COMA in the absence of KETOSIS and ACIDOSIS.
C19.246.099.812*D016883*Diabetic Ketoacidosis*A life-threatening complication of diabetes mellitus
column2: primarily of TYPE 1 DIABETES MELLITUS with severe INSULIN deficiency and extreme HYPERGLYCEMIA. It is characterized by KETOSIS; DEHYDRATION; and depressed consciousness leading to COMA.

column1: C19.246.099.875*D003928*Diabetic Nephropathies*KIDNEY injuries associated with diabetes mellitus and affecting KIDNEY GLOMERULUS; ARTERIOLES; KIDNEY TUBULES; and the interstitium. Clinical signs include persistent PROTEINURIA
column2: from microalbuminuria progressing to ALBUMINURIA of greater than 300 mg/24 h
column3: leading to reduced GLOMERULAR FILTRATION RATE and END-STAGE RENAL DISEASE.

column1: C19.246.099.937*D003929*Diabetic Neuropathies*Peripheral
column2: autonomic
column3: and cranial nerve disorders that are associated with DIABETES MELLITUS. These conditions usually result from diabetic microvascular injury involving small blood vessels that supply nerves (VASA NERVORUM). Relatively common conditions which may be associated with diabetic neuropathy include third nerve palsy (see OCULOMOTOR NERVE DISEASES); MONONEUROPATHY; mononeuropathy multiplex; diabetic amyotrophy; a painful POLYNEUROPATHY; autonomic neuropathy; and thoracoabdominal neuropathy. (From Adams et al.

column1: C19.246.099.937.250*D017719*Diabetic Foot*Common foot problems in persons with DIABETES MELLITUS
column2: caused by any combination of factors such as DIABETIC NEUROPATHIES; PERIPHERAL VASCULAR DISEASES; and INFECTION. With the loss of sensation and poor circulation
column3: injuries and infections often lead to severe foot ulceration

column1: C19.246.099.968*D005320*Fetal Macrosomia*A condition of fetal overgrowth leading to a large-for-gestational-age FETUS. It is defined as BIRTH WEIGHT greater than 4
column2: 000 grams or above the 90th percentile for population and sex-specific growth curves. It is commonly seen in GESTATIONAL DIABETES; PROLONGED PREGNANCY; and pregnancies complicated by pre-existing diabetes mellitus.

Gestational*Diabetes mellitus induced by PREGNANCY but resolved at the end of pregnancy. It does not include previously diagnosed diabetics who become pregnant (PREGNANCY IN DIABETICS). Gestational diabetes usually develops in late pregnancy when insulin antagonistic hormones peaks leading to INSULIN RESISTANCE; GLUCOSE INTOLERANCE; and HYPERGLYCEMIA.

column1: C19.246.240*D003921*Diabetes Mellitus
column2: Experimental*Diabetes mellitus induced experimentally by administration of various diabetogenic agents or by PANCREATECTOMY.

column1: C19.246.267*D003922*Diabetes Mellitus
column2: Type 1*A subtype of DIABETES MELLITUS that is characterized by INSULIN deficiency. It is manifested by the sudden onset of severe HYPERGLYCEMIA
column4: and DEATH unless treated with insulin. The disease may occur at any age
column5: but is most common in childhood or adolescence.

column1: C19.246.267.960*D014929*Wolfram Syndrome*A hereditary condition characterized by multiple symptoms including those of DIABETES INSIPIDUS; DIABETES MELLITUS; OPTIC ATROPHY; and DEAFNESS. This syndrome is also known as DIDMOAD (first letter of each word) and is usually associated with VASOPRESSIN deficiency. It is caused by mutations in gene WFS1 encoding wolframin
column2: a 100-kDa transmembrane protein.

column1: C19.246.300*D003924*Diabetes Mellitus
column2: Type 2*A subclass of DIABETES MELLITUS that is not INSULIN-responsive or dependent (NIDDM). It is characterized initially by INSULIN RESISTANCE and HYPERINSULINEMIA; and eventually by GLUCOSE INTOLERANCE; HYPERGLYCEMIA; and overt diabetes. Type II diabetes mellitus is no longer considered a disease exclusively found in adults. Patients seldom develop KETOSIS but often exhibit OBESITY.

column1: C19.246.300.500*D003923*Diabetes Mellitus
column2: Lipoatrophic*A type of diabetes mellitus that is characterized by severe INSULIN RESISTANCE and LIPODYSTROPHY. The latter may be generalized

column1: C19.246.537*D056731*Donohue Syndrome*Rare autosomal recessive syndrome of extreme insulin resistance due to mutations in the binding domain of INSULIN RECEPTOR. Clinical features include severe intrauterine and postnatal growth restriction
column2: characteristic dysmorphic FACIES; HIRSUTISM; VIRILIZATION; multiple endocrine abnormalities

column1: C19.246.656*D000071698*Latent Autoimmune Diabetes in Adults*Autoimmune diabetes in adults with slowly progressive PANCREATIC BETA CELL failure and the presence of circulating autoantibodies to PANCREATIC ISLETS cell antigens.
C19.246.774*D011236*Prediabetic State*The time period before the development of symptomatic diabetes. For example
column2: certain risk factors can be observed in subjects who subsequently develop INSULIN RESISTANCE as in type 2 diabetes (DIABETES MELLITUS

column1: C19.297*D004392*Dwarfism*A genetic or pathological condition that is characterized by short stature and undersize. Abnormal skeletal growth usually results in an adult who is significantly below the average height.
C19.297.155*D003409*Congenital Hypothyroidism*A condition in infancy or early childhood due to an in-utero deficiency of THYROID HORMONES that can be caused by genetic or environmental factors
column2: such as thyroid dysgenesis or HYPOTHYROIDISM in infants of mothers treated with THIOURACIL during pregnancy. Endemic cretinism is the result of iodine deficiency. Clinical symptoms include severe MENTAL RETARDATION
Pituitary*A form of dwarfism caused by complete or partial GROWTH HORMONE deficiency
column3: resulting from either the lack of GROWTH HORMONE-RELEASING FACTOR from the HYPOTHALAMUS or from the mutations in the growth hormone gene (GH1) in the PITUITARY GLAND. It is also known as Type I pituitary dwarfism. Human hypophysial dwarf is caused by a deficiency of HUMAN GROWTH HORMONE during development.

column1: C19.297.656*D046150*Laron Syndrome*An autosomal recessive disorder characterized by short stature
column2: defective GROWTH HORMONE RECEPTOR
column3: and failure to generate INSULIN-LIKE GROWTH FACTOR I by GROWTH HORMONE. Laron syndrome is not a form of primary pituitary dwarfism (GROWTH HORMONE DEFICIENCY DWARFISM) but the result of mutation of the human GHR gene on chromosome 5.

column1: C19.344*D004701*Endocrine Gland Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the ENDOCRINE GLANDS.
C19.344.078*D000310*Adrenal Gland Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the ADRENAL GLANDS.
C19.344.078.265*D000306*Adrenal Cortex Neoplasms*Tumors or cancers of the ADRENAL CORTEX.
C19.344.078.265.500*D018246*Adrenocortical Adenoma*A benign neoplasm of the ADRENAL CORTEX. It is characterized by a well-defined nodular lesion
column2: usually less than 2.5 cm. Most adrenocortical adenomas are nonfunctional. The functional ones are yellow and contain LIPIDS. Depending on the cell type or cortical zone involved
column3: they may produce ALDOSTERONE; HYDROCORTISONE; DEHYDROEPIANDROSTERONE; and/or ANDROSTENEDIONE.

column1: C19.344.078.265.750*D018268*Adrenocortical Carcinoma*A malignant neoplasm of the ADRENAL CORTEX. Adrenocortical carcinomas are unencapsulated anaplastic (ANAPLASIA) masses sometimes exceeding 20 cm or 200 g. They are more likely to be functional than nonfunctional
column2: and produce ADRENAL CORTEX HORMONES that may result in hypercortisolism (CUSHING SYNDROME); HYPERALDOSTERONISM; and/or VIRILISM.

column1: C19.344.400*D009377*Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia*A group of autosomal dominant diseases characterized by the combined occurrence of tumors involving two or more ENDOCRINE GLANDS that secrete PEPTIDE HORMONES or AMINES. These neoplasias are often benign but can be malignant. They are classified by the endocrine glands involved and the degree of aggressiveness. The two major forms are MEN1 and MEN2 with gene mutations on CHROMOSOME 11 and CHROMOSOME 10
column2: respectively.

column1: C19.344.400.500*D018761*Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 1*A form of multiple endocrine neoplasia that is characterized by the combined occurrence of tumors in the PARATHYROID GLANDS
column2: the PITUITARY GLAND
column3: and the PANCREATIC ISLETS. The resulting clinical signs include HYPERPARATHYROIDISM; HYPERCALCEMIA; HYPERPROLACTINEMIA; CUSHING DISEASE; GASTRINOMA; and ZOLLINGER-ELLISON SYNDROME. This disease is due to loss-of-function of the MEN1 gene

column1: C19.344.400.505*D018813*Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 2a*A form of multiple endocrine neoplasia characterized by the presence of medullary carcinoma (CARCINOMA
column2: MEDULLARY) of the THYROID GLAND
column3: and usually with the co-occurrence of PHEOCHROMOCYTOMA
column6: it can occur with hyperplasia or adenoma of the PARATHYROID GLANDS. This disease is due to gain-of-function mutations of the MEN2 gene on CHROMOSOME 10 (Locus: 10q11.2)
column7: also known as the RET proto-oncogene that encodes a RECEPTOR PROTEIN-TYROSINE KINASE. It is an autosomal dominant inherited disease.

column1: C19.344.400.510*D018814*Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 2b*Similar to MEN2A
column2: it is also caused by mutations of the MEN2 gene
column3: also known as the RET proto-oncogene. Its clinical symptoms include medullary carcinoma (CARCINOMA
column4: MEDULLARY) of THYROID GLAND and PHEOCHROMOCYTOMA of ADRENAL MEDULLA (50%). Unlike MEN2a
column5: MEN2b does not involve PARATHYROID NEOPLASMS. It can be distinguished from MEN2A by its neural abnormalities such as mucosal NEUROMAS on EYELIDS; LIP; and TONGUE
column6: and ganglioneuromatosis of GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT leading to MEGACOLON. It is an autosomal dominant inherited disease.

column1: C19.344.410*D010051*Ovarian Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the OVARY. These neoplasms can be benign or malignant. They are classified according to the tissue of origin
column2: such as the surface EPITHELIUM

column1: C19.344.410.398*D006106*Granulosa Cell Tumor*A neoplasm composed entirely of GRANULOSA CELLS
column2: occurring mostly in the OVARY. In the adult form
column3: it may contain some THECA CELLS. This tumor often produces ESTRADIOL and INHIBIN. The excess estrogen exposure can lead to other malignancies in women and PRECOCIOUS PUBERTY in girls. In rare cases
column4: granulosa cell tumors have been identified in the TESTES.

column1: C19.344.410.431*D061325*Hereditary Breast and Ovarian Cancer Syndrome*Autosomal dominant HEREDITARY CANCER SYNDROME in which a mutation most often in either BRCA1 or BRCA2 is associated with a significantly increased risk for breast and ovarian cancers.
C19.344.410.464*D018311*Luteoma*An ovarian neoplasm composed of LUTEAL CELLS derived from luteinized GRANULOSA CELLS and THECA CELLS. Luteomas respond to GONADOTROPINS
column2: and vary in their hormone production (PROGESTERONE; ESTROGENS; or ANDROGENS). During PREGNANCY
column3: a transient type of luteoma may develop due to an exaggerated LUTEINIZATION of the OVARY.

column1: C19.344.410.531*D008539*Meigs Syndrome*The triad of benign FIBROMA or other ovarian tumors with ASCITES
column2: and HYDROTHORAX due to large PLEURAL EFFUSIONS.

column1: C19.344.410.648*D018310*Sertoli-Leydig Cell Tumor*A sex cord-gonadal stromal tumor consists of LEYDIG CELLS; SERTOLI CELLS; and FIBROBLASTS in varying proportions and degree of differentiation. Most such tumors produce ANDROGENS in the Leydig cells
column2: formerly known as androblastoma or arrhenoblastoma. Androblastomas occur in the TESTIS or the OVARY causing precocious masculinization in the males
column4: or virilization (VIRILISM) in the females. In some cases

column1: C19.344.410.765*D013798*Thecoma*A gonadal stromal neoplasm composed only of THECA CELLS
column2: occurring mostly in the postmenopausal OVARY. It is filled with lipid-containing spindle cells and produces ESTROGENS that can lead to ENDOMETRIAL HYPERPLASIA; UTERINE HEMORRHAGE; or other malignancies in postmenopausal women and sexual precocity in girls. When tumors containing theca cells also contain FIBROBLASTS
column3: they are identified as thecoma-fibroma tumors with less active hormone production.

column1: C19.344.421*D010190*Pancreatic Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the PANCREAS. Depending on the types of ISLET CELLS present in the tumors
column2: various hormones can be secreted: GLUCAGON from PANCREATIC ALPHA CELLS; INSULIN from PANCREATIC BETA CELLS; and SOMATOSTATIN from the SOMATOSTATIN-SECRETING CELLS. Most are malignant except the insulin-producing tumors (INSULINOMA).
Islet Cell*A benign tumor of the pancreatic ISLET CELLS. Usually it involves the INSULIN-producing PANCREATIC BETA CELLS

column1: C19.344.421.249.500*D007340*Insulinoma*A benign tumor of the PANCREATIC BETA CELLS. Insulinoma secretes excess INSULIN resulting in HYPOGLYCEMIA.

column2: Islet Cell*A primary malignant neoplasm of the pancreatic ISLET CELLS. Usually it involves the non-INSULIN-producing cell types
column3: the PANCREATIC ALPHA CELLS and the pancreatic delta cells (SOMATOSTATIN-SECRETING CELLS) in GLUCAGONOMA and SOMATOSTATINOMA

column1: C19.344.421.500.124*D015408*Gastrinoma*A GASTRIN-secreting neuroendocrine tumor of the non-beta ISLET CELLS
column2: the GASTRIN-SECRETING CELLS. This type of tumor is primarily located in the PANCREAS or the DUODENUM. Majority of gastrinomas are malignant. They metastasize to the LIVER; LYMPH NODES; and BONE but rarely elsewhere. The presence of gastrinoma is one of three requirements to be met for identification of ZOLLINGER-ELLISON SYNDROME
column3: which sometimes occurs in families with MULTIPLE ENDOCRINE NEOPLASIA TYPE 1; (MEN 1).

column1: C19.344.421.500.249*D005935*Glucagonoma*An almost always malignant GLUCAGON-secreting tumor derived from the PANCREATIC ALPHA CELLS. It is characterized by a distinctive migratory ERYTHEMA; WEIGHT LOSS; STOMATITIS; GLOSSITIS; DIABETES MELLITUS; hypoaminoacidemia; and normochromic normocytic ANEMIA.

C19.344.421.500.500*D013005*Somatostatinoma*A SOMATOSTATIN-secreting tumor derived from the pancreatic delta cells (SOMATOSTATIN-SECRETING CELLS). It is also found in the INTESTINE. Somatostatinomas are associated with DIABETES MELLITUS; CHOLELITHIASIS; STEATORRHEA; and HYPOCHLORHYDRIA. The majority of somatostatinomas have the potential for METASTASIS.
C19.344.421.500.750*D003969*Vipoma*A tumor that secretes VASOACTIVE INTESTINAL PEPTIDE
column2: a neuropeptide that causes VASODILATION; relaxation of smooth muscles; watery DIARRHEA; HYPOKALEMIA; and HYPOCHLORHYDRIA. Vipomas
column3: derived from the pancreatic ISLET CELLS
column4: generally are malignant and can secrete other hormones. In most cases
column5: Vipomas are located in the PANCREAS but can be found in extrapancreatic sites.

column2: Pancreatic Ductal*Carcinoma that arises from the PANCREATIC DUCTS. It accounts for the majority of cancers derived from the PANCREAS.

column1: C19.344.473*D009384*Paraneoplastic Endocrine Syndromes*Syndromes resulting from inappropriate production of HORMONES or hormone-like materials by NEOPLASMS in non-endocrine tissues or not by the usual ENDOCRINE GLANDS. Such hormone outputs are called ectopic hormone (HORMONES
column2: ECTOPIC) secretion.

column1: C19.344.525*D010282*Parathyroid Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the PARATHYROID GLANDS.
C19.344.609*D010911*Pituitary Neoplasms*Neoplasms which arise from or metastasize to the PITUITARY GLAND. The majority of pituitary neoplasms are adenomas
column2: which are divided into non-secreting and secreting forms. Hormone producing forms are further classified by the type of hormone they secrete. Pituitary adenomas may also be characterized by their staining properties (see ADENOMA
column5: CHROMOPHOBE). Pituitary tumors may compress adjacent structures
column8: and the OPTIC CHIASM. Chiasmal compression may result in bitemporal HEMIANOPSIA.

column1: C19.344.609.145*D049913*ACTH-Secreting Pituitary Adenoma*A pituitary adenoma which secretes ADRENOCORTICOTROPIN
column2: leading to CUSHING DISEASE.

column1: C19.344.609.145.500*D009347*Nelson Syndrome*A syndrome characterized by HYPERPIGMENTATION
column2: enlarging pituitary mass
column3: visual defects secondary to compression of the OPTIC CHIASM
column4: and elevated serum ACTH. It is caused by the expansion of an underlying ACTH-SECRETING PITUITARY ADENOMA that grows in the absence of feedback inhibition by adrenal CORTICOSTEROIDS

column1: C19.344.609.292*D049912*Growth Hormone-Secreting Pituitary Adenoma*A pituitary tumor that secretes GROWTH HORMONE. In humans
column2: excess HUMAN GROWTH HORMONE leads to ACROMEGALY.

column1: C19.344.609.792*D015175*Prolactinoma*A pituitary adenoma which secretes PROLACTIN
column2: leading to HYPERPROLACTINEMIA. Clinical manifestations include AMENORRHEA; GALACTORRHEA; IMPOTENCE; HEADACHE; visual disturbances; and CEREBROSPINAL FLUID RHINORRHEA.

column1: C19.344.762*D013736*Testicular Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the TESTIS. Germ cell tumors (GERMINOMA) of the testis constitute 95% of all testicular neoplasms.

C19.344.762.500*D018310*Sertoli-Leydig Cell Tumor*A sex cord-gonadal stromal tumor consists of LEYDIG CELLS; SERTOLI CELLS; and FIBROBLASTS in varying proportions and degree of differentiation. Most such tumors produce ANDROGENS in the Leydig cells
column2: formerly known as androblastoma or arrhenoblastoma. Androblastomas occur in the TESTIS or the OVARY causing precocious masculinization in the males
column4: or virilization (VIRILISM) in the females. In some cases

column1: C19.344.762.500.249*D007984*Leydig Cell Tumor*Gonadal interstitial or stromal cell neoplasm composed of only LEYDIG CELLS. These tumors may produce one or more of the steroid hormones such as ANDROGENS; ESTROGENS; and CORTICOSTEROIDS. Clinical symptoms include testicular swelling
column2: GYNECOMASTIA

column1: C19.344.762.500.500*D012707*Sertoli Cell Tumor*Gonadal neoplasm composed entirely of SERTOLI CELLS or may have a component of GRANULOSA CELLS. Some of the Sertoli cell tumors produce ESTROGEN or ANDROGENS
column2: but seldom in sufficient quantity to cause clinical symptoms such as FEMINIZATION or masculinization (VIRILISM).

column1: C19.344.894*D013964*Thyroid Neoplasms*Tumors or cancer of the THYROID GLAND.

C19.344.894.800*D016606*Thyroid Nodule*A small circumscribed mass in the THYROID GLAND that can be of neoplastic growth or non-neoplastic abnormality. It lacks a well-defined capsule or glandular architecture. Thyroid nodules are often benign but can be malignant. The growth of nodules can lead to a multinodular goiter (GOITER
column2: NODULAR).

column1: C19.368*D053716*Female Athlete Triad Syndrome*A condition of competitive female athletes in which there are interrelated problems of feeding and eating disorders; AMENORRHEA; and OSTEOPOROSIS.
C19.391*D006058*Gonadal Disorders*Pathological processes of the OVARIES or the TESTES.
C19.391.119*D012734*Disorders of Sex Development*In gonochoristic organisms
column2: congenital conditions in which development of chromosomal
column4: or anatomical sex is atypical. Effects from exposure to abnormal levels of GONADAL HORMONES in the maternal environment
column5: or disruption of the function of those hormones by ENDOCRINE DISRUPTORS are included.

column2: XX Disorders of Sex Development*Congenital conditions in individuals with a female karyotype
column3: in which the development of the gonadal or anatomical sex is atypical.

column2: XX Testicular Disorders of Sex Development*Congenital conditions in individuals in which male GONADS develop in a genetic female (female to male sex reversal).

column1: C19.391.119.064.249*D023961*Gonadal Dysgenesis
column4: XX gonadal dysgenesis may be sporadic or familial. Familial XX gonadal dysgenesis is transmitted as an autosomal recessive trait and its locus was mapped to chromosome 2. Mutation in the gene for the FSH receptor (RECEPTORS
column5: FSH) was detected. Sporadic XX gonadal dysgenesis is heterogeneous and has been associated with trisomy-13 and trisomy-18. These phenotypic females are characterized by a normal stature
column9: elevated plasma LUTEINIZING HORMONE and FSH concentration.

column1: C19.391.119.064.500*D017588*Hyperandrogenism*A condition caused by the excessive secretion of ANDROGENS from the ADRENAL CORTEX; the OVARIES; or the TESTES. The clinical significance in males is negligible. In women
column2: the common manifestations are HIRSUTISM and VIRILISM as seen in patients with POLYCYSTIC OVARY SYNDROME and ADRENOCORTICAL HYPERFUNCTION.
XY Disorders of Sex Development*Congenital conditions in individuals with a male karyotype
column3: in which the development of the gonadal or anatomical sex is atypical.

column1: C19.391.119.096.500*D013734*Androgen-Insensitivity Syndrome*A disorder of sexual development transmitted as an X-linked recessive trait. These patients have a karyotype of 46
column2: XY with end-organ resistance to androgen due to mutations in the androgen receptor (RECEPTORS
column3: ANDROGEN) gene. Severity of the defect in receptor quantity or quality correlates with their phenotypes. In these genetic males
column4: the phenotypic spectrum ranges from those with normal female external genitalia
column5: through those with genital ambiguity as in Reifenstein Syndrome
column6: to that of a normal male with INFERTILITY.

column1: C19.391.119.096.562*D030321*Denys-Drash Syndrome*A disorder of sex development characterized by UROGENITAL ABNORMALITIES; GONADAL DYSGENESIS; and WILMS TUMOR. It is caused by a mutation in the Wilms tumor suppressor gene (GENES
column2: WILMS TUMOR) on chromosome 11.

column1: C19.391.119.096.624*D052159*Frasier Syndrome*A syndrome characterized by CHRONIC KIDNEY FAILURE and GONADAL DYSGENESIS in phenotypic females with karyotype of 46
column2: XY or female individual with a normal 46
column3: XX karyotype. It is caused by donor splice-site mutations of Wilms tumor suppressor gene (GENES

column1: C19.391.119.096.687*D006061*Gonadal Dysgenesis
column3: XY*Defects in the SEX DETERMINATION PROCESS in 46
column4: XY individuals that result in abnormal gonadal development and deficiencies in TESTOSTERONE and subsequently ANTIMULLERIAN HORMONE or other factors required for normal male sex development. This leads to the development of female phenotypes (male to female sex reversal)
column6: and bilateral streak or dysgenic gonads which are susceptible to GONADAL TISSUE NEOPLASMS. An XY gonadal dysgenesis is associated with structural abnormalities on the Y CHROMOSOME
column9: or a mutation in other autosomal genes that are involved in sex determination.

column1: C19.391.119.096.687.500*D018238*Gonadoblastoma*A complex neoplasm composed of a mixture of gonadal elements
column2: such as large primordial GERM CELLS
column3: immature SERTOLI CELLS or GRANULOSA CELLS of the sex cord
column4: and gonadal stromal cells. Gonadoblastomas are most often associated with gonadal dysgenesis

column1: C19.391.119.096.750*D017436*Kallmann Syndrome*A genetically heterogeneous disorder caused by hypothalamic GNRH deficiency and OLFACTORY NERVE defects. It is characterized by congenital HYPOGONADOTROPIC HYPOGONADISM and ANOSMIA
column2: possibly with additional midline defects. It can be transmitted as an X-linked (GENETIC DISEASES

column1: C19.391.119.096.875*D017624*WAGR Syndrome*A contiguous gene syndrome associated with hemizygous deletions of chromosome region 11p13. The condition is marked by the combination of WILMS TUMOR; ANIRIDIA; GENITOURINARY ABNORMALITIES; and INTELLECTUAL DISABILITY.

C19.391.119.129*D047808*Adrenogenital Syndrome*Abnormal SEX DIFFERENTIATION or congenital DISORDERS OF SEX DEVELOPMENT caused by abnormal levels of steroid hormones expressed by the GONADS or the ADRENAL GLANDS
column2: such as in CONGENITAL ADRENAL HYPERPLASIA and ADRENAL CORTEX NEOPLASMS. Due to abnormal steroid biosynthesis
column3: clinical features include VIRILISM in females; FEMINIZATION in males; or precocious sexual development in children.

column1: C19.391.119.129.500*D000312*Adrenal Hyperplasia
column2: Congenital*A group of inherited disorders of the ADRENAL GLANDS
column3: caused by enzyme defects in the synthesis of cortisol (HYDROCORTISONE) and/or ALDOSTERONE leading to accumulation of precursors for ANDROGENS. Depending on the hormone imbalance
column4: congenital adrenal hyperplasia can be classified as salt-wasting
column7: or feminizing. Defects in STEROID 21-HYDROXYLASE; STEROID 11-BETA-HYDROXYLASE; STEROID 17-ALPHA-HYDROXYLASE; 3-beta-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase (3-HYDROXYSTEROID DEHYDROGENASES); TESTOSTERONE 5-ALPHA-REDUCTASE; or steroidogenic acute regulatory protein; among others

column1: C19.391.119.129.750*D017588*Hyperandrogenism*A condition caused by the excessive secretion of ANDROGENS from the ADRENAL CORTEX; the OVARIES; or the TESTES. The clinical significance in males is negligible. In women
column2: the common manifestations are HIRSUTISM and VIRILISM as seen in patients with POLYCYSTIC OVARY SYNDROME and ADRENOCORTICAL HYPERFUNCTION.

column1: C19.391.119.309*D006059*Gonadal Dysgenesis*A number of syndromes with defective gonadal developments such as streak GONADS and dysgenetic testes or ovaries. The spectrum of gonadal and sexual abnormalities is reflected in their varied sex chromosome (SEX CHROMOSOMES) constitution as shown by the karyotypes of 45
column2: X monosomy (TURNER SYNDROME); 46
column7: XY); and sex chromosome MOSAICISM; (GONADAL DYSGENESIS

column10: to male. This concept includes gonadal agenesis.

column5: FSH) was detected. Sporadic XX gonadal dysgenesis is heterogeneous and has been associated with trisomy-13 and trisomy-18. These phenotypic females are characterized by a normal stature

column1: C19.391.119.309.631*D050035*Sexual Infantilism*The permanent lack of SEXUAL DEVELOPMENT in an individual. This defect is usually observed at an age after expected PUBERTY.
C19.391.119.309.872*D014424*Turner Syndrome*A syndrome of defective gonadal development in phenotypic females associated with the karyotype 45

column3: XO). Patients generally are of short stature with undifferentiated GONADS (streak gonads)
column10: and CONGENITAL HEART DEFECTS. NOONAN SYNDROME (also called Pseudo-Turner Syndrome and Male Turner Syndrome) resembles this disorder; however
column11: it occurs in males and females with a normal karyotype and is inherited as an autosomal dominant.

column1: C19.391.119.343*D050090*Ovotesticular Disorders of Sex Development*Conditions of sexual ambiguity in which the individual possesses gonadal tissues of both sexes
column2: tissues from the OVARY and the TESTIS. There can be a testis on one side and an ovary on the other (lateral)
column3: or there may be combined ovarian and testicular tissue (ovotestes) on each side (bilateral). The karyotype may be 46
column7: XY. These disorders have historically been called true hermaphroditism.

column1: C19.391.119.795*D058533*Sex Chromosome Disorders of Sex Development*Congenital conditions of atypical sexual development associated with abnormal sex chromosome constitutions including MONOSOMY; TRISOMY; and MOSAICISM.
C19.391.119.795.124*D005611*Freemartinism*A condition occurring in the female offspring of dizygotic twins (TWIN

column4: TESTICULAR HORMONES from the male fetus can androgenize the female fetus producing a sterile XX/XY chimeric female(CHIMERISM).
