column2: usually formed in the urine-collecting area of the kidney (KIDNEY PELVIS). Their sizes vary and most contains CALCIUM OXALATE.

column1: C23.300.175.850.550.500*D000069856*Staghorn Calculi*Renal calculi with a characteristic shape like antlers of a deer
column2: formed as it extends into multiple calices of the RENAL PELVIS. A large number of staghorn calculi as well as other URINARY CALCULI are composed of STRUVITE.

column1: C23.300.175.850.750*D014514*Ureteral Calculi*Stones in the URETER that are formed in the KIDNEY. They are rarely more than 5 mm in diameter for larger renal stones cannot enter ureters. They are often lodged at the ureteral narrowing and can cause excruciating renal colic.
C23.300.175.850.875*D001744*Urinary Bladder Calculi*Stones in the URINARY BLADDER; also known as vesical calculi
column2: bladder stones

column1: C23.300.190*D058606*Accessory Atrioventricular Bundle*Extra impulse-conducting tissue in the heart that creates abnormal impulse-conducting connections between HEART ATRIA and HEART VENTRICLES.
C23.300.250*D002828*Choristoma*A mass of histologically normal tissue present in an abnormal location.
C23.300.287*D003251*Constriction
column2: Pathologic*The condition of an anatomical structure's being constricted beyond normal dimensions.

column1: C23.300.306*D003560*Cysts*Any fluid-filled closed cavity or sac that is lined by an EPITHELIUM. Cysts can be of normal
column2: abnormal

column1: C23.300.306.500*D010310*Parovarian Cyst*A cyst (CYSTS) near the OVARY
column2: derived from anomalies of the FALLOPIAN TUBES or the BROAD LIGAMENT. The paramesonephric type consists of ciliated cells similar to the oviduct epithelium. The mesonephric type consisted of an epithelium with minimally surface structures. They can be found on the thin oviduct (paratubal cysts) or near its fimbriated end (hydatid of Morgagni).

column1: C23.300.306.750*D013088*Spermatocele*A cystic dilation of the EPIDIDYMIS
column2: usually in the head portion (caput epididymis). The cyst fluid contains dead SPERMATOZOA and can be easily differentiated from TESTICULAR HYDROCELE and other testicular lesions.

column1: C23.300.325*D004108*Dilatation
column2: Pathologic*The condition of an anatomical structure's being dilated beyond normal dimensions.

column1: C23.300.415*D004240*Diverticulum*A pouch or sac developed from a tubular or saccular organ
column2: such as the GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT.
Colon*A pouch or sac opening from the COLON.
Esophageal*Saccular protrusion beyond the wall of the ESOPHAGUS.

column1: C23.300.415.625.900*D016672*Zenker Diverticulum*A DIVERTICULUM at the upper end of the ESOPHAGUS through the cricopharyngeal muscle at the junction of the PHARYNX and the esophagus.

column2: Stomach*Saccular
column3: outward protrusion of all or a portion of the wall of the STOMACH.

column1: C23.300.415.750*D008467*Meckel Diverticulum*A congenital abnormality characterized by the outpouching or sac formation in the ILEUM. It is a remnant of the embryonic YOLK SAC in which the VITELLINE DUCT failed to close.
C23.300.505*D005146*Facial Asymmetry*Congenital or acquired asymmetry of the face.
C23.300.575*D005402*Fistula*Abnormal communication most commonly seen between two internal organs
column2: or between an internal organ and the surface of the body.

column1: C23.300.575.150*D017577*Cutaneous Fistula*An abnormal passage or communication leading from an internal organ to the surface of the body.
C23.300.575.185*D016154*Digestive System Fistula*An abnormal passage communicating between any components of the digestive system
column2: or between any part of the digestive system and surrounding organ(s).

column1: C23.300.575.185.150*D001658*Biliary Fistula*Abnormal passage in any organ of the biliary tract or between biliary organs and other organs.
C23.300.575.185.250*D004937*Esophageal Fistula*Abnormal passage communicating with the ESOPHAGUS. The most common type is TRACHEOESOPHAGEAL FISTULA between the esophagus and the TRACHEA.
C23.300.575.185.250.725*D014138*Tracheoesophageal Fistula*Abnormal passage between the ESOPHAGUS and the TRACHEA
column2: acquired or congenital

column1: C23.300.575.185.375*D005747*Gastric Fistula*Abnormal passage communicating with the STOMACH.
C23.300.575.185.550*D007412*Intestinal Fistula*An abnormal anatomical passage between the INTESTINE
column2: and another segment of the intestine or other organs. External intestinal fistula is connected to the SKIN (enterocutaneous fistula). Internal intestinal fistula can be connected to a number of organs
column5: or the URINARY BLADDER of the URINARY TRACT (colovesical fistula). Risk factors include inflammatory processes

column1: C23.300.575.185.550.600*D012003*Rectal Fistula*An abnormal anatomical passage connecting the RECTUM to the outside
column2: with an orifice at the site of drainage.

column1: C23.300.575.185.550.600.650*D012006*Rectovaginal Fistula*An abnormal anatomical passage between the RECTUM and the VAGINA.
C23.300.575.185.775*D010185*Pancreatic Fistula*Abnormal passage communicating with the PANCREAS.
C23.300.575.500*D016155*Oral Fistula*An abnormal passage within the mouth communicating between two or more anatomical structures.
C23.300.575.500.275*D003751*Dental Fistula*An abnormal passage in the oral cavity on the gingiva.
C23.300.575.500.550*D009957*Oroantral Fistula*A fistula between the maxillary sinus and the oral cavity.
C23.300.575.500.775*D012467*Salivary Gland Fistula*A fistula between a salivary duct or gland and the cutaneous surface of the oral cavity.

C23.300.575.687*D016156*Respiratory Tract Fistula*An abnormal passage communicating between any component of the respiratory tract or between any part of the respiratory system and surrounding organs.
C23.300.575.687.225*D001983*Bronchial Fistula*An abnormal passage or communication between a bronchus and another part of the body.
C23.300.575.825*D014548*Urinary Fistula*An abnormal passage in any part of the URINARY TRACT between itself or with other organs.
C23.300.575.825.250*D001747*Urinary Bladder Fistula*An abnormal passage in the URINARY BLADDER or between the bladder and any surrounding organ.
C23.300.575.825.250.775*D014719*Vesicovaginal Fistula*An abnormal anatomical passage between the URINARY BLADDER and the VAGINA.
C23.300.575.925*D014624*Vaginal Fistula*An abnormal anatomical passage that connects the VAGINA to other organs
column2: such as the bladder (VESICOVAGINAL FISTULA) or the rectum (RECTOVAGINAL FISTULA).

column1: C23.300.575.925.558*D012006*Rectovaginal Fistula*An abnormal anatomical passage between the RECTUM and the VAGINA.
C23.300.575.925.816*D014719*Vesicovaginal Fistula*An abnormal anatomical passage between the URINARY BLADDER and the VAGINA.
C23.300.575.950*D016157*Vascular Fistula*An abnormal passage between two or more BLOOD VESSELS
column2: between ARTERIES; VEINS; or between an artery and a vein.

column1: C23.300.575.950.150*D001159*Arterio-Arterial Fistula*Abnormal communication between two ARTERIES that may result from injury or occur as a congenital abnormality.

C23.300.575.950.150.500*D063748*Bland White Garland Syndrome*A congenital coronary vessel anomaly in which the left main CORONARY ARTERY originates from the PULMONARY ARTERY instead of from AORTA. The congenital heart defect typically results in coronary artery FISTULA; LEFT-SIDED HEART FAILURE and MITRAL VALVE INSUFFICIENCY during the first months of life.

C23.300.575.950.250*D001164*Arteriovenous Fistula*An abnormal direct communication between an artery and a vein without passing through the CAPILLARIES. An A-V fistula usually leads to the formation of a dilated sac-like connection
column2: arteriovenous aneurysm. The locations and size of the shunts determine the degree of effects on the cardiovascular functions such as BLOOD PRESSURE and HEART RATE.

column1: C23.300.575.950.250.500*D020216*Carotid-Cavernous Sinus Fistula*An acquired or spontaneous abnormality in which there is communication between CAVERNOUS SINUS
column2: a venous structure
column3: and the CAROTID ARTERIES. It is often associated with HEAD TRAUMA
column5: BASILAR). Clinical signs often include VISION DISORDERS and INTRACRANIAL HYPERTENSION.

column1: C23.300.707*D006547*Hernia*Protrusion of tissue
column2: structure
column3: or part of an organ through the bone
column5: or the membrane by which it is normally contained. Hernia may involve tissues such as the ABDOMINAL WALL or the respiratory DIAPHRAGM. Hernias may be internal

column1: C23.300.707.186*D004677*Encephalocele*Brain tissue herniation through a congenital or acquired defect in the skull. The majority of congenital encephaloceles occur in the occipital or frontal regions. Clinical features include a protuberant mass that may be pulsatile. The quantity and location of protruding neural tissue determines the type and degree of neurologic deficit. Visual defects
column2: psychomotor developmental delay
column3: and persistent motor deficits frequently occur.

column2: Abdominal*A protrusion of abdominal structures through the retaining ABDOMINAL WALL. It involves two parts: an opening in the abdominal wall
column3: and a hernia sac consisting of PERITONEUM and abdominal contents. Abdominal hernias include groin hernia (HERNIA

column1: C23.300.707.374.500*D020139*Gastroschisis*A congenital defect with major fissure in the ABDOMINAL WALL lateral to
column2: but not at
column3: the UMBILICUS. This results in the extrusion of VISCERA. Unlike OMPHALOCELE
column4: herniated structures in gastroschisis are not covered by a sac or PERITONEUM.

column2: Femoral*A groin hernia occurring inferior to the inguinal ligament and medial to the FEMORAL VEIN and FEMORAL ARTERY. The femoral hernia sac has a small neck but may enlarge considerably when it enters the subcutaneous tissue of the thigh. It is caused by defects in the ABDOMINAL WALL.

Inguinal*An abdominal hernia with an external bulge in the GROIN region. It can be classified by the location of herniation. Indirect inguinal hernias occur through the internal inguinal ring. Direct inguinal hernias occur through defects in the ABDOMINAL WALL (transversalis fascia) in Hesselbach's triangle. The former type is commonly seen in children and young adults; the latter in adults.
Ventral*A hernia caused by weakness of the anterior ABDOMINAL WALL due to midline defects
column4: or increased intra-abdominal pressure. Ventral hernias include UMBILICAL HERNIA

column2: Umbilical*A HERNIA due to an imperfect closure or weakness of the umbilical ring. It appears as a skin-covered protrusion at the UMBILICUS during crying
column4: or straining. The hernia generally consists of OMENTUM or SMALL INTESTINE. The vast majority of umbilical hernias are congenital but can be acquired due to severe abdominal distention.

column2: Diaphragmatic*Protrusion of abdominal structures into the THORAX as a result of congenital or traumatic defects in the respiratory DIAPHRAGM.
Diaphragmatic
column3: Congenital*Protrusion of abdominal structures into the THORAX as a result of embryologic defects in the DIAPHRAGM often present in the neonatal period. It can be isolated
column5: nonsyndromic or be a part of chromosome abnormality. Associated pulmonary hypoplasia and PULMONARY HYPERTENSION can further complicate stabilization and surgical intervention.

column2: Diaphragmatic
column3: Traumatic*The type of DIAPHRAGMATIC HERNIA caused by TRAUMA or injury

column2: Hiatal*STOMACH herniation located at or near the diaphragmatic opening for the ESOPHAGUS
Obturator*A pelvic hernia through the obturator foramen
column3: a large aperture in the hip bone normally covered by a membrane. Obturator hernia can lead to intestinal incarceration and INTESTINAL OBSTRUCTION.

column1: C23.300.707.945*D000069290*Incisional Hernia*Protrusion of tissue at or near the site of an incision from a previous surgery.

C23.300.707.952*D007405*Intervertebral Disc Displacement*An INTERVERTEBRAL DISC in which the NUCLEUS PULPOSUS has protruded through surrounding ANNULUS FIBROSUS. This occurs most frequently in the lower lumbar region.
C23.300.707.968*D008588*Meningocele*A congenital or acquired protrusion of the meninges
column2: unaccompanied by neural tissue
column3: through a bony defect in the skull or vertebral column.

column1: C23.300.707.984*D020047*Rectocele*Herniation of the RECTUM into the VAGINA.
C23.300.775*D006984*Hypertrophy*General increase in bulk of a part or organ due to CELL ENLARGEMENT and accumulation of FLUIDS AND SECRETIONS
column2: not due to tumor formation
column3: nor to an increase in the number of cells (HYPERPLASIA).

column1: C23.300.775.250*D006332*Cardiomegaly*Enlargement of the HEART
column2: usually indicated by a cardiothoracic ratio above 0.50. Heart enlargement may involve the right
column4: or both HEART VENTRICLES or HEART ATRIA. Cardiomegaly is a nonspecific symptom seen in patients with chronic systolic heart failure (HEART FAILURE) or several forms of CARDIOMYOPATHIES.

column2: Left Ventricular*Enlargement of the LEFT VENTRICLE of the heart. This increase in ventricular mass is attributed to sustained abnormal pressure or volume loads and is a contributor to cardiovascular morbidity and mortality.

Right Ventricular*Enlargement of the RIGHT VENTRICLE of the heart. This increase in ventricular mass is often attributed to PULMONARY HYPERTENSION and is a contributor to cardiovascular morbidity and mortality.

column1: C23.300.775.525*D006529*Hepatomegaly*Enlargement of the liver.
C23.300.775.750*D013163*Splenomegaly*Enlargement of the spleen.
C23.300.808*D007870*Leg Length Inequality*A condition in which one of a pair of legs fails to grow as long as the other
column2: which could result from injury or surgery.

column1: C23.300.816*D007971*Leukoplakia*A white patch lesion found on a MUCOUS MEMBRANE that cannot be scraped off. Leukoplakia is generally considered a precancerous condition
column2: however its appearance may also result from a variety of HEREDITARY DISEASES.
Oral*A white patch seen on the oral mucosa. It is considered a premalignant condition and is often tobacco-induced. When evidence of Epstein-Barr virus is present
column3: the condition is called hairy leukoplakia (LEUKOPLAKIA

column2: Hairy*Epithelial hyperplasia of the oral mucosa associated with Epstein-Barr virus (HERPESVIRUS 4
column3: HUMAN) and found almost exclusively in persons with HIV infection. The lesion consists of a white patch that is often corrugated or hairy.

column2: Malformed*Deformities in nail structure or appearance
column7: etc. Genetic diseases such as PACHYONYCHIA CONGENITA can result in malformed nails.

column1: C23.300.820.500*D056684*Yellow Nail Syndrome*A rare condition characterized by the presence of yellow nails
column2: LYMPHEDEMA
column3: and/or PLEURAL EFFUSION with respiratory tract involvement. Abnormal lymphatic network may play a role in its etiology. Occasionally inherited
column4: yellow nail syndrome mostly is sporadic without apparent family history.

column2: Amyloid*Accumulations of extracellularly deposited AMYLOID FIBRILS within tissues.
Atherosclerotic*Lesions formed within the walls of ARTERIES.

column1: C23.300.825*D011127*Polyps*Discrete abnormal tissue masses that protrude into the lumen of the DIGESTIVE TRACT or the RESPIRATORY TRACT. Polyps can be spheroidal
column2: hemispheroidal
column3: or irregular mound-shaped structures attached to the MUCOUS MEMBRANE of the lumen wall either by a stalk

column1: C23.300.825.411*D007417*Intestinal Polyps*Discrete abnormal tissue masses that protrude into the lumen of the INTESTINE. A polyp is attached to the intestinal wall either by a stalk
column2: pedunculus

column1: C23.300.825.411.235*D003111*Colonic Polyps*Discrete tissue masses that protrude into the lumen of the COLON. These POLYPS are connected to the wall of the colon either by a stalk
column2: pedunculus

column1: C23.300.825.557*D009298*Nasal Polyps*Focal accumulations of EDEMA fluid in the NASAL MUCOSA accompanied by HYPERPLASIA of the associated submucosal connective tissue. Polyps may be NEOPLASMS
column2: foci of INFLAMMATION

column1: C23.300.842*D011391*Prolapse*The protrusion of an organ or part of an organ into a natural or artificial orifice.

C23.300.842.624*D056887*Pelvic Organ Prolapse*Abnormal descent of a pelvic organ resulting in the protrusion of the organ beyond its normal anatomical confines. Symptoms often include vaginal discomfort
column2: DYSPAREUNIA; URINARY STRESS INCONTINENCE; and FECAL INCONTINENCE.

column1: C23.300.842.624.249*D052858*Cystocele*A HERNIA-like condition in which the weakened pelvic muscles cause the URINARY BLADDER to drop from its normal position. Fallen urinary bladder is more common in females with the bladder dropping into the VAGINA and less common in males with the bladder dropping into the SCROTUM.

C23.300.842.624.500*D012005*Rectal Prolapse*Protrusion of the rectal mucous membrane through the anus. There are various degrees: incomplete with no displacement of the anal sphincter muscle; complete with displacement of the anal sphincter muscle; complete with no displacement of the anal sphincter muscle but with herniation of the bowel; and internal complete with rectosigmoid or upper rectum intussusception into the lower rectum.

C23.300.842.624.750*D014596*Uterine Prolapse*Downward displacement of the UTERUS. It is classified in various degrees: in the first degree the UTERINE CERVIX is within the vaginal orifice; in the second degree the cervix is outside the orifice; in the third degree the entire uterus is outside the orifice.
C23.300.842.624.875*D014782*Visceral Prolapse*The prolapse or downward displacement of the VISCERA.

column2: Spontaneous*Tear or break of an organ
column3: vessel or other soft part of the body
column4: occurring in the absence of external force.

column1: C23.300.940*D000072663*Spontaneous Perforation*A pathological hole in an organ
column2: blood vessel or other soft part of the body
column3: occurring in the absence of external force.

column1: C23.300.955*D000072717*Tertiary Lymphoid Structures*Aggregates of immune cells formed near the sites of chronically inflamed
column2: infected

column1: C23.300.970*D014102*Torsion Abnormality*An abnormal twisting or rotation of a bodily part or member on its axis.
C23.300.970.249*D060750*Bone Anteversion*Malalignment of a bone in which its head and neck is rotated excessively forward or inward.

C23.300.970.249.500*D060905*Coxa Vara*Hip deformity in which the femoral neck leans forward resulting in a decrease in the angle between femoral neck and its shaft. It may be congenital often syndromic
column2: acquired

column1: C23.300.970.374*D060751*Bone Retroversion*Attachment of a bone in which its head and neck is rotated excessively backward.
C23.300.970.374.500*D060906*Coxa Valga*Hip deformity in which the angle between the femoral neck and its shaft is increased. It may be congenital
column2: acquired

column1: C23.300.970.500*D045822*Intestinal Volvulus*A twisting in the intestine (INTESTINES) that can cause INTESTINAL OBSTRUCTION.

C23.300.970.750*D060725*Uterine Retroversion*A condition in which the UTERUS is found tilted backward toward the spine. The uterus is more commonly found in a straight vertical or anteverted (tipped forward) position. Although retroverted uterus is a normal variant position without symptoms
column2: it is sometimes associated with pain

column1: C23.300.977*D066253*Vascular Remodeling*The active alterations of vascular wall structures
column2: often leading to elevated VASCULAR RESISTANCE. It is associated with AGING; ATHEROSCLEROSIS; DIABETES MELLITUS; HYPERTENSION; PREGNANCY; PULMONARY HYPERTENSION; and STROKE
column3: but is also a normal part of EMBRYOGENESIS.

column1: C23.300.985*D020257*Ventricular Remodeling*The geometric and structural changes that the HEART VENTRICLES undergo
column2: usually following MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION. It comprises expansion of the infarct and dilatation of the healthy ventricle segments. While most prevalent in the left ventricle
column3: it can also occur in the right ventricle.

column1: C23.550*D010335*Pathologic Processes*The abnormal mechanisms and forms involved in the dysfunctions of tissues and organs.
C23.550.035*D000051*Acantholysis*Separation of the prickle cells of the stratum spinosum of the epidermis
column2: resulting in atrophy of the prickle cell layer. It is seen in diseases such as pemphigus vulgaris (see PEMPHIGUS) and DARIER DISEASE.

column1: C23.550.073*D001145*Arrhythmias
column2: Cardiac*Any disturbances of the normal rhythmic beating of the heart or MYOCARDIAL CONTRACTION. Cardiac arrhythmias can be classified by the abnormalities in HEART RATE

Sinus*Irregular HEART RATE caused by abnormal function of the SINOATRIAL NODE. It is characterized by a greater than 10% change between the maximum and the minimum sinus cycle length or 120 milliseconds.

column1: C23.550.073.093.249*D012804*Sick Sinus Syndrome*A condition caused by dysfunctions related to the SINOATRIAL NODE including impulse generation (CARDIAC SINUS ARREST) and impulse conduction (SINOATRIAL EXIT BLOCK). It is characterized by persistent BRADYCARDIA
column2: chronic ATRIAL FIBRILLATION
column3: and failure to resume sinus rhythm following CARDIOVERSION. This syndrome can be congenital or acquired
column4: particularly after surgical correction for heart defects.

column2: Cardiac*The omission of atrial activation that is caused by transient cessation of impulse generation at the SINOATRIAL NODE. It is characterized by a prolonged pause without P wave in an ELECTROCARDIOGRAM. Sinus arrest has been associated with sleep apnea (REM SLEEP-RELATED SINUS ARREST).

column1: C23.550.073.198*D001281*Atrial Fibrillation*Abnormal cardiac rhythm that is characterized by rapid
column2: uncoordinated firing of electrical impulses in the upper chambers of the heart (HEART ATRIA). In such case
column3: blood cannot be effectively pumped into the lower chambers of the heart (HEART VENTRICLES). It is caused by abnormal impulse generation.

column1: C23.550.073.248*D001282*Atrial Flutter*Rapid
column2: irregular atrial contractions caused by a block of electrical impulse conduction in the right atrium and a reentrant wave front traveling up the inter-atrial septum and down the right atrial free wall or vice versa. Unlike ATRIAL FIBRILLATION which is caused by abnormal impulse generation
column3: typical atrial flutter is caused by abnormal impulse conduction. As in atrial fibrillation
column4: patients with atrial flutter cannot effectively pump blood into the lower chambers of the heart (HEART VENTRICLES).

column1: C23.550.073.300*D001919*Bradycardia*Cardiac arrhythmias that are characterized by excessively slow HEART RATE
column2: usually below 50 beats per minute in human adults. They can be classified broadly into SINOATRIAL NODE dysfunction and ATRIOVENTRICULAR BLOCK.

column1: C23.550.073.325*D005117*Cardiac Complexes
column2: Premature*A group of cardiac arrhythmias in which the cardiac contractions are not initiated at the SINOATRIAL NODE. They include both atrial and ventricular premature beats
column3: and are also known as extra or ectopic heartbeats. Their frequency is increased in heart diseases.

column1: C23.550.073.325.050*D018880*Atrial Premature Complexes*A type of cardiac arrhythmia with premature atrial contractions or beats caused by signals originating from ectopic atrial sites. The ectopic signals may or may not conduct to the HEART VENTRICLES. Atrial premature complexes are characterized by premature P waves on ECG which are different in configuration from the P waves generated by the normal pacemaker complex in the SINOATRIAL NODE.

C23.550.073.325.800*D018879*Ventricular Premature Complexes*A type of cardiac arrhythmia with premature contractions of the HEART VENTRICLES. It is characterized by the premature QRS complex on ECG that is of abnormal shape and great duration (generally >129 msec). It is the most common form of all cardiac arrhythmias. Premature ventricular complexes have no clinical significance except in concurrence with heart diseases.
C23.550.073.425*D006327*Heart Block*Impaired conduction of cardiac impulse that can occur anywhere along the conduction pathway
column2: such as between the SINOATRIAL NODE and the right atrium (SA block) or between atria and ventricles (AV block). Heart blocks can be classified by the duration
column4: or completeness of conduction block. Reversibility depends on the degree of structural or functional defects.

column1: C23.550.073.425.025*D000219*Adams-Stokes Syndrome*A condition of fainting spells caused by heart block
column2: often an atrioventricular block
column3: that leads to BRADYCARDIA and drop in CARDIAC OUTPUT. When the cardiac output becomes too low
column4: the patient faints (SYNCOPE). In some cases
column5: the syncope attacks are transient and in others cases repetitive and persistent.

column1: C23.550.073.425.062*D054537*Atrioventricular Block*Impaired impulse conduction from HEART ATRIA to HEART VENTRICLES. AV block can mean delayed or completely blocked impulse conduction.

C23.550.073.425.100*D002037*Bundle-Branch Block*A form of heart block in which the electrical stimulation of HEART VENTRICLES is interrupted at either one of the branches of BUNDLE OF HIS thus preventing the simultaneous depolarization of the two ventricles.

C23.550.073.425.440*D012804*Sick Sinus Syndrome*A condition caused by dysfunctions related to the SINOATRIAL NODE including impulse generation (CARDIAC SINUS ARREST) and impulse conduction (SINOATRIAL EXIT BLOCK). It is characterized by persistent BRADYCARDIA
column2: chronic ATRIAL FIBRILLATION
column3: and failure to resume sinus rhythm following CARDIOVERSION. This syndrome can be congenital or acquired
column4: particularly after surgical correction for heart defects.

column1: C23.550.073.425.780*D012848*Sinoatrial Block*Disturbance in the atrial activation that is caused by transient failure of impulse conduction from the SINOATRIAL NODE to the HEART ATRIA. It is characterized by a delayed in heartbeat and pauses between P waves in an ELECTROCARDIOGRAM.

C23.550.073.547*D008133*Long QT Syndrome*A condition that is characterized by episodes of fainting (SYNCOPE) and varying degree of ventricular arrhythmia as indicated by the prolonged QT interval. The inherited forms are caused by mutation of genes encoding cardiac ion channel proteins. The two major forms are ROMANO-WARD SYNDROME and JERVELL-LANGE NIELSEN SYNDROME.
C23.550.073.547.070*D050030*Andersen Syndrome*A form of inherited long QT syndrome (or LQT7) that is characterized by a triad of potassium-sensitive periodic paralysis
column2: VENTRICULAR ECTOPIC BEATS
column3: and abnormal features such as short stature
column5: and SCOLIOSIS. It results from mutations of KCNJ2 gene which encodes a channel protein (INWARD RECTIFIER POTASSIUM CHANNELS) that regulates resting membrane potential.

column1: C23.550.073.547.720*D029597*Romano-Ward Syndrome*A form of long QT syndrome that is without congenital deafness. It is caused by mutation of the KCNQ1 gene which encodes a protein in the VOLTAGE-GATED POTASSIUM CHANNEL.

C23.550.073.670*D017574*Parasystole*A cardiac arrhythmia that is caused by interaction of two independently initiated cardiac impulses of different rates from two separate foci. Generally one focus is the SINOATRIAL NODE
column2: the normal pacemaker. The ectopic focus is usually in the HEART VENTRICLE but can be in the HEART ATRIUM or the ATRIOVENTRICULAR NODE. Modulation of the parasystolic rhythm by the sinus rhythm depends on the completeness of entrance block surrounding the parasystolic focus.

column1: C23.550.073.845*D013610*Tachycardia*Abnormally rapid heartbeat
column2: usually with a HEART RATE above 100 beats per minute for adults. Tachycardia accompanied by disturbance in the cardiac depolarization (cardiac arrhythmia) is called tachyarrhythmia.
Paroxysmal*Abnormally rapid heartbeats with sudden onset and cessation.

Reciprocating*Abnormally rapid heartbeats caused by reentrant conduction over the accessory pathways between the HEART ATRIA and the HEART VENTRICLES. The impulse can also travel in the reverse direction
column4: atrial impulses travel to the ventricles over the accessory pathways and back to the atria over the BUNDLE OF HIS and the ATRIOVENTRICULAR NODE.

column2: Atrioventricular Nodal Reentry*Abnormally rapid heartbeats caused by reentry of atrial impulse into the dual (fast and slow) pathways of ATRIOVENTRICULAR NODE. The common type involves a blocked atrial impulse in the slow pathway which reenters the fast pathway in a retrograde direction and simultaneously conducts to the atria and the ventricles leading to rapid HEART RATE of 150-250 beats per minute.

Sinoatrial Nodal Reentry*Abnormally rapid heartbeats caused by reentry circuit in or around the SINOATRIAL NODE. It is characterized by sudden onset and offset episodes of tachycardia with a HEART RATE of 100-150 beats per minute. The P wave is identical to the sinus P wave but with a longer PR interval.
Supraventricular*A generic expression for any tachycardia that originates above the BUNDLE OF HIS.
Ectopic Atrial*Abnormally rapid heartbeats originating from one or more automatic foci (nonsinus pacemakers) in the HEART ATRIUM but away from the SINOATRIAL NODE. Unlike the reentry mechanism
column3: automatic tachycardia speeds up and slows down gradually. The episode is characterized by a HEART RATE between 135 to less than 200 beats per minute and lasting 30 seconds or longer.

column2: Ectopic Junctional*A rare form of supraventricular tachycardia caused by automatic
column4: conduction initiated from sites at the atrioventricular junction
column5: but not the ATRIOVENTRICULAR NODE. It usually occurs during myocardial infarction
column7: or in digitalis intoxication with a HEART RATE ranging from 140 to 250 beats per minute.

column2: Sinus*Simple rapid heartbeats caused by rapid discharge of impulses from the SINOATRIAL NODE
column3: usually between 100 and 180 beats/min in adults. It is characterized by a gradual onset and termination. Sinus tachycardia is common in infants
column5: and adults during strenuous physical activities.

column2: Ventricular*An abnormally rapid ventricular rhythm usually in excess of 150 beats per minute. It is generated within the ventricle below the BUNDLE OF HIS
column3: either as autonomic impulse formation or reentrant impulse conduction. Depending on the etiology
column4: onset of ventricular tachycardia can be paroxysmal (sudden) or nonparoxysmal
column5: its wide QRS complexes can be uniform or polymorphic
column6: and the ventricular beating may be independent of the atrial beating (AV dissociation).

column1: C23.550.073.845.940.349*D016170*Accelerated Idioventricular Rhythm*A type of automatic
column2: not reentrant
column3: ectopic ventricular rhythm with episodes lasting from a few seconds to a minute which usually occurs in patients with acute myocardial infarction or with DIGITALIS toxicity. The ventricular rate is faster than normal but slower than tachycardia
column4: with an upper limit of 100 -120 beats per minute. Suppressive therapy is rarely necessary.

column1: C23.550.073.845.940.700*D016171*Torsades de Pointes*A malignant form of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia that is characterized by HEART RATE between 200 and 250 beats per minute
column2: and QRS complexes with changing amplitude and twisting of the points. The term also describes the syndrome of tachycardia with prolonged ventricular repolarization
column3: long QT intervals exceeding 500 milliseconds or BRADYCARDIA. Torsades de pointes may be self-limited or may progress to VENTRICULAR FIBRILLATION.

column1: C23.550.073.922*D014693*Ventricular Fibrillation*A potentially lethal cardiac arrhythmia that is characterized by uncoordinated extremely rapid firing of electrical impulses (400-600/min) in HEART VENTRICLES. Such asynchronous ventricular quivering or fibrillation prevents any effective cardiac output and results in unconsciousness (SYNCOPE). It is one of the major electrocardiographic patterns seen with CARDIAC ARREST.
C23.550.073.961*D054141*Ventricular Flutter*A potentially lethal cardiac arrhythmia characterized by an extremely rapid
column2: hemodynamically unstable ventricular tachycardia (150-300 beats/min) with a large oscillating sine-wave appearance. If untreated
column3: ventricular flutter typically progresses to VENTRICULAR FIBRILLATION.

column1: C23.550.081*D001201*Ascites*Accumulation or retention of free fluid within the peritoneal cavity.
C23.550.113*D064752*Atrial Remodeling*Long-term changes in the electrophysiological parameters and/or anatomical structures of the HEART ATRIA that result from prolonged changes in atrial rate
column2: often associated with ATRIAL FIBRILLATION or long periods of intense EXERCISE.

column1: C23.550.145*D053099*Azotemia*A biochemical abnormality referring to an elevation of BLOOD UREA NITROGEN and CREATININE. Azotemia can be produced by KIDNEY DISEASES or other extrarenal disorders. When azotemia becomes associated with a constellation of clinical signs
column2: it is termed UREMIA.

column1: C23.550.161*D066126*Cardiotoxicity*Damage to the heart or its function secondary to exposure to toxic substances such as drugs used in CHEMOTHERAPY; IMMUNOTHERAPY; or RADIATION.
C23.550.177*D053447*Channelopathies*A variety of neuromuscular conditions resulting from MUTATIONS in ION CHANNELS manifesting as episodes of EPILEPSY; HEADACHE DISORDERS; and DYSKINESIAS.
C23.550.210*D002869*Chromosome Aberrations*Abnormal number or structure of chromosomes. Chromosome aberrations may result in CHROMOSOME DISORDERS.
C23.550.210.024*D059786*Abnormal Karyotype*A variation from the normal set of chromosomes characteristic of a species.
C23.550.210.024.500*D014997*XYY Karyotype*Abnormal genetic constitution in males characterized by an extra Y chromosome.
C23.550.210.050*D000782*Aneuploidy*The chromosomal constitution of cells which deviate from the normal by the addition or subtraction of CHROMOSOMES
column2: chromosome pairs
column3: or chromosome fragments. In a normally diploid cell (DIPLOIDY) the loss of a chromosome pair is termed nullisomy (symbol: 2N-2)
column4: the loss of a single chromosome is MONOSOMY (symbol: 2N-1)
column5: the addition of a chromosome pair is tetrasomy (symbol: 2N+2)
column6: the addition of a single chromosome is TRISOMY (symbol: 2N+1).

column1: C23.550.210.050.500*D009006*Monosomy*The condition in which one chromosome of a pair is missing. In a normally diploid cell it is represented symbolically as 2N-1.
C23.550.210.050.500.500*D002872*Chromosome Deletion*Actual loss of portion of a chromosome.
C23.550.210.050.625*D058670*Tetrasomy*The possession of four chromosomes of any one type in an otherwise diploid cell.
C23.550.210.050.750*D014314*Trisomy*The possession of a third chromosome of any one type in an otherwise diploid cell.
C23.550.210.110*D043171*Chromosomal Instability*An increased tendency to acquire CHROMOSOME ABERRATIONS when various processes involved in chromosome replication
column2: repair

column1: C23.550.210.110.180*D002873*Chromosome Fragility*Susceptibility of chromosomes to breakage leading to translocation; CHROMOSOME INVERSION; SEQUENCE DELETION; or other CHROMOSOME BREAKAGE related aberrations.

C23.550.210.170*D019457*Chromosome Breakage*A type of chromosomal aberration involving DNA BREAKS. Chromosome breakage can result in CHROMOSOMAL TRANSLOCATION; CHROMOSOME INVERSION; or SEQUENCE DELETION.
C23.550.210.182*D058674*Chromosome Duplication*An aberration in which an extra chromosome or a chromosomal segment is made.
C23.550.210.182.249*D058670*Tetrasomy*The possession of four chromosomes of any one type in an otherwise diploid cell.
C23.550.210.182.500*D014314*Trisomy*The possession of a third chromosome of any one type in an otherwise diploid cell.
C23.550.210.190*D007446*Chromosome Inversion*An aberration in which a chromosomal segment is deleted and reinserted in the same place but turned 180 degrees from its original orientation
column2: so that the gene sequence for the segment is reversed with respect to that of the rest of the chromosome.

column1: C23.550.210.310*D000072837*Chromothripsis*Massive number of chromosomal rearrangements and shattering that occurs in cancer cells. The breakpoints are located within one chromosome or chromosome arm.

C23.550.210.430*D018404*Isochromosomes*Metacentric chromosomes produced during MEIOSIS or MITOSIS when the CENTROMERE splits transversely instead of longitudinally. The chromosomes produced by this abnormal division are one chromosome having the two long arms of the original chromosome
column2: but no short arms
column3: and the other chromosome consisting of the two short arms and no long arms. Each of these isochromosomes constitutes a simultaneous duplication and deletion.

column2: Chromosome-Defective*Defective nuclei produced during the TELOPHASE of MITOSIS or MEIOSIS by lagging CHROMOSOMES or chromosome fragments derived from spontaneous or experimentally induced chromosomal structural changes.

column1: C23.550.210.645*D009630*Nondisjunction
column2: Genetic*The failure of homologous CHROMOSOMES or CHROMATIDS to segregate during MITOSIS or MEIOSIS with the result that one daughter cell has both of a pair of parental chromosomes or chromatids and the other has none.

column1: C23.550.210.645.890*D024182*Uniparental Disomy*The presence in a cell of two paired chromosomes from the same parent
column2: with no chromosome of that pair from the other parent. This chromosome composition stems from non-disjunction (NONDISJUNCTION
column3: GENETIC) events during MEIOSIS. The disomy may be composed of both homologous chromosomes from one parent (heterodisomy) or a duplicate of one chromosome (isodisomy).

column1: C23.550.210.702*D011123*Polyploidy*The chromosomal constitution of a cell containing multiples of the normal number of CHROMOSOMES; includes triploidy (symbol: 3N)
column2: tetraploidy (symbol: 4N)

column1: C23.550.210.702.249*D057891*Tetraploidy*The presence of four sets of chromosomes. It is associated with ABNORMALITIES
column2: MULTIPLE; and MISCARRAGES.

column1: C23.550.210.702.500*D057885*Triploidy*Polyploidy with three sets of chromosomes. Triploidy in humans are 69XXX
column2: 69XXY
column3: and 69XYY. It is associated with HOLOPROSENCEPHALY; ABNORMALITIES
column4: MULTIPLE; PARTIAL HYDATIDIFORM MOLE; and MISCARRAGES.

column1: C23.550.210.760*D012303*Ring Chromosomes*Aberrant chromosomes with no ends
column2: i.e.

column1: C23.550.210.815*D012729*Sex Chromosome Aberrations*Abnormal number or structure of the SEX CHROMOSOMES. Some sex chromosome aberrations are associated with SEX CHROMOSOME DISORDERS and SEX CHROMOSOME DISORDERS OF SEX DEVELOPMENT.
C23.550.210.815.970*D014997*XYY Karyotype*Abnormal genetic constitution in males characterized by an extra Y chromosome.
C23.550.210.870*D014178*Translocation
column2: Genetic*A type of chromosome aberration characterized by CHROMOSOME BREAKAGE and transfer of the broken-off portion to another location

column1: C23.550.210.870.680*D010677*Philadelphia Chromosome*An aberrant form of human CHROMOSOME 22 characterized by translocation of the distal end of chromosome 9 from 9q34
column2: to the long arm of chromosome 22 at 22q11. It is present in the bone marrow cells of 80 to 90 per cent of patients with chronic myelocytic leukemia (LEUKEMIA

column1: C23.550.260*D003643*Death*Irreversible cessation of all bodily functions
column2: manifested by absence of spontaneous breathing and total loss of cardiovascular and cerebral functions.

column1: C23.550.260.095*D001237*Asphyxia*A pathological condition caused by lack of oxygen
column2: manifested in impending or actual cessation of life.

column1: C23.550.260.127*D000071298*Body Remains*The physical entity of a deceased human or animal.
C23.550.260.159*D001926*Brain Death*A state of prolonged irreversible cessation of all brain activity
column2: including lower brain stem function with the complete absence of voluntary movements
column5: and spontaneous respirations. Reversible conditions which mimic this clinical state (e.g.
column8: etc.) are excluded prior to making the determination of brain death. (From Adams et al.

column1: C23.550.260.224*D002102*Cadaver*A dead body
column2: usually a human body.

column1: C23.550.260.224.200*D056146*Corpse Dismemberment*Disjoining the limbs or other parts of a corpse
column2: often in association with criminal acts.

column1: C23.550.260.224.617*D011180*Postmortem Changes*Physiological changes that occur in bodies after death.
C23.550.260.224.617.236*D001329*Autolysis*The spontaneous disintegration of tissues or cells by the action of their own autogenous enzymes.
C23.550.260.224.617.839*D012298*Rigor Mortis*Muscular rigidity which develops in the cadaver usually from 4 to 10 hours after death and lasts 3 or 4 days.

column2: Sudden*The abrupt cessation of all vital bodily functions
column3: manifested by the permanent loss of total cerebral

column2: Sudden
column3: Cardiac*Unexpected rapid natural death due to cardiovascular collapse within one hour of initial symptoms. It is usually caused by the worsening of existing heart diseases. The sudden onset of symptoms
column4: such as CHEST PAIN and CARDIAC ARRHYTHMIAS
column6: can lead to the loss of consciousness and cardiac arrest followed by biological death. (from Braunwald's Heart Disease: A Textbook of Cardiovascular Medicine

column1: C23.550.260.322.250.500*D065907*Karoshi Death*Sudden death from overwork
column2: most often as a result of acute CARDIOVASCULAR STROKE.

column1: C23.550.260.322.625*D013398*Sudden Infant Death*The abrupt and unexplained death of an apparently healthy infant under one year of age
column2: remaining unexplained after a thorough case investigation
column3: including performance of a complete autopsy
column5: and review of the clinical history. (Pediatr Pathol 1991 Sep-Oct;11(5):677-84)

column1: C23.550.260.393*D004332*Drowning*Death that occurs as a result of anoxia or heart arrest
column2: associated with immersion in liquid.

column1: C23.550.260.440*D020964*Embryo Loss*Early pregnancy loss during the EMBRYO
column2: MAMMALIAN stage of development. In the human
column3: this period comprises the second through eighth week after fertilization.

column1: C23.550.260.585*D005313*Fetal Death*Death of the developing young in utero. BIRTH of a dead FETUS is STILLBIRTH.
C23.550.260.585.260*D005327*Fetal Resorption*The disintegration and assimilation of the dead FETUS in the UTERUS at any stage after the completion of organogenesis which
column2: in humans
column3: is after the 9th week of GESTATION. It does not include embryo resorption (see EMBRYO LOSS).

column1: C23.550.260.585.630*D050497*Stillbirth*The event that a FETUS is born dead or stillborn.
C23.550.260.657*D066088*Infant Death*The death of a live-born INFANT within its first year of life.
C23.550.260.657.500*D013398*Sudden Infant Death*The abrupt and unexplained death of an apparently healthy infant under one year of age
column2: remaining unexplained after a thorough case investigation
column3: including performance of a complete autopsy
column5: and review of the clinical history. (Pediatr Pathol 1991 Sep-Oct;11(5):677-84)

column1: C23.550.260.730*D063129*Parental Death*The death of the father or mother or another person in this role.
C23.550.260.730.500*D063130*Maternal Death*The death of the female parent.
C23.550.260.865*D066087*Perinatal Death*The death of a FETUS of GESTATIONAL AGE 28 weeks or more
column2: or the death of a live-born INFANT less than 28 days of age.

column1: C23.550.274*D003681*Dehydration*The condition that results from excessive loss of water from a living organism.

C23.550.277*D051799*Delayed Graft Function*General dysfunction of an organ occurring immediately following its transplantation. The term most frequently refers to renal dysfunction following KIDNEY TRANSPLANTATION.
C23.550.288*D004194*Disease*A definite pathologic process with a characteristic set of signs and symptoms. It may affect the whole body or any of its parts
column2: and its etiology
column4: and prognosis may be known or unknown.

column1: C23.550.288.500*D013577*Syndrome*A characteristic symptom complex.
C23.550.291*D020969*Disease Attributes*Clinical characteristics of disease or illness.
C23.550.291.125*D000208*Acute Disease*Disease having a short and relatively severe course.
C23.550.291.187*D058070*Asymptomatic Diseases*Diseases that do not exhibit symptoms.
C23.550.291.187.500*D058345*Asymptomatic Infections*Infections that do not exhibit symptoms.

C23.550.291.250*D002388*Catastrophic Illness*An acute or prolonged illness usually considered to be life-threatening or with the threat of serious residual disability. Treatment may be radical and is frequently costly.
C23.550.291.500*D002908*Chronic Disease*Diseases which have one or more of the following characteristics: they are permanent
column2: leave residual disability
column3: are caused by nonreversible pathological alteration
column4: require special training of the patient for rehabilitation
column5: or may be expected to require a long period of supervision
column7: or care. (Dictionary of Health Services Management

column1: C23.550.291.500.500*D000071069*Multiple Chronic Conditions*Two or more concurrent chronic physical
column2: mental
column3: or behavioral health problems in an individual.

column1: C23.550.291.562*D003289*Convalescence*The period of recovery following an illness.
C23.550.291.625*D016638*Critical Illness*A disease or state in which death is possible or imminent.

C23.550.291.656*D018450*Disease Progression*The worsening of a disease over time. This concept is most often used for chronic and incurable diseases where the stage of the disease is an important determinant of therapy and prognosis.

column2: Spontaneous*A spontaneous diminution or abatement of a disease over time

column1: C23.550.291.671*D060467*Disease Resistance*The capacity of an organism to defend itself against pathological processes or the agents of those processes. This most often involves innate immunity whereby the organism responds to pathogens in a generic way. The term disease resistance is used most frequently when referring to plants.

C23.550.291.687*D004198*Disease Susceptibility*A constitution or condition of the body which makes the tissues react in special ways to certain extrinsic stimuli and thus tends to make the individual more than usually susceptible to certain diseases.
C23.550.291.687.500*D020022*Genetic Predisposition to Disease*A latent susceptibility to disease at the genetic level
column2: which may be activated under certain conditions.
Genetic*The apparent tendency of certain diseases to appear at earlier AGE OF ONSET and with increasing severity in successive generations. (Rieger et al.
column3: Glossary of Genetics: Classical and Molecular

column1: C23.550.291.750*D004200*Diseases in Twins*Disorders affecting TWINS
column2: one or both

column1: C23.550.291.781*D004630*Emergencies*Situations or conditions requiring immediate intervention to avoid serious adverse results.
C23.550.291.812*D019066*Facies*The appearance of the face that is often characteristic of a disease or pathological condition
column2: as the elfin facies of WILLIAMS SYNDROME or the mongoloid facies of DOWN SYNDROME. (Random House Unabridged Dictionary

column1: C23.550.291.875*D007049*Iatrogenic Disease*Any adverse condition in a patient occurring as the result of treatment by a physician
column2: surgeon
column4: especially infections acquired by a patient during the course of treatment.

column1: C23.550.291.875.500*D003428*Cross Infection*Any infection which a patient contracts in a health-care institution.
C23.550.291.883*D000067562*Late Onset Disorders*Pathological conditions (Disorder
column2: SYNDROME
column3: or DISEASE) whose SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS manifest late in the life of an individual.

column1: C23.550.291.890*D058069*Neglected Diseases*Diseases that are underfunded and have low name recognition but are major burdens in less developed countries. The World Health Organization has designated six tropical infectious diseases as being neglected in industrialized countries that are endemic in many developing countries (HELMINTHIASIS; LEPROSY; LYMPHATIC FILARIASIS; ONCHOCERCIASIS; SCHISTOSOMIASIS; and TRACHOMA).
C23.550.291.906*D035583*Rare Diseases*A large group of diseases which are characterized by a low prevalence in the population. They frequently are associated with problems in diagnosis and treatment.
C23.550.291.937*D012008*Recurrence*The return of a sign
column2: symptom

column1: C23.550.291.937.500*D000067251*Symptom Flare Up*A transient exacerbation of symptoms of an existing disease or condition.

C23.550.308*D064806*Dysbiosis*Changes in quantitative and qualitative composition of MICROBIOTA. The changes may lead to altered host microbial interaction or homeostatic imbalance that can contribute to a disease state often with inflammation.
C23.550.325*D004646*Emphysema*A pathological accumulation of air in tissues or organs.
C23.550.325.250*D008478*Mediastinal Emphysema*Presence of air in the mediastinal tissues due to leakage of air from the tracheobronchial tree
column2: usually as a result of trauma.

column1: C23.550.325.500*D013352*Subcutaneous Emphysema*Presence of air or gas in the subcutaneous tissues of the body.
C23.550.325.500.500*D019896*alpha 1-Antitrypsin Deficiency*Deficiency of the protease inhibitor ALPHA 1-ANTITRYPSIN that manifests primarily as PULMONARY EMPHYSEMA and LIVER CIRRHOSIS.

C23.550.340*D005119*Extravasation of Diagnostic and Therapeutic Materials*The escape of diagnostic or therapeutic material from the vessel into which it is introduced into the surrounding tissue or body cavity.

C23.550.347*D057925*Femoracetabular Impingement*A pathological mechanical process that can lead to hip failure. It is caused by abnormalities of the ACETABULUM and/or FEMUR combined with rigorous hip motion
column2: leading to repetitive collisions that damage the soft tissue structures.

column1: C23.550.355*D005355*Fibrosis*Any pathological condition where fibrous connective tissue invades any organ
column2: usually as a consequence of inflammation or other injury.

column1: C23.550.355.274*D002921*Cicatrix*The fibrous tissue that replaces normal tissue during the process of WOUND HEALING.

column2: Hypertrophic*An elevated scar
column4: but which does not spread into surrounding tissues. It is formed by enlargement and overgrowth of cicatricial tissue and regresses spontaneously.

column1: C23.550.355.274.510*D007627*Keloid*A sharply elevated
column2: irregularly shaped
column3: progressively enlarging scar resulting from formation of excessive amounts of collagen in the dermis during connective tissue repair. It is differentiated from a hypertrophic scar (CICATRIX
column4: HYPERTROPHIC) in that the former does not spread to surrounding tissues.

column1: C23.550.355.274.840*D000267*Tissue Adhesions*Pathological processes consisting of the union of the opposing surfaces of a wound.
C23.550.355.550*D054989*Nephrogenic Fibrosing Dermopathy*A chronic
column2: acquired
column4: progressive eruption of the skin that occurs in the context of RENAL FAILURE. It is sometimes accompanied by systemic fibrosis. The pathogenesis seems to be multifactorial
column5: with postulated involvement of circulating fibrocytes. There is a strong association between this disorder and the use of gadolinium-based contrast agents.

column1: C23.550.355.625*D056627*Peritoneal Fibrosis*Disorder characterized by a wide range of structural changes in PERITONEUM
column2: resulting from fibrogenic or inflammatory processes. Peritoneal fibrosis is a common complication in patients receiving PERITONEAL DIALYSIS and contributes to its gradual decrease in efficiency.

column1: C23.550.355.700*D012185*Retroperitoneal Fibrosis*A slowly progressive condition of unknown etiology
column2: characterized by deposition of fibrous tissue in the retroperitoneal space compressing the ureters
column5: and other structures. When associated with abdominal aortic aneurysm
column6: it may be called chronic periaortitis or inflammatory perianeurysmal fibrosis.

column1: C23.550.362*D042822*Genomic Instability*An increased tendency of the GENOME to acquire MUTATIONS when various processes involved in maintaining and replicating the genome are dysfunctional.
C23.550.362.180*D043171*Chromosomal Instability*An increased tendency to acquire CHROMOSOME ABERRATIONS when various processes involved in chromosome replication
column2: repair

column1: C23.550.362.180.180*D002873*Chromosome Fragility*Susceptibility of chromosomes to breakage leading to translocation; CHROMOSOME INVERSION; SEQUENCE DELETION; or other CHROMOSOME BREAKAGE related aberrations.

C23.550.362.590*D053842*Microsatellite Instability*The occurrence of highly polymorphic mono- and dinucleotide MICROSATELLITE REPEATS in somatic cells. It is a form of genome instability associated with defects in DNA MISMATCH REPAIR.
C23.550.369*D005911*Gliosis*The production of a dense fibrous network of neuroglia; includes astrocytosis
column2: which is a proliferation of astrocytes in the area of a degenerative lesion.

column1: C23.550.382*D006099*Granuloma*A relatively small nodular inflammatory lesion containing grouped mononuclear phagocytes
column2: caused by infectious and noninfectious agents.

column1: C23.550.382.250*D004803*Eosinophilic Granuloma*The most benign and common form of Langerhans-cell histiocytosis which involves localized nodular lesions predominantly of the bones but also of the gastric mucosa
column2: small intestine

column1: C23.550.382.375*D016460*Granuloma Annulare*Benign granulomatous disease of unknown etiology characterized by a ring of localized or disseminated papules or nodules on the skin and palisading histiocytes surrounding necrobiotic tissue resulting from altered collagen structures.

column2: Foreign-Body*Histiocytic
column3: inflammatory response to a foreign body. It consists of modified macrophages with multinucleated giant cells
column4: in this case foreign-body giant cells (GIANT CELLS

column2: Giant Cell*A non-neoplastic inflammatory lesion
column3: usually of the jaw or gingiva
column5: multinucleated cells. It includes reparative giant cell granuloma. Peripheral giant cell granuloma refers to the gingiva (giant cell epulis); central refers to the jaw.

column2: Plasma Cell*A slow-growing benign pseudotumor in which plasma cells greatly outnumber the inflammatory cells.
Pyogenic*A disorder of the skin
column5: that usually presents as a solitary polypoid capillary hemangioma often resulting from trauma. It is manifested as an inflammatory response with similar characteristics to those of a granuloma.

column2: Respiratory Tract*Granulomatous disorders affecting one or more sites in the respiratory tract.
Laryngeal*A tumor-like nodule or mass of inflammatory granulation tissue projecting into the lumen of the LARYNX.

column1: C23.550.382.984*D058252*Necrobiotic Xanthogranuloma*A cutaneous necrobiotic disorder characterized by firm
column2: yellow plaques or nodules
column3: often in a periorbital distribution. It is often accompanied by an elevated ERYTHROCYTE SEDIMENTATION RATE; LEUKOPENIA; and MONOCLONAL GAMMOPATHY (IgG-kappa type) and systemic involvement.

column1: C23.550.384*D051261*Granulomatosis
column2: Orofacial*A condition characterized by persistent or recurrent labial enlargement
column4: and other orofacial manifestations in the absence of identifiable CROHN DISEASE; or SARCOIDOSIS. Among experts there is disagreement on whether orofacial granulomatosis is a distinct clinical disorder or an initial presentation of Crohn disease.

column1: C23.550.393*D006130*Growth Disorders*Deviations from the average values for a specific age and sex in any or all of the following: height
column2: weight
column5: or maturation of features. Included here are both acceleration and retardation of growth.

column1: C23.550.393.450*D005317*Fetal Growth Retardation*The failure of a FETUS to attain its expected FETAL GROWTH at any GESTATIONAL AGE.
C23.550.403*D006461*Hemolysis*The destruction of ERYTHROCYTES by many different causal agents such as antibodies
column2: bacteria

column1: C23.550.414*D006470*Hemorrhage*Bleeding or escape of blood from a vessel.

column2: Surgical*Loss of blood during a surgical procedure.

column1: C23.550.414.625*D004438*Ecchymosis*Extravasation of blood into the skin
column2: resulting in a nonelevated

column1: C23.550.414.712*D004844*Epistaxis*Bleeding from the nose.
C23.550.414.734*D058734*Exsanguination*Rapid and extreme blood loss leading to HEMORRHAGIC SHOCK.
C23.550.414.756*D005130*Eye Hemorrhage*Intraocular hemorrhage from the vessels of various tissues of the eye.
C23.550.414.756.300*D002832*Choroid Hemorrhage*Hemorrhage from the vessels of the choroid.
C23.550.414.756.550*D006988*Hyphema*Bleeding in the anterior chamber of the eye.
C23.550.414.756.775*D012166*Retinal Hemorrhage*Bleeding from the vessels of the retina.
C23.550.414.756.887*D014823*Vitreous Hemorrhage*Hemorrhage into the VITREOUS BODY.

tarry

column5: or shock. Purpura fulminans often accompanies or is triggered by DISSEMINATED INTRAVASCULAR COAGULATION.

column2: Thrombocytopenic*Any form of purpura in which the PLATELET COUNT is decreased. Many forms are thought to be caused by immunological mechanisms.
Thrombocytopenic
column3: Idiopathic*Thrombocytopenia occurring in the absence of toxic exposure or a disease associated with decreased platelets. It is mediated by immune mechanisms
column4: in most cases IMMUNOGLOBULIN G autoantibodies which attach to platelets and subsequently undergo destruction by macrophages. The disease is seen in acute (affecting children) and chronic (adult) forms.

column2: Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic*An acquired

Clinical features include THROMBOCYTOPENIA; HEMOLYTIC ANEMIA; AZOTEMIA; FEVER; and thrombotic microangiopathy. The classical form also includes neurological symptoms and end-organ damage

column1: C23.550.414.950.843*D014884*Waterhouse-Friderichsen Syndrome*A condition of HEMORRHAGE and NECROSIS of the ADRENAL GLAND. It is characterized by rapidly developing ADRENAL INSUFFICIENCY; HYPOTENSION; and widespread cutaneous PURPURA.

column1: C23.550.414.993.850*D006473*Postpartum Hemorrhage*Excess blood loss from uterine bleeding associated with OBSTETRIC LABOR or CHILDBIRTH. It is defined as blood loss greater than 500 ml or of the amount that adversely affects the maternal physiology

column3: immediate (within first 24 hours after birth) or delayed (after 24 hours postpartum).

column1: C23.550.421*D022124*Hyperammonemia*Elevated level of AMMONIA in the blood. It is a sign of defective CATABOLISM of AMINO ACIDS or ammonia to UREA.

C23.550.425*D034321*Hyperamylasemia*A condition with abnormally elevated level of AMYLASES in the serum. Hyperamylasemia due to PANCREATITIS or other causes may be differentiated by identifying the amylase isoenzymes.
C23.550.429*D006932*Hyperbilirubinemia*A condition characterized by an abnormal increase of BILIRUBIN in the blood
column2: which may result in JAUNDICE. Bilirubin
column4: is normally excreted in the BILE or further catabolized before excretion in the urine.

column1: C23.550.429.249*D051556*Hyperbilirubinemia
column2: Neonatal*Accumulation of BILIRUBIN
column3: a breakdown product of HEME PROTEINS
column4: in the BLOOD during the first weeks of life. This may lead to NEONATAL JAUNDICE. The excess bilirubin may exist in the unconjugated (indirect) or the conjugated (direct) form. The condition may be self-limiting (PHYSIOLOGICAL NEONATAL JAUNDICE) or pathological with toxic levels of bilirubin.

column2: Neonatal*Yellow discoloration of the SKIN; MUCOUS MEMBRANE; and SCLERA in the NEWBORN. It is a sign of NEONATAL HYPERBILIRUBINEMIA. Most cases are transient self-limiting (PHYSIOLOGICAL NEONATAL JAUNDICE) occurring in the first week of life
column3: but some can be a sign of pathological disorders

Obstructive*Jaundice

column1: C23.550.429.750*D007647*Kernicterus*A term used pathologically to describe BILIRUBIN staining of the BASAL GANGLIA; BRAIN STEM; and CEREBELLUM and clinically to describe a syndrome associated with HYPERBILIRUBINEMIA. Clinical features include athetosis

column6: SEPSIS). This condition occurs primarily in neonates (INFANT

column1: C23.550.444*D006965*Hyperplasia*An increase in the number of cells in a tissue or organ without tumor formation. It differs from HYPERTROPHY
column2: which is an increase in bulk without an increase in the number of cells.

column1: C23.550.449*D033461*Hyperuricemia*Excessive URIC ACID or urate in blood as defined by its solubility in plasma at 37 degrees C; greater than 0.42mmol per liter (7.0mg/dL) in men or 0.36mmol per liter (6.0mg/dL) in women. This condition is caused by overproduction of uric acid or impaired renal clearance. Hyperuricemia can be acquired
column2: drug-induced or genetically determined (LESCH-NYHAN SYNDROME). It is associated with HYPERTENSION and GOUT.

column1: C23.550.455*D020896*Hypovolemia*An abnormally low volume of blood circulating through the body. It may result in hypovolemic shock (see SHOCK).

C23.550.470*D007249*Inflammation*A pathological process characterized by injury or destruction of tissues caused by a variety of cytologic and chemical reactions. It is usually manifested by typical signs of pain

column1: C23.550.470.099*D000210*Acute-Phase Reaction*An early local inflammatory reaction to insult or injury that consists of fever

column3: and an increased synthesis by hepatocytes of a number of proteins or glycoproteins usually found in the plasma.

column1: C23.550.470.251*D005549*Foreign-Body Reaction*Chronic inflammation and granuloma formation around irritating foreign bodies.

C23.550.470.448*D020078*Neurogenic Inflammation*Inflammation caused by an injurious stimulus of peripheral neurons and resulting in release of neuropeptides which affect vascular permeability and help initiate proinflammatory and immune reactions at the site of injury.
C23.550.470.640*D049291*Seroma*Tumor-like sterile accumulation of serum in a tissue
column2: organ
column3: or cavity. It results from a tissue insult and is the product of tissue inflammation. It most commonly occurs following MASTECTOMY.

column1: C23.550.470.646*D012700*Serositis*Inflammation of a serous membrane.

column1: C23.550.470.756.200*D002481*Cellulitis*An acute

column3: and suppurative inflammation of loose connective tissue

column2: Subdural*An intracranial or rarely intraspinal suppurative process invading the space between the inner surface of the DURA MATER and the outer surface of the ARACHNOID.

column1: C23.550.470.790*D018746*Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome*A systemic inflammatory response to a variety of clinical insults

column3: 000 cells/cubic mm or 10% immature forms. While usually related to infection
column4: SIRS can also be associated with noninfectious insults such as TRAUMA; BURNS; or PANCREATITIS. If infection is involved
column5: a patient with SIRS is said to have SEPSIS.

column1: C23.550.470.790.500*D018805*Sepsis*Systemic inflammatory response syndrome with a proven or suspected infectious etiology. When sepsis is associated with organ dysfunction distant from the site of infection
column2: it is called severe sepsis. When sepsis is accompanied by HYPOTENSION despite adequate fluid infusion

column1: C23.550.470.790.500.100*D016470*Bacteremia*The presence of viable bacteria circulating in the blood. Fever
column2: chills
column4: and tachypnea are common acute manifestations of bacteremia. The majority of cases are seen in already hospitalized patients

column1: C23.550.470.790.500.100.275*D019446*Endotoxemia*A condition characterized by the presence of ENDOTOXINS in the blood. On lysis

Opportunistic fungal sepsis is seen most often in immunosuppressed patients with severe neutropenia or in postoperative patients with intravenous catheters and usually follows prolonged antibiotic therapy.
C23.550.470.790.500.360.150*D058387*Candidemia*A form of invasive candidiasis where species of CANDIDA are present in the blood.

C23.550.470.790.500.470*D000071074*Neonatal Sepsis*Blood infection that occurs in an infant younger than 90 days old. Early-onset sepsis is seen in the first week of life and most often appears within 24 hours of birth. Late-onset occurs after 1 week and before 3 months of age.
C23.550.470.790.500.580*D018512*Parasitemia*The presence of parasites (especially malarial parasites) in the blood. (Dorland

column3: but are not limited to LACTIC ACIDOSIS; OLIGURIA; or acute alteration in mental status.

column1: C23.550.470.790.500.900*D014766*Viremia*The presence of viruses in the blood.

column1: C23.550.505*D007431*Intraoperative Complications*Complications that affect patients during surgery. They may or may not be associated with the disease for which the surgery is done

column1: C23.550.526*D007964*Leukocytosis*A transient increase in the number of leukocytes in a body fluid.

column4: or other THERAPEUTICS. Failure to attain a desired outcome from treatment for the condition is not considered an adverse effect.

column2: psychologic
column3: or behavioral changes that occur during the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle. Symptoms of PMS are diverse (such as pain

column1: C23.550.568.968.500*D065446*Premenstrual Dysphoric Disorder*A condition in which a woman suffers from severe depression

column3: and tension before MENSTRUATION. Premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD) may involve a wide range of physical or emotional symptoms
column4: which are more severe and debilitating than those seen with premenstrual syndrome (PMS)
column5: and which include at least one mood-related symptom. Symptoms usually stop when

column1: C23.550.589*D008679*Metaplasia*A condition in which there is a change of one adult cell type to another similar adult cell type.
C23.550.589.500*D009389*Neovascularization

column1: C23.550.717.182*D003790*Dental Pulp Necrosis*Death of pulp tissue with or without bacterial invasion. When the necrosis is due to ischemia with superimposed bacterial infection
column2: it is referred to as pulp gangrene. When the necrosis is non-bacterial in origin

column1: C23.550.717.732.368*D005271*Femur Head Necrosis*Aseptic or avascular necrosis of the femoral head. The major types are idiopathic (primary)

column5: the stomach and ileum are commonly involved. In lymphocytic leukemia the skin is often infiltrated. The central nervous system too is a common site.

column1: C23.550.727.650*D009362*Neoplasm Metastasis*The transfer of a neoplasm from one organ or part of the body to another remote from the primary site.

The pathology is characteristic of neurodegenerative diseases. column1: C23.550.835.900*D018746*Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome*A systemic inflammatory response to a variety of clinical insults

column1: C23.888.144*D001835*Body Weight*The mass or quantity of heaviness of an individual. It is expressed by units of pounds or kilograms.

column1: C23.888.144.300*D020567*Fetal Weight*The weight of the FETUS in utero. It is usually estimated by various formulas based on measurements made during PRENATAL ULTRASONOGRAPHY.
C23.888.144.699*D050177*Overweight*A status with BODY WEIGHT that is above certain standard of acceptable or desirable weight. In the scale of BODY MASS INDEX

column1: C23.888.144.699.500*D009765*Obesity*A status with BODY WEIGHT that is grossly above the acceptable or desirable weight

column5: a BMI greater than 30.0 kg/m2 is considered obese

column4: or more times the ideal weight

column1: C23.888.144.699.500.750*D063766*Pediatric Obesity*BODY MASS INDEX in children (ages 2-12) and in adolescents (ages 13-18) that is grossly above the recommended cut-off for a specific age and sex. For infants less than 2 years of age

column1: C23.888.592.298*D003655*Decerebrate State*A condition characterized by abnormal posturing of the limbs that is associated with injury to the brainstem. This may occur as a clinical manifestation or induced experimentally in animals. The extensor reflexes are exaggerated leading to rigid extension of the limbs accompanied by hyperreflexia and opisthotonus. This condition is usually caused by lesions which occur in the region of the brainstem that lies between the red nuclei and the vestibular nuclei. In contrast
column2: decorticate rigidity is characterized by flexion of the elbows and wrists with extension of the legs and feet. The causative lesion for this condition is located above the red nuclei and usually consists of diffuse cerebral damage. (From Adams et al.

column1: C23.888.592.350*D020820*Dyskinesias*Abnormal involuntary movements which primarily affect the extremities
column2: trunk
column3: or jaw that occur as a manifestation of an underlying disease process. Conditions which feature recurrent or persistent episodes of dyskinesia as a primary manifestation of disease may be referred to as dyskinesia syndromes (see MOVEMENT DISORDERS). Dyskinesias are also a relatively common manifestation of BASAL GANGLIA DISEASES.

column1: C23.888.592.350.090*D001259*Ataxia*Impairment of the ability to perform smoothly coordinated voluntary movements. This condition may affect the limbs

column6: and other structures. Ataxia may result from impaired sensory or motor function. Sensory ataxia may result from posterior column injury or PERIPHERAL NERVE DISEASES. Motor ataxia may be associated with CEREBELLAR DISEASES; CEREBRAL CORTEX diseases; THALAMIC DISEASES; BASAL GANGLIA DISEASES; injury to the RED NUCLEUS; and other conditions.

column1: C23.888.592.350.090.200*D002524*Cerebellar Ataxia*Incoordination of voluntary movements that occur as a manifestation of CEREBELLAR DISEASES. Characteristic features include a tendency for limb movements to overshoot or undershoot a target (dysmetria)

column3: impaired force and rhythm of diadochokinesis (rapidly alternating movements)

column1: C23.888.592.350.090.600*D020234*Gait Ataxia*Impairment of the ability to coordinate the movements required for normal ambulation (WALKING) which may result from impairments of motor function or sensory feedback. This condition may be associated with BRAIN DISEASES (including CEREBELLAR DISEASES and BASAL GANGLIA DISEASES); SPINAL CORD DISEASES; or PERIPHERAL NERVOUS SYSTEM DISEASES.
C23.888.592.350.110*D001264*Athetosis*A dyskinesia characterized by an inability to maintain the fingers

column2: Drug-Induced*Abnormal movements

column1: C23.888.592.350.300*D004421*Dystonia*An attitude or posture due to the co-contraction of agonists and antagonist muscles in one region of the body. C23.888.592.350.500*D009207*Myoclonus*Involuntary shock-like contractions

column4: of a muscle or a group of muscles. This condition may be a feature of some CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM DISEASES; (e.g.
column6: MYOCLONIC). Nocturnal myoclonus is the principal feature of the NOCTURNAL MYOCLONUS SYNDROME. (From Adams et al.

column1: C23.888.592.350.600*D011595*Psychomotor Agitation*A feeling of restlessness associated with increased motor activity. This may occur as a manifestation of nervous system drug toxicity or other conditions.

column2: Drug-Induced*A condition associated with the use of certain medications and characterized by an internal sense of motor restlessness often described as an inability to resist the urge to move.

column1: C23.888.592.350.675*D046608*Synkinesis*An involuntary movement accompanying a volitional movement. It often refers to facial movements that accompany FACIAL PARALYSIS.

column11: and excessive blinking. Tics tend to be aggravated by emotional stress. When frequent they may interfere with speech and INTERPERSONAL RELATIONS. column1: C23.888.592.350.850*D014202*Tremor*Cyclical movement of a body part that can represent either a physiologic process or a manifestation of disease. Intention or action tremor

column3: is aggravated by movement. In contrast

column2: Neurologic*Gait abnormalities that are a manifestation of nervous system dysfunction. These conditions may be caused by a wide variety of disorders which affect motor control
column4: and muscle strength including: CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM DISEASES; PERIPHERAL NERVOUS SYSTEM DISEASES; NEUROMUSCULAR DISEASES; or MUSCULAR DISEASES.

column3: MULTI-INFARCT; ALZHEIMER DISEASE; and other conditions may be associated with gait apraxia.

This condition may be associated with BRAIN DISEASES (including CEREBELLAR DISEASES and BASAL GANGLIA DISEASES); SPINAL CORD DISEASES; or PERIPHERAL NERVOUS SYSTEM DISEASES.

column3: and utilization of knowledge or information.

column1: C23.888.592.604.150.500*D007806*Language Disorders*Conditions characterized by deficiencies of comprehension or expression of written and spoken forms of language. These include acquired and developmental disorders.

column2: syllables
column4: or phrases) due to an injury to a specific cerebral area or occasionally due to emotional factors. This condition rarely occurs in isolation

column2: but cannot provide the name. This condition is associated with lesions of the dominant hemisphere involving the language areas
column3: in particular the TEMPORAL LOBE. (From Adams et al.

column1: C23.888.592.604.150.500.300*D004410*Dyslexia*A cognitive disorder characterized by an impaired ability to comprehend written and printed words or phrases despite intact vision. This condition may be developmental or acquired. Developmental dyslexia is marked by reading achievement that falls substantially below that expected given the individual's chronological age
column2: measured intelligence
column3: and age-appropriate education. The disturbance in reading significantly interferes with academic achievement or with activities of daily living that require reading skills. (From DSM-IV)

column2: Acquired*A receptive visual aphasia characterized by the loss of a previously possessed ability to comprehend the meaning or significance of handwritten words
column3: despite intact vision. This condition may be associated with posterior cerebral artery infarction (INFARCTION
column4: POSTERIOR CEREBRAL ARTERY) and other BRAIN DISEASES.

column2: Pure*Loss of the power to comprehend written materials despite preservation of the ability to write (i.e.
column3: alexia without agraphia). This condition is generally attributed to lesions that disconnect the visual cortex of the non-dominant hemisphere from language centers in the dominant hemisphere. This may occur when a dominant visual cortex injury is combined with underlying white matter lesions that involve crossing fibers from the occipital lobe of the opposite hemisphere. (From Adams et al.

column1: C23.888.592.604.150.500.550*D007805*Language Development Disorders*Conditions characterized by language abilities (comprehension and expression of speech and writing) that are below the expected level for a given age
column2: generally in the absence of an intellectual impairment. These conditions may be associated with DEAFNESS; BRAIN DISEASES; MENTAL DISORDERS; or environmental factors.

column1: C23.888.592.604.150.500.800*D013064*Speech Disorders*Acquired or developmental conditions marked by an impaired ability to comprehend or generate spoken forms of language.

C23.888.592.604.150.500.800.100*D001037*Aphasia*A cognitive disorder marked by an impaired ability to comprehend or express language in its written or spoken form. This condition is caused by diseases which affect the language areas of the dominant hemisphere. Clinical features are used to classify the various subtypes of this condition. column2: expressive
Broca*An aphasia characterized by impairment of expressive LANGUAGE (speech
column4: signs) and relative preservation of receptive language abilities (i.e.
column5: comprehension). This condition is caused by lesions of the motor association cortex in the FRONTAL LOBE (BROCA AREA and adjacent cortical and white matter regions).

column2: Conduction*A type of fluent aphasia characterized by an impaired ability to repeat one and two word phrases
column3: despite retained comprehension. This condition is associated with dominant hemisphere lesions involving the arcuate fasciculus (a white matter projection between Broca's and Wernicke's areas) and adjacent structures. Like patients with Wernicke aphasia (APHASIA
column5: patients with conduction aphasia are fluent but commit paraphasic errors during attempts at written and oral forms of communication. (From Adams et al.

column2: Primary Progressive*A progressive form of dementia characterized by the global loss of language abilities and initial preservation of other cognitive functions. Fluent and nonfluent subtypes have been described. Eventually a pattern of global cognitive dysfunction
column5: there are no Alzheimer or PICK DISEASE like changes
column7: spongiform changes of cortical layers II and III are present in the TEMPORAL LOBE and FRONTAL LOBE. (From Brain 1998 Jan;121(Pt 1):115-26)

column1: C23.888.592.604.150.500.800.100.155.600*D057178*Primary Progressive Nonfluent Aphasia*A form of frontotemporal lobar degeneration and a progressive form of dementia characterized by motor speech impairment and AGRAMMATISM
column2: with relative sparing of single word comprehension and semantic memory.
Wernicke*Impairment in the comprehension of speech and meaning of words
column4: and of the meanings conveyed by their grammatical relationships in sentences. It is caused by lesions that primarily affect Wernicke's area
column5: which lies in the posterior perisylvian region of the temporal lobe of the dominant hemisphere. (From Brain & Bannister

The cortical language centers are intact in this condition. (From Adams et al.

column1: C23.888.592.604.150.500.800.300*D004454*Echolalia*Involuntary (parrot-like)
column2: meaningless repetition of a recently heard word
column4: or song. This condition may be associated with transcortical APHASIA; SCHIZOPHRENIA; or other disorders. (From Adams et al.

column1: C23.888.592.604.150.500.800.500*D009155*Mutism*The inability to generate oral-verbal expression
column2: despite normal comprehension of speech. This may be associated with BRAIN DISEASES or MENTAL DISORDERS. Selective mutism is a psychological condition that usually affects children characterized by continuous refusal to speak in social situations by a child who is able and willing to speak to selected persons. Kussmal aphasia refers to mutism in psychosis. (From Fortschr Neurol Psychiatr 1994; 62(9):337-44)

column1: C23.888.592.604.150.500.800.750*D013342*Stuttering*A disturbance in the normal fluency and time patterning of speech that is inappropriate for the individual's age. This disturbance is characterized by frequent repetitions or prolongations of sounds or syllables. Various other types of speech dysfluencies may also be involved including interjections
