column5: words produced with an excess of physical tension
column6: and monosyllabic whole word repetitions. Stuttering may occur as a developmental condition in childhood or as an acquired disorder which may be associated with BRAIN INFARCTIONS and other BRAIN DISEASES. (From DSM-IV

column1: C23.888.592.604.150.550*D007859*Learning Disorders*Conditions characterized by a significant discrepancy between an individual's perceived level of intellect and their ability to acquire new language and other cognitive skills. These disorders may result from organic or psychological conditions. Relatively common subtypes include DYSLEXIA
column2: DYSCALCULIA

column3: GERSTMANN SYNDROME ) or acquired due to brain damage.

This condition may be developmental or acquired. Developmental dyslexia is marked by reading achievement that falls substantially below that expected given the individual's chronological age
column2: measured intelligence
column3: and age-appropriate education. The disturbance in reading significantly interferes with academic achievement or with activities of daily living that require reading skills. (From DSM-IV)

C23.888.592.604.359.800.400*D018458*Persistent Vegetative State*Vegetative state refers to the neurocognitive status of individuals with severe brain damage

column1: C23.888.592.604.359.800.500*D053608*Stupor*A state of reduced sensibility and response to stimuli which is distinguished from COMA in that the person can be aroused by vigorous and repeated stimulation. The person is still conscious and can make voluntary movements. It can be induced by CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM AGENTS. The word derives from Latin stupere and is related to stunned

column1: C23.888.592.604.359.800.600*D013575*Syncope*A transient loss of consciousness and postural tone caused by diminished blood flow to the brain (i.e.
column2: BRAIN ISCHEMIA). Presyncope refers to the sensation of lightheadedness and loss of strength that precedes a syncopal event or accompanies an incomplete syncope. (From Adams et al.
Vasovagal*Loss of consciousness due to a reduction in blood pressure that is associated with an increase in vagal tone and peripheral vasodilation.

column1: C23.888.592.604.444*D053609*Lethargy*A general state of sluggishness
column2: listless
column5: and having difficulty concentrating and doing simple tasks. It may be related to DEPRESSION or DRUG ADDICTION.

column1: C23.888.592.604.529*D008569*Memory Disorders*Disturbances in registering an impression

column1: C23.888.592.604.529.100*D000647*Amnesia*Pathologic partial or complete loss of the ability to recall past experiences (AMNESIA

column3: ANTEROGRADE). This condition may be of organic or psychologic origin. Organic forms of amnesia are usually associated with dysfunction of the DIENCEPHALON or HIPPOCAMPUS. (From Adams et al.

column2: Anterograde*Loss of the ability to form new memories beyond a certain point in time. This condition may be organic or psychogenic in origin. column3: the HIPPOCAMPUS; FORNIX (BRAIN); MAMMILLARY BODIES; and ANTERIOR THALAMIC NUCLEI). (From Memory 1997 Jan-Mar;5(1-2):49-71)

column2: Retrograde*Loss of the ability to recall information that had been previously encoded in memory prior to a specified or approximate point in time. This process may be organic or psychogenic in origin. Organic forms may be associated with CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA; CEREBROVASCULAR ACCIDENTS; SEIZURES; DEMENTIA; and a wide variety of other conditions that impair cerebral function. (From Adams et al.
Transient Global*A syndrome characterized by a transient loss of the ability to form new memories. It primarily occurs in middle aged or elderly individuals
column3: and episodes may last from minutes to hours. During the period of amnesia
column4: immediate and recent memory abilities are impaired
column5: but the level of consciousness and ability to perform other intellectual tasks are preserved. The condition is related to bilateral dysfunction of the medial portions of each TEMPORAL LOBE. Complete recovery normally occurs
column6: and recurrences are unusual. (From Adams et al.

column1: C23.888.592.604.529.400*D020915*Korsakoff Syndrome*An acquired cognitive disorder characterized by inattentiveness and the inability to form short term memories. (Adams et al.

column1: C23.888.592.604.646*D008607*Intellectual Disability*Subnormal intellectual functioning which originates during the developmental period. This has multiple potential etiologies
column2: including genetic defects and perinatal insults. Intelligence quotient (IQ) scores are commonly used to determine whether an individual has an intellectual disability. IQ scores between 70 and 79 are in the borderline range. Scores below 67 are in the disabled range. (from Joynt

column4: or sensory stimuli presented from one side of the body.

column1: C23.888.592.604.764.100.650*D020238*Prosopagnosia*The inability to recognize a familiar face or to learn to recognize new faces. column8: and other neurological and psychiatric disorders.

column1: C23.888.592.604.764.200*D001308*Auditory Perceptual Disorders*Acquired or developmental cognitive disorders of AUDITORY PERCEPTION characterized by a reduced ability to perceive information contained in auditory stimuli despite intact auditory pathways. Affected individuals have difficulty with speech perception
column2: sound localization
column3: and comprehending the meaning of inflections of speech.

column1: C23.888.592.604.764.700*D010591*Phantom Limb*Perception of painful and nonpainful phantom sensations that occur following the complete or partial loss of a limb. The majority of individuals with an amputated extremity will experience the impression that the limb is still present

column1: C23.888.592.604.882*D011596*Psychomotor Disorders*Abnormalities of motor function that are associated with organic and non-organic cognitive disorders.

C23.888.592.604.882.350*D001072*Apraxias*A group of cognitive disorders characterized by the inability to perform previously learned skills that cannot be attributed to deficits of motor or sensory function. The two major subtypes of this condition are ideomotor (see APRAXIA

column1: C23.888.592.604.882.350.600*D020235*Gait Apraxia*Impaired ambulation not attributed to sensory impairment or motor weakness. FRONTAL LOBE disorders; BASAL GANGLIA DISEASES (e.g.
column2: PARKINSONIAN DISORDERS); DEMENTIA
column3: MULTI-INFARCT; ALZHEIMER DISEASE; and other conditions may be associated with gait apraxia.

column1: C23.888.592.604.882.700*D011595*Psychomotor Agitation*A feeling of restlessness associated with increased motor activity. This may occur as a manifestation of nervous system drug toxicity or other conditions.
C23.888.592.608*D020879*Neuromuscular Manifestations*Signs and symptoms associated with diseases of the muscle
column2: neuromuscular junction

column1: C23.888.592.608.250*D005207*Fasciculation*Involuntary contraction of the muscle fibers innervated by a motor unit. Fasciculations may be visualized as a muscle twitch or dimpling under the skin
column2: but usually do not generate sufficient force to move a limb. They may represent a benign condition or occur as a manifestation of MOTOR NEURON DISEASE or PERIPHERAL NERVOUS SYSTEM DISEASES. (Adams et al.

column1: C23.888.592.608.500*D009120*Muscle Cramp*A sustained and usually painful contraction of muscle fibers. This may occur as an isolated phenomenon or as a manifestation of an underlying disease process (e.g.
column2: UREMIA; HYPOTHYROIDISM; MOTOR NEURON DISEASE; etc.). (From Adams et al.

column1: C23.888.592.608.550*D009122*Muscle Hypertonia*Abnormal increase in skeletal or smooth muscle tone. Skeletal muscle hypertonicity may be associated with PYRAMIDAL TRACT lesions or BASAL GANGLIA DISEASES.

C23.888.592.608.550.500*D009127*Muscle Rigidity*Continuous involuntary sustained muscle contraction which is often a manifestation of BASAL GANGLIA DISEASES. When an affected muscle is passively stretched
column2: the degree of resistance remains constant regardless of the rate at which the muscle is stretched. This feature helps to distinguish rigidity from MUSCLE SPASTICITY. (From Adams et al.

column1: C23.888.592.608.550.550*D009128*Muscle Spasticity*A form of muscle hypertonia associated with upper MOTOR NEURON DISEASE. Resistance to passive stretch of a spastic muscle results in minimal initial resistance (a free interval) followed by an incremental increase in muscle tone. Tone increases in proportion to the velocity of stretch. Spasticity is usually accompanied by HYPERREFLEXIA and variable degrees of MUSCLE WEAKNESS. (From Adams et al.
column2: Principles of Neurology

column1: C23.888.592.608.575*D009123*Muscle Hypotonia*A diminution of the skeletal muscle tone marked by a diminished resistance to passive stretching.
C23.888.592.608.593*D018908*Muscle Weakness*A vague complaint of debility
column2: fatigue
column3: or exhaustion attributable to weakness of various muscles. The weakness can be characterized as subacute or chronic
column5: and is a manifestation of many muscle and neuromuscular diseases. (From Wyngaarden et al.

column1: C23.888.592.608.612*D009133*Muscular Atrophy*Derangement in size and number of muscle fibers occurring with aging
column2: reduction in blood supply

column1: C23.888.592.608.612.500*D055948*Sarcopenia*Progressive decline in muscle mass due to aging which results in decreased functional capacity of muscles.
C23.888.592.608.650*D020385*Myokymia*Successive and rapid contractions of motor units associated with chronic nerve injury. The discharges arise from the peripheral aspects of regenerating nerves
column2: and clinically impart a nearly continuous undulation of the body surface overlying the muscle. (Adams et al.

column1: C23.888.592.608.700*D009222*Myotonia*Prolonged failure of muscle relaxation after contraction. This may occur after voluntary contractions
column2: muscle percussion
column3: or electrical stimulation of the muscle. Myotonia is a characteristic feature of MYOTONIC DISORDERS.

column1: C23.888.592.608.750*D013035*Spasm*An involuntary contraction of a muscle or group of muscles. Spasms may involve SKELETAL MUSCLE or SMOOTH MUSCLE.
C23.888.592.608.750.400*D019569*Hemifacial Spasm*Recurrent clonic contraction of facial muscles
column2: restricted to one side. It may occur as a manifestation of compressive lesions involving the seventh cranial nerve (FACIAL NERVE DISEASES)
column4: or in association with other disorders. (From Adams et al.

column1: C23.888.592.608.750.700*D014313*Trismus*Spasmodic contraction of the masseter muscle resulting in forceful jaw closure. This may be seen with a variety of diseases
column2: including TETANUS
column3: as a complication of radiation therapy
column5: or in association with neoplastic conditions.

column1: C23.888.592.608.875*D013746*Tetany*A disorder characterized by muscle twitches
column2: cramps
column5: laryngospasm and seizures. This condition is associated with unstable depolarization of axonal membranes
column6: primarily in the peripheral nervous system. Tetany usually results from HYPOCALCEMIA or reduced serum levels of MAGNESIUM that may be associated with HYPERVENTILATION; HYPOPARATHYROIDISM; RICKETS; UREMIA; or other conditions. (From Adams et al.

column1: C23.888.592.610*D054971*Orthostatic Intolerance*Symptoms of cerebral hypoperfusion or autonomic overaction which develop while the subject is standing
column2: but are relieved on recumbency. Types of this include NEUROCARDIOGENIC SYNCOPE; POSTURAL ORTHOSTATIC TACHYCARDIA SYNDROME; and neurogenic ORTHOSTATIC HYPOTENSION. (From Noseworthy

column1: C23.888.592.612*D010146*Pain*An unpleasant sensation induced by noxious stimuli which are detected by NERVE ENDINGS of NOCICEPTIVE NEURONS.
C23.888.592.612.054*D015746*Abdominal Pain*Sensation of discomfort
column2: distress
column3: or agony in the abdominal region.

column2: Acute*A clinical syndrome with acute abdominal pain that is severe
column4: and rapid in onset. Acute abdomen may be caused by a variety of disorders

column1: C23.888.592.612.081*D059787*Acute Pain*Intensely discomforting
column2: distressful
column3: or agonizing sensation associated with trauma or disease

column1: C23.888.592.612.094*D018771*Arthralgia*Pain in the joint.
C23.888.592.612.094.700*D020069*Shoulder Pain*Unilateral or bilateral pain of the shoulder. It is often caused by physical activities such as work or sports participation
column2: but may also be pathologic in origin.

column1: C23.888.592.612.107*D001416*Back Pain*Acute or chronic pain located in the posterior regions of the THORAX; LUMBOSACRAL REGION; or the adjacent regions.
C23.888.592.612.107.200*D055111*Failed Back Surgery Syndrome*A condition of persistent pain and discomfort in the BACK and the LEG following lumbar surgery
column2: often seen in patients enrolled in pain centers.

column1: C23.888.592.612.107.400*D017116*Low Back Pain*Acute or chronic pain in the lumbar or sacral regions
column2: which may be associated with musculo-ligamentous SPRAINS AND STRAINS; INTERVERTEBRAL DISK DISPLACEMENT; and other conditions.

column1: C23.888.592.612.191*D059390*Breakthrough Pain*Acute pain that comes on rapidly despite the use of pain medication.
C23.888.592.612.212*D000072716*Cancer Pain*Pain that may be caused by or related to cellular
column2: tissue
column3: and systemic changes that occur during NEOPLASM growth

column1: C23.888.592.612.233*D002637*Chest Pain*Pressure
column2: burning

column1: C23.888.592.612.233.500*D000787*Angina Pectoris*The symptom of paroxysmal pain consequent to MYOCARDIAL ISCHEMIA usually of distinctive character
column2: location and radiation. It is thought to be provoked by a transient stressful situation during which the oxygen requirements of the MYOCARDIUM exceed that supplied by the CORONARY CIRCULATION.
Unstable*Precordial pain at rest
column3: which may precede a MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION.

column2: Variant*A clinical syndrome characterized by the development of CHEST PAIN at rest with concomitant transient ST segment elevation in the ELECTROCARDIOGRAM

Stable*Persistent and reproducible chest discomfort usually precipitated by a physical exertion that dissipates upon cessation of such an activity. The symptoms are manifestations of MYOCARDIAL ISCHEMIA.

column1: C23.888.592.612.274*D059350*Chronic Pain*Aching sensation that persists for more than a few months. It may or may not be associated with trauma or disease
column2: and may persist after the initial injury has healed. Its localization
column4: and timing are more vague than with acute pain.

column1: C23.888.592.612.302*D004433*Earache*Pain in the ear.
C23.888.592.612.316*D058447*Eye Pain*A dull or sharp painful sensation associated with the outer or inner structures of the eyeball
column2: having different causes.

column1: C23.888.592.612.330*D005157*Facial Pain*Pain in the facial region including orofacial pain and craniofacial pain. Associated conditions include local inflammatory and neoplastic disorders and neuralgic syndromes involving the trigeminal
column2: facial
column3: and glossopharyngeal nerves. Conditions which feature recurrent or persistent facial pain as the primary manifestation of disease are referred to as FACIAL PAIN SYNDROMES.

column1: C23.888.592.612.330.500*D014098*Toothache*Pain in the adjacent areas of the teeth.
C23.888.592.612.386*D021501*Flank Pain*Pain emanating from below the RIBS and above the ILIUM.
C23.888.592.612.414*D005926*Glossalgia*Painful sensations in the tongue
column2: including a sensation of burning.

column1: C23.888.592.612.441*D006261*Headache*The symptom of PAIN in the cranial region. It may be an isolated benign occurrence or manifestation of a wide variety of HEADACHE DISORDERS.

C23.888.592.612.441.500*D056124*Slit Ventricle Syndrome*An intermittent and self-limiting headache disorder in individuals with CEREBROSPINAL FLUID SHUNTS emplaced for the treatment of HYDROCEPHALUS. The symptoms of headache
column2: vomiting
column3: and cranial neuropathies are associated with intermittent obstruction of the shunt.

column1: C23.888.592.612.451*D048949*Labor Pain*Pain associated with OBSTETRIC LABOR in CHILDBIRTH. It is caused primarily by UTERINE CONTRACTION as well as pressure on the CERVIX; BLADDER; and the GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT. Labor pain mostly occurs in the ABDOMEN; the GROIN; and the BACK.
C23.888.592.612.530*D059373*Mastodynia*Pain in the breast generally classified as cyclical (associated with menstrual periods)
column2: or noncyclical
column3: i.e. originating from the breast or nearby muscles or joints
column4: ranging from minor discomfort to severely incapacitating.

column1: C23.888.592.612.540*D037061*Metatarsalgia*Pain in the region of the METATARSUS. It can include pain in the METATARSAL BONES; METATARSOPHALANGEAL JOINT; and/or intermetatarsal joints (TARSAL JOINTS).
C23.888.592.612.540.500*D000070607*Morton Neuroma*A nerve inflammation in the foot caused by chronic compression of the plantar nerve between the METATARSAL BONES.
C23.888.592.612.547*D059352*Musculoskeletal Pain*Discomfort stemming from muscles
column2: LIGAMENTS

column1: C23.888.592.612.547.249*D063806*Myalgia*Painful sensation in the muscles.
C23.888.592.612.547.500*D059388*Pelvic Girdle Pain*Discomfort associated with the bones that make up the pelvic girdle. It occurs frequently during pregnancy.

C23.888.592.612.553*D019547*Neck Pain*Discomfort or more intense forms of pain that are localized to the cervical region. This term generally refers to pain in the posterior or lateral regions of the neck.
C23.888.592.612.664*D009437*Neuralgia*Intense or aching pain that occurs along the course or distribution of a peripheral or cranial nerve.
C23.888.592.612.664.275*D000070607*Morton Neuroma*A nerve inflammation in the foot caused by chronic compression of the plantar nerve between the METATARSAL BONES.

column2: Postherpetic*Pain in nerves
column4: resulting from the activation the latent varicella-zoster virus (HERPESVIRUS 3
column5: HUMAN). The two forms of the condition preceding the pain are HERPES ZOSTER OTICUS; and HERPES ZOSTER OPHTHALMICUS. Following the healing of the rashes and blisters

column1: C23.888.592.612.664.675*D055958*Piriformis Muscle Syndrome*A chronic PELVIC PAIN characterized by pain deep in the buttock that may radiate to posterior aspects of the leg. It is caused by the piriformis muscle compressing or irritating the SCIATIC NERVE due to trauma
column2: hypertrophy

column1: C23.888.592.612.664.737*D060545*Pudendal Neuralgia*Pain associated with a damaged PUDENDAL NERVE. Clinical features may include positional pain with sitting in the perineal and genital areas
column2: sexual dysfunction and FECAL INCONTINENCE and URINARY INCONTINENCE.

column1: C23.888.592.612.664.800*D012585*Sciatica*A condition characterized by pain radiating from the back into the buttock and posterior/lateral aspects of the leg. Sciatica may be a manifestation of SCIATIC NEUROPATHY; RADICULOPATHY (involving the SPINAL NERVE ROOTS; L4
column2: L5
column5: often associated with INTERVERTEBRAL DISK DISPLACEMENT); or lesions of the CAUDA EQUINA.

column1: C23.888.592.612.720*D059226*Nociceptive Pain*Dull or sharp aching pain caused by stimulated NOCICEPTORS due to tissue injury
column2: inflammation or diseases. It can be divided into somatic or tissue pain and VISCERAL PAIN.

column1: C23.888.592.612.720.500*D059265*Visceral Pain*Pain originating from internal organs (VISCERA) associated with autonomic phenomena (PALLOR; SWEATING; NAUSEA; and VOMITING). It often becomes a REFERRED PAIN.

column2: Intractable*Persistent pain that is refractory to some or all forms of treatment.
Postoperative*Pain during the period after surgery.

column1: C23.888.592.612.832.500*D010591*Phantom Limb*Perception of painful and nonpainful phantom sensations that occur following the complete or partial loss of a limb. The majority of individuals with an amputated extremity will experience the impression that the limb is still present
column2: and in many cases
column3: painful. (From Neurol Clin 1998 Nov;16(4):919-36; Brain 1998 Sep;121(Pt 9):1603-30)

column2: Referred*A type of pain that is perceived in an area away from the site where the pain arises
column3: such as facial pain caused by lesion of the VAGUS NERVE
column4: or throat problem generating referred pain in the ear.

column1: C23.888.592.612.944*D017699*Pelvic Pain*Pain in the pelvic region of genital and non-genital origin and of organic or psychogenic etiology. Frequent causes of pain are distension or contraction of hollow viscera
column2: rapid stretching of the capsule of a solid organ
column7: or fibrotic processes in adjacent organs. (Kase
column8: Weingold & Gershenson: Principles and Practice of Clinical Gynecology

column1: C23.888.592.612.944.500*D004412*Dysmenorrhea*Painful menstruation.
C23.888.592.612.944.625*D059388*Pelvic Girdle Pain*Discomfort associated with the bones that make up the pelvic girdle. It occurs frequently during pregnancy.

C23.888.592.612.944.750*D055958*Piriformis Muscle Syndrome*A chronic PELVIC PAIN characterized by pain deep in the buttock that may radiate to posterior aspects of the leg. It is caused by the piriformis muscle compressing or irritating the SCIATIC NERVE due to trauma
column2: hypertrophy

column1: C23.888.592.612.972*D056844*Renal Colic*A severe intermittent and spasmodic pain in the lower back radiating to the groin
column2: scrotum
column3: and labia which is most commonly caused by a kidney stone (RENAL CALCULUS) passing through the URETER or by other urinary track blockage. It is often associated with nausea

column1: C23.888.592.636*D010243*Paralysis*A general term most often used to describe severe or complete loss of muscle strength due to motor system disease from the level of the cerebral cortex to the muscle fiber. This term may also occasionally refer to a loss of sensory function. (From Adams et al.
column2: Principles of Neurology

column1: C23.888.592.636.214*D005158*Facial Paralysis*Severe or complete loss of facial muscle motor function. This condition may result from central or peripheral lesions. Damage to CNS motor pathways from the cerebral cortex to the facial nuclei in the pons leads to facial weakness that generally spares the forehead muscles. FACIAL NERVE DISEASES generally results in generalized hemifacial weakness. NEUROMUSCULAR JUNCTION DISEASES and MUSCULAR DISEASES may also cause facial paralysis or paresis.

C23.888.592.636.263*D018589*Gastroparesis*Chronic delayed gastric emptying. Gastroparesis may be caused by motor dysfunction or paralysis of STOMACH muscles or may be associated with other systemic diseases such as DIABETES MELLITUS.

C23.888.592.636.312*D006429*Hemiplegia*Severe or complete loss of motor function on one side of the body. This condition is usually caused by BRAIN DISEASES that are localized to the cerebral hemisphere opposite to the side of weakness. Less frequently
column2: BRAIN STEM lesions; cervical SPINAL CORD DISEASES; PERIPHERAL NERVOUS SYSTEM DISEASES; and other conditions may manifest as hemiplegia. The term hemiparesis (see PARESIS) refers to mild to moderate weakness involving one side of the body.

column1: C23.888.592.636.447*D009886*Ophthalmoplegia*Paralysis of one or more of the ocular muscles due to disorders of the eye muscles
column2: neuromuscular junction
Chronic Progressive External*A mitochondrial myopathy characterized by slowly progressive paralysis of the levator palpebrae
column4: and extraocular muscles. Ragged-red fibers and atrophy are found on muscle biopsy. Familial and sporadic forms may occur. Disease onset is usually in the first or second decade of life
column5: and the illness slowly progresses until usually all ocular motility is lost. (From Adams et al.

column1: C23.888.592.636.447.511.500*D007625*Kearns-Sayre Syndrome*A mitochondrial disorder featuring the triad of chronic progressive EXTERNAL OPHTHALMOPLEGIA
column2: cardiomyopathy (CARDIOMYOPATHIES) with conduction block (HEART BLOCK)
column3: and RETINITIS PIGMENTOSA. Disease onset is in the first or second decade. Elevated CSF protein
column6: and pyramidal signs may also be present. Ragged-red fibers are found on muscle biopsy. (Adams et al.

column1: C23.888.592.636.447.600*D060486*Ophthalmoplegic Migraine*Childhood-onset of recurrent headaches with an oculomotor cranial nerve palsy. Typically
column2: ABDUCENS NERVE; OCULOMOTOR NERVE; and TROCHLEAR NERVE are involved with DIPLOPIA and BLEPHAROPTOSIS.

Progressive*A degenerative disease of the central nervous system characterized by balance difficulties; OCULAR MOTILITY DISORDERS (supranuclear ophthalmoplegia); DYSARTHRIA; swallowing difficulties; and axial DYSTONIA. Onset is usually in the fifth decade and disease progression occurs over several years. Pathologic findings include neurofibrillary degeneration and neuronal loss in the dorsal MESENCEPHALON; SUBTHALAMIC NUCLEUS; RED NUCLEUS; pallidum; dentate nucleus; and vestibular nuclei. (From Adams et al.

column1: C23.888.592.636.637*D010264*Paraplegia*Severe or complete loss of motor function in the lower extremities and lower portions of the trunk. This condition is most often associated with SPINAL CORD DISEASES
column2: although BRAIN DISEASES; PERIPHERAL NERVOUS SYSTEM DISEASES; NEUROMUSCULAR DISEASES; and MUSCULAR DISEASES may also cause bilateral leg weakness.

column1: C23.888.592.636.637.300*D018437*Brown-Sequard Syndrome*A syndrome associated with injury to the lateral half of the spinal cord. The condition is characterized by the following clinical features (which are found below the level of the lesion): contralateral hemisensory anesthesia to pain and temperature
column2: ipsilateral loss of propioception
column3: and ipsilateral motor paralysis. Tactile sensation is generally spared. (From Adams et al.

column1: C23.888.592.636.711*D020828*Pseudobulbar Palsy*A syndrome characterized by DYSARTHRIA
column2: dysphagia
column4: impairment of voluntary movements of tongue and facial muscles
column5: and emotional lability. This condition is caused by diseases that affect the motor fibers that travel from the cerebral cortex to the lower BRAIN STEM (i.e.
column6: corticobulbar tracts); including MULTIPLE SCLEROSIS; MOTOR NEURON DISEASE; and CEREBROVASCULAR DISORDERS. (From Adams et al.

column1: C23.888.592.636.786*D011782*Quadriplegia*Severe or complete loss of motor function in all four limbs which may result from BRAIN DISEASES; SPINAL CORD DISEASES; PERIPHERAL NERVOUS SYSTEM DISEASES; NEUROMUSCULAR DISEASES; or rarely MUSCULAR DISEASES. The locked-in syndrome is characterized by quadriplegia in combination with cranial muscle paralysis. Consciousness is spared and the only retained voluntary motor activity may be limited eye movements. This condition is usually caused by a lesion in the upper BRAIN STEM which injures the descending cortico-spinal and cortico-bulbar tracts.

C23.888.592.636.812*D012133*Respiratory Paralysis*Complete or severe weakness of the muscles of respiration. This condition may be associated with MOTOR NEURON DISEASES; PERIPHERAL NERVE DISEASES; NEUROMUSCULAR JUNCTION DISEASES; SPINAL CORD DISEASES; injury to the PHRENIC NERVE; and other disorders.
C23.888.592.636.943*D014826*Vocal Cord Paralysis*Congenital or acquired paralysis of one or both VOCAL CORDS. This condition is caused by defects in the CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM
column2: the VAGUS NERVE and branches of LARYNGEAL NERVES. Common symptoms are VOICE DISORDERS including HOARSENESS or APHONIA.

column1: C23.888.592.643*D010291*Paresis*A general term referring to a mild to moderate degree of muscular weakness
column2: occasionally used as a synonym for PARALYSIS (severe or complete loss of motor function). In the older literature
column3: paresis often referred specifically to paretic neurosyphilis (see NEUROSYPHILIS). General paresis and general paralysis may still carry that connotation. Bilateral lower extremity paresis is referred to as PARAPARESIS.

column1: C23.888.592.643.500*D020335*Paraparesis*Mild to moderate loss of bilateral lower extremity motor function
column2: which may be a manifestation of SPINAL CORD DISEASES; PERIPHERAL NERVOUS SYSTEM DISEASES; MUSCULAR DISEASES; INTRACRANIAL HYPERTENSION; parasagittal brain lesions; and other conditions.

Spastic*Mild or moderate loss of motor function accompanied by spasticity in the lower extremities. This condition is a manifestation of CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM DISEASES that cause injury to the motor cortex or descending motor pathways.

column1: C23.888.592.700*D011602*Psychophysiologic Disorders*A group of disorders characterized by physical symptoms that are affected by emotional factors and involve a single organ system
column2: usually under AUTONOMIC NERVOUS SYSTEM control. (American Psychiatric Glossary

column1: C23.888.592.708*D011681*Pupil Disorders*Conditions which affect the structure or function of the pupil of the eye
column2: including disorders of innervation to the pupillary constrictor or dilator muscles

column1: C23.888.592.708.150*D015875*Anisocoria*Unequal pupil size
column2: which may represent a benign physiologic variant or a manifestation of disease. Pathologic anisocoria reflects an abnormality in the musculature of the iris (IRIS DISEASES) or in the parasympathetic or sympathetic pathways that innervate the pupil. Physiologic anisocoria refers to an asymmetry of pupil diameter
column4: that is not associated with disease.

column1: C23.888.592.708.362*D015877*Miosis*Pupillary constriction. This may result from congenital absence of the dilatator pupillary muscle
column2: defective sympathetic innervation
column3: or irritation of the CONJUNCTIVA or CORNEA.

column1: C23.888.592.708.362.500*D006732*Horner Syndrome*A syndrome associated with defective sympathetic innervation to one side of the face
column2: including the eye. Clinical features include MIOSIS; mild BLEPHAROPTOSIS; and hemifacial ANHIDROSIS (decreased sweating)(see HYPOHIDROSIS). Lesions of the BRAIN STEM; cervical SPINAL CORD; first thoracic nerve root; apex of the LUNG; CAROTID ARTERY; CAVERNOUS SINUS; and apex of the ORBIT may cause this condition. (From Miller et al.

column1: C23.888.592.708.575*D015845*Tonic Pupil*A pupillary abnormality characterized by a poor pupillary light reaction
column2: reduced accommodation
column4: an enhanced pupillary response to near effort that results in a prolonged
column6: and slow pupillary redilation. This condition is associated with injury to the postganglionic parasympathetic innervation to the pupil. (From Miller et al.

column2: Abnormal*An abnormal response to a stimulus applied to the sensory components of the nervous system. This may take the form of increased

column1: C23.888.592.742*D012640*Seizures*Clinical or subclinical disturbances of cortical function due to a sudden
column2: abnormal
column4: and disorganized discharge of brain cells. Clinical manifestations include abnormal motor
column5: sensory and psychic phenomena. Recurrent seizures are usually referred to as EPILEPSY or seizure disorder.

column1: C23.888.592.763*D012678*Sensation Disorders*Disorders of the special senses (i.e.
column2: VISION; HEARING; TASTE; and SMELL) or somatosensory system (i.e.
column3: afferent components of the PERIPHERAL NERVOUS SYSTEM).

column1: C23.888.592.763.237*D004244*Dizziness*An imprecise term which may refer to a sense of spatial disorientation
column2: motion of the environment

column1: C23.888.592.763.393*D006311*Hearing Disorders*Conditions that impair the transmission of auditory impulses and information from the level of the ear to the temporal cortices
column2: including the sensorineural pathways.

column1: C23.888.592.763.393.341*D034381*Hearing Loss*A general term for the complete or partial loss of the ability to hear from one or both ears.
C23.888.592.763.393.341.186*D003638*Deafness*A general term for the complete loss of the ability to hear from both ears.
C23.888.592.763.393.341.186.500*D054062*Deaf-Blind Disorders*The absence of both hearing and vision.

column2: Bilateral*Partial hearing loss in both ears.

Conductive*Hearing loss due to interference with the mechanical reception or amplification of sound to the COCHLEA. The interference is in the outer or middle ear involving the EAR CANAL; TYMPANIC MEMBRANE; or EAR OSSICLES.
Functional*Hearing loss without a physical basis. Often observed in patients with psychological or behavioral disorders.
High-Frequency*Hearing loss in frequencies above 1000 hertz.
Mixed Conductive-Sensorineural*Hearing loss due to damage or impairment of both the conductive elements (HEARING LOSS
column3: CONDUCTIVE) and the sensorineural elements (HEARING LOSS

column2: Sensorineural*Hearing loss resulting from damage to the COCHLEA and the sensorineural elements which lie internally beyond the oval and round windows. These elements include the AUDITORY NERVE and its connections in the BRAINSTEM.
Central*Hearing loss due to disease of the AUDITORY PATHWAYS (in the CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM) which originate in the COCHLEAR NUCLEI of the PONS and then ascend bilaterally to the MIDBRAIN
column4: and then the AUDITORY CORTEX in the TEMPORAL LOBE. Bilateral lesions of the auditory pathways are usually required to cause central hearing loss. Cortical deafness refers to loss of hearing due to bilateral auditory cortex lesions. Unilateral BRAIN STEM lesions involving the cochlear nuclei may result in unilateral hearing loss.

column2: Noise-Induced*Hearing loss due to exposure to explosive loud noise or chronic exposure to sound level greater than 85 dB. The hearing loss is often in the frequency range 4000-6000 hertz.

column1: C23.888.592.763.393.341.887.772*D011304*Presbycusis*Gradual bilateral hearing loss associated with aging that is due to progressive degeneration of cochlear structures and central auditory pathways. Hearing loss usually begins with the high frequencies then progresses to sounds of middle and low frequencies.

C23.888.592.763.393.341.887.886*D052245*Usher Syndromes*Autosomal recessive hereditary disorders characterized by congenital SENSORINEURAL HEARING LOSS and RETINITIS PIGMENTOSA. Genetically and symptomatically heterogeneous
column2: clinical classes include type I
column5: age of onset of retinitis pigmentosa and the degree of vestibular dysfunction are variable.

column2: Sudden*Sensorineural hearing loss which develops suddenly over a period of hours or a few days. It varies in severity from mild to total deafness. Sudden deafness can be due to head trauma
column5: or can appear without obvious cause or warning.

column2: Unilateral*Partial or complete hearing loss in one ear.

column1: C23.888.592.763.393.505*D012001*Hyperacusis*An abnormally disproportionate increase in the sensation of loudness in response to auditory stimuli of normal volume. COCHLEAR DISEASES; VESTIBULOCOCHLEAR NERVE DISEASES; FACIAL NERVE DISEASES; STAPES SURGERY; and other disorders may be associated with this condition.

column3: Adult*Neurologic conditions in adults associated with acute or chronic exposure to lead or any of its salts. This tends to affect distal nerves and may present as wrist drop due to RADIAL NEUROPATHY. column4: INTERSTITIAL); and saturnine gout. An encephalopathy may rarely occur. (From Adams et al.

column2: Nervous System

column4: and diaphoresis). This condition may occasionally be fatal. It was formerly called delirium tremens. (From Adams et al.

column3: or a combination of factors. Clinical manifestations include variable degrees of weakness; ATROPHY; PARESTHESIAS; pain; loss of reflexes; sensory loss; diaphoresis; and postural hypotension. (From Arch Neurol 1995;52(1):45-51; Adams et al.

column2: Alcoholic*Disease of CARDIAC MUSCLE resulting from chronic excessive alcohol consumption. This disease is usually manifested by DYSPNEA and palpitations with CARDIOMEGALY and congestive heart failure (HEART FAILURE).

column1: C26.819.339*D020210*Central Cord Syndrome*A syndrome associated with traumatic injury to the cervical or upper thoracic regions of the spinal cord characterized by weakness in the arms with relative sparing of the legs and variable sensory loss. This condition is associated with ischemia
column2: hemorrhage
column3: or necrosis involving the central portions of the spinal cord. Corticospinal fibers destined for the legs are spared due to their more external location in the spinal cord. This clinical pattern may emerge during recovery from spinal shock. Deficits may be transient or permanent.

column1: C26.819.678*D013117*Spinal Cord Compression*Acute and chronic conditions characterized by external mechanical compression of the SPINAL CORD due to extramedullary neoplasm; EPIDURAL ABSCESS; SPINAL FRACTURES; bony deformities of the vertebral bodies; and other conditions. column2: weakness

column1: C26.844*D013180*Sprains and Strains*A collective term for muscle and ligament injuries without dislocation or fracture. A strain is an overstretching or overexertion of some part of the musculature.

column3: RHEUMATOID); ACROMEGALY; PREGNANCY; and other conditions. Symptoms include burning pain and paresthesias involving the ventral surface of the hand and fingers which may radiate proximally. column9: and ulnar half of the ring finger. (Joynt

Internal

column1: C26.915.300.200.175.300*D020202*Cerebral Hemorrhage

column3: clinical features may include SEIZURES; APHASIA; VISION DISORDERS; MOVEMENT DISORDERS; PARALYSIS; and COMA.

column2: Diffuse*Brain injuries occurring over a wide area instead of specific focal area.

column1: C26.915.300.200.188.500*D020833*Diffuse Axonal Injury*A relatively common sequela of blunt head injury
column2: characterized by a global disruption of axons throughout the brain. Associated clinical features may include NEUROBEHAVIORAL MANIFESTATIONS; PERSISTENT VEGETATIVE STATE; DEMENTIA; and other disorders.
Traumatic*A form of acquired brain injury which occurs when a sudden trauma causes damage to the brain.

column1: C26.915.300.200.194.250*D001924*Brain Concussion*A nonspecific term used to describe transient alterations or loss of consciousness following closed head injuries. The duration of UNCONSCIOUSNESS generally lasts a few seconds

column4: and severe. Prolonged periods of unconsciousness (often defined as greater than 6 hours in duration) may be referred to as post-traumatic coma (COMA

column1: C26.915.300.200.194.375*D000070624*Brain Contusion*A bruise of the brain from an impact of the skull.

column2: Chronic*Conditions characterized by persistent brain damage or dysfunction as sequelae of cranial trauma. This disorder may result from DIFFUSE AXONAL INJURY; INTRACRANIAL HEMORRHAGES; BRAIN EDEMA; and other conditions. Clinical features may include DEMENTIA; focal neurologic deficits; PERSISTENT VEGETATIVE STATE; AKINETIC MUTISM; or COMA.

column1: C26.915.300.200.200.500*D000070627*Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy*Degenerative brain disease linked to repetitive brain trauma. Progressive symptoms may include MEMORY LOSS; AGGRESSION; or DEPRESSION.

column2: Post-Traumatic*Recurrent seizures causally related to CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA. Seizure onset may be immediate but is typically delayed for several days after the injury and may not occur for up to two years. The majority of seizures have a focal onset that correlates clinically with the site of brain injury. Cerebral cortex injuries caused by a penetrating foreign object (CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA
column3: PENETRATING) are more likely than closed head injuries (HEAD INJURIES
column4: CLOSED) to be associated with epilepsy. Concussive convulsions are nonepileptic phenomena that occur immediately after head injury and are characterized by tonic and clonic movements. (From Rev Neurol 1998 Feb;26(150):256-261; Sports Med 1998 Feb;25(2):131-6)

column1: C26.915.300.400*D020209*Cranial Nerve Injuries*Dysfunction of one or more cranial nerves causally related to a traumatic injury. Penetrating and nonpenetrating CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA; NECK INJURIES; and trauma to the facial region are conditions associated with cranial nerve injuries.

column2: or sixth
column3: cranial nerve. Injury to this nerve results in lateral rectus muscle weakness or paralysis. The nerve may be damaged by closed or penetrating CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA or by facial trauma involving the orbit.

column1: F01.145.544*D007266*Inhibition (Psychology)*The interference with or prevention of a behavioral or verbal response even though the stimulus for that response is present; in psychoanalysis the unconscious restraining of an instinctual process.

column1: F01.700.250.500.500*D000071257*Emergence Delirium*A form of DELIRIUM which occurs after GENERAL ANESTHESIA.

F01.700.470*D053609*Lethargy*A general state of sluggishness

column5: and having difficulty concentrating and doing simple tasks. It may be related to DEPRESSION or DRUG ADDICTION.

column1: F01.700.625*D008569*Memory Disorders*Disturbances in registering an impression
column2: in the retention of an acquired impression
column3: or in the recall of an impression. Memory impairments are associated with DEMENTIA; CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA; ENCEPHALITIS; ALCOHOLISM (see also ALCOHOL AMNESTIC DISORDER); SCHIZOPHRENIA; and other conditions.

column1: F01.700.625.100*D000647*Amnesia*Pathologic partial or complete loss of the ability to recall past experiences (AMNESIA
column2: RETROGRADE) or to form new memories (AMNESIA
column3: ANTEROGRADE). This condition may be of organic or psychologic origin. Organic forms of amnesia are usually associated with dysfunction of the DIENCEPHALON or HIPPOCAMPUS. (From Adams et al.

column2: Anterograde*Loss of the ability to form new memories beyond a certain point in time. This condition may be organic or psychogenic in origin. Organically induced anterograde amnesia may follow CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA; SEIZURES; ANOXIA; and other conditions which adversely affect neural structures associated with memory formation (e.g.
column3: the HIPPOCAMPUS; FORNIX (BRAIN); MAMMILLARY BODIES; and ANTERIOR THALAMIC NUCLEI). (From Memory 1997 Jan-Mar;5(1-2):49-71)

column2: Retrograde*Loss of the ability to recall information that had been previously encoded in memory prior to a specified or approximate point in time. This process may be organic or psychogenic in origin. Organic forms may be associated with CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA; CEREBROVASCULAR ACCIDENTS; SEIZURES; DEMENTIA; and a wide variety of other conditions that impair cerebral function. (From Adams et al.
Transient Global*A syndrome characterized by a transient loss of the ability to form new memories. It primarily occurs in middle aged or elderly individuals
column3: and episodes may last from minutes to hours. During the period of amnesia
column4: immediate and recent memory abilities are impaired
column5: but the level of consciousness and ability to perform other intellectual tasks are preserved. The condition is related to bilateral dysfunction of the medial portions of each TEMPORAL LOBE. Complete recovery normally occurs
column6: and recurrences are unusual. (From Adams et al.

column1: F01.700.625.400*D020915*Korsakoff Syndrome*An acquired cognitive disorder characterized by inattentiveness and the inability to form short term memories. This disorder is frequently associated with chronic ALCOHOLISM; but it may also result from dietary deficiencies; CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA; NEOPLASMS; CEREBROVASCULAR DISORDERS; ENCEPHALITIS; EPILEPSY; and other conditions. (Adams et al.
column2: Principles of Neurology

column1: F01.700.687*D008607*Intellectual Disability*Subnormal intellectual functioning which originates during the developmental period. This has multiple potential etiologies
column2: including genetic defects and perinatal insults. Intelligence quotient (IQ) scores are commonly used to determine whether an individual has an intellectual disability. IQ scores between 70 and 79 are in the borderline range. Scores below 67 are in the disabled range. (from Joynt

column1: F01.700.750*D010468*Perceptual Disorders*Cognitive disorders characterized by an impaired ability to perceive the nature of objects or concepts through use of the sense organs. These include spatial neglect syndromes
column2: where an individual does not attend to visual
column4: or sensory stimuli presented from one side of the body.

column1: F01.700.750.100*D000377*Agnosia*Loss of the ability to comprehend the meaning or recognize the importance of various forms of stimulation that cannot be attributed to impairment of a primary sensory modality. Tactile agnosia is characterized by an inability to perceive the shape and nature of an object by touch alone
column2: despite unimpaired sensation to light touch

column1: F01.700.750.100.300*D005862*Gerstmann Syndrome*A disorder of cognition characterized by the tetrad of finger agnosia
column2: dysgraphia
column4: and right-left disorientation. The syndrome may be developmental or acquired. Acquired Gerstmann syndrome is associated with lesions in the dominant (usually left) PARIETAL LOBE which involve the angular gyrus or subjacent white matter. (From Adams et al.

column1: F01.700.750.100.650*D020238*Prosopagnosia*The inability to recognize a familiar face or to learn to recognize new faces. This visual agnosia is most often associated with lesions involving the junctional regions between the temporal and occipital lobes. The majority of cases are associated with bilateral lesions
column2: however unilateral damage to the right occipito-temporal cortex has also been associated with this condition. (From Cortex 1995 Jun;31(2):317-29)

column1: F01.700.750.150*D062026*Alice in Wonderland Syndrome*Neurological condition characterized by disturbances in VISUAL PERCEPTION
column2: most often of BODY SCHEMA
column3: TIME PERCEPTION and HALLUCINATIONS. It is associated with MIGRAINE
column8: and other neurological and psychiatric disorders.

column1: F01.700.750.175*D066190*Allesthesia*A neurological disorder in which a sensory stimulus

column1: F01.700.750.200*D001308*Auditory Perceptual Disorders*Acquired or developmental cognitive disorders of AUDITORY PERCEPTION characterized by a reduced ability to perceive information contained in auditory stimuli despite intact auditory pathways. column1: F01.700.750.300*D006212*Hallucinations*Subjectively experienced sensations in the absence of an appropriate stimulus

column1: F01.700.750.400*D007088*Illusions*The misinterpretation of a real external
column2: sensory experience.

column1: F01.700.750.700*D010591*Phantom Limb*Perception of painful and nonpainful phantom sensations that occur following the complete or partial loss of a limb. The majority of individuals with an amputated extremity will experience the impression that the limb is still present
column2: and in many cases

column1: F01.700.812*D059607*Polydipsia
column2: Psychogenic*A clinical disorder characterized by excessive fluid intake (polydipsia); HYPONATREMIA; and POLYURIA in SCHIZOPHRENIA and other psychiatric disorders. Impaired water metabolism in psychogenic polydipsia can result in WATER INTOXICATION.

column1: F01.700.875*D011596*Psychomotor Disorders*Abnormalities of motor function that are associated with organic and non-organic cognitive disorders.

F01.700.875.350*D001072*Apraxias*A group of cognitive disorders characterized by the inability to perform previously learned skills that cannot be attributed to deficits of motor or sensory function. The two major subtypes of this condition are ideomotor (see APRAXIA
column2: IDEOMOTOR) and ideational apraxia
column3: which refers to loss of the ability to mentally formulate the processes involved with performing an action. For example
column4: dressing apraxia may result from an inability to mentally formulate the act of placing clothes on the body. Apraxias are generally associated with lesions of the dominant PARIETAL LOBE and supramarginal gyrus. (From Adams et al.

column1: F01.700.875.350.099*D055964*Alien Hand Syndrome*An apraxia characterized by the affected limb having involuntary
column2: autonomous

column2: Ideomotor*A form of apraxia characterized by an acquired inability to carry out a complex motor activity despite the ability to mentally formulate the action. This condition has been attributed to a disruption of connections between the dominant parietal cortex and supplementary and premotor cortical regions in both hemispheres. (From Adams et al.

column1: F01.700.875.350.600*D020235*Gait Apraxia*Impaired ambulation not attributed to sensory impairment or motor weakness. FRONTAL LOBE disorders; BASAL GANGLIA DISEASES (e.g.
column2: PARKINSONIAN DISORDERS); DEMENTIA
column3: MULTI-INFARCT; ALZHEIMER DISEASE; and other conditions may be associated with gait apraxia.

column1: F01.700.875.700*D011595*Psychomotor Agitation*A feeling of restlessness associated with increased motor activity. This may occur as a manifestation of nervous system drug toxicity or other conditions.

F02.463.425.280*D004193*Discrimination Learning*Learning that is manifested in the ability to respond differentially to various stimuli.

column2: Response*The principle that after an organism learns to respond in a particular manner to a stimulus

column2: Stimulus*The tendency to react to stimuli that are different from
column4: the stimulus used as a conditioned stimulus.

column2: Psychophysiologic*The disappearance of responsiveness to a repeated stimulation. It does not include drug habituation.
Learned*Learned expectation that one's responses are independent of reward and
column4: do not predict or control the occurrence of rewards. Learned helplessness derives from a history
column6: of having received punishment/aversive stimulation regardless of responses made. Such circumstances result in an impaired ability to learn. Used for human or animal populations. (APA

column1: F02.463.425.448*D007173*Imprinting (Psychology)*A particular kind of learning characterized by occurrence in very early life

column3: and relative insusceptibility to forgetting or extinction. Imprinted behavior includes most (or all) behavior commonly called instinctive

column1: F02.463.425.475*D007266*Inhibition (Psychology)*The interference with or prevention of a behavioral or verbal response even though the stimulus for that response is present; in psychoanalysis the unconscious restraining of an instinctual process.

F02.463.425.475.538*D011334*Proactive Inhibition*The state or process hypothesized to account for poorer learning rate for elements later in a series as compared to the learning rate for elements coming earlier in a series.

F02.463.425.475.724*D011931*Reactive Inhibition*Tendency toward a lessened strength of response due to practice or activity. It is independent of the effect of reward and is a direct function of time interval since the last response and the number of preceding responses.

F02.463.425.720*D018794*Problem-Based Learning*Instructional use of examples or cases to teach using problem-solving skills and critical thinking.

column3: and discovery that find a solution which is not guaranteed to be optimal

column1: F02.463.425.770*D012054*Reinforcement (Psychology)*The strengthening of a conditioned response.

column1: F02.463.425.770.379*D007721*Knowledge of Results (Psychology)*A principle that learning is facilitated when the learner receives immediate evaluation of learning performance. column2: and

column1: F02.739.527*D005863*Gestalt Theory*A system which emphasizes that experience and behavior contain basic patterns and relationships which cannot be reduced to simpler components; that is

column1: F02.739.660*D018187*Personal Construct Theory*A psychological theory based on dimensions or categories used by a given person in describing or explaining the personality and behavior of others or of himself. The basic idea is that different people will use consistently different categories. The theory was formulated in the fifties by George Kelly. Two tests devised by him are the role construct repertory test and the repertory grid test. (From Stuart Sutherland
column2: The International Dictionary of Psychology

column1: F02.739.794*D011574*Psychoanalytic Theory*Conceptual system developed by Freud and his followers in which unconscious motivations are considered to shape normal and abnormal personality development and behavior.
F02.739.794.206*D004532*Ego*The conscious portion of the personality structure which serves to mediate between the demands of the primitive instinctual drives
column2: (the id)

F02.739.794.253*D005120*Extraversion (Psychology)*A state in which attention is largely directed outward from the self.

F02.739.794.438*D007439*Introversion (Psychology)*A state in which attention is largely directed inward upon one's self.

F02.739.794.471*D007602*Jungian Theory*A theoretical psychoanalytical system centered around symbols of the unconscious with the unconscious material derived from two sources - the personal unconscious (repressed or forgotten experiences
column2: thoughts and feelings) and the collective or objective unconscious (the universal inherited qualities which dispose individuals to behave in ways similar to their ancestors).

column1: F02.739.794.511*D007989*Libido*The psychic drive or energy associated with sexual instinct in the broad sense (pleasure and love-object seeking). It may also connote the psychic energy associated with instincts in general that motivate behavior.

column2: oral

F04.711.513.703*D057190*Stroop Test*Timed test in which the subject must read a list of words or identify colors presented with varying instructions and different degrees of distraction. (Campbell's Psychiatric Dictionary. 8th ed.)

F04.711.513.838*D014145*Trail Making Test*The subject's ability to connect 25 numbered and lettered circles in sequence in a specific length of time. A score of 12 or below is suggestive of organic brain damage.
F04.711.647*D010556*Personality Tests*Standardized objective tests designed to facilitate the evaluation of personality.

F04.711.647.138*D001538*Bender-Gestalt Test*A psychological test consisting of nine geometric designs on cards. The subject is asked to redraw them from memory after each one is presented individually.
F04.711.647.513*D010555*Personality Inventory*Check list
column2: usually to be filled out by a person about himself
column3: consisting of many statements about personal characteristics which the subject checks.

column1: F04.711.647.513.146*D002416*Cattell Personality Factor Questionnaire*Self report questionnaire which yields 16 scores on personality traits
column2: such as reserved vs. outgoing

column1: F04.711.647.513.463*D008347*Manifest Anxiety Scale*True-false questionnaire made up of items believed to indicate anxiety
column2: in which the subject answers verbally the statement that describes him.

column1: F04.711.647.513.535*D058010*Millon Clinical Multiaxial Inventory*A psychological test consisting of true/false items. It is used as a diagnostic screening or clinical assessment of adults who evidence problematic emotional and interpersonal symptoms or who are undergoing PSYCHOTHERAPY or a psychodiagnostic evaluation.

F04.711.647.513.607*D008950*MMPI*A personality inventory consisting of statements to be asserted or denied by the individual. The patterns of response are characteristic of certain personality attributes.
F04.711.647.513.886*D013732*Test Anxiety Scale*A self-reporting test consisting of items concerning fear and worry about taking tests and physiological activity
column2: such as heart rate

column1: F04.711.647.622*D011386*Projective Techniques*Techniques to reveal personality attributes by responses to relatively unstructured or ambiguous stimuli.
F04.711.647.622.341*D007282*Ink Blot Tests*Projective tests utilizing ink blots to which a subject responds. They are used in personality diagnosis.
F04.711.647.622.341.387*D006698*Holtzman Inkblot Test*Personality evaluation based on the scoring of several variables as a result of the subject's responses in perceiving 47 inkblot plates.

F04.711.647.622.341.736*D012392*Rorschach Test*A projective test used to evaluate a broad range of personality variables including pathology of thought and perception. The subject's responses to inkblot prints are scored along with subjective interpretation by the test administrator.

F04.711.647.622.851*D013803*Thematic Apperception Test*A projective technique which focuses primarily on the dynamics of interpersonal relationships. It consists of a series of 31 pictures that depict various social situations and interpersonal relations. A subset is selected by the examiner and presented to the subject who is asked to tell a story about each picture. The stories are interpreted in terms of the subject's relations to authority figures
column2: to contemporaries of both sexes
column3: and in terms of the compromises between external demands and the needs of the id

column1: F04.711.647.745*D012659*Semantic Differential*Analysis of word concepts by the association of polar adjectives
column2: e.g.
column5: father. The adjectives are usually scaled in 7 steps. The subject's placement of the concept on the adjectival scale indicates the connotative meaning of the concept.

column1: F04.711.647.905*D014936*Word Association Tests*Lists of words to which individuals are asked to respond ascertaining the conceptual meaning held by the individual.
F04.711.780*D011594*Psychometrics*Assessment of psychological variables by the application of mathematical procedures.
F04.754*D011613*Psychotherapy*A generic term for the treatment of mental illness or emotional disturbances primarily by verbal or nonverbal communication.
F04.754.017*D056447*Animal Assisted Therapy*The use of live animal as a means of therapy
F04.754.017.500*D056147*Equine-Assisted Therapy*Therapy assisted by the use of a horse and/or its movement
column2: including equine-assisted psychotherapy

column1: F04.754.035*D019341*Aromatherapy*The use of fragrances and essences from plants to affect or alter a person's mood or behavior and to facilitate physical
column2: mental
column3: and emotional well-being. The chemicals comprising essential oils in plants has a host of therapeutic properties and has been used historically in Africa
column5: and India. Its greatest application is in the field of alternative medicine. (From Random House Unabridged Dictionary

column2: techniques can be categorized as comprehensive or focused.

column1: F04.754.137.301.750*D058765*Neurofeedback*A technique to self-regulate brain activities provided as a feedback in order to better control or enhance one's own performance
column2: control or function. This is done by trying to bring brain activities into a range associated with a desired brain function or status.

column1: F04.754.137.365*D000072466*Cognitive Remediation*Behavioral treatment that uses drill and practice
column2: compensatory and adaptive strategies to facilitate improvement in targeted learning areas.

column1: F04.754.137.428*D015928*Cognitive Therapy*A direct form of psychotherapy based on the interpretation of situations (cognitive structure of experiences) that determine how an individual feels and behaves. It is based on the premise that cognition
column2: the process of acquiring knowledge and forming beliefs
column3: is a primary determinant of mood and behavior. The therapy uses behavioral and verbal techniques to identify and correct negative thinking that is at the root of the aberrant behavior.

column1: F04.754.137.428.249*D064869*Acceptance and Commitment Therapy*Contextually focused form of cognitive behavioral psychotherapy that uses MINDFULNESS and behavioral activation to increase patients' psychological flexibility in areas such as ability to engage in values-based
column2: positive behaviors while experiencing difficult thoughts

column1: F04.754.137.428.500*D064866*Mindfulness*A psychological state of awareness
column2: the practices that promote this awareness
column3: a mode of processing information and a character trait. As a therapy mindfulness is defined as a moment-to-moment awareness of one's experience without judgment and as a state and not a trait.

column1: F04.754.137.506*D003887*Desensitization
column2: Psychologic*A behavior therapy technique in which deep muscle relaxation is used to inhibit the effects of graded anxiety-evoking stimuli.

column1: F04.754.137.506.162*D057169*Eye Movement Desensitization Reprocessing*A technique that induces the processing of disturbing memories and experiences
column2: by stimulating neural mechanisms that are similar to those activated during REM sleep. The technique consists of eye movements following side-to-side movements of the index and middle fingers
column3: or the alternate tapping of the hands on the knees. This procedure triggers the processing of information
column4: thus facilitating the connection of neural networks.

column1: F04.754.137.506.325*D007171*Implosive Therapy*A method for extinguishing anxiety by a saturation exposure to the feared stimulus situation or its substitute.
F04.754.137.506.662*D063367*Virtual Reality Exposure Therapy*Treatment technique in a virtual environment which allows the participant to experience a sense of presence in an immersive
column2: computer-generated
column4: interactive environment that minimizes avoidance behavior and facilitates emotional involvement. (from Curr Psychiatry Rep (2010) 12:298)

column1: F04.754.137.750*D012064*Relaxation Therapy*Treatment to improve one's health condition by using techniques that can reduce PHYSIOLOGICAL STRESS; PSYCHOLOGICAL STRESS; or both.
F04.754.137.750.500*D019122*Meditation*A state of consciousness in which the individual eliminates environmental stimuli from awareness so that the mind can focus on a single thing

column1: F04.754.137.875*D055865*Sleep Phase Chronotherapy*A progressive advance or delay of bedtime until the desired bedtime is achieved.
F04.754.168*D001638*Bibliotherapy*A form of supportive psychotherapy in which the patient is given carefully selected material to read.

F04.754.215*D016500*Color Therapy*A form of phototherapy using color to influence health and to treat various physical or mental disorders. The color rays may be in the visible or invisible spectrum and can be administered through colored lights or applied mentally through suggestion.

F04.754.252*D003419*Crisis Intervention*Brief therapeutic approach which is ameliorative rather than curative of acute psychiatric emergencies. Used in contexts such as emergency rooms of psychiatric or general hospitals
column2: or in the home or place of crisis occurrence
column3: this treatment approach focuses on interpersonal and intrapsychic factors and environmental modification. (APA Thesaurus of Psychological Index Terms

column1: F04.754.278*D003614*Dance Therapy*The use of dancing for therapeutic purposes.
F04.754.293*D000071441*Emotion-Focused Therapy*Intervention that relies on free expression of emotions with coaching to enhance awareness of emotional experiences.

column2: as well as self-confidence.

column1: F04.754.424*D006990*Hypnosis*A state of increased receptivity to suggestion and direction
column2: initially induced by the influence of another person.

column1: F04.754.424.386*D001326*Autogenic Training*Technique based on muscle relaxation during self-hypnotic exercises. It is used in conjunction with psychotherapy.
F04.754.424.771*D013404*Suggestion*The uncritical acceptance of an idea or plan of action.
F04.754.424.771.299*D001346*Autosuggestion*Suggestion coming from the subject himself.
F04.754.462*D019018*Imagery (Psychotherapy)*The use of mental images produced by the imagination as a form of psychotherapy. It can be classified by the modality of its content: visual
column2: verbal
column7: or kinesthetic. Common themes derive from nature imagery (e.g.
column12: etc. Imagery is used in the treatment of mental disorders and in helping patients cope with other diseases. Imagery often forms a part of HYPNOSIS
column15: and of BEHAVIOR THERAPY. (From Encyclopedia of Human Behavior

column1: F04.754.570*D062525*Narrative Therapy*A form of PSYCHOTHERAPY that centers on the individuals as the experts in their own lives and views problems as separate from people. It is assumed that people have many skills
column2: competencies
column6: and abilities that will assist them to reduce the influence of problems in their lives.

column1: F04.754.592*D009629*Person-Centered Therapy*A nondirective psychotherapy approach originated by Carl Rogers. The goals of therapy are to promote the client’s congruence
column2: self awareness
column3: and self acceptance. This approach views the client as naturally directed toward self actualization
column4: and only needing facilitative conditions in order to promote this tendency.

column1: F04.754.664*D010989*Play Therapy*A treatment technique utilizing play as a medium for expression and communication between patient and therapist.
F04.754.709*D011575*Psychoanalytic Therapy*A form of psychiatric treatment
column2: based on Freudian principles
column3: which seeks to eliminate or diminish the undesirable effects of unconscious conflicts by making the patient aware of their existence
column5: and inappropriate expression in current emotions and behavior.

column1: F04.754.709.437*D005608*Free Association*Spontaneous verbalization of whatever comes to mind.
F04.754.709.838*D014152*Transactional Analysis*A psychoanalytic therapy wherein each social transaction is analyzed to determine the involved ego state (whether parent-like

column1: F04.754.720.107*D000035*Abreaction*A process in psychotherapy in which the patient is desensitized to emotionally painful

column1: F04.754.720.107.333*D002399*Catharsis*The release of ideas

column3: and repressed material from the unconscious
column4: accompanied by an emotional response and relief. (From Dorland

column2: Brief*Any form of psychotherapy designed to produce therapeutic change within a minimal amount of time

column1: F04.754.785*D011617*Psychotherapy
column2: Rational-Emotive*The replacement of illogical and unrealistic ideas with more realistic and adaptive ones through direct intervention and confrontation by the therapist.

column1: F04.754.804*D011937*Reality Therapy*Method of psychotherapeutic treatment based on assumption of patients' personal responsibility for their own behavior. The therapist actively guides patients to accurate self-perception for fulfillment of needs of self-worth and respect for others. (From APA
column2: Thesaurus of Psychological Index Terms

column1: F04.754.864*D012960*Socioenvironmental Therapy*Therapy whose primary emphasis is on the physical and social structuring of the environment to promote interpersonal relationships which will be influential in reducing behavioral disturbances of patients.
F04.754.864.392*D008884*Milieu Therapy*A treatment program based on manipulation of the patient's environment by the medical staff. The patient does not participate in planning the treatment regimen.

F04.754.864.392.701*D013808*Therapeutic Community*Psychotherapeutic technique which emphasizes socioenvironmental and interpersonal influences in the resocialization and rehabilitation of the patient. The setting is usually a hospital unit or ward in which professional and nonprofessional staff interact with the patients.
F04.754.864.581*D011615*Psychotherapy
column2: Group*A form of therapy in which two or more patients participate under the guidance of one or more psychotherapists for the purpose of treating emotional disturbances

column1: F04.754.864.581.136*D019546*Couples Therapy*Psychotherapy used specifically for unmarried couples
column2: of mixed or same sex. (From APA

column1: F04.754.864.581.273*D005196*Family Therapy*A form of group psychotherapy. It involves treatment of more than one member of the family simultaneously in the same session.
F04.754.864.581.550*D008388*Marital Therapy*A form of psychotherapy involving the husband and wife and directed to improving the marital relationship.
F04.754.864.581.679*D011577*Psychodrama*Primarily a technique of group psychotherapy which involves a structured
column2: directed
column3: and dramatized acting out of the patient's personal and emotional problems.

column1: F04.754.864.581.679.653*D012381*Role Playing*The adopting or performing the role of another significant individual in order to gain insight into the behavior of that person.
F04.754.864.581.813*D012681*Sensitivity Training Groups*A group of people who meet in an unstructured setting to learn about themselves
column2: interpersonal relationships
column3: and group processes and about larger social systems.

column1: F04.754.864.696*D012114*Residential Treatment*A specialized residential treatment program for behavior disorders including substance abuse. column2: A. P. and Fawcett
